title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT JUMPS 28%
description: The United States foreign merchandise trade deficit hit $10.3 billion in January, a 28 percent jump from the previous month, as a flood of imports swamped the country's best export performance in more than three years, the Government said today.

title: CAPITALS BEAT RANGERS FOR 5TH STRAIGHT TIME
description: Recognizing the omen, Craig Patrick said: ''We've been warned. We'll be more prepared the next time or that'll be it.''

title: MISSOURI COUPLE IS ACCUSED OF ILLEGALLY EXPORTING ARMS
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted a Missouri couple for illegally exporting an antitank- missile-guidance system and other advanced military equipment to South Africa and other foreign countries, the United States Customs Service announced here today.

title: NO NEED FOR THE MX
description: On what line of reasoning, if any, should Congress now vote $1.4 billion to provide President Reagan with 21 additional MX missiles, each bearing 10 independently targetable nuclear warheads, in addition to the 21 missiles already approved?

title: SCREEN: WOODY ALLEN'S NEW COMEDY, 'PURPLE ROSE OF CAIRO'
description: EVERYTHING about Cecilia (Mia Farrow) is tinged with melancholy, including the time - the depressed 1930's - and the place, a drab little New Jersey town where even the sunlight looks gray. Her husband, Monk (Danny Aiello), a big, short-tempered lug, isn't a bad sort, really, and, like almost every other man in town, he's out of a job and not looking for work. However, when he's had a few beers, he's inclined to push her around a bit.

title: Edelman Would Sell Datapoint
description: Asher Edelman, a New York investor, disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that if he gains control of the Datapoint Corporation, he intends to sell the company. Mr. Edelman holds 2,185,000 Datapoint common shares, or 11 percent of the shares outstanding of the San Antonio-based business computer company. He has begun to solicit consents from shareholders to replace the board of directors.

title: THE MATISSE WE RARELY SEE
description: THAT Henri Matisse was one of the most seductive draftsmen who ever lived is well known to anyone who patrols the auction houses and the dealers' galleries. Rarely have drawings been more instantly approachable than the kind of Matisse that turns up for sale here, there and everywhere.

title: Penney Net Falls 16.9%
description: The J.C. Penney Company reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income fell 16.9 percent, reflecting the heavy markdowns and higher inventories that plagued retailers throughout the period. The company's earnings dropped to $216 million, or $2.89 a share, from $260 million, or $3.47 a share, a year earlier.

title: BROADWAY
description: EUGENE O'NEILL'S ''Long Day's Journey Into Night'' may be headed for a Broadway run after an absence of almost 30 years. Jonathan Miller, the British director of stage, opera and television, author and lecturer, has indicated interest in directing it. Jack Lemmon is the name most discussed for the role played by Fredric March in 1956 and Julie Harris is being talked about for the female lead.

title: THE ANTI-NICARAGUA DRIVE
description: The Reagan Administration is waging an increasingly violent war of words over Nicaragua, using Secretary of State George P. Shultz, retiring Central American military commander Gen. Paul F. Gorman and the President himself to conduct what White House officials call an ''educational campaign'' to pressure Congress to vote more funds for operations in Nicaragua. In fact, the campaign is little more than a propaganda offensive - and fortunately most Americans seem to know better than to take it at face value.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Bulls, at Chicago. With a 4-24 record away from home, the Knicks find any road game unappealing, and tonight they must also try to handle Michael Jordan, the Bulls' spectacular rookie. The Knicks did win their last meeting against Chicago, on Jan. 5 in Madison Square Garden, although Jordan outscored Bernard King, 42-34. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M.)

title: AN IMPORT TAX ISN'T THE ANSWER
description: Like Archimedes in the bath, most of us have experienced a brilliant idea suddenly surfacing, an idea that would instantly solve our problems. Unlike Archimedes's inspiration (involving the measurement of volume), ours often turn out not to be so brilliant after all. I suspect this might be true of the latest magic cure for the nation's ills now being hawked around - an import surcharge.

title: Lawmaker Says U.S. to Close Some Social Security Offices
description: The Department of Health and Human Services is quietly circulating a proposal that could result in the closing of more than half the nation's 1,340 Social Security field offices, Representative Edward R. Roybal, Democrat of California, said today.

title: ART: AT LEVOR HOUSE, ENVIRONMENTAL WORKS
description: ''ART AND THE ENVIRONMENT'' is a somewhat arbitrary sampling of environmental art that is nevertheless a useful and timely guide to an art form that is now almost a quarter of a century old. The exhibition was organized by Artists Representing Environmental Art, which invited 33 artists, most of whom are represented by drawings, photographs or maquettes. What is exciting about the show is not only being able to explore an artistic direction still alive with possibility, but also being able to consider projects that are still in the proposal stage.

title: MORGENTHAU SAYS GOETZ CASE MAY GO TO 2D GRAND JURY
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said yesterday that he was considering asking a new grand jury to decide whether to indict Bernhard H. Goetz on charges of attempted murder in the shooting of four young men on a subway train.

title: BOOTHE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

It also said results for the latest quarter and year include net income of $1,209,000, or 25 cents a share and $2,991,000, or 62 cents a share, respectively, attributable to gains from the sale of securities. The gains in the latest periods compare with gains of $57,000, or 1 cent a share, in the year-ago quarter and $4,026,000, or 79 cents a share, in the previous year from the sale of securities. The latest quarter and year also include gains from the sale of real estate and mortgages of $100,000, or 2 cents a share, and $4,258,000, or 88 cents a share, respectively, as well as gains of $1,614,000, or 33 cents a share, for the year-ago quarter and $4,786,000, or 94 cents a share, in the previous year.

title: Throwing Money at Farmers By passing its emergency farm aid bills this week, Congress has pushed the general budget debate a big step backward. It would have been unrealistic to expect Congressmen to turn their backs on the invading army of farmers demanding emergency credit. But they could have won something for their votes in the way of reductions and reforms in other, less urgent subsidy programs. If Congress couldn't check the impulse to throw money at
description: this problem, think what's in store when harder cuts come up. The outlook for cutting the budget deficit has turned from dim to grim.

The Investment Company Institute is a public spokesman for the mutual fund industry.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 1, 1985

title: 'You Don't Look So Bad . . .' If the criminal justice system can't protect New Yorkers, why shouldn't they try to defend themselves? That was the question first raised by the tormenting case of Bernhard Goetz. Mr. Goetz's own account of the incident, just released, changes the question: When does defending yourself turn into appointing yourself judge, jury and executioner? It is a question that demands a prompt answer - in a trial.
description: The bare outline of the story quickly elevated Mr. Goetz to national celebrity. Minding his own business on a December day, he entered a subway car, there to be menaced by four teen-agers supposedly armed with sharpened screwdrivers. Fearing a mugging, he pulled a gun and fired. The four fell wounded. A grand jury, turning aside charges of assault and attempted murder, indicted him only for gun possession, and many people cheered.

title: GREENPOINT, STILL AN URBAN, ETHNIC VILLAGE
description: GREENPOINT is closer to Manhattan, at least as the crow flies, than almost any other neighborhood in Brooklyn. But it is also a world away, a neighborhood altogether different from, say, the elegant promenade blocks of Brooklyn Heights, where splendid views keep attention firmly focused on Manhattan, or the rich brownstone blocks of Park Slope, lined with lush trees. Greenpoint is not so refined, not so set in middle-class ways. And it seems as if it could not care less that its waterfront looks right across the East River to a broad swath of the midtown Manhattan skyline.

title: O'Neill Looks Ahead To 1987 Retirement
description: Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said today that he plans to write a book and teach a college course when he retires from Congress in two years and that he would consider doing television commercials.

description: The United States said today that it was ready ''to re-engage in the peace process'' in the Middle East in any way the Arabs and Israelis thought appropriate.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Air Wisconsin Inc., Appleton, Wis., said it had signed a commitment to buy 12 Fokker F-27 MK500 Project aircraft for more than $72 million.

title: MCCORMICK OIL & GAS PARTERSHIP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results as the company became a limited partnership on Jan. 31, 1984. Results for the full year period represent 11 months of operations.

title: LEADERS OF ANTI-SANDINISTAS FORM ALLIANCE URGED BY U.S.
description: A coalition of Nicaraguan opposition leaders intends to hold a news conference in Costa Rica this weekend to announce a unified plan of political action against the Sandinista Government, an action the Reagan Administration has been urging.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''I WONDER,'' said Inger Elliott with a wide grin, ''what Goldberg really wrote? All we're going to hear tonight are his variations.''

description: b-Net loss.

title: VIETNAM WAR VETERANS AT YET ANOTHER BIVOUAC
description: One rainy night this winter, a woman in a long evening gown approached a weathered green tent near the Vietnam Memorial here. She was crying. ''I've tried for two years to be able to walk by that wall,'' she told Frank Vanover, who was on nightshift at the Veterans Vigil of Honor.

title: Mother Is Sentenced For Defying Probation
description: Jackie M. Fourthman, who had been ordered by a judge not to have children for 15 years after her son died of abuse, has been sentenced to three years in prison for giving birth to a child outside the state.

title: HOUSE PANEL URGES APPROVAL OF SENATE FARM BILL TO SAVE 2 MEASURES
description: The House Rules Committee recommended today that the House accept the Senate's emergency farm credit legislation in full.

title: HEIR APPARENT TO DR. SPOCK
description: He makes it clear right away that he hates being called ''the new Dr. Spock.'' Of course, Dr. Michael B. Rothenberg understands why some people might want to call him that. After all, he trained as a pediatrician and a psychiatrist, just as Dr. Benjamin Spock did. Dr. Rothenberg is also an outspoken children's advocate and an indefatigable peace activist. And ultimately, he will become the sole author of Dr. Spock's classic book, ''Baby and Child Care.''

title: COLONIAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Prenatal X-Ray Linked To Infant Cancer Risk
description: Children who were exposed to medical X-rays while still in the wombs face about two and a half times the usual risk of cancer, and even low doses of radiation may be harmful to the unborn, a study has concluded.

title: 4 REGISTER STATIONS SOLD
description: In another step toward liquidation, the board of the Des Moines Register and Tribune Company today approved the sale of four radio stations for $11.6 million.

title: HEALTHCARE SERVICES GROUP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SLAN OFFICER IS BURIED IN WESTCHESTER
description: -ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 28 - Officer Gary Stymiloski, who was shot to death Sunday night after he stopped a car on the Saw Mill River Parkway in Yonkers, was buried today in the presence of a grieving family and an estimated 5,000 police officers from around the country.

title: The Sweater Is Warned Although St. John's was
description: beaten Wednesday night by Georgetown, ending a 19-game winning streak, Lou Carnesecca

title: SCREEN: EARLY TAVIANI
description: PAOLO and Vittorio Taviani's ''Allonsanfan'' was made in 1974, when the brothers' film making style was a good deal more quixotic than it is today. Fevered and fanciful, it follows an aristocrat named Fulvio (Marcello Mastroianni), a onetime revolutionary now living in post-Napoleonic Italy, through a series of adventures and hallucinations. These often seem interchangeable, which is one of the film's eccentricities. They are frequently accompanied by odd bursts of song, which is another.

title: THE SURGE IN SUPERCOMPUTERS
description: In just the last 18 months, all three of the nation's largest auto makers have installed supercomputers in their design centers, seeking to test-drive their prototypes without ever building them.

title: KETCHUM & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After tax credits of $180,000 for the quarter and $359,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $154,000 for the quarter and $637,000 for the 9 months.

title: Asarco, Weeks
description: Weeks Petroleum Ltd. has told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it holds 2,834,500 common shares of the New York-based Asarco Inc., or 10 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: NATIONAL HMO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Year-ago results are not available since the company went public in December 1983.

title: Argentine Devaluation
description: The Argentine central bank reduced the value of the peso by 4 percent today, putting it at 268.15 pesos to the dollar. It was the latest in a long series of small, periodic devaluations and the fourth this year to exceed the average daily decline of 0.76 percent.

title: U.S. Tactics Remind Lange of Totalitarianism
description: New Zealand's Prime Minister said today that the United States wants to drive him from office because of his antinuclear policy and is using tactics ''akin to the very totalitarianism we're supposed to be fighting against.''

title: TORONTO DOMINION BANK (CANADA) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: U.M.W. Selling Stock in Bank
description: The United Mine Workers of America has agreed to sell its controlling interest in the National Bank of Washington for about $70 million, the bank announced. The buyers are three New York investors and a number of senior officers of the bank, including Luther H. Hodges Jr., the chairman of the Washington Bancorporation, the bank's holding company.

title: THE FIRST AGREEMENT IN THIS YEAR'S STATE LABOR TALKS IS ANNOUNCED
description: State officials today announced an agreement on the first new contract of this year's labor negotiations.

title: 4 DERBY FAVORITES IN FLORIDA
description: The four early favorites for the May 4 Kentucky Derby are all running here Saturday at Gulfstream Park, and it is difficult to see how the races will do more than rearrange the order in which they dominate the division. Chief's Crown should have a cakewalk in the $50,000 Swale Stakes at seven furlongs, and Proud Truth, Stephan's Odyssey and Banner Bob tower over their eight rivals going nine furlongs in the $300,000 Florida Derby.

title: WHITE HOUSE SCORNS PEACE OFFER FROM NICARAGUA
description: The White House today called the latest peace overtures from President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua a ''change without substance'' aimed primarily at influencing votes in the United States Congress.

title: 4 P.M., Scream
description: Capitol Hill offices and corridors are swarming with constituents who have come from afar to protest President Reagan's proposed budget cuts.

title: Democratic Uruguay, and Counting Secretary Shultz is in Montevideo today for the inauguration of Julio Maria Sanguinetti and the restoration of democracy to Uruguay after nearly 13 years. Uruguay thus becomes the sixth South American country in less than six years to shed military rule.
description: Further progress is on the way. In just two weeks another inauguration, in Brasilia, will end 21 years of military rule in Latin America's biggest nation.

title: MONEY TRADERS' SLEEPLESS NIGHTS
description: On Wednesday night, Rony Schlapfer slept. And that was unusual for the chairman and co-founder of Capital Management International Inc., a small company that specializes in foreign currency trading and whose owners have been making money but losing sleep this week.

title: DISTRIBUTED LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
RKO GENERAL PLANS TO SELL A RADIO UNIT
description: RKO General Inc., a subsidiary of Gencorp Inc., said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its six-year-old RKO Radio Networks to United Stations Radio Networks 1 and 2 Inc. for an undisclosed sum.

title: GOTAAS-LARSEN SHIPPING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NATIONAL GAS & OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect a 7 percent stock dividend paid in December 1984.

title: Back on Track Sometime Soon
description: Angel Cordero Jr., the all-everything jockey who broke his right hand in a spill at Aqueduct on Jan. 24, has an appointment with his doctor in New York this afternoon, and if everything goes as he hopes, it will mark his first step on the road back to the turf. ''If he takes the cast off,'' Cordero said at the track yesterday, ''I'll probably fly to Miami on Saturday morning to start working horses.''

title: REAGAN ORDERS MEESE TO EXAMINE WAYS TO CURB VIOLENCE IN SCHOOLS
description: President Reagan today ordered Attorney General Edwin L. Meese 3d to examine ''possible modifications in Federal law'' that would expand the rights of teachers and administrators to fight violence in schools.

title: P.L.O., CRITICIZING EGYPT'S PLAN, CALLS FOR A U.N.-SPONSERED PARLEY
description: A spokesman for the Palestine Liberation Organization in Tunis today criticized Egypt's call for direct peace talks between Israel and a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation. He said an international peace conference with P.L.O. participation was the ''proper framework'' for making peace.

title: SLOPES NOW BETTER GROOMED
description: For decades the shapes of ski

title: MEMPHIS STATE TOPPLED BY DETROIT
description: Greg Wendt scored 23 points and Keith Gray added 21 as Detroit upset Memphis State, 71-66, tonight.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a production error, an article about air pollution in homes in some copies of the Home section yesterday was incomplete. The complete article will appear in the Home section next Thursday.

title: LAMSON & SESSIONS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,312,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $13,133,000 for the quarter and $20,971,000 for the year.

title: Quartet at Vanguard
description: The alto saxophonist Arthur Blythe will lead his quartet tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard (255- 4037), 178 Seventh Avenue South below 11th Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. There is an $8.50 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: REALIST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Debt Issues
description: Aeroflex Laboratories Inc., a manufacturer of military and industrial products, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $25 million of convertible subordinated debentures due 2005, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: South Africa Frees A White Dissenter
description: A leader of the banned African National Congress, Dennis Goldberg, who has spent more than 20 years in jail, was released today and allowed to fly to Israel, the South African state radio reported.

title: GOVERNOR OF LOUISIANA IS INDICTED BY JURY INVESTIGATING STATE GRAFT
description: Gov. Edwin W. Edwards of Louisiana was indicted on conspiracy charges today by a Federal grand jury investigating allegations of corruption in state government.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HILTON REJECTED FOR LICENSE TO OPERATE A JERSEY CASINO
description: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission today rejected the Hilton Hotels Corporation's application for a casino license. The dissenters cited what they said were Hilton's past associations with organized crime.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in some copies yesterday about the St. John's- Georgetown basketball game incorrectly identified a Georgetown player taking a shot. He was Ralph Dalton.

title: FARM FRESH INC reports earnings for 16wks to Dec 31
UNITRODE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,350,000 from the deferral of DISC income taxes.

title: JAZZ AT COOPER UNION
description: The guitarist James Emery will lead his chamber-jazz ensemble in a free concert tonight at 8 at Cooper Union's Great Hall, Seventh Street between Third and Fourth Avenues.

title: Anti-Semite Convicted In Toronto Case
description: Ernst Zundel, a German-born commercial artist and anti-Semitic pamphleteer, was convicted today of ''publishing false news'' in a tract declaring that accounts of the Nazi crimes against Jews are a fabrication.

title: DOW MOVES UP 2.98 AS VOLUME EASES
description: Stock prices moved only slightly ahead yesterday despite a modestly stronger bond market and a somewhat rejuvenated United States dollar.

title: Genentech Stake
description: Genentech Inc. said Boehringer Ingelheim International G.m.b.H. had purchased 750,000 Genentech shares, or just under 5 percent of the total outstanding, at $53.41 a share, for a total of $40 million. Genentech also said it was in the process of completing an agreement with Boehringer, a privately owned West German concern, for the commercial development of tumor necrosis factors as anti-cancer agents in Europe and other, unspecified markets. Genentech, a company involved in genetic engineering, closed today at $51.50 in over-the-counter trading, off $1.25.

title: AM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-After tax credits of $2.4 million for the quarter and $4.2 million for the 6 months. c-After credits of $51 million, or $1.29 a share, for the quarter and $52.3 million for the 6 months. The year-ago figures were restated for an accounting change. In the year-ago net the credit consisted of tax credits, termination of a pension plan and charges for estimated bankruptcy settlements.

title: Farm Prices Are Steady
description: The prices that farmers receive for raw products held steady in February but still averaged 6.2 percent below the levels of a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: SCREEN: ROB REINER'S 'SURE THING'
description: ROB REINER'S new film, ''The Sure Thing,'' is glowing proof of two things: Traditional romantic comedy can be adapted to suit the teen-age trade, and Mr. Reiner's contribution to ''This Is Spinal Tap'' was more than a matter of humor. That film had its laughs, of course, but it also had enough sweetness and cohesiveness to make an audience somehow care about its characters, even at their most idiotic. ''The Sure Thing,'' which opens today at Loew's State and other theaters, brings the same affectionate style to bear on a charmingly mismatched collegiate couple. They spar their way through a cross-country journey to California to see their respective mates, falling in love with each other along the way.

title: BLAIR, JOHN & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1984 figures reflect operations since March 15 of Advo-System Inc., when it became a wholly owned subsidiary of John Blair.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Note and Bond Prices Gain
description: The credit markets recovered yesterday from Wednesday's debacle, but securities dealers said that investor demand remains very weak amid fears that interest rates will rise in the future.

title: CLERICS DENOUNCE CURBS ON AIDING LATIN ALIENS
description: Bitterly denouncing what they called ''scandalous policies'' of the Reagan Administration, more than 200 religious leaders today pleaded for a stop to the deportation of Salvadoran and Guatemalan aliens and the jailing of American church workers who try to shelter them.

title: PRAIRIE OIL ROYALTIES COMPANY LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 4-for-1 stock split on Jan. 8. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Financial Corp.
description: The Financial Corporation of America said its evaluation of its loan portfolio had not been completed in the time previously anticipated and it now expects 1984 results to be released by the end of March. The company had earlier said it expected to release the figures by the second half of February. As a result of the evaluation completed so far, ''we have instituted more stringent procedures in the areas of loan documentation, appraisal techniques and underwriting standards,'' William J. Popejoy, chairman, said.

title: QED EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Transfers to Continue For Gifted Youngsters
description: After a long dispute, Community School Board 2 in Manhattan has voted to continue for at least a year to let parents send gifted children and their siblings to special programs at schools outside their neighborhood, particularly to Public School 6.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Making it official,

title: MOBILE COMMUNICATIONS OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Pentagon Plans New Inquiry On Admiral's Grenada Arms
description: The Pentagon's Inspector General will open a second investigation into the actions of Vice Adm. Joseph Metcalf, who received a letter of caution after trying to bring captured weapons back from Grenada, a Defense Department spokesman said today.

title: FILM: 'PRIVATE FUNCTION'
description: NOT since the end of the collaboration between Roy and John Boulting (''The Man in the Cocked Hat,'' ''I'm Alright, Jack'') and the golden age of the Ealing Studios has there been a stylish English comedy of such high-hearted, self-interested knavery as ''A Private Function,'' reuniting those two love-crossed stars of ''The Missionary,'' Michael Palin and Maggie Smith.

title: MAIN STREETS GIRDING TO DO BATTLE WITH THE SUBURBAN SHOPPING MALL
description: Tell Rosa Maria Castillo-Kesper that Main Street is dying, that the suburban shopping mall has taken over, and she stands up, shouting and shaking her head.

title: Market Place ;   Bell Regionals: Analysts Split
description: What Frank E. Plumley, a telecommunications analyst for the Standard & Poor's Corporation, calls the ''Bell babies'' have given outstanding performances in the stock market so far, but opinion is divided about their future growth. These seven Bell regional holding companies were created at the start of 1984 by the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're ready to get more actively engaged if the parties that have to be engaged are ready to do so.'' - Richard W. Murphy, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, on Middle East peace proposals. (A1:6.)

title: ANALYSTS BELIEVE PAN AM CAN SURVIVE A STRIKE, IF IT'S SHORT
description: Cushioned by $400 million in cash reserves, Pan American World Airways can withstand a long strike, according to several airline industry analysts.

title: GUESS WHO'S GOING ABROAD WITH BUSH
description: Somewhere in the Sudan next week, amid talks with President Gaafar al-Nimeiry and a visit to the Wad Sherifie refugee camp, Vice President Bush is expecting another encounter.

title: Couples Leads at 63
description: Fred Couples holed out of a bunker for one of six consecutive birdies today as he shot a course-record nine- under-par 63 in the first round of the $500,000 Honda Classic at the Eagle Trace Tournament Players Club course.

title: UPDATING THE PARENTS' BIBLE
description: The first section of the book is still titled ''Trust Yourself'' and the first words of the text still say ''You know more than you think you do.''

title: GOLDSMITH IN TALKS WITH ICAHN
description: Sir James Goldsmith, the multimillionaire British businessman, is considering whether to join Carl C. Icahn in trying to take over the Phillips Petroleum Company, a source close to Sir James said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   An Open and Shut Case
description: A West Side couple emerged from

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday about the New Jersey race for governor incorrectly identified Joe Petrillo. He is the Democratic chairman of East Hanover.

title: SCITEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
YES, FORCE WAS USED WHEN KIM WENT HOME
description: To the Editor:

title: UNIVERSAL COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Commodore Selects Bates/New York
description: After going through an agency competition that involved six shops, Commodore International in West Chester, Pa., the leading marketer of home computers, has decided on Ted Bates Advertising/New York. The billings could be in excess of $50 million and the Bates assignment will be to create all of the advertising but place only the print advertising.

title: Mexico Signs Steel Curb Pact
description: The United States trade representative, Bill Brock, said today that Mexico has signed an agreement voluntarily restricting its steel exports to the United States for five years.

title: DISPUTE OVER BARNEYS PLAN RESOLVED
description: What's in a wall?

title: FORDHAM AND IONA ADVNCE IN PLAYOFFS
description: Tony McIntosh sank an 18-foot jumper from the top of the key with four seconds remaining in overtime tonight, providing Fordham with a 44-42 victory and a berth in the semifinal round of the Metro Athletic Athletic Conference tournament at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: FOLGER THEATER TO STAY OPEN
description: An agreement has been reached to keep open the Folger Shakespeare Theater for at least the next two years, according to the director of the parent Folger Shakespeare Library.

title: FOR A SHINING FUTURE, NAPLES WILL BURNISH ITS PAST
description: This city has a reputation for crime, violence, gangs, traffic, pollution, smuggling and disorganization raised to the level of principle. City governments seem to collapse every few months, and art works are allowed to decay in crumbling churches and palaces.

title: Picking Top Dog
description: O.K., canine fans, the 1984 list of American Kennel Club registrations is finally in, and what they show - a blare of trumpets, please - is that for the second straight year the most popular pooch in this vast land was none other than the cocker spaniel.

title: FIBRONICS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REPUBLIC HEALTH CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $170,000 for the quarter and $2,645,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $582,000 for the quarter and $1,888,000 for the year. Results reflect the acquisition of Horizon Health Corp. and Health Resource Corp. of America on a pooling- of-interests basis.

title: The Mule Will Not Be Forgotten Oct. 26
description: To the Editor:

description: b-After a gain of $564,000 on the disposal of marine construction equipment and a loss of $2 million on a timber contract cancellation charge. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $183,000 for the quarter and $524,000 for the 9 months. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,715,000, a gain of $3,657,000 from the disposal of marine construction equipment and a timber contract cancellation charge of $2 million.

title: MEXICO CHARGES TWO IN AN ESCAPE LINKED TO DRUG ABDUCTION
description: Two people were charged today in connection with the escape of a reputed drug trafficker who is wanted in the kidnapping of a United States narcotics agent, the Mexican Attorney General's office said.

title: LOUISIANA HAS A LONG LINE OF JAILED OFFICIALS
description: It was called the Louisiana Hayride, a Robin Hood approach to government that was fueled by the immense oil wealth of the state and set in motion by the Kingfish himself, Huey P. Long.

title: INVENTION DESIGN ENGINEERNG ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid in September 1984.

title: FORMER MILITARY AIDES QUESTION SPACE-BASED DEFENSE PLANS
description: Three former makers of military policy told Congress today that the Soviet Union would probably increase its arsenal of offensive nuclear weapons if the United States attempted to build a huge space-based defense against nuclear attack.

title: Farewell, Teeley
description: The boss was away, making

title: Magic Chef Sues To Block Merger
description: Magic Chef Inc., which has interests in appliance manufacturing, has asked a Federal court to block a sale involving rival appliance companies on antitrust grounds.

title: SMALL-BUISNESS AGENCY ASSAILED BY STOCKMAN
description: David A. Stockman, the budget director, today defended President Reagan's proposal to abolish the Small Business Administration before a hostile Senate committee.

title: SCREEN: BARREL'S 'LUST IN THE DUST'
description: PAUL BARTEL'S ''Lust in the Dust'' gets off to a promising start, with lurid letters announcing the movie's title, set against a bleak, sun-baked desert landscape and a soundtrack song about a ''tarnished man,'' his ''tarnished hand'' and a ''tarnished tumbleweed.'' The film, a narrator intones with proper solemnity, is ''a tale about men and women who become slaves to their passions.''

title: E & B MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Leaders Announced at New Global Unit
description: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that it had created a subsidiary to coordinate its global business growth.

title: Governor Alters Plans On Banking Nominee
description: Heather Low Ruth's planned nomination as New York State banking superintendent has been canceled because her husband has a job dealing with banks.

title: A New Type Of Tax-Exempt
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company this week introduced a new kind of tax-exempt bond combining the features of non-interest-paying zero coupon bonds and regular, interest-bearing bonds.

title: Gas Pipeline Refund
description: The Midcon Corporation said today that a unit, the Natural Gas Pipeline Company, would refund $113 million to its utility and municipal customers in a settlement of a 1983 rate filing with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.

title: WASHINGTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $41,049 for the quarter and $858,898 for the year. c-Operating earnings. d-Includes extraordinary gains of $126,759 for the quarter and $249,259 for the year.

title: VLI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HUNTS AGAIN CHARGED IN 1979-80 SILVER DEALS
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today charged the Hunt brothers, Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt, and several of their associates with manipulating the silver market in 1979 and 1980.

title: SELMA, 20 YEARS AFTER THE RIGHTS MARCH
description: Karyn Reddick knows the stories of that bloody Sunday, 20 years ago, when 600 civil rights marchers were turned back from the Edmund Pettus Bridge by tear gas and bullwhips and mounted sheriff's deputies wielding clubs. One cannot grow up in Selma and not know.

title: City Trash Reported Dumped In Nassau by Private Haulers
description: A six-week investigation indicates that private carting companies are trucking garbage from New York City and illegally dumping it in Nassau County, District Attorney Denis Dillon said today.

title: OPERA: VERDI'S 'ERNANI' IS REVIVED AT THE MET
description: THE Metropolitan Opera, like other major companies, can round up a strong cast for almost any new production. What happens in later seasons, however, often does not bear dwelling on. As in last evening's ''Ernani,'' the first appearance this season for a production that was new in 1983, revivals often can offer only one or two internationally recognized stars. A certain amount of slippage in vocal quality comes to be taken for granted, shrugged off even by audiences that should know better.

title: Griffey Surgery Disclosed
description: The Yankees never announced it, but Ken Griffey had a piece of cartilage removed from his right knee with arthroscopic surgery Dec. 12 in New York. Asked about the knee, Gene Monahan, the trainer, said Griffey was on a program and ''looks pretty darn good to me.'' It was the same kind of surgery Don Mattingly had last Friday. . . . The Yankees announced the signings of Rich Bordi and Bobby Meacham to major league contracts and Dan Briggs and Henry Cotto to minor league contracts.

title: New York Telephone Details Rate Plan
description: The New York Telephone Company yesterday proposed an expected revamping of its rates. Rates for toll calls would largely fall, local rates would rise in some cases and fall in others to get closer in line with costs, and residences would pay more for ''supplemental'' services - Touch- Tone and a second phone line in the home.

title: THEATER: 'HITCH-HIKERS,' A WELTY DRAMATIZATION
description: FOR all the eloquence of Eudora Welty's essays about her fiction, there is still no substitute for plunging into the work itself. As the author has said (in ''How I Write''), no predictable schemes govern her stories; we must abandon ourselves to ''the mysteries rushing unsubmissively through them by the minute.'' In ''The Hitch- Hikers'' - the story now adapted to the stage by Larry Ketron at the WPA - the mysteries bubble up in every sentence. The tale's events are casual and often oblique - but, like a welter of tiny roots digging into the soil, they connect below the surface to form a dense and violently twisted pattern of life.

title: GROMYKO MEETS WITH THE SPANISH PRIME MINISTER AMID MADRID-WASHINGTON STRAINS
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union arrived here today for a two-day official visit during which he is expected to encourage Spain to oppose American plans to develop a space- based missile defense system.

title: A HALTING CHERNENKO IS ON TV AGAIN
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko was shown on television today for the second time in five days in a carefully staged appearance in which he looked exhausted, unsteady on his feet and short of breath.

description: THE MATTER OF WALES: Epic Views of

title: HORRORS OF HORS d'OEUVRES CIRCUIT

description: b-Net income

title: JORDAN AND BULLS TOP KNICKS
description: As has happened so many times for them on the road this season, it was another night of squandered opportunities for the Knicks tonight.

title: CABARET: COLLINS & FRIEDMAN
description: Jeanette Collins and Mimi Friedman, a brilliant up-and-coming team of actress-comedians, work in the sensitive area where social satire and character impersonation merge into a seriously funny portraiture of American life. In their act, which plays at the Ballroom (253 West 28th Street), Thursdays through Saturdays at 11 P.M., the two sing country songs, offer a scathing parody of ''Sneak Previews'' and advertise a bogus diet product called ''Snooz 'n' Lose.''

title: URUGUAY INSTALLS CIVILIAN PRESIDENT
description: Julio Maria Sanguinetti took office as the elected President of Uruguay today, restoring this country's long democratic tradition after 12 years of military rule.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: A BROAD MEASURE OF FUTURE GROWTH IN ECONOMY JUMPS
description: The Government index designed to predict the course of the economy jumped 1.7 percent in January, the biggest increase in 19 months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Radio Pitch for MX?
description: With the Reagan Administration revving up its campaign to create public support for the MX missile, White House aides have been discussing the possibility of President Reagan's making a strong pitch on evangelical radio programs around the country for funds for the weapon system.

title: JUST SOME JUNK AT TWILIGHT
description: Dear Norman: Yes, I did see that story about the entrepreneurial scheme to put a cemetery in orbit, or an ashcan in space, as I cannot help thinking of it.

title: REAGAN APPEARS FIRM ON AN ANTISATELLITE WEAPON
description: The Reagan Administration seems determined to press on with the testing and development of a weapon to destroy satellites, despite warnings that the military value of the weapon may be minor.

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: TECH-SYM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
15 Tons of Marijuana Seized
description: Federal agents seized an estimated 15 tons of marijuana from a leaky Panamanian cargo ship Thursday, detained six crew members and searched for a British captain and first mate who fled, the Coast Guard said. The 180-foot cargo ship, Fatuk, limped into port last Friday with multiple problems, including a serious leak, said Lance Jones, a Coast Guard spokesman at the Boston station. Customs Service agents and Coast Guard officers searched the ship's hold Thursday and found the marijuana under 100 tons of frozen shark meat, Mr. Jones said.

title: STEWART-WARNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $585,000 related to an excess of pension fund assets and balance sheet accruals over the cost of annuities purchased for employees of a subsidiary's non-contributory pension plan. The company said results for the 1983 quarter and year are after charges of $601,000 relating to the estimated costs of closing a foreign manufacturing facilities.

title:
PATENTS;

An Alarm Alerts Fatigued Drivers
description: A way to alert car drivers that they are excessively fatigued was patented this week for the Nissan Motor Company of Japan.

title: J. PAT O'MALLEY
description: J. Pat O'Malley, an Irish-born actor with extensive stage, screen and television experience, died Wednesday.

title: CALIFORNIA BANK SUES 6 IN LOSSES OVER MORTGAGES
description: The Bank of America sued six employees today, charging them with ''gross negligence'' for their involvement in a mortgage-backed securities scandal that has led to huge losses and embarrassment for the bank.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SOPRANO IN BROOKLYN The soprano Kathleen Battle of the Metropolitan Opera has won critical esteem in her young career. Her performance in the title role of Handel's ''Semele'' at Carnegie Hall was praised Monday by Donal Henahan of The New York Times, who cited her ''flawless, perfectly pitched runs, the precision and ease of her leaps and tricky intervals, the sensuous curve of her phrases, the pathos and delicacy of her reading of the text.''

title: CHESS CHALLENGER COMPLAINS OF PREPARATIONS FOR REMATCH
description: The challenger for the world chess championship, Gary Kasparov, said today that procedures for planning a September rematch with the champion, Anatoly Karpov, were inadequate.

title: Letter: On Mass Transit The City Should Regulate Vans To the Editor:
description: Your Jan. 29 editorial ''On Keeping Vans in Their Place'' calls attention to an important and complex issue and requires some clarification.

title: CANADIAN OCCIDENTAL PETROEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company attributed the improved results to the acquisitions of Canada-Cities Service Ltd. as of Aug. 1, 1983, and the Cities Offshore Production Co., acquired in early 1984.

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS UP 2%
description: Construction spending jumped 2 percent in January, lifted by increased building of offices and shopping centers, the Commerce Department said today. The rise was the biggest in eight months.

title: SATURDAY, MARCH 2, 1985
description: International

title: SATELLITE PROBLEMS SCRUB SHUTTLE FLIGHT
description: The planned launching of the space shuttle Challenger next week has been scrubbed because of problems with two $100 million satellites, space officials announced tonight. Senator Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, had been scheduled to be a passenger on the spaceship.

title: LUCILLE LONG HUNT
description: Lucille Long Hunt, the sister of former Gov. Huey P. Long of Louisiana, died Thursday after a brief illness, family members said.

title: On the Brink
description: Denny Crum's remarkable string of 20 or more victories in each of his 13 previous seasons as head basketball coach at Louisville is in great jeopardy, but there is another streak about which he is much more concerned.

title: TOSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a pre-tax loss of $131,700,000 for the quarter and year on the writedown of assets and related termination costs, and a tax credit of $2,000,000 for the year. c-After pre-tax losses on the writedown of assets and related termination costs of $113,500,000 for the quarter and $333,500,000 for the year, and tax credits of $4,408,000 for the quarter and $92,180,000 for the year.

title: Importers and Association Of Car Dealers Hail Move
description: The companies that import automobiles into the United States today welcomed President Reagan's decision to end restraints on Japanese car imports.

title: WILSON FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $564,000. c-Net income includes an extraordinary gain of $24,909,000.

title: GIRL DIES IN HER 2D OPERATION FOR HEART-LIVER TRANSPLANT
description: A Texas teen-ager who was the third person in the world to undergo a simultaneous heart-and-liver transplant died this morning when her new heart failed while she was undergoing a second transplant operation, doctors said.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 28.

title: COLONIAL PENN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $15,000. c-After realized investment losses of $105,000 for the quarter and $1,714,000 for the year. d-After realized investment losses of $32,000.

title: NEW BANK RULES BY FED
description: In a continuing effort to bolster the financial underpinning of the banking industry, especially big banks, the Federal Reserve Board gave preliminary approval today to new guidelines for the ratio of capital to total assets that banks should maintain.

title: BOB EVANS FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
For World Safeguards
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about a jazz concert by James Emery at Cooper Union gave an incorrect date. The concert will take place March 8. A performance by the Sir Roland Hanna quartet announced for tomorrow in the same article will not take place.

title: WHEN FAMINE GIVES EARLY CLUES
description: Africa is environmentally bankrupt. An entire continental breakdown is by no means impossible. Yet for 3,000 years,African people lived in balanced harmony with their environment, never straining the carrying capacity of nature. By drawing on that experience and by monitoring local food prices and other social phenomena that give early clues about impending problems, it may be possible to delay or prevent future famines.

title: MATTINGLY SEEKING MORE PRODUCTIVITY
description: In his second season in the major leagues, Don Mattingly led the American League with a .343 batting average, 207 hits and 44 doubles. He was among the top five with 110 runs batted in and a .537 slugging percentage, and he also hit 23 home runs.

title: A CORRECTION
description: A sentence in a letter Feb. 28 from Nancy Gooban on the proposed ''Star Wars'' defense system appeared incorrectly. It shoud have read, ''We can protect our missiles from destruction by a simple launch-on-warning policy to insure that silos are empty before incoming missiles arrive - for this, we do not need to spend $1 trillion and years of research.''

title: Niskanen Quits Economic Post WASHINGTON, March 1
description: William A. Niskanen

title: THE TUNA SANDWICH: HOWEVER YOU LIKE IT
description: ''The Joy of Cooking'' has failed me. After more than 25 years of finding everything I ever needed in it, the cookbook came up short this week when I was searching for the quintessential tuna fish sandwich.

title: Perma Seeks All of Kaiser The Perma Resources Corporation, a Colorado Springs
description: energy company, will acquire

title: Brooks Weighs His Options
description: Herb Brooks, discharged Jan. 21 as coach of the Rangers, is one of the candidates being considered to take over as coach of the Boston Bruins next season.

title: KENTRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,276,000. c-Net income.

title: PANEL URGES $7.5 BILLION FOR TOXIC WASTE CLEANUP
description: The Senate Environment and Public Works Committee, largely rejecting a Reagan Administration proposal, today recommended budgeting $7.5 billion over five years to clean up toxic waste sites.

title: SALE BAN ENDS ON MASSEY SHARES
description: Masset-Ferguson Ltd. said yesterday that a year-old agreement under which stockholders had agreed not to sell their shares had ended, and that an additional 68 million shares would now be released for trading, subject to United States and Canadian securities regulation.

title: RIO ALGOM LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31

PATENTS;

VERSATILE BARBED FENCING
description: WASHINGTON A VERSATILE type of wire fencing made with a stainless steel strip that has sharp barbs that can be instantly erected or dismantled is to be patented next Tuesday. Patent 4,503,423 is assigned to the Man Barrier Corporation, Seymour, Conn.

title: 2 BROTHERS ARE CHARGED IN 3 BROOKLYN SLAYINGS
description: Two brothers were charged last night with killing three men and injuring eight others, including three children, in a drug robbery-related rampage of shootings, stabbings and torture inside a Brooklyn house Wednesday night.

title: GOVERNOR SEEKS BIG CRACKDOWN ON TAX EVADERS
description: Saying cheating on New York State taxes is ''in the billion dollar range,'' the Cuomo administration today proposed a package of bills to crack down on tax evasion.

title: CROWN CENTRAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Exceeded by preferred dividend requirements and includes a pre-tax gain of $29 million from a reduction in LIFO inventories and a gain of $13 million from the sale of service stations on Long Island.

title: Reagan Terms Nicaraguan Rebels Moral Equal of Founding Fathers
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  President Reagan said today that the rebels seeking to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government were the ''moral equal of our Founding Fathers.''

title: John Eager Howard, 82, Dies; Researcher at Johns Hopkins
description: John Eager Howard, a leader in endocrinology and metabolism research who developed drug treatments to prevent some kinds of kidney stone formations, died Wednesday at his home here.

title: Back to the Subway
description: After three weeks of recuperating from a major operation, David L. Gunn, who heads the subway and bus system and has steadfastly refused the car and driver that go with his job, decided it was time to go back to work.

title: COASTAL IN OFFER FOR RESOURCES
description: The stock of the American Natural Resources Company surged to a 52- week high in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as company officials indicated that they would fight an expected acquisition attempt.

title: LSB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $23,730,652 from the sale of certain debt. c-Net loss after an extraordinary gain of $697,073 from the purchase of debentures.

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SCREEN: CHUCK NORRIS IN 'MISSING IN ACTION 2'
description: Chuck Norris is back, dishing out patriotism and heavy sadism in ''Missing in Action 2 - The Beginning,'' which opened yesterday at the UA Twin and other theaters. Confused by the chronology? Don't be. ''Missing in Action,'' the first film in the series, told what happened when Colonel Braddock (Mr. Norris), a Vietnam veteran and former prisoner, went back to rescue missing men. Everything went swimmingly: The men were rescued, and the film made money. So, a second installment is here to reveal the details of Braddock's 1972 escape. If it too does well, we will undoubtedly be seeing a Part 3 covering his high school years.

title: TV and Movie Writers Get Producers' Offer
description: Television and movie producers concluded a 15-hour negotiating session early today by putting forward what they described as their best and final contract offer for a vote by the Writers Guild of America.

title: Bell Resources
description: Bell Resources Ltd. said it had exercised an option to acquire UB Minerals Inc. from the General Electric Company's General Electric Holdings subsidiary for $118.8 million, in addition to the $6.3 million option fee paid last April.

title: Bhopal Should Not Stop Cooperative Development
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Pinklon Thomas, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, must undergo a medical examination before he fights again because of reports that he is suffering from an eye problem, according to the W.B.C. president,

title: VA. COMMONWEALTH GAINS
description: Rolando Lamb scored 20 points to lead Virginia Commonwealth to an 85-62 victory over North Carolina- Charlotte tonight in the opening round of the Sun Belt Conference Tournament.

title: STUDENTS AT COLUMBIA HONOR TRAILBLZING FEMALE LAWYER
description: In 1873, the United States Supreme Court ruled that Myra Bradwell was not constitutionally entitled to practice law. ''The paramount destiny and mission of woman,'' wrote Justice Joseph B. Bradley, ''are to fulfill the noble and benign office of wife and mother. That is the law of the Creator.''

title: Green's Brother Hurt
description: The Bulls' forward Sidney Green, whose brother Bernie was injured during a shooting that left three people dead in a Brooklyn house Wednesday, expressed relief before the game that his brother, who saved the lives of several people, had survived the ordeal. ''He's doing pretty well considering,'' he said.

title: Leave 'em Speechless
description: Gen. John J. Vessey Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was reminiscing the other night about what he called the best speech he had ever heard.

title: Jersey Church Wins A Ruling Over Name
description: A state appeals court ruled today that a Plainfield church can use the words ''Christian Science,'' disallowing another church's claim of a monopoly on the name.

title: NATO CHIEF FINDS CONVENTIONAL FORCES LACKING
description: The Supreme Commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization told Congress today that NATO military forces continued to be heavily overmatched by the Warsaw Pact and would be forced to surrender or resort to nuclear weapons within days of a Soviet attack.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Consumer Saturday column on Jan. 19 about safety in cars incorrectly described the scope of laws requiring devices to restrain children. All states and the District of Columbia have such laws.

title: Baxter Travenol Adds Compucare
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., based in Deerfield, Ill., said that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Compucare Inc. in a stock transaction valued at about $73 million. In a statement, Vernon R. Loucks Jr., Baxter Travenol's president, said the acquisition, expected to be completed during the second quarter, would aid his company's expansion in the ''rapidly growing hospital information systems market.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $871,094 and a gain of $3,304,943 from the sale of warehouses.

title: EX-MOVIE IDOL STARS IN INDIA'S FEATURED ELECTION
description: N. T. Rama Rao was seated on the roof of a sturdy Chevrolet stationwagon at the head of a 22-vehicle motorcade sweeping through the towns and villages of his native state.

title: BUILDER TRANSPORT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The increase in average outstanding shares in 1984 resulted from the company's initial public offering in October 1983.

title: U.S. CLARIFIES LETTER ON BANK
description: In what it called a clarification, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency said today that a letter it issued Tuesday did not mean to imply that the agency had cited the Bank of Boston in 1982 for a violation of the international currency reporting regulations.

description: At the recent libel trial of charges brought by Gen. William C. Westmoreland against CBS, there were 68 days of testimony and 9,745 pages of transcripts.

Bill Rates Are Up Sharply
description: Interest rates on Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with short-term rates rising while note and bond yields declined.

THE MOOD HAS CHANGED

Limiting Movement Of Head in Golf Swing
description: Two men who believe golfers should limit head movement when swinging at the ball have invented a sensor to let players know when this is happening. James E. Obenauf of Tucson, Ariz., and Charles E. Brodish of Mercer Island, Wash., were granted patent 4,502,035 this week for the device, which is already in production.

title: FRONTIER HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: J. DONALD RAWLINGS
description: J. Donald Rawlings, senior partner in the law firm of Hardy Peal Rawlings Werner & Coogan, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Kings Point, L.I. He was 74 years old.

title: CONTINENTAL MATERIALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,250,000, or 98 cents a share, from the settlement of a dispute and an after-tax gain of $900,000, or 74 cents a share, from the sale of a plant for the quarter and year. The company said the gains were partially offset by the writedown of an investment, which decreased net income in the latest quarter and year by $530,000, or 44 cents a share.

title: A Nixon's Schooldays
description: One of the items that will be up for bids at the Sidwell Friends School auction on April 27 is a leather-bound, autographed copy of Richard M. Nixon's book ''Leaders,'' published in 1976.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Washington Bullets , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Bullets have swept the four games between the teams this season. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WPAT, 930; WFAS, 1230; and WGBB, 1240; 7:20 P.M.).

title: Eastern Is Given Reprieve on Debt
description: Eastern Airlines' lenders say the company is no longer in technical default on about $2.5 billion in debt, the airline said today.

title: Watchful Loft Dwellers
description: Late Thursday night, John Vidol and his neighbor, James Lipton, were returning home to their lofts at 37 West 26th Street after another grueling session with their lawyer on how to make their illegal residences legal when they heard it: the sound of steel on cinder block. Thieves were tunneling from the fire stairs into the G. T. Chains jewelry company on the 11th floor.

title: NETS FINALLY TOP.500
description: In the aftermath, Stan Albeck allowed himself a smile and a sigh of relief. Four months into the season, his team finally may have reached a turning point.

title: CHARITA BAUER, 62, TV ACTRESS
description: Charita Bauer, a popular daytime serial actress for more than 35 years, died Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 62 years old.

title: THE DANCE: STEPHANIE SKURA
description: Thanks to Stephanie Skura and a merry band of pranksters, dance was destroyed on Tuesday night in the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater (219 West 19th Street). The demise of the art occurred during ''Survey of Styles,'' an outrageously amusing work conceived by Miss Skura and choreographed by her in collaboration with her cast.

title: CONNECTICUT PROSECUTOR UNDER SIEGE
description: ''Corruption prosecutors don't have a great life expectancy, and there's a good reason for that,'' Austin J. McGuigan was saying of his tenure as Connecticut's Chief State's Attorney.

title: Lesson to Forget
description: Chub Feeney, president of the National League, has warned the Chicago Cubs' pitching coach,

title: CREST-FOAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Official on Probation After a Fatal Accident
description: The Supervisor of the Town of Essex, N.Y., was sentenced yesterday to three years' probation and fined $500 for driving while intoxicated in an accident that killed a pedestrian last year.

title: Bridge:Baron Egmont von Dewitz Was Known for Sense of Fun
description: One of the bridge world's most colorful characters died recently in Cologne, West Germany, at the age of 77. He was Baron Egmont von Dewitz, a high court judge who was known for his sense of fun, his courtly manner, his long cigarette holder and his wide general knowledge: He was one of the few people, professional historians apart, who could name all 26 marshals of the Emperor Napoleon.

title: ADVANCED COMMUNICATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TOSCO'S QUARTERLY LOSS GROWS TO $155.2 MILLION
description: The ailing Tosco Corporation, a large, indepedent oil refiner that has suffered heavy losses for the last two years, said today that it lost $155.2 million in the fourth quarter.

title: Discord at the Opera
description: The Metropolitan Opera likes to think of its supporters as a great big family. But no family is complete without heated disagreements.

title: Cypriot Rejects Vote, But Offers No New Plan
description: President Spyros Kyprianou tonight rejected a challenge issued by Parliament last Friday that he resign and call new presidential elections. But he failed to offer an expected formula for ending the crisis.

title: Starting Over
description: They had not talked to each other for a year, largely because of the bitter, now-settled dispute in which the Yankee owner withheld payments that were to have gone to his star right fielder's foundation for children. But when George Steinbrenner stepped onto the field at Fort Lauderdale Stadium yesterday, he walked right to the batting cage - where Dave Winfield awaited his turn to hit - then put his arm round Winfield, patted him on the back and spoke to him.

title: NEW YORK'S WAR ON DROPOUTS
description: Dropouts are far and away the most serious problem facing New York City's public schools. About 42 percent of all who enter the million-student system may leave before completing the full 12 years. Yet until recently, city officials seemed insufficiently concerned.

title: FILM: OCCULT CREATURES EVOKED IN 'GHOULIES'
description: ''Ghoulies,'' which opened yesterday at the RKO Warner and other theaters, is a U.S.O. (Unidentified Screening Object), one of that increasing number of exploitation films that, without warning, suddenly flop down onto New York like exhausted dogs.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They are the moral equal of our Founding Fathers and the brave men and women of the French Resistance.'' - President Reagan, speaking about Nicaraguan rebels. (1:2.)

title: 'Shoemaker' Publisher Challenges Jersey Law
description: Simon & Schuster Inc., publisher of ''Shoemaker,'' a book by Flora Rheta Schreiber about the convicted murderer Joseph Kallinger, went to court Friday to challenge a state law that permits victims to share in the profits criminals earn from books, movies and other endeavors based on the offense.

title: SPERRY AND ITT TALKS ARE ENDED
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it had been conducting preliminary merger talks with the Sperry Corporation, but that they had been ''terminated.''

title: NEW STAKE IN ASAROO
description: A successful Australian corporate investor, Robert Holmes a Court, has acquired a 10 percent interest in Asarco Inc., setting off speculation about whether he plans to attempt a takeover of the big American mining company.

title: A LACK OF DATA IS SEEN AS A BAR TO SUNY SHIFTS
description: Budgeting and accounting deficiencies in the State University of New York need to be remedied before the current move toward autonomy takes effect, Comptroller Edward V. Regan said today.

title: U.S. Says Grave in Zimbabwe May Hold Kidnapped Tourists
description: The State Department said today that a gravesite found in Zimbabwe might contain the bodies of two Americans, two Britons and two Australians kidnapped in July 1982.

title: CONOLOG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ODD ALLIANCE BATTLES EDUCATION CUTS
description: At One Dupont Circle, the nation's higher education associations have rallied the shock troops of college students and presidents.

title: EMOTIONS ARE HIGH FOR REDMEN FINALE
description: When St. John's earned its No. 1 ranking five weeks ago, the first team it faced was Providence College. After a lethargic start the Redmen went on to defeat the Friars, 77-60, in an uninspiring game at the Providence Civic Center.

title: Tolerance May Not Be the Best Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: WILL JAPANESE GO EASY ON DETROIT?
description: For all that American auto makers have done to remake their industry, almost no one doubts that with the lifting of quotas on imports, Japan's car companies have it in their power to greatly increase their sales and deal Detroit a new body blow. Whether they will in fact do so will most likely be determined over the next few weeks by the Japanese Government.

title: Big Audience for Big GameBRISTOL, Conn., March 1 (UPI) - ESPN's live telecast of the Georgetown-St. John's college basketball game Wednesday night was seen in 2.9 million homes - the largest audience in the cable network's five-year history.
description: That figure represents an 8.0 rating and a 12 share in ESPN's audience of 35.7 million households nationwide.

title: SOCKING IT HARD TO THE CITIES
description: From the perspective of cities and states, the Administration's domestic policy recalls the ancient Chinese torture of force-feeding victims with a banquet and then punching them repeatedly in the stomach.

title: YOU'RE NEVER TOO OLD TO ROCK AND ROLL
description: Rock-and-roll isn't just for adolescents any more. The pop-music business has rediscovered older and younger fans, outside the 16- to 25- year-old audience everyone had taken for granted.

title: Rooms for Runners Bowing to pressure from upstarts such as the New York City Marathon, the organizers of the venerable Boston Marathon have agreed to pay some of the expenses for top runners in the 1985 race but are still refusing to offer prize money, according to the race administrator,
description: Guy Morse. He said the race committee of the Boston Athletic Association, which sponsors the race, had voted to pay for hotel accommodations for 20 ''elite'' runners, reversing a long tradition.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NORANDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $51,400,000 for the quarter and $29,000,000 for the year. Year-ago results are restated to reflect an accounting change. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: NO CHILD ABUSE, NO ADULT ABUSE
description: America discovered sexual child abuse in 1984. Investigations and arrests at day care centers in New York, New Jersey, Illinois, Alabama, Tennessee and California frightened parents and plunged early childhood educators into re-examination of hiring procedures. Some new vigilance is surely appropriate, but we must be careful, in our efforts to investigate the problem, to protect civil liberties and due process.

title: TURNER STATEMENT
description: The stock market reacted sharply yesterday to reports that Ted Turner, the Atlanta-based cable and broadcasting entrepreneur, was considering an attempt to take over CBS Inc. CBS stock was among the most active on the New York Stock Exchange, with more than 1.2 million shares traded, and the price of the stock jumped $4 a share, to $88.50.

title: Indictment Called Insufficient To Extradite Ex-Nazi Official
description: A Federal magistrate refused today to extradite a former Nazi official to Yugoslavia to face mass murder charges, saying the indictment was not specific enough.

title: Bucks Are Sold
description: After two weeks of intense negotiations, the Milwaukee Bucks were sold yesterday to a 50-year-old former supermarket-chain owner

title: 4 SCORING PASSES WIN FOR FLUTIE
description: Doug Flutie felt that he did not have to prove himself tonight. Then, with quiet confidence, he went out and proved to any skeptics that a neophyte, 5 feet 9 3/4 inches tall, can win in professional football.

title: Lessons of Libel Suits
description: To the Editor:

title: STEPHENS TAKES HIS PRIZE IN STRIDE
description: HIALEAH, Fla.

title: 20-YEAR LOW IN CITY FIRES POSTED IN '84
description: Building fires in New York hit a 20-year low last year, according to statistics released by the Fire Department.

title: Burton Zohman, 85, Doctor Who Studied Heart Disease
description: Dr. Burton L. Zohman, a cardiologist and researcher, died of coronary artery disease last Saturday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 85 years old.

title: NETWORKS INTERPRET FEBRUARY RATINGS SWEEPS
description: After 28 hard-fought nights, the three television networks rested for a moment yesterday, then seized the Nielsen results of the February ratings sweeps, which ended Thursday, and interpreted them as each saw fit.

title: BRNF Trust Bars Sale of 30 Planes
description: The trustees of the BRNF Liquidating Trust, which acquired some of the assets of the Braniff International Corporation after its 1982 bankruptcy proceedings, have rejected an offer from the Deutsche Bank Capital Corporation to buy 30 Boeing 727-20 aircraft and spare parts for $160 million.

title:
PATENTS;

System for Storing Genealogical Records
description: A Florida mother and two daughters received a patent this week on a system for storing genealogical records. Patent 4,501,559, granted Beth H. Griswold, and her daughters, Gail E. and Alexandra F. Griswold, of Melbourne Village, says that a minimum number of pieces of paper will cover several generations and various ancestors.

title: Jazz America Festival At Lehman College
description: The Jazz America Festival at Lehman College in the Bronx is presenting free concerts this weekend. Tickets are available at the box office at the theater of the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts.

title: INSTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $181,000 for the quarter from the reversal of a tax credit and a loss of $1,659,000 for the year related to certain terminated and redefined product lines of the company's U.K. subsidiary. c-Includes a tax credit of $148,000.

title: A DRACAENA BLOOMS ON MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS
description: Fantastic! - Ethel Feagley

title: U.S., IN PRAISING PRETORIA, EXPRESSES WORRY ON ARRESTS
description: The Reagan Administration issued a policy statement on South Africa today that sought to balance the Administration's concern about the recent arrest of opposition leaders with continued backing for President P. W. Botha's program of change.

title: E.P.A. Seeks $3.9 Million Fine
description: The Union Carbide Company is being fined $3.9 million for a delay in reporting the testing of a chemical that could pose a substantial risk to human health, the Environmental Protection Agency said this evening.

title: Alaskan Train Kills 24 Moose in One Night
description: An Alaska Railroad freight train killed 24 moose in a single night this week.

title: LAW AND (BIRTH) ORDER
description: Starting with John Jay in 1789, American Presidents have appointed 102 Supreme Court justices. Randomly, one would expect 38 to have been first- borns or only children and 38 to have been last born. But when Paul Weber of the University of Louisville studied the roster of justices, he found an oddly different result. There have been 56 first-borns and only children, a strikingly high proportion, and only 19 last-borns, a strikingly low one.

title: CALLAHAN MINING CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes 12 cents a share from the sale of a discontinued operation. The company said the principal cause of the profit fall-off was the lower price of silver which averaged $7.59 an ounce in 1984 compared with $10.45 in 1983. In addition, exploration expenditures although pared from a budgeted $8.5 million to $7.1 million, represented an after-tax charge against 1984 earnings equivalent to 53 cents a share. The previously announced pretax writeoff of $1,215,000 on the sale of Callahan's 49.9 percent interest in the K.R.M. Petroleum Corp. also impacted results to the extent of 17 cents a share, after tax, the company added.

title: PENTAGON AGREES NUCLEAR WARFARE COULD BLOCK SUN, FREEZING EARTH
description: The Pentagon today accepted as valid a theory that nuclear war could generate enough smoke and dust to blot out the sun and cause severe climatic cooling.

title: Mariners Sign Davis
description: Alvin Davis, the Seattle first baseman who was the American League's rookie of the year last season, has reached an agreement on a new one- year contract, according to the club, which disclosed no financial terms. . . .

title: REAGAN TERMS NICARAGUAN REBELS 'MORAL EQUAL OF FOUNDING FATHERS'
description: President Reagan said today that the rebels seeking to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government were the ''moral equal of our Founding Fathers.''

title: GUATEMALA, AWAITING VOTE, LEARNS KILLINGS RISE
description: Political killings and human rights violations increased significantly in Guatemala last year, according to figures provided by the American Embassy here.

title: 1980 Campaign Debt
description: Mark Green neither holds political office nor is he running for one. So why were 200 people crammed into Loulette Samuel's West Side apartment Thursday, paying $125 for the privilege of helping him pay off a campaign debt from 1980, when he ran and lost to Representative Bill Green?

description: Parliament has overwhelmingly cleared Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of charges that he illegally received money from a West German industrial conglomerate.

title: ARMY PHONES NEED $30 MILLION REPAIR
description: The Army is planning to spend $30 million to change its new long-range combat communication system because it discovered the devices were not capable of communicating with those used by the Air Force.

title: West German to Visit Israel
description: President Richard von Weizs"acker is scheduled to visit Israel Oct. 8-11, his office announced today. It will be the first visit there by a West German head of state. The visit is to be made at the invitation of the Israeli President, Chaim Herzog, the West German President's office said.

description: The two big pieces on Thursday's New York Philharmonic program at Avery Fisher Hall were Bartok's Concerto No. 3 for piano and the Brahms Second Symphony. Still, it was the third item - Aaron Copland's ''Music for the Theater'' - that created such an interesting confluence of cultures.

description: Right after the George Stavropoulos spring and summer fashion show in the ballroom of the Regency Hotel this week, Evangeline Gouletas-Carey insisted that her first choice was ''the satin dress with diamonds.'' She quickly added that she wasn't averse to ruffles either and that she actually coveted ''one of everything.''

title: DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
COMPLEX PROBLEMS OF TEEN-AGE PREGNANCY
description: The problem under consideration was adolescent pregnancy, and the seminars, lectures and workshops holding the attention of 900 people at the fourth annual conference of the Children's Defense Fund encompassed prenatal care, jobs and job training, tax reform, Federal budget cuts, child care and improved health and education policies. But no matter what the issue, it was almost always connected with adolescent pregnancy, and that problem, as Marian Wright Edelman, president of the advocacy organization, put it,''has no quick fixes.''

title: DOLLAR'S HECTIC WEEK ENDS ON A CALM NOTE
description: The dollar yesterday ended one of the most turbulent weeks in the history of floating exchange rates with uncharacteristic calm. Resisting intervention by several central banks, the dollar was little changed in light trading.

title: CAMPBELL RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: OPERA: 'ERNANI,' BY VERDI, REVIVIED AT THE METROPOLITAN
description: The Metropolitan Opera, like other major companies, can round up a strong cast for almost any new production. What happens in later seasons, however, often does not bear dwelling on. As in Thursday evening's ''Ernani,'' the first appearance this season for a production that was new in 1983, revivals often can offer only one or two internationally recognized stars. A certain amount of slippage in vocal quality comes to be taken for granted, shrugged off even by audiences that should know better.

title: YES, TARGETED SUBSIDIES ARE CHEAPER
description: ''There's simply no justification,'' argues President Reagan, ''for the Federal Government . . . to be borrowing money to be spent by state and local governments, some of which are now running surpluses.'' The President has a point. Although the case against so-called general revenue sharing - no-strings Federal subsidies to cities and towns - is not as straightforward as Mr. Reagan contends, it is hard to justify aid that is so poorly targeted.

description: Playing against the Hartford Whalers, a distant last in the Adams Division, the Devils were listless again tonight and lost, 4-1, for their sixth consecutive defeat.

description: President Reagan, on the unanimous advice of his Cabinet, cleared the way today for Japan to ship more cars to the United States.

title: DROUGHT TURNS NOMADS' WORLD UPSIDE DOWN
description: It is called the Road of Hope. But just as the bulldozers return daily to clear the 700-mile road of the advancing Saharan sands, hope in this nation often seems futile.
