description: At precisely 10 P.M. Thursday, a green van pulled up on Vanderbilt Avenue next to Grand Central Terminal. Four people got out, opened the back doors and began to unload.

title: Betsy King Takes Lead
description: Betsy King shot a four-under-par 68 today to pass Patty Sheehan and take a one- stroke lead after two rounds of the $150,000 Turquoise Classic. Miss King's round gave her a two-round total of seven-under-par 137. Miss Sheehan, the first-round leader, struggled with a 73 for a total of 138.

title: YOUTH GOETZ SHOT OFFERS TO TESTIFY
description: One of the four young men shot by Bernhard H. Goetz is willing to testify against Mr. Goetz, even without immunity from prosecution, if the state reopens its case before a new grand jury, the youth's lawyer said yesterday.

Imperial Chemical
description: Imperial Chemical Industries said it had completed the previously announced acquisition of the chemical interests of the Beatrice Companies for $750 million. The company said it had issued 18 million shares to raise part of the purchase price, and the balance would be met from the group's cash resources and existing bank facilities.

title: TJALLING C. KOOPMANS, NOBEL HONOR WINNER
description: Dr. Tjalling C. Koopmans, the co- winner of the 1975 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science for his theories on the optimal allocation of resources, died Tuesday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Hamden, Conn.

description: Federal approval for a test to screen donated blood for a suspected antibody of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, is expected to be announced today in Washington, Federal health officials said last night.

description: President Reagan is planning to name a high-level group to study the handling of nuclear weapons in the United States, a source close to the group said today.

description: Chris Mullin will not be leaving Alumni Hall this afternoon. He will not be saying goodbye, even if everyone else will. ''We're going to play more games,'' he said yesterday with a shrug. ''They just ain't going to be here.''

description: Olgivanna Lloyd Wright, the collaborator and wife of Frank Lloyd Wright and, since his death in 1959, the keeper of his architectural legacy, died of a heart attack yesterday at Scottsdale (Ariz.) Memorial Hospital North. She was 85 years old and lived at Taliesin West, a colony for apprentice architects the Wrights built in the desert near Scottsdale.

He was 66 years old.

description: Stock prices surged to new highs on a wave of institutional buying yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at a record 1,299.36, up 15.35 points, after being as high as 1,306.76 at midafternoon.

description: Internorth Inc., which is based in Omaha, bought half interest in the Valero Energy Corporation's west Texas natural gas pipeline system for 68 million, the two companied said yesterday. The pipeline, which will be operated as a joint venture, gives Internorth access to the growing market for industrial gas on the Texas Gulf Coast, said Randall Blauvelt, an Internorth spokesman.

title: J.C. HERLIHY, 79, EX-STATE JUSTICE J. Clarence Herlihy, a former presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, Third Department, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Glens Falls, N.Y. He was 79 years old.
description: Justice Herlihy, was elected as a Republican to the State Supreme Court in 1955. He was appointed to the Appellate Division in 1958 by Gov. W. Averill Harriman, and in 1969 Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller appointed him presiding justice, a position he held until he reached the mandatory retirement age of 70 in 1975.

title: Approval in Japan
description: Japanese Government officials and automobile manufacturers today applauded the United States decision not to press for extension of Japan's export quotas, saying that the American consumer would benefit from resulting lower prices and greater selection.

description: Gov. Bill Allain, again rejecting legislative plans for pay increases for teachers, said today that their expanding wildcat strikes were a ''breach of contract'' and warned that school districts could lose state aid if the actions persisted.

title: STRAWBERRY WILL EXTEND PACT
description: Darryl Strawberry agreed today to a long-term contract with the Mets that he said would foreclose any future haggling and provide the security he needs ''to make the most of my career.''

title: INTENSE TEACHING WINS AT IOWA
description: It is nearly 2 P.M., the hour that the Iowa women's basketball team begins practice. Already, a hamburger and a slab of pizza have reached the desk of Coach C. Vivian Stringer. Her husband, Bill, carried in the hamburger; her assistant coach, Marianna Freeman, delivered the pizza.

title: HOUSING FOR FAMILIES: PROS AND CONS
description: Our parish was recently contacted by a mother in desperate need of housing. Her husband is out of work, they have six children and are temporarily living in an unheated room in a friend's basement in Kearny.

description: House Democrats gathered at the plush Greenbrier resort this weekend to hear blunt talk about their problems.

title: Survivors Sought in Sinking
description: A tugboat with six crewmen aboard sank early today off northern California. The tugboat sent out a distress call shortly after midnight saying it was listing heavily in swells as much as 30 feet high. The crewmen, who were not identified, were reported to be donning survival suits when ''communications were lost,'' said the Coast Guard.

description: ''Modern pictures have made the very definite effort to leave the frame. But do they stay out, do they go back and if they do is that where they belong and has anybody been deceived.'' - Gertrude Stein, ''Lectures in America''

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Busy Butcher Serves Meats Around County Trim-Rite Meats, opened seven years ago in Elmsford, custom cuts American prime beef fore- and hindquarters, or lamb and pork, and stores the double freezer-wrapped, frozen parcels at no extra charge until asked for by the buyer. The inventory list can be added to, or additional free deliveries made and paid for when received, on the basis of bimonthly fliers with specials and promotions sent to a mailing list of 2,000, or from the pick-up room's blackboard of weekly promotions.

title: ZABAGLIONE, AN ITALIAN DESSERT
description: ZABAGLIONE (or zabaione and, in French, sabayon) has become a favorite Italian dessert. According to the food writer and teacher Giuliano Bugialli, the warm, custardy froth of egg yolks, sugar and wine is served more frequently to end a meal in this country than it is in Italy. He contends that the mixture was originally served as a tonic, stirred into morning coffee.

title: MARK F. ETHRIDGE Jr.
description: Mark F. Ethridge Jr., former editor of The Detroit Free Press, died of cancer Friday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 60 years old.

title: A Plan onAgent Orange
description: The 200,000 veterans who claim that they were harmed by the herbicide Agent Orange while in Vietnam had their first look last week at a master plan for distributing the $200 million that the drug's manufacturers have agreed to pay in settlement of the claims.

title: A Lost Retarded Boy Survives With 3 Dogs
description: An 8-year-old mentally retarded boy who disappeared in freezing temperatures after following his dogs into heavy woods has been found after spending a night in a ravine under the dogs.

title: WHEN PUTTERING BECOMES A MANIA
description: THE day my husband's dream became my reality was the day I should have packed it in.

title: ENOUGH GREENMAIL
description: On a recent visit to New York, I picked up a newspaper and discovered in the business section that my company might be the target of a takeover attempt. It caught my attention. But it was no surpr large, is vulnerable to the tidal wave of hostile takeovers that we have seen in recent years. Some may find this ironic. For more than 10 years, as a critic of corporate raiders, stock- market speculators, opportunistic bankers, lawyers, arbitrageurs and other power-hungry players in the real-money monopoly game of hostile takeovers, I have argued that such takeovers loot corporate treasuries, cheat shareholders and undermine our ability to compete in world markets. I have warned that they lead to the misuse of capital; force management to sacrifice long-term strategy and the development of new products and services for short-term gains; inhibit innovation, and cause job losses and economic upheaval that disrupt the lives of employers and communities.

title: HELPING ELDERLY AVOID INJURY
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission has announced a campaign to help the elderly avoid household injuries that send them to hospital emergency rooms at a cost of $3 billion a year.

title: BEAUTY ABOVE US
description: All too often, Timothy Ferris believes, photographs of outer space are used as mere handmaidens to a written text. In SPACESHOTS: The Beauty of Nature Beyond Earth (Pantheon, $24.95), Mr. Ferris, the author of ''Galaxies'' and ''The Red Limit: The Search for the Edge of the Universe,'' rights this wrong with terrific vengeance by displaying 78 space photographs unadorned by words.

title: SUTCLIFFE'S PRICE: A KING-SIZE BED
description: After Rick Sutcliffe won 16 games and lost only 1 in slightly more than half a season last year, the Chicago Cubs were prepared to give him just about anything he wanted to keep him from fleeing elsewhere as a free agent. The Cubs gave him $9 million for five years, they agreed to give him low-interest loans of $500,000 a year and they said they would pay for a single room on the road.

title: ARAFAT DENOUNCES U.S. RESPONSE TO JORDAN ACCORD AS 'SHAMEFUL'

title: MUSEUM TAKES A LOOK AT ARTIST-RUN GALLERIES
description: FRUSTRATION over limited gallery opportunities sometimes provokes artists to seek other ways to present their work. Artist-run galleries have become a significant part of the Island art scene - so much so, in fact, that the Islip Art Museum has mounted an exhibition calling attention to the phenomenon.

title: Hanging Judge at State The head of the State Department's Bureau of Politico-Military Affairs has personally indicted, tried and convicted Leslie Gelb of The New York Times for what he considers irresponsible, even traitorous conduct. What was Mr. Gelb's offense? He did his job as a responsible journalist by reporting on an international controversy over nuclear weapons. That is no offense at all. What is truly offensive here is the behavior of the official, Lieut. Gen. John Chain. It calls out for repudiation.
description: General Chain is displeased with The Times's account, on Feb. 13, of United States contingency plans to deploy nuclear depth charges in Canada, Iceland, Bermuda and Puerto Rico without consulting their Governments. The story noted that the disclosure of the plans by William Arkin, a Washington critic of American weapons policy, had caused public and even parliamentary debate abroad.

title: TAX PLANNING IN UNCERTAIN TIMES
description: THE tax clock is running. While many people have yet to even focus on the task of filling out their 1984 tax returns, time is already fast encroaching on tax-saving opportunities for next year. Because of changes in the tax law, many taxpayers will belatedly discover, if some steps are not taken immediately, that valuable deductions are being lost as each day passes. Onerous new record-keeping requirements for cars and computers used for business, for instance, mean taxpayers may already be losing if they are not keeping daily logs.

description: I don't know where Mr. Gallagher went to high school, but I do know the difficulties confronted by the staff and students at a great many off our urban and suburban high schools.

title: CONCERT: NATIONAL ORCHESTRA
description: The new Fritz Reiner Center for Contemporary Music at Columbia University celebrated its establishment this past week by presenting two free concerts of music that used to be contemporary. The music in question was all by composers who in one way or another were associated with Columbia. That may be a laudable concept, and Friday's orchestral concert - the first, on Tuesday, was devoted to chamber repertory - had its moments. But contemporary does not mean 20th century, it means now, if we're to believe the dictionary.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: its upraised sword was lost to vandals 20 years ago - stands before the Bergen County Courthouse, a lone sentinel against the seasons and a reminder to Hackensack's residents and visitors that history was made and shaped there. The Revolutionary War officer is buried in a cemetery across from the courthouse.

title: WEST SIDE SCHOOL PREPARES $4.5 MILLION EXPANSION
description: After 20 years of frustrated efforts to expand on Manhattan's Upper West Side, Columbia Grammar and Preparatory School has begun a $4.5 million project to erect a new building and renovate its present accommodations.

title: Goetz Checked,Then FiredAnother Round
description: A week after Bernhard H. Goetz shot four young men on a subway train two months ago, he described the experience to police officers in New Hampshire, where he had surrendered. According to their reports, Mr. Goetz said he calmly drew a pistol from his belt and shot at each of the four teen-agers. When he discovered moments later that the fourth man was not bleeding, he said, ''You don't look too bad. Here's another one.'' He then shot at him again.

title: HOW TO BATHE RECORDS AND SOLVE OTHER PROBLEMS
description: I'm just catching up with the mail. Actually, that's

title: WILL THE KOREA FUND BLOSSOM?
description: Shares of the Korea Fund, a closed-end

title: 'Horn Hunting'In Yellowstone
description: The ranchers and loggers of Montana have a tradition of adding to their incomes by ''horn hunting,'' or the illegal collection of fallen elk antlers in the Yellowstone Park area. More generously defined, it can mean hunting down an occasional elk or deer out of season for family dinner.

title: RANSEY OVERCOMES PRESSURE, HARDSHIP
description: Even now, when he's alone and trying to cope with the unusual pressures of playing basketball for a living, Kelvin Ransey turns to his father for inspiration.

title: KOCH'S TROUBLES WITH THE PRESS
description: To some, Mayor Koch's recent charge that three newspaper columnists wrote ''racist'' articles must have come as something of a surprise. But to those more familiar with the Mayor's behavior, the attack late last month was surprising not in kind, but in degree.

title: CUOMO CREDITS LAW FOR DIP IN DEATH TOLL
description: Governor Cuomo said that highway fatalities had decreased last December and January in New York State and that he thought the state's new seat-belt law was the reason.

title: Barbara S. Griffin To Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Quigley Griffin of Hopewell, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Barbara Sargent Griffin to Christopher Alfred Cole, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Cole of Guilford, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title:
PROSPECTS;

On the Job Front
description: As 1985 unfolds, the ranks of the unemployed should thin, partly because the economy is still improving and partly because the nation's labor force is not growing as fast as the number of jobs, according to M.D. Levy, chief economist of the Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia.

title: IT'S A LONG WAY TO SAO PAULO
description: For a group of players in Montreal two innovations will surface today. They are competing in play-offs to determine which of three teams will compete in the world team championships in Sao Paulo, Brazil, in October.

title: CAMPUS MINORITY HIRING LAGS
description: THE State Universities at Stony Brook and Farmingdale are lagging in recruiting minority faculty members, but the Old Westbury campus reports a minority faculty representation of over 45 percent.

title: The Rugged Stability Of Suede
description: LEATHER HAS BEEN softened into clothing since men first dressed themselves. Today, light- weight suede, made from lamb, goat, pig, hairsheep or calf, is a particularly popular material for men's wear. Durable enough to be used for upholstery, it ''breathes'' naturally, making it cool in summer and warm in winter. It conjures up a rugged, handsome image. It is also expensive.

title: FLORIDA DERBY TO PROUD TRUTH
description: Chief's Crown and Proud Truth have emerged as the clear early favorites for the Kentucky Derby, and in that order, although the respective purses they won in separate races at Gulfstream Park today do not reflect that ranking.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Bulls, at Chicago. Although Michael Jordan has averaged 26.7 points against them, the Nets have come away with two victories in the three meetings with Chicago this season. (Television - Sports Channel, 1:30. Radio - WNBC 660, 1:30 P.M.)

title: Miss Green Plans Wedding in June
description: Eleanor Duff Green and Robert Allen Long Jr., who graduated with the class of '80 from the University of North Carolina, where they were both Morehead Scholars, plan to be married June 29.

title: TEAMING UP ON AID FOR BACK PAIN
description: INCAPACITATED by back pain - and frustrated by the lack of consistent answers to his basic questions - five years ago Arthur C. Klein began what was then an informal study of what ailed him. But he ''couldn't find any facts,'' he said, ''only tunnel research that seemed to prove what the particular sources wanted to prove: That is, if the research was done by chiropractors, it proved they were effective; by orthopedists, that they knew where they were at.''

title: New G.S.A. Administrator
description: Dwight Ink, who has served in various Government jobs under six Presidents, is to become acting head of the General Services Administration Monday, according to an announcement. Mr. Ink, 62 years old, is to take over from Raymond A. Kline, the current Acting Administrator, who is retiring. Mr. Ink comes to the agency from McManis Associates, a Washington management consulting concern, His most recent position in the Reagan Administration was as vice president for administration of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation.

title: Recent Sales

title: Headliners;   Justice in Nigeria
description: For more than a year, Marie Lee McBroom, a 59-year-old commodities dealer from Jersey City, sat in a Nigerian prison, suffering from malaria and haunted by the vision of a firing squad. But last week, she was safe in her daughter's Manhattan apartment, only a day after a Nigerian court found her not guilty of illegal oil dealing.

description: OPERATION AVALANCHE: The Salerno Landings, 1943. By Des Hickey and Gus Smith. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.)

title: Car Quotas
description: To the Editor:

title: Miners' StrikeFades in Britain
description: For almost a year, Britain's powerful National Union of Miners has been striking to stymie a Government plan to close coal mines that are no longer economical. Time and economic hardship have eroded the miners' often violent militancy and last week more than half of the union's 186,000 members were reported back at work.

title: BODY MAXIMUM
description: For the millions of women who are dedicated to the pursuit of fitness, a trim well-toned body is a sought-after goal; for a professional model, it is serious business. Models may appear naturally flawless, but their seeming perfection is at least partly the result of discipline.

title: TAX POLICY: IN SEARCH OF SIMPLICITY
description: QUESTION: Many critics of this plan say it would not be good for the economy - that you haven't taken a close enough look at the overall economic impact. How do you respond to that?

title: HIS CARNAL ITCH
description: EXPERIMENT IN AUTOBIOGRAPHY

title: BAROQUE MASTERS TURNING 300
description: THE year was 1685. In Westchester, which by act of the New York General Assembly had officially become a county two years earlier, life was proceeding at a somewhat normal pace. Frederick Philipse continued to buy up large tracts of land in the Yonkers area. Construction of the Old Dutch Church in North Tarrytown was completed. And the area now known as Peekskill was deeded by local Indians to Jacobus Dekay and other settlers.

title: Stock Trades
description: To the Editor:

title: NAZIS WHO ARE ALIVE AND WELL MAY FINALLY BE LIVING IN FEAR
description: Over the years, he has been reported in a lot of places, including Paraguay, Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Bolivia, Peru, West Germany, Austria, Portugal, Miami and even Mount Kisco, N.Y. As the 40th anniversary of V-E day nears, Josef Mengele, the notorious Auschwitz death camp doctor, is presumably alive at the age of 73, and, with a $1.4 million price on his head, is the center of a growing international clamor that erupted anew in Congress last week.

title: POP: KIP HANRAHAN
description: Kip Hanrahan aims for one of the most ambitious musical fusions of the 1980's - synthesizing rock, Latin dance rhythms, Brazilian pop, jazz and improvisation along with lyrics that are both confessional and surreal.

title: BASEBALL'S NEWEST MILLIONAIRES
description: Here are the baseball contracts signed during the offseason that have a guaranteed annual average of $1 million or more. Figures, in order, are annual average of contract, contract years and total; where there is another figure in parentheses, it is the total including non-guaranteed years. Contract details from various management and player sources.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: The 40th anniversaries of many of the events of World War II have been marked by books recently. Herewith a representative sample.

title: Libeling History
description: Harboring anti-Semitic thoughts and a false view of history is one thing. Putting them into print is quite another, a Canadian jury decided last week.

title: SCIENTISTS FACE THE 12-METER CHALLENGE
description: Efforts to design a new 12-Meter yacht that can beat the Australians in the next America's Cup Races has led to widespread involvement by leading scientists in the United States. Many consider it a crucial test of American technology.

title: Sidney Studt Symington, Film Maker, To Wed Nancy Jaye Rothman in June
description: Nancy Jaye Rothman and Sidney Studt Symington plan to be married in June, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Rothman of Providence, R.I., have announced.

title: JERSEY COURT REFUSES TO EXTEND LIABILITY OF HOSTS
description: Hosts of social events who serve liquor are not liable for the negligent acts of intoxicated guests that have nothing to do with driving, a New Jersey appeals court has ruled.

title: THE ART OF DRESSING
description: John Russell is the chief art critic for The New York Times. During my initiation to life in this country I had trouble telling Bill Blass, the couturier and chocolatier, from Phil Glass, the composer of ''Einstein on the Beach.'' A more effective recipe for conversational gridlock has yet to be devised.

title: A Wedding in July For Miss Dorsher
description: -backed securities department of Drexel Burnham Lambert in New York, and Sven Austin Wehrwein, a vice president of the brokerage firm, plan to be married in July, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Dorsher of Glenview, Ill., have announced.

title: COMPANY TRIES 'DIFFICULT' PLAY
description: ''IT'S a comedy on the outside, but it's screaming inside.'' That is how David Rosenberg, the director, summed up Peter Nichols's ''Passion,'' the third play in the Westport Community Theater's 29th season. The final performance in the two-weekend run will take place tonight at 7:30.

title: NEW CASSETTES: VINTAGE COMEDY TO BOLSHOI OPERA
description: Eugene Onegin Directed by Roman Tikhomirov Corinth Video 106 minutes. $69.95

title:
COMPETITION FOR INTELSAT?;

NEW ENTRANTS WOULD LOWER PRICES
description: PRESIDENT Reagan determined last November that the national interest would best be served by allowing privately owned United States satellite systems into international communications. For Intelsat, the non-profit communications cooperative that has provided the bulk of international communications for the last two decades, as well as the users of international communications, President Reagan's action and the likely emergence of private satellite systems signal the start of a promising era of greater competition and technological progress.

title: RULING ON DEVELOPMENT OF HOSPITAL LAND IS ASSESSED
description: A JUDGE'S ruling that White Plains does not have to consider a proposal to develop 180 acres of New York Hospital land has left the proposals' opponents ''greatly relieved.'' But one of the development partners said last week that he was ''not going to go away.''

title: FAMILY LIFE-A SUCCESS STORY
description: THE state policy requiring Family Life education programs in all public-school districts comes up for reauthorization before the State Board of Education on Wednesday.

title: BREAKING UP GOVERNMENT'S MONOPOLY ON PRISON CELLS
description: WASHINGTON PRISON is a growth industry. The number of Americans behind bars has doubled to 663,000 in the past decade, and experts predict more than $7 billion will be spent on new facilities in the coming one. Sensing a market, private companies have begun to play a larger role in what has generally been a public function since the 19th century, when some states shipped convicts to entrepreneurs who used them as slaves on plantations and in factories. There are now about two dozen major correctional facilities under private ownership or operation. The newest, a 175-bed detention center for illegal aliens operated by the Corrections Corporation of America for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, is to open next week in Laredo, Tex. The company also runs a 350-bed alien detention center in Houston, a 30-bed facility for the Federal Bureau of Prisons in Fayetteville, N.C., and a 325-bed jail in Chattanooga, Tenn., whose inmates range from murderers to drunken drivers. Two brothers, Charles and Joseph Fenton, are building a $20 million, 715-cell maximum security penitentiary north of Pittsburgh. Last week, Martin Tolchin, a reporter in the Washington Bureau of The New York Times, asked two experts - James K. Stewart, director of the National Institute of Justice, the research arm of the Justice Department, and Mark A. Cunniff, executive director of the National Association of Criminal Justice Planners, which represents officials in 75 major urban areas - to discuss private prisons and their implications.

title: LILCO WEIGHING STRATEGY ON EVACUATION
description: THE court judgment that the emergency evacuation plan crafted by the Long Island Lighting Company is illegal came as particularly galling news to the utility executives struggling to find ways to open the bedeviled Shoreham nuclear plant.

title: MUSIC
description: There are three important new music concerts taking place this week, all deserving of attention. However, there's one small catch - all three are scheduled to occur simultaneously on Saturday night at 8 P.M.

title: ORATORIO: 'THEODORA,' BY HANDEL
description: Theodora'' is one of Handel's last dramatic oratorios, and his only on a Christian subject. The heroine, a Christian woman, is condemned by the Roman president of Antioch to slavery as a temple prostitute; Didimus, a Roman officer converted by Theodora, helps her escape at the cost of his own freedom. She surrenders herself anew, hoping to exchange her life for his, but ''not so our laws are to be trifled with,'' declares the tyrant Valens, and both lovers perish.

title: WHAT CAN BE DONE ABOUT CRIME
description: Roger Starr's article is an excellent starting point for a serious discussion of crime prevention. If an agenda for solving lawless behavior is to be structured, it is crucial to impress upon the judiciary that the enforcement of probation terms is serious business.

title: Child Guardianship And Bureaucracy
description: I would like to respond to the article by David Hechler, ''Debate Over Bill to Create a Law-Guardian Agency'' (Feb. 3).

title: DETROIT'S DESIGNS FOR THE FUTURE
description: This is a city with a form of high- stakes gambling that matches just about anything Las Vegas or Atlantic City can offer - the bets the nation's automobile manufacturers must make on what their customers will buy years down the road.

title: CUOMO'S ECONOMIC PLAN SPUTTERS
description: When Governor Cuomo created the post of Director of Economic Development last November, it was trumpeted as the most visible sign of the administration's midterm realignment, a reordering that would set the tone for the coming two years. For the first time, some two dozen state agencies, public authorities and departments involved in development projects would report to a single state official, an economic development ''czar,'' as it came to be called in Albany.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THE lives of 40 ''foremothers'' of Jersey City State College students will be the focus of the Women's History Week celebration of the Bergen County Commission on the Status of Women.

title: James E. Tannenbaum To Marry Ellen Silver
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Bernard N. Silver of Hazlet, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Tracy Silver, to James Edward Tannenbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael D. Tannenbaum of East Rockaway, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

description: Serious Talk in Cincinnati

title: VCR'S BRING BIG CHANGES IN USE OF LEISURE
description: Until they bought a video cassette recorder a year ago, Gretchen and Gregg Lyle of Los Angeles went to the movies two or three times a month. Now, Mrs. Lyle says, they hardly ever go. Instead, they rent at least one movie each weekend and watch it at home.

title: SCRAMBLE TO SURVIVE
description: -South Negotiations. Edited by Jagdish N. Bhagwati and John Gerard Ruggie. 338 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. Cloth, $30. Paper, $12.50.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: DRESDEN 1945: The Devil's Tinderbox. By Alexander McKee. (Dutton, $18.95.)

title: MATCH OF GIRLS' DENTAL RECORDS DISPUTED
description: HER tombstone is anchored to the ground with steel rods to prevent its theft, and although two years have passed since she was buried not far from where her body was found, she still evokes strong emotions.

title: SAFEGUARDS Sparing the Child The ban on corporal punishment recently voted by New York's Board of Regents is as enlightened an educational reform as any in recent years. Striking schoolchildren who misbehave is an outmoded form of discipline. That was acknowledged privately by a majority of the board, but it was reluctant to act because an official ban seemed to conflict with the state penal code. It includes an exemption from criminal assault charges for teachers who use corporal punishment to discipline their students.
description: Nonetheless, 137 of the state's 750 school systems, including New York City, outlawed corporal punishment. Now, bolstered by a legal green light from the State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, and by local boards concerned about child abuse, the Regents have finally prohibited it statewide.

title: Helen Bartlett to Wed Anthony Hass
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Leffingwell Bartlett of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen Buck Bartlett, to Anthony Cecil Hass, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Hass of Washington and New York. The wedding is planned for June 22.

title: G.O.P. Group Elects Leader
description: Fernando de Baca, White House assistant to Presidents Nixon and Ford from 1974 to 1976, has been elected chairman of the Republican National Hispanic Assembly at the group's convention here. Mr. de Baca, 45 years old, a native of Albuquerque, N.M., is a business executive in Washington. Although only 30 percent of the 4.5 million registered Hispanic voters are Republicans, Mr. de Baca said, ''The Hispanic pendulum is swinging strongly toward the Republican Party.''

title: OVERLOOKED DEDUCTIONS MAY MEAN OVERPAID TAXES
description: THIS year, as in the past, Americans will give Uncle Sam a windfall - they will overpay their taxes. Experts say many people often pay considerably more than necessay, simply because they overlook important deductions.

title: On the Wrong Track
description: SNOWBOUND IN THE Washington unreality zone not long ago, I turned on the television for news of open escape routes only to find myself being stared at by several media heavyweights. One was saying, ''America feels good about itself again,'' and the others must have noticed that I'd lifted an eyebrow the way I do when I am thinking ''Oh, bosh, rot, nonsense and so what!'' because they all glared at me, very testylike, you know.

description: ROBERT LINDSEY is the Los Angeles bureau chief of The New York Times.

The Palace, which charges $80 for a double room, is one of the city's luxury hotels; the other hotels cited in the chart were primarily in the moderately expensive category.

description: Paper-thin gold feathers, spirals, serpents and twigs fashioned into crowns, earrings, necklaces and bracelets dazzle the eye and puzzle the mind viewing ''Power and Gold: Jewelry From Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines,'' at Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue (at 70th Street), through April 28.

title: 20 HELD IN 7 STATES IN SWEEP OF NAZIS ARMING FOR 'WAR' ON U.S.
description: Federal agents investigating an armed neo- Nazi group that the authorities say stole more than $4 million to finance a ''war'' against the United States have arrested more than 20 people in seven states. But the agents have recovered little of the money and are still gathering evidence on other suspects.

title: ;   A Salute To Immigrants
description: Both articles dealing with immigrants on the Feb. 3 Opinion Page allowed me the opportunity of reminiscing about my struggling, yet challenging, days in 1961 as a recently arrived non-English-speaking immigrant. In reading the articles entitled ''New Americans: Making the Most of Opportunity'' and ''New Americans: Not So Different,'' my thoughts turned to February 1970, when I first started teaching in Flushing, Queens, the community mentioned in the article.

title: TAX-EXEMPT INVESTMENTS: THE EMPHASIS IS ON SAFETY
description: SOMETIMES lost amid the attention paid to more exotic and more aggressive devices - moviemaking, say, or boxcar leasing - are traditional investments that rank high in their ability to minimize one's taxes. These vehicles offer major tax advan- tages as well as values grounded, for the most part, in legitimate economic activities.

description: year-old office boy at the former Harborside Terminal on the Hudson River waterfront here, Michael W. Sonnenfeldt used to eat lunch on the south pier and watch the ships go by.

description: When former President Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, arrived at 742 East Sixth Street on the Lower East Side five months ago, they attracted a horde of reporters eager to capture them renovating an abandoned tenement for the neighborhood's poor.

description: Announcement has been made by Judge and Mrs. Richard L. Nahley of Danbury, Conn., and South Londonderry, Vt., of the engagement of their daughter Susan Campbell Nahley to Patrick Martin Reilly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Reilly of Shorewood, Wis. The wedding is to be in June.

title: SONDHEIM HONORED IN BRIDGEPORT
description: THE Mertens Contemporary Composers Festival started in 1970 at the University of Bridgeport with the purpose of honoring American composers and introducing them and their work to the university community. Such giants of American music as Virgil Thomson, Aaron Copland and Howard Hanson have been thus saluted over the years, and now it is the turn of a genius of the musical theater, Stephen Sondheim.

title: HOSPITAL COPTER SERVICE IS SET
description: STATE agencies have approved the first two aeromedical services in Connecticut. Hartford Hospital plans to start its emergency helicopter service by June while Flight Unlimited, a private charter company based in Stratford, is to start its medical transportation business immediately.

title: Stacey Gold Engaged To Marry in Summer
description: The engagement of Stacey Gold and Isidore Mayrock, graduates of Boston University, has been announced by the future bride's mother, Ruth B. Gold of Scarsdale, N.Y., and East Hampton, L.I. Her fiance is a son of Harry Mayrock of Old Westbury, L.I., and the late Marjorie Fortunoff Mayrock. A summer wedding is planned.

title: GOOD ITALIAN AT A REASONABLE PRICE
description: FOR those who have given up on finding a Fairfield County restaurant featuring home cooking at prices that make it possible for an entire family to dine out, there is hope. Anacapri more than fulfills both requirements.

title: DISPUTES SURROUND PROGRAMS FOR HOMELESS
description: THE Rev. John P. Gould is, by calling, a peaceful man. However, last week he predicted that should he have to go to court to defend his church's right to shelter the homeless, ''then we're going to have World War III right here in Yonkers.''

title: Arctic Panel Gets Chairman
description: President Reagan has announced the appointment of James H. Zumberge, president of the University of Southern California, as chairman of a Federal Arctic Research Commission. Mr. Zumberge of San Marino, Calif., will serve a four-year term on the newly created panel, which is charged with developing an integrated national Arctic research policy for Government agencies.

title: CONCERT: CLEO LAINE
description: Two musicians who thoroughly exemplify the British idea of jazz as a genteel art form closely related to classical music are the husband and wife team of Cleo Laine and John Dankworth. Miss Laine, whose magnificent smoky alto can be comfortably stretched all the way from a rich baritone to a clear, high coloratura, has a voice that almost demands to be exploited for its agility in blending operatic and jazz techniques.

title: Screen and TV Writers Plan to Strike Tuesday
description: Motion picture and television script writers on the West Coast have rejected a contract proposed by producers and will strike Tuesday, the Writers Guild of America said today.

title: LOOKING GOOD
description: John Duka, formerly a style reporter for The Times, is now a freelance writer and media consultant. This was going to be a story about Kimberley DuRoss, the beautiful stepdaughter of Henry Ford 2d. It was going to be about someone who represents a specific, current style, a grown-up debutante who has an international tan and a closet full of furs and ball gowns, and who knows young men with names like Tassilo von Holeinone.

title: FORDHAM AND IONA WIN AND GAIN FINAL
description: The pregame instructions in the St. Peter's dressing room today read: ''Deny McIntosh and Samuels the ball.''

description: THERE IS SACEUR?'' demands a voice from the command post. All hell is breaking loose in the Balkans, the Persian Gulf is ablaze with burning tankers, and the Supreme Allied Commander Europe - Saceur - is AWOL. He turns up, breathless, 10 minutes late, explaining that his pregnant wife had a false alarm.

description: TRENTON WHEN he announced his candidacy for Governor here last month, Robert J. Del Tufo formally began a quest that actually started nearly a year earlier, when he resigned from the State Commission of Investigation.

title: LINGERIE IN LITERATURE
description: John Gross is a book critic for The New York Times. The greatest provocations of lust,'' wrote the author of ''The Anatomy of Melancholy,'' Robert Burton, in the 17th century, ''are from our apparel.'' Nowhere is this more liable to be the case, the evidence suggests, than when a garment carries a double charge, when it is meant to conceal and to be concealed at the same time. And though writers may, of course, turn their attention to lingerie for other reasons - in the interest of comic effect, for example, or of blunt realism - the overwhelming odds, if they choose to do so, are that it will be in an erotic context.

title: NEW PEACE EFFORT BY LATIN NATIONS BACKED BY SHULTZ
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua met for an hour here today and appeared to clear the way for a resumption of the Central American peace efforts of the Contadora group.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SOME SURVIVED. By Manny Lawton. (Algonquin Books, $16.95.)

title: Predicting The Weather
description: You are absolutely right (''They're Getting Better at Predicting the Weather - Even If You Don't Believe It!'' by James Gleick, Jan. 27).

title: Student's Views Held Unrealistic
description: In his Feb. 10 Opinion Page article, Paul Gallagher, a student at Brown University, finds all sorts of illegalities, affronts and violations of moral behavior in the recent Supreme Court decision permitting school officials, under certain circumstances, to search students or their lockers.

title: Chocolate Factory Burns
description: Fire raced through the Van Duyn chocolate factory and warehouse today, destroying hundreds of pounds of candy and thousands of Easter baskets, fire officials said. Easter baskets floated from warehouse doorways as 75 firefighters poured tons of water on the fire. A Fire Bureau spokesman said the the flames had a ''kind of white color,'' apparently from burning chocolate.

title: A BETTER GAME HEIGHTENS PRESSURE ON OFFICIALS
description: It was late one night last week when a

title: Housing for Families: Pros and Cons
description: Those of us concerned with the plight of children in our society appreciated the fine article on Feb. 3 by Sandra Gardner, ''Housing Hard to Find for Those With Children.''

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: BIOGRAPHIA LITERARIA: Or Biographical Sketches of My Literary Life and Opinions, by Samuel Taylor Coleridge, edited by James Engell and W. Jackson Bate. (Princeton University, $19.95.) Coleridge began writing ''Biographia Literaria'' as a preface to a collection of his poems. With the scholarly apparatus of the Bollingen Series ''Collected Works of Samuel Taylor Coleridge,'' this edition of the 1817 classic of philosophy and literary criticism runs to more than 400 pages. D. J. R. Bruckner observed here in 1983 that there is ''no critical method that it does not speak to in some way, from linguistic analysis to psychological interpretation'' but warned, ''It is not an easy book.''

title: Fairer to Tax Sale of All Fuels, Not Just Oil
description: To the Editor:

description: IT WAS the state's Department of

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MINDBEND. By Robin Cook. (Putnam, $15.95.)

title: Gromyko TrainsFor Arms Talks
description: As though warming up for the arms-control talks that the United States and the Soviet Union will resume in Geneva March 12, Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko spent last week telling Italians and Spaniards how they ought to share Moscow's dislike for the Reagan Administration's Strategic Defense Initiative. Although the proposal is only in the research stage, Moscow, whose space technology is lagging, has indicated that the so- called ''Star Wars'' will be its principal target in Geneva.

title: Nicaragua, Soap and Froth
description: The United States' quarrel with Nicaragua is acquiring the day-to-day suspense of a television soap, ''Uncle Knows Best.'' Uncle is rich, powerful and short-tempered. His scapegrace nephew, Nick, recklessly rejects Uncle's values and seeks the protection of a bad crowd, the Red Beards. They arm him with switchblades and he says he won't change his ways or friends until Uncle leaves him alone.

title:
GARDENING;

AVOIDING MONOTONY IN PLANTINGS
description: THE overuse of a relatively small number of tree species has led to an unnecessary monotony in our park, garden and avenue plantings. In addition, several of those species commonly used exhibit either undesirable characteristics or are subject to devastation by insect pests or diseases.

title: FINDING THE FLAW IN THE FOOTNOTES
description: It may be laudable and necessary

ART;

VINTAGE POP ART AT PRINCETON
description: PRINCETON

title: Virginia Keitt Marries
description: Virginia Ellen Keitt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John K. Keitt of Naples, Fla., was married there yesterday to Michael Whitney Dudley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Dudley of Naples and Sharon, Vt. The Rev. Gordon H. Mann, assisted by the Rev. Samuel C. Walker, performed the ceremony at Trinity-by-the-Cove Episcopal Church.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MAGICIAN. By Raymond E. Feist. (Doubleday, paper, $8.95.)

title: Nina Stillman to Wed David Mandel in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Stillman of Merrick, L.I., and Becket, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Nina Lynn Stillman, to David Scott Mandel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fredric H. Mandel of Glencoe, Ill. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Three Dramas of Emotional Conflict
description: The first Broadway production of Arthur Schnitzler's ''Affairs of Anatol,'' starring the young, gifted and doomed John Barrymore, opened Oct. 14, 1912 to reasonably favorable notices. The unsigned review in The New York Times reported that it ''sends one from the theater in a pleasant state of mind,'' which was surely not the dramatist's primary intention. The following Sunday, the Times critic mildly took note of a few reader demands that he denounce this Viennese frolic through one man's ''amatory'' adventures; although he agreed that some theatergoers might consider the play unsuitable for the young, he still thought it good fun for anyone mature enough to resist corruption.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

THE DATE MADE A DIFFERENCE FOR THE LINCOLN CENT
description: Thousands of coin collectors are observing their silver anniversary in the hobby. They are among the bumper crop that got their introduction through the ''small-date'' Lincoln cents of 1960. These coins were the single biggest factor in the hobby's dramatic growth during that period.

title: SAVING FACADES
description: When it comes to interior maintenance, the owners of most cooperative buildings know their stuff. But according to local preservationists, exterior maintence is another matter.

title: One Casino Wins,Another Loses
description: Resorts International had all its chips riding on one number last week when the New Jersey Casino Control Commission met to decide whether or not to renew the company's Atlantic City license. That number was three, the number of votes Resorts needed to avoid losing its authority to operate its casino. The company won, but barely, and only with new restrictions on its corporate structure.

title: BODY MINIMAL
description: Wendy Wasserstein is a playwright and the author of the Off Broadway comedy ''Isn't It Romantic?'' This is written for Raquel, Morgan, Jane, Joan, Linda and Victoria. I want to thank them for helping me enter 30, approach 40 and commit to a healthier, more vital 50. Without their guidance, concern and inspiration, I would never have realized that I've devoted my life to a unique and easy-to-follow diet and exercise plan: The Body Minimal.

title: REAGAN ASSAILS BUDGET'S CRITICS IN BROAD ATTACK
description: President Reagan, urging Congress to muster the ''political courage'' to approve his budget, delivered a sweeping attack today on Democrats, farm state legislators, business executives, educators and mayors critical of the Administration's assault on domestic spending.

title: THE NAZI WHO MADE A COMEBACK
description: ALBERT SPEER The End of a Myth. By Matthias Schmidt. Translated by Joachim Neugroschel. Illustrated. 276 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $14.95.

description: Residential Energy Credit

description: DANGEROUS OFFENDERS The Elusive Target of Justice. By Mark H. Moore, Susan R. Estrich, Daniel McGillis and William Spelman. 252 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $20.

description: Labels matter in zoning. If a land-planning concept requires something called

title: ISRAEL FORCE RAIDS LEBANESE VILLAGE
description: Israel was reported today to have mounted the largest operation in its week-and- a-half-old crackdown in southern Lebanon, moving in force into a Shiite Moslem stronghold.

title: CANADA'S NUCLEAR MOTHERLODE
description: KEY LAKE, Saskatchewan

title: FITTING HOUSING INTO TIGHT URBAN SPACES
description: Over the last decade, new housing in most New Jersey cities has been limited to high-rise apartment buildings because there simply is not enough land available to build sufficient numbers of affordable one- and two-family houses.

title: Pitt 85, Villanova 62
description: Charles Smith scored 18 points, 14 of them in the first half, as Pittsburgh handed Villanova its worst loss ever in Big East play.

title: ART: MODERNISM IN YONKERS SHOW
description: They say an optimist is one who is not in possession of all the facts. This is obviously not the case with Mary Delahoyd, who teaches art history at Sarah Lawrence College and who, to judge from the exhibition she has mounted for the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, knows her Modernism inside out.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY NOW TAXABLE
description: ONE of the most misunderstood changes in the 1984 tax law is the provision that taxes some Social Security benefits. Although the provision is aimed primarily at the wealthy aged, it can easily affect retired people who continue to work, those on more than one pension and those who intend to live off investments, even if they are tax-exempt.

title: TOPPLE THE SANDINISTAS
description: Shedding the pretense that United States aid to the Nicaraguan rebels could aim at any goal other than the overthrow of the Sandinista Government, President Reagan has significantly strengthened the case for aid. He has also helped us focus on the heart of the matter: should the United States encourage the overthrow of Communist governments where we can? To me, both the history of our relations with the Soviet Union and the particular circumstances in Central America argue strongly that we should.

title: RADICALIZING IMPRESSIONISM
description: THE PAINTING OF MODERN LIFE

title: THE PRICE OF QUALITY
description: Price and that most elusive characteristic of wardrobe- building, value, have always been important to women, but rarely more so than they are now. Specifically, this attitude translates into an avoidance of ephemeral styles and an embrace of quality over quantity; it means an increasing number of women are scouting for sales, frequenting discount stores and simply buying fewer - but longer-lasting - clothes.

title: REAGAN'S NEW DOLLAR STRATEGY
description: WASHINGTON THE week of the dollar is over.

title: Nuclear-War Article Called 'Influential'
description: The Jan. 6 Opinion Page article ''Thinking About the Unthinkable,'' by Robert N. Johnson, a professor of psychology at Ramapo State College in Mahwah, was informative and influential. Figuratively speaking, it gave me a shove toward the realities of nuclear war.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: SUNDAY, MARCH 3, 1985 International

title: WETLANDS COMPROMISE: VAGUE AREAS
description: TRENTON AN UNEASY compromise was struck last week between environmental and building interests over a long-debated measure to protect 200,000 acres of the state's unregulated freshwater wetlands.

title: A 'RIBBON' FOR PEACE UNFURLED ON L.I.
description: ''IT'S the right idea at the right time,'' Sandy Chapin said at the C. W. Post Center the other day as she supervised the installation of ''The Ribbon,'' a series of handcrafted panels on the theme ''Celebration of Life - What I Cannot Bear to Think of As Lost Forever in a Nuclear War.''

title: TAORMINA'S STOP FOR SYBARITES
description: MARY SIMONS, a frequent visitor to Sicily who lived in Italy for six years, is an associate editor of Life magazine.

title: GOVERNORS CAUTIOUS IN ENDORSING THE PRIVATE OPERATION OF PRISONS
description: The nation's governors have cautiously endorsed the private operation of prisons and other correction facilities.

title: 'FREDERICK' REIGNS
description: ROMULUS LINNEY'S first play, ''The Sorrows of Frederick,'' traveled a tenuous, rocky road from its world premiere in Los Angeles in 1967 to Off Broadway, where it wound up in 1976 after side trips to Canada, West Germany, Austria and England.

title: TWO WEST COAST COMPOSERS COME EAST
description: Continuum, one of our best and boldest new-music groups, is offering what looks in advance to be one of the season's most stimulating programs Saturday evening in Alice Tully Hall. Largely underwritten by California's principal private patron of new music, Betty Freeman, the concert will pair the two best-known senior citizens of what is sometimes called the ''California School,'' Lou Harrison and Robert Erickson.

title: Sue Lowe Is a Bride
description: The marriage of Sue L. Lowe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Robert Lowe of Syracuse, to Mark D. Betts, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter James Betts of Williamsport, Pa., took place yesterday at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church in New York. The Rev. William H. Lazareth performed the ceremony. The bride is a copy editor for Data Communications, a McGraw-Hill trade journal. Mr. Betts is a technician with Power Station, a music recording station in New York.

title: AMERICAN MAINSTREAM STYLE
description: Twenty years ago, when the ready-to-wear industries of Europe were struggling to achieve acceptance as serious purveyors of style, American women were widely recognized as the best dressed in the world. They still are. They have available to them an extensive source of moderately priced, carefully-thought-out and expertly produced styles that can hold their own alongside the best-designed clothes anywhere in the world. The clothes fit well, require a minimum of alterations and are reasonably durable. Even more important, they look right, enabling a woman to feel her best.

title: AMERICAN SPRING STYLE
description: Top designers' clothes exhibit the latest fashion trends and are as modern as moving video images. Here and on following pages are examples, some shown on video screens.

title: Canadian Takes Downhill
description: Todd Brooker of Canada, given the advantage of an early start, broke the Swiss-Austrian grip on the World Cup series today with his first downhill victory of the season.

title: Drexel Captures Title In League Wrestling
description: George Kovack pinned Havien Armengua of Hofstra in 2 minutes 23 seconds of overtime today, giving Drexel the team title in the East Coast Conference wrestling championships at Hofstra.

title: Chernenko On View
description: Soviet television showed Konstantin U. Chernenko twice last week, in his first appearance in almost two months. The Soviet leader appeared unsteady, grim-faced and short of breath as he cast his ballot (at left) for the Supreme Soviet and again when he received parliamentary credientials on his victory.

title: Movies on Credit
description: It seemed to be a natural: the use of credit cards to buy movie tickets from a machine.

title: Suusan E. Cory, Architect, Wed To Peter Smith
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston yesterday Susan Elizabeth Cory, a daughter of Mrs. Robert Hanright of Singer Island, Fla., and Paul R. Cory of Saddle River, N.J., was married to Peter Whitall Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Smith of Meadowbrook, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frank Greer and the Rev. Joseph Holbrook, the bride's grandfather.

title: VISION OF SPACE DEFENSE POSING NEW CHALLENGES
description: President Reagan's vision of defensive systems to render nuclear weapons ''impotent and obsolete'' is moving strategic thinking and nuclear competition toward a new era.

title: COUPLES AND STRANGE IN TIE
description: Fred Couples and Curtis Strange held sole possession of first place two times each during the third round of the $500,000 Honda Classic today. But when their round on the Eagle Trace Tournament Players Club ended, they were back where they started today - tied for the lead.

title: Susan Nankin Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Nankin of Orange, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Hilary Nankin to Mark Allan Greenfield, a son of Ruth Greenfield of Scranton, Pa., and the late Myer B. Greenfield.

title: PINNING DOWN 'PUBLIC ACCEPTANCE'
description: Recently in this space I mentioned how desperately few non-operatic works composed since World War II have been able to gain wide public acceptance, in contrast to the first four decades of this century when music was in a remarkable period of creative efflorescence. To buttress the point, I made up a list of pieces that have either entered the standard repertory or made an impact on public consciousness in some other way, such as through recordings. Long before my list reached 50 works I found myself scratching for justifiable candidates and bending criteria almost to the breaking point. Perhaps I should not have been surprised, therefore, that in response to my request for ''additions and corrections'' the strongest response came from those who voted for subtractions. Works by Berio, Penderecki, Messiaen, Lutoslawski, Crumb, Carter, Bernstein and Stravinsky received the most protest votes.

title: BULLETS TOP KNICKS, BLUNTING LATE RALLY
description: As they have done so many times, the Knicks called upon Bernard King last night to deliver them. In an uncharacteristic display, he did not respond.

title: Soft-Bed Cures
description: To the Editor:

title: AUSTRIAN CAPTURES FIRST CUP VICTORY
description: An Austrian, Katrin Gutensohn, a silver medalist in the downhill at the recent World Championships, captured her first World Cup victory today in a downhill on Vail Mountain.

title: THE SPA LIFE IN FLORIDA
description: TIA SCHNEIDER DENENBERG, whose photographs appear frequently in the Travel Section, is a labor arbitrator. Her sister, Dr. JUDITH S. STERN, a professor of nutrition at the University of California at Davis, contributed to this article.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: STAYING HEALTHY OVERSEAS
description: With more and more Americans traveling to remote places, increasing attention is being paid to the importance of keeping them healthy overseas and providing them with high-quality care in emergencies.

title: Lange ProtestsU.S. PressureOn New Zealand
description: As New Zealand's Prime Minister David Lange sees it, he is David and the United States is, well, Goliath. ''The type of pressure which large powers can exert over the small ones is seen by the people in a small democracy as being somewhat akin to the very totalitarianism we are supposed to be fighting against,'' he contended last week.

title: ON PRIVATE TRANSGRESSIONS AND HOLDING THE PUBLIC TRUST
description: It was of no little significance that only one day elapsed last week between the disclosure that a high official of the Securities and Exchange Commission had periodically beaten his wife and his resignation.

title: Defendants GainThe Right toPsychiatric Aid
description: Although the Supreme Court has recently chipped away at some of its past decisions, at least one judicial monument still provides inspiration. In the landmark Gideon v. Wainwright decision of 1963, the Court required states to make lawyers available for defendants who could not afford them.

title: Thinking of Math And Motivation
description: Prof. Louis Rotando in his article ''Mathematical Illiteracy: What Can Be Done to Remedy the Situation'' (Jan. 27) points out that there are a host of reasons, besides low starting salaries and other monetary factors, that may account for the present state of mathematics education on all levels. If his many prescriptions are carried out, an improvement in the condition of math education will almost certainly take place.

title: BLOOD UNIT SERVES AS MEMORIAL
description: TWENTY years ago, when the children of Norma Jacobson and Betty Spiegel of Mamaroneck were diagnosed as having acute lymphocytic leukemia, there was little that could be done for them. Hematology, the study of the blood and the blood-forming organs, was a relatively new specialty, and chemotherapy, the treatment of the disease with toxic chemicals, was in its infancy. The children were treated at New York Hospital in Manhattan, and the families, who met in the hospital, were given figures on life expectancy, ranging from several months to two years.

title: L.I. ADDICTS AIDED WITH METHADONE AND A NEW ALTERNATIVE
description: young, old, rich, poor, white, black and Hispanic - share a problem so serious that it brings them together between one and seven times a week. They meet at Long Island methadone clinics to receive a synthetic opiate that has been commonly used to detoxify and then maintain those accustomed to heroin.

title: Poland BacksDown on Prices
description: The Polish Government last week appeared to be shaking hands with itself. Abandoning plans for sweeping increases in food prices, it gave credit for its retreat to protests by the Government-backed official unions, which President Wojciech Jaruzelski hopes will supplant Solidarity, the outlawed independent union movement.

title: MORE DRUNKEN DRIVERS MEET STIFF PENALTIES
description: MORE drunken drivers in Connecticut than ever before are being arrested, and repeated offenders are suffering harsher penalties.

title: UNDERWEAR ATTITUDES
description: The story is that Garbo, informed that a new film role required her to wear dull, tailored clothes, insisted on a spectacular wardrobe of pure silk underwear. The studio balked at the idea of wasting money on costumery that no one would see. After all, who would know what Garbo had on underneath? ''

title: ART
description: Jonathan Borofsky is one of the most representative artists of his 1960's generation. He is someone who accepts no traditional categories and frontiers.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: Start pepper and eggplant seed indoors. . . . Take cuttings of geraniums and begonias to root as summer bedding plants. . . . Start tuberous begonias and caladiums indoors to plant in tubs on the patio. . . . Continue pruning. . . . Apply dormant spray for scale and mite control.

title: DON'T BLAME THE 'SMALL-CAPS'
description: Investors assume that 1984 was a disastrous

title: On Whom the Rain Falls
description: To the Editor:

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;

LONDON TROVE FOR BARGAINS IN WOOL
description: ELAINE GOODMAN is a writer and lyricist.

title: MICHAELS PRAISES HIS OFFENSE
description: The New Jersey Generals were pleased at what they accomplished Friday night in trouncing the Renegades, 28-10, in Orlando, Fla. Coach Walt Michaels, because of his 30 years in pro football, knows that one victory or one defeat does not make a season. Yet, he was satisfied with what the Generals were able to accomplish in mixing the passing and extemporaneous running of Flutie with the planned and programmed running of the team's two big backs, Herschel Walker and Maurice Carthon.

title: Spy Trial in Norway
description: When Arne Treholt was a high-ranking official in Norway's Foreign Ministry, he had a reputation for determination. He brought that quality to bear last week in an Oslo courtroom, where he pleaded not guilty of spying for the Soviet Union. Mr. Treholt said he had been pressured into making false confessions and argued that he ''saw nothing wrong'' with giving a K.G.B. agent what he called unimportant classified files while he was at the United Nations several years ago.

title: HOW MUCH DEMOCRACY WILL ZIA ACCEPT?
description: It was easy for President Mohammed Zia ul-Haq's critics to dismiss last week's election in Pakistan. Hundreds of political figures had been arrested. Campaigning was hampered by a ban on political parties, processions, rallies and even loudspeakers. The Government did not even bother to specify the powers of the National Assembly being elected.

title: MANNA FROM HEAVEN
description: AVERY CORMAN is author of the novels, ''Oh, God!'' ''Kramer vs. Kramer'' and ''The Old Neighborhood.''

title: BACK TO CHINA
description: Nina Simonds is the author of ''Classic Chinese Cuisine'' (Houghton Mifflin, 1982) and the forthcoming ''Chinese Seasons.'' MANY FOOD PROFESsionals visiting China during the last 10 years have come away disappointed in what they went there to survey - the food. To be sure, they found hints in a dish or two of the exquisite refinement and delicacy that has characterized Chinese cooking for much of its 5,000- year history. But for the most part, it seemed evident that the food would never be as fine as it had been in prerevolutionary days, both Communist and Cultural.

title: DELAYS AHEAD AT PENN STATION
description: RIDERS of the Long Island Rail Road, long accustomed to standing during rush hours, unannounced delays and threats of strikes that force contingency planning, are headed for eight weeks of planned inconvenience, delays and changes in schedules.

title: Statistics About Women
description: To the Editor:

title: SUDDENLY, THE INTERNATIONAL DEBT CRISIS IS CLOSE TO HOME
description: It will happen without a clash of cymbals or a ringing of bells. Most Americans won't even be aware of any change in their daily lives, although their living standards may be affected in the future.

title: THE VINIFICATION OF THE NORTH COAST
description: FRANK J. PRIAL is the wine columnist for The New York Times.

title: THE POET IN ALL HIS SQUALOR
description: IN CUSTODY By Anita Desai. 204 pp. New York: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: PHONE CONCERN FORMS MIDWEST PHILANTHROPY
description: Ameritech, the parent company of five Bell telephone companies in the Middle West, has established a philanthropy ''to test new concepts in economic development, public policy and the use of comunications for the benefit of society.

title: HOUSING FOR FAMILIES: PROS AND CONS
description: The clothes drier in the laundry bears a rusty message, ''Alison was here,'' having been put there some seven years ago by the now elegant and responsible young woman who occasionally visits her parents in this building.

description: IN Huntington, in the heart of Mexican chain

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: CARIBOU By Meg Wolitzer. 167 pp. New York: Greenwillow. $10.25. (Ages 12 and up)

title: VERBATIM: LIVING WITH MOSCOW
description: 'We cannot wish (the Soviet Union) away. It is here and it is militarily powerful.

title: Yanks Sign Cowley, Rasmussen
description: The Yankees today signed the pitchers, Joe Cowley and Dennis Rasmussen, and the second baseman, Rex Hudler, leaving only Don Mattingly unsigned. Mattingly had stitches removed from his right knee today and announced he would triple his rehabilitation workouts. He underwent surgery for torn cartilage incurred while exercising at home.

title: Lucy Henke Wed To T.R. Donohue
description: Lucy Louise Henke, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Werner Henke of Lafayette, La., was married there yesterday to Thomas R. Donohue, a son of Mrs. Ray Anthony Donohue of Key West, Fla., and the late Mr. Donohue. The Rev. Stephen William performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension.

title: '84 TAX ACT BROUGHT NEW RULES TO THE GAME
description: Congress produced changes in income averaging, charitable contributions, employee benefits, interest free loans, and more.

title: Sally Solis-Cohen Engaged to Wed Peter Rabinowitz
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Leon Solis-Cohen Jr. of Rydal, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Sara Solis-Cohen, to Peter Andrew Rabinowitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Rabinowitz of New York. An August wedding is planned.

title: Linda Raftery, Nurse, Weds Dr. Philip Spiro
description: Linda Leighanne Raftery, a registered nurse at the Chowan County Hospital in Edenton, N.C., and Dr. Philip Marget Spiro, the physician-director of the Columbia (N.C.) Clinic, were married yesterday. The Rev. Donald Ostroth, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Alpine (N.J.) Community Center.

title: L.I.U., MARIST ADVANCE
description: Andre Ervin scored 29 points today to lead Long Island University to an 89- 68 victory over Wagner in the opening round of the East Coast Athletic Conference Metro Division tournament.

title: COMPUTERS CAN EASE PREPARATION
description: THERE is really only one reason to use a personal computer and specialized software to prepare a tax return and that is to ease an altogether burdensome chore. A personal computer cannot interpret tax law, nor can it supply records of deductible expenses that its owner neglected to keep. Most software programs can assist only with Federal, not state, taxes. But a personal computer can ease the task of preparing taxes to the extent that the taxpayers using it understand how the tax laws apply to their particular returns.

title: Coco Miller, an Executive, To Marry Ralph H. Marin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Miller of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nicole Alice Miller, to Ralph H. Marin, a son of Margaret Marin of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late Leo Marin. A June wedding is planned.

title: Safe Toys
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE STYLES OF SPRING
description: This could be called a season of S's. To begin, it is spring, and most of the silhouette shifts are small or subtle. The newest skirts are short. Some, even with suits, are cut like sarongs. The overwhelming majority of tops are shaped like shirts. Shoulders are spacious. Separates - those disparate tops and bottoms that are meant to be switched around - are more important than single-piece outfits. The sum of the parts is substantial. Shoes are the most interesting fashion accessory, particularly because they can alter the balance of proportions of the square- shouldered tops and slim skirts. The shape of the body is defined even in clothes that skim lightly over it. And the newest evening dresses are skintight and sexy, like swimsuits.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS March 3, 1985
description: Fiction*1

title: IN CHOOSING A SHELTER, SEEK ECONOMIC BENEFITS
description: UTTERING the words ''tax shelter'' is enough to make people run these days. First, the Internal Revenue Service began a crackdown on shelters that it considered abusive. Then, the Treasury Department proposed such sweeping tax changes that shelters would be largely eliminated.

title: UNUSUALLY POWERFUL HEROIN KILLS 6 IN WASHINGTON
description: Six people died and at least 15 were hospitalized between Friday and this morning, apparently after injecting themselves with unusually potent heroin sold on the streets here.

title: What the Bank ofBoston Knew
description: Since the onset of the Bank of Boston's legal difficulties, chairman William L. Brown has repeatedly insisted that his bank did not fully comply with Federal currency reporting regulations between 1980 and 1984 because it did not know about them.

title: OPERATION HALTS BLEEDING IN HEART PATIENT
description: Murray P. Haydon, the third person to receive an artificial heart, was taken back to surgery this evening for a one- and-a-half hour operation in which doctors identified a point in a remnant of his natural heart as the source of bleeding in his chest.

title: ;   Municipal Wastes: Likely Approaches
description: In all the outcry over the alleged insufficient capacity of the county's new garbage-burning plant in Peekskill, not much has been said about why so much garbage has to be disposed of there. Maybe we should redefine the problem. Which is the more efficient way to achieve a match between the size of the waste stream and the size of the waste-burning machine: to build a bigger machine, or to generate less waste? The latter approach deserves much more attention than it seems to be getting.

title: U.S. OVERTURNS BENEFITS PACT FOR NEW YORK LONGSHOREMEN
description: The Federal Maritime Commission has overturned the formula used to finance fringe benefits for longshoremen in the Port of New York, calling it ''unfair and unjustly discriminatory.''

title: Q. & A. WITH CITY'S QUEENS PLANNER
description: Since 1980, Peter Magnani, a veteran of 17 years in the Department of City Planning and the former director of planning for the Bronx, has been director of the department's Queens office. In a recent interview he discussed the borough and the Planning Department's preparations for rezoning.

title: CLUB TO COMPLEX
description: Until the mid-1970's dairy farms and fruit orchards dominated the landscape around Princeton, N.J. But since then the open spaces that surround the university town have been a magnet for developers of both commercial and residential projects.

title: REREADING AND OTHER EXCESSES
description: REREADING books is an antisocial habit. If I keep it up, I'm not going to be invited out anymore. It's a pity, because rereading books has become a sort of addiction. If a book is really good, it deserves to be read again, and if it's great, it should be read at least three times.

title: Aebli Leads by 2 Shots In Hong Kong Open
description: Mark Aebli, a club pro from Sebring, Fla., birdied the 18th hole today and gained a two-stroke lead over Greg Norman of Australia going into the final round of the Hong Kong Open golf tournament.

title: STOCKS HIT RECORD IN ONE-DAY RALLY
description: Stocks took off on Friday, ending what had started as a quiet week. The Dow Jones industrial average went as high as 1,306.76 before falling back in last-minute profit taking to close at a record 1,299.36, up 23.52 on the week. Traders apparently were excited about several developments, including a 1.7 percent surge in the index of leading economic indicators, the lifting of quotas on Japanese car imports and other signs that the economy is rolling ahead without new inflation.

title: I WISH I'D ASK HER
description: VISITS with my mother were often as much pain as pleasure, but a particular one is a delight to remember. It was when I went ''home'' for six weeks while my father was sick. The hours with my mother began to hang heavy, but she happened to mention some ancient relative I couldn't place, and I got pencil and paper.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER/AMONG OTHER THINGS, SAY CHEESE
description: HARTSDALE

title: STUDENT'S VIEWS HELD UNREALISTIC
description: What Mr. Gallagher fails to realize is that schoolchildren are not really citizens.

title: REDEFINING OFICE STYLE
description: Esther B. Fein is a reporter for The New York Times. There were 18 running suits, six cocktail dresses, an old blue blazer and a pleated tan skirt hanging in my closet on the day I graduated from college. It was May 1981, and while students across the country were popularizing the preppy look, I was showing the schleppy look. The formal wear was the anomaly in the closet, necessitated by several family weddings and bar mitzvahs; sweatsuits were the norm.

title: Quiroz-Olivo Bout Put Off MARACAIBO, Venezuela, March 2 (UPI) - The World Boxing Association junior-flyweight title fight between the champion, Francisco Quiroz, and Joey Olivo was postponed today by the Venezuelan boxing commissioner hours before the match was scheduled to begin.
description: Commissioner Alberto Sarmiento said the fight was suspended after the Venezuelan promoter, Rafito Cedeno, failed to deposit $65,000 before a Friday deadline. The W.B.A. had said earlier it would not sanction the fight before the money was deposited.

title: KANSANS WEIGHING DOLE IN NEW ROLE
description: Across the gently rising hills and rich bottomlands here in eastern Kansas, green fields of young wheat lay gleaming under a warming sun in scenes bright with the promise of rich harvests.

title: Data Bank;   March 3, 1985
Miss Delahunt and William McGraw, CBS Account Executives, to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Delahunt of Homewood, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Mary Delahunt to William Scott McGraw, a son of Virginia Snyder Parker of Weston, Mass., and James H. McGraw 3d of Short Hills, N.J. The wedding is planned for October.

title: FARMERS TURN UP THE HEAT ON THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET
description: -election, President Reagan has been enjoying if not a second honeymoon on Capitol Hill, at least a midwinter vacation. The holiday ended abruptly last week, when both the House and the Senate defied threats of a Presidential veto and passed legislation designed to help farmers finance their spring planting. In the Senate, eight members of the President's own party voted against him; in the House, 84 of the 182 Republicans defected.

title: BOUQUETS, AFFECTION FOR SENIOR REDMEN
description: It was a day for pomp and circumstance, for rolling out the red carpet and tossing bouquets. This was a day when the fans chanted for the guests of honor to return to the court for a curtain call like entertainers returning to the stage. And the one they cheered for the most was Chris Mullin, who has called the corridors and basketball court in Alumni Hall his home for four years.

description: AFTER preliminary oratorical flourishes in his State of the Union Message, President Reagan turned to the issues of the day, and the very first one he mentioned - before the deficit, before war and peace, before abortion and education and crime - was taxes.

title: Nancy Rickenbacker to Marry in June
description: Mrs. David E. Rickenbacker of Hartford, Vt., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Nancy Clark Rickenbacker, to Mark Schindler, the son of Donald Schindler of Montvale, N.J., and Scot Schindler of Sharon, Vt. A June wedding is planned.

description: schools, saying they wanted to restore a balance between sports and

title: THE ART OF GLAZING
description: ONE of the easiest ways to refinish an old piece of furniture, or to apply an attractive finish to an inexpensive piece of unfinished furniture, is to use a technique often referred to as ''antiquing,'' but also known, more accurately, as glazing. A glazed finish eliminates the need for stripping off the old finish first, and there is no need to fill in dents, scratches, gouge marks or other physical blemishes - in fact, these can add to the overall effect after the glazed finish has been applied.

title: RESORTS TO CHANGE ITS TOP COMMAND
description: LAWRENCEVILLE

title: A JOURNALISM MOVIE THAT RAISES TOUGH QUESTIONS
