title: RADICAL REVISION ENLIVENS A NEW MOZART REQUIEM
description: One of the pivotal dramatic conceits in Peter Shaffer's play ''Amadeus'' is Antonio Salieri's plot to murder Mozart and appropriate his Requiem. According to this version, now immortalized on film, Salieri commissioned the Requiem anonymously and planned to kill Mozart when the piece was finished. He would then have the Requiem performed as his own tribute to his late colleague - and posterity would remember him for at least that one masterwork.

title: THREE DRAMAS OF EMOTIONAL CONFLICT
description: Virginia Woolf was a multifarious creature - fluent, iconoclastic, vulnerable, savage, high-minded, low-minded, and intermittently insane. The youngest daughter of a dogmatic, Victorian father, Leslie Stephens, she lost her mother, her brother, and her half-sister while still young and these deaths made terrible breaches on her psyche. It was left to her and her sister, Vanessa, to weather the world on limited means. They began to invite a few people to Gordon Square in Bloomsbury on Thursday and from those tentative starts there emerged the label of ''Bloomsbury'' and all its association of intellectual and cultural sovereignty.

title: PENGUINS BEAT RANGERS BY 5-4
description: By the time they got to Pittsburgh, or by the time they were ready to play, the Rangers might as well have gone home.

title: CHAMBER MUSIC: THE RAPHAEL TRIO
description: There was a gracious evenness of manner and proportion in most of the Raphael Trio's playing on Wednesday night. The three pieces, performed in Carnegie Recital Hall, expressed the confidence of the three musicians, both in their material and in themselves.

title: TRYING TO AVOID AUDITS CAN BE A COSTLY EXERCISE
description: WHEN it comes to income tax audits, sometimes the unknowable can prompt taxpayers into the unthinkable. Overcautious taxpayers, fearing a summons from the Internal Revenue Service, may deliberately un- derestimate their deductions. That may - or may not - avoid an audit, but it will certainly result in higher tax payments.

title: On Language;   MEDIUM-RARE BOOK LINGO
description: O WHAT IS SO RARE as an afternoon spent browsing through an antiquarian bookstore, tenderly examining used books that have made themselves scarce?

title: PORT CHESTER CHURCH IN ZONING DISPUTE
description: PORT CHESTER THREE years ago, the Second Pentecostal Church John 3:16 in Port Chester began holding services in Spanish in a two- story wood-frame building that was once a drugstore.

title: AIDS BLOOD TEST TO BE AVAILABLE IN 2 TO 6 WEEKS
description: Federal health officials say that a blood test to screen for acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, licensed today for commercial production, will be widely available in the United States in two to six weeks.

description: Roger Starr's article, ''Crime: How It Destroys, What Can Be Done'' (Jan. 27), warrants the serious attention of all involved in the criminal justice field.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Times Magazine today on Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist misattributes a quotation concerning the appointments of Earl Warren and others to the Supreme Court. The quotation is from A. E. Dick Howard, a law professor at the University of Virginia.

description: A PROPOSAL to resolve the issue of county versus Federal control at the Westchester County Airport is expected to be considered tomorrow by the Board of Legislators.

ART;

A LOOK AT 'BUILT' SCULPTURES IN YONKERS
description: MARCIA HAFIF, a painter on the faculty of Sarah Lawrence College, has stepped out of her usual element to assemble an exhibition of ''built'' sculptures at the Sarah Lawrence Gallery in Yonkers. The revelation is that for all the hefty materials of construction the exhibition contains, it is on the whole a quiet and meditative experience.

title: JOHN B. KELLY JR., U.S. OLYMPIC CHIEF
description: John B. (Jack) Kelly Jr., the newly elected president of the United States Olympic Committee and a member of one of Philadelphia's most prominent families, died this morning as he was jogging near his Center City residence. He was 57 years old.

title: HOW A POPULAR BEER FELL OUT OF FAVOR
description: For decades, business school professors have sharpened students' skills by using the case study method to examine real-world business problems. Students are asked to study a corporation and come up with ideas about what should be done to improve its prospects. What follows below is a variation on that approach. The company under examination is the Miller Brewing Company of Milwaukee. The recommendations come from a variety of concerned voices.

title: TIMING SALES OF SECURITIES PROFITABILITY
description: WHILE investors are always eager to make top dollar on their trades, they too often overlook the significance of positioning their holdings to save on taxes, and thereby do not really make top dollar. But there are a number of ways to time investment moves to slash or postpone the tax bite on gains easily and legally.

One reason Mr. Starr's plan will not work is that the cost of his nine proposals would be staggering and would require massive borrowing and/or severe cuts in education and other essential services.

description: WASHINGTON, D.C.

description: ''When we first came here,'' said Walter Ganz, who with his wife, Ruth, kissed Englewood, N.J., goodbye a dozen years ago, ''there were just two things to do in this town: skiing and sex. Do you know what the biggest thing is now?'' A pause. ''

title: OPEN CAGE OFFERS A TRAINING GROUND
description: WRITING a book about the travails of an actress turned artistic director and producer, acting coach and would-be arts administrator seems a likely next step for Mount Vernon's indefatigable Tina Sattin. In fact, she's been doing just that, but Miss Sattin will not be putting the finishing touches on her tome - working title: ''Interim Report'' - until she finds a full-time professional administrator to run the Mount Vernon Fine Arts Cultural Center, which she founded and had incorporated in 1976.

''In this sense: I have written opinions and joined opinions that have said that the Fourth Amendment

title: THE SYSTEM, WORKS DON'T FIX IT
description: THE winds of domestic deregulation are now blowing on intercontinental and transoceanic satellite communications, an arena that since 1964 has been the responsibilty of Intelsat, the global satellite communications organization created at the urging of the United States to bring an efficient and affordable commercial satellite telecommunications system to the world.

title: IRA'S EXPLOSIVE POPULARITY
description: INDIVIDUAL RETIREMENT ACCOUNTS have become so commonplace that one chain of discount stores is offering them to its customers. In 10 K-Mart stores in the San Diego area shoppers can open an I.R.A. while they buy their toys and appliances.

title: SAFEGUARDS
description: Underarms Control

title: PAYING A CALL ON EUROPE'S ARISTOCRATS
description: The Duchess of Medinaceli can't remember how many castles she owns in her native Spain. Her best guess is between 90 and 100, but this uncertainty regarding numbers is atypical; she is well aware that she is nine times a duchess, 18 times a marchioness, 19 times a countess, four times a viscountess and 14 times a grandee, as well as the present head of a family that has included three saints and two popes.

title: Luzinski in Middle
description: Public high school coaches in New Jersey are required to have at least 60 hours of college credits. The rule doesn't apply to parochial schools unless they voluntarily agree to abide by it, but when officials of the 19- school Burlington County Scholastic League learned that the league's only parochial school, Holy Cross in Delran, had hired a freshman baseball coach who didn't measure up to the standard, there was a move to block the appointment.

title: Minnesota Senate Passes Farm Aid Bill
description: The Minnesota Senate passed a $25 million bill Friday to provide interest subsidies to financially pressed farmers, who are also calling for a ban on mortgage foreclosures.

title: 'PRINECESS DOE': A MAN'S OBSESSION
description: BLAIRSTOWN LIEUT. ERIC KRANZ'S obsession began on a muggy summer afternoon two and a half years ago, when a girl's body - badly decomposed, the skull crushed - was found on the rim of a ravine at Cedar Ridge Cemetery here.

title: AS A DUO GOES SOLO, MARITAL DISCORD TURNS LYRICAL
description: When Richard and Linda Thompson broke up in 1982, after their sixth album together and their first United States tour, a decade-long marriage and a brilliant performing duo was torn apart. Such albums as ''I Want to See the Bright Lights Tonight'' and ''Shoot Out the Lights'' had topped critics' polls and established a dedicated cult following for the Thompsons, on the strength of Richard's songs - hard-headed lyrics tied to modal melodies - and of Linda's strong, melancholy lead vocals.

description: LOS ANGELES

title: A BIRTHDAY FOR 'MIKADO'
description: ''With joyous shout and ringing cheer,'' celebrations honoring the centenary of Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Mikado'' begin this week with New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players' performances at Symphony Space and a banquet in London. Later this year, there will be an exhibit at the Pierpont Morgan Library, and WNET will broadcast the 1967 D'Oyly Carte movie version, the only fairly authentic film we have of that sadly moribund compoany in its most popular vehicle.

description: SLOW DANCING By Elizabeth Benedict. 276 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: McEnroe Defeats Fleming by 6-4, 6-0
description: Top- seeded John McEnroe traded aces with Peter Fleming in the first set and then allowed his doubles partner only 8 points in the second set en route to a 6-4, 6-0 victory Saturday in a semifinal match of the $375,000 World Championship Tennis Shootout.

title: Suing ForArt's Sake
description: When Henry Reed gave the Whitney Museum of American Art his collection of the paintings, drawings and writings of Morgan Russell in 1978, he maintains, it was on the understanding that the Whitney would exhibit the works of the early 20th century American artist and publish a scholarly catalogue. Since no exhibition has yet been mounted and no catalogue published, Mr. Reed, a New Jersey insurance broker, is suing to get back his gift.

title: Deadly Bird Disease Hunted In 26 States and Puerto Rico
description: A deadly disease that has already forced the destruction of 2,000 exotic birds in Florida is now being hunted in 25 other states and Puerto Rico, Federal officials say.

title: THE DEFICIT'S CLEAR AND PRESENT DANGER
description: Richard A. Snelling is the former Governor of Vermont.

title: WESTCHESTER OPINION ;   GUESTS AND HOUSEGUESTS ARE RIGHT AT HOME
description: HOUSEGUESTS are like dead fish: after the second day they both begin to smell. As the part owner of two houses, how often I had heard that old saying quoted to me, and how much I tried to keep it out of mind recently when some old friends came to live with us. People shook their heads knowingly when we mentioned that our acquaintances, two adults and their two children, ages 3 and 9, were staying with us for what started out as days, became weeks, and ended as (almost) two months. ''It won't work,'' we were informed. ''It'll wreck your friendship,'' sages opined. ''Why in the world would you do something like that?'' most asked.

title: A BUILDING BOOMLET GIVING MANHATTAN 9,000 APARTMENTS
description: Not in five years have Manhattan streets been so clogged with construction trailers, plywood barricades, concrete trucks and towering cranes - inescapable evidence of a small boom in apartment- house development.

Fewer Bankruptcies
description: Fewer businesses are going under of late, mainly because the cost of borrowing has moderated, credit is easier to get and the economy is strong.

title: A FATAL ACCIDENT, A FATHER'S CRUSADE
description: JOSEPH RIZZO heard the skidding first and then two collisions. ''I told my wife, 'Call 911, this is a bad one,' '' he said. Then Mr. Rizzo, who is a Suffolk County Legislator, ran outside his home at 229 Manhattan Boulevard in Islip Terrace and discovered that the driver pinned inside the wrecked 1977 Toyota was his daughter Joan.

title: AN OLD ICEBOX GETS A NEW LIFE AND IMPORTANCE
description: WHEN we came to the house in Goldens Bridge, the icebox was there, solid, dark and ancient. It stood in the scariest part of the basement, between the massive stone wall and the furnace, an area too narrow and too far from the stairs. Yet the box held an attractive force, and often I would swing back its heavy doors and peer inside, careful not to stand too close, before my whole body shuddered and I bolted up the stairs looking for a warm room and a real voice.

title: BAROQUE STAGE IN A SWEDISH PALACE
description: JASON MARKS is an associate professor of English and journalism at Bernard M. Baruch College of the City University of New York.

title: WHAT CAN BE DONE ABOUT CRIME
description: Roger Starr's article suggests a sort of urban triage. It describes and prescribes for the symptoms, but does not satisfactorily propose treatment for the underlying disease.

title: OPENING THE SPRING TRAINING DOORS
description: My dad sat perched on the edge of his seat as Sandy Koufax delivered the third strike. Another batter was gone, and John Roseboro, the catcher, flipped the ball down to third base as Koufax turned and searched for the resin bag. Kneeling in the on-deck circle, I knew it was now up to me. I had a job to do.

title: WHY OPERA IN NEW YORK DESERVES A MINI-MET
description: Earlier this season, the Washington Opera mounted a production of Rossini's ''Italian Girl in Algiers,'' with Fran,cois Loup as a brilliant, hilarious Bey Mustaf a. By the end of the performance I heard, a neighbor had compared him in succession to nearly every great figure of vintage cinematic comedy.

title: THE DEBT TO THE INDOCHINESE IS BECOMING A FISCAL DRAIN
description: The fall of South Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia to the Communists a decade ago started one of the great refugee dramas of the century. Since 1975, about 1.4 million Indochinese have found new lives abroad, more than half of them in the United States. ''Our nation's resettlement of over 725,000 Vietnamese, Lao and Cambodians ranks as one of the largest, most dramatic humanitarian efforts in history,'' Roger Winter, director of the United States Committee for Refugees, said last week. President Reagan underscored that success in his State of the Union address when he singled out the achievements of Jean Nyugen, who fled with her family from Vietnam in 1975 and who will graduate from West Point in May.

title: COYOTE POPULATION INCREASING IN STATE
description: COYOTES are turning up in many parts of Connecticut, according to state biologists, who add that the animal does not deserve its reputation for being dangerous to humans.

title: DANCE: MARIKO SANJO
description: When Mariko Sanjo and her company of 10 dancers paused, they could have been statues or figures in a painting. When they moved, they could have been statues or figures in a painting come to life. The works that Miss Sanjo brought to the Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium of the Asia Society on Friday night showed a great concern for pictorial composition.

Trail, senior vice president of Oppenheimer Industries, a major real estate broker and manager based in Kansas City, Mo.

title: LOUISIANA INDICTMENTS: ONLY THE NAMES CHANGE

description: PALM BEACH, FLA.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION

description: Over the past decade, as the pressure for affordable housing within commuting distance of midtown Manhattan has mounted, residential developers have pushed northward in New York State beyond Rockland County into the farmland of Orange County.

title: MOTHER, ARMED
description: THE UPPER ROOM By Mary Monroe. 309 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $14.95.

title: TIPS FOR YOUNG PROFESSIONALS
description: CONSIDER the tax plight of young urban professionals. They earn $30,000 to $50,000 annually, enough to place them in a 40 percent tax bracket. City dwellers for the most part, they frequently live in high-priced rented apartments that afford no tax deductions at all. And if they are unmarried with no children, they can take a paltry single exemption on their tax returns.

title: MERCHANTS WELCOME TAX CHANGE
description: WARREN ROSENBERG is in a double bind. His store, Danielson Surplus Sales, is nestled in a corner of the state about 15 miles from Massachusetts and 5 from Rhode Island. He must stand by, frustrated, as potential customers drive across those borders to escape Connecticut's 7.5 percent sales tax. Come April 1, however, Mr. Rosenberg expects his border problems to vanish.

title: PARIS COUTURE
description: The recherche world of made-to- order clothes is also a laboratory for designers' most creative ideas. Here and on following pages are some of this spring's.

title: CABLE TV
description: Of all the films that opened last year, probably none came as so pleasant a surprise as ''Splash,'' a heartwarmingly funny tale of romance between man and mermaid. It will be seen Sunday at 8 P.M. on Showtime, Tuesday at 8 P.M. on HBO, Friday at 12:30 P.M. and 12:30 A.M. on Showtime and 2 P.M. and 8 P.M. on Cinemax.

title: CABARET: COWINGS AND SHAW PERFORM
description: The team of Marion Cowings and Kim Shaw can be viewed either as an unusual cabaret act or an unusual jazz act. In either case, their ability to draw successfully and imaginatively from both styles sets their performances apart.

title: 67-7 WEIGHT THROW BY EAGAN IS WINNER
description: Patrick Egan, a 23-year-old senior at the University of Rhode Island, won the 35-pound weight throw today as the 64th Indoor IC4A track championships began in Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: The Soul-Searching Continues for Graham Greene
description: Graham Greene is 80 now. For his birthday last fall, the brewery his great-grandfather founded in 1799 made a special edition of its light St. Edmunds ale for him with a special label. He liked that, and the beery lunch in the English countryside that went with it. The rest of the birthday was not so terrific, nor is being 80. ''It's not more peaceful, it's not more certain,'' he says. The big advantage, he suggests, is that at 80 you are more likely these days to beat out encountering your end in a nuclear war. The other side of the problem, Greene goes on, is that ''I really don't want to survive myself'' - a phrase that doesn't have anything to do with nukes, but with the body hanging around while the mind departs.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Political StormsIn Louisiana
description: Louisiana has produced more than its share of colorful and magnetic politicians, but the current Governor, Edwin W. Edwards, is one of the most popular since the legendary Gov. Huey P. Long held sway in the 1920's and 30's.

title: DIVERS LET NOTHING STAND IN THEIR WAY
description: THE thermometer reads an unseasonably warm 43 degrees Fahrenheit, but it feels much colder out on the frozen expanse of Lake Mahopac.

title: QUARTERLY FILING, AN ONEOUS TASK
description: TAX time comes just once a year for the majority of individuals who receive a regular paycheck from which Uncle Sam has already withheld his due, or close to it. But a large number of taxpayers must file up to four times a year - each time accurately estimating their payments or incurring penalties.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN GENEVA
description: PAUL HOFMANN is the author of ''O Vatican! A Slightly Wicked View of the Holy See'' (Congdon & Weed).

title: TOURING PARNASSUS
description: SOMETHING SAID Essays. By Gilbert Sorrentino. 266 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. Paper, $15.50.

title: TREASURY PLAN'S IMPACT
description: As many taxpayers go through the motion in preparation for filing their returns this year, a nagging thought undoubtedly keeps popping into their minds: The Treasury's new tax proposal and how it could alter all the rules.

title: Texan to Join Oceans Panel
description: John E. Flipse, associate dean of engineering at Texas A&M University, will be sworn in Monday as chairman of the National Advisory Committee on Oceans and Atmosphere. Mr. Flipse will fill the post for which Anne M. Burford, former head of the Environmental Protection Agency, was designated by President Reagan last summer. Mrs. Burford withdrew before taking office.

description: The Chieftains, a six-member Irish instrumental ensemble formed 22 years ago and now on a 40-city North American tour, will be in Madison this afternoon.

title: Helms Tells of His Role In the Bid to Buy CBS
description: Senator Jesse Helms, whose conservative followers are trying to take control of CBS, says his ''good friend'' Ted Turner, the Atlanta broadcasting executive, asked his blessing before preparing his own takeover attempt.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're asking Congress to have the political courage to cut $50 billion by Easter.

title: A CONGRESSMAN'S DAY
description: DOVER THE first thing that hits the eye in Representative Dean A. Gallo's Congressional office here is that the 6-foot-4 freshman Republican from Parsippany nearly tops Senator Bill Bradley.

title: NEW RULES FOR SPECIAL SITUATIONS
description: The individual income tax is just that - individual - and a return will mirror a person's or a family's individual financial situation. But certain situations, while not applicable to everyone, will be reflected on millions of returns. The tax rules governing some of those situations, moreover, either changed for the 1984 tax year or affect financial planning for the 1985 tax year. Among the more common special situations that affect individual taxpayers are alimony, child-care credits, energy credits, income averaging, income from abroad, moving expenses and selling a home.

title:
ART;

TREATING THE CANVAS AS AN OBJECT IN ITS OWN RIGHT
description: -honored concept of a painting as a ''window'' framing a scene - a hole in the wall, through which the viewer observes the imagery presented - is opposed by the idea of the canvas as an independent, self-referential creation existing for its own sake, as an object in its own right.

title: TAXPAYERS CAN TELL IT TO THE JUDGE
description: WHILE most of the public attention focuses on plans for grand-scale tax reform in Congress, some of the most important tax changes every year come from court rulings on individual taxpayers' cases.

title: THEATER: 'RACHEL PLAYS,' BY LEAH K. FRIEDMAN
description: There's a backyard clothesline, a kitchen sink, a stove, a fire escape to sleep on, and a stoop for hanging out in ''The Rachel Plays'' by Leah K. Friedman. While these two bittersweet little plays at the American Jewish Theater at the 92d Street Y are called world premieres, they seem more like a revival of the Yiddish melodramas that riveted faithful audiences a half-century ago on downtown Second Avenue.

title: Ambulances in Dallas Under Criticism Again
description: A woman has died of a heart attack she suffered in an ambulance that stopped on the way to the hospital so the driver, whose shift was ending, could be relieved, officials said.

title: AIDS Baby
description: Doctors said the baby had no more than three years to live. Her Haitian mother had died of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, and the infant also had the illness.

title: SHORE-AREA ACCORD SOUGHT
description: WILDWOOD ASSEMBLYMAN Guy F. Muziani, a thorn in the side of casino gambling since he was the Mayor of Wildwood in 1976 - the year the gaming referendum was approved - says he has ''finally opened'' what could be ''meaningful communication'' with the casino industry.

description: Katarina Witt of East Germany will defend her women's title at the World Figure Skating Championships opening here Monday.

description: Frontier Airlines employees and four investment groups have formally offered to buy the financially distressed airline's outstanding common stock for $16 a share, or more than $200 million, a spokesman said today.

description: Carry Nation has been dead 74 years and it has been longer than that since hymns have been sung on saloon steps throughout Kansas beseeching God to rid the state of strong drink. But ''demon rum'' is still the subject of fiery debate here.

description: -1806) was a contemporary of Joshua Reynolds and Thomas Gainsborough and, like them, painted portraits. His subjects, though, were not the aristocrats of England but the horses and dogs they owned.

WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

description: Coach Bob Knight of Indiana has been suspended for Sunday's basketball game at Iowa as punishment for a chair-throwing incident during the Indiana-Purdue game Feb. 23.

title: FOR FILING HELP, TURN TO THE I.R.S.
description: ROUGHLY 60 percent of the 95 million Americans who pay taxes prepare the returns themselves, the Internal Revenue Service says. But where do those people turn for help? In many cases, to the I.R.S. itself.

title: CompromiseAt Mt. Sinai
description: There is a healthier future in store for Mount Sinai Medical Center on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and for the neighborhood around it. State health planners last week approved the center's scaled-down proposal to spend $488 million over the next six years to overhaul its medical complex along Fifth Avenue between 98th and 102d Streets.

title: SHAW'S 'CANDIDA' STILL YOUNG AT 87
description: THE Nassau Repertory Theater has changed its name to the Long Island Stage Company to reflect more clearly its standing as the Island's leading professional theater. This theater by any other name will, if we are to judge by its current production of George Bernard Shaw's ''Candida,'' continue to provide us with first-rate entertainment. Shaw's wit and originality zeroed in on the human condition to the continued delight of playgoers everywhere.

title: Rum
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;

A SALOON SETTING IN WEST ORANGE
description: -American restaurant in West Orange, is a warm, informal place in a saloon setting. Opened five months ago by Julio Rodriguez (hence the Spanish pronunciation, ''Hulio'') who was ma^itre d'h^otel for many years at Nero's in Livingston, the restaurant has enjoyed word-of-mouth popularity from his longtime loyal patrons.

title: The HungerEpidemic andIts Symptoms
description: About a year ago, a group of doctors and public health researchers fanned out to find ''the human face of hunger.'' Judging from a report issued last week, it stared back at them almost everywhere they looked. ''Hunger is getting worse, not better,'' the Physician Task Force on Hunger in America said, attributing the problem ''in substantial measure to clear and conscious policies of the Federal Government.'' The group's chairman, Dr. J. Larry Brown of the Harvard School of Public Health, added that hunger was an epidemic that would take $5 billion to $7 billion a year in new aid to cure.

description: BANNON McHENRY is a writer who lives in New York.

description: STATE health officials are preparing for what they fear could be ''a major outbreak'' of measles when students who attend Boston University return home next week for spring break.

description: During a program that a group called Microwave presented Wednesday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio, Toni Wisti danced a nonchalant solo. Her ''Ode to a Skid Kid'' was filled with easy-going skips and slides across the floor.

title: MUBARAK TRIES TO JUMP START STALLED MIDEAST PEACE TALKS
description: Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak's call last week for direct talks between Israel and a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation ignited for a while new hopes for peace after years of deadlock, which followed the rejection of President Reagan's peace plan in 1982. But by week's end, squabbling within the Palestine Liberation Organization and the rejection by P.L.O. Chairman Yasir Arafat of parts of Mr. Mubarak's proposal for reviving the long-stalled Camp David process dampened expectations that a united front could be assembled quickly to negotiate with Israel.

title: FUTURE EVENTS FOR MANY CAUSES ;    Seeking a Cure March 4 - An estimated 300,000
description: baffling disease called scleroderma, from the Greek meaning ''hard

title: BUSINESS GIVES COUNTY A HIGHER RATING
description: A SURVEY of Westchester's top executives indicated last week that they find the county an increasingly favorable place in which to do business or that the advantages of moving elsewhere were disappearing - or both.

title: Daniel Prefontaine to Wed Miss McCarty on Aug. 17
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. McCarty of Ithaca, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Anne McCarty, to Daniel H. Prefontaine, a son of Loretta Prefontaine of Sheldon, N.Y., and John Prefontaine.

title: GIVE HIGHER EDUCATION ITS DUE
description: ''The number of out-of-state students attracted to public or private colleges in Connecticut is small compared with the exodus of Connecticut students to colleges out of state. In the fall of 1980, 50.5 percent of college-bound high school graduates matriculated out of state, compared with 36.2 percent who attended state public institutions and 13.3 percent who attended independent colleges and universities in Connecticut. Among all states, Connecticut has consistently ranked with the top five as a net exporter of students.''

title: PLAYERS SET EMERGENCY FUND
description: After discussing the club owners' concerns about baseball's financial state, the executive board of the Players Association voted today to hold on to nearly $2.4 million in player-licensing revenue in order to use it for possible study of the owners' financial records.

title: Marietta Barnes Marries Joseph Henry Delehant
description: Marietta Barnes, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Tate Barnes Jr. of Winchester and Rockport, Mass., was married yesterday to Joseph Henry Delehant, the son of Lillian Tansey Delehant of North Haven, Conn., and the late Raymond Francis Delehant. The Rev. Charles Reinhardt performed the ceremony at the Winchester Unitarian Church, assisted by the Rev. George Dufour, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: TOWN CHANGES GOVERNMENTS
description: BYRAM TOWNSHIP GROWING pains and budget problems prompted voters in this rural Sussex County community of 7,500 people to choose a new system of local government last month.

title: ADULT BOOKSTORE OPENS UNDER SIEGE
description: THEY tried changing the law. When that failed, they argued their position in court. But despite a two-year fight by opponents of a new pornographic bookstore, it opened as the West Haven Country Newstand on Route 1 last week. The opponents have responded with daily picketing, urging passers-by to ''Say 'No' to Porno'' and to ''Go Home and Read a Good Book.''

title:
GARDENING;

AVOIDING MONOTONY IN PLANTINGS
description: THE overuse of a relatively small number of tree species has led to an unnecessary monotony in our park, garden and avenue plantings. In addition, several of those species commonly used exhibit either undesirable characteristics or are subject to devastation by insect pests or diseases.

title: THE WRONG WAY TO TREAT MOSCOW
description: For weeks on end, we have been hearing assertions from senior figures in Washington to the effect that it is only the great buildup of America's military strength (presumably since late 1983) that has brought the Russians ''back'' (although it is not exactly that) to the arms negotiation table. And now we find ourselves similarly assured that only the completion of the MX missile program, as urged by the Administration, could give the Russians the incentive to deal seriously with us at that table, once they come.

title: THREE DRAMAS OF EMOTIONAL CONFLICT
description: Long after its acclaimed debut on television in 1956 and its reincarnation on film six years later, Rod Serling's ''Requiem for a Heavyweight'' is coming to Broadway, fulfilling a dream of its late author.

title: NASSAU NEEDS ITS OWN LEGISLATURE
description: A COUNTY legislature structured both to represent the people of Nassau County and to respond effectively to their many, sometimes conflicting problems is a goal that continues to elude those residents sincerely interested in promoting our quality of life and the economic stability of the county.

title: MAYORS URGE BUDGET FREEZE AND NEW TAXES
description: Seventeen mayors meeting in New York yesterday called for a freeze on Federal spending and new taxes to cut the deficit, estimated to be about $200 billion this year.

title: BATHING SUITS AND BALL GOWNS
description: This spring designs for evening echo the lines and fabrics of those for swimming.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: STUDY AT OXFORD, AUTO TRAIN PRICE CUTS
description: Two 3-Week Seminars In England From a 28-course academic menu that ranges from Roman Britain to 20th-century poets, adults interested in combining study with travel may take intellectual nourishment this summer at Oxford University's Worcester College.

title: Teachers Institutes And State Grants
description: The article, ''Teachers Institutes Sharing State Aid'' (Jan. 27), did not present a balanced picture of the role of staff-development centers and teachers institutes. While one cannot deny the importance of personal growth, your having highlighted exercise and cooking, neither of which is funded through state moneys, presented an inaccurate view of the valuable work state funding has addressed. State grants were specifically for Teacher Resource and Computer Training Centers. The staff-development programs engaged in by the funded centers go substantially beyond the offering of courses for personal and professional growth.

title: New Trial for Coast Mayor
description: Mayor Roger Hedgecock has been ordered to appear May 8 for his second trial on charges of conspiracy and perjury related to an alleged scheme to finance his 1983 mayoral campaign illegally. Judge James Malkus of Superior Court ignored pleas Thursday from Mayor Hedgecock's attorney, Michael Pancer, for a delay in setting the trial date or a delay in the trial itself. The Mayor's first trial ended Feb. 13 with a hung jury.

title: Heeding Their Need
description: The call for help from the streets could not have been more urgent. Who could have closed eyes and heart to the plight of the homeless and hungry during the winter just ending? Happily, a record number of eyes and hearts opened as more donors than ever contributed to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

description: ORLANDO, Fla.

title: Zebra Transplant
description: After a horse gave birth to a full- blooded zebra last May in an embryo- transplant experiment by the Louisville (Ky.) Zoo, zoo officials said the procedure might be used to increase the populations of endangered equine breeds.

title: Quoting Einstein
description: To the Editor:

title: IN BETHANY, PUPILS MAKE MUSIC TO LEARN BY DOING
description: AN elementary school music teacher in Bethany decided that the easiest way for his pupils to learn music was by playing a variety of instruments. So, using materials ranging from wooden soy sauce barrels to plastic utility buckets, the teacher, Marc Diamond, built 30 conga drums, 48 glockenspiels, 30 keyboards, 30 guitars and 30 tenor drums.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AIRLIFT TO WARSAW: The Rising of 1944. By Neil Orpen. (University of Oklahoma, $14.95.)

description: THE CHIP How Two Americans Invented the Microchip and Launched a Revolution. By T. R. Reid. Illustrated. 243 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: Nine Accused ofMaking a Racket
description: Crime in New York City may become less organized thanks to the indictment last week of the five men who, federal prosecutors said, head the city's Mafia organizations. The indictment charges the five reputed leaders and four associates with racketeering, a broad allegation that covers their supposed involvement in extortion schemes and conspiracy to commit murder.

title: WHAT CAN BE DONE ABOUT CRIME
description: Roger Starr's quaint notion that, back in the good old days, ''the criminal types'' all lived on the other side of town certainly indicates that he would do well to read a history book before he tries to write one. His recipe for handling subway crime is simplistic, destructive and capable of increasing the problems of crime.

title: THE SOUL-SEARCHING CONTINUES FOR GRAHAM GREENE
description: John Vinocur is the Paris bureau chief of The New York Times.

title: A 'SUPERGIRL' CONTINUES TO LIVE UP TO THE TITLE
description: ON a December day in 1982, a car carrying Massapequa-born Helen Slater toward London's Heathrow Airport stopped briefly at Pinewood Studios.

title: PORTRAIT OF A MILITARY LEGEND
description: ''American Caesar'' is a milestone of sorts - a five-hour documentary series devoted to one man, Gen. Douglas MacArthur, and shown simultaneously over broadcast and cable television. It is adapted from William Manchester's superb biography, and, like the book, it doesn't demand that we approve of MacArthur, only that we respect him. It is possible he was the most gifted military man the United States has ever produced. Certainly he was one of the most controversial, although ''American Caesar'' assiduously tries to keep a perspective. Was MacArthur arrogant, willful and vain? He was. Was he also dedicated, honorable and conscientious? He was those things, too - ''a great thundering paradox of a man,'' the documentary asserts, who coveted both victory and authority, and could simultaneously despise and celebrate war. The series, jointly produced by Metromedia Television and the Turner Broadcasting System, begins tonight on WNEW-TV at 6 and on TBS at 8.

title: 401(K) DEFERS INCOM
description: EMPLOYEES whose companies sponsor 401(k) plans can readily heed the cardinal rule of many tax planners: Defer income. Those who elect to participate in the plan tell the company what percentage of their salaries to defer, and the money accumulates tax-free until withdrawn, just as it does in an Individual Retirement Account, but certain wrinkles in the law give 401(k) plans advantages even over an I.R.A.

title: THE CRIPPLING INHERITANCE
description: TWENTY-SIX years ago this winter, I resigned a scholarship at Oxford University, rented a small room in Paris and set out to write a novel. Four years later, tremulous with terror, I packed up my clothes and typewriter and returned to Boston. It had taken me all that time to realize that while I knew something about ''voice'' and ''style'' and ''the structure of the novel,'' I knew very little about living. Eighteen months after I faced that fact - 18 months of reflection marred by intermittent moments of panic - I answered an appeal for teachers and organizers posted near the subway by a group of which I'd never heard whose acronym was CORE.

title: 'Fortress Dresden Will Be Defended'

title: LONDON ORCHESTRAS ARE NOT LIKE OURS
description: New Yorkers, who have only one full-time orchestra, with a subscription system and four opportunities each week to hear the same program, would find a quite different situation in London. That city has five full-time symphony orchestras. One is the BBC, which is predominantly a studio orchestra. The other four are concert-giving; one, the Royal Philharmonic, is visiting Carnegie Hall this weekend with its conductor laureate, Yehudi Menuhin.

title: LOWLY MAPLE LEAFS TOP ISLANDERS, 4-2
description: The playing surface here at the Maple Leaf Gardens is lighted by rows of huge spot lights, and tonight they lit up the Islanders' deficiencies.

title: TOWN IN GERMANY AIDS SOUP KITCHEN
description: WHILE Connecticut residents replied to pleas for money to feed the starving people of Ethiopia, a suburb of Munich has donated money to feed the hungry in Willimantic.

title: Crews Breach 2d Portal Seal In Mine Where Fire Killed 27
description: Emery Mining Corporation crews have opened a second sealed portal of the burning Wilberg Mine and have started spraying nitrogen foam inside to extinguish fires smoldering in coal seams.

title: THE TAX CODE SPEAKS ENGLISH ONLY WHEN QUOTING YOUR TAX RATE
description: RELATIVELY few people check it out of the library. Buy it? Only those who absolutely must. In Hollywood, there seems to be no interest in shaping it into a mini-series. Nevertheless, the book - if it can rightfully be called a book - seems right now to have more impact on Americans than anything else ever written, outside the Bible. It's a reasonably safe bet that no one has read it in its entirety, and the average individual has never even seen it, though it has been out for decades.

title: THE WAR BEHIND THE LINES IN IRAN AND IRAQ
description: The United Nations is now confronting for the first time the condition of prisoners of war in one of today's bloodiest conflicts. Tariq Aziz, the Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister of Iraq, is expected in New York tomorrow to urge the Security Council to discuss a mechanism for an exchange of prisoners between Iraq and Iran.

title: I.R.S. TURNS UP THE HEAT ON TAX-SHELTER ABUSE
description: Internal Revenue Service agents are spending more time than ever before - 20 percent of their working hours last year - seeking tax-shelter abuses. And they are spending less time doing audits. Since 1981, when Roscoe L. Egger Jr. became the I.R.S. Commissioner, the agency's enforcement budget has increased by $700 million, he said, and the I.R.S. has increased its collections from major enforcement programs by 80 percent to $34 billion. These figures, Mr. Egger said, are proof that his focus on tax shelters is paying off. Indeed, the 64-year-old Mr. Egger has been getting good marks from some of his predecessors and from others for changes he has wrought since joining the I.R.S. from Price Waterhouse, where he was a partner in charge of the Washington office.

C.D. Rates Heading Up?

Amundson of La Crosse, Wis., and the late Raymond C. Amundson. A May wedding is planned.

title: SCHOOLS REACT TO AID PLAN
description: SINCE the announcement of the White House budget proposals to reduce financial assistance for college students by $2.3 billion, financial-aid officers and other college administrators have been trying to assess the potential impact on their students and institutions.

title: THE BOOKS GUIDE THE UNINITIATED
description: AS inevitable as death and, yes, taxes is the avalanche each year of new books for taxpayers. Many are perennials, updated annually to accommo- date changes in the tax law. Others are in bookstores for the first time. And to fit the various needs of the taxpayers they are intended to help, some are fairly sophisticated, while some are elementary.

title: Reagan to LeadTax Charge
description: The appearance of Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d before the House Ways and Means Committee, chairman Dan Rostenkowski said before the fact, would send the issue of tax revision ''from the cloisters into the coliseum.'' Mr. Baker did not fulfill Mr. Rostenkowski's prediction. But he did give the first authoritative notice that sometime this spring battle will be joined.

description: The Rev. Lucia Peavey Ballantine, the assistant rector at the Episcopal Church of St. Luke in the Fields in New York, and Ron William Walden, an assistant professor of theology at Fordham University, plan to be married May 4.

description: Big was beautiful for geraniums until indoor gardeners were introduced to the world of dwarf geraniums. Then the tide turned.

title:
ANTIQUES;

A HISTORY OF TRADING
description: FROM the time of its first settlement more than 300 years ago, Norwich has provided a natural trading place. It was planned that way. The old town in southeastern Connecticut was laid out in 1659 at the point where the Yantic and the Shetucket Rivers form the head of the Thames, the broad river that flows down to Long Island Sound near New London. Traders from along the coast and from England landed new goods at New London; smaller ships took these to Norwich, where local products could be exchanged for them.

title: Encouragement For Tyrell Biggs
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SOFT BED CURES
description: To the Editor:

title: Amy Susan Alter To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Amy Susan Alter to Dr. Yohan Jeffereis has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Alter of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and West Tisbury, Mass., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Deryck Jeffereis of Bombay, India.

title: Wedding PlannedBy Rebecca Frost
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Lee Frost of New York have announced the engagement of his daughter Rebecca Frost to John Raymond Cuevas, a son of Sylvia Rosado and Adrian Cuevas, both of New York. The wedding is planned for May.

title: SANDINISTAS PIN HOPES ON CONGRESS
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua WITH an eye on Congress, where the Reagan Administration is battling for money for the anti- Sandinista rebels, the Nicaraguan Government last week launched a major diplomatic offensive. In a series of declarations - to a delegation of Roman Catholic bishops headed by Archbishop John J. O'Connor of New York, to foreign diplomats in Managua, and to fellow Latin American heads of state gathered in Montevideo, Uruguay - President Daniel Ortega Saavedra announced a moratorium on purchases of new weapons systems and promised to send home 100 of the Cuban ''military instructors'' who are assisting his army.

title:
DINING OUT;

COZY NEIGHBORHOOD SPOT IN RYE
description: PRETTY enough to make dining out a little special, with prices moderate enough so dinner with family or friends won't break the bank and with food interesting enough to keep a large regular clientele happy and amused, Tripps is the kind of restaurant every neighborhood should have.

title: RECITAL: JANE COOP, PIANIST
description: Jane Coop, a Canadian pianist whose debut here five years ago elicited favorable comment, was presented in recital at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday night by the Center for Inter- American Relations in cooperation with the Y and the Canadian Consulate General.

title: The Loss Of a Child
description: Thanks to Tim Page for his honest and moving article, ''Life Miscarried,'' (About Men, Jan. 27). Those of us who have lost a child through miscarriage often feel that only other parents who have experienced a similar loss can truly understand the pain we feel.

title: A FEAR OF DOGS SLOWLY WANES
description: GROWING up in New York City, I had to walk long distances to attend elementary and high school. There were no school buses in my area, and car pools were unheard of then. Rain, sleet and snow never bothered me in my journeys, but stray dogs terrified me. A large German shepherd, and even small dogs taking their morning constitutional were enough to make me cross over to the other side of the street, just to avoid them. I had been bitten by a dog when I was a toddler.

title: ONE SOCIALIST REAGAN CAN WARM UP TO
description: Italy's Prime Minister, Bettino Craxi, is a Socialist with probably more pluses than minuses as far as the Reagan Administration is concerned.

title: INDULGING A PREOCCUPATION WITH TIME
description: PLEASANTVILLE

title: THE RUSSIANS SEEK I.B.M. COMPATIBILITY
description: The Soviet electrical engineer in Perm, a city tucked away at the edge of the Ural mountains, was angry. Trying to boost his productivity, he had struggled in vain for a year to build his own personal computer, piecemeal, from parts dribbling out of Russian electronics factories. ''Hundreds of thousands of bare computer components aren't needed by anybody,'' he wrote in Literaturnaya Gazeta, a weekly newspaper popular among the Soviet intelligentsia. ''What we need instead are hundreds of thousands of complete computer systems.''

title: KEAN SIGNS MEASURE TO PHASE OUT INHERITANCE TAX ADOPTED IN 1982
description: A measure that is expected to save taxpayers $109 million by 1991 by phasing out the state's inheritance tax was signed into law this week by Governor Kean, who called the tax ''one of the cruelest.''

title: AN AMERICAN CONDUCTOR ABROAD
description: It's a familiar pattern: a gifted

title: A 'Dream House' And Loss of Wetlands
description: I found the article on Fleets Neck in Cutchogue ('' 'Dream House' Halted in Beach Dispute,'' Jan. 27) to be very well written. There are, however, some problems that need clarification.

title: EMPLOYEE BENEFITS RESTRICTED
description: The nation's accounting firms are flooding the executive suites this year with a new pamphlet - travel logs that businessmen will dutifully have to fill out when they use their company cars. Without detailed records of mileage and expenses, the companies and individuals could forfeit their traditional deductions on the cars as a business expense.

title: SPRING FLORAL SHOW OPENS FRIDAY
description: IN 1935 nine Greenwich women

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

BOBBY SHORT BENEFIT
description: BOBBY SHORT is coming to town, and the Ecumenical Emergency Food Pantry will benefit. The jazz pianist, famous for his urbane style and sophisticated renditions of Cole Porter, Gershwin and other composers, will perform at the Woman's Club of White Plains, on Saturday, March 30.

title: ADOPTED SCHOOLS
description: Increasingly, school districts nationwide - faced with rising costs, declining enrollments and lower tax bases - have been looking to new sources for special programs for students and faculty. Westchester is no exception to this trend and now has schools in two districts aided by major corporations taking part in the United States Department of Education's Adopt-a-School Program.

title: PRESERVING A LOW PROFILE
description: The block between Fifth and Madison Avenues, 70th to 71st Streets, is one of the few remaining on the Upper East Side with no tall buildings. The Frick Collection occupies the whole of the Fifth Avenue side of the block, and on the 71st Street side, at No. 22, is a five-story Italian Renaissance style limestone town house built in 1923.

title: THE CIRCULAR DRIVEWAYS OF HELL
description: LINDEN HILLS By Gloria Naylor. 304 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $16.95.

title: FOUR TAX PROFESSIONALS AND HOW THEY CAN HELP
description: MORE than 30 million taxpayers will seek professional help in filing their tax returns this year. But where to turn? Tax experts say that the complexity of an individual's tax situation should be the primary determinant. A high- paid business executive with tax shelters and estate concerns probably should seek the advice of a tax lawyer. But a young professional whose income comes from a W-2 form and some interest and dividends should find that an inexpensive tax preparation service is adequate.

title:
CAMERA;

STURDY TRIPODS
description: Poorly selected tripods are often the cause of ruined pictures and sometimes ruined cameras. When I was an amateur photographer, I went to Europe for a vacation to take pictures.

title: NEW YORKERS PAY MORE THAN THEIR NEIGHBORS
description: DIANE STOLZ, who works in Manhattan as an architect and lives on the Upper East Side, bemoans the fact that New York taxes ''are much higher across the board, from sales to personal income,'' than taxes in New Jersey, Connecticut or California, where she grew up.

title: NEW CASSETTES: VINTAGE COMEDY TO BOLSHOI OPERA
description: His Girl Friday Starring Cary Grant, Rosalind Russell, Ralph Bellamy, Gene Lockhart; directed by Howard Hawks, 1940 Kartes Video 91 minutes. $19.95

title:
GARDENING;

AVOIDING MONOTONY IN PLANTINGS
description: THE overuse of a relatively small number of tree species has led to an unnecessary monotony in our park, garden and avenue plantings. In addition, several of those species commonly used exhibit either undesirable characteristics or are subject to devastation by insect pests or diseases.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a Feb. 17 article about epilepsy, the meeting date of the Epilepsy Association of Westchester County Self- Help Group was incorrect. The group meets at 7 P.M. on the first Wednesday of every month at White Plains Hospital.

title: EUROPEAN STYLE
description: Fashion directions emanate, in the main, from four major centers: Paris, Milan, London and New York. London's offerings are usually the funkiest and New York's the most sensible.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FAMILY ALBUM. By Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $16.95.)

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: GREAT PAINTERS Written and Illustrated by Piero Ventura. 160 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $15.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: TV'S INTERVIEWER PAR EXCELLENCE
description: Five years ago, Roone Arledge, the president of ABC News, put a little-known diplomatic correspondent on the air at 11:30 P.M. to oversee a 20-minute nightly interview and news analysis program. Few gave the venture much chance of attracting a large enough number of viewers to survive. Although the correspondent had distinguished himself with his reporting, he had yet to prove himself as an anchor; indeed, he had been removed from a job as a weekend anchor by Mr. Arledge only three years earlier.

title: PHILIPPE NOIRET: NO ''METHOD'' TO HIS ART
description: Soft and cushy as an overstuffed armchair, Rene has developed an equally comfortable approach to his job as a policeman in Paris's 18th arrondissement. A purse may be snatched before his eyes, but he averts his gaze rather than give chase; the prisons are too crowded, he reasons, and besides, crime statistics in his district are high enough, so headquarters frowns on too many arrests. At his favorite cafe, Rene happens to know about the gambling that goes on in the back room; but he doesn't do anything about it, so his lunch every day is free. When he visits a neighborhood clothing store, the proprietor presses him to accept an armful of shirts; the tacit understanding is that Rene will ignore the illegal aliens working in the shop.

title: May Nuptials Set By Lauren Ginter
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence U. Ginter of West Chester, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter Lauren Michelle Ginter to Robert Arnold Jackson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Jackson of Lawrenceville, N.J. The wedding is planned for May 11.

title: WHO WON? WHO KNOWS?
description: THE two candidates who ran for Southold Town trustee last November are hoping that one of them will get elected before it's time to run again.

title: Carol A. Clark Married To Peter Bede Butler
description: Carol Ashley Clark, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Watson Gerould Clark 3d of Tenafly, N.J., and Bremen, Me., was married yesterday to Peter Bede Butler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Butler of Tenafly and Amagansett, L.I. The Rev. Harry Chase, assisted by the Rev. Joel Schevers, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Tenafly.

title: COUPLE PUBLISH LONDON NEWSLETTER
description: THE city of London, which has been an inspiration to authors and poets throughout the centuries, has in the last year inspired Janet and Nicholas Wedge of Millwood to begin a new publication, London Outlook.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ''YES, we're being sued for $60 million,'' confirmed Alan A. Block, co-author with Frank R. Scarpitti of

title: UNBEATEN PRYOR RETAINS TITLE
description: Aaron Pryor returned from what he called ''the twilight zone'' and grittily pulled out a split 15-round decision today over an inspired Philadelphia fighter named Gary Hinton to remain undefeated and the International Boxing Federation's junior-welterweight champion.

title: No Headline
description: IN SHORT: FICTION

title: TAX REDUCTION TACTICS THAT NAKE A DIFFERENCE
description: WHAT taxpayer is not delighted to find yet one more deduction that will enable him to hold onto a few more dollars of his hard-earned money. George Scharfenberger, the chief executive officer of the City In vesting Company, for instance, has made finding tax-saving deductions his hobby. He often spends his free time poring over tax materials, and tells friends that he does not consider his weekend complete unless he has figured out a new way to save on his taxes.

title: THE SURPRISING MERCE CUNNINGHAM
description: Merce Cunningham has long been fascinated by chance and change. Nevertheless, each of his dances manages to have a special atmosphere and, judging from his comments about them in a recent interview, his three newest works have their own choreographic personalities. All three will be featured during the season by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company that opens Tuesday at the City Center and that will also include performances of ''Pictures,'' ''Inlets 2,'' ''Trails'' and ''Roadrunners.''

title: WHAT CAN BE DONE ABOUT CRIME
description: Over the last 20 years, I have been a judge in the City, County, Supreme and Surrogate Courts in the state of New York. Roger Starr's article is one of the finest I have read on the problem of crime. It takes what I like to call a common-sense, realistic view of the problem, and his nine- point program offers an affirmative starting point for what can be done to combat crime in our society. JOSEPH S. MATTINA Surrogate Judge

title: 9 U.S.-MEXICO CROSSINGS ARE CLOSED AFTER THREATS
description: Security at border stations between the United States and Mexico was stepped up and nine border crossings were closed Saturday night after threats against United States Customs Service agents, officials of both countries said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, MARCH 4, 1985

title: WORKERS HELP IMPROVE NORTH GENERAL HOSPITAL'S FISCAL HEALTH
description: When it became apparent that an elevator was stuck at North General Hospital recently, the first person to attend to the problem, rushing to the basement to see what could be done, was Eugene L. McCabe, who also happens to be president of the hospital.

title: 10-YEAR SEARCH BRINGS CAMBODIAN BOY TO U.S.
description: For more than a decade, Phat and Sokha Mau, Cambodians living in Queens, have been piecing together bits of telegrams, accounts of telephone calls and the scattered recollections of Cambodian refugees, all in the hope of finding the son they left behind in a country now ravaged by war.

title: DUTCH COLONIAL CULTURE ALIVE AGAIN AT SYMPOSIUM
description: Laura Linder, the archivist of the First Reformed Church of Schenectady, a 300-year-old church founded by Dutch settlers in 1680, had come to New York City hoping to find someone who could read the church's earliest records.

title: Purim Pageantry
description: Little girls wore crowns. Little boys,

title: IT ISN'T SPYING
description: The Reagan Administration has invoked the espionage laws to prosecute a civilian employee of the Navy for providing classified information to a publication. Congress has refused to make publication of a secret a crime, but the Justice Department argues that since the Russians also read, publishing a secret is tantamount to giving it to them. Superficially appealing as that argument may be, it is legally unsound and damaging to American democracy.

title: Sandra Shulman Becomes Bride of Ira Greenstein
description: Sandra Shulamith Shulman and Ira Greenstein, third-year law students at New York and Columbia Universities respectively, were married yesterday at the Loews Glenpointe Hotel in Teaneck, N.J. Rabbi H. Z. Rappaport, uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony. Cantor Eleazor Shulman, cousin of the bride, assisted.

title: 2 HOUSES CLASH IN TOURNAMENT
description: THE Big East's seventh postseason tournament begins at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night following a regular season that was routine in one sense and rather surprising in another.

title: Article 066427 -- No Title
description: Farmers and allied interests have contributed a total of $8.2 million to the current members of Congress, including many from districts with small farm populations, according to reports filed with the Federal Election Commission.

title: UNAUTHORIZED SALES UP FOR CARS FROM EUROPE
description: Stefan Antel will sell you a Mercedes-Benz 500 SEL model for about $46,000, although the manufacturer's suggested list price is $51,200. This helps explain why Tyson's Motors, Mr. Antel's business in suburban Washington, is prospering.

title: IN LIMELIGHT, IN TWILIGHT
description: IT is noon on the day after his No. 1 ranked team was

title: Higher Treasury Yields Expected
description: At this week's regular auction of new Treasury bills, interest rates are likely to be the highest since mid- November of last year, based on rates prevailing last week.

title: Links
description: Washington's social scene is often a study in contrasts. A case in point involves two functions to be held tomorrow night.

title: Set Aside Irrelevant Passion in the Goetz Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Futures/Options;   The Industry Comes of Age
description: WHEN the leaders of the futures industry gather tomorrow

title: VILLANOVA RALLIES TO WIN IC4A TITLE
description: Villanova, as it has so many times in the past, stormed from behind with a victory in the final event, the mile relay, to win the team championship today at the IC4A Indoor Track Championships.

title: LAWYER SAYS COAST BANK SUED TO GET INSURANCE
description: The lawyer for one of the Bank of America employees sued and dismissed by the bank Friday said this weekend that his client did nothing wrong and that the bank was merely trying to get insurance money.

title: DANCE: TWO COMPANIES AT SYMPHONY SPACE
description: NOW in its 10th year, the Harlem Cultural Council's ''Dancemobile Indoors'' series has continued to present the work of black choreographers who range from the most experienced to those just starting out. Saturday night's concert at the Symphony Space was shared by the Walter Nicks Dance Company and Forces of Nature, a new troupe directed by Abdel R. Salaam, with Dyane Harvey as assistant artistic director.

title: Sandor Scheiber, a Hebraist And Rabbi, Dies in Budapest
description: Rabbi Sandor Scheiber, a scholar of Hebrew and director of the Soviet bloc's only rabbinical seminary, died of cancer in Budapest yesterday.

title: Mets Sign Darling
description: Ron Darling signed a one-year contract with the Mets today that will nearly quadruple his rookie salary of $40,000.

title: HIGH BONN AIDE IN SURPRISE VISIT TO SOVIET UNION
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher flew to Moscow today for an unexpected meeting on Monday with his Soviet counterpart, Andrei A. Gromyko.

title: On Making Childbirth Preferable to Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. S. M. Stern, Podiatrist, Is Wed to Lynne J. Anfang
description: At the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue yesterday Lynne J. Anfang, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack D. Anfang of New Hyde Park, L.I., was married to Dr. Stuart M. Stern, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Stern of Hicksville, L.I. Rabbis Seymour

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
Derby Leaders
description: Nine weeks before last year's Kentucky Derby, Time for a Change and Dr. Carter had just finished one-two in the Flamingo Stakes to become the early Derby favorites while Swale had yet to make his first start of the year. Nine weeks before the 1983 Derby, Croeso had just beaten Copelan in the Florida Derby and those two looked like the ones to beat while virtually nobody had heard of Sunny's Halo. A year earlier, Timely Writer had just won the Flamingo as if he might be unbeatable, and Gato del Sol was still looking for his first victory of the year.

title: New York Financier Turns to Washington
description: Peter del Col has been a New York banker and financier for virtually all of his professional life. But before the end of this year his financial fortunes will in large part rest on what happens in and around the nation's capital.

title: Shoemaker Tops $100 Million
description: Bill Shoemaker became the first jockey whose mounts surpassed $100 million in career earnings when he rode Lord at War to a 1 3/4-length victory in the $500,600 Santa Anita Handicap today before a record crowd at Santa Anita Park.

title: ISLANDERS HOLD OFF SABRES, 3-2
description: A week of losing for the Islanders was put to an end tonight by Billy Smith.

title: A BENDEL FIRST: CHILDREN'S WEAR
description: Children's clothes are coming to Henri Bendel. As might be expected, the clothes have a high fashion quotient. As might not be expected, they are not outrageously expensive.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AUDIENCE CRITIQUES The public is invited to help the American Folk Theater develop new scripts. On six Monday evenings starting tonight at 7, rehearsed readings will be given of a work in progress that is being considered for production. The site will be the Outer Space Gallery at 2710 Broadway at 104th Street, in the building that houses the theater's offices.

title: Kuwait Announces A Cabinet Shuffle
description: The Crown Prince and Prime Minister, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, shuffled his 15-member Cabinet today, introducing eight new ministers to serve in a new Government.

title: RON HOWARD PRODUCING 'MAXIMUM SECURITY,' SERIES ON HBO
description: Hollywood production companies have relied on most of the city's smarter restaurants to hold luncheons and cocktail parties to announce upcoming films and television shows. But last week producers turned to the recently closed Lincoln Heights jail in downtown Los Angeles for a news conference to introduce the principals involved in creating ''Maximum Security,'' a series that will begin on Home Box Office, the pay-cable service, on Tuesday at 10 P.M.

title: DOLLAR'S RISE: COPING ABROAD
description: In most of the world, the soaring dollar provokes a tangle of astonishment, pleasure, pain, frustration and embarrassment.

title: Black Hawks 5, Blues 2
description: The right wing Steve Larmer broke a 2-2 tie late in the second period with his 37th goal of the season. Jack O'Callahan of Chicago added a third-period goal at 5:45 and Al Secord tallied his 12th of the season on an empty-net shot with 18 seconds remaining.

title: U.N. AT 40: TALK OF A WAYWARD CHILD
description: Like so many disappointed parents, many of the participants at a two-day conference on the ''United Nations at 40'' expressed disillusionment, anger and resentment that the child they had conceived did not turn out the way they wanted.

title: FEARS OF TOXIC SHOCK ALTER BUYING HABITS
description: In the four and a half years since toxic shock syndrome first became a household word, reaction to the disease has caused significant changes in the buying habits of women and in the sales of manufacturers.

title: AFTER 3 YEARS, BRUINS PRESSING FOR A TURN IN LUCK
description: BOSTON

title: WHY TOUT SOUTH AFRICA?
description: There may be a hidden purpose in the zigzag maneuvers of South Africa's President P. W. Botha. He may be embarked on an effort to camouflage what is most outrageous in the apartheid system - the denial of all political rights to 21 million blacks. Or just possibly, he hopes that some modest reforms may acquire a momentum of their own and begin to enfranchise blacks. But if that is his vision, as some of his countrymen hope and others complain, he conceals it well - even from his well-wishers in the Reagan Administration.

title: WESTCHESTER SUSPECT FIGHTING RETURN TO U.S.
description: The suspect in the slaying of a Westchester County police officer is fighting extradition from Canada, where he was arrested Saturday night, investigators here said today.

title: A Belted Driver Is a Safer Driver in an Emergency Situation
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE INTERVENTION SEEN IF DOLLAR SURGES AGAIN
description: Western central banks are poised for another strike, if necessary, against dollar speculators this week after making two coordinated attacks last Wednesday and Friday that cost them around $3 billion, according to European monetary officials.

title:
DOLLAR'S RISE: COPING ABROAD;

Confusion in Canada Over Currency's Fall
description: There is no consensus about why the Canadian dollar has fallen against the United States dollar, but exporters and speculators betting on a further decline in the Canadian currency are not complaining. Still, there is concern about the inflationary impact caused by the widening divergence of the currencies, because 70 percent of Canada's imports are from the United States.

title: IN FRANCE, WEAK FRANC ALSO HAS A BRIGHT SIDE
description: France has found the strong dollar easy to live with so far. ''It doesn't only have inconveniences,'' Finance Minister Pierre Beregovoy remarked last week.

title: Earning a Chance
description: There is nothing particularly extraordinary about a championship- caliber basketball team with a valuable member named McAdoo. What is noteworthy, however, is that this McAdoo - Norris, a third cousin of Bob, the Los Angeles Laker forward, and a guard at St. Raymond's High School in the Bronx - helps run the team's fast-breaking offense with only one arm. ''I'm telling you, Norris can do anything we need him to do on the court,'' said Bob DelleBovi, who has coached St. Raymond's, the top-ranked high school team in New York State, to a 24-2 record, including an 80-63 victory over Archbishop Stepinac in yesterday's Catholic High Schools' Athletic Association quarterfinal. McAdoo, nicknamed Lucky, hit a 20-foot jumper for a key basket in yesterday's triumph. ''I have no qualms about putting him in when the situation calls for it,''DelleBovi said.''

title: PORT OF NEW YORK AND NEW JERSEY SHOWED MAJOR CARGO GAINS IN '84
description: The Port of New York and New Jersey showed strong gains in the volume of cargo handled last year, the Port Authority announced yesterday.

title: OLYMPIC COMMITTEE LEADER
description: John B. (Jack) Kelly Jr., recently elected president of the United States Olympic Committee and a leading advocate of amateur sports for more than 30 years, died Saturday while jogging near his Center City home in Philadelphia. He was 57 years old.

title: REAGAN'S STAR WARS BID: MANY IDEAS CONVERGING
description: In January 1982, Dr. Edward Teller, a physicist who played a central role in developing the hydrogen bomb, met with President Reagan to discuss new ways of trying to destroy enemy missiles and warheads during an attack.

title: Books: European Battle
Flames 7, Kings 0
description: Doug Risebrough's short-handed goal triggered a four-goal first-period burst in a span of 6:23 and the Calgary goalie, Rejean Lemelin, made 29 saves over all. It was the Flames' third consecutive victory but their first in five games this season against Los Angeles. The teams are locked in a three-way battle with Winnipeg for second place in the Smythe Division.

title: SARAH G. BLANDING, VASSAR'S 6TH CHIEF
description: Sarah Gibson Blanding, the first female president of Vassar College, died yesterday at a retirement home in Newtown, Pa., where she had lived since 1980. She was 86 years old.

title: RETTON CAPTURES AMERICAN CUP TITLE
description: Mary Lou Retton became the first female gymnast to win three American Cup all-around titles, needing only two events today to establish her superiority over a field of mostly unproven international challengers.

title: NETS TRIUMPH DESPITE JORDAN'S 37
description: Michael Jordan was simply the most magical basketball player in the city today. But there is only so much one man can do, no matter how wonderfully gifted he may be.

title: In Italy, the 'Dollarone' Fuels Inflation Worries
description: ''Inflation and Superdollar: Craxi Calls the Ministers,'' read the headline on the front page of La Repubblica last week. L'Unit a, the Communist paper, had a funny cartoon of the dollar: Under George Washington's picture, instead of ''One Dollar,'' it read ''Dollarone.''

title: COMPUTERS PROMOTE CANDOR
description: MALCOLM FOXWORTH, once a name on the electronic bulletin board, is no more. His words glowed briefly on the computer screens of Rose Salerno and fellow members of a Long Island computer club, and then Malcolm Foxworth cashed in his microchips.

title: Sara Eisenman Wed To Richard Schlussel
description: Sara Blu Eisenman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Eisenman of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard Norman Schlussel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Schlussel of Monsey, N.Y. Rabbis Moses D. Tendler; Jacob Reiner, the bride's uncle; Abner Groff, the bridegroom's uncle, and Nachum Muschel officiated at the Birchwood Manor in Whippany, N.J.

title: MUSIC: MICHEL PINTE, ORGANIST
description: MICHEL PINTE'S Friday night organ concert at St. Vincent de Paul Church afforded the listener an opportunity to explore some unusual repertory. Mr. Pinte, who serves as the organist at the St. Augustin Church in Paris, presented an engaging survey of French organ music from the last two centuries.

title: REORGANIZED LABOR
description: Organized labor has set out to reinvent the labor movement for the post-industrial age. At least that seems to be the upshot of a remarkable report recently adopted by the executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. It's a set of ideas that even critics of organized labor can welcome. Like unions or not, this report ought to provoke fresh thought about jobs, job protection and ''what it is workers can do through their unions.''

title: Geer, DuBois Shows How to Reduce Costs
description: Back in the old days when Geer, DuBois was a midtown agency, it created Dry Dock Country for a bank client.

title: West Bank University Closed By Israel Over Banned Books
description: The Israeli Government said today that it had closed the Palestinian-run Bir Zeit University in the occupied West Bank for at least a week after finding banned books and other materials there.

title: 9 FRENCH CITIZENS HELD IN ETHIOPIA
description: Nine French citizens have been taken hostage in Lalibala, an Ethiopian city about 200 miles north of Addis Ababa, diplomats and relief officials said today.

title: McEnroe Is Winner; 15 Aces
description: John McEnroe hit on only 45 percent of his first serves, but whizzed across 15 aces in defeating Kevin Curren, 7-5, 6-1, 7-6, in the final of the $375,000 World Championship Tennis Shootout today.

title: INOUYE'S ORCHIDS FOR ISRAEL
description: A bronze menorah rests atop the Senator's oversized rolltop desk and a similar, silver candelabrum adorns another wall. A ram's horn used in New Year services is displayed nearby, next to a painting of the Wailing Wall in Jerusalem.

title: King Wins
description: Betsy King won the $150,000 L.P.G.A. Samaritan Turquoise golf classic today on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff. Miss King, who birdied the final hole of regulation play to force the playoff with Patty Sheehan, eagled the first playoff hole to win the tournament.

title: Outsider Selected at Combustion
description: Combustion Engineering Inc. said that Dudley C. Mecum, managing partner of the New York office of Peat Marwick and a former Government official, had been named president of its urban systems and services business, effective April 1.

title: OUTDOORS: TRAIL RECIPES FOR HIGH-ENERGY MEALS
description: THE arrival of a paperback by Yvonne Prater and Ruth Mendenhall called ''Gorp, Glop and Glue Stew'' - a title that might have extinguished the curiosity of a less adventurous reader - has renewed my desire to take to the woods with pack on my back.

title: Subdued Palettes
description: Not Just Black and White,'' an exhibition of paintings, sculpture, photographs and drawings done with a minimum of color, will be on view through March 22 at the City Gallery of the Department of Cultural Affairs, 2 Columbus Circle. More than 20 artists are represented in the show. Hours are Monday through Friday, 10 A.M. to 5:45 P.M. Admission is free.

title: Hard-Pressed Democrats
description: The mood was sober at the triannual meeting of the College Young Democrats of America, held Saturday in Hamilton Hall at Columbia University.

title: A BELTED DRIVER IS A SAFER DRIVER IN AN EMERGENCY SITUATION
description: For the Good of All

title: Mannes Trio to Perform
description: The Mannes Trio, the resident ensemble of the Mannes College of Music, will make its New York debut tomorrow at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.

title: One Death in Avalanches
description: Avalanches killed a member of a party riding snowmobiles and trapped 30 other people at a recreation area, the authorities said today.

title: GUNSLINGERS WIN WITH LATE SAFETY
description: The defensive lineman Jeff Chaffin sacked the Arizona Outlaws quarterback Doug Williams for a safety with 1 minute 8 seconds left to earn the San Antonio Gunslingers to a 16-14 victory today.

title: IMPORT SHOWROOMS HAIL END OF QUOTAS
description: As soon as Rolf Rastadt heard that President Reagan would not ask Japan to extend its automobile export quotas, he went shopping for a new pickup truck to replace his 1973 Datsun.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When I think about Selma I think about blacks not being able to drink water when we were thirsty.

title: 'ROMANCE,' NBC MOVIE WITH CHERYL LADD
description: THERE'S a certain kind of fantasy that demands, more than anything else, a soft glow. This is the kind that is marketed cleverly in advertisements for assorted cosmetics and perfumes. And tonight at 9 on NBC, it is used as the very essence of a television movie entitled ''Romance on the Orient Express.''

title: Salvador Cleric Reports 86 Killed in a Week
description: Archbishop Arturo Rivera y Damas of San Salvador said today that 86 people died in political violence last week, eight of them civilians killed by right-wing death squads.

title: HEART PATIENT IS STABLE AFTER SURGERY FOR BLEEDING
description: Murray P. Haydon, the third human to receive an artificial heart, has made ''generally satisfactory progress'' after undergoing a one- and-a-half hour operation Saturday night to stop bleeding into his chest, a hospital official said today.

title: Concessions Rejected At Connecticut Plant
description: Union workers at the state's largest brass mill rejected, by 561 to 246, a management request for $2.5 million in wage and benefit concessions Sunday.

title: Elusive Japan-U.S. Steel Pact
description: Last September the United States and Japan reached an agreement ''in principle'' under which Tokyo said it would hold its exports of steel to 5.8 percent of the United States market. Five months later the accord has yet to be completed.

title: FREED SOUTH AFRICAN EXPLAINS WHY HE TOOK BOTHA'S OFFER
description: A leader of the banned African National Congress who was released from prison in South Africa and allowed to fly to Israel said today that he might one day return to South Africa to continue his political struggle.

title: TEEN-AGER'S SUICIDE POINTS TO LOST GENERATION IN FOSTER CARE
description: When Rickie Warner, a tall and temperamental 14-year-old, moved in with Linda and Ron Decker last summer, he entered his 32d foster home in nine years. It turned out to be his last.

title: Marschalk Co. Running Ads for Marschalk Co.
description: For those who were able to resist responding to the full-page ads in the Friday issues of The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal that said ''For good ads, call Mike. 212-708- 8888,'' the answer is that Mike is Mike Lesser, chairman of the Marschalk Company, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. But the idea came from Andrew Langer, the president, who said early Friday afternoon that the ads had four phones at the agency going all morning starting at 8.
