title: Resources Rejects Bid By Coastal
description: The chairman of the American Natural Resources Company told his counterpart at the Coastal Corporation that its $2.3 billion takeover bid for American Natural Resources is ''entirely inadequate,'' according to an exchange of letters made public by both companies.

title: INDIANA IS ROUTED WITHOUT KNIGHT
description: Indiana, playing without Coach Bobby Knight, was routed by Iowa, 70-50, in a Big Ten game today.

title: Jets 6, Oilers 3
description: Jim Nill scored twice as Winnipeg extended the defending Stanley Cup champions' losing streak to three games.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: THE TENTH MAN. By Graham Greene.

title: Advertising;   Screened Ads for Parents
description: -free since its founding 15 years ago, will open up its pages next September. It will be offering advertisers the minds and hearts not of the preschool, nonreading audience but of their parents.

title: LATE JACKSON RALLY BEATS BEACH CHANNEL
description: Greg Harvey's expression never changed. But the star for Andrew Jackson conceded he was worried when Beach Channel took a 54-49 lead after three periods in yesterday's quarterfinal game of the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs at Alumni Hall in Queens.

title: REGAN'S REIGN: HOLD THE MAALOX, HOLD THE TUMS
description: Shortly before 6:30 each night, a limousine carrying Donald T. Regan glides away from the West Wing of the White House on its way to his home in Mount Vernon, Va.

title: Market Place;   What Next For the Dow?
description: IN a hold-your-breath finish, the Dow Jones industrial average set a record high on Friday but

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: INSIGHTS INTO CUOMO BUDGET
description: Bearing charts and surrounded by assistants, with crowds of spectators occasionally cheering or booing, 15 state commissioners and agency heads have come before legislators in the last four weeks, doing their part to help sell Governor Cuomo's budget.

title: DEMOCRATS' TALKS LEAD TO QUARRELS
description: House Democrats met here this weekend to begin a party revival, search for new policies and to push for unity. But, as the meeting ended, the Democrats were still having their usual share of squabbles.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 4, 1985

title: RANDOLPH BEATS TEST OF TIME
description: The roster does not read like a veritable Who's Who in baseball, but it serves to tell the story:

title: POLICE MOTIVES QUESTIONED IN COAST VICE RAID
description: Since a vice squad raid Feb. 1 on a downtown pornographic film theater, one thing has led to another, and now the San Francisco Police Department finds itself in trouble with members of the Police Commission and some professional news organizations.

title: BIG EAST SENIORS REMEMBER
description: Perhaps more than any other graduating class, this year's Big East seniors have been the primary force behind the conference's rapid development.

title: UKRAINIAN LEADER BEGINS VISIT TO U.S.
description: A Soviet delegation led by Vladimir V. Shcherbitsky, the Ukrainian Communist Party chief, flew to the United States today, marking the first time since 1973 that a Politburo member other than Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko has visited Washington.

title: DANGER IN THE DESERT
description: The question,'' said a Moroccan journalist, ''is whether real war is inevitable.'' Everybody here understands what is meant by ''real war.'' It is war between Morocco and Algeria, not just pursuit of Algerian- supported Polisario guerrillas in the Western Sahara.

title: Required Reading;   Comparative Law
description: Your meeting is a most appropriate time and place to announce the completion of a major work of legal scholarship.

title: DEVILS TOP FLYERS
description: The Devils put together an inspired performance this evening after six consecutive losses and defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 5-2, before a sellout crowd of 19,040 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Premieres of 3 Works By Merce Cunningham
description: Three premieres will be presented by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company during its season at City Center, from tomorrow through March 17.

title: FARRELL ACCUSES KOCH OF TAKING DIVISIVE STANCES
description: Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell accused Mayor Koch yesterday of taking positions that were dividing New York City and ''speaking to one group against another.''

title: EPISCOPAL CHURCH RESISTS EVICTION BY ITS DIOCESE
description: A small church in the East New York section of Brooklyn, a conservative stray from the Episcopal fold, has been served with an eviction notice by the Long Island diocese.

title: PURCHASERS OPTIMISTIC ON QUARTER
description: Increases in new orders and production in February will virtually assure a healthy first quarter for the economy, although there are signs that a declining phase is beginning, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report to be released today.

title: For Britain, the Goal Is Greater Stability
description: After weeks of watching the dollar gain on the pound, financial circles here greeted the pound's sudden surge last week of 4 cents in two days with a combination of panic and relief. When it became clear late in the week that the dollar still had plenty of strength, concern again focused on the unstable market conditions that it created.

title: OPERA: VIRGINIA TROUPE IN MUSGRAVE'S 'HARIET'
description: Norfolk lies scarcely 100 miles south of Maryland's Eastern Shore and the soft flat farmland where Harriet Tubman was born into slavery. Thus, ''Harriet, the Woman Called Moses,'' Thea Musgrave's new opera, enjoyed both a man-made and a natural setting at the Center Theater this afternoon.

title: Clark and His Links
description: When William P. Clark announced he was quitting as Interior Secretary and leaving the Reagan Administration, he said he was going back to his California ranch. But like many others who came to Washington for what they thought was a temporary assignment, Mr. Clark has found it hard to sever his links entirely.

title: Syracuse Wins
description: Jadine Daye hit a 10-foot jump shot four seconds before the final buzzer today to give Syracuse a 57-56 victory over Villanova and the Big East championship in women's basketball. The sophomore guard Janice Long, voted the most outstanding player of the tournament, was the high-scorer for Syracuse with 21 points and 7 rebounds.

title: 'A Manifestation of Peace'
description: Writers from East and West Germany scheduled a joint meeting. Arab writers joined Israeli writers in Tel Aviv. In Tokyo, members of Japanese P.E.N., the writers' organization, celebrated Writers for Peace Day yesterday by showing ''All Quiet on the Western Front.''

title: THE CHAIN REACTION
description: -wing think tank

title: JAN SAWKA OPENS ONE-MAN EXHIBITIONS
description: When Jan Sawka emigrated from Poland to New York in 1977, his main resources were, by his own account, ''$52 and the support of my wife and my kid.'' This week, Mr. Sawka, who was one of Poland's leading artists but was almost unknown when he came to this country, opens a series of one-man art exhibitions that mark a dramatic reversal of his fortunes.

title: PAYING TAXES FOR FRINGES
description: WASHINGTON

title: BURNS AND CHANNING: MEETING OF OLD FRIENDS
description: George Burns, who describes himself as ''a neat old Jew,'' was cutting his smoked salmon into neat small pieces Friday night, an activity that didn't for a moment stop his barrage of one- liners and reminiscences. He had just picked up a lemon wedge when a man in a plaid sports shirt came over, grabbed his arm, handed him a cigar as a gift, and a small card to autograph.

title: Second Try on Export Controls
description: Following their defeat last year, sponsors of export control legislation are trying again, and harder.

title: Bangladesh Confines Opposition Leaders
description: The two main opposition leaders in Bangladesh, Begum Khaleda Zia and Sheik Hasina Wazed, were put under house arrest Saturday as part of a ban on political activity and a tightening of martial law instituted Friday by the President, Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad.

title: X-Rated Movies Shown On Campus in Michigan
description: A Michigan State University students' film club has shown two X-rated movies with the protection of a Federal judge who said school administrators could not ban the films from the campus.

title: Debt Issues
description: Alco Standard Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $50 million of convertible subordinated debentures, due 2010, through underwriters led by First Boston Corp.

title: JAZZ: REUNION AT TOWN HALL
description: SEVEN veterans of the Swing Era held a musical ''swing reunion'' on Friday and Saturday evenings at Town Hall that was more evocative because of who they were than because of what they played.

title: ISRAELI CABINET APPROVES 2D STAGE OF TROOP PULLOUT FROM LEBANON
description: The Israeli Cabinet approved plans today for the second phase of the army's three- stage withdrawal from Lebanon.

title: CIVIL DEFENSE RELOCATION PLAN SAID TO BE DROPPED
description: The Government has quietly shelved a controversial plan to evacuate whole cities to rural areas in the event of nuclear war, according to officials of the nation's civil defense agency.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: MONDAY, MARCH 4, 1985 International

title: Accounts
description: * IKEA, the Swedish furniture retailer, to Goldberg/Marchesano and Associates, Washington.

title: STRANGE TRIUMPHS IN PLAYOFF
description: Curtis Strange went through an unusual round of golf for a winner today before finally beating his close friend, Peter Jacobsen, on the first hole of a playoff in the $500,000 Honda Classic.

title: A JOBS STUDY REVEALS A PATTERN OF PROBLEMS AMONG VETERANS OF VIETNAM
description: A study of Vietnam veterans in New York City that will be the basis of a jobs program has found that black and Hispanic veterans and those who saw heavy combat are plagued by severe occupational, social and psychological problems.

title: Fed's Interpreters View Rise in Rates
description: Fed watching - a favorite pastime of economists who look to the central bank's actions and statements for clues to changes in interest rates - has yielded mixed results lately, leaving analysts unsure of the Fed's willingness to encourage higher interest rates.

title: ROCK: ODAM IN DEBUT
description: -TONK anarchy reigned Wednesday at Folk City, in the person of Norman Carl Odam, better known as the Legendary Stardust Cowboy. Mr. Odam, who refers to himself as ''The Lege,'' hails from Lubbock, Tex., and has been performing since the 1960's. His New York debut lived up to his reputation as one of rock's truest eccentrics.

title: Gunman in Ulster Kills A Catholic Policeman
description: A Roman Catholic police sergeant was shot and killed today as he prepared to go to mass with his family at Enniskillen, near the border with the Irish Republic, officials reported. The killing was the 10th police death in four days to be blamed on the Irish Republican Army.

title: BRIDGE: FOR THE 18TH EARL OF DERBY, THE WHAT-IF IS ABSORBING
description: Half a millennium ago a decision by a single family changed the course of British history and gave rise to one of the great what-ifs. What if the Stanley family had not come to the aid of the invading Henry Tudor at the Battle of Bosworth Field?

title: The Book, if Not Dead, Is Moribund
description: To the Editor:

title: STRONG 2D PERIOD WINS FOR RANGERS
description: Robbie Ftorek took a few seconds last night to deliver a message to the Penguins, to his teammates, to the fans at Madison Square Garden, and maybe even himself.

title: FOR CRAMPED JAPAN, 55 MILLION BICYCLES IS A GLUT
description: Now that the United States says it no longer cares for auto export quotas by Japan, Americans are starting to worry about a possible flood of Japanese cars.

title: CONCERT: TREANOR
description: ELIZABETH TREANOR'S Saturday afternoon recital gave evidence that she is an accomplished violinist, with a broad, full tone, a secure technique and an extroverted manner.

title: Bloomingdale's Head
description: As expected, Federated Department Stores Inc., based in Cincinnati, has named Robert Tammero as president of its New York-based Bloomingdale's department store division. Mr. Tammero had been president of Federated's Abraham & Straus chain.

title: EMILY SOPHIE BROWN
description: Emily Sophie Brown, Connecticut's first female legislator, died Friday at her home after a long illness.

title: HANDICAPPING THE LOOPHOLERS
description: By the time the battle of the flat tax is over, we will know who really runs this country, and for whom.

title: RUSSIANS SEEK TO HALT DECLINE IN OIL PRODUCTION
description: A potentially serious decline in Soviet oil production that began in 1983 has accelerated this year, causing concern in the Kremlin leadership.

title: Mary Donovan Pandaleon Is Married to Irving Mahl
description: The marriage of Mary Donovan Pandaleon, assistant dean for community services and director of special programs at Westchester Community College in Valhalla, N.Y., to Irving Mahl of Danbury, Conn., took place yesterday in Chappaqua, N.Y. Town Justice George Roberts of Lewisboro, N.Y., performed the ceremony at Joan Friedland's home.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference Tournament, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The consolation game between St. Peter's and Army is at 7 P.M., followed by the championship game between Fordham and Iona at 9 P.M. (Television - MSG Network, 7 P.M. and 9 P.M. Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7; 7 P.M. and 9 P.M.)

title: 84% REPEAT OFFENDER RATE EXAMINED
description: Almost 84 percent of arriving inmates at state prisons around the country in 1979 were repeat offenders, according to a study conducted by the Bureau of Justice Statistics and made public today.

title: BILL TAKES NEW LOOK AT COUPLES
description: Last Wednesday State Senator Bill Sarpalius introduced a bill that would prohibit any state official from hiring anyone with whom he or she ''cohabits.'' This was defined as living with ''another adult of the opposite sex in a relationship that resembles a husband and wife relationship.''

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Change at Playtex Is Called a Surprise
description: Turmoil continues at the top of International Playtex, a key segment of Beatrice Companies' consumer products group.

title: FRONTIER TO WEIGH OFFER FOR AIRLINE
description: Today the directors of Frontier Holdings Inc. are expected to consider a $200 million offer by a consortium of investors to buy the outstanding common stock of Frontier Airlines, the company's financially troubled subsidiary.

title: FED DEBATES A CHART'S SHAPE
description: A long- simmering and highly technical debate over the way the Federal Reserve presents its monetary targets has burst almost overnight from arcane professional journals into the high-stakes arena of practical economic policymaking.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNEY: IT'S NOT ONLY WHO, BUT WHERE
description: IF he must leave the city on basketball

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: When Kelly Hrudey of the Islanders and John Vanbiesbrouck of the Rangers became involved in a fight late in the second period of a game two weeks ago, both received game misconduct penalties and were replaced by the teams' other goaltenders, Billy Smith and Glen Hanlon. If either Hanlon or Smith had been injured or ejected, would the starting goalie have been permitted back in the game?

title: Muir Cornelius Moore Chosen by Thrift Unit
description: Muir Cornelius Moore, which specializes in financial advertising, has landed the account of Northeast Savings of Hartford, an institution that operates in Connecticut, upper New York State and Massachusetts.

title: For Now, Japanese See Little to Cause Concern
description: If the strong dollar has prompted head-shaking all over Europe, it has caused little more than a bit of tut-tutting here.

title: A NEW PRIDE SURGES OVER ST. JOHN'S U.
description: It was the morning after the Redmen of St. John's University had been defeated by Georgetown University, ending the glorious 19-game winning streak that had made them the nation's No. 1 college basketball team and the pride of all New York.

title: SELMA MARCHERS MARK 1965 CLASH
description: More than 2,500 people paraded through the streets of this river city today, retracing the route of a group whose protest march 20 years ago marked a turning point in the movement for black voting rights in the South.

title: POP: RON TOWERS AT FREDDY'S
description: RON TOWERS, a crooner whose musical personality is still largely unformed, is a vocalist torn in several directions. Mr. Towers, who appeared at Freddy's through Saturday night, has a light pop baritone with a modest range that he tends to push beyond its limits, and he is hindered by a medicore trio of bass, drums, and piano that undercuts his more appealing qualities with crude, slogging arrangements.

title: Seagram Picks Agency For Special Campaign
description: With growth in the liquor industry hard-hit as a health-conscious society turns from spirits to lighter drinks, the House of Seagram is preparing to put an undisclosed amount of millions of dollars behind an ad compaign to educate the public to its way of thinking - that there is no more alcohol, glass for glass, in a highball than in wine or beer.

title: No Headline
description: A threatened strike by Hartford public school teachers was called off today, but the teachers union said it would sue if a disputed contract was not ratified.

title: RECITAL: ZOLTAN KOCSIS
description: SUNDAY afternoon concerts tend to be relaxed, easy-going affairs, specifically designed to place few demands on an audience. Therefore the pianist Zoltan Kocsis deserves some credit for bravery; his Sunday program at Town Hall, part of the People's Symphony Concerts, contained two hours of substantial, challenging music - without a guaranteed crowdpleaser on the bill.

title: THE END AND THE BEGINNING
description: THOSE engaged in higher education are about to enter a period known as ''March Madness,'' which in the ''doo-wop'' days not long ago meant a spring break spent on Florida beaches and the inspiration for movies such as ''Where the Boys Are.'' Now, where the boys and girls are, and for that matter, where the money is, are the various sites for the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

title: MCHALE SCORES 56, A RECORD FOR CELTICS
description: Kevin McHale set a club record with 56 points, and Larry Bird, who had held the previous mark, sparked a fourth- quarter surge as the Boston Celtics defeated the Detroit Pistons today, 138-129.

title: Fire in Recording Studio
description: A fire on Saturday swept through a recording studio used by rock music stars, causing more than $3 million in damage. The fire, at the Caribou Ranch, may have been started by an electric heater, Detective Pittman Orr of the sheriff's office said.

title: West Germans Uneasy, But Trade Is Booming
description: At an economic policy meeting of the opposition Social Democrats last week, former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt called for Western European nations to join forces to combat United States interest-rate and deficit policies that he said were creating a dollar overvalued by about 30 percent, draining needed capital from European industry and dramatically worsening the debt situation in Latin America.

title: Economic Calendar Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.
description: Monday

title: Beefed-Up Bet
description: He will earn at least $335,000 this season under the contract that he signed the other day, and so it might seem unlikely that Dwight Gooden would ever wonder where his next meal was coming from.

title: Training on the Job
description: Between the time he won a silver medal in the decathlon at the 1956 Olympics and a gold medal at the 1960 Games, Rafer Johnson helped support himself by doing odd jobs at a peach cannery.

title: STAGE: IN CAMBRIDGE, WILSON'S 'CIVIL WARS'
description: The American Repertory Theater production of two and a half hours' worth of Robert Wilson's ''Civil Wars: A Tree Is Best Measured When It Is Down'' marks the first time a major portion of that massive, still-uncompleted work has been staged in his native country. It is also the first new large- scale Wilson work of any sort to have been done in the United States since ''Einstein on the Beach'' in 1976; the first collaboration between Mr. Wilson and an established American theater company, and the first time his work has been offered for the bemused contemplation of a regular subscription audience.

title: COLLEGES REVISING GUIDELINES FOR DISTRIBUTING AID TO STUDENTS
description: Like dozens of selective private colleges across the country, the College of Wooster in Ohio has prided itself on admitting freshmen without regard to financial circumstances and then providing needy students with equivalent packages of financial aid.

title: CURRENT FILM HEROES ARE ADRIFT IN ALIEN CULTURES
description: A HERO exploring foreign territory, adrift in an alien culture: The theme isn't new, but its prevalence in recent films is extraordinary. In settings from South Africa (''The Gods Must Be Crazy'') to Southern California (''Beverly Hills Cop'') from India (''A Passage to India'') to Harlem (''The Brother From Another Planet'') to rural Pennsylvania (''Witness''), current screen characters are seen wandering as outsiders through worlds they don't entirely comprehend.

title: 4th Person Sought In Slaying of 3
description: Brooklyn detectives yesterday were trying to identify the last suspect still at large in a shooting and stabbing rampage at the home of a reputed drug dealer.

title: NKOMO ACCUSES ZIMBABWE OF AN EFFORT TO RIG ELECITON
description: Joshua Nkomo, the beleaguered opposition leader of Zimbabwe, accused the authorities today of seeking to demoralize and ''dehumanize'' his followers in the troubled western areas of the country in order to rob him of votes in elections scheduled for later this year.

title: NAILING SANCTUARY-GIVERS
description: The Reagan Administration has unleashed its full fury against a group of church workers in Arizona and Texas who have chosen as a matter of religious conscience to provide sanctuary to Central American refugees, primarily from El Salvador and Guatemala. Two people were tried and convicted in Houston last month for conspiracy to violate immigration laws; 16 others have been indicted in Phoenix on charges of smuggling, transporting and harboring illegal aliens.

title: GEORGETOWN ROLLS
description: Four years ago, Patrick Ewing entered Georgetown University with a shy demeanor, a massive wing span and the potential to become one of the most intimidating forces in college basketball. He has long since reached that potential, and this afternoon the 1984- 85 Georgetown team joined him.

title: Pan Am Domestic Trips Still Grounded in Strike
description: Pan American World Airways said again yesterday that it was trying to operate 40 percent of its scheduled international flights serving the United States, as a strike by the Transport Workers Union continued.

title: In Jamaica, Our Aid ;   Worsens the Trouble
description: To the Editor:

title: Renewed Jobless Aid in Doubt
description: Despite a big push now under way in Congress, chances are not considered bright for extending a Federal unemployment benefits program for the long-term jobless beyond its March 31 expiration.

title: Evans and His Links
description: Michael Evans, the personal photographer to President Reagan, will be leaving the White House later this month to devote full time to his photographic studio in Washington. He covered Mr. Reagan's unsuccessful bid for President in 1976 and was one of the first people hired for the White House staff when President Reagan took office in January 1981.

title: TWO DODGERS ON A MISSION
description: VERO BEACH, Fla.

title: SUTTER-LESS CARDS OPTIMISTIC
description: Is there life after Bruce Sutter? Whitey Herzog, manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, conceded today that they were about to find out. And he said that the keys to survival were Neil Allen and Jack Clark.

title: 7th Death From Heroin Reported in Washington
description: A 27-year-old District of Columbia man has become the seventh fatality reported from heroin overdosing in the Washington area, the police said today.

title: Family Tradition
description: It has been more than 12 years since Roberto Clemente lost his life when his transport plane crashed into the sea off Puerto Rico just after takeoff on a mercy mission to Central America.

title: 'WALL STREET'S PRIVATE EYE'
description: While churchgoers in Bartlesville, Okla., in December were sending up prayers to preserve the independence of the Phillips Petroleum Company, lawyers for the oil giant were resorting to a more down-to-earth tactic: hiring a detective agency, Kroll Associates of New York, to uncover anything that might prove damaging to Phillips's nemesis, T. Boone Pickens.

title: NEW PLAN IS OFFERED BY PHILLIPS
description: Conceding that its recapitalization plan had failed to win shareholder approval, the embattled Phillips Petroleum Company last night offered a new proposal to its shareholders in an effort to remain independent.

title: 5-PART SERIES ON 'TODAY' LOOKS AT VIETNAM
description: -part report on NBC's ''Today'' suggests that high spirits, good works and incipient capitalism flourish. Does this mean the reports tilt toward America's old adversaries? Well, yes and no, and if this is equivocal, so are the reports. Don't dismiss them for that, however; they are fascinating pieces of work.

title: Ads Help Grace Open Home Decorating Units
description: Last week, with the proper advertising support, the Retail Group of W. R. Grace & Company opened up the first two units in its Home Quarters Warehouse, a proposed chain of state-of-the-art home decorating centers.

title: MINERS IN BRITAIN END LONG STRIKE WITHOUT ACCORD
description: Britain's coal miners called off their turbulent strike today, almost a year after it began, and will return to their jobs on Tuesday.

title: Kemp and His Links
description: Representative Jack Kemp of upstate New York has made no secret of the fact that he may seek the Republican nomination for President in 1988.

title: NEW CBS FILM FOCUSES ON CHILD MOLESTATION
description: ''KIDS DON'T TELL'' is a television movie that is something of an earnest documentary in search of a workable film script. The production, on CBS at 9 this evening, tackles the subject of child molestation with the sincere horror that the subject demands, but it fails to translate its feelings into dramatic clout. Two admirable performances by Michael Ontkean and JoBeth Williams are left floating in an interesting but meandering sea of statistics and case histories.

title: Extradition of Yugoslav Is Ordered but Stayed
description: A Federal magistrate today ordered Andrija Artukovic extradited to Yugoslavia, but specified that Mr. Artukovic, who is accused of helping the Nazis carry out war crimes, could be tried for only one murder.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 5, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Overseas Credit Sought by Sears
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that it had awarded a mandate to Dean Witter Capital Markets International, one of its financial services subsidiaries, to arrange a $500 million revolving underwriting facility.

title: Insurer Loss Seen
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. said that it expects to report a ''significant fourth-quarter loss'' and that it intends to sell the underwriting companies acquired as part of the Alexander Howden Group.

title: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $149,133. The year-earlier quarter's figures were restated to reflect discontinuation of Tri-Med subsidiary.

title: PACE QUICKENS IN CREATING OF VACCINE FOR GONORRHEA
description: THE bacteria called gonococci are among the most feared agents of human infection. They cause gonorrhea and, through that sexually transmitted disease, produce an immense amount of human misery including pain, social stigma, sterility in men, infertility and other serious gynecologic problems in women, and sometimes permanent harm to newborn infants.

title: Reagans Mark Anniversary
description: President and Mrs. Reagan today marked their 33d wedding anniversary with a quiet luncheon in the Oval Office.

title: SUPERSWEETENER FOUND
description: The three-dimensional structure of the sweetest substance known to man has been determined, a feat that promises to shed light on how the molecules of some substances interact with human taste buds to produce the sensation of sweetness.

title: EXCERPTS FROM WHITE HOUSE REPORT ON THE MX
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's report to Congress on continuing the acquisition of the MX missile, which the Administration calls the Peacekeeper, issued today by the White House:

title: OVERCOMING OBSTACLES IN A STUDENT'S HOME
description: JOYCE R. COPPIN, a school district superintendent in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood, where she began teaching 27 years ago in an elementary school, recently ran into one of her former pupils while visiting a school.

title: CANADA'S TRENDY BOOMTOWN: WHO'S FOR QUICHE?
description: It's enough to make a grizzled prospector choke on his caribou steak. They're peddling capucchino and bagels to customers down at the Float Base Cafe.

title: The Mob's Weak Spot: The Wallet Here they come again, the aging mobsters of New York. Flanked by bodyguards and lawyers, they quickstep through a media gantlet at the courthouse, snarling for reporters, fending off cameras with umbrellas and coats.
description: Some dismiss such scenes as self-promotion for prosecutors. Top mafiosi may be indicted, but with the best lawyers they often avoid conviction. At worst they might post a few million for bail, perhaps serve a short prison term - minor irritations.

title: REPCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $92,000 for the quarter and $261,000 for the year. c-Net loss.

title: FARMERS RALLY IN WASHINGTON
description: About 700 Middle Western grain farmers rallied at the Agriculture Department and the White House today, demanding higher guaranteed prices for their products and strict controls on production. Participants said they want to see both provisions included in farm legislation this year.

title: Boeing Drops Request For a Reimbursement
description: The Boeing Company billed the American taxpayers for at least $126,847 in 1982 political contributions, adding the cost to the price of weapons systems it built for the Pentagon. But the company abruptly withdrew the request for reimbursement within hours after the billing was publicly disclosed.

title: BRIEFS
U.S. AND ISRAEL SET PACT TO END TARIFFS BY 1995
description: All tariffs between the United States and Israel would be eliminated within 10 years under an agreement the two countries have just concluded - the first free-trade pact that Washington has reached with any country, Administration trade officials said today.

title: Computer Consortium Backed
description: The Justice Department, in its strongest endorsement yet of corporate cooperation in research and development projects, said yesterday that it would not challenge the activities of the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation, a consortium of 20 major computer companies.

title: TEXTRON TO SELL BELL HELICOPTER
description: Textron Inc. today put up for sale its Bell Helicopter subsidiary, a mainstay of the conglomerate for two decades.

title: JACKSON NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net realized investment gains of $2,086,058 for the quarter and $1,677,297 for the year. c-After net realized investment gains of $455,576 for the quarter and $1,253,139 for the year The latest year net also includes a tax credit of $15,037,000.

title: Blood-Boosting Ban
description: Blood boosting will be banned by the International Olympic Committee before the 1988 Winter Games in Calgary, the chairman of the committee's medical commission said yesterday.

title: Officer Cleared In Driver's Death
description: A Bronx grand jury decided yesterday not to indict a city police officer who had shot and killed a man driving a stolen car.

title: DOROTHY W. NEWMARK
description: Dorothy Wood Newmark, the widow of Joseph M. Newmark, the former president of Atlantic Cruise Lines, died of a heart attack Friday at Mt.

title: Management Shifts at Airbus PARIS, March 4 (AP) -
description: Jean Pierson, a senior executive of France's state-owned

title: BRUCE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings are not reported for the year-ago periods since the company went public in November 1984.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary yesterday of Sarah G. Blanding, a former president of Vassar College, incorrectly identified the British economist Harold J. Laski, with whom she studied. Mr. Laski was an assistant to Clement R. Attlee when Mr. Attlee (not Mr. Laski) was Winston S. Churchill's Deputy Prime Minister, from 1942 to 1945.

title: 20 Million Hungry People
description: A team of physicians toured the country in 1979 looking for hunger. They found almost none. Federal nutrition efforts had eliminated most of the gross malnutrition and hunger in America. But it appears that much of that great work has already been undone. According to the Physician Task Force on Hunger in America, which toured the country for 10 months last year, at least 20 million Americans now know hunger.

title: Johnson Buying Hoover Universal
description: Johnson Controls Inc., an electronic instruments company based in Milwaukee, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Hoover Universal Inc., a diversified manufacturing concern, in a transaction valued at about $490 million.

title: MAGNETIC CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
FAMILY PLAYS A CRUCIAL ROLE
description: WHEN Murray P. Haydon's family learned that his failing heart would keep him alive only a few more days, his son, Derek, asked his father's cardiologist, Dr. Jerome P. Lacy: ''Is this it? Is Dad going to die? Is there nothing we can do for Dad?''

title: STOP & SHOP COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: The latest quarter represents 13 weeks of operations compared with 12 weeks for the year-ago quarter. The 1985 year represents 53 weeks of operations compared with 52 weeks for the 1984 year.

title: CHICAGO RIVET & MACHINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
West Virginia Pollution Bonds
description: Mason County in West Virginia offered $30 million of 28-year pollution control bonds for the Appalachian Power Company yesterday.

title: BIOGRAPHY OF ALLARD LOWENSTEIN CHALLENGED
description: A new biography of former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein asserts that the late civil-rights and antiwar activist had worked for the Central Intelligence Agency. Those assertions are being challenged by Lowenstein family friends and lawyers, who tried unsuccessfully to obtain changes before publication.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Well-Known Money Raiser
description: Why has a longtime member of a

title: SUPREME COURT UPHOLDS CLAIM BY ONEIDA INDIANS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that two upstate New York counties were liable to three tribes of Oneida Indians for the unlawful 18th-century seizure of their ancestral lands.

title: Hundreds Flee Fires In Galapagos Islands
description: Brush fires have burned for three days on one of the Galapagos Islands, the site of rare plant and animal species, the islands' Governor, Washington Freire, said today.

title: Georgia Bonds Yield 5.5% to 9.7%
description: Dekalb County of Georgia offered $62.1 million of water and sewer revenue bonds yesterday.

title: Prosecutor Meets With IRT Victim
description: The prosecutor who is considering reopening the Bernhard H. Goetz case held a private meeting late yesterday with one of the four young men shot by Mr. Goetz.

title: On Readers Per Copy
description: In seemingly lighthearted fashion, the

title: MARCOS OUSTS FOREIGN MINISTER
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, in an apparent move to still signs of dissent within the Government, removed his Foreign Minister today and rebuked his Minister of Labor.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
STATE DEPT. OFFICIAL TO LET STAFF TALK TO TIMES CORRESPONDENT
description: The director of the State Department's Bureau of Politico-Military Affairs said today that he had decided to lift an order forbidding members of his bureau to talk to a correspondent for The New York Times.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Resources Chairman May Fight a Takeover
description: For years, Arthur R. Seder Jr. has carried in his wallet a tattered card imprinted with the letters of a standard military eye chart. He got it after he failed the vision test to become a bomber pilot in World War II.

title: TANAKA'S ILLNESS MAY UNSETTLE JAPANESE POLITICS
description: Doctors announced tonight that former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka, the most powerful figure in Japanese politics, had suffered a more serious stroke than initially suspected.

title: Spaceship Payload Removed
description: Two satellites were removed from the space shuttle Challenger's cargo bay, including a possibly defective one that caused the cancellation of a mission that was scheduled last Thursday.

title: Criminal Onus On Executives
description: Two years ago, a worker at the Film Recovery

title: MAVERICKS' BID TO DRAFT EWING WANES
description: In 1980-81, their first season as an expansion franchise, the Dallas Mavericks had a roster consisting mostly of castoffs, including several journeymen centers. That same season, Patrick Ewing was a highly-recruited senior playing center at Rindge & Latin High School in Cambridge, Mass.

title: THE CITY ;   Main Break HaltsWest Side Subway
description: A broken water main on the Upper West Side halted subway service on several lines yesterday, delaying tens of thousands of riders during the morning rush.

title: VAN DORN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MILITARY PENSION STUDY FINDS AFFLUENT GET BULK OF BENEFITS
description: Most military retirement benefits go to a ''relatively small and elite group'' of the nation's veterans who live in the wealthiest fifth of American households, according to a private study issued today.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
TENNIS STAR'S MANSION IS DESTROYED BY ARSON
description: A fire set by arsonists virtually destroyed a 52-room mansion here that had been purchased last year by Ivan Lendl, the professional tennis player, the authorities said today.

title: Taiwan Takes Charge of Bank
description: The Government of Taiwan took control of the nation's largest bank today to stem a run by depositors who have withdrawn the equivalent of $383.1 million in the last three weeks.

title: ZAYRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PROCEDURES TO IDENTIFY BODIES ARE CRITICIZED
description: The state and city reports on the Medical Examiner's office were both critical of procedures for handling people required to identify relatives who have died. Many are kept waiting, treated callously or exposed to unnecessary trauma, the reports said.

title: FOR CRAXI, BAGELS, LOX AND CUOMO
description: ''Hey, what do you know? It's the President of France,'' one construction worker yelled to another as they watched a motorcade of limousines and police cars get stuck in traffic on East 49th Street.

title: Bush in the Sudan 'On a Pilgrimage'
description: Vice President Bush arrived here today for a seven-day journey through some of the most drought-scorched parts of Africa.

title: NEW-HOME SALES RISE WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) - New-home sales climbed 2.6 percent in January, the second consecutive monthly increase, and the median price of a new home soared by the highest percentage in almost 20 years, the Government said today.
description: New single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 620,000 units in January, according to the Commerce Department and the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: BRIEFS
description: Bobbie Brooks Inc. said it had reached an agreement with Pubco Corp. for Pubco to buy 48 percent of Bobbie Brooks common stock for cash. The agreement is subject to approval by Bobbie Brooks shareholders.

title: Argentine Military Chief Quits Over Budget Cuts
description: The armed forces Chief of Staff, Julio Fernandez Torres, resigned today to protest cuts in Argentina's military budget.

title: 2 INVESTIGATIONS SHARPLY CRITICAL OF CITY CORONER
description: The state and the city issued reports yesterday sharply criticizing the management of the New York City Medical Examiner's office for what the state report called ''serious shortcomings in virtually all critical areas of its operation.''

title: Colorado Issue
description: Arvada, Colo., offered $30.1 million of general obligation bonds at competitive bid yesterday.

title: TACKLING THE TEXTBOOK ISSUE
description: TEXTBOOKS were under fire long before the present clamor for better schools began. But the current drive to improve education has given new impetus to the push for textbook reform. Now a committee of leading public school administrators is tackling the issue.

title: POLITICAL ASYLUM: THE FRENCH REFLECT
description: The family of Kadim Latifi, a former cook at the American Embassy in Afghanistan, recently spent eight days in a transit lounge at Orly Airport here trying to win admission to France as political refugees.

title: BLAST IN LEBANON KILLS 15 IN MOSQUE
description: A huge explosion thought to have been caused by a bomb destroyed a Shiite mosque in Israeli-occupied southern Lebanon today, killing at least 15 people, the police reported.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IT'S always a treat to find a designer with a totally individual approach who doesn't follow the whims of fashion yet manages to make clothes with an undeniable chic. Louis DeLuca of DeLuca-Simone is one of these. In his little shop and workroom in SoHo, he has put together a small collection of tailored clothing for men and women, adding a few things each season.

title: WINCOM CORP reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
A NEVER-ENDING GAME: MUSICAL PERQUISITES
description: When there is change in the White House staff, insiders watch for two fateful omens of fading power and status. One is someone's name suddenly showing up on the President's schedule for a farewell photograph. The other is an official being moved to the fourth floor of the Executive Office Building, the gray baroque structure next door.

title: TALKS ON BASEBALL REMAIN UNCERTAIN
description: Don Baylor, the American League union representative, was talking today about the slow pace of labor negotiations. ''You can miss four or five meetings,'' he said, ''then show up and you haven't missed a thing.''

title: Ad Measuring Service Has Name Changed
description: Interactive Market Systems is changing the name of its two-year-old Publishers Advertising Reports unit to Leading National Advertisers, the name of a 37-year-old company it acquired in December 1983.

title: Showboat Rally Beats Bulls, 24-14
description: Walter Lewis, the Showboats' quarterback, brought Memphis alive in the second half, running for two touchdowns and throwing for another to gain a 24-14 victory tonight over the Jacksonville Bulls in a United States Football League game.

title: COURT BACKS PROSECUTION ON CONFESSION ISSUE IN MIRANDA RULE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that if the police fail at first to advise a suspect of his Miranda rights, it does not necessarily make a later confession inadmissible in court, if the warnings are properly given in the meantime.

title: TIE/COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $303,000 for the quarter and $1,362,000 for the year. c-Includes extraordinary income of $13,000,000.

title: 2 POSNER COMPANIES IN DIFFICULTY
description: Two companies controlled by Victor Posner, the Miami financier, reported financial troubles yesterday.

title: A WALTER MITTY OF MAPS
description: In winter, John A. Wolter can bake among the maps of Guadeloupe. In summer, he can cool off with a cartographical jaunt to Gstaad.

title: REDMEN SEEKING AN EDGE
description: Lou Carnesecca had given the team a day off on Sunday, and now, yesterday, after a brief film session and a short chalk talk, he set the captives free again.

title: ZONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $35,870 from the sale of an office. c-Net loss.

title: HINES, EDWARD LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $8.6 million and a reduction of a tax benefit of $186,000. c-After a tax benefit of $271,000. d-After income from discontinued operations of $8.6 million and a tax benefit of $1,725,000. e-After income from discontinued operations of $5.5 million and a tax benefit of $1.5 million.

title: Owens-Illinois, Charter Medical
description: The Charter Medical Corporation said that the board of Health Group Inc. had agreed to sell substantially all Health Group assets to Charter and Owens-Illinois Inc.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Celtics , at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. The Knicks have not managed to win a game in four attempts against the Celtics this season.

title: Pan Am and Unionists Seem Set for Long Strike
description: Both Pan American World Airways and the Transport Workers Union appeared to be digging in for a long strike yesterday as managers staffed terminals and planes while other unions continued to remain outside picket lines.

title: PENN ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MX MOMENTUM LEANING TO PASSAGE
description: Congressional leaders said today that the momentum on Capitol Hill now seemed to be moving in favor of the Administration's request to release $1.5 billion to produce 21 MX missiles.

title: Troopers Find Effects Of a Missing Woman
description: The state police, during a routine burglary investigation, found belongings of a missing Mount Vernon woman in a vacation cabin in the Catskills today, officials said.

title: NORLIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,071,000 for the quarter and $16,034,000 for the year, and extraordinary losses of $1,900,000 for the quarter and $3,092,000 for the year. c-Net income after a loss of $8,071,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $14,000,000. d-After a loss of $15,581,000 from discontinued operations. e-The company did not report sales for the year-ago periods because in 1984 it decided to get out of its musical instrument business, which was its only operation in 1983. Norlin acquired Charles P. Young Co., a financial printer, at the end of 1983. This acquisition was the source of all 1984 sales. Sales for 1983 were reclassified under discontinued operations.

title: Zapped by 'Star Wars'
description: Daniel Graham resigned last month from the Office of Technology Assessment's advisory board on the proposed Strategic Defense Initiative. In a parting statement, the retired Army lieutenant general criticized the O.T.A., a research arm of Congress that is studying the project, as being biased against the ''Star Wars'' proposal.

title: EX-DEFENSE DEPUTY ENTERS A GUILTY PLEA IN STOCK TRADE CASE
description: W. Paul Thayer, former Deputy Secretary of Defense, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court here today to obstructing justice by giving false testimony to the Securities and Exchange Commission while it was investigating whether he had engaged in illegal insider stock trading.

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
POLAND INCREASES SOME FOOD PRICES
description: The Government increased the price of food sharply today.

title: Spurs Beat 76ers
description: Artis Gilmore scored 23 points, Mike Mitchell added 20 and Gene Banks contributed 19 tonight as they led the San Antonio Spurs to a 109-103 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: DYNAMICS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CUT LOOSE FROM CHUN
description: In its dealings with third world countries, the Administration has demonstrated a persistent tendency to mistake the weakness of an unpopular allied leader for a crisis in the society he rules - to mistake an unstable regime for an unstable nation. This conceptual muddle explains why so much of America's prestige and power has so often seemed tied to the uncertain future of an unpopular dictator. Our policy in South Korea is a case in point.

title: F.C.C. Bars Complaint Against CBS Broadcast
description: Two weeks after Gen. William C. Westmoreland's libel suit against CBS was settled out of court, the Federal Communications Commission today dismissed a complaint by the American Legal Foundation that CBS News deliberately distorted and falsified a documentary on enemy troop strength in Vietnam.

title: Eastern Plans Special Fare
description: Eastern Airlines will offer one-way transcontinental fares of $98 on special predawn flights, starting April 1.

title: ADVANCE CIRCUITS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 23
Bridge:Bermudans Lead Mexicans In Competition in Montreal
description: A startling upset seemed in prospect in Montreal last night in the three-cornered playoffs to determine a team to compete in the 1985 World Team Championships. The winners will join the United States as the North American representatives in the Bermuda Bowl contest in Sao Paulo, Brazil, in October.

title: NUMAC OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of U.S. reserves amounting to $11,514,350.

title: President Adds a Post At Anderson Clayton
description: Anderson Clayton & Company said it had named its president, W. Fenton Guinee Jr., to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective April 1. He will succeed T.J. Barlow, 62, who will remain chairman of the Houston-based food products company.

title: 3 Coaches Indicted
description: A Pickens County (S.C.) grand jury returned misdemeanor indictments against three former Clemson coaches yesterday for illegal possession and distribution of prescription drugs. The three former coaches indicted were

title: E.P.A. ORDERS 90 PERCENT CUT IN LEAD CONTENT OF GASOLINE BY 1986
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it was considering a total ban on leaded gasoline by 1988. It issued final rules for removing 90 percent of the lead currently in automobile fuel by the end of this year.

title: DRUG TESTING OF CONTROLLERS AND F.A.A. PILOTS IS URGED
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has recommended that regular tests for drug use be given to air traffic controllers and others in safety-related jobs in the agency, according to Government officials.

title: SKATER CUTS A FRESH FIGURE
description: On the far end of the Redwood City Ice Lodge, in an area staked out with orange cones, a solitary skater patiently cuts precise figure-8's on the frosty ice. In a rink crowded with children twirling, spinning, jumping to a quasi-jazz arrangement of ''Don't Sit Under the Apple Tree,'' the solitary skater's skill makes her stand out.

title: Why New York Needs Big-Time Football
description: To the Editor:

title: VERMONT LAWYER WINS IN RESIDENCY RULE CASE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that states may not exclude nonresidents from admission to law practice.

title: Not a Model System ;   For Preschool Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: PERFECT FIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'PEACE STUDIES'- HARDLY ACADEMIC
description: The faculty of Arts and Science at New York University recently approved of a ''minor'' status for ''peace studies'' with only one dissent in the faculty vote. This new minor, to be included in the fall curriculum, is expected to evolve into an academic major. Alas, peace studies is the academic liberal's latest effort to impose his brand of peace on an unwary student population.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 5, 1985

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SURVIVING THE ISSUES
description: WHEN Jonathan F. Fanton, president of the New School for Social Research, said that he found in his travels that many Americans were wilfully turning their backs on national and foreign policy issues, he touched a nerve. Ordinary citizens spoke up not to defend themselves or their communities but to agree.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The mass transit Federal subsidy is another head shaker. In Miami, the $1 billion subsidy helped build a system that serves less than 10,000 daily riders.

title: Indomitable 10-Year-Old
description: Lisa Olson was pretty excited after a

title: Northeastern
description: Northeastern International Airlines was grounded when a bankruptcy judge ordered the carrier to return its four Boeing 727 passenger planes to Guiness Peat Aviation, its aircraft leasing company.

title: Banking Merger Set in Carolina
description: The First Union Corporation and the Northwestern Financial Corporation - North Carolina's third- and fourth-largest banking companies, respectively - have agreed to merge. The merger, which would give the new company combined assets of more than $10 billion, would involve a stock transaction valued at about $300 million, according to First Union's treasurer, Bob Lee.

title: LYNCH COMMUNICATIONS SYSEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $355,000, or 11 cents a share, related to the discontinuance of the company's Atlas product line.

title: Aquino Witness Reappears
description: The first civilian witness to dispute the military version of the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. in 1983 emerged from hiding today and testified at the trial of the armed forces chief, Gen. Fabian C. Ver, and 25 others.

title: A Bach Pilgrimage
description: When the sun rises on March 21 in Eisenach, East Germany, where Johann Sebastian Bach was born, members of the Washington Bach Consort will be there to wish their favorite composer a happy 300th birthday. Seventy-two singers and instrumentalists from the Consort are making the pilgrimage and will perform at the International Bach Festival, the only American musicicans invited to do so by the East German Government.

title: Mostek Plans Layoffs for 620
description: The Mostek Corporation, citing the continuing downturn in the semiconductor industry, said that it would lay off 500 employees at its Carrollton, Tex., headquarters and 120 workers at its Colorado Springs wafer fabrication facility.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tim Mayotte , who recently won his first professional men's tennis tournament last month in Delray Beach, Fla., was named the Nabisco Grand Prix player of the month for February. . . .

title: THE STAGE: ANNALS OF A DELI
description: ''NORTHERN BOULEVARD'' sets itself the Herculean task of merging two ill-matched forms - the sprawling family saga and the chirpy, old-fashioned musical comedy. In telling the history of a Queens delicatessen, this bulky, overweight musical, at the AMAS Repertory Theater, glosses 40 years of social history, beginning just before the bombing of Pearl Harbor and ending in 1981. Over the course of its 13 scenes, all of them set in Simon's Delicatessen, we watch the price of bologna skyrocket, hear how the neighborhood is changing, and follow the fortunes of its proprietors, Jerry and Rosalyn Simon (Morgan Mackay and Alice Cannon), from marriage to retirement.

title: Smell Anything?
description: A recent news release from the Department of Agriculture has a faint aroma of politics.

title: Put-Upon Presidents
description: To the Editor:

title: VOGART CRAFTS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 1
MEETING OF ANZUS ALLIANCE IS POSTPONED
description: The United States, in its latest move to press New Zealand to lift a ban on warships capable of carrying nuclear weapons, won agreement from Australia today to postpone indefinitely any further meetings of the three-nation Anzus alliance.

title: Vietnam Scraps Tour Of Refugee Camps
description: Vietnam, saying it ''could not cope'' with all the foreigners asking to visit Vietnam before the 10th anniversary of the capture of Saigon next month, has called off a United Nations-sponsored press visit to refugee sites in Vietnam, according to United Nations officials.

title: IRAQ ASKS PRISONER EXCHANGE
description: The Foreign Minister of Iraq urged the Security Council today to arrange an exchange of prisoners between Iran and Iraq.

title: TRUMPET SKIRTS: A BREEZY 30'S FASHION SHAPE
description: The gentle winds of the last few weeks have stirred up one of the breeziest fashion shapes seen on New York City's streets in a while: long trumpet-shaped skirts that are snugly fitted from waist to the top of knee, then flare out dramatically below. Godets, a dressmaker's staple, create the circular hem.

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
9 Freed in Ethiopia By Armed Rebels
description: Five French Air Force crewmen, abducted by armed rebels when their plane landed with tons of food for famine victims, were released unharmed today and flew back to Addis Ababa.

title: FRASER WELCOMES A TAKEOVER BID BY EGYPTIANS
description: The House of Fraser, the retailing group that owns Harrods department store, today welcomed a $658 million takeover bid from the wealthy Egyptian family that is its largest shareholder.

title: THIRD BASE IS STILL A PUZZLE FOR THE METS
description: Ray Knight, No. 77 in the long line of third basemen in the Mets' history, has something in common with Howard Johnson, who is No. 78: In 1985, both want to be No. 1.

title: REAGAN RENEWS ATTACK, CALLS TAX CODE 'UNFAIR'
description: President Reagan, in his sharpest criticism of the nation's tax system, today pressed his demand for a tax overhaul and called the current code ''unfair, inequitable, counterproductive and all but incomprehensible.''

title: ANTHONY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $982,000 from the sale of property. c-After a gain from discontinued operations of $195,000. The share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in December 1984.

title: 4,700 POOR FAMILIES TO GET VOUCHERS TOWARD RENT
description: Some poor families in New York City and New Jersey will be able to shop for their own housing with the help of Government vouchers, under a pilot project approved by the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: DRESSED IN A WALTZING MODE
description: What came first - the ball gown or the Viennese ball? Both have become popular on the New York social scene of late, and no one is quite sure if one led to the other. But if there had been no Viennese ball planned by the New York Philharmonic for May, there would have been no fashion show of ball gowns at Saks Fifth Avenue last week.

title: CONCHEMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-After a gain of $370,000 on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Chess Cheats in Moscow
description: What was initially a suspicion now seems a high probability - that the Soviet Union twisted the rules twice to save an exhausted world chess champion from a humiliating defeat. To Americans, that's a matter of more than passing consequence.

title: FOREST OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest year net included a gain of $1,783,000, or 28 cents a share, from an over-estimated liability in 1983 for refunds relative to a federal energy regulatory commission ruling. The prior year net was reduced by $3,480,000, or 54 cents a share, from the estimated liability.

title: BEN ROSENBERG
description: Ben Rosenberg, a theatrical manager and producer on Broadway, died of a heart attack Sunday at Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 73 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Fort Lauderdale.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about St. John's University misidentified two graduates of its law school, Herbert B. Evans and Joseph W. Bellacosa. Mr. Evans is in private law practice and Mr. Bellacosa is Chief Administrator of the New York State courts.

title: SOUTHERN MINERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $69,000. c-Net loss. Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid Jan. 4.

title: U.S.F.L. Gets Luther
description: Ed Luther , for five years the backup to

title: Hundreds of Cars Splattered With a Purple Dye in Jersey
description: Several hundred motorists found their cars splattered with a pinkish purple dye yesterday after they drove down a stretch of U.S. Route 22 in New Jersey where a truck spilled an indelible dye onto the road, the police said.

title: Dailey Accepts Penalty
description: Quintin Dailey , the Chicago Bulls guard who was suspended for two games for missing a practice, intends to take his punishment and return to the team after the suspension, his attorney,

title: Candy Could Help Dieter, Study Says
description: A candy bar or an English muffin added to a low-calorie diet daily would satisfy the brain's need for carbohydrates and could help many fat people lose weight, a researcher says.

title: Two French Film Stars Receive Caesar Awards
description: Alain Delon won the best actor award and Sabine Azema the best actress honors Saturday night at the 10th annual presentation of the Caesar trophies to members of the French film industry.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 5, 1985 International

title: MARKET PLACE ;   Magellan Fund Strong on Cars
description: Peter Lynch owns an eight-year-old Concord made by American Motors. But when it comes to automobile stocks, his mutual fund, he says, ''owns practically everything that rolls down the road.''

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
GROVE SOLD TO ANN GETTY AND BRITISH PUBLISHER
description: Grove Press, the iconoclastic publishing house that brought Samuel Beckett, Jean Genet and Bertolt Brecht to American readers, has been sold to a company headed by Ann Getty, the wife of an heir to the Getty oil fortune, and George Weidenfeld, the British publisher.

title: JEFFREY MARTIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
REAGAN ASKS VOTE FOR MX FINANCING TO AID ARMS TALKS
description: President Reagan today formally asked Congress to release funds to continue the MX missile program, saying the missiles were critical to the success of arms control talks beginning in Geneva next week.

title: THE DANCE: TWO WORKS PRESENTED BY SOLOMONS
description: G US SOLOMONS Jr. has never followed the crowd, but his wise and wry perspective was blurred in two typically varied dances presented by the Solomons Company/Dance on Sunday at Symphony Space in the closing performance of the Dancemobile winter series.

title: Pay the Unemployed for Doing Their Bit
description: To the Editor:

title: COMARCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CREDIT MARKETS ;   Bonds Sag in Light Trading
description: Bond prices sagged further in light trading yesterday, as market participants reacted negatively to signs suggesting that a further tightening in monetary policy by the Federal Reserve Board may at hand.

title: ROBOT DEFENSE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago results are for the period beginning May 27, 1983, the date of the company's inception.

title: RESPECT GROWS FOR SKILLS OF NORTHERN INDIANS
description: DAZZLED by the grandeur of the Maya and Inca civilizations to the south, anthropologists have often overlooked or underestimated the achievements of the North American Indians. They stood in awe of Mayan astronomy and calendars, for example, and assumed that the ''skywatchers'' of the northern tribes did little more than plot the seasons.

title: THE STAGE: KATE NELLIGAN IN 'VIRGINIA'
description: WHEN the lights go up on ''Virginia,'' Edna O' Brien's play about Bloomsbury's high priestess, there's a pause during which we see the star, Kate Nelligan, only in silhouette. For that second or two, we worry, as we did last year at ''A Moon for the Misbegotten,'' whether this actress can possibly transform herself into a character that she in no way obviously resembles. Virginia Woolf, after all, may be the most thoroughly (if not excessively) documented literary figure of this century. The audience arrives with a fixed image that is hard to square with the heroines that Miss Nelligan has previously created on New York stages - the chilly and embittered idealist of David Hare's ''Plenty,'' the raucous earth mother of O'Neill's ''Moon.''

title: ALL SHAREHOLDERS TO GET MORE
description: Carl C. Icahn, the multimillionaire New Yorker, called off an $8.1 billion takeover bid for the Phillips Petroleum Company yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Who's Building Is That?

title: Budget Freeze or Flood? If Congress has decided that the budget deficit is not a problem after all, let the House vote quickly today to approve the emergency farm bill. Raising farm subsidies just when fiscal sanity requires cutting them would be a clear declaration that the lid's off. Even if President Reagan then vetoes and is upheld, Congress's irresponsibility would damage all other cost containment.
description: There's no telling what this farm bill would cost, and that's one part of the problem. It's an open-ended ''entitlement,'' authorizing funds for any farmer who qualifies. The sponsors estimate a cost of no more than $500 million over five years. The Administration estimates up to $2 billion in only two years. Either way, it's what the White House has called it: budget-busting.

title: Arthur Andersen
description: Arthur Andersen & Company, the nation's largest accounting firm, said that it was negotiating to bring the SGV Group, an East Asian accounting cooperative with 3,500 personnel, into Andersen's international organization.

title: QUAKE TOLL IN CHILE RISES TO 135
description: The Government imposed a midnight-to-5 A.M. curfew today to prevent looting as aftershocks from an earthquake Sunday continued to rock towns along the coast and in the central valley.

description: A Legal Aid Society lawyer and Greenwich Village Democratic leader said yesterday that she was considering a primary challenge to Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, who has had virtually no opposition in his last two elections.

He later did his running. But now, as the 26-year-old shortstop strolled toward the clubhouse, two Astro security men approached him.

In fact, the ''Frontline'' production is more like an entertainment: Watch the participants while they put together a television program. ''Frontline'' has a good story to tell, but it surrenders to histrionics while it tells it. The program will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 tonight.

title: IONA TOPS RAMS FOR TITLE, 57-54
description: With 61 seconds remaining tonight and the game tied at 54-54, Iona's Arnie Russell found a flaw in Fordham's trapping defense and wound up free underneath for a dunk. Jerry Hobbie prevented the basket by fouling Russell, but the Gaels' best free-throw shooter hit both shots, and Iona went on to win, 57-54, and retain its Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference championship at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: PRIMATE'S AFRICAN CONNECTION
description: ONE of the strangest, smallest and least known of the primates is the tarsier. The size of a small squirrel, it is nocturnal with enormous eyes that help it see in the dark.

title: Kosar Is Undecided
description: Bernie Kosar , the University of Miami quarterback, practiced with the Hurricanes at the team's opening of spring drills yesterday and has put off deciding whether to turn professional for the 1985 National Football League season. Kosar, a 21-year-old sophomore who could graduate by summer, has until April 16 to notify the N.F.L. that he would like to be drafted.

title: STAGE: A NEW MOLIERE
description: TAKING a breather from tragedy and trilogy, the City Stage Company is presenting Moliere's ''George Dandin'' in a new Americanized adaptation by Alex Szogyi. The play, originally staged for the court at Versailles in 1668, is a brief, frolicsome prose comedy about a prosperous peasant who marries a noblewoman and lives to regret his drive to join the upper crust. Poor old George Dandin is not only cuckolded, he is forced to apologize to his wife and her seducer.

title: STATE TO OFFER G.M. 2 SITES FOR A NEW AUTO FACTORY

title: THE BIG WINNERS IN THE PHILLIPS DEAL
description: Although the Phillips Petroleum Company is escaping with its independence intact, the view on Wall Street is that the real winners in the fight for control of the Oklahoma oil giant were Carl C. Icahn, T. Boone Pickens and the Phillips shareholders. By forcing Phillips to sweeten its offer to shareholders, Mr. Icahn proved that he and T. Boone Pickens are an effective one- two punch. Even among those on Wall Street who have not been fans of either, there was unqualified admiration for their ability to come out ahead - and improve the lot of all Phillips shareholders in the process.

The Rainbow 190 costs $6,495, has 640,000 characters of basic memory and a 10 million-character storage disk and will be available in July, Digital said.

At the age of 11, in her seventh year as a competitive runner, she is putting her thoughts on paper and keeping those thoughts in a secret place at her family's home in Brooklyn.

Ross Perot, the Texas computer executive, according to Miss Myerson. Mr. Perot has offered to invest $70 million in the museum if it moves to Dallas. ''It had a positive and constructive atmosphere,'' Miss Myerson said of the meeting.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: EASTERN LORE Favorite Folk Tales of Japan'' is the title of tonight's illustrated lecture presented by the Institute for Asian Studies. Barbara Ruch will discuss fairy tales and ancient story-telling and how they affect the way the Japanese look at the emotions of joy and sorrow. Medieval painted scrolls and books contain a number of these tales, and slides of scroll and book illustrations will be shown, depicting folk heroes and heroines.

title: Uruguay Ends Censorship
description: The new civilian Government declared a formal end today to censorship that the former military regime had imposed on news dispatches sent abroad. Under military rule, which ended with the inauguration of President Julio Maria Sanguinetti last Friday, foreign journalists were required to submit copies or recordings of all dispatches to the Interior Ministry before they could be transmitted.
