description: The Dead Moon,'' an opera for children by Jeffrey Bishop, will be performed by students of the Cathedral School of St. John the Divine today at 6:30 P.M. in Synod Hall at the school, at Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street.

title: NEW DISK BY SMITHS IS A HIT
description: AN album of songs about self- doubt, suicidal depressions, the slaughter of animals to provide meat for our tables, and how the British educational system can stifle human potential doesn't sound much like a commercial proposition. But the album in question, ''Meat Is Murder,'' by the Smiths, was so eagerly awaited in Britain that it

title: STROTH RATES FLUTIE WITH TOP PASSERS
description: When it comes to comparing quarterbacks with million-dollar contracts, Vince Stroth is in a remarkable position. Stroth, the left guard for the Generals, blocked for three of them in college, Marc Wilson, Jim McMahon and Steve Young, and now is protecting a fourth, Doug Flutie.

title: MALRITE COMMUNICATIONS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $375,000 from the disposal of KLBB-AM Radio in Minneapolis. c-Includes a pre-tax gain of $5,500,000 from the disposal of WCTI- TV and income of $727,000 from life insurance proceeds.

title: Bank Move Challenged
description: The Federal Reserve Board said today that it had given a Missouri bank holding company two weeks to justify moving one of its branches from Missouri to Kansas - or face shutting down the Kansas operation. C. Todd Conover, the Comptroller of the Currency, approved the relocation of Mark Twain Bank from Independence, Mo., to Overland Park, Kan., - about 16 miles away - on Feb. 21. In approving the action by Mark Twain Bancshares Inc. of St. Louis, Mr. Conover cited a narrow Federal law allowing national banks to move within a 30-mile radius. The Kansas Bankers Association has opposed the relocation on the ground that it violated both Federal and Kansas state law.

title: SEOUL ENDING BAN ON 14 OPPOSITION FIGURES
description: The South Korean Government announced today that 14 banned politicians would be removed from a blacklist. They include the two most prominent opposition figures, Kim Dae Jung and Kim Young Sam.

title: Carbide Sets Chemical Plan The Union Carbide Corporation said it plans to reduce inventories at its Institute,
description: W.Va., plant of a toxic chemical that killed more than 2,000

title: 85% OF BRITISH MINERS ARE BACK AT WORK
description: The British coal industry staggered back toward full operation today as most miners who had not already abandoned their strike marched back to their jobs. But some miners stayed at home and some who reported for work were turned away by unofficial pickets.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph of bacteria in Science Times yesterday with an article about gonorrhea vaccines was incorrectly attributed. It was provided by the Journal of Infectious Diseases.

title: VERMONT SYRUP MAKERS WORRY ABOUT MAPLES' HEALTH
description: Maurice Rheaume began the sugaring season recently as he has for the last 14 years, tending a wood fire into the night as clear maple sap was boiled down to sweet amber syrup.

title: DEMOCRATS IN JERSEY GOVERNOR RACE OUTLINE GOALS
description: Five Democrats who hope to run for Governor of New Jersey in the fall took turns today exhorting their party to forget last year's national election defeat and to concentrate on winning back the State House.

title: KODAK, JAPAN'S CHINON PLAN A 35-MM. CAMERA
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, which has reportedly been disappointed by recent sales of its disk camera and instant-photography camera, yesterday announced a renewed effort to capture part of the booming market for 35-millimeter cameras. It said it would produce such a camera with Chinon Industries of Japan, a technology partner.

title: MCHALE SCORES 42 POINTS AS CELTICS DOWN KNICKS
description: Ray Williams's much-heralded return to Madison Square Garden last night failed to live up to its pre-game hype, but it didn't matter. His new employers, the Boston Celtics, didn't need him - or, at least, they didn't use him much.

title: THREE-WAY STRUGGLE OVER CINTROL OF U.P.I.
description: The owners, creditors and employees of United Press International today struggled for control of the news service, which some participants said was rapidly running out of money to stay in business.

title: LOWE'S COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THERE is a category of foods that might well be called ''chameleons'' because they can change their flavor drastically when combined with other things.

title: 23 OLD MASTERS OF OKLAHOMA GEOLOGIST TO BE AUCTIONED OFF
description: A major collection of 23 Italian, Dutch and French old masters, acquired over the last decade by Samuel T. Fee, an Oklahoma geologist, will be auctioned May 9 at Christie's. The sale will be the first in the auction house's expanded galleries at Park Avenue at 59th Street.

title: Swedes Quit Chile
description: Fearing for their safety, the Swedish Davis Cup tennis team has left Chile after the severe earthquake and aftershocks Sunday, and the status of the series scheduled to begin Friday is uncertain. Chilean sources said that the Swedes had offered to play at Rio de Janeiro.

title: HOW LAWMAKERS VOTED ON FARM AID
description: Following are the positions of representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut when the House today passed a bill containing aid for Africa and credit help for American farmers. A ''yes'' represents a vote for the package and a ''no'' represents a vote against it; ''xxx'' means not voting.

title: Mullins Named Coach Basketball is the only money-making sport at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, and after three dismal seasons the Sun Belt Conference school has moved to shore up its tattered meal ticket. It named
description: Jeff Mullins, a former Duke all-American and National Basketball Association all-star, as basketball coach and athletic director. He replaces

title: IRANIAN ARTILLERY POUNDS BORDER CITY AFTER IRAQI AIR RAIDS
description: Iranian forces shelled the Iraqi border city of Basra this evening, fulfilling a threat made the day before. Iraq responded with rocket fire and said it would hit 30 Iranian towns Wednesday.

title: Vietnamese on Attack In New Cambodia Battle
description: Vietnamese forces have broken a two-week lull on the battlefields of Cambodia with an assault on two resistance camps, Thai military sources said today. The Thais said the Vietnamese had also began their first ground attack on the guerrillas of Prince Norodom Sihanouk.

title: NEW A.T.&T. COMPUTER PUSH
description: After a rocky entry into the computer business last year, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is looking to a new organization, a new leader and - later this month - a distinctive new personal computer as it struggles to compete with the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: HADCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: b-Net income

title: Crane Picks President
description: The Crane Company yesterday named Edwin F. Phelps president and chief operating officer.

title: EASY ICE CREAM MAKER
description: IT may seem a bit premature to

title: New Breed of Squirrel
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising;   Philip Morris Returns To 'Uncola' Strategy
description: The Seven-Up Company, the Philip Morris subsidiary that has learned to profit by playing on the fears of consumers, is returning to the ''uncola'' advertising theme after 10 years without it.

title: CONNELLY CONTAINERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JEWS HINT CONCERN ON DEMOCRATS
description: American Jews voted heavily Democratic in the 1984 Presidential election, but many of them are worried about the direction of the party, particularly on foreign policy, a study said today.

title: Glacier General Assets Seized
description: The California Department of Insurance said today that it had seized most of the assets of the Glacier General Assurance Company.

title: BRIEFING ;   Recognition
description: Representative John McCain, an Arizona Republican serving his second term in Congress, may not be a household name to most Americans but is apparently becoming one in Vietnam.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: 2 TOP EMPLOYEES REMOVED FROM CORONER'S OFFICE
description: Two top employees of the New York City Medical Examiner's Office were removed from their jobs yesterday and transferred out of the agency, according to the Health Department.

title: A FILM RIPOFF BY THE JAPANESE
description: American films and television programs are the most sought after United States exports. No other nation has yet been able to compete with our visual creative efforts. It is the one industry in which we have global dominance. Now, because of electronic wizardry unimagined a decade ago, it is possible for anyone to buy a device that allows them to copy - for pennies - films that cost millions of dollars to create.

title: THE STAGE: 'REAL ESTATE' HAS PREMIERE IN CAPITAL
description: Louise Page's ''Real Estate,'' in its American premiere at the Arena Stage, dramatizes the unspoken - veiled looks and interrupted thoughts as the play subtly reveals the melancholic loneliness of a family of solitary individuals.

title: Pennsylvania Education Bonds
description: The Pennsylvania Higher Educational Facilities Authority offered $36.6 million worth of serial bonds.

title: FARM CREDIT BILL IS PASSED BY HOUSE
description: Ignoring threats of a Presidential veto, the House of Representatives today passed an emergency measure on farm credit that could provide some immediate cash to financially distressed farmers preparing to plant their spring crops.

title: Denver Sewer Authority
description: A syndicate led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company purchased $28.8 million of Metropolitan Denver Sewer Authority bonds yesterday at competitive bid.

title: LIVER: UNDERRATED, OFTEN OVERCOOKED
description: LIKE a talented performer suffering from bad press, liver has a hard time landing a starring role in many kitchens. Being organ tissue, not muscle, it has a flavor. Above all, it has texture - one that does not immediately appeal to diners with less than catholic tastes. Its appeal is further diminished by the way cooks generally serve it: even a certified liver fancier must struggle to down the dry, overcooked preparations that are so sadly commonplace. The result is a small- scale food scandal.

title: The Auto Quota: We Asked for It . . . President Reagan's decision to let lapse the import quota on Japanese cars is completely welcome. By any reasonable calculation, the cost of the restraints has outweighed the value of the jobs saved.
description: Yet the decision produces its own irony. The problem now may be to persuade Japan to

title: KINCAID FURNITURE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
More Instant Replays
description: Harry Usher, commissioner of the United States Football League, said that instant replays to appeal officials' calls would be extended to all televised games.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: f825Socialist Mayor Wins Re-election in Vermont
description: Bernard Sanders, the nation's only Socialist Mayor, easily defeated six other candidates today to win re-election to a third two-year term.

title: Expanding Horizons
description: David A. Hays needed to get away

title: Advertising;   People
description: * Willard G. Hadlock and

title: CITY LISTING MOST-WANTED CRIMINALS
description: Mayor Koch and Police Commissoner Benjamin Ward announced yesterday that the city had started publishing lists of its 100 most-wanted fugitives and was offering cash rewards for information resulting in their capture.

title: NCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
200,000 Strike in Peru
description: More than 200,000 Government office workers went on strike today, demanding 100 percent pay increases to help them cope with Peru's 125 percent inflation rate.

title: The Decline in Israel's Economy Requires Dramatic Remedy
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOLS ACCUSED OF EVADING REVIEWS FOR U.S. FINANCING
description: A top Federal science board has charged that 15 universities in the last two years created ''a dangerous precedent'' by circumventing usual merit reviews and obtaining more than $100 million directly from Congress to build laboratory facilities.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: For Chocolate Buffs

title: Academic Charges
description: A former dean at Laurinburg Institute in North Carolina said that two basketball players who had attended summer school had ''simply paid their tuition, got their grade point averages and moved on to their college basketball careers.''

title: 68-Year-Old Arrested In Shooting on Street
description: A 68- year-old retired gardener has been arrested in the killing of a young man who witnesses said accosted him and called him an obscene name on a downtown street Monday afternoon.

title: 2 ARE INDICTED IN FATAL CRASH OF A FIRE TRUCK
description: Two city firefighters have been indicted in the death of a Queens man whose car was rammed by their fire truck as they headed to a takeout restaurant.

title: BIG B INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   LILY-TULIP PRESIDENT ADDS CHAIRMAN'S TITLE
description: Lily-Tulip Inc., a leading maker of disposable cups, named its president and chief executive, Albert J. Dunlap, to the additional post of chairman, effective immediately. The chairman's job had been vacant since a group of investors formed the company, which had been a unit of Owens-Illinois Inc., in a leveraged buyout in 1981.

title: CRAXI AND REAGAN DISCUSS ARMS PLAN
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of Italy, after meeting with President Reagan today, said the two leaders had a ''broad and encouraging convergence'' of views, but he avoided an outright endorsement of the Administration's research program to develop antimissile defensive weapons.

title: DILLARD DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: The results include the impact of the acquisition of Stix stores from Associated Dry Goods on Jan. 30, 1984 and the purchase of 17 John A. Brown stores and Diamond's stores from the Dayton-Hudson Corp. on Sept. 20, 1984.

title: NAVRATILOVA EXTENDED
description: Martina Navratilova had a sluggish start, then went on to defeat Ann Henricksson, 7-6, 6-2, in the opening round of the United States Women's Indoor tennis championships tonight. Pam Shriver, returning from a layoff, and Hana Mandlikova also won.

title: No Movement in Talks
description: The latest session in the negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement for baseball produced no open books today. Nor did it produce any movement.

title: PURIM BOOK, LARGE-SIZE CLOTHES
description: 1.*A Gift for Purim The Jewish holiday of Purim, which is tomorrow this year, commemorates the saving by Queen Esther of the lives of Jews in Persia. The holiday is traditionally celebrated not only by feasting but also by reading the ''Book of Esther,'' known as ''Megillah Esther.'' A handsome edition of the book has recently been published in Hebrew and English with calligraphy and illumination by Shoshana Walker, a New York-born artist who now lives in Israel. She has surrounded the Hebrew text with colorful floral designs and the English text with gold geometrics. The 2,000 limited editions of the book are $45 at the Kibbutz Store, 856 Lexington Avenue (near 65th Street). 2.*Macy's Little Shop Little Shop II is Macy's answer to the larger woman's search for stylish clothes in sizes 14 to 22. In a 1,200- square-foot, airy, cream-colored shop, there are silk dresses for work, beaded silk tops by Sweelo in a jet black and silver flower motif for black-tie events, and, for casual wear, Nancy Heller's red and white cotton pullover ($82) and red cropped pants ($64). The shop is on the seventh floor, adjacent to Macy's Woman Shop, at Herald Square. 3.*Cool New Sandals Whether you are planning a winter trip to warmer climes or just planning ahead for warmer weather, these platform sandals from Mario Rapagnani will keep your feet cool and elevated at the beach. They are made of cotton cord, with a light sole of rubber simulated to look like cork, and come in black or white, in sizes 6 to 10.

title: PITTSBURGH-DES MOINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: FILM: ROCK SATIRE, 'FABULOUS STAINS'
description: ''LADIES AND GENTLEMEN, THE FABULOUS STAINS'' promises to be of interest as a show business satire, but it's notable chiefly as a footnote to the career of Diane Lane. Miss Lane was 15 in 1981, when the film was made and when Paramount decided against releasing it, for the obvious reasons that it's neither funny nor incisive. The latter fact is surprising, since the film was directed by Lou Adler, the ''A'' in A & M records and formerly the manager of Carole King. Mr. Adler surely knows his way around the music business, but the film reflects none of that expertise.

title: Levitz Switches To Tender Offer
description: The Levitz Furniture Corporation said that it had abandoned plans for a leveraged buyout of the company at $39 a share, or $318 million, and that the acquisition group had decided instead to begin a tender offer for all shares at the same price.

title: WHAT MOSCOW MIGHT DO IN REPLYING TO 'STAR WARS'
description: The Soviet Union is approximately equal to the United States in basic research on directed energy, like lasers and subatomic-particle beams, that would be required for a broad land- and space- based missile defense system, according to Pentagon reports.

title: HILTON REJECTION SEEN AS SETBACK IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: New Jersey's rejection of a gambling license for Hilton Hotels Corporation's new Atlantic City casino is a major setback for both the redevelopment of Atlantic City and expansion there of the casino business, gaming industry officials and stock analysts said.

title: A TEACHER AT BROOKLYN TECH IS STABBED BY YOUTH IN SCHOOL
description: A teacher at Brooklyn Technical High School was stabbed four times yesterday by a youth in a stairwell at the building. The teacher, Susan Traun, 42 years old, was reported in stable condition at Brooklyn Hospital..

title: GEMCO NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RYKOFF-SEXTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: HOWL OF THE 80's Allen Ginsberg was one of the poets of the 1950's and 60's whose works represented and spoke to a social and cultural movement. He became a celebrity, well known even outside his literary milieu. His acknowledged use of psychedelic substances, his poetry and his anti-Vietnam War posture turned him into a national figure.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
CONCERT: ROSTROPOVICH AND PROKOFIEV
description: PROKOFIEV'S Sinfonia Concertante for Cello and Orchestra, one of remarkably few works written since World War II to gain a foothold in the standard repertory, owes its status to the labors of Mstislav Rostropovich, for whom it was composed 34 years ago. Both during his career in the Soviet Union and in the years since he took up residence in the West, Mr. Rostropovich has waged a fierce and successful campaign for the work, which he championed once again last night at Carnegie Hall as soloist with the National Symphony under the baton of Rafael Fr"uhbeck de Burgos. From the length and warmth of the ovation that followed his performance one might have thought that the audience was cheering what it regarded as a familiar and beloved masterpiece.

title: PAYOLA'S RETURN TO RECORDS REPORTED
description: The musicians, singers and others in the music business who gathered here last week for the annual Grammy awards honoring the best in recorded music had much to celebrate. After a painful four- year slump, record sales have begun to boom again across the nation.

title: U.S. Says It Destroyed Korean Airliner Tape
description: The Defense Department said today that the Air Force had erased a radar tape that traced part of the flight of a South Korean airliner shot down over Soviet territory in 1983, but that the tape had recorded the plane's fate.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''It seems the Democrats are more interested in harvesting votes than in harvesting crops.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST WEDNESDAY, MARCH 6, 1985
description: The Economy

title: San Jose Giants?
description: The owner of the San Francisco Giants,

title: CBS to Subpoena Ted Turner in Suit
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that it would subpoena Ted Turner, owner of the Atlanta-based Turner Broadcasting System Inc., in connection with its lawsuit against Fairness in Media, a group that has solicited conservatives to buy stock in CBS.

title: BASIC AMERICAN MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FARM BANKS' TROUBLES ARE WORSENING
description: The financial condition of the nation's agricultural banks has seriously deteriorated and will get worse, according to a study by the Comptroller of the Currency.

title: Bond Prices Are Stronger
description: Bond prices staged a comeback yesterday, regaining the ground lost on Monday.

title: Brazil Sets Inflation Goal BRASILIA, March 5 (AP) - The Government will seek to cut inflation in half this year as it tries to negotiate new terms for repayment of its huge debt load, Brazil's central bank said today.
description: According to a report submitted to the International Monetary Fund in Washington, Brazil's leaders hope to chop inflation to 120 percent from the annual rate of 223 percent registered at the end of 1984, the bank said.

title: GOLDSMITH MOVE AWAITED
description: SIR JAMES GOLDSMITH, the secretive British businessman, may have an important announcement to make in a few days, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: DENNISON YOUNG, 72, CARDIOLOGIST
description: Dr. Dennison Young, a pediatric cardiologist who helped adapt the heart pacemaker for use in children, died of cancer yesterday at his home in White Plains. He was 72 years old.

title: Thrift Unit Deal
description: United First Federal Savings and Loan of Sarasota, Fla., and the Cityfed Financial Corporation of Palm Beach announced a merger agreement.

title: RUSSIAN WARNS OF RESPONSE
description: A senior Soviet military officer said today that if the United States pushed ahead with its ''Star Wars'' effort, the Kremlin would respond by expanding its offensive nuclear arsenal rather than negotiating reductions.

title: DESTINATION? GENEVA. MISSION? SURPRISE CONTROL
description: Senators do not get themselves to Capitol Hill by 7:30 A.M. very often to hear lectures about ''throw-weights'' and ''hardened silos'' and other arcane issues involved in arms control negotiations. ''The hour of the morning,'' Senator Sam Nunn noted wryly, ''serves as a weeding-out process.''

title: N.B.A. LOTTERY DAY IS LISTED ON MAY 12
description: The top prize is Patrick Ewing. The date of the National Basketball Association's lottery drawing will be May 12, a Sunday, at 2 P.M. at a New York hotel. That is when one of the seven teams that fail to make the playoffs will get the draft rights to the awesome 7-foot Georgetown University center.

title: Indian Elections End In a Burst of Violence
description: Mobs hurled explosives at voting booths and clashed with the police today during India's final round of state elections. The Congress Party of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi took the lead in three states.

title: HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes nonrecurring gains of $2,974,000 in the quarter and $5,302,000 for the year from the sale of restaurants and investment securities net of charges, primarily related to the closing or sale of nine Bojangles' restaurants located principally in the rural areas of central Louisiana and eastern Texas. c-Includes nonrecurring gains of $592,000 in the quarter and $2,567,000 for the year from the sale of restaurants and investment securities net of charges, primarily related to the closing or sale of nine Bojangles' restaurants located principally in the rural areas of central Louisiana and eastern Texas.

title: '85 MICHELIN TABS WINNERS AND LOSERS
description: The 1985 Guide Michelin for France, published today, restored its highest rating, three stars, to the Auberge du P ere Bise in Talloires. The restaurant had held the guide's top ranking from 1951 until 1983, when it was demoted to two stars. Since there were no demotions from the guide's three-star ranks this time around, the addition of the Auberge du P ere Bise boosts the three- star total to 19, four of them restaurants in Paris.

title: 4th Suspect Listed In Drug Killings
description: Detectives said yesterday that they had identified the last suspect being sought in connection with a shooting and stabbing rampage last Wednesday at the home of a reputed drug dealer in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: SENATOR SAYS TESTS SHOW FLAWS IN WEAPON
description: Senator Mark Andrews charged today that tests of an Army weapon to protect infantry and armored divisions indicated it had ''serious shortcomings'' in performance and operation.

title: NEW REGULATORY BOARD IN BRITAIN GETS A HEAD
description: The job of organizing and running a new regulatory body for British financial services will go to Sir Kenneth Berrill, the 64-year-old chairman of Vickers da Costa, the stockbroking firm.

title: PRESS CURB ORDERS IN SPY TRIAL ON THE COAST
description: A Federal district judge, declaring that ''the public's right to a fair trial'' is equal to that of defendants, today barred lawyers in a case involving three people accused of spying for the Soviet Union from talking to reporters about the case.

title: Upjohn Plans Unit in Japan The Upjohn Company said
description: that it would form a

title: Wham, British Group, Invited to Play in China
description: For the first time, a Western pop band has been invited to tour China.

title: Whither Papandreou?
description: Monteagle Stearns, the United States Ambassador to Greece, has returned to Washington for consultations at a time when the Reagan Administration is reviewing its policy toward the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, whose bursts of anti-American oratory regularly annoy many high-level officials in Washington.

title: False Arrest
description: Three Fort Lauderdale police officers walked into the Yankees' spring- training clubhouse yesterday, took Joe Cowley into a back room and told him that they were arresting him for reckless driving, a result of some of his recent cutting-up in the parking lot at Fort Lauderdale Stadium.

title: TAX GAIN ON CONRAIL SALE CITED
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation could recover more in tax benefits than the $1.2 billion it would pay the Government for the Consolidated Rail Corporation, according to David H. Brockway, the staff chief of the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation.

title: REPORT URGES STATE TO ALLOW FISHING IN 2 POLLUTED WATERS
description: Fishing should be permitted on chemically contaminated stretches of the Hudson River and on Onondaga Lake, even though the contamination of fish in those waters has not abated, because people fish there anyway, a state report has recommended.

title: CRIME VICTIMS SEEKING A GREATER LEGAL VOICE
description: Five years after she was attacked and pistol- whipped in her car in Brooklyn in 1975, Dr. Shelley Neiderbach was mugged at knifepoint in her apartment-building lobby.

title: San Juan Star Staff Going Back to Jobs After Strike
description: Employees began returning to work today after settlement of a four-and- a-half-month strike at The San Juan Star.

title: Resources, Coastal In Court in 2 States
description: The Coastal Corporation and the American Natural Resources Company conducted legal skirmishes in two states yesterday as they continued their battle over Coastal's $2.3 billion acquisition bid.

title: Inner Circle
description: Decisions, Decisions. Whom to eat with?

title: SENATORS ACCEPT HOUSE BILL TO END HIGHWAY STALEMATE
description: The Senate, after scrapping its own highway bill, voted overwhelmingly today for a House bill that would release to the states $7.2 billion in Federal funds for road construction.

title: GOLDEN NUGGET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After extraordinary losses on debt retirements of $2,788,000 for the latest year and $1,551,000 for the earlier period.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE name Marie Merzon appeared, until recently, in three-foot-high red letters on a billboard at Fifth Avenue and 40th Street. The giant sign - part of the scaffolding surrounding the construction of the Republic Bank Tower on the southwest corner - read: FOR RENTAL INFORMATION CALL MARIE MERZON 930-6119

title: Datapoint Plans Delaware Appeal
description: The Datapoint Corporation said that it would appeal a ruling issued by the Chancery Court in Delaware against the enforcement of a bylaw amendment that would make it more difficult for the company to be taken over by a group led by Asher B. Edelman, a New York investor. The group had filed suit earlier this month to have the bylaw declared invalid.

title: RRIGHTS REPORT ON NICARAGUA CITES RECENT REBEL ACTIVITIES
description: A new report from a private human rights group is sharply critical of rights abuses by the American-backed Nicaraguan rebels. It also assails abuses by the Nicaraguan Army but says there has been ''a sharp decline'' in violations by the army since 1982.

title: BUDGET TALKS IN ALBANY FOUNDER ON TAX QUESTION
description: The effort to reach agreement on a state budget foundered as it began today when the Assembly Speaker insisted on a decision on a special tax package before talks could start.

title: Edwin Rosskam, 81, Is Dead; Photographed River Scenes
description: Edwin Rosskam, a freelance photographer and writer, died Feb. 25 at his home in Roosevelt, N.J. He was 81 years old.

title: PORTRAITS AT EXHIBITION OF GARBLES AND SHREDS
description: Federal bureaucrats moved like gray glyphs on a screen of broadloom this morning, lining up for their annual computer software convention and learning to ''garbleize,'' perchance to confuse; to pulverize and not merely shred; to voice-synthesize and not have to sight-read the endless paperwork that is the stuff of this city. Floppies are always being stolen, misplaced, and this product, from our Enigma line, will safely garbleize your input,'' Shane Panjvani, a computer software dealer with the Isolation Systems company, said to an understanding listener. He was selling an encoding device to protect information on the soft, floppy disks of personal computers, a device that would leave an office snoop with only paragraphs of gibberish on his screen.

title: BUSH, VISITING REFUGEES IN SUDAN, IS 'DEEPLY MOVED'
description: They galloped alongside the motorcade of four-wheel-drive vehicles moving swiftly on the narrow road in the eastern Sudan.

title: States Will Pay for Federal Student-Aid Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: Deere, G.M. Unit Discuss Venture
description: Deere & Company and the Detroit Diesel Allison division of the General Motors Corporation said that they had signed a letter of intent to study a joint venture in the diesel engine business.

title: Honeywell Selling Japan Unit to NEC
description: Honeywell Inc. and the NEC Corporation of Tokyo said that Honeywell would sell its Information Systems subsidiary in Japan to NEC.

title: A NURSING HOME GETS READY FOR PURIM
description: Like the warmer weather and the chirping birds, the smell of hamantaschen baking in the oven has always meant the coming of spring for Sophie Segal. For 60 years, Mrs. Segal kneaded the dough and fashioned the three-corner pastries eaten on the Jewish festival of Purim, which comes with the changing season.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Pennsylvania Sells $102 Million in Bonds
description: The State of Pennsylvania yesterday sold $102 million worth of general obligation bonds at competitive bid.

title: Car Record Rules Are Backed
description: Administration tax officials urged Congress today not to change the law enacted last year that requires people who drive cars on business to keep detailed records of the business and personal use of the cars.

title:
MUST MENGELE REMAIN UNCAUGHT?;

A REAGAN EFFORT IS NEEDED
description: Forty years after Dr. Josef Mengele helped create hell on earth at Auschwitz as a servant of Hitler's Final Solution, there is renewed optimism that finally he may be on the verge of being brought to justice.

title: BOSSY GETS 50TH GOAL IN LOSS
description: The Islanders should have won tonight for so many reasons. They were the team that came back from two goals down to tie the game in the third period. They were the team to tie the game again in the final minute. And they were the team to celebrate a milestone for one of their players.

title: LOSSES ADDING UP IN E.S.M. CLOSING
description: The closing of E.S.M. Government Securities Inc., a little-known securities dealer in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., began to ripple throughout the financial system yesterday. Local governments as well as financial institutions that had lent it more than $1 billion could face losses and financial hardship, according to E.S.M.'s court-appointed receiver and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: 22 U.S. Military Bases Listed as Unnecessary
description: Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, today made public a list of 22 military facilities around the country that he said could be closed for a saving of $500 million a year if the White House was willing to endorse so politically unpopular an idea.

title: KANSAS CITY JINX PLAGUES NETS AGAIN

title: STAGE: FAMILY PORTRAIT, 'OCTETTE BRIDGE CLUB'
description: THE opening vignette of ''The Octette Bridge Club,'' the new play at the Music Box, is a Norman Rockwell illustration come to life. Eight sisters in Providence, R.I., have gathered without their husbands, as they do twice a month, for a night of gossip, home- baked pie and cards. The sisters are a merry, close-knit clan of Irish descent. They giggle as a newspaper photographer takes a picture of their ''club'' for the Sunday rotogravure section; they speak or sing in unison at the drop of a cloche hat. The year is 1934, and, as the women never cease reminding us, this was a time when families still had roots.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: CALCIUM has become the nutrient of the 80's, eclipsing even salt as a cause for dietary concern. Though nearly every American grew up knowing that calcium builds strong bones and most of us were repeatedly admonished to drink lots of milk, which is calcium-rich, few realized that this mineral remained crucial to maintaining a healthy skeleton after they stopped growing.

title: DOLLAR ERODING ASSETS ABROAD
description: American companies with operations abroad long used hedging techniques to protect earnings from the ravages of foreign currency fluctuations. But, lulled by an accounting change that serves to protect those earnings, many American companies have stopped hedging, and now find their corporate equity being eaten away by the strength of the dollar - and the shrinking value of their assets in foreign countries.

title: ROBERT BLAKE AS PRIEST IN 'HELL TOWN' ON NBC

Mr. Blake, who also wrote the script, plays Father Noah (Hardstep) Rivers, a former convict who has become a Roman Catholic priest at the inner-city parish of St. Dominic's. Hardstep is a one-man posse, advising friend and foe that ''nobody hurts nobody in Hell Town.''

title:
MUST MENGELE REMAIN UNCAUGHT?;

I SAW HIM IN ACTION
description: I was deported from my home town in Germany in 1939, when I was 16, and arrived in Auschwitz in the winter of 1942-43. We arrived at night, after spending approximately one week locked up in cattle cars. It was a horror. All around were shouts by SS men, ''Juden-Raus!,'' and barking, biting dogs. There was crying, screaming, mass hysteria. All we knew was that we were surrounded by barbed wire fences.

title: WHAT'S TIRAMISU? WELL, IT DEPENDS...
description: DOES it come from Tuscany? Lombardy? Campania? Piedmont? Veneto? The origins of tiramis u, the ''newest'' Italian dessert in New York's restaurants, are as hazy as the authentic recipe - if indeed there is such a thing for the dessert, a deceptively airy but shamefully rich creation in the mousse-pudding family that has at least 200 variations, according one authoritative source. In its most common form tiramis u - literally, ''pick me up'' or ''lift me up'' - is made with mascarpone, the soft, buttery Italian double cream cheese, plus eggs, coffee, sugar, chocolate pieces and the Italian equivalent of ladyfingers, savoiardi. The biscuits are dipped in the coffee, the mascarpone mixed with the eggs and sugar. The play of textures and flavors seems particularly appealing to Americans. The variations may add zabaglione, almonds, whipped cream or any of a wide variety of spirits; some substitute cocoa for chocolate. Some chefs separate the eggs, mixing the yolks with the mascarpone and folding beaten whites into the cheese mixture to lighten it. Others use only the yolks to make a zabaglione that is either combined with the mascarpone or served in a separate layer.

title: Cleaning Up the Coroner's Office The question whether New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot Gross, is guilty of mishandling specific cases involving charges of police misconduct remains the subject of pending inquiries. But two reports released Monday by state and city investigators amply confirm another alarming conclusion of an investigation by The New York Times. The Medical Examiner's office, they suggest, is so chaotic that it doesn't function reliably. Action to correct that intolerable situation need not await the additional inquiries.
description: Reports prepared by the Governor's and Mayor's offices repeat and amplify many of the points raised in the Times series. The most serious include the Medical Examiner's routine violation of a city requirement that two physicians observe all homicide autopsies, his office's chronic inability to produce autopsy reports promptly and its continued reliance on outmoded or broken equipment.

description: Joe Mullaney will coach at least one more game, compliments of Keith Lomax.

title: Chief Executive Resigns At Consumers Power
description: The Consumers Power Company, the financially troubled Michigan utility, has accepted the resignation of its chairman and chief executive, John D. Selby. The company said the move would be effective Nov. 1, provided the company's bank debt is restructured and a successor is in place for Mr. Selby, who is 63.

title: Interest Bill Rising ;   On Federal Bonds
description: To the Editor:

title: DECLINE IN DIVORCE IS FIRST IN 20 YEARS
description: For the first time in 20 years, fewer Americans have obtained divorces. The number decreased by 43,000 between 1981 and 1982, according to a new population report.

title: Required Reading ;   Birth of the 1040
description: Q. Why are personal income tax forms called ''1040's''?

title: BUSINESS TENANTS ASK CURBS ON LANDLORDS SELLING ELECTRICITY
description: Landlords in many office and industrial buildings in New York City are reselling electricity to their tenants at prices far higher than the landlords paid to buy it from the Consolidated Edison Company.

title: MUSIC: OHIO ENSEMBLE
description: THERE were many reasons to take an interest in Monday evening's concert at Carnegie Hall. The University of Cincinnati's College-Conservatory of Music, one of this country's leading conservatories, was presenting its Philharmonia orchestra, billed rather grandly as the ''Cincinnati Philharmonia.'' There was the first American performance of a complete song cycle by Alexander Zemlinsky, Schoenberg's teacher and brother-in- law. There was a world premiere. There was the chance to monitor the vocal progress of Clamma Dale, the American soprano.

title: Deaver Car Discount Didn't Upset Reagan
description: President Reagan said today that he saw nothing wrong with the use of diplomatic passports by Michael Deaver and other White House staff members to get discounts on nine BMW automobiles while they were in West Germany to arrange the President's visit there in May.

title: EVEREST & JENNINGS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for 14wks to Dec 30
description: b-Includes gain of $2,515,000, or 32 cents a share, from the sale of real estate for the quarter and year. The year-earlier quarter and year comprised of 13 weeks and 52 weeks, respectively.

title: THE PRESIDENTS' PLANES
description: ''AIR FORCE ONE: The Planes and the Presidents'' is similar in tone to ''Call to Glory,'' the ABC series now defunct. We are meant to be gripped by glorious planes and what they mean. Indeed, we are gripped, but not consistently and not nearly enough. The planes, no matter how glorious, are still only means of transportation. The one-hour documentary will be seen on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

title: LAWYERS DENY CRISIS IN MEDICAL MALPRACTICE INSURANCE
description: An organization of trial lawyers, responding to assertions by the American Medical Association, said today that ''there is no medical malpractice insurance crisis'' and that the average American physician spent less than 3 percent of gross income for such insurance.

title: EDWARD M. BERMAN
description: Edward M. Berman, a former vice president and advertising manager of the Abraham & Straus department stores, died of cancer Tuesday at Memorial Hospital in Sarasota, Fla.

title: TAPES ON ORGANIZED CRIME RELEASED
description: The Bronx District Attorney's office released transcripts yesterday of secretly recorded conversations in which organized-crime suspects talked in 1979 of bribing city, state and Federal officials, as well as of other crimes.

title: GREEN MOUNTAIN POWER CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The year-earlier figures restated to recognize deferred taxes that should have been provided for in connection with R-fueling outages at a nuclear plant.

title: BUDGET PLAN CUT BY SCHOOL BOARD IN UNUSUAL STEP
description: The Board of Education, stung by criticism that its proposed budget of $4.38 billion for 1985-86 was too large and diffuse, has taken the unusual step of cutting the proposal even before it is sent to City Hall, where it almost certainly will be further reduced.

title:
GARDENING;

SELECTING PLANTS THAT SUIT THE CLIMATE
description: WITH a change of season almost in the air, gardeners are already planning their spring planting. Before they order this season's crop of trees, shrubs and perennials from new seed and nursery catalogues, however, prudent gardeners will make sure that their selections are reliably hardy for their region.

title: U.S. SAYS ISRAELIS SHOW LITTLE GAIN IN ECONOMIC PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration told Congress today that Israel had failed so far to make enough progress in its economic recovery plan for the United States to meet its request for a major increase in economic aid.

title: Medical Team Reports Battle In a City in Northern Ethiopia
description: Four American medical workers said today that a seven-hour battle took place in the northern Ethiopian city of Lalibala over the weekend.

title: RIGHTS UNITS BOYCOTT AFFIRMATIVE ACTION HEARINGS
description: Civil rights groups refused today to participate in affirmative action hearings of the Commission on Civil Rights, and a black Congressman left after calling the sessions ''farcical and meaningless.''

title: DARK SIDE OF 'STAR WARS': SYSTEM COULD ALSO ATTACK
description: The weapons envisioned for President Reagan's defensive shield against ballistic missile attack could be used with devastating effect offensively, according to many supporters and critics of Mr. Reagan's program.

title: Maryland Mayor Leaves In Midst of Campaign
description: The Mayor of this city in western Maryland has left town in the midst of a re-election campaign, and his brother says he ''may be back next week and he may be back next year.''

title: PILOTS AGREE TO CROSS PICKET LINES IN STRIKE AGAINST PAN AMERICAN
description: The pilot's union reached a back-to- work agreement with Pan American World Airways yesterday, creating a major breach in a week-long strike, as other workers remained out.

title: STYLES THAT TAKE NEW LOOK AT SPRING
description: NO, a flowered straw hat and a navy blue suit with white pique collar and cuffs are not the answer. Spring fashions today are far more lively and diverse.

title: Mesa Selling Phillips Stock
description: An investor group led by T. Boone Pickens said yesterday that it would exercise its right to sell 8.9 million shares of Phillips Petroleum Company stock to that company for $53 a share, realizing a profit of $89 million.

title: Not Guilty Plea Entered In Coast Prison Deaths
description: Stephen Bingham, a lawyer who surrendered after 13 years in hiding, pleaded not guilty today to charges of murder and conspiracy stemming from an attempted escape from San Quentin prison in 1971.

title: SLAYER OF TAMPA BOY ELECTROCUTED IN FLORIDA
description: John Paul Witt was executed today for the abduction and murder of an 11- year-old Tampa boy, killed 12 years ago when he went to a store to buy candy for his younger brother.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   New York City Prices $300 Million in Bonds
description: New York City yesterday priced a $300 million offering of general obligation bonds.

title: FOR FREED LEFTISTS IN URUGUAY, HIDDEN TERRORS
description: They were huddled together on the edge of the crowd, watching with amazement as the downtown plaza slowly filled with red flags and chanting youths. Their gaunt bodies, sunken cheeks and near-shaven heads immediately identified them.

title: STAGE: 'LOVES OF ANATOL,' REVMPED SCHNITZLER
description: ALTHOUGH failed stagings of valuable plays of the past are hardly a novelty, the Circle in the Square's new version of Arthur Schnitzler's ''Anatol,'' retitled ''The Loves of Anatol,'' must stand in a class apart. This is not, as such calamities usually are, merely an inept production. Nor is it a radical reinterpretation of the text, about which reasonable people might disagree. What the director Ellis Rabb has done to Schnitzler's work is to mutilate it willfully, with a thoroughness that could bring fans of the original text to tears even as the rest of the audience is put to sleep.

description: Among the most striking series of sports posters anywhere is the one that the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith plans to begin distributing soon to schools, military installations, arenas and virtually everywhere else that young, sports-minded people might congregate. Each of the black-and-white posters features one of the 10 stars whom the A.D.L. signed up for the series: Larry Holmes, Alberto Salazar, Tiffany Chin, Walter Payton, Debbie Armstrong, Julius Erving, Julianne McNamara, Dave Winfield, Bryan Trottier and Evelyn Ashford. description: An $11.8 million settlement has been reached in a negligence suit stemming from a 1980 explosion in a Queens factory that killed 11 people, lawyers said yesterday.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Reagan Says He Regrets New Zealand's Policy
description: President Reagan, in a statement made public today, has told the newly arrived Ambassador of New Zealand that the United States ''deeply regrets the decision by the New Zealand Government to change the operational character of our previous cooperation under the Anzus alliance.''

title: U.N. IN LEBANON, FEARING ATTACK, ORDERS AMERICANS OUT OF DANGER
description: Americans working with United Nations peacekeeping forces in southern Lebanon have been taken off the job for fear of possible attacks by Shiite Moslem militants, United Nations officials said today.

title: NEW INTERPRETATIONS OF VIVALDI'S 'FOUR SEASONS'
description: VIVALDI'S ''Four Seasons'' is the most popular item in the domestic compact-disk catalogue, with nine versions already listed, and now another recording is about to be imported into this country. It's by Andrew Parrott and his Taverner Players, with John Holloway as the violinist, and it's without qualification the best performance of this warhorse of warhorses that this determined listener has ever heard.

title: Smith Barney Is Censured
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it had censured Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company for failing to properly supervise one of its brokers. The action stemmed from $780,000 in losses suffered by customers of the firm's Rhinelander, Wis., office after they sold uncovered options of the Cities Service Company in June 1982.

title: Youth in Goetz Case Emerges From Coma
description: Darrel Cabey, the most seriously wounded of the four youths shot by Bernhard H. Goetz on a subway train last December, came out of a seven- week coma yesterday but has ''significant brain damage,'' a spokesman at St. Vincent's Hospital said.

title: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $2,686,000. The company has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code since Nov. 4, 1983.

description: Attorneys sent to Nicaragua by the International Human Rights Law Group, the Washington Office on Latin America and the office of Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Connecticut, say they have conducted their own interviews with victims cited in Mr. Brody's report.

title: G.&W. Net Falls 32.7% In Quarter
description: Gulf and Western Industries, citing sharply higher interest expense because of its purchase of Prentice-Hall Inc., reported a 32.7 percent drop in earnings for the second quarter, ended Jan. 31.

title: ERC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest year net reflects start-up costs of about 15 cents a share for Intercad Corp., a subsidiary that develops and markets computer-aided design and software.

title: C.D. Yields Up Sharply
description: For the second consecutive week, yields on money market deposits were little changed in the latest week, while yields on six-month certificates of deposits increased sharply.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Bond Prices Drop After an Early Rally
description: For the second consecutive Wednesday, remarks made in Washington by the Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, about a potentially sharp drop in the value of the dollar in foreign exchange markets reverberated through the credit markets, sending bond prices lower.

title: Books: O Canada
description: THE CANADIANS. By Andrew H. Malcolm. 385 pages. Times Books. $17.95. AS one of those Canadian nationalists who love America only at a distance, I am frequently interviewed by earnest journalists who, by the time they arrive, are glassy-eyed with boring facts and contradictory views. But the charade must be played out, and I end up reciting my set piece on how Canadians resent being drowned in American dollars, American culture and the American dream - feeling like one of those witch doctors in old documentaries about emerging African states.

title: VOLCHER VIEW ON CURRENCY
description: The Federal Reserve's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, suggested today that some type of fresh, coordinated action by governments would be desirable to reduce gyrations in the currency markets.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES BILL ON FARM AID, CITING THE DEFICIT
description: President Reagan vetoed emergency farm credit legislation today, saying the measure was a ''massive new bailout that would add billions to the deficit.''

title: Jersey Extends Sex Education
description: The New Jersey Board of Education unanimously approved today a five- year extension of a statewide requirement that all public schools teach the family life curriculum, which includes sex education.

title: CITY REVISES ITS FINANCIAL PLAN
description: The Koch administration has revised its preliminary financial plan for the coming fiscal year by reducing projected salary increases for all unionized municipal employees.

title: Mattingly Makes Progress
description: Don Mattingly indicated he is pleased with the progress of his right knee, from which torn cartilage was removed by arthroscopic surgery Feb. 22, and said he would begin throwing Thursday, then probably start hitting a few days after that.

title: EXPERTS FIND AIR POLLUTION IN THE HOME A GROWING RISK
description: ALL the caulking, weatherstripping and insulating of the energy-conscious 70's has had an unintended and unhealthy effect: air pollution in homes. As outside air is kept out, household pollutants are sealed in. Cigarette smoke, paint odors, insecticide sprays, animal hairs, airborne asbestos fibers, mildew, oven fumes, even air-fresheners collect in the air. Tests have linked them to everything from coughs to an increased risk of cancer.

title: Minstar Stake
description: A group of investors led by the Leucadia National Corporation of New York has increased its stake in Minstar Inc. to 895,000 common shares, or 8.4 percent of the company's shares outstanding, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Minstar, which is based in Minneapolis, is a diversified manufacturing concern. According to the filing, the Leucadia group bought the shares ''to obtain an equity position in Minstar for investment purposes'' and has ''no plans or intentions to seek control of the company, to seek to influence its affairs or to seek representation on its board of directors.''

title: Break in Pipeline Cuts Water To a Trickle in Jersey Town
description: A break in a main cut off all but emergency supplies of water today to this town of 8,500 people in northwestern New Jersey.

title: KNICKS TROUNCED BY PISTONS, 114-90
description: Vinnie Johnson, a reserve guard, scored 19 of his 21 points in the first half, and the center Bill Laimbeer finished with 20 as the Detroit Pistons easily defeated the Knicks, 114-90, tonight.

description: '' And now that I've vetoed this bill, I hope that Congress will get the message and work with me to reduce spending in a responsible way that does not threaten our national security.

description: The Koch administration has failed to spend nearly all of the $43 million in its current budget for building or renovating shelters for the homeless, City Council President Carol Bellamy said yesterday. She recommended that most of the money be used instead to build permanent housing for the homeless.

title: U.S. STUDIES RETALIATION AGAINST JAPAN ON TRADE
description: Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, said today that the Reagan Administration had begun to explore ways of retaliating against Japan for restricting imports from America. The first move, he suggested, may be in telecommunications.

title: Swedish Price Increases
description: Producer prices in Sweden rose 1.4 percent in January from December and were up 7.2 percent from a year earlier, Statistics Sweden said today. In December, producer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent from a month earlier and 7.6 percent from a year earlier, the Government agency said.

title: Northwest Cuts
description: Northwest Airlines said it was cutting its lowest midweek fare between Minneapolis and Newark to $89, from $109.

title: STATE COMPTROLLER FINDS CUOMO BUDGET BALANCED
description: Splitting with his fellow Republicans, the state's chief fiscal officer said today that Governor Cuomo's proposed budget was balanced.

title: REGULATION OF AUDITORS DEFENDED
description: John S. R. Shad, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, defended the agency's oversight of the accounting profession today before members of a Congressional subcommittee who warned that S.E.C. actions to date were lax and invited legislative action.

And since they had all written one-act comedies that they wanted to get on the stage, they formed Tri-Co. Productions, which will present the works tonight at 8 through March 17 at the Inroads Theater, 150 Mercer Street.

title: New Butcher Indictments
description: Jake Butcher, the former Tennessee banker who already faces 93 Federal bank fraud charges, was indicted by a Federal grand jury on 17 counts of income tax evasion, officials said today.

title: Arrested Island Leaders Appear in Court in Miami
description: Videotapes played in court today showed Norman Saunders, Chief Minister of the Turks and Caicos Islands, counting $20,000 he had accepted from an undercover agent, then offering his protection for cocaine smugglers in the West Indies islands.

description: William Carroll Keeley, former president and chairman of the Vanadium Corporation of America, died Feb. 27 at his home in Fairfield, Conn.

description: Voting is expected to be close today as shareholders decide whether to approve National Intergroup Inc.'s bold and contested plan to merge into the Bergen Brunswig Corporation.

description: A former lawyer has testified before a State Senate Committee that he participated in the bribery of several judges and in other irregularities to win medical malpractice and negligence cases in New York City courts from 1979 to 1982.

description: b-Includes a writedown of $7,400,000 representing the company's investment in an enhanced oil-recovery project. c-Net income.

title: Holdouts in Mine Strike Dwindling in Britain
description: Resistance to a return to normal operations in the British coal industry began to crumble today, 72 hours after the formal end to the yearlong miners' strike, and the state-owned National Coal Board said 92 percent of its men were at work.

title: THAI FORCES CLASH WITH VIETNAM
description: Thai troops and aircraft attacked Vietnamese forces that had crossed the border in an effort to surround the last major Cambodian resistance camp, the Thai Army said today.

title: Man in Gun-Sale Plot Given Up to 15 Years
description: A conspirator who plotted to sell 10,000 submachine guns to detectives posing as Latin American terrorists was sentenced yesterday to serve 5 to 15 years in prison.

title: SOVEREIGNITY MADE SOVIET BLOC ISSUE
description: East Germany's Communist Party daily has reprinted remarks by a Hungarian official that seem to question the so-called Brezhnev doctrine of limited sovereignty for Eastern European countries.

title: MISSISSIPPI TEACHER WALKOUTS ARE VIEWED BY SOME AS THREAT TO PROGRESS
description: Amid an emotional outpouring of public support, the State of Mississippi adopted landmark legislation in late 1982 aimed at improving the quality of a public school system often ranked last among the 50 states.

description: A judge today voided the contract the state awarded for construction of a parkway to Jimmy Carter's Presidential library and permanently enjoined the contractor from continuing the work.

DANCE: RUSH TROUPE
description: PATRICE REGNIER'S choreography came suddenly to life in the opening section of the Rush Dance Company's ''American Nights'' on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, where the Don Redlich Dance Company is also playing. Dancing in silence, Miss Regnier and Anthony Stafford enacted a strongly focused, engrossing psychic and dance partnership. The shift of control from one dancer to the other gave the duet a playful air at times, but the piece ended on a mysterious dramatic note, recalling the striking solo Miss Regnier created for Sallie Wilson some years back.

title: Joffrey Receives Award
description: Robert Joffrey, founder and director of the Joffrey Ballet, will receive the third annual Distinguished Service Award of the Dance Notation Bureau today at 6 P.M. at the New York State Theater, where the company is appearing through March 31. Bess Myerson, Commissioner of Cultural Affairs of the City of New York, will present the award to Mr. Joffrey. The reception, sponsored by Philip Morris Inc., will precede a performance of John Cranko's ''Romeo and Juliet'' by the Joffrey Ballet.

description: Senator Jake Garn, whose space debut was delayed by the cancellation of the space shuttle Challenger's flight planned for this week, will be on the crew of the shuttle Discovery later this month or in early April, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today.

title: UNSANCTIONED ARTIFICIAL HEART IMPLANTED IN ARIZONA PATIENT
description: Doctors in Arizona implanted an experimental artificial heart yesterday in a dying 32-year-old man whose body had rejected a transplanted human heart.

title: TUG OF WAR ON BUDGET
description: President Reagan's decision today to veto farm credit legislation, coming a day after the Senate Budget Committee voted to slash the Administration's request for military spending, graphically dramatizes the conflicting priorities advanced by Congress and the White House as the battle over next year's budget heats up.

title: 5-Year Eurobonds Offered by Canada
description: The Canadian Government, which issued $1.05 billion (Canadian) worth of bonds in its domestic market on Tuesday, yesterday offered $500 million worth of five-year Eurobonds in London.

description: Mortgage rates in February dropped for the seventh consecutive month, the Government said today, but analysts warned that the long slide might have come to an end.

description: Mayor Koch withdrew yesterday from a scheduled television appearance with two black columnists whose work he recently called ''racist.'' He said it ''would not be in the best interests of a unified city'' to go ahead with the program.

title: SCOUTING ;   Hard to Fight Mother Nature
description: A city that wants to put up a completely covered sports stadium can hope to save many millions of dollars in construction and maintenance costs by opting for a fiberglass dome instead of something like concrete. But the collapse of the roof at the Pontiac Silverdome earlier this week offered another reminder that inflatable domes are far more vulnerable to the vagaries of nature. And, other than special vigilance during heavy weather, there's not much that can be done about it.

description: It will be like a family reunion tonight when four Stradivarius instruments that once belonged to Nicolo Paganini are reunited with their long-lost elder brother.

title: Dow Down 11.48 After Volcker Talk
description: Renewed fears over interest rates and the course of the dollar depressed stocks yesterday as investors weighed the latest pronouncements of the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker.

title: Topics ;   Dry Lakes and Damp Dogs ;   American SpanielWhen she was a child, a friend tells us, everyone she knew owned a cocker spaniel. Her grandfather had one, a small black female that wiggled when she walked and whose ears - thanks to her big water bowl - were always wet.
description: This being the first dog our friend had ever met, it was the one to which she gave her heart.

title: U.S.F.L. Final At Meadowlands
description: The United States Football League will announce Sunday that its championship game will be played at Giants Stadium on July 14, according to a league source.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Choice of Party Favors
description: There were 50 cakes with 50 candles

title: Clippers Drop Lynam
description: The slowdown offense that

title: State Schools at 4
description: To the Editor:

title: HOOPLA WINDS DOWN AT FRENCH FILM FESTIVAL
description: When the French Film Festival opened here last November, a plane bursting with Gallic celebrities, including French Culture Minister Jack Lang and the glamorous actress Catherine Deneuve, descended on New York. ''Deneuve Queen of New York!'' was the front-page headline in France's mass-circulation Sunday newspaper, Journal du Dimanche. ''Audiovisual New Deal Between France and the U.S.A.!'' trumpeted Liberation, a respected French daily.

title: The Fallout From the Dollar Boom
description: What in the world is happening to the dollar? It's being bid up relentlessly. Does it matter? A great deal, though President Reagan doesn't concede that. Should anything be done? Several things, but they need a push.

title: DEMOCRATS' FOE-NEO-LIBERALS
description: Can neo-liberalism redeem the Democrats? Will the party be restored if it jettisons what remains of its New Deal past and adopts the neo- liberals' free market creed? The answer is a definitive ''no'' - for neo- liberalism is deeply implicated in the Democrats' demise.

title: ALFIN FRAGRANCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
EMC INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTION
description: A theater review on Tuesday, of the City Stage Company's presentation of ''George Dandin'' by Moli ere, misidentified the director. He is Laurence Maslon.

title: ORDERLY TRANSITION AT RCA
description: The RCA Corporation yesterday completed its first orderly change of command since David Sarnoff, its patriarch, began giving up the reins of power two decades ago.

title: Justice for All
description: As war is too important to be left to generals, justice in New York is too important to be left to lawyers. The public has plenty of reason to demand improvements in a system that appears to be sinking in a sea of inefficiency. Yet Speaker Stanley Fink, a thoughtful man, seems convinced the Assembly need not consider serious reforms.

title: VALTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $238,598 from the termination of a pension plan.

title: Cross Burned in Illinois At a Candidate's Home
description: Katie Jackson Booker, a black candidate for Mayor, awoke at 2 A.M. today to see a wooden cross burning in her front yard.

title: BULLET THAT HIT BLACKMUN HOME SEEN BY POLICE AS A RANDOM SHOT
description: Officials investigating a shooting incident at the home of Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the Supreme Court last week told him almost immediately that they believed the shot was fired randomly or at a distant target and was not aimed at him, a police spokesmen said today.

title: SPI PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Dunlop Unit Confirms Talks Dunlop North America Inc.,
description: a subsidiary of Britain's Dunlop Holdings P.L.C., confirmed

title: Russians Capture World Pairs Title
description: Yelena Valova and Oleg Vasiliev of the Soviet Union won the first gold medal of the World Figure Skating Championships today, taking the pairs title after an impressive performance in the free- skating part.

title: ANIXTER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $64,000 for the quarter and $133,000 for the 6 months.

title: Scalp Is Tested In Fugitive Case
description: The Toronto police were completing tests today on human scalp material found in the car of a fugitive arrested in the killing of a Westchester County police officer, according to authorities here.

title: Costs Reach $1.2 Million In Child Molesting Case
description: The case in which seven officials of the Virginia McMartin Preschool are accused of sexual abuse of children has cost the courts more than $1.2 million since February 1984, and may become Los Angeles County's most expensive criminal case, officials said today.

title: CAPITOL HILL TABLOID READ BY 'EVERYONE' NEARS 30TH BIRTHDAY
description: As founder and editor of Roll Call, the durable weekly newspaper that chronicles the comings and goings and gossip of Capitol Hill, Sid Yudain is almost as much a Congressional fixture as Senate bean soup.

title: Rabbi Found Dead In His Apartment
description: A 70-year-old retired rabbi was found dead yesterday with a gag in his mouth on the kitchen floor of his apartment in Flushing, Queens.

title: CANADA ANNOUNCES PLAN TO REDUCE ITS ACID RAIN
description: The Canadian Government announced a major environmental plan today to reduce airborne emissions of sulfur and nitrogen oxides, better known as acid rain, by 50 percent in eastern Canada over the next nine years.

title: Pillsbury Stock
description: The Pillsbury Company said its directors had approved the purchase of up to 750,000 shares of its common stock through May 31, 1986, to be used for employee benefit plans. Pillsbury's stock closed today at $47.25 a share, unchanged, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: HANDY LITTLE VACUUMS
description: SPECIALIZED vacuums are available for many small cleaning jobs. The lightweight Mini-Vac is ideal for removing crumbs from tablecloths or debris from a desk top. It measures approximately 4 1/2 by 3 1/4 inches and is made by A. K. Das.

title: Leased-Backed Sperry Unit Notes
description: The Sperry Finance Corporation yesterday offered $200 million of six- year lease-backed notes.

title: U.S.-Soviet Differences Are Cited After Parley
description: Talks conducted over three days between a bipartisan group of members of Congress and 30 members of the Supreme Soviet were cordial but failed to resolve disagreements between the two countries in critical areas, the participants said today.

title: METS PUT STOCK IN 4 YOUNG PITCHERS
description: Dave Johnson calls them ''my June graduating class.'' They are the young players who have the best chance to make the Mets now or to graduate from the minor leagues by June. And this year, the class consists of four strong-armed pitchers led by Calvin Schiraldi.

title: 2 Elected to Hall of Fame TAMPA, Fla., March 6 - Enos Slaughter and Arky Vaughan, hitting stars in the big leagues 30 years ago, were elected to baseball's
description: Hall of Fame by the Veterans Committee today. But Phil Rizzuto and 27

title: Bridge:Canadian Team Wins Place In the World Championship
description: The right to compete in the 1985 World Team Championships in Sao Paulo, Brazil, in October has been won by a Canadian sextet - Gordon Campbell, Drew Cannell, Mike Chomyn, Doran Flock, Subhash Gupta and Bryan Maksymetz. They won a decisive victory in a three-cornered playoff in Montreal and will join a United States team in representing North America.

title: MAINE UTILITY REPORT QUALIFIED
description: The Maine Public Service Company said yesterday that its auditor, Deloitte Haskins & Sells, had qualified its report of the company's 1984 financial results because of uncertainty over the troubled Seabrook nuclear power project. The auditing firm also stated that the utility might be ''unable to continue as a going concern'' unless conditions improved.

title: Hoffmann Patent
description: Hoffmann-LaRoche Inc., the subsidiary of F. Hoffmann-LaRoche & Company Ltd. of Basel, Switzerland, said it had received the first United States patent for alpha interferon. There are three classes of interferon. Hoffmann-LaRoche said it had patents on all 12 types of alpha interferon, which is produced by white blood cells.

title: THE REGION ;   Man Gets 4 Years In Feud Killing
description: ''I'm sorry it ever happened, and I wish I could turn back the clock,'' a trembling defendant said today as he was sentenced in Nassau County Court to 4 to 12 years in prison for the shooting death of a neighbor.

title: INDEPENDENCE HEALTH PLAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net gain of $500,000, or 13 cents a share, from an officer's death benefit. c-After a tax credit of $454,000.

title: Transactions
description: Signed Nick Eskasy, infielder, and Jeff Russell, pitcher, to one-year contracts. CLEVELAND (AL) - Joe Klein reportedly has accepted position of senior vice president-baseball operations, LOS ANGELES (NL) - Orel Hershiser, pitcher, and Dave Anderson, shortstop, agreed to one-year contracts. title: HUSSEIN ENDORSES EGYPT'S BID TO U.S.
description: King Hussein of Jordan today endorsed a proposal by President Hosni Mubarak that the United States start discussions with a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation on peace talks with Israel.

title: WESTERN UNION LOSS $62 MILLION
description: The Western Union Corporation, reeling from heavy losses in its two- year-old electronic mail service, yesterday reported a $62.2 million loss in the fourth quarter and said that its auditors would issue a qualified opinion about the company's financial report for the year.

title: OFFICE WORKERS AND ARTISTS DEBATE FATE OF A SCULPTURE
description: The turbulent relationship between public art and the public came to a crowded Manhattan courtroom yesterday as a debate raged over an enormous steel wall now bisecting a downtown plaza.

title: A GOOD MIDEAST TIDE
description: The agreement announced Feb. 11 between Yassir Arafat and King Hussein of Jordan on a joint set of principles for peace with Israel is an indication that, on one level at least, events in the Middle East are moving in the right direction. Washington should not overestimate this progress. But it would, in my personal view, be a grave mistake to miss this opportunity to move toward peace.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: South African Police Break Up Black Protests
description: Riot policemen fired rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse black demonstrators today as about 40,000 pupils across the country boycotted classes.

description: b-Net loss

description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany paid a quick visit to Poland today.

title: DANCE: JOFFREY BALLET IN 'ROMEO AND JULIET'
description: -ever season of regular repertory at Lincoln Center, the Joffrey Ballet opened last night at the State Theater with the first American production of John Cranko's grandly theatrical ''Romeo and Juliet.''
