description: Q.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: THESE products, which have been issued by manufacturers in recent months, are helpful for do-it-yourself projects indoors and out:

title: CECILLIA STARK
description: Cecillia Stark, who played the small but pivotal role of Aunt Lotte in Jim Jarmusch's 1984 film ''Stranger Than Paradise,'' died of a heart attack Saturday, her 86th birthday, in Cleveland.

title: TENTATIVE ACCORD REACHED ON SAVIN U.P.I.
description: Tentative agreement was reached today on a plan to restructure the ownership of United Press International.

title: MARKET PLACE ;   RETAIL CHAINS IN NEW ERA
description: Department store chains have entered the early stages of a new era that will be characterized by increasing price competition, according to Thomas P. Farley, a retailing analyst for Salomon Brothers. This situation, he pointed out, offers a marked contrast to the decade of the 1970's when the industry enjoyed a high degree of pricing flexibility.

title: BANISTER CONTINENTAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-No comparable figures available since the company has changed its fiscal year.

title: WESTERN UNION TELEGRAPH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $4,895,000 from a tax benefit and an after-tax gain from the termination of an inactive retirement plan. The company noted that the loss in the year-ago quarter reflected year- end adjustments that included a writedown of $110,000,000 in the value of telecommunications equipment and a provision of $15,000,000 for employee severance costs. Results for 1984 include severance costs amounting to $36,000,000 resulting from work force reductions that have been implemented or are planned. Of this amount $27 million was recorded in the fourth quarter.

title: THE MAN BEHIND THE FERRARO AD
description: The commercial came last night during ABC's prime time adventure ''The Fall Guy.'' For 30 seconds, a woman sat near her two daughters in a scene so diffuse and bright that it might have been a video interpretation of a French Impressionist painting.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, MARCH 7, 1985
description: The Economy

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page article last Saturday about President Reagan's decision against asking Japan for further export quotas on automobiles misstated the combined 1984 earnings of General Motors, Ford and Chrysler. They were $9.8 billion.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TESTIMONY ON U.S. ECONOMIC AID TO ISRAEL
description: Following are excerpts from testimony today to the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Europe and the Middle East by W. Allen Wallis, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, on economic aid to Israel:

title: CHINA SUCCUMBS TO BEAUTY PAGEANTS
description: The finals of a beauty contest were held in China today, an event that attracted more than 600 young men and women, all eager to try their luck with judges seeking a Mr. Canton and a Miss Canton.

title: POLL FINDS MOST AMERICANS FEARFUL OF BEING HARMED BY CUTS IN BUDGET
description: From students worried about paying for college to elderly people afraid they will not be able to make ends meet in their retirement, more than half of all Americans are concerned that they, their families or the nation will be hurt if Congress accepts President Reagan's proposals to reduce domestic spending.

title: ORCHESTRA: ROTTERDAM PHILHARMONIC PERFORMS
description: LISZT'S ''Faust'' Symphony is not an unfairly neglected work. It appears on programs just often enough to remind us that the same composer who could write the magnificently taut Piano Sonata in B minor could, at about the same time, produce music as hollow and full of wind as a balloon. However, this problematical work will always fascinate conductors in search of out-of-the-way repertory because of its dramatic subject. Isn't there an off chance that there may be more to its 75-minute meanderings than past experience has led listeners to believe?

title: A Treasure Not for Raiding The Museum of the American Indian, one of the world's finest and largest ethnological collections, is threatening to desert New York and sell itself to Dallas. The reasons are clouded in controversy, but it's not a loss to be regarded lightly or resisted only with court action. H. Ross Perot of Texas is proposing to buy a billion-dollar resource for $70 million.
description: The museum's million artifacts range in age from several millenniums to just a few years, and come from locations between the Arctic and Tierra del Fuego. Unfortunately, the museum's own location, at 155th Street and Broadway, discourages both visitors and contributions.

title: LIMIT SURTAX ON PARKING, KOCH SAYS
description: Mayor Koch reversed himself yesterday and announced his support for state legislation that would cut by more than half the tax Manhattan residents with cars registered in the borough pay for parking their cars in garages.

title: Rolls-Royce Is Set For New Ad Campaign
description: Rolls-Royce with its agency, Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, will be embarking on a new campaign tomorrow and while the old theme prevails, the effort is different in almost every other way.

title: Let's Study That
description: Daunted by 40 recent studies on the impact of the arts on local economies, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts has decided that there is only one thing to do: order up a study of the studies.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   President of Pabst Planning to Leave
description: William F. Smith Jr., president and chief executive of the Pabst Brewing Company, said yesterday that he expects to announce his resignation within two weeks in the wake of the company's takeover by Paul Kalmanovitz, the California brewer and investor.

title: CML GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
BRONXITE IS TAKING HIS SHOT IN PARIS
description: There is a local flavor this weekend, from White Plains to Queens and all the way to Paris, where Pedro Vilella, a Bronxite, has transferred temporarily from the Lexington Avenue IRT to the Metro.

title: U.S. REGULATORS EXPECT RISE IN PROBLEM BANKS
description: The number of banks that have financial problems and need special scrutiny has increased by almost 40 percent since the end of 1983, Federal regulators say, and they expect the number to climb still higher this year.

title: MAYORAL HOPEFULS QUESTION GOETZ-CASE PROCEDURE
description: Four Democratic mayoral candidates, speaking at a forum in an Upper West Side church, last night questioned the Manhattan District Attorney's handling of the Bernhard H. Goetz case.

title: DEMOCRATS GIVE REAGAN SUPPORT ON ARMS TALKS
description: President Reagan won warm pledges of bipartisan support from Congressional leaders today before sending his negotiators to a new round of arms control talks in Geneva.

title: REFAC TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPENT CORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SEMY ERNEST, CHEF WHO LED IN CULINARY EDUCATION, DIES
description: Semy Ernest, a chef at many prominent American hotels and a leader in culinary education, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 96 years old.

title: LIVING IN A FORMER CHURCH: SPACE, DRAMA AND TRANQUILITY
description: A double-height ceiling in an apartment or house is often overenthusiastically called a cathedral ceiling. But in the case of Nancy Olson's one-bedroom Brooklyn apartment, the 15-foot-high vaulted ceiling with Gothic trim is actually part of the former South Congregational Church in Carroll Gardens. The 1860 Romanesque Revival church, which has a Gothic interior, was converted last year into 26 rental apartments. In Miss Olson's, the living room and bedroom both have tall stained-glass windows.

title: BODY OF U.S. DRUG AGENT BELIEVED FOUND IN MEXICO
description: Two badly decomposed bodies, found today on a ranch southeast of Guadalajara, were tentatively identified as a kidnapped United States drug agent and a Mexican who sometimes worked as his pilot, United States officials announced.

title: THE PECCADILLOES OF ARMADILLOS
description: Ouiet, please. The scholar is about to begin. He is Dr. Angus Gillespie, a purveyor of folklore and iconography who was seduced by bumper stickers and swizzle sticks and South American legends lost in the mists of time.

title: Asarco Studies Alternatives'
description: Asarco Inc., reponding to the recent acquisition of 10 percent of its stock by a company controlled by Robert Holmes a Court, the Australian investor, said yesterday that it was studying ''the full range of alternatives'' available to it.

title: 106 Sued by U.S. On Student Loans
description: The Federal Government yesterday sued 106 New Yorkers accused of failing to repay student loans.

title: Head of Times Mirror To Become Chairman
description: Robert F. Erburu, president and chief executive of the Times Mirror Company, will add the title of chairman next Jan. 1, the publishing company announced. He will succeed Otis Chandler, great-grandson of the founder of The Los Angeles Times, the company's flagship newspaper. Mr. Chandler, 57, will become chairman of the Times Mirror executive committee. He has been chairman of the company since 1981.

title: INTERNATIONAL WRITER'S CONGRESS SET
description: Some of the greatest names in literature from around the world, including several Nobel laureates, are scheduled to meet in New York next January in the first such gathering in the United States for 20 years. The host will be PEN American Center under the presidency of Norman Mailer.

title: GEORGETOWN AND ST. JOHN'S WARY ABOUT OPPOSITION
description: The Big East Conference's sixth postseason tournament, featuring the No. 1 and No. 2 teams in the nation, continues today with afternoon and evening doubleheaders at Madison Square Garden.

title: DIODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After tax credits of $132,979 for the quarter and $391,138 for the 9 months.

title: NOMA INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings figures net income per Class A share.

title: ROCKCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FINDING THE FINISH TO REPAIR ANTIQUES
description: It is not easy to imagine how the fine old antiques we see today looked when they were ready for delivery centuries ago. The best among them must have presented a fine sight - a very new-looking piece, all spick-and- span, as indeed it should be. As today, it had better arrive in that condition, too, and woe betide the driver who took the cart too carelessly over rough roads and ''distressed'' the piece along the way. The mellowness of surface, the odd nick or occasional scratch that added up to the softer appearance admired today came much later. Customers, then as now, wanted a brand-new look on their brand-new piece of furniture.

title: HIGH-FLYING GOAL
description: LANDOVER, Md.

title: MAIL-ORDER LAB SUED OVER TESTS ON COW'S BLOOD
description: A California mail-order medical laboratory that says it tests blood for allergic reactions to food was sued for fraud by the State Attorney General today after the company failed to detect that a sample of cow's blood was not human blood.

title: I CAN'T HEAR YOU, I HAVE A CAREER IN MY EAR
description: In the world of Washington politics and diplomacy, words are not always what they seem. To make it through the day and live to fight again, the players have evolved a language of their own.

title: NATIONAL AIRPORT: GIVING NEW MEANING TO CONGESTION
description: Parking a single-engine car at Washington National Airport these days can take steelier nerves than landing a big jet.

title: DEALERS' E.S.M. LOSSES ARE CALLED MANAGEABLE
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which oversees the unregulated market for government securities, announced yesterday that losses stemming from the collapse of E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. were not ''of unmanageable proportions in the dealer community'' but added that it still does not know ''the whole story.''

title: UNITED STATES TRUCK LINES INC OF DELAWARE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ETHIOPIA SAID TO LAG ON PRIORITY FOR FOOD AT DOCKS
description: A senior relief official said today that Ethiopian authorities were not honoring a pledge to keep three berths at this Red Sea port continuously available for the unloading of food for famine victims.

title: Crocker Cuts Midland Net
description: A huge loss at the Crocker National Corporation, the Midland Bank Group's American subsidiary, overshadowed strong growth in Midland's other businesses during 1984 as the group's overall net income fell 60 percent, to $47.3 million, from $119.7 million in 1983.

title: New Debt Group At Merrill Lynch
description: In a move it said was in response to important changes in the debt market, Merrill Lynch & Company announced yesterday that it had formed a new debt transactions group.

title: Philon Uses AC&R
description: AC&R Advertising, a Ted Bates Worldwide subsidiary, has been named to do advertising for Philon, Inc., a software supplier to the microcomputer industry. Billings are expected to be around $2.5 million. This is Philon's first full-service agency.

title: AWARDS FOR FURNITURE, LIGHTING DESIGN
description: Progressive Architecture received 920 entries from 23 countries this year in their annual furniture and lighting design competition. ''The number of entries goes up every year,'' said Pilar Viladas, senior editor of the publication, a journal for architects and designers, ''We trying to encourage people to come up with new ideas about furniture and lighting .'' The entries are considered by a jury of professional architects and designers and the competition as a whole has come to be considered as a mini-barometer of changing styles in furniture design.

title: LOSSES GROW IN QUARTER AT STATE SAVING BANKS
description: The financial condition of New York's state-chartered savings banks continued to deteriorate in the fourth quarter, but industry spokesmen said they expected a substantial improvement this quarter because of lower interest rates.

title: WOMEN'S HISTORY HONORED FOR MONTH
description: WOMEN'S History Month began last Friday, and a number of conferences, performances, forums and study groups are scheduled for New York in March, all keyed to the educational theme of ''helping to write women back into history,'' according to Kay J. Wight, chairman of the New York Commission on the Status of Women.

title: COUSINS PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company noted that it sold its interests in six shopping centers during 1984 generating more than $46 million of pre-tax income.

title: Israel Rejects P.L.O. Role
description: Israel today rejected the call by King Hussein and President Mubarak for a central role for the P.L.O. in peace talks.

title: SCOUTING ;   Apple Picking
description: Especially when it comes to negotiating contracts, Bob Woolf, the sports attorney, doesn't like comparing apples and oranges. But if he wants one of his clients, the Knick center Bill Cartwright, to remain in the Big Apple, he'll have to deal with a lot of such comparisons - all of them coming from Dave DeBusschere.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Columbia Pictures Industries has promoted Harvey J. Lehman to vice president-administration.

title: BMC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,367,000 for the quarter and $4,455,000 for year. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $148,000 for the quarter and $290,000 for the year. BMC made a fourth quarter provision of $900,000 for estimated losses to be incurred in the future disposal of two business segments.

title: Channel 13 Presents Essay on Elephants
description: Another television show about elephants? What could we possibly learn about them that we didn't know before and that warrants a viewer's attention in the bargain?

title: Flutie Is No.1 in Football Pay
description: New information about Doug Flutie's contract reveals that the rookie quarterback is the highest salaried player in professional football. He will earn $1,250,000 this season, according to several sources who have examined his contract with the Generals - $350,000 more than Joe Montana will earn next season after leading the 49ers to victory in the Super Bowl.

title: FILM: 'MASK,' BOGDANOVICH TALE OF A RARE DISEASE
description: ''Mask,'' the year's first major fatal disease movie, is Peter Bogdanovich's California- biker version of ''The Elephant Man.'' The film, opening today at the New York Twin Theater, is based on the true story of Rocky Dennis. The 16-year-old Rocky is a perfectly ordinary teen-ager except for the fact that he suffers from craniodiaphyseal dysplasia, a disorder, according to the film, in which calcium accumulates in the skull to swell the head to almost twice its normal size.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Pat Cummings , the Knick center who has missed three games because of back spasms, expects to return to the lineup tomorrow afternoon against the Philadelphia 76ers at the Garden.

title: KEARNEY-NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $459,000 for the quarter and a loss of $649,000 from discontinued operations of Kearney Magnetics for the year. c-After a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $4,140,000 for the quarter and year. d-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $11,000 for the quarter and $42,000 for the year.

title: FLAMES RALLY TO BEAT RANGERS
description: These are extreme times for the Rangers: They are awfully good or awfully bad. Tonight, after watching a 3-0 lead dissolve into an 11-5 loss to the Calgary Flames, they ought to be awfully concerned about what lies ahead, if anything, in the playoffs.

title: MORE FLOODING FEARED
description: Students skipped class to stack sandbags along the flooded Illinois River today as the Red Cross called for relief workers to care for more than 1,100 people who had been left homeless by flooding.

title: PRIESTS GATHER TO PONDER THEIR DWINDLING RANKS
description: Virtually all of the 615 Roman Catholic parish priests in Brooklyn and Queens locked up their churches yesterday and gathered to talk about what their Bishop called a major crisis - the rapidly declining number of priests available to serve the 1.3 million Catholics in the diocese.

title: California Utility Mortgage Bonds
description: Southern California Edison offered $225 million of first and refunding mortgage bonds, due March 15, 2015.

title: WABC-TV Account Is Going to Lois Pitts
description: Wasting no time, WABC-TV, Channel 7, which announced Monday that it had reached an impasse in its contract negotiations with Altschiller, Reitzfeld, Solin and was bidding it farewell, has reported that it is taking its approximately $5 million advertising account to Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK.

title: PLY-GEM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HAITIAN ROCK BAND
description: The Haitian rock band Tabou Combo will perform tonight at 11:30 at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (475-5120). Tickets are $15.

title: Hunt Sugar Unit In Chapter 11
description: The Great Western Sugar Company, one of the last assets of the Hunt International Resources Company, has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The Denver-based company had been shut down last week by its parent company, which is owned by Nelson Bunker Hunt and W. Herbert Hunt of Dallas.

title: The Seat Set-To
description: Although the new Congress is now entering its third month, the House Energy and Commerce Committee, faced with such major issues as the sale of Conrail and curtailing funds to Amtrak, finds itself limping along at less than full speed, with Republicans boycotting subcommittee hearings in protest over what they consider an unfair allocation of seats.

title: Chicago's Archbishop Voices 'Misgivings' on 'Star Wars'
description: Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago tonight expressed ''profound misgivings'' about the Reagan Administration's Strategic Defense Initiative, popularly known as ''Star Wars.''

title: E.P.A. FACES TEST ON TRUCK POLLUTION
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is under court order to regulate air pollution from trucks and buses by next week, but the Office of Management and Budget is seeking to weaken the proposed rules.

title: Mozart From Salzburg
description: The Mozarteum Orchestra of Salzburg, under the direction of Hans Graf, will play at Avery Fisher Hall tonight at 8.

title: F.D.A. PONDERS ACTION ON UNSANCTIONED IMPLANT
description: A spokesman for the Food and Drug Administration said today that it had not decided whether to act against surgeons who implanted an artificial heart that had not received Federal approval.

title: Discussing Plants
description: A discussion on the care of indoor plants will be led by Joel Rapp on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue (718) 622-4433. Mr. Rapp is author of the book ''Mr. Mother Earth's Hassle-Free Indoor Plants'' and the host of a show on WABC-AM. Admission is $2; 50 cents for those under 12 and the elderly.

title: ZIMBABWE PARTY REPORTS ATTACKS
description: At least 56 supporters of the Zimbabwean opposition leader Joshua Nkomo have been abducted and probably killed by squads operating at night and in unmarked cars in the troubled province of Matabeleland, church officials and opposition figures said this week.

title: ELDERLY SEE SHARE OF HOSPITAL COSTS SOAR
description: Because of Federal efforts to reduce Medicare's soaring costs, elderly beneficiaries are seeing sharp increases in their out-of-pocket expenses for a stay in the hospital, Federal health officials said yesterday.

title: What 4-Year-Olds Can Teach the School System
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: STORY OF A BOXER, ROD SERLINGS'S 'REQUIEM'
description: Watching John Lithgow's heavyweight performance in ''Requiem for a Heavyweight,'' one desperately wants to believe there's just as much heft to the newly arrived stage version of Rod Serling's 1956 teleplay. There isn't, but fans of the gifted star may want to see what he's up to at the Martin Beck these nights. An actor who has often done his best work playing athletes - from an English rugby player (''The Changing Room'') to a transsexual football player (''The World According to Garp'') - Mr. Lithgow is a seething figure of bruised flesh and wounded pride in the role of Serling's pugilist, Harlan ''Mountain'' McClintock.

title: PACIFIC GAS TRANSMISSION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a reduction of $3,597,000 for the quarter and year resulting from the establishment of reserves for the company's investments in the completion phase of the western leg of the Alaskan natural gas transportation system and the Rocky Mountain pipeline project, a writedown of $600,000 for the quarter for the company's investment in an enhanced oil recovery project, and an after-tax gain of $3,000,000, or 32 cents a share, for the year from the sale by the company's subsidiary, Pacific Transmission Supply Co., of deep gas leasehold rights in the Lake Ridge unit of the Hoback Prospect in western Wyoming. c-After a reduction of $3,500,000 from a reserve for the company's general rate case proceeding, reflecting a settlement agreement. The additional reserve covered the period from March 18, 1982 through Dec. 31, 1983.

title: COASTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TEXSCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income. The company said net income for the year-ago quarter was restated to include a gain of $128,000 due to revisions of the company's effective tax rate. Net income for the year-ago 9 months was restated to show a reduction of $1,587,000 due to the correction of the purchase price allocation of acquisitions and revision of the company's effective tax rate.

title: The Japanese Stock Outlook
description: A SHARP break in prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange last spring sent the Nikkei Dow Jones average tumbling below 10,000 and caused global money managers to worry about the outlook for Japanese equities. Their concern, as it turned out, was overdone.

title: CHIN 2D IN TOKYO SKATING
description: With speed and powerful leaps, Tiffany Chin of the United States today moved briskly into strong contention for the women's singles title at the 1985 world figure skating championships.

title: People
Blues at Tramps
description: The Paul Butterfield Blues Band will perform tonight and tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777- 5077) . Sets begin at about 9:30 and midnight; there is a $9 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: BRITISH GOVERNOR BIDS CHIEF RESIGN IN ISLES OFF BAHAMAS
description: The British Governor of this windswept protectorate of 37 little islands north of the Caribbean called today for the resignation of the elected head of government, who has been accused of involvement in a conspiracy to smuggle drugs into the United States.

title: Joseph Wolman, Pianist, 79; Director of a Chamber Group
description: The pianist Joseph Wolman, who was musical director of the Chamber Music Associates, died of cancer on Feb. 28 at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: George Schick, 76, Is Dead; President of Music School
description: The conductor George Schick, who was president of the Manhattan School of Music from 1969-76, died in Manhattan Thursday after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: GETTING THE AFFLUENT TO COOPERATE AT AN L.I. COMPLEX
description: On a former estate nestled in the thick woods of Long Island's North Shore, a delicate balance is being attempted. Here, on 160 acres of trees and ponds just off Sheep Lane, some wealthy and often strong-willed property buyers are being asked to cooperate with - and submit to - a homeowners association that has absolutely no legal power. It is an exercise in friendly, and sometimes not so friendly, persuasion.

title: A DEDICATED HEART SURGEON
description: Some time back, after the second of his transplant patients had died right after surgery because of the rapid failure of the new heart, Dr. Jack Copeland vowed that he would do everything in his power to see that it never happened again. Dr. Copeland's emergency decision Wednesday to defy Federal rules and public controversy by temporarily sustaining a patient with an unapproved artificial heart came as no surprise to many of his colleagues and patients, who described him as a brilliant surgeon who was unusually dedicated to his patients.

title: ALBERT E. WAUGH
description: Albert E. Waugh, a former provost and vice president of the University of Connecticut, died Wednesday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.

title: CHOMERICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $1,045,000 from the reversal of a tax benefit. c-Net income after tax benefits of $280,000 for the quarter and $900,000 for the year. d-After a tax benefit of $185,000.

title: SCAASI'S SLENDER SIREN LOOK
description: The message for spring from Arnold Scaasi centers on pure luxury, which is as it should be, since these are fashions for women who have sufficient interest in clothes to have them made to order and sufficient income to pay for them. Though the designer has recently opened a ready- to-wear concern on Seventh Avenue, the focal point of his work is still his custom collection.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: By John Gross;
description: SMALL WORLD: An Academic Romance.

title: SEAT-BET LAW IS USED TO FIGHT PROSTITUTION
description: Police officers are using New York State's new mandatory seat-belt law to discourage prostitution on the West Side.

title: VA. TECH IS UPSET IN METRO OPENER
description: Alton Lee Gipson scored 33 points and David Speights added 23 to lead Florida State to a 97-93 upset of Virginia Tech in the opening round of the Metro Conference tournament today.

title: THE NEW TEAM AT PAPLER
description: -winning art director, has left Wells, Rich, Greene to join what was Plapler & Associates and has become a partner in what is now Plapler Russo Wilvers & Associates. And with the move he adds his graphics skills to the copywriting talents of Lawrence Plapler, the former president, and John Russo, who will now be sharing his creative director title with his former boss, Bob Wilvers.

title: RICHTON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $431,000 for the quarter and 9 months, and extraordinary gains of $415,000 for the quarter and $3,108,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss after a loss of $674,000 from discontinued operations. d-Includes a gain of $651,000 from discontinued operations. All 1984 results are restated.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: MEMORIE LEWIS settled into her seat at the table, sighed, turned to Morton Janklow and said: ''This is the first year the party is in one place. It's wonderful to be able to sit here and enjoy dinner.'' The party was the Joffrey Ballet's annual benefit, held Wednesday on the Promenade of the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center after the opening of ''Romeo and Juliet.''

title: Walesa Faces Charges Of Inciting Unrest
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, and three colleagues received summonses today to report to the Gdansk prosecutor for questioning on charges of inciting public unrest and organizing illegal protests.

title: CITY AND 12 OIL COMPANIES DIFFER ON GASOLINE RATINGS
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs accused 12 oil companies yesterday of misrepresenting gasoline octane ratings, but the companies denied the charges, saying the department's testing methods were at fault.

title: Whither Trabandt?
description: Energy Secretary John S. Herrington has proposed that a former Capitol Hill aide, Charles A. Trabandt, be named to a Republican slot on the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. But while President Reagan is said to have approved the move, Mr. Trabandt's name has not been submitted for Senate confirmation, primarily because of opposition of some Senate Republicans who favor another term for a current commissioner, Georgiana Sheldon.

title: The Answer Man
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York,

title: Bridge:Card Table Figures in Plot Of New Play on Broadway
description: There were Martha and Mary and Connie and Nora and Alice and Ann and Lil and Betsy. They were eight sisters in Rhode Island, and for 13 years, from 1931 to 1944, they played their two-table game twice monthly.

title: BUILT COCA-COLA EMPIRE
description: Robert W. Woodruff, a college dropout who became the driving force behind the growth of the Coca-Cola Company and built it into an international financial empire, died today in Emory University Hospital. He was 95 years old and had been hospitalized for 10 days.

title: Sushi and tempura on Park Avenue.
description: Whenever I dine at a sushi bar and admire the nimble-fingered chefs at work as they banter and laugh, I wish I had a Japanese dictionary to memorize the phrase ''Is that still fresh?'' After all, freshness is the sine qua non of Japanese restaurants, and my rule of thumb in choosing one is: ''The busier the dining room, the better the fish.''

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
Marching Orders
description: Rail birds come in all shapes and sizes but - at least the way the term is commonly applied - never with feathers. Still, there is a scene to be seen these days at Aqueduct, where each race is preceded by not one post parade, but two.

title: Indiana Loses
description: Coach Bob Knight of Indiana returned from a one-game suspension tonight and was rudely greeted by Sam Vincent, who scored 31 points and led Michigan State to a 68-58 victory in the Big Ten Conference game.

title: PIEDMONT MANAGEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: BASS AND DRUMS
description: The trumpeter Lester Bowie and Brass Fantasy, his nine-member brass-and-drums group, will perform tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at Carnegie Recital Hall, 154 West 57th Street (247-7800). Tickets are $10.

title: U.S. Vows to Find Killers
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that those responsible for killing Mr. Camarena Salazar would be tracked down and ''brought to justice.''

title: 2 FOUND GUILTY IN THEFT OF $11 MILLION AT SENTRY
description: Two men were convicted and one was acquitted last night of Federal charges involving the theft of $11 million from the Sentry armored-car company in the Bronx.

title: DRAWING THE LINE
description: PARIS The election is indeed over. But

title: JAPAN'S VIEW OF 21ST CENTURY
description: There are talking robots, walking robots, robots that draw pictures, robots that play Bach on the organ, and singing stuffed animal robots. There are computer-designed 3-D movies featuring songs with refrains like ''Machines and humans can be friends.'' There are even what have been dubbed ''ladies of the future'' - phalanxes of hostesses dressed in high- tech metallic shades of silver and gold.

title: ELECTRONIC MEMORIES & MAGETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $617,000 for the quarter and the year. c-Net income

title: CANADA MAY EXPEL MAN HELD IN OFFICER'S SLAYING
description: Canadian police authorities said today that Alex J. Mengel, who was seized in Toronto last Saturday as a fugitive in the killing of a Westchester County police officer, could be deported as an illegal alien next week.

title: Iran and Iraq Step Up Attacks on Civilians
description: Iraq and Iran reported artillery attacks on six border communities today and pledged further widening of their four-and-a-half-year-old war, in whose latest phase civilians have become the targets.

title: Confidence Index Is High By The Associated Press American consumers retained ''a relatively high level''
description: of confidence in the economy

title: OFFICER CHARGED IN THE SHOOTING OF A TEEN-AGER
description: A Queens grand jury indicted a police officer yesterday for seriously wounding a 17-year-old youth who tried to flee after the officer had caught him jumping a subway turnstile last December. The youth, who was paralyzed below the waist, is in the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst.

title: SEAT OF POWER AND WOE
description: Consider the special psychological lure of Washington. What sets the capital apart from all other American cities, what gives it an appeal like no other is - let's face it - power.

title: Rare posters to be offered.
description: More than a score of rare posters by Alphonse Mucha, A. M. Cassandre, Henri de Toulouse- Lautrec and Walter Schnackenberg are among the 330 items to be offered tomorrow in the first sale organized by Poster Auctions International, a new specialty auction house. The sale begins at 1 P.M. at the Essex House, 160 Central Park South.

title: Money Supply Up $3.6 Billion
description: The Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that the nation's basic money supply grew by $3.6 billion for the week ended Feb. 25.

title: CBS SPECIAL ON THE ILLUSIONIST DAVID COPPERFIELD
description: Once every year or so, CBS brings forth a special featuring ''The Magic of David Copperfield.'' The 1985 edition, seventh in the series, can be seen tonight on Channel 2 at 8 o'clock.

title: COASTAL'S CHIEF PLAYS TO WIN
description: He is one of the most disliked, if envied, men in the oil patch. To this day, municipal officials in Texas complain that he promised them 20 years of cheap energy, then reneged. Competitors marvel at how, penniless and relatively inexperienced, he could start a gas-pipeline company from scratch, win some big cities as customers, and build a $6 billion- a-year energy comglomerate.

title: DENTISTS MAY ENDORSE ANTI-PLAQUE INGREDIENT
description: The American Dental Association's Council on Dental Therapeutics will probably grant its seal of approval in the ''near future'' to several proposed agents for toothpastes or mouthwashes that fight plaque and gum disease, an official said today.

title: Back to Work
description: After the kind of relaxing winter vacation in Southern California that befits a multimillion-dollar champion, John Henry returned to the workaday world Wednesday, when he was taken by van away from the easy life at Galway Downs in Temecula to a stall at Santa Anita, 60 miles south.

title: Sun Buy-Back
description: The Sun Company said it plans a $500 million, multiyear stock repurchase program.

title: Wounds of Old Labor Battles Reopened
description: To the Editor:

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Houston Astros , at Kissimee, Fla., 1:30 P.M. This is the first spring game for the Yankees. The Mets have an intrasquad game, at St. Petersburg, Fla. Basketball

title: THE DANCE: PREMIERE OF CUNNINGHAM WORK
description: Watching Merce Cunningham's choreography can be like watching traffic. That was certainly evident when the Merce Cunningham Dance Company offered the New York premiere of ''Doubles'' and this season's first performance of ''Trails'' Wednesday night at the City Center.

title: HOYAS DEMORALIZE CONNECTICUT, 93-62
description: While preparing his Connecticut team for top-ranked Georgetown, Coach Dom Perno took an unusual approach in trying to solve the fierce full-court defensive pressure expected from the Hoyas in the opening round of the Big East Conference tournament. He matched his starters against seven defenders during practice to simulate the Hoyas' intensity.

title: EMERGENCY FUND DRIVE IS BEGUN AT FISK UNIVERSITY
description: Officials and alumni of the financially troubled Fisk University here have stepped up their effort to rescue the school, at one time one of the foremost black colleges in the nation.

title: Laidlaw Dismisses 10% of Employees
description: Laidlaw Adams & Peck Inc. said it had dismissed 33 employees in its institutional brokerage division, or about 10 percent of its total work force. Robert H. Clayton Jr., the securities firm's chairman and chief executive, said the employees had been discharged in part because of their response to salary cuts imposed last month after the dissolution of Laidlaw's merger with Henry Ansbacher Holdings P.L.C., a British merchant bank.

title: E.S.M. COLLAPSE: A LESSON IN SAFETY
description: The collapse of E.S.M. Government Securities Inc.,, a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., firm with losses estimated at more than $250 million, is a reminder to local government officials and other investors that their supposedly safe investments in United States Treasury securities can be jeopardized by problems at the securities firm they do business with.

title: Policeman and 2 Ex-Officers Are Arrested in Burglaries
description: A city police officer and two former officers were arrested Wednesday and charged with burglarizing two cheese shops, a restaurant and a bar in South Philadelphia.

title: NEW PATTERNS IN GIVING CHALLENGING UNITED WAY
description: As Americans increase their charitable gifts these days, they increasingly want to make a direct selection of the organizations to receive their dollars, according to two studies.

title: SALVADOR ARMY-SPOKESMAN SLAIN
description: The chief spokesman for the Salvadoran Army was shot and killed at a fashionable sports club today by gunmen who draped a rebel banner over his body, witnesses said.

title: LAWMAKERS AGREE ON STRATEGY TYING THE MX TO GENEVA
description: An influential group of senators and representatives have agreed on a broad strategy linking the future of President Reagan's nuclear weapons program to signs of American ''good faith'' at the arms control talks in Geneva.

title: MARGE SCHOOT, CINCINNATI BOOSTER, IS ROOTING FOR HER HOME TEAM
description: Mention the name ''Marge'' in Cincinnati and almost everyone knows whom you're talking about. She is Marge Schott, the new principal owner of the Cincinnati Reds baseball team, and she is feisty, flamboyant and plain-talking.

title: No Headline
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 8, 1985 International

title: Debt Issues
description: Branch Corp. is offering $30 million of 8 3/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2005, priced at 100, through underwriters led by Robinson-Humphrey Co.

title: Union Carbide Works To Reopen U.S. Plant
description: The Union Carbide Corporation has started preliminary construction work needed to reopen its methyl isocyanate unit here, which has been closed since 2,000 people died when the chemical leaked from a company plant in Bhopal, India.

title: UNIVERSAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BRIEFS
description: Bell Communications Research, Livingston, N.J., said it had become the 21st corporate shareholder in the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corp. of Austin, Tex., a research consortium. The Bell unit was formed last year in the breakup of the Bell System and is owned by the seven regional telephone holding companies.

title: Finance Company Increases Offering
description: The International Lease Finance Corporation offered $75 million of four-year notes, an increase from $50 million.

title: WHO LEADS CATHOLICS?
description: As the Roman Catholic Church in America prepares for the 20-year review of the Second Vatican Council in Rome next autumn, those who study and report on Catholicism may legitimately wonder whether the Church's leaders have enough credibility left for the meeting to matter much one way or another.

title: Miller-Wohl Head Quits After Only Nine Months
description: Philip Brous, the president of Miller-Wohl Stores, is resigning today, about nine months after the large women's apparel chain was acquired by the Petrie Stores Corporation.

title: Bodies of 3 Tourists Identified
description: The remains of a young American and two other foreign tourists kidnapped by rebels in 1982 in Matabeleland have been positively identified, Prime Minister Mugabe announced here today.

title: Sperry Statement
description: The Sperry Corporation, which broke off merger talks last week with the ITT Corporation, said yesterday that ''we are not now in discussions with anyone nor are we planning to hold discussions with anyone.'' The statement, which seemed to leave open the possibility of future talks, came after widespread rumors about the company's availability for takeover pushed the stock up $3 a share at one point yesterday. The stock closed at $51.375, up 37.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: WRITERS GATHER TO CELEBRATE NEW HOPWOOD ENDOWMENT
description: ''I was an ignoramus when I came and nearly one when I left,'' the speaker said of his college days at the University of Michigan. Indulgent laughter bubbled up from the audience. The speaker was, after all, the playwright Arthur Miller. His audience was filled with writers. And they had come together Wednesday evening, in a small room on the 11th floor of the Harper & Row building, to celebrate a milestone in the life of the university's creative writing program.

title: SUN CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $606,000 for the quarter and $1,034,000 for the year. c-Net loss after a loss of $168,000 from discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $835,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ERIC SLOANE, WHO CELEBRATED EARLY AMERICANA IN PAINTINGS
description: The painter and author Eric Sloane, who evoked early American life in dozens of books and paintings, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital. Mr. Sloane, who was 80 years old, lived in Santa Fe, N.M., and was visiting New York for an exhibition of his paintings that opened Monday at the Hammer Galleries, 33 West 57th Street.

title: CDN IMPERIAL BANK OF COMERCE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Apollo Stompers
description: The pianist Jaki Byard and his big band, the Apollo Stompers, will perform tonight and tomorrow at 10 P.M. and midnight at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue at 29th Street (244-0997). Tickets are $8.

title: Customer Renews Tandon Order
description: The Tandon Corporation said its largest customer had renewed a previously canceled order for some of Tandon's disk drives. As a result, Tandon said, a change-over to a new generation of disk drives later this year will not hurt 1985 earnings as much as previously believed.

title: Final Workout for Mets
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 The Mets held their final workout Thursday before starting the countdown to opening day.

title: ART: MIDDLE-CLASS SATIRE FROM WILLIAM KING
description: The sculptor William King has been satirizing humanity for so long that it seems doubtful he could play the subject straight even if he wanted to. Actually, he has had his ''serious'' moments, notably in his large figures of the 1970's, composed of shapes cut from aluminum plate, and he's having them again in the show at the Terry Dintenfass Gallery, 50 West 57th Street.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ashton-Tate Co., Culver City, Calif., a publisher of microcomputer software, has appointed Ronald S. Posner executive vice president of sales and marketing.

title: JOHN THOMPSON'S WAY
description: He returned to the scene of the crime yesterday, where last week John Thompson stepped out of character and upstaged his St. John's counterpart, Lou Carnesecca, in what will rank as the Brink's job of the college basketball season and qualify Thompson for an honorary degree in the field of psychological ploys.

title: POLYSAR LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Arctic Visitor
description: It was a thrilling moment for John Farrand Jr. He saw a gyrfalcon.

title: Five Mexicans Shot in Texas; One Dead and 4 Hospitalized
description: Five Mexican nationals were found shot near a rural road today after an apparent robbery, and one of the victims bled to death after his throat was cut, the authorities said.

title: A MEMORANDUM: U.N. DIPLOMACY
description: To Lieut Gen. Vernon A. Walters:

title: Dow Shows Drop Of 8.84, to 1,271.53
description: Stock prices fell across a broad front again yesterday, depressed by doubt over the weekly money supply figures and the course of interest rates and the economy.

title: CONCERT: A DUO PLAYS DOUBLE-BASS
description: It must take quite a bit of imagination to establish a performing ensemble that has an original repertory of only one work, but that's what two Dutch double- bass players, Hans Roe lofsen and Ru dolf Senn, have done in banding together as the Grand Duo Concertant. The pre-existing work from which they derived their name is Giovanni Bottesini's Grand Duo Concertant, which dates from about 1850.

title: 'WEST INDIES,' MUSICAL HISTORY
description: Med Hondo's ''West Indies,'' playing today and tomorrow at the Thalia, is a revolutionary musical in both senses of the word. This witty, scathing Mauritanian-Algerian co-production offers an angry view of West Indian history, using imaginative staging and a very fluid visual style. The film's single set is an enormous slave ship, which doubles as anything from a disco to the court of tire history of colonization in the Caribbean. Though this sounds like much more material than a single film can encompass, Mr. Hondo's resourcefulness is a continual surprise.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
STATE COMPTROLLER SAYS NEW YORK CITY'S ECONOMY IS STRONGEST IN 25 YEARS
description: New York City's economy is stronger now than at any time in the last 25 years and should continue to grow steadily, the State Comptroller said yesterday.

title: THE SCREEN: PHILIPPE NOIRET STARS IN 'MY NEW PARTNER'
description: In a long and distinguished career in French films that have included Bertrand Tavernier's

title: PATIENT WITH 3D IMPLANTED HEART STRUGGLES FOR HIS LIFE IN ARIZONA
description: A 33- year-old Arizona auto mechanic today was given his third new heart in 46 hours, the latest one a human organ to replace an experimental mechanical device. Tonight, although he showed slight improvement, he was in extremely critical condition, struggling to overcome the complications of his marathon surgery.

title: U.S. PICKS DELEGATION FOR PARLEY ON WOMEN
description: Maureen Reagan, the President's daughter, has been named by the State Department to head the 36- member United States delegation to the world women's conference being sponsored by the United Nations this summer in Nairobi, Kenya.

title: Triple Bill of Rock
description: The Del-Lords, a New York rock band, will head a triple bill tonight at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place at East 15th Street (477-3728) . Live music begins at about 11:30; the Del-Lords will perform sometime after 1 A.M. Tickets are $10.

title: GLOOM CONTINUES AT HIALEAH
description: After 50 afternoons of racing at Gulfstream Park without a drop of rain smudging the track, it began to pour an hour before post time for the opening of Hialeah Park today. That shower of hard luck, which probably kept many customers at home, seemed to reflect this track's relatively hard times.

title: DINING OUT GUIDE ;   Special Egg Dishes
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday LEAR WITH A TWIST

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about an artificial heart implant at the University of Arizona misstated what a Food and Drug Administration official had told the university hospital. The agency said it did tell the hospital the procedures that should be followed to get permission for the implant, but according to spokesmen for both the agency and hospital, it did not tell the hospital not to proceed with the implant. Articles on the operation appear today on pages A1 and A18.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Glucksman to Start A Consulting Firm
description: After less than five months as an executive vice president of the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company, Lewis L. Glucksman plans to resign to start his own corporate finance consulting company, a spokesman for the American Express Company, Fireman's Fund's parent, said yesterday.

title: PLAY BALL! AND POLITICS
description: The good news is that the baseball

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: The plot aside, a variety of things about Brian De Palma's next film are of interest. For one, ''Wise Guys'' is a comedy, and the director has not concentrated on humor since his ''Greetings'' days of the late 1960's. For another, much of it is being shot in Newark and Jersey City. For a third, Mr. De Palma was a relatively late addition to ''Wise Guys,'' which already had two stars, a screenplay and a strongly visible and opinionated producer by the time the director became involved. The producer is Aaron Russo, who also produced ''The Rose,'' ''Trading Places,'' ''Partners'' and ''Teachers,'' and who says he and Mr. De Palma will not be locking horns. ''We have a relationship that borders on love,'' Mr. Russo said.

title: NOVO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings figures represent net income per American Depository Share.

description: their financial books to the players' union. But he added that he would not be deterred by opposition from the

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,657,000 and a nonrecurring charge for a divestiture of $9.3 million. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $546,000. The 1984 results were restated to reflect the discontinuation of the company's recreational products business.

title: UNITED STATES CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MUSIC: LEINSDORF CONDUCTS THE NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC
description: Before Bach sat down to write his own music, we are told, he often would go to a keyboard and play the works of other composers. No doubt he took off from the original piece before long and began to improvise, allowing imagination to flow freely. Similar devices are used by many artists and artisans to undam the creative juices, though the results are not usually worth presenting in public.

title: 3 Lead in Rich Uniden Event
description: Pat Meyers, Alice Miller and Bonnie Lauer each shot 2-under-par 70 today to share a one-shot lead after the first round of the $330,000 Uniden Invitational. The 72-hole tournament, second only to the Dinah Shore in purse money on the women's pro golf tour, offers $49,500 to the winner.

title: Peso Devalued By Mexico
description: The Government has decided to devalue Mexico's currency, the peso, at a slightly higher daily rate to increase the competitiveness of Mexican exports.

title: Recovery Comes In Small Steps
description: Bob Bourne bent the three middle fingers on his right hand. It was the simplest of tasks, but it pleased him. His recuperation was going as scheduled.

title: Busy Stages at Public
description: Live theater will fill all but one of the five stages this weekend at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street (598- 7150.) In the Newman Theater, Edna O'Brien's ''Virginia,'' with Kate Nelligan, is on tonight at 8, tomorrow at 8 and Sunday at 3 and 8.

title: PRESIDENTIAL LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $3,711 for the quarter and $1,138,711 for the year. c-Includes realized investment gains of $1,245,660 for the quarter and $3,731,660 for the year. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid Jan. 10.

title: TRINITY RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: NORTH CANADIAN OILS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said 1984 results include the operations of Bankeno Mines Ltd. for the fourth quarter.

title: K Mart Offers 10-Year Notes
description: The K Mart Corporation yesterday offered $150 million worth of 10-year notes.

title: WORKERS REJOICE OVER U.P.I. ACCORD
description: On Wednesday, as frantic negotiations were under way between the owners of United Press International and the troubled news agency's principal creditor, some U.P.I. staff members began clearing out their desks amid reports of bouncing payroll checks and fears of imminent bankruptcy.

title: Greenmail: Who's the Villain?
description: T. Boone Pickens . . . Carl Icahn . . . Saul Steinberg . . . Irwin Jacobs . . . Sir James Goldsmith. Their names are spoken with a shudder in board rooms from Pittsburgh to Bartlesville. They are the new buccaneers of capitalism, making millions by taking over, or just threatening to take over, America's largest corporations.

title: ART: ABSTRACT PAINTERS REGAIN OLD CHARISMA
description: The reign of Realism over the last few years has by no means subdued the large and hardy band of abstract painters in our midst, most of whom have stubbornly refused to convert from their strongly held faith. Their work has certainly not been absent from the current scene; it's simply that it no longer basks in the consensual glow conferred by a dominant trend.

title: WPIX's Pat Harper Will Go to WNBC-TV
description: Pat Harper, who has co-anchored WPIX-TV news broadcasts since 1975, is leaving the station to go to WNBC-TV, the National Broadcasting Company station announced yesterday. She will co-anchor the news program ''News 4 New York'' with Chuck Scarborough, beginning April 22 at 6 P.M.

title: NATIONAL GALLERY SEEKS MONEY FROM THE PUBLIC
description: The 35,000 people on the National Gallery of Art's mailing list will find something unusual included in this month's mailing: the first solicitation for contributions from the public ever made by the museum.

title: DEVILS TIE ON 2 GOALS IN LAST 40 SECONDS
description: The Devils tied the Islanders tonight, 4-4, but the Devils considered it a moral victory because they rallied for two goals against Billy Smith in the last 40 seconds of regulation at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: THREE SINGERS REFLECT ON MUSIC CAREERS
description: Joan Baez is wearing two hats. Nina Simone has a new home base. And Triona Ni Dhomhnaill is mixing her native Irish music with other sounds. The three singers are making appearances in New York this weekend, and they reflected this week on their careers.

title: Journalists Protest Israeli Move
description: The Foreign Press Association in Israel today protested the Israeli Army's treatment of Beirut-based journalists in southern Lebanon and urged it to lift restrictions on news coverage in the area. On Wednesday, the Israeli Army detained five reporters from the north for four hours and confiscated their material.

title: Last Gasp For Leaded Gas Lead is a cheap and dirty way of improving the quality of gasoline. Cheap to the blender, that is - lead costs the motorist more in car maintenance than he saves at the pump. And the lead spewed from tailpipes into city air causes widespread damage to health. The Environmental Protection Agency has now taken an important step toward the outright ban of leaded gas.
description: The damage caused by the emitted lead is dispersed and insidious - a few points shaved off children's I.Q. scores, a small extra chance of an adult's heart attack. The evidence for such subtle poisoning is hard to gather and easy to criticize.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The aroma of simmering bean gravy slips under the door and sets up a roadblock at the intersection of 57th Street and 10th Avenue. Follow the scent and you will find yourself in a jovial little storefront restaurant with wood-paneled walls holding primitive paintings of island scenes, red-vinyl chairs, a tile floor and some of the most capacious eaters this side of the Bermuda Triangle.

title: Block Depicts Reagan As Sensitive to Farms
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that President Reagan did not mean to suggest that only a handful of farmers were having critical problems with cash flow.

title: CORRECTION
description: A film review on Wednesday of ''Ladies and Gentlemen, the Fabulous Stains'' misidentified a founder of A & M records. The ''A'' stands for Herb Alpert, the company's vice chairman.

title: YANK FARMHAND PLUGS ALONG
description: Dan Briggs has played baseball professionally for 15 years. He has spent only three and a half of those years in the major leagues, with five teams. The rest of the time he has played in 11 minor league cities and Japan.

title: BETANCOURT DECLARES CANDIDACY FOR BRONX BOROUGH PRESIDENT
description: Ismael Betancourt Jr. yesterday announced his candidacy for Bronx borough president, setting up a three-way Democratic primary race and a split among prospective Hispanic challengers of Borough President Stanley Simon.

title: SOVEREIGN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $15,404 for the quarter from the reversal of a tax credit and a nonrecurring gain of $1,506,522, or 15 cents a share, for the quarter and year from an adjustment to deferred taxes. c-Includes tax credits of $24,087 for the quarter and $122,032 for the year.

title: Hurricane Insurance
description: Bernie Kosar , the University of Miami quarterback, has taken out a $2 million insurance policy to protect his potential future earnings, his father said.

title: REAGAN, GREETING A SOVIET LEADER, SAYS THE U.S. DOES NOT SEEK WAR
description: President Reagan agreed with a visiting Soviet Politburo member today that the Soviet people would not start a war against the United States, but added, ''Unfortunately, the people in the Soviet Union don't have much to say about what their Government does.''

title: Business Digest;   FRIDAY, MARCH 8, 1985
description: Companies

title: Jazz at Sweet Basil
description: The New York Jazz Quartet - Roland Hanna on piano, Frank Wess on flute and saxophone, George Mraz on bass and Billy Hart on drums - is appearing tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Untimely Ace for Sutton
description: Hal Sutton beat the odds today but did so about 72 hours too soon when he got a hole-in-one on the par-3 17th hole in the first round of the Hertz Bay Hill Classic. Any player who makes an ace at No. 17 in the final round Sunday will make $1 million - $500,000 for himself and $500,000 for charity.

title: THE MANSION-MUSEUMS OF OLD NEW YORK
description: When we think of private residences that have become museums, the Cooper-Hewitt and the Frick Collection generally come to mind. But there also exist a handful of lesser known museums that have been preserved as period houses and are worth an expedition. These buildings are some of the last vestiges of old New York not yet swallowed up by the city's ferocious urbanization. And half the fun of visiting them is the chance to explore the different neighborhoods of Manhattan.

title: BECKETT TRILOGY AT LA MAMA ANNEX
description: The American premiere of a work by Samuel Beckett has to be counted among the more significant events of any theatrical season. And when that premiere involves three patriarchs of today's experimental theater, expectations are bound to run high. ''Samuel Beckett Trilogy'' - an evening of short pieces that opens at the La Mama Annex on Sunday - will bring together George Bartenieff, Fred Neumann and Julian Beck. That three such figures should gather for almost a month of Beckett constitutes a rare kind of tribute from one generation of experimentalists - the three men are in their 50's - to the 78-year- old author who started it all.

title: Italian Medieval Music
description: The Ensemble Project Ars Nova will perform a program titled ''Music from the Italian Trecento'' Sunday afternoon at 3 as part of the Corpus Christi Church's Music Before 1800 series.

title: Flutie's Footsteps
description: Shawn Halloran, a candidate to succeed Doug Flutie as Boston College's starting quarterback, forsees some pitfalls: ''I hope they don't compare me to Doug as a player, because the pressure would just be unbelievable.

title: Thais Say They Ousted Vietnamese From Hills
description: The Thai Army said today that it had driven Vietnamese troops from a line of hills inside the border, repelling the largest single intrusion into Thai territory in the six years since the Vietnamese invaded neighboring Cambodia.

title: RENDEZVOUS ON THE RHINE: A BRIDGE REMEMBERED
description: Sixty-five-year-old Carmine Sabia, a visitor from Bellmore, L.I., was standing with his wartime buddies behind a banner that read: ''Cross the Rhine With Dry Feet: Courtesy of 9th Armd. Div.''

title: No Objections
description: Holman Harley , a West Virginia basketball starter, may not have attended the prep school summer session courses that helped him gain collegiate eligibility, but West Virginia says he is still eligible and the Atlantic 10 Conference says it is West Virginia's call.

title: MANAGEMENT EMPLOYEES COPING WITH TOUGH NEW JOBS IN PAN AM STRIKE
description: Normally, Jeanette Billett would be sitting at a computer terminal at her office at the Pan American World Airways Building in midtown Manhattan, working on her reports as a financial analyst for the airline.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   49% Rise in Financing By Private Placements
description: The volume of private placement financing rose dramatically last year, to $53.1 billion, according to statistics released yesterday by IDD Information Services, a research organization.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Part of being a physician is, within reason and with a reasonable chance of survival, there's a greater law than the F.D.A., and that's an obligation of a doctor to try to do anything he can to save a life when he thinks that there's a chance.'' - Dr. Cecil Vaughn. (A1:2.)

title: A HOUSING BILL TO AID THE POOR PASSED IN JERSEY
description: The New Jersey Legislature today passed a bill intended to help towns meet their obligations under the State Supreme Court's Mount Laurel decisions, which require them to provide housing opportunities for the poor.

title: BOSTON COLLEGE SHOT ROLLS OUT
description: In a game marked by nine lead changes in the second half, it took a bit of luck to prevent a 10th one and allow Syracuse to come away with a 70-69 victory in the second Big East quarterfinal at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

title: Polish Loan Bid Reported
description: The Polish Government is seeking fresh loans totaling $1.7 billion from its Western creditor governments, according to European government officials.

title: THE GLORIES OF SAN MARCO AT THE MET
description: In back of virtually every abbey, monastery, cathedral and basilica in Western Europe, there is something called ''the treasury.'' Sometimes it contains

title: NEW YORK ON NO DOLLARS A DAY
description: Most New Yorkers are quick to tell you what can be done in the city for a few pennies - a harbor tour on the Staten Island Ferry, a performance by the New York Philharmonic in rehearsal, a visit to NBC's studios - but it is the aficionados who know how to do it all without spending a cent.

title: RECEIVER ASKS COURT TO RELEASE E.S.M.'S ASSETS
description: The court-appointed receiver for E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. delivered a plan to a Federal district judge late today trying to unfreeze some of the firm's assets to relieve the financial distress that its closing has caused for municipalities that were its customers.

title: Dunking for the Fun of It
description: It was only warm-ups, but Althea Ford was already airborne.

title: ART: OLD-MASTER SHOW FROM THE ALBERTINA
description: ''Old Master Drawings From the Albertina'' reminds us what drawing can be. Drawing now tends to refer either to investigation, representation, performance, composition or to a model for work in another medium. During the four centuries covered in this show at the Pierpont Morgan Library, however, a single drawing could be all those things at once. Because it is so much of a piece, an image that D"urer or Rubens summoned from the paper can seem miraculous. Like all great Old Master exhibitions, this one reminds us, above all, what art can be.

title: SCREEN: TERENCE STAMP IN 'THE HIT'
description: ''The Hit'' is a disappointing English underworld movie directed by Stephen Frears, who, in 1971, made the memorable ''Gumshoe'' with Albert Finney. The new movie, which opens today at the Plaza, is less a film noir than a film gris, partly because almost all of it takes place in sun- drenched Spain and because the characters talk too much. These guys don't have to use guns. All they have to do is open their mouths and bore each other to death.

title: AMERICAN HERITAGE LIFE INESTMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital losses of $112,633 for the quarter and $31,366 for the year. c-After a capital loss of $75,699. d-After capital gains of $74,717.

title: MARCH FOR RIGHTS RESOUNDS AFTER 20 YEARS
description: Reminiscent of 20 years ago, when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. led another group of marchers to the steps of the Alabama Capitol, more than 2,500 people gathered here today to renew a plea for justice and civil rights for blacks.

title: Coffee Linked to Cholesterol
description: Sedentary and mildly active middle- aged men who drink more than two cups of coffee a day are more likely to have high blood levels of cholesterol and a certain protein, suggesting they might have an increased risk of heart disease, researchers reported today.

title: Two Forwards Recalled
description: The Islanders recalled the forwards Roger Kortko and Mark Hamway from their top affiliate, Springfield, because of injuries to Clark Gillies (ankle), Duane Sutter (knee), Patrick Flatley (hip) and Bob Bourne (cut hand). . . . The forward Rich Preston (back spasms) and the defenseman Bruce Driver (sprained knee) did not play for the Devils.

title: Measles Takes a Doctor To Religious Campus
description: A doctor today was allowed on the campus of the tiny Christian Science college struck by an outbreak of measles to examine four children suspected of having measles and to observe nearly 30 students in isolation.

title: PAUL BLEY AND HIS PIANO RETURN TO NEW YORK
description: For the first time in the 1980's, the pianist Paul Bley is performing in New York this weekend. Not only does his engagement through Sunday at Lush Life break his silence on the local scene, it's also the first time he's played in a club in 10 years. In recent years, he has done most of his performing in European concert halls.

title: Walking in New York
description: Two walking tours in Brooklyn - to Williamsburg and Park Slope - and one along Manhattan's ''Millionaire's Mile'' on Fifth Avenue are planned Sunday by the 92d Street Y. All three begin at 11 A.M. and require advance registration: 427-6000, extension 179. The history, homes and traditions of the Satmars, an orthodox Jewish sect, are the subjects of the Williamsburg tour.

title: Fewer Make First Appliction For Unemployment Benefits
description: About 403,000 people applied for unemployment benefits for the first time in the week ended Feb. 23, down 8,000 from the previous week, the Labor Department announced today.

title: In That Case, What About the Ketchup?
description: Ordering hamburgers and french fries in Barrymore's, 267 West 45th Street, yesterday, the diners had the temerity to ask whether the potatoes came with the meal.

title: Jail for Southland Officer
description: A former Southland Corporation vice president, who admitted involvement in a company bribery scheme and later testified against other defendants, was sentenced yesterday to three months in jail and two years' probation.

title: I.B.M. Divides Operating Unit
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday split up the operating group that builds its mainframe computers and semiconductors.

title: BILLS WILL SEEK TO STIFFEN HAZARDOUS-CARGO RULES
description: The transporting of hazardous materials on New York State's highways and roads would be subject to sweeping new regulations under legislation to be introduced by two key lawmakers next week.

title: Belligerence on Nicaragua Isolates U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Sperry Unit Trims Its Note Offering
description: The Sperry Lease Finance Corporation offered $192.5 million of six- year lease-backed notes.

title: Israeli Soldier Killed
description: An Israeli soldier was killed today in an exchange of fire with Lebanese Army troops, the military command here said.

title: Ancient Music Concert
description: Christopher Hogwood and his Academy of Ancient Music will begin their first American tour with a performance at Avery Fisher Hall, Broadway and 65th Street, Sunday at 8.

title: STOCKMAN DEFENDS IGNORING DEFICIT REDUCTION ACT
description: David A. Stockman, the budget director, today defended a Reagan Administration order that Federal agencies ignore some sections of the Deficit Reduction Act of 1984.

title: Money Fund Assets Decline
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell $1.36 billion, to $211.67 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: YEAR OF ELAYS PLAGUE RENOVATION OF A BROOKLYN IRT STATION
description: For months, the long, narrow mezzanine of the Clark Street subway station in Brooklyn has been cut in half by a makeshift wooden barrier. The station's platform has been strung with temporary lights. And passengers have had to walk over a ditch alternately covered with sand, blacktop and boards.

title: WHAT 4-YEAR-OLDS CAN TEACH THE SCHOOL SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: 'STAR WARS' AND MANKIND: UNFORESEEABLE DIRECTIONS
description: President Reagan's proposal for a vast system of space defense against ballistic missiles appears to be gaining strong momentum, even as members of Congress and experts outside the Government ask whether it is hurling the nation onto a new strategic course before the future implications can be fully considered.

title: APPLE SETS OUTPUT HALT FOR WEEK
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it would close its four factories for a week because of an oversupply of computers brought about by sluggish sales. It is the first time that fast- growing Apple has ever had to shut down production.

title: Arizona State's Choice
description: While

title: Miamian Dead After Mixup
description: A retired news photographer who was accidentally injected with a toxic preservative while in surgery last week was pronounced dead Wednesday after life-support systems were disconnected at his family's request, a hospital official said. The patient, Bob East, 64 years old, had been considered brain dead after being injected with glutaraldehyde, instead of spinal fluid, while undergoing surgery for facial cancer.

title: Intergroup Cites Merger Approval
description: National Intergroup Inc. said today at a special meeting that its stockholders had apparently approved by a ''clear-cut majority'' the company's proposed merger with the Bergen Brunswig Corporation.

title: 'STAR WARS' PLAN FOR EUROPE IS URGED
description: A French general has called for France to lead Western Europe in the development of its own space-based missile defense program.

title: U.S. AGENT'S BODY FIRMLY IDENTIFIED
description: The United States Ambassador said today that ''beating and asphyxiation'' caused the deaths of a United States drug agent and a Mexican pilot whose bodies were discovered Wednesday.

title: ROBERT B. SOUR
description: Robert B. Sour, the former president of Broadcast Music Inc., died Wednesday in New York City after a brief illness. He was 79 years old. Mr. Sour, a native New Yorker, became a full-time songwriter in 1929 and was one of three lyricists for the song ''Body and Soul.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Grounded, for a Night
description: As an initiation for the white-knuckled, the counseling program known as Fly Without Fear had planned to take 70 people tonight on a flight to Jamaica.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE VOTES TO CONTINUE MASS TRANSIT AID
description: The Senate Budget Committee voted today to continue Federal subsidies for Amtrak and mass transit, rejecting President Reagan's proposals to end them.

title: Orangemail: Why It Got Paid The case of Agent Orange, the herbicide sprayed over Vietnam to protect American troops from ambush, has come full circle. The manufacturers have put up $180 million to settle the claims of veterans alleging injury. But the Federal court that is distributing the money plans to pay veterans whether or not Agent Orange caused their illness.
description: Why not compensate only those injured by Agent Orange? Because no veteran is known to have such injuries. ''It is totally uncertain whether any serious adverse health effects could have been caused by the level of Agent Orange exposure veterans might have received in Vietnam'': so concluded the court's special master, Kenneth Feinberg, in the proposed settlement plan submitted to Federal Judge Jack Weinstein last week.

title: Rebels Kidnap Mayor
description: Leftist guerrillas stormed the northeastern town of Osicala, kidnapped the mayor and his secretary and burned the telephone office, a spokesman for the mayor's party said.

title: PUBLISHING: A BLOW AGAINST PIRACY
description: Piracy continues to plague American and British book publishers, and it was a major topic of conversation at the midwinter meeting of the Association of American Publishers. One speaker estimated that publishers lost $1 million a year to the foreign ''pirates,'' who publish books without paying for them.

title: ST. JOHN'S, GEORGETOWN, SYRACUSE AND VILLANOVA GAIN
description: Walter Berry said that for the last five days he had been nagged by memories of St. John's season finale against Providence at Alumni Hall. The Redmen's winning margin of 72- 53 was far more handsome than their performance that day and Berry had played his worst game of the season.

title: Drums at Vanguard
description: The drummer Elvin Jones will lead his quartet tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard , 178 Seventh Avenue South below 11th Street (255- 4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. There is an $8.50 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: WRIGHT-HARGREAVES MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a special gain of $3,471,000. c-Includes special gains of $795,000 for the quarter and $6,681,000 for the year.

title: Business in the Courtroom
description: Among many cases heard yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, perhaps the most unusual was one in which four witnesses from Young & Rubicam threw themselves on the mercy of New York Telephone.

title: Shocks Still Shake Chile
description: Aftershocks of Chile's worst earthquake in 25 years sent shudders through the devastated countryside at four-minute intervals today as thousands of people camped in the streets. Rescue teams ended the search for people trapped in collapsed houses and the death toll from Sunday's quake stood at 151.

title: Generals' Sales Up
description: The Generals have sold ''over 40,000'' season tickets, according to

title: ZYCAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $30,000. c-Includes tax credits of $772,000 for the quarter and $384,000 for the year.

title: WAL-MART STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a reduction of $853,000 from the costing of inventories under the LIFO method. c-After a reduction of $10,172,000 from the costing of inventories.

title: NICARAGUA BARS OPPOSITION CHIEF'S RETURN, CITING REBEL TIES
description: Nicaragua today refused to permit Arturo Cruz, the principal civilian oppositon leader, to enter the country on the grounds that he had aligned himself with rebel forces.

title: Lindqvist Tops Turnbull PRINCETON, N.J., March 7 (AP) - Wendy Turnbull, the second-
description: seeded player, was upset by sixth-seeded Caterina Lindqvist of Sweden,

title: TEMPER, TEMPER
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Democrat of Massachusetts, and Robert H. Michel, Republican of Illinois, have been colleagues and golfing buddies for 30 years. So it was a remarkable scene on the House floor Monday when the two faced off against each other, spurting hot anger and harsh words.

title: Music for Keyboards
description: The composer Terry Riley will perform new music for keyboards and voice tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Samaya Foundation, 75 Leonard Street between Broadway and Church Streets (925-9763) . Tickets are $10.

title: Chef From Paris
description: Guide Michelin is apparently better at detecting curdled bearnaise than tracking famous chefs.

title: 2 Doctors Are Accused In Fake-Abortions Case
description: Two doctors who operate a Brooklyn abortion clinic were charged yesterday with falsely telling women they were pregnant and then pretending to perform abortions on them.

title: AFRICA'S DROUGHT SEARS THE LAND OF TIMBUKTU
description: A deep cavity interrupts the wind- scoured landscape of sand dunes and scattered brush outside this ancient town.
