title: SCREEN: 'VARIETY,' BY BETTE GORDON
description: A feninist film about a woman working as a ticket- taker in a porno movie theater might automatically be expected to hold some interest. But Bette Gordon's ''Variety,'' which opens today at the Waverly, has a painfully underwritten screenplay (by Kathy Acker) and a static, uncommunicative directorial style. Its opening expository scenes, in which Christine (Sandy McLeod) first goes to work at the Variety Theater, possess a great deal more tension than what subsequently unfolds. The idea that Christine might develop a growing fascination with voyeurism and pornography, while provocative, is something that Miss Gordon is almost entirely unable to articulate in visual terms.

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized gains of $4,510,000. c-After realized losses of $19,794,000 for the quarter and $15,196,000 for the year. d-After realized losses of $15,798,000. The company said results for latest year are not entirely comparable to those of 1983 since only the fourth quarter of 1983 included the operations of Southeastern Aviation Underwriters Inc., which was acquired in October 1983.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of investments of $194,695 for the quarter and $540,241 for the year, a tax credit of $6,783,301 for the year related to the Tax Reform Act of 1984, and a gain of $537,209 for the year from an accounting change. c-Includes gains on the sale of investments of $2,462,207 for the quarter and $6,237,758 for the year.

title: Do We Really Want ;   Europe More Like Us?
description: To the Editor:

title: NICARAGUAN REBELS SEEKING INQUIRY INTO ABUSE CHARGES
description: The Nicaraguan Democratic Force, the largest of the United States-backed rebel groups seeking the overthrow of the Managua Government, called today for additional investigations into allegations that its members had committed abuses against unarmed civilians in Nicaragua.

title: IDC SERVICES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $777,000. c-After a tax credit of $642,000. There are no share earnings in the previous year since the company went public in January 1984.

title: Boxing Mystery
description: Showing up at a

title: Another O'Neill, this time a musical, is on its way here.
description: Thiw seems to be the year for Eugene O'Neill in New York. ''Strange Interlude'' is on Broadway, a production of ''Long Day's Journey Into Night'' is being discussed, and as of April 11 ''Take Me Along,'' based on his comedy ''Ah, Wilderness!'', will be back.

title: 290,000 Cadillacs Recalled Because of Pollution Problem
description: The General Motors Corporation will recall 290,000 Cadillacs to fix potentially defective pollution control equipment, the third recall by the company in five months for the same problem, the Environmental Protection Agency says.

title: FED, REAGAN AND THE DOLLAR
description: THE soaring dollar was jolted again this week

title: Contractor Bills Studied
description: The division of Rockwell International Corporation that builds the B-1 strategic bomber billed the Government for more than $23,000 in club memberships in 1982, according to Pentagon records made public today.

title: UNITED STATES HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Arms Harmonica
description: Edward L. Rowny, who headed the talsk on arms reduction in Geneva from 1979 until this year, had his own way of relieving tension when negotiations threatened to bog down. He would pull out his harmonica and play a few Russian songs.

title: U.S. TELLS THE U.N. OF THREATS ON THE AMERICANS IN LEBANON
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick told the Security Council today that the United States had received information about three threats against Americans in Lebanon if the United States vetoed a Lebanese draft resolution now before the Council.

title: TAKEOVER TALK SPURS A.N.R. STOCK
description: Wall Street traders, sensing the start of a major takeover battle between two big oil and gas companies, bid up the stock price of the American Natural Resources Company yesterday to $62.625, well over the $60- a-share, or $2.3 billion, hostile bid for the company made by the Coastal Corporation last Friday.

title: COLLEGES ARE TAKING NEW STEPS TO REDUCE DRINKING ON CAMPUS
description: The pub at Princeton University is now a cafe. Its grand opening last week featured a jazz ensemble, small round tables with candles, 14 kinds of coffee and 8 kinds of tea, pastry, fruit juice and not one drop of alcohol.

title: Ex-U.S. Attorney Guilty Of Disclosing Indictment
description: A Federal court jury took 20 minutes today to convict a former United States Attorney on charges of improperly telling a friend about a grand jury indictment.

title: QUOTA END SPURS SHIFT AT CHRYSLER
description: The Chrysler Corporation, responding to the Reagan Administration's decision not to ask Japan to extend automobile export quotas, said yesterday that it was no longer interested in acquiring or building another assembly plant in the United States.

title: ALAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes writeoff of $1.5 million primarily in advances to company-operated drilling programs. c-Net income

title: Kansas Stunned in Big Eight
description: Barry Stevens, Iowa State's career scoring leader, poured in 25 points tonight as the Cyclones stunned Kansas, 75-59, in the semifinals of the Big Eight Conference tournament.

title: CHOCK FULL O' NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $52,000 for the quarter and $54,000 for the 6 months c-After income from discontinued operations of $15,000. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $176,000.

title: PATIENCE GOES INTO EXTRA INNINGS
description: That special time of year is coming again when I plant my hands on my 9-year- old's shoulders, look him straight in the eye and make him solemnly promise that he will care for me in my old age in return for what I will soon endure for him. For I am about to be frozen, eaten alive by insects, bored to tears and hit on the head by a foul ball if I dare to read a newspaper - all for the great American tradition of Little League baseball.

title: Justice Resigns in Minnesota Because of Cheating Charge
description: Justice John J. Todd of the Minnesota Supreme Court, accused of cheating on a bar examination, submitted his resignation to Gov. Rudy Perpich today. But he said, ''My conscience is clear.''

title: MANDILIKOVA ROUTS NAVRATILOVA, 7-6, 6-0
description: The moment could not come quickly enough for Hana Mandlikova or Martina Navratilova, but for different reasons.

title: General Strike Brings Bolivia to a Standstill
description: Bolivia was paralyzed by a general strike today that was called to protest tough economic policies imposed to fight the country's high inflation rate. If the strike continues, the Government warned, the military may seize power in Bolivia again.

title: Export Push By Singapore
description: Singapore's Government will give private businessmen more freedom to increase exports and fuel the nation's economic growth during the next few years, the Education, Health and Finance Minister, Tony Tan, told Parliament today.

title: WRITER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFS
TRAIL BLAZERS TOP INCONSISTENT NETS
description: A week ago, the Nets were in the midst of an encouraging road trip. Today, they are searching for some kind of consistency.

title: Foreman of Reagans' Ranch Found Dead of Heart Attack
description: Lee Clearwater, President Reagan's ranch foreman, was found dead of a heart attack today in his house on the ranch in the Santa Ynez mountains near Santa Barbara, Larry Speakes, a White House spokesman, said.

title: U.S. SAYS ITS TEAM IN TALKS ON ARMS HAS WIDE LATITUDE
description: President Reagan has authorized American negotiators to explore an accord with the Soviet Union in which the Russians could have an advantage in strategic missiles in return for allowing the United States to keep its advantage in long-range bombers, his national security adviser said today.

title: Ethiopian Army Aids Famine Relief Effort
description: Soviet trucks driven by Ethiopian soldiers carried American grain into this country's main storage and transshipment center here today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jim Kyte , a defenseman for the Winnipeg Jets, has been suspended for five games for an incident last week in which he punched

title: RELIANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   She Must Have Been A Beautiful Baby
description: The young mother, with her fetching, blonde baby girl in a stroller, boarded the No. 1 downtown train at West 86th Street.

title: MARYLAND BANKS ASSAIL ACCORD WITH CITICORP
description: An agreement between Gov. Harry Hughes of Maryland and Citicorp that would permit the nation's largest banking institution to participate in all aspects of the state's banking business drew vigorous opposition today from Maryland bankers.

title: A 100TH BIRTHDAY PARTY FOR A FELLA NAME OF RING
description: Well if that fella Ring Lardner was still around he would of ast what all the fuss were about. And just think what he would of said when he learnt that the answer was Ring Lardner.

title: ITALY ARRESTS U.S. TAX LAWYER IN FRAUD CASE
description: Italian officials said today that they had arrested an American lawyer for fraud and tax evasion in a case that United States and Italian officials said could have wide repercussions.

title:
PATENTS;

Making Better Nuclear Fuels
description: A method of producing improved nuclear fuels was patented this week for the Department of Energy.

title: Fed Easing on Farm Loans
description: The Federal Reserve Board announced today that it was easing requirements for farm banks to borrow money from the central bank.

title: Books of The Times;   A Concise Matisse
description: MATISSE. By Nicholas Watkins. 240

title: DANCE: REDLICH GROUP HONORS HANYA HOLM
description: The opening night performance of the Don Redlich Dance Company on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue) had the air of an occasion. The evening was devoted to the choreography of Hanya Holm, the American modern dance pioneer and influential teacher, and the theater was filled with members of the dance world, among them Alwin Nikolais - Miss Holm's former pupil - and Paul Taylor. At the end of the evening a spotlight picked out the 92-year-old choreographer in the audience, bringing her to her feet for a crisp bow.

title: 4 Women in Tie
description: Jane Blalock shot a five- under-par 67 today to jump into a tie for first place with Bonnie Lauer, Alice Miller and Patty Sheehan at 141 midway through the $330,000 Uniden Invitational.

title: DOER AND SLUMLORD BOTH
description: Donald Trump, the developer, is in the newspapers almost every day for one thing or another. If he isn't building a skyscraper castle or a football team, he is trying to harass some tenants out of one of his properties.

title: Eagles Deal Due
description: Leonard Tose's ownership of the Philadelphia Eagles neared its end yesterday as lawyers were kept busy in Miami completing details of the agreement to transfer the club to Norman Braman, a south Florida businessman who is a native of West Chester, Pa. According to several sources familiar with the transaction, the work is due to be completed today with the signing of contracts.

title: A SCRAPPY HOYA HELPS FILL A VOID
description: By today's standards, the time for high school basketball stars to make their choice of a college had long since passed. In the brave new world in which large adolescents can be traced, examined, catalogued, compared, contrasted, pursued, wooed, bought and sold before their senior season has even begun, Perry McDonald of George Washington Carver High School in New Orleans was falling way behind his peers.

title: Injustices Fuel the Flames of Northern Ireland
description: To the Editor:

title: VENDO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $480,000 for a reserve to cover the restructuring of a Belgium unit.

title: JOBLESS RATE DCLINES SLIGHTLY TO 7.2%
description: Despite a large decline in manufacturing jobs and a decrease in the average factory workweek, the nation's unemployment rate fell by an insignificant amount in February and employment rose over all, the Labor Department reported today.

title: ELECTION RESULTS SHOW WEAK SPOTS IN GANDHI PARTY'S ARMOR
description: For a few months, a glow of near-invincibility seemed to surround Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. His promises to revamp industry, eliminate corruption and forge a new national unity stirred hope even among the cynical in India. But this week, the results of the latest parliamentary election brought India back to some familiar realities. Instead of the 80 percent electoral sweep he scored in December, Mr. Gandhi and the Congress (I) Party won 57 percent of the seats at stake in state legislative elections that were held in 11 of India's 21 states and one union territory.

title: MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a foreign exchange translation and transaction accounting loss of $90,000, after taxes. c-Includes a gain of $1,063,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change, a gain of $7,174,000 from the reversal of a DISC tax provision on a net basis, and a foreign exchange translation and transaction accounting loss of $32,000, after taxes.

title: Private Services Conducted For Kelly, U.S. Olympic Chief
description: John B. Kelly Jr. was buried in a suburban Philadelphia cemetery this morning at a small private ceremony attended by members of his immediate family and of the royal family of Monaco.

title: Mixed Notices for New Yank
description: In his first time at bat as a Yankee, Dale Berra came within feet of hitting a grand slam, the ball being caught at the fence. The Yankees, though, were more interested in the performance of a player who came to them from Pittsburgh with Berra.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES FALL
description: Bond prices surged yesterday, turning in their most impressive performance in more than a month. Trading activity was brisk.

title: MANGOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. Results for 1984 include the operations of HCR International which was acquired on Dec. 28, 1983.

title: AZINGER IN LEAD AT BAY HILL CLASSIC
description: Good putting lessens the need to be extremely close with approach shots and permits a golfer to relax: He knows he has a good chance to sink the ball if he gets to the green. The result of relaxation is that approach shots become more accurate.

title: CUOMO ASSERTS RESPECT FOR LAW IS ON THE DECLINE
description: ''There is less respect for the law in this country than ever before,'' Governor Cuomo said today.

title: City Increases
description: Bond Offering The City of New York said

title: VILLAGE'S 'HEARTBEAT,' A CHEMICAL PLANT, RAISES FEARS
description: Since shortly after the turn of the century, this tiny village in the heart of the fruit belt has depended on a sprawling chemical factory that manufactures pesticides.

title: Poles Mark Campus Protest
description: Police officers sealed off Warsaw University today while students laid flowers at a plaque marking the start of a wave of student demonstrations in 1968. About 150 students were allowed to take part in the ceremony. The 1968 protests began after militants broke up a meeting called to protest an official campaign against intellectuals.

title: ROBERT WOODRUFF IS DEAD: CREATED COCA-COLA EMPIRE
description: Robert W. Woodruff, a college dropout who became the driving force behind the growth of the Coca-Cola Company and built it into an international financial empire, died Thursday at Emory University Hospital. He was 95 years old and had been hospitalized for 10 days.

title: G.M.-Japan Talks
description: The General Motors Corporation wants Japan to allow G.M.'s affiliates, Isuzu Motors Ltd. and the Suzuki Motor Company, to export about 234,000 vehicles to the United States in the year ending March 1986, a G.M. official said. Henry Leonard, vice president of the G.M. Overseas Distribution Corporation, said that G.M. wants to import about 150,000 subcompacts from Isuzu and 84,000 from Suzuki for sale by its Chevrolet division. Under the existing quotas, which the Reagan Administration has said it will not push to extend, Isuzu can export 49,500 cars and Suzuki 17,000.

title: Transactions
description: Signed Tom Herr, the second baseman, to a 4-year contract. Terms were not announced, but the pact is reportedly worth about $3.1 million. HOCKEY ISLANDERS (NHL) - Returned Mark Hamway, right wing, to their Springfield farm team.

title: The Man With the Illegal Heart
description: The artificial heart has at last proved it has a useful role - as a stopgap until a compatible human heart is found. Surgeons at the University of Arizona have implanted an unapproved pump devised by a Phoenix dentist into a patient whose transplanted heart had been rejected. Though the patient has now died, the pump apparently worked well enough for a second human heart to be found and implanted 11 hours later.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is less respect for the law in this country than ever before.'' - Governor Cuomo. (26:6.)

title: FILM INSTITUTE HONORS GENE KELLY
description: When Gene Kelly was given the American Film Institute's 13th Life Achievement Award Thursday night, he blushed and said: ''I never wanted to be a dancer. My whole ambition was to play shortstop for the Pittsburgh Pirates.''

title: EQUITY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: WOMAN PARALYZED BY A MISTAKE IN INJECTING ANTICANCER DRUG
description: The wrong drug was injected into the spinal column of a pregnant 21-year-old woman at a hospital here, leaving her paralyzed and breathing only with the aid of a respirator, the hospital disclosed today.

title: E.P.A. PULLS BACK ON ASBESTOS RULES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency pulled back today from a decision announced last month to turn over the regulation of asbestos to two other Federal agencies.

title: FLIGHT IS DELAYED
description: A falling metal bucket smashed into the top of the space shuttle Discovery today, leaving gashes that forced a delay of its next flight, space agency officials said.

title: FETAL HEALTH: NEW EARLY DIAGNOSIS STUDIED
description: When Debbie and Maury Fisher of Highland Park, Ill., learned that their second child, a son, Todd, now 4 years old, had Tay-Sachs disease, they decided not to have more children. But when Mrs. Fisher found herself pregnant again in July 1983, she underwent a test that informed her in the 11th week of her pregnancy that she would have a normal child.

title: Chinese Forces Attack Vietnam
description: Chinese troops launched a fresh attack on Vietnam's positions along their common border today, but the action appeared to fall short of the wider offensive that Peking has threatened over Vietnam's actions in Cambodia.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Philadelphia 76ers , at Madison Square Garden, 1:05 P.M. (Television - MSG Network, 1 P.M. Radio - WPAT, 930; WFAS, 1230; and WGBB, 1240; 12:50 P.M.).

title: She Grapples With a Difference
description: Don Flavin has been the wrestling coach at Northern Illinois University for 16 years, but not until last week did he achieve a long-cherished goal: the Huskies' first Mid-America Conference championship.

title: THE SCREEN: 'NIGHT PATROL'
description: Night Patrol,'' which opened yesterday at the RKO Warner Twin and other theaters, is not exactly ''Airplane!'' but it's better than ''Airplane 2.'' It also possesses a kind of consistent vulgarity that isn't easy to achieve, even with the help of a handy anthology of bad-taste jokes, without which ''Night Patrol'' wouldn't have been possible.

title: MARSHALL READY TO JOIN ELITE
description: When John Marshall ran for Plainfield (N.J.) High School, there was little doubt he would become one of the world's fastest runners. Now, as a 21-year-old Villanova senior, he has achieved that, and he has grown as a person as well.

title: VIATECH INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $78,000 from the company's equity interest in Dixie Union and a tax credit of $131,000. c-Net income.

title: Soviet Skaters 1,2 in Ice Dancing
description: The Soviet Union swept the top two spots in ice dancing today at the World Figure Skating Championships.

title: Big Pact for Stieb
description: The way the Toronto Blue Jays see it, at the age of 27 their star pitcher,

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: AN INTENSELY PRIVATE FAMILY EMPIRE
description: On the day in mid-November when Samuel I. Newhouse Jr. announced that his family's vast communications company would acquire a 17 percent stake in The New Yorker, Mr. Newhouse declared that there were no plans to add the magazine to the multibillion-dollar family empire.

title: TELECOM CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $736,000 and a tax credit of $745,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $1,530,000.

title: MERCANTILE STORES CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CORRECTION
description: An article on Feb. 25 about ''Night of 100 Stars II'' at Radio City Music Hall listed one participant erroneously. Doug Flutie, the quarterback of the New Jersey Generals, did not appear.

title: AL TODD
description: Al Todd, who set a major-league record for catchers in 1937 by playing 128 games in a row without a passed ball, died today.

title: RADIO EXCHANGES SUPPORT THEORY ON CAUSE OF JETLINER PLUNGE
description: ''We're very emergency, emergency!'' radioed the China Airlines crewman. He said the Boeing 747 airliner, which had been cruising normally at 41,000 feet, had just plunged to 10,000 feet.

title: Democratic Party Post
description: After almost six weeks as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Paul G. Kirk Jr. has made his first staff appointment, that of Brian Lunde as executive director. Mr. Lunde, 30 years old, worked in Jimmy Carter's 1976 Presidential campaign and then as executive director of the Kentucky State Democratic Party. Since 1981, he has been the national committee's director of state party services.

title: Udall Doffs 2 Hats
description: Because of his interest in arms control, Representative Morris K. Udall, Democrat of Arizona, gave up his seat this year on the House Committee on Post Office and Civil Service to become a junior member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

title: 'Leader' Opening Delayed
description: The opening performance of ''Leader of the Pack,'' the musical by Anne Beatts based on the life and songs of the pop composer Ellie Greenwich, has been postponed.

title: Uruguay's Parliament Approves Amnesty
description: Uruguay's parliament approved a bill today that would release 267 political prisoners and criminals confined by the former military Government on charges ranging from distributing pamphlets to assassination.

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The share earnings for all periods reflect a 25 percent stock dividend paid on Nov. 21, 1984.

title: GIOVANNI GRANZOTTO
description: Giovanni Granzotto, president of the Italian news agency ANSA, died of liver failure here today, his office reported.

title: Feed-Grain Payments ;   And Surplus Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: LOUISIANA'S GOVERNOR ENTERS PLEA OF NOT GUILTY TO CHARGES OF FRAUD
description: Gov. Edwin Edwards pleaded not guilty today to Federal charges of racketeering, mail fraud and wire fraud.

title: SHOULD FEDERAL SUBSIDY FOR AMTRAK BE ENDED?
description: As part of his sweeping deficit-cutting agenda, President Reagan has asked Congress to end Federal subsidies to the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, which operates Amtrak.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the Scouting column in Sports Pages yesterday misstated the travel direction for Santa Anita from Galway Downs. It is north.

title: 'Shurocracy' in Pakistan
description: President Zia of Pakistan is in many respects a typical third-world dictator. He seized power in 1977 and shows little inclination to relinquish it. But he also wants respect, especially from Americans, and therefore attempts to clothe his regime in democratic garb. Like other strongmen, he has invented a word for his political regimen: ''shurocracy,'' derived from the Arabic ''shura,'' meaning advice or consensus. He proposes to reach it cautiously in three stages.

title: EAST GERMANS ASSAIL EMIGRES
description: The East German authorities began an unusual propaganda campaign this week that appears to be aimed at discouraging a new wave of applications from people seeking to live in West Germany.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Master of the House
description: From his family's townhouse on

title: QUIETLY, SHARON GOES BACK TO POLITICS
description: After emerging with something of a moral victory from his libel suit against Time magazine, Ariel Sharon has slipped quietly back into Israeli politics - so quietly that some Israelis may not even know he is back.

title: Finding Employment ;   For the 'Unemployable'
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;

Using Bacteria to Make Drugs and Chemicals
description: A process patented this week by Prof. Gary V. Paddock of the Medical University of South Carolina is regarded as improving the technique of producing pharmaceuticals and chemicals by using bacteria.

title: TECHAMERICA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $398,987 from a litigation settlement. c-Net income after the loss of $398,987 from a litigation settlement.

title: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $76,000 and a DISC tax credit of $1,500,000.

title: AUDIT SAYS CITY PROFITS FROM OTB MAY DRY UP
description: The financial outlook for the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation is so ''bleak'' that the agency may soon stop earning money for the city, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday.

title: EDITOR SAYS STAFF DID NOT GIVE 'OUR APPROVAL'
description: Pausing frequently to contain his emotions, William Shawn, the editor of The New Yorker for 32 years, told his fellow staff members yesterday that ''we were not asked for our approval, and we did not give our approval'' to the decision to sell the magazine to S. I. Newhouse.

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Why a Voice for Labor Should Be Heard on the M.T.A. Board
description: To the Editor:

title: SCRIPT WRITERS REACH A TENTATIVE ACCORD
description: Striking movie and television scriptwriters reached a tentative agreement with producers today after a four-day walkout. After the agreement was announced, some television programs moved to resume work on episodes that had been canceled.

title: CHARVOZ-CARSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $35,000 for the quarter and $496,000 for the 6 months.

title: SCREEN: 'LOVELINESS' OPENS
description: There are a couple of contemporary touches to ''Lovelines,'' which opened yesterday at the UA Twin and other theaters: the high-school principal is a woman, and some of the kids dream of starring in a rock video on MTV. Otherwise, it's entirely Neanderthal.

title: Ghana Frees 202 Prisoners
description: Ghana's leader, Lieut. Jerry J. Rawlings, today ordered the release of 202 political prisoners, including two former Government ministers, to mark independence day. The official Ghana News Agency named the former ministers as John S. Nabila, Minister of Presidential Affairs, and Samuel K. Riley-Poku, Minister of Defense.

title: BELGIAN TOWN SEES REASONS TO WELCOME MISSILES
description: A weatherbeaten house of whitewashed brick just down the road from the large Belgian Air Base here contains a new cafe, called the Florennade. It was opened by a group of young antinuclear activists from elsewhere in this country who hope it will become a center of local opposition to the expected installation nearby of 48 American cruise missiles.

title: End Night-Ride Fee
description: To the Editor:

title: Dunlop and BTR Reach an Accord
description: Dunlop Holdings P.L.C. and BTR P.L.C. said that they had reached agreement on an increased offer by BTR for Dunlop. Dunlop's board said in London that it considered the increased offer, which values the British-based tire maker at about $108 million, to be ''fair and reasonable'' and would recommend that it be accepted by all shareholders.

title: Pirelli Plant Closing
description: Industrie Pirelli S.p.A. is to close a tire manufacturing plant on the outskirts of Milan with the loss of more than 2,000 jobs, a senior company official said today. Pirelli announced its decision to shut the plant, in the suburb of Bicocca, early this year, but delayed the closing because of strong resistance from trade unions. The company said it would transfer production from the factory, which has made mostly truck tires, to another plant near Turin.

title: SPAIN'S FASHION RENAISSANCE
description: After years of wallowing in the doldrums, Spanish designers of women's fashions are showing a new creativity and enthusiasm.

title: 5 ARE ACCUSED OF LAUNDERING DRUG MONEY AT ATLNATIC CITY CASINOS
description: Federal authorities last night announced the arrests of five people whom they described as international heroin traffickers responsible for the ''laundering of millions of dollars in narcotics proceeds through casinos in Atlantic City.''

title: Bridge:Early Congratulations ProvePremature at National Pairs
description: Appearances were deceptive in the Grand National Pair Championship here Thursday night.

title: Your Money ;   Figuring Rates Of Ginnie Maes
description: Interest rates advertised by dealers in mortgage-backed securities issued by the Government National Mortgage Association often show a wide disparity. For instance, a potential buyer of these so-called Ginnie Maes may have seen ads encouraging purchases this week at yields ranging from as little as 11 1/2 percent to as much as 14 3/4 percent.

title: ARIZONA TOWN IS A CASUALTY IN THE BORDER WAR ON DRUGS
description: Carlos Silva had almost no customers today at the Gila Auto Supply. Ray Ewing, a retired copper miner, could not cross the border to get his usual $2 haircut in neighboring Naco in the Mexican state of Sonora, and the Rev. John Ellitson had to cancel his Thursday night prayer meeting at the Mexican Baptist Church over the border.

title: Sweden Sets Price Freeze
description: The Social Democratic Government of Prime Minister Olof Palme today announced a general price freeze in Sweden to keep inflation within the 1985 target of 3 percent.

title: 156 Teachers Dismissed In Mississippi Strike
description: School officials in one Mississippi county dismissed 156 teachers today for refusing to return to work in the first showdown between teachers and officials in a 12-day strike.

title: Israelis Deny Abuses
description: The Israeli Army denied today a report by a southern Lebanese doctor that the army had taken an unconscious man from a hospital operating room and had raided a vocational school.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: HOLLYWOOD ROAST There are few things show people enjoy spoofing as much as they do the movies. Today, a new group of spoofers of Hollywood moves into the Ballroom, a restaurant and nightclub at 243 West 28th Street (244-3005).

title: Clippers Sue League
description: The Los Angeles Clippers, facing a $25 million damage suit by the National Basketball Association in connection with the Clippers' unauthorized move from San Diego this season, have filed a countersuit against the N.B.A. The Clipper suit, charging ''various fraudulent acts,'' seeks $100 million in damages.

title: Semiconductor
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that it would lay off about 400 workers at its Salt Lake City semiconductor facilities during a retooling of the plant that will take several months.

title: IN RICHARD ROFFMAN'S WORLD, EVERYONE'S A STAR
description: Not all stars in New York are big stars. But Richard Roffman - the agent extraordinaire of West End Avenue - manages to make his clientele of lesser luminaries feel like giants of the entertainment industry.

title: FARRELL ASSERTS HE WON'T SEEK JACKSON'S HELP
description: Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. said yesterday that he would not seek the endorsement of the Rev. Jesse Jackson or ask him to campaign in Mr. Farrell's bid for the Democratic mayoral nomination.

title: BALLET: CAST CHANGES IN JOFFREY'S 'ROMEO'
description: A new cast of principals stepped into the Joffrey Ballet's three-act ''Romeo and Juliet'' Thursday night at the New York State Theater. The results were slightly different but as positive as opening night's - primarily because John Cranko's treatment of the Prokofiev score always creates a vibrant ensemble, a public drama in which private tragedy is only a part.

title: Don't Tread on Me
description: A few news articles about the cockroach problem in Congressional office buildings and the next thing you know Washington gets the honor of hosting a industrial- strength cockroach symposium.

title: Union Chiefs to Meet On Strike at Pan Am
description: The presidents of Transport Workers Union locals on strike against Pan American World Airways agreed yesterday to meet together Sunday to seek a way to restart negotiations with the company, according to union leaders.

title: Stocks Fall Slightly As Rate Fears Remain
description: Stock prices fell slightly yesterday, hampered once again by interest rate fears.

title: CONNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest 9 months includes an after-tax writedown of $1,750,000 in the carrying value of its investment in advances made to the Quadstar Corp., a 30 percent owned affiliate.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT IS STABLE IN REGION BUT RISES 1.4% IN NEW YORK CITY
description: The number of jobless men and women remained relatively stable in New York State and New Jersey last month, but their ranks grew by 1.4 percent in New York City, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. The regional commissioner of the bureau, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, said the rise in the city unemployment rate, to 9.6 percent, partly reflected the fact that many retail firms waited until last month to release sales workers hired for the Christmas season.

title: Bank Violation Alleged On Political Donations
description: A United States Attorney today said that the Mutual Bank of Boston had violated the Federal Election Campaign Act by putting pressure on its officers to contribute to the bank's political action committee.

title: GOODEN, DARLING THROW HARD
description: One year after they were rookies trying to win jobs, Dwight Gooden and Ron Darling made their debuts as the Mets' two ranking pitchers today. And they stirred an overflow crowd with two snappy innings of shutout baseball apiece in the team's first camp game of spring training.

title: OEA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Luzinski Draws Crowd
description: The turnout yesterday for the freshmen baseball team at Holy Cross High School in Delran, N.J., was ''at least double that of a normal year,'' according to

title:
PATENTS;

Producing an Aldehyde From Primary Alcohol
description: The Cetus Corporation, a genetic engineering company in Emeryville, Calif., received a patent this week for a method of making an aldehyde - a colorless fluid oxidized from alcohol - from a primary alcohol.

title:
PATENTS;

Improving Color TV Reception
description: WASHINGTON

title: A 2D BANK IN BOSTON SAYS IT DIDN'T REPORT BIG CASH TRANSFERS
description: The Shawmut Bank of Boston, the third-largest bank in Massachusetts, disclosed today that it had failed to report some international cash transactions and had improperly exempted some of its customers from Federal currency-reporting regulations.

title:
PATENT;

Clock Shows the Time In All Countries, Zones
description: A clock for indicating the time in all of the world's countries and time zones was patented this week by an Australian.

title: SL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $65,000 for the quarter and $72,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $44,000 for the quarter and $66,000 for the 6 months. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June 1984 and a 6 percent stock dividend in November 1984.

title: Clemson Fills Top Post
description: Clemson University has appointed

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about the strike against Pan American World Airways understated the size of the Independent Union of Flight Attendants.

title: Penn Clinches Ivy League Title
description: Terry Bromwell scored 25 points and Karl Racine added 21 to lead Pennsylvania to a 74-71 victory over Cornell University tonight, clinching the Ivy League title for the Quakers.

title: A COURTHOUSE IN BALTIMORE RENAMED FOR BLACK LEADER
description: Lawrence W. Hughes, 61 years old and black, had believed it would happen, but never in his lifetime. Baltimore, a city where Jim Crow once reigned, was about to name its courthouse for a black man.

title: EUROPE'S FIGHT OVER A FIGHTER
description: In a red, high-security hanger here in western Lancashire, at Europe's largest combat aircraft factory, a radically different fighter is slowly taking shape. According to the laws of aerodynamics, the plane should be incapable of flight, let alone combat.

title: Times Mirror
description: The Times Mirror Company's stock dropped $3 a share, to $46.25, in New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, a day after the company said that negotiations to sell its newsprint and forest-products operations to Boise Cascade had fallen through.

title: Serling's 'Requiem' to Close
description: Requiem for a Heavyweight,'' a play by Rod Serling about a boxer at the end of a 14-year career, will close after this evening's performance at the Martin Beck Theater. Directed by Arvin Brown, the drama will have run for eight previews and four performances.

title: NEW WAY TO USE BANK CARD
description: MILLIONS of bank customers in the New York metropolitan area who use credit cards and bank cards to withdraw cash from automatic teller machines were offered a new convenience this week: They can now use hundreds of additional teller machines operated by banks where they have no accounts.

title: Judge Freezes E.S.M. Assets
description: Federal District Judge Jose A. Gonzalez Jr. today froze the assets of the former officers and directors of E.S.M. Government Securities Inc., which failed last Friday. He also approved a motion by the court-appointed receiver, Thomas Tew, a Miami lawyer, to allow some of E.S.M.'s customers, mostly municipalities, to liquidate securities they hold as collateral for loans made to E.S.M.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Grimy Jewel in the Crown
description: The coal miners who returned to Britain's pits this week after a year of fruitless strife did not end a strike so much as an explosion of class bitterness. Theirs is a society now seriously frayed by pessimism and bitter confrontation.

title: Landmarking Needs a Review
description: After 18 years of indecision, the Landmarks Commission last month thwarted a Fifth Avenue office development to save three buildings of uncertain quality. The controversy stirred Mayor Koch to mount a study of the landmark process to see if changes are warranted. They are.

title: REAGAN CRITICAL OF BUDGET VIEW OF SENATE PANEL
description: The White House criticized the Republican- controlled Senate Budget Committee today, saying it was ''marching in the wrong direction'' by agreeing to cut the military budget while sparing domestic programs.

title: Candid Shots by Dole
description: Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, is quoted in the April issue of M magazine as making this comment about Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia: ''He's tall and he's rich.

title: SECOND TEST FOR AIDS APPROVED
description: The Government has approved a second screening test for blood contaminated by acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, after laboratory results indicating it was the most sensitive indicator of possible exposure to the disorder.

title: PUBLIC INDICTMENTS HAT CONVICT
description: When indictments are announced these days, too often they amount to convictions.

title: AUSTRALIAN CHIEF AFFIRMS ALLIANCE
description: Prime Minister Bob Hawke said today that there was no possibility that his Government would adopt the antinuclear stance that led New Zealand to deny visiting privileges to American warships.

title: Police Car and a Bus Collide Causing Minor Injuries to 21
description: A collision between a police patrol car and a rented school bus yesterday in the Bronx left 2 officers in the car and 19 people on the bus injured, but none were believed to be seriously hurt, the police reported.

title: DIGICON INC.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $340,000 from the reversal of a tax credit.

title: McLaughlin Wins Heat
description: Willie McLaughlin of Manhattan won his 400-meter heat in 47.29 seconds and beat two Olympic medalists - Antonio McKay of Georgia Tech (second here in 47.33) and Gabriel Tiacoh of Washington State and the Ivory Coast (fifth in 48.35). McLaughlin and McKay advanced to the final. . . . Carol Lewis of Houston led the women's long jump qualifiers with 21 feet 9 inches.

title: Flyers Triumph And Tie for Lead
description: Ilkka Sinisalo and Derrick Smith each scored a goal and had one assist as the Philadelphia Flyers defeated the Washington Capitals, 4-2, tonight and tied the Capitals for the Patrick Division lead. The Flyers swept the home-and-home series on successive nights.

title: Thomas C. Colt Jr., 80, Dies; LedArtMuseumsin3States
description: Thomas C. Colt Jr., who directed art museums in Virginia, Oregon and Ohio, died Wednesday. He was 80 years old and lived in Oakwood, Ohio.

title: ALEJANDRO THOMAS Y JORGE
description: We inhabit the Age of Overstatement. That's why I didn't pay much attention the other day when President Reagan said the people trying to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government were the ''moral equals'' of our Founding Fathers.

title: ACAPULCO Y LOS ARCOS RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   And Make It Snappy
description: When his turn came up at a

title: U.S. Told to Pay Father For Hiding His Children
description: A father who said the Government hid his two children from him for almost two years while their mother was being protected as a Federal witness has won a $100,000 settlement from the Government, according to court papers.

title: FINANCIAL CORP. SEES BIG '84 LOSS
description: The Financial Corporation of America said today that it expects to report an unexpectedly large loss for 1984 of between $500 million and $700 million.

title: 'MARCH MADNESS' BECOMES UGLY
description: Patrick Ewing's reputation

title: INDIA PLANS TO SUE CARBIDE IN THE U.S. OVER BHOPAL LEAK
description: A high official in India said yesterday that the Government would file suit in the United States on behalf of all victims of the gas leak at the Union Carbide Corporation plant in Bhopal, India, last December.

title: 'Star Wars' Will Lead Us to the Death Star
description: To the Editor:

title: German G.N.P. Grows
description: West Germany's gross national product grew 2.6 percent in 1984 from a year earlier, the Federal Statistics Offiice said today.

title: ABUSING CHILDREN BY SMOKING
description: Most of us know about the dangers of smoking. And most of us are deeply concerned about child abuse. But what we have overlooked is the child abuse caused by smokers. In fact, smoking adults inflict serious damage upon the developing child, starting with its embryonal life and continuing throughout its formative years. A nursing baby may receive nicotine in breast milk or by inhaling it.

title: Lesser Charge
description: Claudell Washington , the Atlanta Brave slugger who was charged last month with possession of cocaine and marijuana, got a break yesterday when a California prosecutor dropped the felony cocaine charge while pressing the misdemeanor marijuana count. If found guilty, He could be suspended from baseball for a year.

title: CHINA REAFFIRMS COMMUNISM
description: Deng Xiaoping, China's top leader, said in remarks made public today that action should be taken to impress on the people of China that Communism remains the country's ultimate goal despite the Government's espousal of policies permitting private enterprise and foreign investment.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, MARCH 9, 1985
description: International

title: WEBCOR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an inventory writedown of $2,800,000 to reflect current market conditions of certain telecommunications products and the phasing out of its watch product line. c-Net income.

title: Charles Morse Stotz, Leader In Architectural Restoration
description: Charles Morse Stotz, an architect best known for his work in architectural restoration, died Tuesday at Shell Point Village, a retirement home in Fort Meyers, Fla. He was 86 years old.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 9, 1985 International

title: U.S. Leads in Davis Cup KYOTO, Japan, March 8 (AP) - Playing without John McEnroe,
description: the world's top-ranked player, the United States took an easy 2-0 lead

title: ST. JOHN'S ATTAINS BIG EAST FINAL WITH GEORGETOWN
description: The end result was merely one more convincing step on Georgetown's way to the defense of its national championship. But along the way, the 74-65 victory over Syracuse in a semifinal game of the Big East Conference tournament last night held another emotionally charged episode in a series of such moments that has characterized the four-year Patrick Ewing era at Georgetown.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Victor W. Farris, 75; Industrialist-Inventor
description: Victor Wallace Farris, a multimillionaire industrialist and an inventor whose inventions included the paper milk carton, died of a heart attack Thursday in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 75 years old and had lived in West Palm Beach for 20 years.

title: TURNING TO FOOD FOR SOLACE
description: What child has not been offered a lollipop to assuage the pain after skinning a knee or enduring a shot at the doctor's office? Foods that comfort us as children are not necessarily those that make us feel better as adults when everything goes wrong, but more often than not there is a link. When it comes to comforting foods, people involved professionally with food are like everyone else.

title: N. CAROLINA WINS IN OVERTIME
description: Underdog Wake Forest led most of the way tonight before North Carolina rallied for a 72-61 overtime victory in the opening round of the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament. The regular season had been characterized by balanced play, so it was no surprise that Wake Forest, seeded seventh, gave the second-seeded Tar Heels difficulty.

title: No Perks
description: On the way to a 16-11 record this season, Coach Pete Lonergan of Niagara led his Purple Eagles to one of only two regular-season victories that anyone achieved at the expense of St. John's. A lot of good it did him. When he tried to get a ticket to the Big East tournament semifinals at Madison Square Garden last night, Lonergan, like thousands of other basketball fans, found himself shut out and had to settle for watching on television.

title: A.N.R. Studies Other Offers The American Natural Resources Company has confirmed that it is considering
description: several alternatives to the proposed tender offer of the

title: AN 'UNDERSTANDING' ON REQUEST FOR AID REPORTED BY ISRAELI
description: The Israeli Finance Minister said today that he had achieved ''tangible results'' in a meeting with Secretary of State George P. Shultz on his Government's request for a large increase in American economic aid that until now the Reagan Administration had delayed acting upon.

title: ARIZONAN IS DEAD AFTER 3 IMPLANTS
description: A 33- year-old Arizona automobile mechanic who was given three hearts in 46 hours of marathon surgery died here at 2:20 P.M. today.

title: 3D RECIPIENT TAKES STEPS
description: Murray P. Haydon, the world's third recipient of a permanent artificial heart, took a few steps today and ate solid food, a spokesman for Humana Hospital Audubon said.

title: POWER CORP OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $15,520,000 for the quarter and a special gain of $41,392,000 for the year. c-After a special charge of $1,598,000 for the quarter and a special gain of $263,000 for the year.

title: Pro-Israeli Officer Slain
description: An officer of the Israeli-backed militia known as the South Lebanon Army was shot dead today by gunmen in Jezzin, a Christian town in Israeli-occupied territory east of Sidon, security officials said.

title: Reagan 'Just Fine' After Tests
description: President Reagan underwent a complete battery of medical tests today, including a checkup on a benign colon growth discovered last year. Afterward he made a thumbs-up sign and said he felt ''just fine.''

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
U.S. CITES MOVES ON CURRENCY
description: The United States intervened seven times in foreign exchange markets from August through January, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday. The Fed also confirmed that it had intervened since then, but it refused to give details.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   The Fine Print
description: Americas has been restored to its

title: I.R.S. SAYS TAX SHARE OF AFFLUENT UP
description: The share of Federal income taxes paid by Americans with annual incomes of more than $75,000 rose 25 percent between 1980 and 1983, and the portion paid by those with incomes under $19,000 declined by about the same amount, the Internal Revenue Service said today.

title: DROP IN PUPILS IMPERILS WESTPORT'S HIGH SCHOOL
description: Over the last decade, Westport has closed five of its seven elementary schools. And it intends to shut one of its three middle schools in 1986.

title: INJUSTICES FUEL THE FLAMES OF NORTHERN IRELAND
description: To the Editor:

title: GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,044,000. The year-ago results were restated to reflect the acquisition of Sunkist Soft Drinks as a discontinued operation.

title: U.S. CARRIER LEAVES SPAIN: LINK TO LEBANON SEEN
description: The aircraft carrier Eisenhower hurriedly left the Spanish island of Majorca Thursday night and sailed into the Mediterranean, after Shiite Moslem militants threatened Americans in Lebanon, United States officials said.

title: NEWHOUSE PURCHASING THE NEW YORKER
description: The New Yorker magazine, a proudly independent arbiter of good taste in fine fiction, reportage and humor for more than 60 years, agreed yesterday on a sale to Samuel I. Newhouse Jr. for $142 million.

title: CONGRESS AIDE DEALS WITH 'A WHOLE NEW WORLD'
description: In his 27 years as top aide in the same Congressional office, Harry K. Nicholas has served one man who was like a father, a second who was like a brother, and now a third who is young enough to be his son.

title: The Marketplace Way to Erode Rural America
description: To the Editor:

title: CAR BOMB KILLS 62 OUTSIDE BEIRUT NEAR HOME OF A TOP SHIITE CLERIC
description: A car-bomb killed at least 62 people and wounded 200 today in a densely populated Shiite Moslem suburb of Beirut, Lebanese officials said.

title: TITLE TO ALL HALLOWS
description: All Hallows, which had stunned St. Raymond's to advance to the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship game, toppled the defending champion, Christ the King, 61-49, to capture the city title last night at Fordham's Rose Hill Gym.

title: Merger Talks Held By Castle & Cooke
description: Castle & Cooke Inc., the financially troubled food and real estate company, said today that it was involved in preliminary discussions with another company about a possible merger. The company said the agreement might be a no-premium merger, meaning that Castle & Cooke stockholders might receive less than the market value of their shares.

title: LEADING DEVELOPERS REPRESENTED AT BRIEFING ON SALE OF THE COLISEUM
description: More than 100 representatives of some of the city's most prominent real- estate and architectural firms gathered at the New York Coliseum yesterday for a briefing on what the city and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority are looking for in proposals to redevelop the site.

title: EQUITABLE OF IOWA COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $229,862. c-After investment losses of $942,617. d-After realized investment losses of $161. e-After realized investment gains of $943,580.

title: GATES LEARJET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Fumes Force 600 to Flee
description: A train carrying chemicals derailed and caught fire today, forcing 600 people to flee their homes, the authorities said. Evacuees were taken to a National Guard armory and schools in the sparsely settled area of south Alabama to wait out the fire and the threat of wafting toxic fumes. No injuries were reported.

title: DANIEL SCHORR LEAVES CNN OVER DISPUTE ON CONTRACT
description: Daniel Schorr, who was Ted Turner's first employee at his Cable News Network, left the television service yesterday after he was refused a new contract for reasons the network's executives would not discuss.

title: THOUSANDS CAN RETAKE BAD PHOTOS ON LICENSES
description: Since New York State began putting color photographs on driver's licenses last July, thousands of motorists have received licenses with such poor reproductions that the Department of Motor Vehicles has offered to redo them free.

title: CAMBODIA REBELS CLING TO LAST BORDER OUTPOST
description: Cambodian guerrillas defending their last major base on the Thai border struggled today to hold off advancing Vietnamese troops, according to the chief of Thailand's armed forces.

title: MORE TOWNS HIT IN GULF WAR
description: Iran said Iraqi warplanes raided cities and towns in western Iran today, killing or wounding 400 people in the city of Piranshahr alone.

title: AMERICAN BILTRITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $540,000 for the quarter and $1,532,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $133,000 for the quarter and $11,000 for the year and an extraordinary credit of $70,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Firestone Plans To Shut Plant
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said it plans to close its Des Moines tire plant, laying off 1,500 hourly and 330 salaried employees. The company said the planned closing comes after the United Rubber Workers union's international policy committee rejected a package of work rule changes and wage concessions that had been approved by the union local in Des Moines last week.

title: ATTRACTING THE RESEARCH DOLLAR
description: Hard-pressed for funds and eager to support more research, scores of universities around the country are developing corporate research parks in their backyards.

title: Home Address
description: They're expecting more than 50,000 for the Doug Flutie-Steve Young shootout and whatever else develops in the Generals' home opener tomorrow - quite a crowd, when you consider the omission of a piece of information from a brochure that arrived in the mail the other day.

title: Illinois River Drops a Bit; At Least 1,700 Displaced
description: The flooding Illinois River, which has displaced at least 1,700 people and killed four people, dropped slightly here today, giving riverfront towns the first hope in two weeks that the worst may be over.

title: RALPH INGERSOLL, EDITOR AND PUBLISHER
description: Ralph Ingersoll, a journalist, author and publisher who founded the newspaper PM in the 40's and was an early guiding spirit behind The New Yorker, Fortune and Life magazines, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach, Fla. He was 84 years old.

title: SALANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,241,000 for the quarter and year and a provision for closures of $10,031,000 for the year. c-Net income.

title: Former Nebraska Official Is Fined for Perjury
description: A judge today sentenced former State Attorney General Paul Douglas to three years of probation for perjury and ordered him to perform 1,500 hours of volunteer work and pay a $25,000 fine.

title: COLOR EXPLODES
description: FUN AND CASUAL CLOTHES PREDOMInate for spring and summer, which is as it should be. The most popular fabric is cotton, in a variety of forms - washed, crinkled, crushed, textured to look like corduroy, meshed, knitted - all washable and requiring little or no ironing. Following a trend in the young junior market, the shapes are relaxed and oversized, baggy and comfortable; they are clothes to wear now, not to grow into.

title:
PROSPECTS;

Gambling Boom, or Bust
description: New York City's Off-Track-Betting Corporation recently tried out a new high-payout wager: The Big Apple Double Exacta, in which a bettor had to pick finishers at both Aqueduct and Roosevelt Raceway. Harry McCabe, president of O.T.B., noted that ''for the first time in the history of racing, so far as I know,'' the trotting (Roosevelt) and thoroughbred (Aqueduct) establishments cooperated.

title: DIVERSITY IS THE WORD FOR AMERICAN DANCE TODAY
description: ''Today ballet thrives with large audiences supporting sometimes as many as four simultaneously touring companies in North America. The number of permanent ballet institutions in Great Britain is in excess of those on the Western side of the Atlantic.'' Times have changed since Irving Deakin, a promoter of ballet in America, wrote these words in ''At the Ballet'' in 1956.

title:
LEISURE;

 A GARDEN OF REMINISCENCES
description: Richard M. Bacon is a freelance writer and horticultural consultant.

title: Sell Conrail?Not Just Yet
description: Whether the Administration's plans for selling Conrail are ultimately approved or derailed is anybody's guess, but for now Capitol Hill's skeptics seem to have a firm hand on the throttle.

title: California Leads Arms Work
description: California, the leading state in Pentagon contract work, remains the largest recipient of payroll dollars paid by the Defense Department, according to a summary released Friday.

title: CONVICTION CLOUDING FUTURE FOR OHIO REPUBLICAN
description: A Cleveland lawyer, J. William Petro, once considered a bright young man on the rise in Republican politics in Cuyahoga County, now has an uncertain future.

title: ADORNMENT AND FANTASTICATION
description: HABITATIONS OF THE WORD

title: COLUMBIA U. CREATES A LAW PROFESSORSHIP IN HONOR OF SCHOLAR
description: A professorship honoring Adolf A. Berle, a legal scholar and statesman, has been established by Columbia University.

title: ANYONE COULD BE AN ARTIST
description: REDESIGNING THE WORLD

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;

WHAT'S IN A NAME
description: A HAIDA POTLATCH (University of Washington, $14.95) is a poignant account of a gathering of Indians in a small village in British Columbia. Seeing a decline in the culture of the Haida, who live in Alaska as well as British Columbia, a young Indian named Robert Davidson acted.

title: REAGAN'S RISKY APPROACH
description: The Administration is bringing a new approach to the arms-control negotiations, which resume Tuesday in Geneva. It deserves a serious hearing - but it carries real risks and is likely to prove unproductive.

title: South KoreaLifts a Ban
description: South Korea's President Chun Doo Hwan has cleared the decks for his trip to Washington next month by acting to defuse criticism of his treatment of political opponents. The Government last week lifted the ban on the last of the 811 politicians blacklisted after General Chun seized power in November 1980.

title: BEHIND THE SPLIT CASINO-LICENSE DECISIONS
description: LAWRENCEVILLE STATEMENTS by members of the state's Casino Control Commission upon relicensing Resorts International one day and refusing to license the Hilton Hotels Corporation two days later point up a major difference that the commissioners saw in the presentations made by the two companies.

title: TIME FOR REDMEN TO REASSESS
description: The end of one tournament became the beginning of another. When the emotion from the Madison Square Garden court turned to resignation in the St. John's dressing room last night after Georgetown's 92-80 victory in the championship game of the Big East tournament, there was a thought to ponder as they waited to see who, and where, the Redmen would play in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Beth Pniewski to Wed
description: The engagement of Beth A. Pniewski, a corporate counsel with the American Mutual Insurance Companies in Wakefield, Mass., to Philip D. Wilson, an international marketing manager for Prime Computer in Framingham, Mass., has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Edward S. Pniewski of Hyde Park, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Wilson of Rumson, N.J.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GENEVA ACCORD. By John Whitman. (Crown, $14.95.)

title: MUSIC: FIGUEROA FAMILY
description: Figueroa is a big name in music in Puerto Rico, and from time to time members of the large musical family appear here in New York. Last Tuesday night, Guillermo Figueroa, violinist, and his sister Yvonne, a pianist, gave a concert at Tully Hall that included the participation of a string quartet made up of still other members of the family.

title: Toxic Building
description: Four years after the State Office Building in Binghamton, N.Y., was closed and sealed because an electrical fire had spread toxic chemicals through its 18 floors, the State Health Department said it would ventilate the structure. The announcement last month prompted protests by citizens who feared contamination.

title: TOXIC WASTE THREAT TERMED FAR GREATER THAN U.S. ESTIMATES
description: The threat from toxic waste that faces the nation is much more serious and will be much more costly to resolve than the Government has estimated, two Congressional research agencies have concluded.

title: An ExceptionTo Miranda
description: Once again, the Supreme Court took a narrow view of the rights of the criminally accused as established by the Warren Court. A six- member majority ruled last week that an initial failure by the police to tell a suspect of his right to remain silent and to have a lawyer present does not necessarily make a later confession inadmissable in court if the suspect has been given the required warning in the meantime.

title: Glenn Faces Deadline On His Campaign Debt
description: Senator John Glenn faces a March 31 deadline for paying off a $1.85 million debt from his 1984 Presidential bid, but he says he is seeking an extension from the four Ohio banks involved.

title: Miss Wells Plans A June Wedding
description: The engagement of Linda Wells to Britton Jones has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Wells of St. Louis, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr.and Mrs. James E. Jones of Bedford Hills, N.Y. A June 21 wedding is planned.

title: THE U.S. IS URGED TO EXTEND CRIME INSURANCE
description: New York officials are fighting to keep alive the Federal Crime Insurance program, which is targeted for elimination by the Reagan Administration. The program allows about 27,000 New York City residents in high crime areas to purchase home and business insurance.

title: ACIDIC WATER A PERIL TO STRIPED BASS
description: Emerging from the ongoing detective work to determine the cause of the startling decline in the migratory populations of East Coast striped bass is the realization that, in some spawning streams, acidic water is the villain.

title: ROUND DANCERS TO DIP AND SWAY IN FESTIVAL TODAY
description: HUNDREDS of Connecticut couples are donning their dancing shoes each week and going to school gymnasiums and community centers for an evening of round dancing.

title: A WORLD OF DISCOVERIES ;   OFF THE BEATEN TRACK
description: One of the delights of travel is coming upon a restaurant, a neighborhood, a city - even an entire region - that does not appear on traditional tourist itineraries. Discoveries may range from a hotel cherished by local residents to an out-of-the-way street that sums up the spirit of a nation, to a waterway that reveals the heart of a country. Here, Times correspondents from around the world suggest some unusual attractions.

title: Taking Issue With Richler
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: JEWS IN OLD CHINA: Studies by Chinese Scholars. Translated, compiled and edited by Sidney Shapiro. (Hippocrene, $15.95.)

title: UConn Students Not to Blame
description: It was regrettable to me that it took a gossipy, unscientific ''report'' on student life at the University of Connecticut to put UConn students on the front page of The Connecticut Weekly (''UConn Report Scorns 'Intellectual Poverty,' '' Feb. 10).

title: Smells
description: To the Editor:

title: GREEK SOCIALISTS IN SURPRISE SHIFT
description: The governing Socialist Party threw Greek politics into confusion today by unexpectedly withholding its support from President Constantine Caramanlis and nominating its own presidential candidate for next Friday's election.

title: EXECUTIVES SAY INCOME-TAX CUT WOULD HELP BUSINESS GROW
description: Business executives say that cutting New York's personal income tax would better enhance their ability to expand and hire new workers than would cuts in corporate taxes, according to results of a new survey.

title: THREE FIRMS THAT OUTPERFORM THE PACK
description: PROFESSIONAL money managers have had their share of turmoil over the past two years. In both 1983 and 1984, for instance, more than two-thirds of the pros failed to match the performance of the Standard & Poor's 500 index, the most commonly used proxy for the market.

title: TIBETAN EMIGRES PROSPER BUT DREAM OF THE HOMELAND
description: The Thondens have had good news from home: Shops that were closed for more than 20 years have reopened in downtown Lhasa, people are more relaxed and some color is returning to life in Tibet.

title: Ellen Clarke Plans to Wed
description: Ellen Dean Clarke, an assistant in the subsidiary rights department at Random House, and Pierre de Saint Phalle, a partner in the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, plan to be married April 13.

title: Ingrid Bloomquist Marries Marvin Pope in Greenwich
description: Ingrid Brostrom Bloomquist, the widow of Howard Richard Bloomquist, and Marvin Hoyle Pope were married yesterday at the bride's home in Greenwich, Conn.

title: HOSPITALS FORM ETHICS PANELS
description: CONFUSION about physicians' legal responsibility - and liability - when patients request not to be resuscitated appears to be the central concern prompting area hospitals to form committees on ''bioethics.'' The absence of Federal or state legislation that clearly defines terms and sufficiently protects physicians from latter civil or criminal suits in ''do-not- resuscitate'' cases has led in the past to what one physician describes as ''surreptitious'' ways of communicating and documenting such orders - an issue the new committees want to address.

title: ECONOMIC REWRITE
description: To the Editor:

title: Abigail Franklin To Wed May 18
description: Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin A. Franklin of Garret Park, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Abigail Jane Franklin to Derald Gene Plumer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Jackson Plumer of Charleston, S.C. The wedding is planned for May 18.

title: BEIRUT BOMBINGS TRIGGER THREATS AGAINST U.S.
description: TWO explosions killed at least 85 people in Shiite

title:
GARDENING;

APPLES THAT ARE DISEASE-RESISTANT
description: APPLES are the most popular of all fruits in this country. This year's crop, one of the largest, is estimated to have exceeded 196 million boxes, which contained about one bushel each. This estimate does not include those grown in backyards and home orchards.

title: Pope's Canceled Visit Makes Mark in Canada
description: The log skeleton of a giant tepee casts a weak shadow across windblown snowdrifts that undulate like waves down to the frozen confluence of the Mackenzie and Liard Rivers. Buffalo tails and colored streamers lashed atop the frame seem to rattle in the cold, now hovering at 30 below zero.

title: Peasants in BoliviaThreaten to Block Cities
description: Militant peasants, supporting a three- day-old general strike, threatened today to block all roads leading into the cities of Bolivia. The army said it would intervene if they tried to halt food shipments.

title:
FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;

Graffiti Struggle
description: With graffiti increasing despite the arrest of offenders, the City Council in New Rochelle, N.Y., tried a last resort. It banned the sale of spray paint to anyone under the age of 18.

title:
ART;

MUSEUM'S PERUVIAN ART STANDS OUT
description: WHEN a regional museum mounts a special exhibition based on its permanent collection, the installation becomes an opportunity to evaluate these holdings as a community resource.

title: WHEN A DAUGHTER IS MURDERED
description: ON Oct. 3, 1984, my daughter Karin Minkin was murdered in her apartment one block away from the campus of Tulane University in New Orleans, where she was a sophomore student. Hundreds of times since then my wife and I have been asked by well-meaning friends and acquaintances ''How are you doing?'' We always answer ''O.K.'' We're not O.K. We never will be O.K. We simply can't bear to tell the story of what we've been through. Yet, I think that I can tell some of the story just this once, so I won't have to say ''O.K.'' again.

title: UNDER BRADY, NEW TONE EMERGES ON BOARD
description: IT was early January, and the

title: STRONG CURBS URGED IN WAKE OF UNSANCTIONED HEART IMPLANT
description: As a Food and Drug Administration team prepares to come here next week to investigate the use of an unsanctioned artificial heart, three experts in the laws and ethics of medicine called on Government officials to take strong measures to prevent the similar use of experimental medical procedures.

title: RESORT PACT GAINS
description: -casinos here have agreed to consider, and in some instances go along with, suggestions made by Assemblyman Guy F. Muziani that could lead to joint promotional efforts with other resorts, backing new recreational facilities and the improvement of key highways.

title: CHINESE WITH A WELCOME TWIST
description: -food mania continues to spread. A late-blooming example is the two-month old restaurant North China in Brookfield.

title: Two Strategies for Keeping Jobs in the U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: WITT SKATES TO TITLE
description: Katarina Witt, the defending champion, performing with steely determination to the graceful strains of Gershwin music, won her second straight world figure skating title today.

title: NEW ROLE: PROFESSOR OTTINGER
description: RICHARD L. OTTINGER, the former Westchester Representative was digging through papers and books on his desk at the Pace University School of Law, searching for a document.

title: LILCO LAND EYED AS ASH SITE
description: A 17-ACRE parcel in Riverhead Town owned by the Long Island Lighting Company is under consideration as a dump for thousands of tons of toxic ash from garbage incinerators that are proposed for Long Island.

title: Ex-Lawyer TellsOf Court Bribes
description: A former lawyer has told a New York State Senate Committee that he and other lawyers bribed judges, court clerks and court officers to win medical malpractice and negligence cases in New York City.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Westchester Guide last Sunday gave the incorrect date for a lecture by Irving Lavin, professor of art history at the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton. He will give the second of four lectures on Caravaggio, at 6:30 Tuesday in the film viewing room of the Performing Arts Center at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers.

title: October Wedding Is Being Planned By Miss Oresman
description: The engagement of Deborah Ann Oresman to Dr. Edward Kevin Kasper has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Oresman of Darien, Conn., and Captiva Island, Fla., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Kasper of Wilton, Conn.

title: WRIERS AS MOTHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Kate A. NearpassTo Marry in May
description: Kate Ann Nearpass, curatorial assistant in the archives and collections of the International Center for Photography in New York, and Warren Russell Ogden, a printmaker and photographer, plan to be married in May, her father, Dr. D. C. Nearpass of College Park, Md., has announced.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SUNDAY, MARCH 10, 1985 International

title: EX-HEAD OF O.A.S. QUITS U.S. COMPANY

title: DEFENSE IN SPACE

title: NEW HELP IN DEALING WITH SUICIDE
description: BOB saw no other alternative in life and decided, at the age of 21, to ''blow his brains out.'' His parents caught him loading the gun and took it away.

title: Murdoch Plans a New Paper
description: Rupert Murdoch announced tonight that he would start a new, 24-hour British newspaper later this year, similar to his New York Post. The newspaper, also to be called The Post, will be published as a London evening and a national morning paper. Through his British subsidiary, News International, Mr. Murdoch, an Australian, owns The Times of London and The Sun, a mass- circulation paper, among other publications.

title: SAVING A TRIANGLE
description: Not many triangular buildings have been erected in New York, and few match the distinction of the Flatiron Building at Madison Square. But one, the old Cocoa Exchange building at the intersection of Beaver, Pearl and Wall Streets, erected in the 1920's, is an ornament of the Financial District, and now it has an assured future.

APPLES THAT ARE DISEASE-RESISTANT
description: APPLES are the most popular of all fruits in this country. This year's crop, one of the largest, is estimated to have exceeded 196 million boxes, which contained about one bushel each. This estimate does not include those grown in backyards and home orchards.

title: ZOELLER, STRANGE TIED FOR LEAD
description: For Fuzzy Zoeller, winning has a different meaning these days. ''Any time I can get out of bed in the morning and walk out here and swing that golf club I'm winning,'' said the winner of last year's United States Open, who underwent major surgery on his back in September. ''Whether or not I can win the Bay Hill Classic is something I don't know.''

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Sound Creations, a six month old troupe describing itself as ''the only regularly scheduled children's theater company in northern Westchester,'' presents the sixth of eight productions, ''The adventures of Robin Hood,'' at 2 P.M. Saturday in the Yorktown Community Center, on Commerce Street. It will be repeated at the same time the following Saturday. Tickets are $4 at the door or call 528-5191 for reservations.

title: Aid After a Conversion
description: Several disabled tenants in our rent-stabilized building, which is being converted to a co-op on a noneviction plan, are receiving Section 8 rent subsidies. Others receive public assistance from the city. What protection will these tenants have when the conversion is completed? . . . G. W. C., Brooklyn.

title: NATIVE ROOTS FEED VIBRANT ROCK
description: Rock 'n' roll was born and bred in America, but a considerable number of American fans find it more appealing when the singer has a British accent and a new haircut. Pop fads come and go with dazzling rapidity in Britain, where a young band can jump in a van and tour the country in a few months' time. In America, a new band faces years of touring in order to reach a comparably broad audience, and there are fewer independent record labels and little in the way of adventurous radio programming to help careers along. It must be pretty dispiriting for such a band to pull into some American town for a show at the local new wave club only to hear a steady diet of British records and the opinon, still surprisingly prevalent, that British musicians are now better at playing rock 'n' roll.

description: Doug Sulliman scored his 20th goal of the season midway through the final period today to break a 4-4 tie and lead the Devils to a come-from-behind 8-5 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: State Employees' Group Told Of Need for Revenue Sharing
description: Thirty-four states that now have budget surpluses would have deficits without Federal revenue-sharing funds and other aid that President Reagan wants to cut, the Federation of State Employees says.
