title: EDDIE MURPHY'S COMIC TOUCH
description: Eddie Murphy is coming back to his home town a superstar. With his ''Beverly Hills Cop'' breaking box- office records, Mr. Murphy is now the hottest actor in Hollywood, but finds appearing live in concert ''relaxing.'' Radio City Music Hall has scheduled him for five performances over the weekend of March 22. When ticket windows for the event were opened a month ago at 8 o'clock in the morning, all 36,000 tickets were sold within hours. Those who don't remember Mr. Murphy from his four seasons on NBC's ''Saturday Night Live'' had a chance to remind themselves of the Murphy style most recently when he returned to the show as a guest-host two months ago, smiling, cheerful but sassy, offering the audience advice as to which dolls to give children as Christmas presents. He displayed each doll in turn, noting regretfully that the G.I. Joe doll had shrunk from eleven inches to four inches. ''But as small as Joe is, he's still a macho guy,'' Mr. Murphy observed. ''Not like Ken here.'' Mr. Murphy lifted a Ken doll of the famous Ken-and- Barbie couple. ''Remember Ken?'' asked Mr. Murphy. ''Check out Ken's pink shirt, all right? Check out the way he combs his hair. And look at his posture.'' Mr. Murphy adopted an admonitory tone. ''Moms and Dads, unless you want your sons to live in the 'Village' and skip to work, keep them as far away from Ken as possible, all right?'' Wild hilarity and applause. Mr. Murphy then paired off a Barbie doll with macho G.I. Joe.

title: TOWARD A DEFENSE STRATEGY
description: The starting point for any rational discourse on the Strategic Defense Initiative - and many discourses on it have not been rational - is a large dose of modesty at predicting what science can offer in the future. How many times in our history has human ingenuity overcome human expectations and even expert predictions?

title: 'Flaubert's Parrot'
description: Gustave Flaubert has been the subject of a nearly obsessive number of biographies and critical studies, including Jean-Paul Sartre's outsized recreation of the writer's psychic life in ''The Family Idiot.'' Now Julian Barnes, a British novelist and journalist, has succumbed to the temptation to make Flaubert the central figure in a novel. The temptation in fact seems hard to resist, since the austere image of Flaubert - the hermit of Croisset who sacrificed living to his unending quest for style, the father of modernism who wished most of all to write ''a book about nothing'' - is so belied by what we know of the man and his rich inner life.

title: Coaches IndictedIn Drug Scandal
description: When Clemson University runner Augustinius Jaspers died in his dormitory room last October, doctors blamed heart disease. But they found something else during the autopsy: traces of phenylbutazone, an anti-inflammation pain killer for which the 23-year-old athlete did not have a prescription.

title: THE DISPUTE OVER AFFIRMATIVE ACTION: WHOSE CIVIL RIGHTS?
description: WASHINGTON THE lines were sharply drawn well before the start of the Civil Rights Commission's sometimes testy ''consultation/hearing'' last week on affirmative action. A majority of the Commission, like the Reagan Administration, opposes quotas, and some members have criticized affirmative action plans designed to give preference to specified groups, such as blacks and women.

title: Happy LandingIn Westchester
description: Westchester County's modest ambitions for its airport in Purchase, N.Y., are likely to be preserved as a result of a proposed out- of-court agreement unanimously approved last week by the County Board of Legislators. The deal would give county officials final say over the facility's future, thus preventing it from being developed into a major airport.

title: THE COST OF LIVING
description: ACCEPTABLE RISKS. By Pascal James Imperato and Greg Mitchell. 286 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95. DAY-TO-DAY living on the Wild West frontier could became an occupational hazard when bullets started flying. ''He died of livin','' was old Doc Adams's disingenuous diagnosis of the cause of a cowboy's demise on television's ''Gunsmoke'' series when the man failed to dodge a stray bullet.

description: Rightly or wrongly, a listener anticipates sonic wonders from any group that dares to assume the mantle of the Mozarteum Orchestra of Saizburg. title: New & Noteworthy
description: BERNARD M. BARUCH: The Adventures of a Wall Street Legend, by James Grant. (Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) Bernard M. Baruch, the legendary financier and adviser to politicians, earned his first million by age 30, in 1900. His attributes included an encyclopedic grasp of the stock market and an outgoing personality. But in this biography, James Grant revises the myth of his invincibility, detailing instances of the financier's errors. Our reviewer, Linda Robinson, wrote last year that though Mr. Grant's book was ''ridden with jargon and tangled prose, it does offer insights into its subject.''

title: The New YorkerTakes a Buyout
description: To hear the present owners tell it, nothing will change at The New Yorker except the names on the stock certificates when a communications empire run by the Newhouse family absorbs the company that publishes the 60-year-old magazine. The merger is expected to be completed later this month after a decision by The New Yorker's directors last week to accept an offer of $142 million for the 83 percent of the company not already held by Newhouse's Advance Publications Inc.

title: A WORLD OF DISCOVERIES ;   OFF THE BEATEN TRACK
description: One of the delights of travel is coming upon a restaurant, a neighborhood, a city - even an entire region - that does not appear on traditional tourist itineraries. Discoveries may range from a hotel cherished by local residents to an out-of-the-way street that sums up the spirit of a nation, to a waterway that reveals the heart of a country. Here, Times correspondents from around the world suggest some unusual attractions.

description: The miners tramped back to work here in the Midlands, in Yorkshire, in Wales and in Scotland last week, marching behind their banners and their colliery bands, trying to hold their heads high. They hadn't lost, they said.

description: To judge by the laughter, the audience on Friday at City Center might have been watching the Marx Brothers. Merce Cunningham, whose company dances at the theater through March 17, is at his sly silliest in ''Roadrunners.'' Yet there is a good deal of beauty in this fun.

title: Judith Iva Weil to Wed
description: The engagement of Judith Iva Weil, a vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, to Bruce David Stephens, a systems analyst for Bank Leumi in New York, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Weil of Woodmere, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance, who changed his name, is the son of Earl Swetow and Emmeline Swetow, both of Los Angeles. A May wedding is planned.

Since then numerous mayoral committees have studied the taxi industry in search of a solution. More than once, the committees have offered recommendations to cure the problems, but little has changed.

title: THE WORLD IN A NUTSHELL

We wonder in this age of jet travel when astronauts have turned our eyes from earth to outer space, whether there is still an interest in world maps, globes and centuries of objects documenting man's discoveries of the continents.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Back in 1953, when Dwight Eisenhower was President and a senator named Joseph McCarthy was the second most powerful man in the country, a science-fiction novel called ''The Space Merchants'' appeared. The authors, Frederik Pohl and C. M. Kornbluth, offered a satirical view of the future in the mode of Aldous Huxley's ''Brave New World'' and George Orwell's ''Nineteen Eighty-Four'' but in a lighter vein. The world of ''The Space Merchants'' was dominated not by ideologues or technocrats or warlords but by advertising agencies. A vast population of consumers was kept under control by methods of persuasion that seemed only slightly in advance of the bag of tricks Madison Avenue was already using. For example, there was the ''spherical trust.'' Interlocking chains of addiction - induced by special additives and psychological conditioning - insured that a consumer, once hooked, would remain loyal to the products sold by a particular conglomerate. A few mouthfuls of Crunchies began the chain reaction. ''The Crunchies kicked off withdrawal symptoms that could be quelled only by another two squirts of Popsie from the fountain. And Popsie kicked off withdrawal symptoms that could only be quelled by smoking Starr Cigarettes, which made you hungry for Crunchies.''

description: Jessica Lynn Primoff and David J. Allon, graduates of Brandeis University, plan to be married in June. The future bride, the daughter of Mrs. Melvin Primoff of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and the late Mr. Primoff, is enrolled in the doctoral program in economics at Stanford University. Mr. Allon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Allon of Herzliya, Israel, is with DJA Financial Associates in Waltham, Mass.

title: FUNDS VOTED FOR INQUIRY ON GARBAGE
description: Westchester's investigation into its garbage program, now more than two months old, got its first financing -- up to $200,000 -- from the Board of Legislators last week. But afterward, the man in charge of the investigation, Ogden R. Reid, refused to acknowledge the sum as a final ceiling on his inquiry's expenditures. He indicated he would do his best to stay within those limits but if more money were needed he would request it of County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE;

title: IS ABUNDANCE GOOD FOR US?
description: CULTURE AS HISTORY: The Transformation of American Society in the Twentieth Century. By Warren I. Susman. Illustrated. 321 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $22.95. Paper, $12.95. THE central conflict in American culture, Warren I. Susman argues in this brilliant and insightful volume of essays, has been between the values of production and consumption, work and leisure, saving and spending, between the old Puritan culture of frugality and the consumer culture of abundance. Mr. Susman locates the battle's turning point in the 1920's. A practitioner of the new social history would labor long and hard to measure which groups of Americans experienced the transition and when. Mr. Susman, a cultural historian and director of the Institute for Contemporary Culture at Rutgers University, looks instead at the way a few emblematic figures dealt with the defeat of hallowed older values.

title: ROBERT J. BOOHER
description: Dr. Robert J. Booher, surgeon emeritus at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and a frequent contributor to medical and surgical journals, died at his home in Bronxville, N.Y., Friday of hepatitis. He was 71 years old.

description: WILLIAM HASTIE

title: Japan-Bashing Can Backfire
description: If Japan doesn't lower barriers to American imports, warns Bill Brock, the President's Trade Representative, ''we will have to decide what steps to take.'' Senate Foreign Relations Committee members are even less diplomatic. Chairman Richard Lugar wants a 20 percent tariff on Japanese products until Tokyo cries uncle.

title: RETURN OF THE FRENCH BISTRO
description: CERTAIN foods never go out of fashion. One type of cooking that has remained resolutely in style is that of the French bistro.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Dallas Mavericks, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 1 P.M. Coach Dick Motta of Dallas is one short of his 700th victory in the National Basketball Association, which would make him the fourth coach to achieve that mark. Red Auerbach leads with 938. (Television - SportsChannel, 1 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 1 P.M.)

title: A WELFARE TURNABOUT IN PATERSON
description: PATERSON

title: MEETING THE NEEDS OF THE AGED
description: RECENT reports indicate that architects are considering designing housing explicity for the elderly. This is in anticipation of a burgeoning population of people who will need this specialized housing.

title: BOOKSTORES FOR BABY BOOMERS
description: WHEN Marilyn Welch set up a children's bookstore in San Francisco 11 years ago, she decided to name it the Land of Counterpane, after a poem by Robert Louis Stevenson. ''It's a terrible name for a bookstore,'' she said, ''because no one can remember it, but I thought there should be some memorial to such a wonderful poet in the city where he worked.''

title: NKOMO STRUGGLES TO HANG ON AS THE UNDERDOG IN ZIMBABWE
description: In these cattle-rearing lands, where horizons seem infinite, they like to compare politics to the behavior of the herds. Take the proverb, ''You cannot have two bulls in one kraal.'' Since independence from Britain in 1980, the adage has been borne out by the widening rift between the men whose rival armies fought rebellious white settlers to gain power, Prime Minister Robert Mugabe and minority leader Joshua Nkomo.

title: Rubens
description: To the Editor: A most delightful tour through the house in which Rubens lived (Travel, Jan. 13) sensitively portrayed the crippled master as sit

title: Future Events
description: From Past to Future

title: Quake Hits Central Alaska
description: A moderate earthquake shook central Alaska early today, but state troopers said they had no reports of injuries in the sparsely populated area. The Alaska Tsunami Warning Center said the quake measured 6.3 on the Richter scale of earthquake intensity and was centered about 110 miles northwest of Fairbanks.

title: The Death Of a Newspaper
description: When a newspaper dies and there is no notice in the obituaries, where does one mourn? Who is to tell of its long and honorable career? Who is to mention the famous progenitor, Walt Whitman, who went on to stun the world with his poetry and note his celebration of America?

title: R. Susan Stern Weds David Getz, a Lawyer
description: The marriage of R. Susan Stern, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Stern of Sands Point, L.I., and Stuart, Fla., to David L. Getz took place yesterday at the Pierre in Manhattan. The bridegroom is a son of Sylvia Getz of North Hills, L.I., and the late Ernest S. Getz.

title: AFTER EUROPE'S GREAT DOLLAR RAID
description: PARIS

title: A WORLD OF DISCOVERIES ;   OFF THE BEATEN TRACK
description: One of the delights of travel is coming upon a restaurant, a neighborhood, a city - even an entire region - that does not appear on traditional tourist itineraries. Discoveries may range from a hotel cherished by local residents to an out-of-the-way street that sums up the spirit of a nation, to a waterway that reveals the heart of a country. Here, Times correspondents from around the world suggest some unusual attractions.

title: WORLDS OF OUR MAKING
description: CULTURE THEORY

title: TREASURES IN SURPRISING PLACES
description: Most of the art treasures and curiosities of Europe are conveniently situated in museums and other public places in or near the capital cities. Centuries of centralization have seen to that.

title: Margaret Brown To Wed in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Brown of Dallas, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter Margaret Colleen Brown to Edward James Tregurtha, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Tregurtha of Darien, Conn. The wedding is planned for June.

title: A PILGRIM IN COUNTY DONEGAL
description: STATION ISLAND: By Seamus Heaney. 123 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95. FROM the first poem in Seamus Heaney's remarkable new collection, it is clear we are in the hands of a master. He makes it all seem too easy. One of the infernal shades in the title poem advises the poet after his descent to hell ''that the main thing is to write / for the joy of it.'' He surely does.

title: ROAD RUNNERS GIVE EXERCISE TO HOMELESS
description: The 20 men competing on the running track in Fort Washington the other day were part of an unusual event - an experimental running program for residents of city shelters.

title: Wall St. Research
description: To the Editor:

title: DEBTS NAG GROUP ON BLACK HISTORY
description: The organization that started annual celebrations of black history nearly 40 years ago faces an uncertain future even as it sees an expansion of interest in the subject.

title: Fire Destroys Gym At Amherst College
description: A fire today destroyed the Amherst College gymnasium, causing $3 million to $4 million in damage, officials said.

title: A FIRST FOR THE IRISH OF GREENWICH
description: AS it does each spring, Greenwich will be celebrating today with a rousing St. Patrick's Day Parade down Greenwich Avenue. And for the first time in its 11-year history, the parade will be led by a woman.

title: U.S. ARMS OFFICIAL, IN GENEVA, VOICES HOPE ON THE TALKS
description: American arms control negotiators arrived in Geneva today to meet Soviet officials in what the chief American delegate described as a first step toward abolishing nuclear weapons altogether.

title: ;   The Flying Spikes Of Slaughter
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Nina Ann Barrett To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. I. John Barrett of Redding, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nina Ann Barrett to Ellis Carl Booker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin E. Booker of Wyncote, Pa., and New York. An early May wedding is planned.

title: THE GOOD LIFE
description: SUCCESS HAS CERTAINLY not spoiled the Italians when it comes to enjoying the financial fruits of their fashion labors. Last November, for instance, the designer Laura Biagiotti invited 60 guests for dinner. As they arrived at her home, Castello di Marco Simone, just 30 minutes outside of Rome, they were greeted by a sight out of the 15th century, which was when the castle was built. The castle was illuminated solely by candles, 390 of them. At its entrance, the hostess - wearing a white taffeta gown with a brilliant ruby necklace and red slippers - greeted princes and princesses, dukes and duchesses, as well as the guests of honor, William A. Wilson, the United States Ambassador to the Vatican, and his wife, Elizabeth. Inside, everyone was seated at little round tables covered with antique lace tableclothes, while butlers and waiters hovered over them.

title: MUSIC: THE HAGEN QUARTET
description: The most engaging moments of the Hagen Quartet's Wednesday evening concert at the Metropolitan Museum were provided when the violinist Gidon Kremer joined the group for a performance of a Schubert Rondo for violin and string quartet. Mr. Kremer's chaste, even austere, manner made for a distinctly etched contrast with the looser, more effusive playing of the quartet. This daffy, arpeggiated concertino is not one of Schubert's most distinguished efforts, but the performance was direct and sure, and made an agreeable impression.

title: DEFENSE IN SPACE
description: Permit me to list some bothersome points in the Brzezinski-Jastrow-Kampelman case for space defense.

title: 'The Tenth Man'
description: The story behind the book is as curious as if Graham Greene had written it. Evidently, during World War II, he feared impoverishment. ''Brighton Rock'' (1938) had been his big success (8,000 copies sold), but it was followed by ''The Power and the Glory,'' with a first printing (incredible, no?) of a mere 3,500. So Greene turned to Hollywood and did work for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

title: OKLAHOMA REPEATS AS TITLIST BY EDGING IOWA STATE, 73-71
description: Tim McCalister and Anthony Bowie kept Oklahoma together as Wayman Tisdale sat during most of the second half with fouls today, and the Sooners withstood a furious bid by Iowa State for a 73-71 victory in the title game of the Big Eight Conference tournament.

title: PAIRING NATURE AND FANTASY
description: GALLERY NORTH in Setauket, celebrating its 20th anniversary as a showcase for a wide range of artwork and crafts, is now featuring a joint exhibition of paintings by Christian White and mixed collages by Carole Jay.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;

DISNEY REVISITS ''TREASURE ISLAND''
description: Steve Schneider frequently reports on developments in cable.

title:
ANTIQUES;

ACCESSORIES TO BE FEATURED IN GREENWICH
description: THERE will be 54 exhibitors on hand March 22 through 24, to help raise money for scholarships awarded annually by the Greenwich Women's Club. The Greenwich Spring Antiques Show, to be held in the Civic Center, will offer an exhibit of English and American furniture and accessories, plus two lectures on ''Living and Decorating with Antiques.''

title: Economic Rewrite
description: To the Editor:

title: GOLDEN NUGGET ABANDONING PLANS FOR A 2D JERSEY CASINO
description: Plans to build a second casino hotel here have been abandoned by Golden Nugget Inc., which says the New Jersey gambling-casino industry has not grown as company officials had hoped.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption accompanying a photograph in the About Westchester column last Sunday misidentified the man behind the counter at the Hartsdale County Cheesery. He was Larry Alpin, an employee of the food store.

title: A WORLD OF DISCOVERIES ;   OFF THE BEATEN TRACK
description: One of the delights of travel is coming upon a restaurant, a neighborhood, a city - even an entire region - that does not appear on traditional tourist itineraries. Discoveries may range from a hotel cherished by local residents to an out-of-the-way street that sums up the spirit of a nation, to a waterway that reveals the heart of a country. Here, Times correspondents from around the world suggest some unusual attractions.

title: Malpractice No Sign Of Incompetence
description: On Feb. 24, it was reported that the state's Board of Medical Examiners had been unable to use completed insurance reports on malpractice cases ''to identify incompetent doctors.''

title: INTEREST RATES GIVE CONFUSING SIGNALS
description: The outlook for interest rates continues to be clouded, but the trend since the end of January has definitely been up. Treasury yields have been creeping up on both long- and short-term instruments despite the Federal Reserve's insistence that monetary policy has not been tightened. Indeed, the narrowest measure of the money supply, M-1, has been rising, and the latest week's increase of $3.6 billion pushed M-1 almost $9 billion above the Fed's target. And while the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported that mortgage rates dropped in February for the seventh month, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said they began rising in mid-February. Still, some analysts say any increases in rates will not last in the face of a booming economy with controlled inflation.

title: WHEN TELEVISION WATCHES PEOPLE
description: The unblinking eyes of the tiny television cameras peered into every room of the Chicago apartment used by the terrorists. The F.B.I. had secretly broken in and installed the hidden lenses because the agents believed the targets of their surveillance, wise to ways of hidden microphones, might try playing the radio loudly when they spoke or working in silence as they assembled their bombs.

title: CHORUS RAISES MUSIC, EMOTION TO THE CEILING
description: ''REQUIEM aeternam . . . .'' Basses begin singing and tenors join in just before the altos and sopranos in the poignant adagio that opens Mozart's ''Requiem.''

title: ROMANTIC AGONY
description: SCHUMANN: The Inner Voices of a Musical Genius. By Peter Ostwald. Illustrated. 390 pp. Boston: Northeastern University Press. $28. ROBERT SCHUMANN (1810-1856) remains one of the greatest and most popular of the Romantic composers, but scholars seem so far to have taken him for granted. An authoritative modern biography of him has yet to be written in English, and very few books about him at all have come out in recent years. By contrast, his wife, the great pianist Clara Schumann, nee Wieck, has been the subject of two recent well-researched books.

title: ''WEST SIDE STORY'' RETAINS ITS THRILL
description: The Darien Dinner Theater production of ''West Side Story'' cannot be accurately called a revival because, astonishingly, the theater has never mounted the milestone musical. Even so, it does just what a revival should, usefully, do -- approach the work anew, so it can be appraised afresh. For most audiences, ''West Side Story'' is, assumedly, a revival.

title: WAVE OF CURRICULUM CHANGE SWEEPING AMERICAN COLLEGES
description: Students at Barnard College are studying more mathematics, professors at Stanford University are dusting off their Greek and Roman texts and, in Minnesota, Gustavus Adolphus College has thrown out its entire course catalogue and started over.

title:
ANTIQUES;

ANTIQUES SHOW IN GREENWICH
description: THERE will be 54 exhibitors on hand March 22 through 24 to help raise money for scholarships awarded annually by the Greenwich Women's Club, in Connecticut. The Greenwich Spring Antiques Show, to be held in the Civic Center, will offer an exhibit of English and American furniture and accessories, plus two lectures on ''Living and Decorating with Antiques.''

title: HOPES FLY HIGH ON TINY GLIDER
description: IT is not a better mousetrap that

title: WARM MEMORIES, HARSH REALITIES
description: What the Big East tournament offers - in addition to a revenue-sharing plan for the conference teams - is a nostalgic look at the past when big-time college basketball was an important part of the sporting life in New York City. That was brought to mind again this week when the professorial-looking Joe Mullaney of Providence coached his final game during the tournament and talked about the way it was.

title: BELLAMY AND FARRELL VOW TO AID MINORITY BUSINESS
description: Two Democratic mayoral contenders, speaking at a candidates' forum in Harlem, said yesterday that the city had not done enough to support the development of minority businesses and that, if elected, they would do more.

title: CABARET: THE MCCOURTS
description: If a good yarn-spinner is someone who can resuscitate stereotypes with gusto and a sharp eye for detail, Frank and Malachy McCourt, transplanted Irishmen who have turned their autobiographies into an evening of cabaret comedy, certainly qualify. Interweaving stories, songs, and broad character monologues, the brothers, who are appearing at the Top of the Village Gate through next Sunday, tell of growing up poor in the town of Limerick and emigrating to the United States.

title: HOME IS WHERE THE ELDERLY BELONG
description: OWLS with great round eyes and tufted ears stare at you from the walls of Helen Blair's well-kept apartment on South Evergreen Avenue in Woodbury. The birds, her creations, are made from latchwork, a craft using woolens and cottons.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

WESTCHESTER MONIKERS?
description: Quick! How many professional basketball teams in Westchester can you name?

title: SLEEK SETTING FOR ITALIAN CUISINE
description: EVER so gradually, Italian restaurants are becoming trendy, and as new places open they begin to look more like Palazzo in Massapequa Park than those cliches decorated with flocked red wallpaper and paintings of gondolas.

title: Angelica Elsebet Braestrup Is Married
description: Angelica Elsebet Braestrup, a daughter of Peter Braestrup of Washington and Angelica Hollins Braestrup of Sabillasville, Md., was married yesterday to Briggs Swift Cunningham 4th, a son of Briggs Cunningham 3d and Mrs. Townsend W. Hoopes of Washington. The Rev. William Tully performed the ceremony at St. Columba's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: A WORLD OF DISCOVERIES ;   OFF THE BEATEN TRACK
description: One of the delights of travel is coming upon a restaurant, a neighborhood, a city - even an entire region - that does not appear on traditional tourist itineraries. Discoveries may range from a hotel cherished by local residents to an out-of-the-way street that sums up the spirit of a nation, to a waterway that reveals the heart of a country. Here, Times correspondents from around the world suggest some unusual attractions.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bernardsville $525,000 *2* Young Road, 5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 30-year-old *2* colonial; pool, 2-stall barn, fireplace in solarium, *2* 5x acres; taxes $4,837. Fanwood $135,000 *2* 85 Kempshall Terrace, 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2* 17-year-old colonial; marble floor in foyer, *2* fireplace, cul-de-sac; taxes $2,791. Branford, Conn. $77,000 *2* 18 Barton Court, 3-bedroom, 1-bath, *2* 15-year-old ranch; cul-de-sac, aluminum siding; *2* taxes $895.

title: More PressureOn New Zealand
description: The President was diplomatic, befitting the occasion. ''We continue to regard the people of New Zealand as our friends,'' Mr. Reagan told that nation's new Ambassador to Washington, Sir Wallace Rowling, when he presented his credentials at the White House last week.

title: CONSERVATIVE RABBIS CONVENE IN MIAMI BEACH
description: Conservative rabbis from around the world will gather today in Miami Beach for their first convention since agreeing to admit women to their ranks. The issue of women as Conservative rabbis, although decided in a mail ballot last month, is expected to dominate the three-day meeting.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Seven ski racers, including

title: MOVING A SANCTUM
description: In 1926, when Fred F. French erected the distinctive Art Deco office building on Fifth Avenue and 45th Street that still bears his name, he designed for himself an elaborate suite of offices. They were decorated with carved oak paneling, brass ceiling fixtures, stained-glass windows from the castles and chapels of Switzerland and Germany, European antiques and Persian carpets woven especially for the rooms.

title: RESERVES MOVE TO THE FOREFRONT OF DEFENSE
description: Nearly 15 years ago, when James H. Webb Jr. was commanding a Marine Corps rifle company in Vietnam, he and his men regarded the National Guard and reserve armories back home as cozy havens where draft dodgers played cards and grew beer bellies.

title: Dorinda Elliott Is Engaged
description: Osborn Elliott and Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Dorinda Elliott to Alan Paul Ignatius, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Ignatius of Washington. A May wedding is planned.

title: JAZZ: THE SEBESKY BAND
description: Don Sebesky's 12-piece jazz band, which made a very impressive New York debut last June at Fat Tuesday's, is even better in its current return engagement, which runs through tonight at the club, Third Avenue at 17th Street.

title: LARCHMONT LAWYER IS CITED FOR EFFORT AGAINST CORRUPTION
description: LARCHMONT IN 25 years as a prosecutor and investigator, Joseph

title: BRONX FOOD BANK LINKS DONORS AND THE HUNGRY
description: Arnold Greenberg's problem was the 300 cases of apple, pineapple and cranberry juices that sat in his Queens warehouse gathering dust, the cans dented but the juice drinkable.

title: JERSEY OUTLINES !)-YEAR PLAN TO CUT HIGH COST OF ENERGY
description: The State Energy Commissioner has issued a 10- year master plan designed to hold the line on future energy costs by expanding conservation and recycling efforts and by developing cogeneration systems.

title: EASTON STARTS PROGRAM TO SAVE FARMS
description: EASTON has become the first town in Connecticut to establish a municipal farmlands- preservation program with an ordinance intended to help stem the growing residential development of the town's agricultural land.

title: Christian Speer Coan Marries Lise D. Mauer
description: Lise Denise Mauer, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Michael Joseph Mauer of Red Bank, N.J., was married yesterday to Christian Speer Coan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Frederick Gaylord Coan of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Stark Jones performed the ceremony at the Roslyn (L.I.) Presbyterian Church.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN CLIFTON
description: A dozen miles west of midtown

title: ASSEMBLY G.O.P. THWARTS GOVERNOR
description: HARTFORD GOVERNOR O'NEILL and the Republican majorities in the General Assembly, already at odds over some legislative issues, have found something new to squabble over - appointments to state posts, including boards and commissions.

title: DIGITAL TV-CLEAR OUTLINES, SHARP DETAIL, TRUE COLOR
description: ''Digital'' has become a trendy buzz- word, redolent of the computer - the icon of our age. Calling anything digital implies praise and precision, even though the meaning of the term is rarely understood. Now that digital television is upon us, it may be well to recap its principles and their impact.

title: Melissa Matteo Plans Marriage
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Richard S. Matteo of Teaneck, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Melissa Ann Matteo, to Arnold Cale Johnson Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson of Chevy Chase, Md. A September wedding is planned.

title: Software
description: To the Editor:

title: Jack Kemp's Year of Decision
description: Steven V. Roberts's article, ''Jack Kemp's Year of Decision'' (Feb. 3), makes some interesting observations.

title:
GARDENING;

APPLES THAT ARE DISEASE-RESISTANT
description: APPLES are the most popular of all fruits in this country. This year's crop, one of the largest, is estimated to have exceeded 196 million boxes, which contained about one bushel each. This estimate does not include those grown in backyards and home orchards.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The problem of the hungry in the city is not going to go away.'' - Pamela Green, executive director of the Food for Survival Foodbank. (34:5.)

title: TOPICS
description: MOVE over, Messrs. Harris and Gallup. An accurate barometer of American public opinion is at hand. Me.

title: THERE WAS A HOLE, THEN IT WAS GONE
description: THERE was a hole in Thornwood that kept getting bigger and bigger for more than a century, until it got so big a 20-story building could easily have been put inside.

title: COLLEGE DECIDES TO ADMIT MEN
description: ''TODAY'S Albertus for Today's Woman,'' reads the cover of the current catalog of Albertus Magnus, a 60-year-old college in New Haven. The cover needs revising.

title: Judge to Get Appellate Post
description: Federal District Judge Carol Los Mansmann of the Western District of Pennsylvania will be nominated by President Reagan to the United State Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, the White House announced Thursday. The Third Circuit, based in Philadelphia, handles appeals cases from Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware and the Virgin Islands. Judge Mansmann, 42 years old, earned a law degree at Duquesne University and was assistant solicitor of Allegheny County before being appointed to the Federal bench.

title: AN ENGLISH 'BORIS' AT THE STATE OPERA
description: NEWARK TWO and a half years ago, Alfredo Silipigni, conductor and general director of the New Jersey State Opera, decided to stage Mussorgsky's ''Boris Godunov,'' one of the most challenging works in the operatic repertory.

title: ST. ANTON: TOWN OF SKIERS
description: Snowmaking has arrived in St. Anton, there's a new lift up top for experts, but the basic elements that make this village such a satisfying place to ski - its size, its people, its magnificent terrain, its ski school - remain intact.

title: MUSIC
description: One of this country's most remarkable performing groups will be playing twice in Manhattan this week. The Kronos Quartet has made a burgeoning career for itself, with international and national tours and several forthcoming recordings, by defying all the conventional music-business wisdoms.

title: CITY RAISES THE STAKES WITH BID TO SAVE INDIAN MUSEUM
description: When the Museum of the American Indian agreed to consider a $70 million offer last month from H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer entrepreneur, to move from New York to Dallas, it sounded to some like a rescue, to others like a raid. Last week, New York City jumped in to renew an offer it had made to help the troubled institution on the upper edge of Harlem, and it promised that the museum has far more to gain here than in Texas.

title: Eastern's Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: KILLINGS IN MEXICO BRING U.S. ANGER INTO THE OPEN
description: The battle against illegal drugs, which has long been one of the areas of greatest cooperation between the United States and Mexico, has recently become one of the points of greatest tension. The battered bodies of a United States drug enforcement agent, Enrique Camarena Salazar, and a Mexican pilot who sometimes worked with him were found in plastic bags on a Mexican ranch last week, a month after the men had been kidnapped. Powerful Mexican drug traffickers are suspected of being responsible.

title:
CAMERA;

HOW TO CHOOSE THE BEST LENS FOR THE PICTURE
description: Bob Nadler is a freelance writer and photographer.

title: Natalie Heerdt Weds F.G. Fitz-Gerald
description: Natalie Sonntag Heerdt, a daughter of Fritz A. Sonntag of Johannesburg and the late Golda Sonntag, was married yesterday at Calvary Episcopal Church in New York to F. Gregory Fitz-Gerald, executive vice president and treasurer of the American Express Company. The Rev. Thomas F. Pike, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Bert Aaron Siegel officiated.

title: A SMALL, BUT ELITE, 'MOST WANTED' LIST
description: WILLIAM R. MURRAY, L'eggs promotion director, says he gets at least one call a week from companies interested in a joint promotion. Michael Gunn, director of promotion for American Airlines, says he gets ''hit every day.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture credit in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday, with a photo grouping on page 32, was incorrectly positioned. The picture of Leonard Woolf, not Virginia Woolf, should have been credited to Gis ele Freund.

title: THE SORROW OF SAYING GOODBYE TO OUR HOUSE
description: THERE is a statistic for it. I have forgotten it now, but there is no need to be scrupulous about it. Americans move a lot. We also breed and die according to statistical tables, but we are all given our own lives, to color in the details.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE COURAGE TO CHANGE. Hope and Help for Alcoholics and Their Families. By Dennis Wholey. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.)

title: ST. CATHY OF CHICAGO
description: VIRGIN AND MARTYR

title: BOTH SIDES IN GULF WAR AGAIN RAID CIVILIAN AREAS
description: Iran and Iraq continued the bombardment of civilian targets for a fifth day today, and the Iraqis were reported to be bracing for an Iranian ground offensive.

title: Connecticut Physician Held in Wife's Murder
description: A doctor was charged today with first-degree murder in the death of his wife, whose body was found early Friday in a car that had crashed into a utility pole here, the police said.

title: Miss Cushing Of Sotheby's Is to Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Robert M. Cushing of New York and Quogue, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Murray Cushing, to John Douglas Block, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Block of Princeton, N.J. The wedding is planned for June.

title: CONCERT: CENTER FOR AMERICAN MUSIC
description: Americans suffer from a perplexing cultural insecurity. For too many people, classical music still means

title: BEETHOVEN QUARTETS EVOKE MUSICAL PERSONALITIES
description: Andrew L. Pincus writes extensively about music.

title: A HAIRY RELATIONSHIP
description: With disrespect to Russell Baker's ''A Hairy Relationship,'' I would like to emphasize that God made only a limited number of perfect heads. The rest He covered with hair. Bald is beautiful! JOSEPH J. NEUSCHATZ, M.D.

title: THERE'S NO AVOIDING MUSIC VIDEOS
description: On television, there is ''Miami Vice,'' a police show set to rock music, filmed in pastel colors and from odd, sometimes jarring angles. In commercials, eye- popping images reverberating to a thumping beat sell Ford automobiles, Safeguard soap and Perugina chocolates; a teen-ager bops around a kitchen preparing Campbell's chunky soup to the tune of Sam and Dave's ''Soul Man,'' and Lionel Richie croons for Pepsi-Cola. In movie theaters, ''Flashdance'' and ''Footloose'' have spawned ''Purple Rain,'' ''Heavenly Bodies'' and even ''Cotton Club.'' In fashion, the calculated disarray of rock performers has become the look of the 80's. And on stage, snippets of the music and dancing of a musical scheduled to open tomorrow on Broadway, ''Leader of the Pack,'' have already been encapsulated on 3-minutes-and-20-seconds of video tape for mass television viewing.

title: Defense In Space
description: At last, a clear and comprehensible explanation for nuclear-attack deterrents, an issue, up to now, posed primarily in emotional and oversimplified critical terms (''Defense in Space Is Not 'Star Wars,' '' by Zbigniew Brzezinski, Robert Jastrow and Max M. Kampelman, Jan. 27). The authors make hard sense of what President Reagan has been talking about. WILLIAM BALLIN

title: OBSESSED WITH THE HERMIT OF CROISSET
description: FLAUBERT'S PARROT. By Julian Barnes. 190 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95. GUSTAVE FLAUBERT has been the subject of a nearly obsessive number of biographies and critical studies, including Jean-Paul Sartre's outsized recreation of the writer's psychic life in ''The Family Idiot.'' Now Julian Barnes, a British novelist and journalist, has succumbed to the temptation to make Flaubert the central figure in a novel. The temptation in fact seems hard to resist, since the austere image of Flaubert - the hermit of Croisset who sacrificed living to his unending quest for style, the father of modernism who wished most of all to write ''a book about nothing'' - is so belied by what we know of the man and his rich inner life.

title: GETTING A SOLID GRIP ON ENGLISH
description: year-old student from Africa, stepped off a bus at the White Plains Hotel a little more than a year ago, he could barely speak or read English. ''I found someone to call Manhattanville,'' Mr. Abeidna said, recalling the day, ''and they sent somebody to pick me up. I was waiting in the hallway of the hotel, but I didn't know who to look for. I only found out because he was smiling.''

title:
PERSONAL FINANCE;

I.R.A.'S- WHERE TO PUT THE MONEY
description: WHEN the Tax Act of 1981 made Individual Retirement Accounts available to all workers, an I.R.A. seemed like an agreeable tax break, but hardly a significant investment. Now workers who dutifully (and wisely) put aside annual contributions are finding that their accounts are bulging with serious money. As some I.R.A.'s approach the $10,000 mark, owners increasingly see their accounts as investments to be managed, not as savings accounts to be left unattended.

title: Children's Books
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDY FINDS TEACHER SATISIFACTION LAGS IN CITY
description: Public school teachers in New York City are less satisfied with their jobs and more critical of their schools than are teachers in the rest of the state and throughout the country, according to a survey by Louis Harris and Associates.

title: STATES SEEK RIGHT TO TAX MAIL-ORDER GOODS
description: State tax officials, seeking a potential new source of revenue, urged the Federal Government Friday to let states collect sales taxes on consumer mail-order purchases of goods from outside the state.

title: NICE'S FLOWER MARKET ABLOOM
description: Because the residents of Nice are passionately fond of flowers, the city's flower market is visited daily by what appear to be as many residents as visitors. Even in the most modest Nice hotel entrances visitors will find elaborate floral arrangements that are changed every day or so; flowers are used matter-of-factly as an integral part of the decor in restaurants and shops as well as in many homes. ''I can't remember when I didn't have fresh flowers in my apartment,'' a woman who has lived in Nice for 10 years said. ''They have become a part of my life.''

title: FUGITIVE TIED TO ACCOSTING OF GIRL
description: The state police said yesterday that Alex J. Mengel, the man suspected of killing a Westchester County police officer last month, may have tried to kidnap a 13-year-old girl near Syracuse three days after the killing.

title: 90 SCIENTISTS AND ECONOMISTS WIN SLOAN RESEARCH AWARDS
description: Ninety scientists and economists have been selected to receive $25,000 research awards from the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation of New York.

title: CONGRESS GIVES AUDITORS AN ACCOUNT OF THEIR SHORTCOMINGS
description: For more than half a century, auditors have been the public's watchdogs, examining corporation books to protect investors and creditors. But the watchdogs last week found themselves under critical scrutiny on Capitol Hill. Such major accounting firms as Arthur Andersen, Peat Marwick and Ernst & Whinney came under attack from members of a House panel for failing to warn of a series of financial catastrophes in the last few years that left hundreds of thousands of investors and creditors with hundreds of millions of dollars in losses.

title:
THE SHIPPER;

FOUR VOICES ON CONRAIL'S FUTURE
description: THE Staggers Rail Act of 1980 became law with the overwhelming support of the railroad industry and the industrial shipping community. Its underlying philosophy is that competition regulates more effectively than the directives of an administrative agency. The U.S. Steel Corporation, as a substantial user of rail transportation, concurred in this philosophy and actively supported passage of the Staggers Act.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER/JUST KIDS
description: GREENBURGH IT looked like a scene from a

title: 29 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The City Department of Health last week released a list of 29 food establishments cited for violations of the health code. In addition, it listed 3 that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, 2 that were closed for having failed to do so, and 1, previously cited but not closed, that corrected violations.

title: No Headline
description: Conviction Reversed; Jury Exclusions Cited

title: PAPER MILL: 'INHERIT THE WIND'
description: MILLBURN IN THEIR program notes written

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THERE are people who like to look at themselves in the mirror, and there are those who don't. I do not exclude men from this categorical categorization. I saw too many young fellows preening their ''D.A.'' haircuts before plate-glass windows or rear-view mirrors. (Remember the sinuous, sensuous, stylized swoop of arms and hands as they smoothed back the wings over their ears? Oh, you don't. You must not have been a girl in the late 1950's.)

title: A SECOND HOME: SURPRISES
description: A COUPLE of years ago, I bought a condominium in a development called Driftwood Harbor, right smack on Manhasset Bay. Actually, I didn't buy a condominium; what I bought was a town house, to listen to the builder. So I bought this town house at Driftwood Harbor, all marble and glass, window walls and floating stairs, a five- mile view from every room and infinity from the bathroom skylights - a reward for a lifetime in the salt mines, a retirement retreat for my declining years, even though I have a while to go before retiring.

title: INDUSTRIAL DESIGN COMES OF AGE
description: DONALD GENARO was struggling to come up with a new surgeon's scalpel. He was rummaging in his mind for a way to make the handle less slippery - to give it, as he would say, ''good purchase.'' As he doodled on paper, his thoughts drifted off and finally fastened on the steps of a tractor that a co-worker had designed. The steps sported tiny metal protrusions for the farmer to wipe his boots on. Good enough. And so the handle of the Bard-Parker scalpel sports a nest of circular bumps and a more trustworthy grip than surgeons had been accustomed to.

title: CUPS OF FELLOWSHIP
description: THERE ARE TIMES IN MY TRAVELS when I happen across a dish - usually one with which I am almost totally unfamiliar - that generates downright ecstasy. This happened not long ago when I visited Los Angeles to judge a cooking contest, sponsored by the March of Dimes, with a clutch of celebrities gathered around the cookstoves. Among them were Geoffrey Holder, the multitalented actor, director, et al., and his wife, Carmen de Lavallade; Cesar Romero and Constance Towers, the actor and actress; Rudi Gernreich, the designer; Gary Collins, the television personality, and his wife, Mary Ann Mobley, the former Miss America.

THE LABOR LEADER;

title: UNLIMITED ENGAGEMENT?
description: London's winter weather may or may not be particularly inviting, but its artisitc and potical climate seems to appeal to Andrei Gavrilov, one of the Soviet Union's top young pianists. Mr. Gavrilov, 29, has been in London since mid-February to make a recording of Chopin compositions. Last week, the Home Office said he had applied for an extension of his British visa. The pianist and his wife, Natalya (the daughter of the chairman of the Soviet's State Bank), have not applied for asylum, but the decision to lengthen a visit to a Western country has been used before as a preliminary step by artistic defectors. Mr. Gavrilov, a winner of the prestigious Tchaikovsky piano competition in Moscow in 1974, gave two concerts in London last year that were received enthusiastically by audiences, but met with mixed reviews from the critics.

title: WINNING MUNICIPAL SERVICES
description: Many buyers of suburban condominiums discover soon after they move in that unlike the owners of single- family houses nearby, they are not getting such municipal services as garbage collection, snow removal, street lighting and road maintenance.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: IN the latest bit of political gamesmanship between Republican and Democratic legislators, a new sign appeared Wednesday at the

title: TEEN-AGERS ADVISE STORE ON FASHION
description: JILL ANDREWS, a senior at Montville High School, is a teen-age fashion consultant to Filene's, the Boston-based department store chain, in a new program being tried in Connecticut.

title: TOO MANY CHIEFS, TOO FEW SKILLS
description: THE PENTAGON AND THE ART OF WAR: The Question of Military Reform. By Edward N. Luttwak. Illustrated. 333 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95. ONE would not want Mr. Luttwak for an enemy. Not only does he have voluminous sources and overwhelming arguments, he also has a cutting wit. The Joint Chiefs of Staff are ''that most unmilitary organization''; senior officers, after a ''career-long lack of responsibility'' are ''unfit to exercise command when war and all its risks must suddenly be confronted''; the defense establishment, the Executive and the Congress, is engaged in an ''amiable conspiracy'' that ignores the failures of the past and turns a blind eye to the disasters of the future.

Discoveries may range from a hotel cherished by local residents to an out-of-the-way street that sums up the spirit of a nation, to a waterway that reveals the heart of a country. title: Measles Keeps Students From Spring Vacation
description: While thousands of college students around the country are on spring vacation, as many as 200 students at Principia College will remain on campus bcause of a measles outbreak.

title: DEMOCRATS GETTING THEIR ACT TOGETHER
description: ATLANTIC CITY NEW JERSEY Democrats met here for three days last week at a conference that drew criticism before it started but got generally good marks after it ended.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MADDY'S SONG. By Margaret Dickson. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.)

title: BACH FESTIVALS REACH A PEAK
description: SINCE concert observances of Bach's 300th birthday began at least a year ago, one might be forgiven for saying ''enough already.'' On the other hand, for those who have not yet reached the saturation point, the last of the season's Candlelight Concerts at the Wilton Library presents a recital by Thomas Stacy, the English horn soloist of the New York Philharmonic, and the harpsichordist Kenneth Cooper. There will be music of Handel, Telemann and other masters, but right up front, Bach's Sonata in E flat (762-8028).

title: STRATFORD THEATER HOPES FOR REVIVAL
description: ALTHOUGH the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford appears abandoned and dark most of the time, both the state and the theater's management hope visitors to the grounds will help bring the new state park to life.

title: Bullish onNew York
description: The economic forecast for New York City is mostly sunny, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said last week. In a report prepared for the State Financial Control Board, which has overseen the city's finances since the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, Mr. Regan said that New York's economy is stronger now than at any other time in the past 25 years, and that steady growth is likely to continue.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: AMELIA BEDELIA GOES CAMPING By Peggy Parish. Illustrated by Lynn Sweat. 55 pp. New York: Greenwillow Books. $8.75. (Ages 5 to 8)

title: Two MarcosAides Are Out
description: There were two new openings in the Cabinet of Philippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos last week. One minister was pushed; the other jumped.

title: Nuggets 126, Pacers 116
description: Lafayette Lever scored 13 points, handed out 15 assists and broke a club record with 10 steals to give the Nuggets their 16th straight victory at home.

title: AVOIDING WHAT HAPPENED TO T.W.A.
description: PUTTING together a joint promotion can be arduous. It can mean month-long negotiations, ambiguity, second-guessing and some hard-nosed bargaining as each company tries to get the maximum exposure for its product for the minimum cost. And, since the benefit that each company will derive from the promotion is a matter of guesswork, settling on an equitable division of costs can be ''as complicated as negotiating a futures commodities contract,'' said Joseph Smyth, senior vice president of marketing at Intercontinental Hotels.

title: THE MAN ROBERT FROST CALLED 'THE BEST NEGLECTED POET'
description: WHEN Robert Francis, newly out of graduate school at Harvard University, moved to Amherst, Mass., in 1926 to pursue a high school teaching career, the home of Amherst College and Emily Dickinson had less than 6,000 inhabitants and was still small enough to be considered intimate. Today, with the State Agricultural College turned into a towering University of Massachusetts for more than 23,000 students, the place named for Lord Jeffrey Amherst has become a city.

title: Dr. Weiden WedTo Dr. D. M. Lans
description: Dr. Jacqueline P. Weiden, a postdoctoral fellow in clinical psychology at the New York University Medical Center, was married yesterday to Dr. David M. Lans, the chief resident in the department of medicine at the Kings County Hospital Center of the State University of New York in Brooklyn. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony in his study at Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan.

title: Rodino Leaves Walter Reed
description: Representative Peter W. Rodino, Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, left Walter Reed Army Hospital today after five days of tests. Mr. Rodino, the 75-year- old chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, entered the hospital Monday because of chest pains. Peter Esker, a spokesman for the hospital, said it would have no comment on his condition. But Deborah Stashower, one of Mr. Rodino's aides, said he was feeling ''very well.''

title: TWO ARTISTS IN A CLASSICAL CROSSOVER
description: TWO performers best known for their popular recordings will step into the classical music world next Sunday when they appear with the Philharmonia Virtuosi at the State University of New York campus at Purchase.

title: FOCUS PUT ON FINDING SITE FOR TOXIC ASH
description: Faced with a 1990 deadline, state and Long Island officials have started the process of selecting a site to bury toxic ash from garbage incinerators yet to be built.

title: RAISING BOYS: A MOTHER'S DILEMMA
description: Louise Lague, a Connecticut-based writer, is the mother of two sons.

description: Leaders of Nicaragua's principal opposition coalition said today that they had been summoned to state security headquarters here and warned to cut all ties with the opposition leader Arturo Jose Cruz.

title: CONGRESS TO RESUME FIGHT ON AID TO FARMERS
description: President Reagan's veto of the emergency farm credit bill Wednesday ended only the first skirmish in a political battle over farm policy that is expected to continue with few pauses until late fall.

title: Dr. Bonnie Blatt and Dr. David Goldmann to Wed
description: The engagement of Dr. Bonnie Joan Blatt to Dr. David Robert Goldmann has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Earl L. Blatt of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Goldmann of Maplewood, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: GIANT STRIDES BY LOUISIANA TECH
description: Twice a week, Karl Malone takes the interstate from Louisiana Tech and travels 15 miles toward Summerfield, then pulls over to the side of the road.

title:
GARDENING;

APPLES THAT ARE DISEASE-RESISTANT
description: APPLES are the most popular of all fruits in this country. This year's crop, one of the largest, is estimated to have exceeded 196 million boxes, which contained about one bushel each. This estimate does not include those grown in backyards and home orchards.

title: GRANDMOTHER'S LIFE, AS TOLD BY A POET
description: FOR Honor Moore, what began as a little girl's wide-eyed fascination with a glamorous grandmother has matured into a careful study of a painter's troubled life.

title: HOUSING STUDY FINDS SHIFT TO OWNERSHIP
description: Narrowly defined, the purpose of the housing survey done by an independent scholar for the city every three years is to find out whether the rental vacancy rate is low enough to justify a renewal of rent regulations. In fact, it amounts to a full-length portrait of economic and social change in a dynamic city, supported by excruciatingly detailed statistical data.

title: Case of Mother, 11
description: Soon after giving birth to a son in 1982, an 11-year-old Manhattan girl, with the consent of her grandmother, agreed to surrender her rights to the baby. But last summer, after a Bronx couple had petitioned the Surrogate's Court for permission to adopt the baby, the court blocked the move.

title: Warriors 118, Suns 115
description: Purvis Short scored 12 of his 44 points in the fourth period as the Golden State Warriors won only their fourth road game this season.

title: Gillian LindHas Nuptials
description: Gillian Margaret Lind, the daughter of Mrs. Robert S. Lind of Dunfermline, Fife, Scotland, and the late Dr. Lind, was married in Edinburgh yesterday to Douglas Martin Eisenhart, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Eisenhart of Rochester. The Rev. Frank T. Smith performed the Church of Scotland ceremony at the Cramond Kirk.

title: HOT UNDER THE COLLAR
description: Does Representative Robert Dornan, Republican of California, possess a quick temper or is he just a stickler for sartorial detail? Mr. Dornan, one of the more conservative members of Congress, got into a heated discussion on the House floor last week with an old adversary, Representative Thomas J. Downey, a liberal Democrat from Long Island. Mr. Downey asked Mr. Dornan if he had called him a ''draft-dodging wimp'' for opposing American aid to anti-Sandinista rebels in Nicaragua. Mr. Dornan said he certainly had, and repeated the phrase. Mr. Downey claimed the Californian the grabbed him by the collar and tie and threatened him with ''bodily harm,'' but Mr. Dornan contended that he held Mr. Downey's tie only because it ''needed to be straightened.''

title: A WORLD OF DISCOVERIES ;   OFF THE BEATEN TRACK
description: One of the delights of travel is coming upon a restaurant, a neighborhood, a city - even an entire region - that does not appear on traditional tourist itineraries. Discoveries may range from a hotel cherished by local residents to an out-of-the-way street that sums up the spirit of a nation, to a waterway that reveals the heart of a country. Here, Times correspondents from around the world suggest some unusual attractions.

title: Low Marks forDr. GrossAnd His Office
description: City and state health officials delivered a second opinion last week on the management of the New York City Medical Examiner's office. In separate reports, the officials cited serious administrative shortcomings; the state report said that the office had failed to fulfill ''its basic public-service mission'' and that management problems cast doubt on its ability ''to contribute credibly and effectively to the criminal justice system.''

title: GREEK TOWN ON WRONG SIDE OF CYPRUS DEBATE
description: Seven Greek Cypriot men sat on the porch of the coffeehouse in this once Greek town near the tip of the country's northeastern panhandle.

title: Death Toll Climbs In Indian City Clashes
description: Six people have been killed in the south Indian city of Hyderabad in violence set off by voting disputes.

title: F.B.I. INVESTIGATING POSSIBLE CRIME TIES TO PROJECTS IN JERSEY
description: Federal officials in New Jersey are investigating possible financial ties between major organized-crime figures and high-rise and town-house projects along the waterfront in Edgewater, according to court records and an F.B.I. official.

title: Archbishop Pleads Not Guilty To Charge of Drunken Driving
description: Archbishop John Roach, past president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, pleaded not guilty Friday to a charge of drunken driving, the authorities said. Archbishop Roach, scheduled for arraignment on next Tuesday, entered the plea by mail, said James P. Reuter, acting Chisago County Attorney.

title: THE STAGE: 'SHALOM,' A MUSICAL FROM ISRAEL
description: Shalom 85,'' the Israeli musical extravaganza now in town, has more music than a bar mitzvah and a bigger wardrobe than you might find in the garment district. From the moment it starts, the band keeps playing, the dancers keep dancing and nobody wastes much time in talking. Language is not a problem here.

title: THE BEST DEFENSE
description: As in most other fields of activity, the technological revolution is, bit by bit, making an impact upon the world of tournament bridge. For two decades we have had computer-dealt hands, thanks to the initiative of Martin Scheinberg; and also some - probably not enough - computerization of work at the headquarters office of the American Contract Bridge League in Memphis, Tenn.

description: Things of the Past For the Present

title: LISTENING TO ANCESTRAL VOICES
description: UNLESS SOUL CLAPS ITS HANDS: Portraits and Passages. By Erika Duncan. Illustrated. 208 pp. New York: Schocken Books. $17.95. STANLEY KUNITZ must have misheard or misunderstood the question - or been so startled by it that he could only grasp the nearest defense against the hazards of the literary life. The occasion was the ceremonial presentation to Olga Broumas, the ''younger'' poet who had just been selected by Mr, Kunitz for the Yale Younger Poets prize. His interrogator was Erika Duncan, the author of this collection of ''portraits and passages.'' Mrs. Duncan, a novelist who teaches creative writing at New York University, had asked him if he felt threatened about conferring the award on one with a ''lesbian separatist'' position. Mr. Kunitz replied, ''If you stop being vulnerable, you die.''

title: AMONG GERMAN BALLETS, THE HAMBURG IS CENTER STAGE
description: Otis Stuart was an editor of ''ballett international'' in Cologne in 1983 and 1984.

title: Debbie Fishbein Weds R. P. Schiller, Lawyer
description: Debbie Ellen Fishbein, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Fishbein of Penn Valley, Pa., was married yesterday to Ronald Paltin Schiller, a son of Richard Allgood Schiller and Joan Dubrow, both of Philadelphia. Rabbi Max Hausen performed the ceremony at the Bellevue Stratford Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Miss Szymanski Engaged to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Bruna R. Berti of Rosemont, Ill., and Leonard W. Szymanski of Niles, Ill., of the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Olivia Szymanski, to Thomas H. K. Brooks, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Brooks of New York and Greenwich, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: IN CHIC RESORT, RACES FOR THE WORLD CUP RAISE A SMALL-TOWN CIVIC SPIRIT
description: These are the chic days of this elite ski resort in the Rockies, when the sun is warm, the snow is deep and the mood is such to entice the sleek to the slopes in bikinis. But Aspen's customary sparkle was all the more aglitter these last several days as it became the stage for a leg of the World Cup, a series of downhill and slalom races conducted around the world each winter with the finest skiers in the world. The race, which began this morning at 10 o'clock and is scheduled to close Sunday, includes such skiers as Franz Klammer of Austria, Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland and Billy Johnson, who won an Olympic Gold Medal for the United States last year.

title: MASTERS OF THE PIANO DISPLAY THEIR ARTISTRY
description: Egon Petri (1881-1962) was a well- known Dutch pianist, a Busoni pupil who settled in the United States in the 1930's and had a long and productive international career. But he never really made the public impact that was his right. The short, baldheaded, serious Egon Petri was not exactly a glamorous type, and throughout his life he was looked upon by many concertgoers merely as another one of those good pianists who made his annual recital tours.

title: ESCAPIST ENTERTAINMENT HAS ITS OWN REWARDS
description: While watching the two-hour pilot and first hour-long weekly episode of ''Moonlighting,'' the new ''romantic comedy'' series on ABC Tuesdays evenings at 10, I found myself getting almost mushy about the rewards, however transient, of purely escapist entertainment. ''Moonlighting'' stars Cybill Shepherd and David Willis as a pair of unlikely investigators working together in preposterous circumstances on cases that are never terribly convincing. For not-so-coincidental lookalikes, television historians need go back in the schedule files no further than such currently established series as ''Remington Steele'' or ''Scarecrow and Mrs. Smith.'' The genre is evidently here to stay. Only the faces and gimmicks change.

FASHION PREVIEW;

MILAN'S MOMENT

title: FRANKS WINS THE 400 IN 46.27
description: Michael Franks surprisingly failed to make the United States Olympic team last year, so as far as he was concerned he won his Olympic medal today. Actually, his victory came as the National Collegiate Athletic Association's indoor track and field championships ended, but any time Franks beats an Olympic 400-meter medalist he considers it special.

title: CUOMO PROPOSES CURBS ON RATE INCREASES FOR NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: Governor Cuomo has proposed three measures intended to protect New Yorkers from large increases in utility rates stemming from costly nuclear power plant projects.

title: AN OFFICE BOOM TRANSFORMS ONCE-AILING CONNECTICUT CITY
description: As a result of a steady migration of corporate offices that began 15 years ago, this suburban city 43 miles northeast of Manhattan has become the center of one of the nation's largest concentrations of major corporate headquarters.

title: CONCERT: NEW YORK CHORAL SOCIETY AT CARNEGIE
description: The Faure Requiem is about as seraphic, angelic a piece of music as anyone has ever written. Sections like the ''Pie Jesu'' and the final ''In Paradisum'' seem to float free from earthly cares, rapturously rocking in clestial bliss. The whole score, in a good performance, can sustain a mood of rapt wonderment.

title: Shift at Conservative Group
description: Robert Dolan of New York City has resigned as chairman of Young Americans for Freedom, one of the nation's largest conservative groups, a spokesman for the organization said today. Terrel Cannon of Lincoln, Neb., has been elected as the new chairman. The organization is based in Sterling, Va. Mr. Dolan appeared on stage with President Reagan at last week's Conservative Political Action Conference.

title: BUSH TO ANNOUNCE PLAN TO AID 'FREE MARKET' FARMING IN MALI
description: Vice President Bush is to announce here Sunday that this country will be the first selected by the Administration for financing under an experimental program designed to encourage ''free market'' agricultural practices, Administration officials said today.

title: IT'S LIKE OLD TIMES IN LOUISIANA POLITICS

REMEMBERING BRECHT: DIRECTOR, TEACHER, DEMAGOGUE

THE WORLD;

Congress WeighsAtrocity ChargesIn Nicaragua
description: Accusations of atrocities involving Nicaraguan rebels may make it that much harder for President Reagan to persuade Congress that the insurgents deserve aid. Americas Watch, a private organization that is sometimes consulted by the State Department, said last week that rebels had kidnapped, tortured, raped, mutilated and murdered numerous unarmed civilians. Checking on similar charges, a New York Times reporter interviewed a witness who said he had heard the screams of civilians being burned to death and a woman who said she had been raped by 50 guerrillas of the Nicaraguan Democratic Force.

title: PLAYING THE GAME
description: PERIODICALLY SOMEbody says, ''Keep up the good fight because one man can make a difference.'' I have given this in explanation to the Internal Revenue agent who has for months been insisting that paying 49 percent of one's earnings in income taxes, as I have done, is not good enough. Why do I keep resisting him, he asks, when by coughing up another 3 percent or 4 percent, plus interest and penalties, he can make the pain stop?

title: A GOOD DEED, BUT A DISSERVICE TO GERSHWIN
description: Now that the hip-hooray and ballyhoo over the arrival of ''Porgy and Bess'' at the Metropolitan Opera have died down, a few general observations may be permitted about the Gershwin work as it appears in its Lincoln Center context. First, let us try to dispose of the tiresome old argument about whether ''Porgy'' is an opera, a debate that dates from the premiere 50 years ago and makes sense only if the word opera is defined so rigidly that it loses all meaning historically. Opera can and does embrace everything from Poulenc's one-woman show, ''La Voix Humaine,'' to ''Aida'' with live elephants, from masque to staged oratorio. ''Porgy'' is at least as legitimately an opera as ''Mahagonny'' or ''Street Scene,'' Kurt Weill works that have enjoyed the attention of our largest opera companies.

PROPOSED ARTS FETE DEBATED
description: THEODORA BOOKMAN, executive director of Friends of the Arts, calls herself ''an optimist who's a realist, too.'' The two traits coalesce tonight when Zubin Mehta and the Israel Philharmonic perform at the C. W. Post Center's Bush-Brown Concert Theater in Brookville. The concert is the centerpiece of an elaborate fund-raiser that inaugurates a drive to establish a permanent summer festival of the arts on the Island.

title: CABARET: MUSICAL TAKEOFFS
description: Montgomery, Plant and Stritch, a trio of singers - two stand-up women, one piano-playing man - cover much of the history of pop close harmony from the 1930's through the 1950's in their stint at Don't Tell Mama, 343 West 46th Street, where they will be performing Wednesdays through Saturdays until March 23.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BARS BAIL FOR 16 APARTHEID FOES
description: The authorities, invoking a catch-all security law, have said 16 prominent opponents of white minority rule detained last month will not be granted bail before or during their trial, which is expected to last 18 months.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN HONG KONG
description: Landing at Hong Kong's Kai Tak Airport is one of the world's more interesting flying experiences. The approach over the Kowloon Peninsula, where most Hong Kong residents live packed into tall apartment buildings sticking into the air like concrete teeth is such a close shave that you actually see people eating dinner. What's more, they probably see you.

title: LEARNING ABOUT LEARNING ABROAD
description: Ponder this: You stay with families in three different places in Australia and New Zealand to learn what farming in those countries is like. You visit a sheep ranch to see how dogs are trained. You learn about handcrafts and the technology of gold mining, and you stroll down the main street of a one-time boom town. You view breathtaking mountain scenery and gentle rolling countryside and absorb Sydney's cultural liveliness and Melbourne's charm. All for $2,959 a person for 17 days, including round-trip air fare from San Francisco.

title: VATICAN REPORTS ITS BUDGET HAD $29 MILLION DEFICIT IN '84
description: The Vatican announced today that it ran a deficit last year of 58.4 billion lira, roughly $29 million.

title: Sarah Watts Weds John Lohse, a Radio Engineer
description: At the Presbyterian Church in Basking Ridge, N.J., yesterday Sarah Elisabeth Watts, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William O. Watts of Millington, N.J., was married to John Daniel Lohse, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Austin W. Lohse of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. J. Calvin K. Jackson performed the ceremony.

title: LIKE GROWN-UPS, AND DIFFERENT
description: THE CHILD AS POET: MYTH OR REALITY? By Myra Cohn Livingston. 354 pp. Boston: The Horn Book. $24.95. MYRA COHN LIVINGSTON has paid the movement to put poets in public schools the great compliment of a thorough, serious evaluation and critique in ''The Child as Poet: Myth or Reality?'' She includes an overview of the work of poet-teachers of the past, such as Flora Arnstein and Langston Hughes, as well as a survey of the last 20 years when having poets teach in the schools has been led by the Teachers and Writers Collaborative. Perhaps most impressively, throughout this book, Mrs. Livingston looks closely and analytically at texts written by children, both those of child geniuses of the past and of participants in the creative writing programs in many schools today. What, she asks, are the strengths and weaknesses of children as poets? What are their natural proclivities and capabilities? She always judges the work of children by the same high standards she holds adult poetry to.

Larsen, one of more than 300 Eastern swimmers taking part in the United States Swimming Metropolitan championships, finished in 1 minute 38.88 seconds to beat John Wichel of the Gotham Aqua Kings, a 17-year-old student at Stuyvesant High School, who was timed in 1:40.10.

What kept her below Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd was her inconsistency and a tendency to slip into gloomy moods when her strokes faltered.

title: ISRAELI CRACKDOWN STIRRING ILL WILL AMONG SHIITES IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: Israel's crackdown in southern Lebanon, aimed at curbing attacks by Shiite Moslems on Israeli troops, is deepening a resentment among the population that could strengthen support for anti- Israeli guerrillas.

title: PENTAGON PUTS A RIPPLE IN DEFENSE CONTRACTOR'S CASH FLOW
description: After months of scrutiny, the Pentagon slapped its largest military contractor on the wrist last week for submitting improper bills. It was the first disciplining of the General Dynamics Corporation since charges of fraudulent activity arose last year, but it may not be the last.

title: STUBBS PAINTED ENGLISH LIFE, NOT JUST HORSES
description: Among the great painters of the 18th century, none had until lately so low a profile as George Stubbs, who was born in 1724 and died in 1806. Not until 1957 did he have a major exhibition even in his native England, where he had been regarded till then as top man in a minor league. As long ago as 1780 Josiah Wedgwood, head of the great pottery firm that bears his name, had put the problem in a single sentence. ''Nobody,'' he said, ''suspects Mr. Stubbs of painting anything but horses and lions, or dogs and tigers, and I can scarcely make anyone believe that he ever attempted a human figure.''

title: JURY DUTY SET TO CHANGE
description: -selection process, though not without imperfections, is supplying the courts with adequate numbers of jurors, according to lawyers, judges and judicial administrators around the state.

description: WHEN Governor Cuomo came to Long Island last week to talk about his proposed state budget, he again used the opportunity to make a policy statement about a key issue to the Island.

description: Lech Walesa, the leader of the outlawed Solidarity movement, was questioned today by Government prosecutors whom he said ordered him not to leave Gdansk, his home city, without police permission.

title: King Babar Wins
description: After saving ground to the stretch, King Babar swung wide for the drive and easily passed the dueling pace- setters to post a convincing two- length victory in the $87,000 Swift Stakes for 3-year-olds yesterday at Aqueduct.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

COIN OF THE YEAR
description: For the second consecutive year, a United States coin has taken top honors in the ''Coin of the Year'' competition sponsored by a major hobby publisher. The winner this time is the 1983 Olympic silver dollar, the first of three Unied States coins issued to commemorate and help finance the 1984 Summer Olympic Games in Los Angeles.

title: SCOTTISH ISLE OF HILLS AND HEATHER
description: December brings the first real storm of the winter. Outside the trees are thrashing and the horizontal rain blows in off the Atlantic. A child's swing, hung from the trees, pendulums ceaselessly back and forth. Sea birds are caught and make slow turns like skaters. But there is a peat fire and the anticipation of a dram of whisky to keep the cold out. Hard then to imagine this place in the spring or summer.

title: THE REAL NORTH AMERICA, EH?
description: ''THE CANADIANS,'' by Andrew H. Malcolm, is not a pretty-picture book, all wilderness parks and icicles, nor is it a travel guide, all restaurants. Instead it's an ambitious, enthusiastic and wide-ranging study of a country recently thought, even by those who live there, to be unambitious, unenthusiastic and narrow-ranging. The results will surprise many, especially the Canadians themselves.

title: BREAKING AWAY FROM SYDNEY
description: On the south coast of New South Wales, lies Bingie Beach, a scallop of pale cream sand embraced by two craggy points of rocks and sheltered by the slopes of scrub- covered dunes. Gentle waves of the Pacific Ocean, crested by white foam that glistens in the high morning sun, roll in a perpetual surf that only a few people happen upon.

The award, which consists of $5,000 in cash and a silver medallion, is granted annually by Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, which oversees the Nathan estate. Mr. Nathan, a noted drama critic who wrote for more than 30 publications, died in 1958 at the age of 76.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT MAPLE LEAFS, 4-2

description: New York State plans to limit or perhaps ban fishing for striped bass because Federal rules have further restricted the acceptable levels of PCB's in the fish, state officials said yesterday.

But there is still one last place to go before bringing the evening to a close: the Churreria de San Gines, where madrilenos have been gathering since the last century for hot chocolate and fritters called churros.
