title: THE VERY TIMELY ART OF ROBERT LONGO
description: ''The most important thing about being an artist is to figure out where you're supposed to be, and who's your audience,'' says Robert Longo. ''Then you sort of catch your time. You have to know and understand the realm of high art and what the boundaries are. Most artists just flounder around and read too many art magazines.'' Cocky, clever, a cultural iconoclast with a sharp nose for the Zeitgeist, Mr. Longo at 32 is one of the most ambitious and versatile animateurs of the present generation. A media-child weaned on television, movies and news magazines, his multichannel skills include drawing, sculpture, performance art, video, film and music (he used to man the guitar in a rock band). His way of catching our ''time'' is by playing back to us the pressures, contradictions and even hopes engendered by its charged mix of cultures - urban, corporate, technological and media - in taut, sometimes powerful icons that he has said ''exist somewhere between movies and monuments.''

title: Revenue Sharing's Benefits Outweigh Problems

title: Chicago Loves Baseball
description: Some Chicagoans love their baseball teams so much that they are willing to condone radical changes to keep their favorites in town, if necessary. Those were some of the findings of a recent survey conducted by Northwestern University's Medill School of Journalism, which also found that almost 30 percent of Chicago residents consider the Cubs their favorite team and 12 percent named the White Sox.

title: AUGURIES FROM A WINTER OF DISCONTENT
description: We are in a junk glut of epidemic proportions. From Jan. 1 through March 1 this year, the reviewers of The New York Times, who cover most, though not quite all, of the film openings in Manhattan, reviewed 58 new movies, compared to 42 in the first two months of 1984. That's a rather staggering increase, especially since 37 of those films opened in February, which has only 28 days. You might be inclined to think of this as a kind of movie renaissance, that is, until you make a quick rundown of some of the titles.

title: NEW FACE ON 15TH
description: A turn-of-the century town house on West 15th Street in Chelsea, where properties that can be redeveloped are becoming scarcer by the day, is being gutted and rebuilt as a residential cooperative that will feature studios.

title: FORMER PLAYERS FILL EXECUTIVE SUITES
description: Woody Woodward's lament: ''When I played, we worked 12 months of the year because we had to get jobs in the off- season and the front office worked seven months. Now players work seven months and the front office works 12 months. My timing was less than desirable.''

title: JAZZZ: PAUL BLEY QUARTET
description: When Paul Bley and his quartet take on a tune, the theme-and-variations form of most jazz performances is left far behind. The tune might pop up now and then amid solos, or get played once and abandoned; some solos are set off, others interlaced.

title: STRAUSS OPERAS IN CONCERT
description: One of the freshest and most successful operatic ventures of recent years, whether you go by critical response (mostly raves) or audience reaction (mostly sellouts) has been the concert opera series overseen by Matthew Epstein at Carnegie Hall. It all started with a Rossini Opera Festival, a trio of works featuring Marilyn Horne, in 1982-3; next came a season of French Opera-Comique with Frederica von Stade as the common element (nothing common about her singing, of course). Now we are in the midst of a Handel series that most recently featured Kathleen Battle as Semele. What next?

title: KNICKS DEFEAT 76ERS ON BASKET BY KING
description: Bernard King's acrobatic, off-balance bank shot, after a miss by Rory Sparrow, enabled the Knicks to edge the Philadelphia 76ers, 131-129, yesterday at Madison Square Garden. The winning shot came with three seconds to go in the second overtime.

title: ISRAEL DEFENDS CRACKDOWN, CITING 'DRAMATIC INCREASE' IN TERRORISM

title: YOUTH IN SCHOOL SUICIDE DIES
description: A teen-ager who shot himself in front of high school classmates died Friday. Bruce Perry, 17 years old, a student at a vocational high school, was pronounced dead after being removed from life support systems at St. Luke's Hospital at the request of his family. The authorities say a boy who gave his name as Bruce called a suicide-prevention group shortly before the shooting Wednesday, but hung up, saying he had a class to attend.

Miss DeSocio graduated cum laude from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Starr is a summa cum laude graduate of Princeton University.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN OPTS OUT
description: Released after more than 22 years as a South African political prisoner, Dennis Goldberg asked last week for understanding from other imprisoned leaders of the banned African National Congress who chose to reject the conditional amnesty offered by President P. W. Both. Mr. Goldberg, interviewed at an Israeli kibbutz where he was visiting his daughter, said he was ''not as strong'' as Nelson Mandela, the head of the outlawed political group, and others. He said he had been tired and simply had to get out, and that imprisoned comrades had recommended that he accept the amnesty. A South African-born engineer, Mr. Goldberg said he felt ''high just from being free,'' but added that he would not settle permanently in Israel because of its support for South Africa.

Surgeons at the University of Arizona performed the operation without permission from the Federal Food and Drug Administration, and they used a heart that had not been approved, either.

title: MUSIC: NATIONAL CHORALE SOLOISTS PERFORM HANDEL
description: Whether it is a Handel tricentennial year or not, it is always worth hearing ''Alexander's Feast'' (1736), one of his grandest, most brilliant, musically exalted settings for soloists, chorus and orchestra. That is not to say the National Chorale Soloists' version Wednesday night at Merkin Concert Hall was without merit in itself: there was much in isolation to admire, and as a whole the performance let us realize what Handel had wrought. But there were flaws, too.

title: REAGAN KILLS FARM AID AS BATTLE OPENS ON SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON ''THERE has been a change in public opinion,'' said Senator Robert W. Kasten Jr. in the anteroom of the Senate Budget Committee one afternoon last week. Last year, the Wisconsin Republican reflected when asked about criticisms of the budget committee's actions, an across-the-board freeze on Federal spending ''was considered pie in the sky, and now it's a cop-out.''

title: WOMEN'S SAFETY ON CAMPUS
description: ''A WOMAN in general, being more vulnerable, feels less safe than a man anywhere,'' Pat Long was saying in the provost conference room at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

title: METS ARE HIGH ON CHRISTENSEN

But just about all 25 jobs on the team are filled now, and only one rookie figures to make the team in spring training - a strong, silent 24-year-old outfielder named John Christensen.

description: Governor Kean is correct. Legislation imposing a cap on state expenditures must await resolution of the broadly supported movement to reform the Federal tax structure and the rigors of the Reagan budget proposals for 1986.

title: ON ORWELL, HANDEL AND INDIA
description: To the Editor:

title: Data Bank;   March 10, 1985
Salt Pollution
description: For seven years, 40 farmers in Rice County, Kan., contended in a suit that they were entitled to damages because salt had polluted the ground water, forcing them to grow dry-land wheat and milo instead of more profitable corn. Last August, in Federal District Court in Wichita, Judge Frank G. Theis found that the American Salt Company, which had been working underground salt beds in the county since 1908, was the polluter.

title: REAGAN STEPS UP CAMPAIGN FOR MX
description: President Reagan stepped up his effort today to win support for the MX missile, linking the success of the Geneva arms talks in large measure to the Congressional votes this month on the weapons program.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

JOY OF TEACHING IS WORTH THE PAIN
description: THERE has been much talk lately about teachers being underpaid and undervalued, and as an instructor at a community college, I agree with that. We teachers do deserve more money and we, like the comedian Rodney Dangerfield, ''don't get no respect.'' I have even heard people say that we should not mind the low pay because teaching is a rewarding job. Well, I would not teach for the rewards alone, but the rewards are what keep me teaching. Those not involved in community college education cannot know what a demanding, frustrating but joyous job it is.

title: 3 WRITERS FIND THAT PERSISTENCE PAYS
description: FOR the poet Margaret F. Gibson of Preston, the moral might be, never give up. After being rejected for a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts for nine straight years, Miss Gibson - and two other Connecticut writers - was awarded the $20,000 fellowship earlier this year.

title: COURSE EXAMINES VIOLENCE
description: A NEW course at the University of Connecticut is examining forms of violence against women, from the subtle portrayals of women as sex objects in advertisements to rape in a city alley.

title: 'The Fiasco Of Nuclear Power'
description: I thought the fiasco of nuclear power with its huge cost overruns and investor losses had by now become so evident that even its most rabid advocates would have been shamed into silence.

title: Kim Barth Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Barth of Mount Kisco, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kim Barth to David A. Kembel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ruben Kembel of Arvada, Colo.

title: A FIRST HOME: SHOCKS
description: THE search for the Holy Grail was a cinch compared with the adventures of countless Long Island baby-boomers in search of their first homes. Theirs is a frustrating journey of financial barriers, ''affordability gaps'' and grueling reminders that they are falling further and further behind their older peers, parents and grandparents in achieving home ownership.

title: SUCCESS AND THE SOVIET WRITER
description: In the West success is automatically followed by the magic stereotypes of Fame and Fortune - one could call them two-handed clapping. They are the indivisible ingredients of success in the cultural-commercial mythology of this contemporary society, and they turn into each other in a certain vicious circle, sometimes to the brink of absurdity. Fame and Fortune are not twin sisters in the Soviet literary world. One reaches a certain level of Soviet fortune by being promoted ideologically. In other words, one becomes a bearer of infamy rather than fame. Genuine literary fame in the Soviet Union often brings nothing but trouble; therefore, success in Soviet literature always creates a feeling of complicity - either against the bureaucratic ruling class or for it. If one can compare success with applause, I would say that success Soviet-style is a sort of one- handed clapping.

title: JACKSON AND KENNEDY IN FINAL
description: Greg Harvey and Ron Edwards put the Andrew Jackson fast break into high gear in the second half, combining for 20 of the Hickories' 24 fourth- quarter points, to propel Jackson to a 58-51 upset over Boys and Girls High in the Public Schools Athletic League semifinals yesterday at St. John's Alumni Hall.

title: NOTED CANCER RESEARCHER ALTERING ROLE
description: DR. Irving J. Selikoff, whose research on occpational and environmental diseases led to a cure for tuberculosis and revealed the perils of asbestos dust, will retire in July as director of the Mount Sinai Medical School's environmental science laboratory.

title: LETTERS
description: Housing Options

title: WHEN ALZHEIMER'S STRIKES
description: ''I SAID goodbye to my mother several years ago,'' confided a friend whose mother recently succumbed to a variety of illnesses. Now, I can only estimate the time our goodbyes might have been made with my own mother.

title: CANADIAN PLAYERS LEAD BRIDGE EVENT
description: The bridge players of Canada, facing an invasion by thousands of United States players, have had plenty to cheer about this week. Before the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League began Friday, their team had won the right to compete in the 1985 World Team Championships in Brazil. And in the opening men's pair championship, two Montreal experts led into the final session tonight.

title: AVOIDING THE PITFALLS OF SPREADSHEETS
description: PERSONAL computing's widest impact in business to date has probably been in financial planning, budgeting and record keeping - areas where spreadsheet software has made its mark. VisiCalc, the first of the ''calc'' packages, as they are known, was as crucial in selling early Apples as the machines themselves were. Lotus 1-2-3 played a comparable role in the selection of the I.B.M. personal computer by many corporate buyers following its introduction.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Easter egg decorating, an Eastern European tradition, began in the first century A.D. Instruction in this delicate skill will be available in at least three locations this week.

title: INVASION OF THE COMPACT DISKS
description: Like sharks in a feeding frenzy, they attacked the compact-disk bins. The scene was a CD sale a couple of weeks ago at a big West Side record store. As bemused clerks stood about idly in the nearly abandoned remainder of the store, consumers groped feverishly through the dwindling CD supplies, grabbing freshly priced disks from the hands of harrassed employees who were trying to stamp them straight out of their shipping boxes. Customers elbowed their way up to the cash registers with armfuls of CDs, spending $150 to $200 apiece. So much for any lingering signs of the record industry's sales doldrums. Digital laser compact disks - silvery, mirror-shiny, four-and-three- quarters inches in diameter and able to reproduce sounds with an astonishing clarity and precision - have become a revolutionary force in the music business in the past few months. Although they have been available in the United States since mid- 1983, it was this past holiday season that saw the CD sales explosion, which hardly abated in January and February; if anything, it's mushroomed.

title: Nepal, $12.60, Wins Seminole
description: Nepal, a gawky colt who was switched from dirt to grass last year in an effort to help his development, returned to the dirt today looking all grown up and professional. He scored an easy 3 1/2- length victory in the $87,700 Seminole Handicap at Hialeah Park and looked ready to join the ranks of the top older horses in the country.

title: Ex-Defense AidePleads GuiltyIn Stock Inquiry
description: When W. Paul Thayer resigned early last year as the Pentagon's No. 2 civilian, he maintained that accusations he had engaged in illegal insider stock trading were ''entirely without merit.'' But in a Federal courtroom in Washington last week, he pleaded guilty of obstructing justice by giving false testimony to the Securities and Exchange Commission when he denied involvement in a stock-trading scheme.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

CULTURAL PACE
description: The Cultural Committee of Pace University in Pleasantville was begun five years ago to finance programs in the performing arts and liberal arts on that campus. Sixteen student, faculty and administrative representatives serve on the committee, which over the years has supported a variety of activities and presentations, including readings by outstanding national and international poets, foreign films, a weekly Jazz at Noon program and the Pace Literary Magazine. The committee is sponsored by Pace and all of its events are free and open to the public.

title: JAZZ: BIRTHDAY AT CONDON'S
description: Anniversaries galore are being celebrated this month at Eddie Condon's, the jazz club at 144 West 54th Street.

title: WHEN REASON FLEES
description: BOSTON

title: U.S. IS REVIEWING BENEFITS STANCE
description: The Reagan Administration says it is reassessing a policy under which the Social Security Administration has asserted a right to disregard precedents set by Federal courts if they differ from the agency's interpretation of the law.

title: JAZZ: AN ECLETIC PROGRAM AT THE RITZ
description: Raucous, multicultural, self-conscious New York City spawned a new kind of art music in the late 1970's - one that embraces classicl formalism and rock's impact. Three of its top practitioners performed Thursday at the Ritz; a fourth, John Zorn, was the ultra eclectic disk jockey between sets.

title: POLAND FINDS NEW ROAD TO A DEAD END
description: For Poland, the conflict was familiar. On one side, an inefficient economy burdened by low productivity and a shortage of capital could no longer support subsidies in food prices. On the other, hard-pressed workers made it known that higher food prices would drive them to greater despair or malingering, and perhaps into the streets. Food-price increases, after all, led to unrest in 1970 that toppled one Government and, a decade later, spurred the growth of the independent Solidarity trade union that helped bring down another.

title: RURAL PRESENCE OF THE PAST
description: Originally settled by Dutch dairymen and traders, Lewisboro Township, in northeastern Westchester County, has held much of its rural flavor despite its proximity to New York City. In Waccabuc, one of Lewisboro's most bucolic hamlets, a developer now is creating a colony of 42 single-family residences designed to fit both the character of the area and the tastes of buyers who want 18th- and 19th-century-style houses with the conveniences of condominium ownership.

title: CIRCLING THE GLOBE: A JOURNEY IN TIME
description: It was simple. So long as we kept going forward, we could stop in any city in the world that Trans World Airlines or Qantas Airlines flies to. I had accumulated 175,000 miles in the T.W.A. frequent- flyer bonus program, and the airline had presented my wife and me with free first-class tickets around the world. All we had to supply was the time (and the money to support ourselves on the ground).

title: SPARKY TO MANAGE FOREVER
description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 9 - SPORTS OF THE TIMES

title: HE CHEATED DEATH
description: THE TENTH MAN

title: CLAMPING GLUED WOOD FOR A STRONGER JOINT
description: Today's wood glues are stronger and more versatile than ever, but if not properly used they can still lead to disappointment. For example, most require clamping pressure while they dry, so it is important that this part of the directions be carefully followed if you want to insure a strong, long-lasting joint that will not fail under stress.

title: Salvadoran Violence
description: Civilians also continued to suffer in El Salvador's civil war. Archbishop Arturo Rivera y Damas of San Salvador said eight civilians were killed by right-wing death squads in the week ending last Sunday.

title: PRODUCT LIABILITY: THE NEW MORASS
description: The A. H. Robins Company postponed its annual meeting, set for next month, until the company determines how many millions of dollars it should set aside to pay to women injured by its Dalkon Shield contraceptive device. The reserve could reduce or wipe out the company's quarterly dividend.

title: FLYING CLOUD
description: The Flying Cloud, one of the famed Yankee clipper ships of the mid-19th century, is featured on a 25-cent postal card issued last month at Salem, Mass. The denomination reflects the new international postage rates for sending a postcard or postal card by surface mail to any country except Mexico and Canada.

title: VERBATIM: AID TO ISRAEL
description: 'The plan they have (for economic recovery) won't do the trick. And if we give them $800 million of supplemental aid as the plan now stands, we're convinced that will disappear and their economy won't be any better off, and they'll face bigger problems later on, they'll be back for more money, with worse problems.' W. Allen Wallis,

title:
ANTIQUES;

PRINCETON SHOW REFLECTS AREA'S LEANINGS
description: PRINCETON ONE OF the factors contributing to the perennial success of the Princeton Antiques Show is the astute reflection that it mirrors of the preferences of the area in which it is held.

title: Elizabeth D. Ellis To Marry July 27
description: Dr. F. Henry Ellis Jr. of Brookline, Mass., and Mrs. John Adams Blanchard of Needham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Dunston Ellis to

title: SUFFOLK DREDGING AT ISSUE
description: THE Suffolk County Legislature is preparing to put the county back into the dredging business, and that has sparked heated comments from public officials and private dredgers.

title: STAGE: ORTON'S 'What the Butler Saw'
description: Joe Orton's last play, ''What the Butler Saw,'' is a demented madhouse farce in which there are no patients on the premises. In fact, everyone is impatient - a lascivious doctor, his wanton wife and various interlopers expressing a multitude of lustful persuasions. The comedy is footloose and tongue-tripping, accelerating to an eccentric epiphany. Unfortunately, only a minimum of the essential spirit of Orton is evidenced on stage in Andrei Belgrader's revival at the Yale Repertory Theater.

title: Georgia Tech Will Face North Carolina
description: Georgia Tech and North Carolina, two teams playing their best basketball of the season, weathered stiff semifinal challenges today to advance to Sunday's final of the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament.

title: WINE
description: Restaurants featuring a good assortment of wines packaged in half-bottle size (375 milliliters) encourage proper mating of food and drink withut promoting overindulgence. At such establishments, a couple can choose a fish appetizer and lamb or beef entree and not be forced to settle for a carafe of rose, glasses of house wine or full bottles of white and red. Also, individuals part of a large group can easily avoid unpalatable combinations -- such as dry, white Chablis with steak or hardy, red Cabernet Sauvignon with fillet of sole -- by ordering a half bottle when a wine selection is made to please the majority.

title: EUGENE ATGET-HIS ART BRIDGED TWO CENTURIES
description: Over the last four years the Museum of Modern Art's department of photography has organized a series of four major exhibitions involving a total of close to 500 photographs, supervised the publication of four exquisitely reproduced books and devoted uncounted hours to research and writing, all with one aim: to establish Eug ene Atget (1857-1927) as a great photographer.

title: A WORLD OF DISCOVERIES ;   OFF THE BEATEN TRACK
description: One of the delights of travel is coming upon a restaurant, a neighborhood, a city - even an entire region - that does not appear on traditional tourist itineraries. Discoveries may range from a hotel cherished by local residents to an out-of-the-way street that sums up the spirit of a nation, to a waterway that reveals the heart of a country. Here, Times correspondents from around the world suggest some unusual attractions.

title: A WORLD OF DISCOVERIES ;   OFF THE BEATEN TRACK
description: One of the delights of travel is coming upon a restaurant, a neighborhood, a city - even an entire region - that does not appear on traditional tourist itineraries. Discoveries may range from a hotel cherished by local residents to an out-of-the-way street that sums up the spirit of a nation, to a waterway that reveals the heart of a country. Here, Times correspondents from around the world suggest some unusual attractions.

title: THE UNSEEN WORLD OF JOHN J. AUDUBON
description: Roger Tory Peterson, whose ''A Field Guide to the Birds East of the Rockies'' is now in its fourth edition, is completing the revised Western volume.

title: DARIEN RENEWS THRILL OF 'West Side Story'
description: THE Darien Dinner Theater's production of ''West Side Story'' cannot accurately be called a revival since the theater has never before mounted the milestone musical. Even so, it does just what a revival has todo - and that is to approach the work anew, so it can be appraised afresh. In any case, for most audiences ''West Side Story'' is a revival indeed.

title: TOPICS
description: AS the days grew warmer, the roses on the side of our house would bloom. These were not the American Beauty prize-winning sort, but the simple climbing variety that flourishes around many suburban homes. The thorny bushes were tied onto two white trellises, carefully angled to lean against the shingles of the house, with white string usually saved from bakery boxes, and were, it appeared, to be forever upheld in this manner.

title: JACK KEMP'S YEAR OF DECISION
description: So what if some people out there think of Jack Kemp as ''an intellectual lightweight, a one-time jock with a good barber and a smooth tan, stuffed full of ideas that he does not completely understand''? A fellow Californian with those same qualities now occupies the White House.

title: IN THE CONCERT WORLD, SPRING IS HERE
description: AS the balmy temperatures of the last two weekends made clear, spring is not too far away, and as if to prove the point two spring festivals will be opening for musical business next Saturday. At the Masters School, more specifically in the historic Estherwood Mansion on its Dobbs Ferry campus, the first of three ''Spring Music at Estherwood'' recitals presents Barbara Held, Diana Mizelle and Mimi SternWolfe in a variety of works for flute, double-bass and piano.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;

PHOTOGRAPHY
description: There is something rich and darkly glamorous about the urban world of Ralph Gibson's photographs. It is, on the whole, a world of things rather than people - statues, moldings, automobiles, doorways, signs - sometimes viewed close-up, sometimes seen from a distance, as if by accident, between other things.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

BREAKFAST LOBBYING
description: EGGS and lobbying were on the menu at a breakfast for members of Westchester's Albany delegation held earlier this month on the campus of the State University of New York at Purchase. The 90-minute session, arranged by college officials, was largely devoted to discussing the effect Governor Cuomo's proposed budget would have on the college.

title: BUILDER SEEKS AID FOR MILL SITE
description: -Sanford carpet mills have stood vacant in the northern section of Enfield, their crumbling brick edifices the symbol of the end of an industrial era.

title: WRITERS AS MOTHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: A WORLD OF DISCOVERIES ;   OFF THE BEATEN TRACK
description: One of the delights of travel is coming upon a restaurant, a neighborhood, a city - even an entire region - that does not appear on traditional tourist itineraries. Discoveries may range from a hotel cherished by local residents to an out-of-the-way street that sums up the spirit of a nation, to a waterway that reveals the heart of a country. Here, Times correspondents from around the world suggest some unusual attractions.

title: THE NEW STRATEGIC REALITY: MAD IS DEAD
description: The exchange between the Ukrainian Communist Party boss Vladimir Shcherbitsky and Ronald Reagan in the Oval Office last week was considerably more spirited than reported.

title: ILLINOIS TOWN'S BATTLE OVER RADIOACTIVE WASTE DISPOSAL TESTS U.S. POLICY
description: A long-running battle over how to dispose of four big deposits of radioactive waste and numerous pockets of it in this town of 13,000 people has grown into a test of national policy.

title: RABBI ZALMAN S. DWORKIN, 85, A LEADER OF LUBAVITCHER SECT
description: Rabbi Zalman Shimon Dworkin, dean of the worldwide Lubavitch Rabbinic Council, died of cancer Saturday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 85 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   A Top Engineer Moves Up at I.B.M.
description: At the International Business Machines Corporation, the traditional way to the top is through the company's marketing operations - the past three chief executives were all former salesmen.

title: Handel's 'Belshazzar' By Pro Arte Chorale
description: The Pro Arte Chorale and soloists will present Handel's ''Belshazzar'' Tuesday at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall, Broadway and 67th Street.

title: MOTTA WINS 700TH
description: Somewhere between finding respectability and striking an imposing playoff pose, the Nets have begun to slump badly. Their timing couldn't be worse.

title: Nuclear Downturn Hurts Water Plant
description: Each day, a plant here takes 14 million gallons of normal water and turns it into three or four 45-gallon batches of what is called heavy water.

title: HOW NEW YORK DESIGNS A HOUSING PROGRAM
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebels and Soldiers Skirmish in Turkey
description: Eight separatist guerrillas and two soldiers were killed in a clash near Diyarbakir, eastern Turkey, the semi official Anatolian press agency said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In view of the projected developments, in which I cannot possibly participate, as of today I terminate my services as President of the Republic, resigning from the rest of my term.'' - Constantine Caramanlis of Greece. (A1:6.)

title: FRENCH CENTER AND RIGHT MAKE GAINS
description: Centrist and conservative opposition parties won major victories today over the Socialists and Communists in voting for regional councils that was regarded as a final test run before the national legislative elections next year.

title: Looking Ahead At Gold Prices
description: FOR many months now, the price of gold has

title: States Faulted on Inspections
description: Inspection programs to control automobile exhaust fumes are being weakened because too many states have fought the system and too many inspection centers have ignored strict antipollution standards, a report to Congress says.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 11, 1985 SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Address Chic
description: Meanwhile, the Democratic National Committee, which moved into its new headquarters building at the corner of Ivy and South Capitol Streets last December, has received permission from the Postal Service to change its address from 20 Ivy Street to 430 South Capitol Street.

title: 70 NATIONS MEET TODAY IN GENEVA ON PLEA TO INCREASE FAMINE AID
description: Representatives from 70 countries and from dozens of private agencies and international groups will meet in Geneva Monday to discuss a United Nations report that says an extra $1.5 billion is required to meet emergency relief needs in 20 African countries. It is the largest United Nations conference to deal with the crisis of drought and famine.

title: DANCE: JOSE MOLINA TROUPE
description: Jose Molina puts on a good show. That was evident from the first moments of his performance with the Jose Molina Bailes Espanoles on Saturday at Carnegie Hall, when he and his three dancers dressed in costumes the colors of anemones, moved like bright ghosts onto a dimly lighted, mysterious stage and began to dance.

title: GEORGIA TECH TAKES A.C.C. FINAL, 57-54
description: For 59 minutes, Georgia Tech chased North Carolina and a dream. Finally, with the score tied at 50, the Tar Heels made a crucial mistake, opening the way for Tech to rush to a 57-54 victory in the final of the 52d Atlantic Coast Conference tournament.

title: TV Unit Attacked in Spain
description: Suspected Basque separatists in a speeding car opened fire today on a television technical van parked outside a sports stadium, the authorities said. Three police officers and two television technicians were wounded, they said.

title: CITY'S ROCK CLUBS FEAR INCREASE IN DRINKING AGE
description: New York City's thriving rock music clubs may have to sharply curtail the number of live performances they present, or risk going under, if the legal drinking age in New York State rises from 19 to 21 years old, according to club operators and owners. Since these clubs have long been a proving ground for new performers whose innovative styles strongly affect pop music internationally, a decrease in their activity could have a pronounced effect on the music business.

title: RefugeesContinue Hunger Strike
description: Eighteen Afghan refugees held for 10 months while seeking political asylum refused to take food and water for a sixth day yesterday to protest their detention by immigration authorities in New York, their lawyer said.

title: Edward Andrews, 70, Actor In Broadway Plays and Films
description: Edward Andrews, a versatile actor who appeared in 51 films and 31 Broadway plays, died of a heart attack Friday. He was 70 years old and lived in Pacific Palisades, Calif.

title: BALLET: CRAGUN AND HAYDEE IN JOFFREY 'ROMEO'
description: When the Stuttgart Ballet introduced John Cranko's ''Romeo and Juliet'' to New York in 1969, the Romeo was Richard Cragun and the Juliet was Marcia Haydee. Mr. Cragun and Miss Haydee were once again a memorable pair of star- crossed lovers on Saturday night in the New York State Theater when they appeared as guest artists in the Joffrey Ballet's production of the work.

title: NEW YORK TRIES TO SAVE ITS VANISHING STATE BIRD
description: A rescue mission is under way in New York State to save the bluebird, the harbinger of spring that is also the official state bird.

title: TRYING TIMES FOR SUPERRICH TEXANS
description: Nelson Bunker Hunt, one of the Texas superrich, once observed that a billion dollars is not what it used to be.

title: CHUN DESERVES AMERICANS' PATIENCE
description: When President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea visits the United States next month, Americans will undoubtedly try to project their ideals onto South Korea's political landscape. In all likelihood, a small but vocal group of Americans who are critical of the Chun record will press their cause through petitions and demonstrations. Unfortunately, in their single- mindedness, they paint a grossly unfair caricature of South Korean politics and the Chun administration.

title: Allis Seeking An Extension
description: The Allis- Chalmers Corporation said it has asked its banks and institutional lenders to extend the expiration date of its current financing agreement to May 31, from March 15.

title: GRESCHNER ADAPTS TO FORWARD ROLE
description: The wording in Ron Greschner's contract is vague. He likes it that way.

title: The Great Proliferators
description: To the Editor:

title: American Standard To Promote President
description: As part of a continuing management succession plan, American Standard Inc. said it expects to name its president, William B. Boyd, to the posts of vice chairman and chief executive officer.

title: MY ANSCHLUSS FOOTBALL
description: Exactly 47 years ago, on March 11, 1938, my parents, my brother and I sat in our living room in Vienna and heard Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's voice cry out from the radio: ''God protect Austria!'' It was the day Austria died. A few sentences earlier, he'd said German troops were crossing the border on the pretext of putting down Red riots throughout the city.

title: PAVILION RISING AT SEAPORT DRAWS OPPOSITION
description: Just south of the Brooklyn Bridge, hard by the Fulton Fish Market, a vast red steel-and- glass pavilion is rising on a newly rebuilt Pier 17.

title: All Scream for Sushi
description: Let the word go forth: Washington

title: GREECE WITHOUT CARAMANLIS: A FREE REIN FOR THE SOCIALISTS?
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's astonishing reversal in barring the re-election of President Constantine Caramanlis led today to the departure of the man whom Greece's American and European allies considered the principal restraining influence on the Socialist Prime Minister's anti-Western policies.

title: Greycom Chief Resigns
description: -year-old chairman and chief executive officer of Greycom, the public relations subsidiary of Grey Advertising, has resigned because of ''irreconcilable differences'' with Frances Friedman, the president and chief operating officer. The public relations firm was Grey & Davis when Mr. Rutman, who had his own shop for 18 years, came in to run it in 1979, and it kept that name until it acquired Frances Friedman Associates last year.

title: Marcos's Opponents To Run Single Candidate
description: Major Philippine opposition groups agreed today to unite behind a single candidate against President Ferdinand E. Marcos in the 1987 presidential elections.

title: NEW ISSUES RAISED FOR U.S. ON GREECE
description: Administration officials said today that Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's unexpected decision to withdraw support for the re-election of President Constantine Caramanlis would intensify the debate in Washington on American policy toward Greece.

title: Delay Asked for Hearing In Mississippi Walkout
description: The state attorney general, Jackson school officials and the state's largest teachers organization agreed today to ask a judge to delay until next week a hearing in which he was to decide whether a two-week strike by 9,300 Mississippi teachers is illegal.

title: Settlement Backed
description: The Indian Government is prepared to forgo litigation and settle with the Union Carbide Corporation on compensation for the victims of the gas leak in Bhopal, a senior official said today.

title: MUSIC: NINA SIMONE SINGS
description: One never knows quite what to expect from a Nina Simone concert. In her sporadic club appearances over the last two years, the expatriate ''high priestess of soul'' has offered emotionally charged, often brilliantly iconoclastic interpretations of such unpromising fare as ''My Way'' and ''Feelings.''

title: A BIG CHILL AT THE BALL PARK, A BIG BILL AT THE HOUSING AUTHORITY
description: After several futile moves toward getting a downtown stadium built for the San Francisco Giants baseball club, Mayor Dianne Feinstein has retreated to Square 1 with a proposal for spending $70 million or more for a dome for Candlestick Park. The response has been about as warm as a July night at the ''Stick,'' at the southern tip of the city along San Francisco Bay, where wind-blown fog chills fans who left their parkas home.

title: GENERALS TRIUMPH BY 35-24
description: Doug Flutie put on his kind of show today.

title: U.S. FARM DEBT REPORT DISPUTES REAGAN FIGURES
description: One- third of all family-size commercial farms, owing almost one-half of all farm debt, will face financial difficulty in 1985, and 13.7 percent of such farms are either insolvent or on the verge of insolvency, an Agriculture Department study says.

title: The American Way
description: They call it the World Cup, but the world of World Cup skiing was long a distinctly small one, bounded largely by the mountains of Europe and dominated by European skiers and European organizers, who have jealously kept the sport centered on their home turf.

title: TOSE LEAVES N.F.L. FAMILY
description: National Football League owners had a ''mixed reaction'' to the news that Leonard Tose had sold the Philadelphia Eagles and will no longer be a member of the N.F.L. family, Commissioner Pete Rozelle said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: THE OLDER WOMAN Older women, those over 50 years of age, are the most underemployed group of theater professionals. At least, this is the word from the POW (Professional Older Women) Theater Festival that starts today for three consecutive Mondays at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, near Astor Place, under the auspices of Joseph Papp. According to POW, actresses, by age 50, usually find themselves ''involuntarily retired.''

title: HELPING FARMERS WITH STRESS
description: JoAnn Forsness knows the problem well. The cost of farming outpaces revenue. Stretched to his credit limit, a farmer or rancher can no longer borrow enough money to stay in business.

title: Off-Duty Officer Hurt in Gunfight
description: An off-duty police officer exchanged gunfire with a would-be robber in the Bronx early yesterday, and the two men were each wounded in the leg, the police said.

title: McCann and Reynolds
description: The R.J. Reynolds Industries assignments to McCann-Erickson announced last Wednesday would be a lot more financially rewarding to the agency if it was handling the account on a full-service basis.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Atlanta Braves , at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 8 P.M. This is the Yankees' first televised game from their training camp this spring.

title: A Loss and a Gain
description: When a member of Congress is defeated for re-election and joins a law firm, usually in Washington, it is not uncommon for a news release to go out making the announcement.

title: NEW PHONE COMPANY TWIST
description: Not long ago, the Langley Air Force Base outside Norfolk, Va., resolved to cut its long-distance phone bill. So telecommunications experts at the base began planning to have a microwave radio system installed to link the base directly to its long-distance carrier, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: NICARAGUA SHOW-AND-TELL
description: On Wednesday afternoon, 150 scholars, corporate lobbyists, representatives of religious groups and a variety of foreign policy buffs will gather on the fourth floor of the Old Executive Office Building to participate in one of the least publicized activities of the Reagan Administration - its long-running series of weekly briefings on Central America.

title: L.I. Girl Betters Two State Marks
description: Kathy Franey of Massapequa (L.I.) High School won two events in meet-record times Saturday in the New York State high school indoor track-and-field championships in the Carrier Dome.

title: Miss Gregor Marries A.N. Poris in Austin
description: Katherine Lynn Gregor, a daughter of Harold L. Gregor of Bloomington, Ill., and Sandra J. Gregor of Austin, Tex., was married yesterday in Austin to Andrew Neil Poris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Poris of Haworth and Loveladies, N.J. Judge Debra Ravel of the Justice Court of Travis County performed the ceremony at the home of Jane Koock.

title: 'Contras' No Democrats
description: To the Editor:

title: Unusual Return
description: He was an all-American at Holy Cross High School in Queens, so it should come as no surprise that Glen McMillan is making a name for himself on the local college scene.

title: LUZINSKI TRIES TEACHING
description: DELRAN, N.J.

title: Texas Women Are Seeded First
description: Texas was ranked No. 1 today for the fourth annual N.C.A.A. women's basketball tournament. Old Dominion was seeded second in the 32-team field.

title: Men and Women at Work
description: Members of Congress have complained frequently in recent years about their staggering schedule, but they have not exactly suffered from overwork in the first two months of the 99th Congress.

title: Required Reading;   Promises, Promises
description: Following is an excerpt from ''Presidents and Promises'' by Jeff Fishel, professor of government and co-director of the Center for Congressional and Presidential Studies at American University:

title: HEAD OF P.B.A. CALLS FOR KOCH TO ENTER STALLED NEGOTIATIONS
description: The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association called on Mayor Koch yesterday to ''personally intervene'' in the stalemated labor negotiations between the city and its uniformed workers.

title: HOLMES RELIES ON INNER STRENGTH
description: He was built all wrong, with spindly ankles and thin calves that would never be able to support the heavyweight bulk above, except the bulk was hollow. It had no heart.

title: Guessing Who's Coming To Dinner
description: As owners of the Texarkana, a fashionable Cajun restaurant at 64 West 10th Street, Abe and Alene de la Houssaye have had their share of trying experiences - like the time the roast pork, which is cooked slowly in the main dining room, burst into flames.

title: Flood Victims Get Relief As Illinois River Falls By United Press International
description: Flood victims in Illinois got a long- awaited reprieve yesterday from the rising Illinois River, which had forced 2,000 people from their homes.

title: Maintaining Stability in South Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: REUTERS BUYS A NICHE IN U.S. TRADING ROOMS
description: Reuters Holdings P.L.C. and Rich Inc. met in the office about 10 years ago. Now, they are engaged and expected to be married next month.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Miami yesterday on an accident at Jackson Memorial Hospital that left a patient brain dead misidentified the head of the surgical team. He is Dr. James Ryan Chandler.

title: I Get a Kick Out of You
description: When Representative Edward F. Feighan received a letter from several colleagues announcing the start of a new karate class in the House gymnasium, he penned a note to Representative Thomas M. Foglietta.

title: Vacancies at Agriculture
description: The droves of hard-pressed farmers who came to town last week to seek more Federal aid did not seem to notice the shortage of top officials at the Department of Agriculture.

title: LAUER WINS IN L.P.G.A.
description: Bonnie Lauer, who had failed to live up to her early promise during the last 10 years on the tour, shot a four-under-par 68 today to gain a five- stroke victory over Alice Miller in the $330,000 Uniden tournament.

title: KEEPING THEM DOWN ON THE FARM
description: When he vetoed emergency farm credit legislation last week, President Reagan claimed that the relief would come too late to help farmers this spring. Whatever the accuracy of that remark, it obscures the larger issue. Simply stated: must we sacrifice the traditional family farm in the name of greater agricultural efficiency?

title: QUIET WEEK FOR TREASURY OFFERINGS
description: The only Treasury financings scheduled this week are today's regular auction of new bills due in three and six months.

title: STAGE: 'AS IS,' ABOUT AIDS, OPENS
description: There are some subjects audiences would just as soon not hear about in the theater, and surely one of them is AIDS, the lethal illness dramatized by William M. Hoffman in his play, ''As Is.'' But it would be a mistake for any theatergoer to reject this work out of squeamishness. Strange as it may sound, Mr. Hoffman has turned a tale of the dead and the dying into the liveliest new work to be seen at the Circle Repertory Company in several seasons. Far from leaving us drained, ''As Is'' is one of the few theatrical evenings in town that may, if anything, seem too brief.

title: SPOUSES TEACHING SPOUSES
description: Whoever said you can't teach an old dog new tricks might have added the observation that you can't teach your spouse, old or new, any skill - at least not usually, and not without a host of difficulties. ''There are inherent contradictions between what people want from marriage and what teaching involves,'' said Richard H. Mikesell, a Washington psychologist who counsels couples.

title: Those Retreat Democrats
description: Undaunted by reports of some inter-party disputes during a recent weekend retreat by House Democrats, Senate Democrats will stage their own outing March 29- 31. They, too, will be going to West Virginia, but to the Bavarian Inn in Shepherdstown, overlooking the Potomac River, a spot not quite as lavish as the Greenbrier resort used by the House Democrats.

title: QUESTION FOR GENEVA
description: PARIS After all the briefing, there is still

title: WILLIAM E. JENNER, EX-SENATOR, DEAD
description: William E. Jenner, a former Republican Senator from Indiana who accused George C. Marshall of befriending Communists after World War II, died Saturday night at the age of 76.

title: Wrong Bets in Atlantic City
description: In probably no business except gambling would a company invest $300 million without assurance that it could eventually put the asset to profitable use. But that's what Hilton Hotels Corporation did in Atlantic City. Its 26-story casino-hotel now sits idle, awaiting a legal and probably also extralegal struggle to reverse the Casino Control Commission's denial of an operating license.

title: Anti-Communist Group Raided by Polish Police
description: The police raided a meeting of an outlawed anti-Communist group in Warsaw and arrested at least five members, the wife of the group's leader said today.

title: SUCCESSOR TO PEALE IS INSTALLED AT A HISTORIC MANHATTAN CHURCH
description: The Rev. Dr. Arthur Caliandro, the son of Italian immigrants, officially succeeded the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale yesterday as the senior minister of Marble Collegiate Church, the nation's oldest continuous congregation.

title: Indiana, U.C.L.A. In N.I.T.
description: Indiana, U.C.L.A., Houston, Louisville and Marquette, schools that are usually thinking in terms of a national championship this time of year, were among the 32 teams selected yesterday for the National Invitation Tournament.

title: MILOS FORMAN WINS DIRECTORS GUILD AWARD
description: Milos Forman won the Directors Guild of America 1984 award as best movie director Saturday night for ''Amadeus,'' a glittering re-creation of the world of Mozart and the court composer who was his implacable enemy.

title: People
GROWTH AND INFLATION DEBATED
description: One of the thorniest issues facing economists - the relationship between money supply growth, the economy and inflation - is a matter of great debate among policy makers in the Federal Reserve Board and the Reagan Administration, who want both growth and low inflation.

title: U.S. PRESSING PLAN TO CONTRACT WORK
description: The Reagan Administration has heightened its efforts to transfer a wide range of public assets and programs to private enterprise, and it estimates that the changes will save more than $200 million a year by 1989.

title: Pakistan's Conservative Islamic Values
description: To the Editor:

title: I.R.S. WANTS MORE AUDITS
description: WASHINGTON

title: Marchers Protest Plans Of Farm Area to Secede
description: About 100 blacks demonstrated Saturday against a proposal that this tobacco-farming community secede from a predominantly black county.

title: Jersey AIDS Tests Due For High-Risk Groups
description: A medical installation here will soon offer blood tests to people with a high risk of contracting acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS. The aim is to keep such people from going to blood banks to find out if they have the deadly disease.

title: SCHROEDER AND FAMILY TAKE AFTERNOON RIDE ON THE TOWN
description: William J. Schroeder spent 30 minutes of a sunny afternoon riding through Louisville neighborhoods on his first trip away from Humana Hospital Audubon since he received a permanent artificial heart Nov. 25, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: An Error in Her Favor
description: Having been mugged before, the mink-bedecked Upper East Side woman was keeping a wary watch, even at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 56th Street.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Pan Am and Union Urged to End Strike
description: A Federal mediator yesterday instructed Pan American World Airways and Transport Workers Union officials to meet Wednesday in a joint effort to end the walkout that began Feb. 28.

title: RUSSIAN SAYS GOAL IN GENEVA IS BAR TO SPACE WEAPONS
description: The chief Soviet arms negotiator, arriving here with his delegation Sunday, said that Moscow's goal in renewed arms talks with the United States is ''preventing an arms race in space and terminating it on earth.''

title: CUBS REFUTE CAREER CRITICS
description: MESA, Ariz.

title: Officials Study Bank in Boston
description: Currency reporting practices at the Bank of New England are being reviewed by Federal officials to determine if any willful violation of Federal law has been committed.

title: Lenders Demand More
description: Bankers, concerned about bad debts, are requiring bigger down payments and taking other precautions that will make homes less affordable, the president of the nation's largest single source of home mortgage money said Friday.

title: Kathie Strong Marries
description: The marriage of Kathie J. Strong, a member of the class of '85 at the State University of New York Downstate Medical Center, to Guido Schlesinger, a member of the public relations division of A.T.&T. Technologies in Berkeley Heights, N.J., took place in Manhattan yesterday.

title: MINISTER OUSTED FROM HIS PULPIT DELIVERS SERMON OUTSIDE CHURCH
description: A dissident Lutheran minister who was freed last week after serving a 112-day jail sentence for contempt of court returned today to preach outside the church from which he has been ousted.

title: 3 SOVIET LEADERS ARE CALLING OFF FOREIGN TRAVELS
description: The apparent hurried return of three Kremlin officials from visits abroad signaled the possibility today that the Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko, had died.

title: Agency's Travisano Moving On
description: RON TRAVISANO, after 21 years of working with Jerry Della Femina in the ad game, is leaving their agency a rich man to pursue a new love.

title: WOODWARD IN CBS FILM ON ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE
description: In recent years, television has offered a variety of what what one producer, Dave Bell, calls ''disease-of-the-week movies.''

title: SMOKING CITED IN 1
description: Six people, including four children, were killed in two fires early yesterday in New Jersey, officials said.

title: INSURANCE AGAINST POLLUTION IS CUT
description: Costly environmental disasters in recent years are leading the insurance industry to curtail pollution coverage. This leaves thousands of companies with little protection from damage claims and confounds the Government's ability to secure payment for the nation's toxic-waste bill.

title: SOVIET SAYS U.S. IS POISONING TALKS
description: The Government newspaper Izvestia accused the United States today of poisoning the atmosphere around arms talks due to open Tuesday in Geneva. It said Washington sought to ''hamper a businesslike and constructive consideration of the problems on the agenda.''

title: The Magician Works Magic
description: There is a quality about Doug Flutie that can make football exciting in the springtime. That is not something to be easily dismissed. It can be baffling to the senses to follow a Winnebago into a stadium parking lot on a mild Sunday afternoon in March; to smell the charcoal burning at a tailgate party, and see young men in numbered jerseys tossing a football. But Flutie can make it seem as if there is nothing out of place.

title: ZOELLER COMEBACK CAPPED BY VICTORY
description: Fuzzy Zoeller completed one of golf's memorable comebacks today when he won the Hertz Bay Hill Classic. The victory came 5 months and 13 days after undergoing surgery on a ruptured spinal disk that had pained him severely for years.

title: POLITBURO MEMBER AND DELEGATION ABRUPTLY CURTAIL VISIT TO THE U.S.
description: A Soviet Politburo member, Vladimir V. Shcherbitsky, unexpectedly cut short the American visit of his Soviet delegation today and planned to return to Moscow on Monday, State Department officials said tonight.

title: Philadelphia Shop Gets Silo Inc. Assignment
description: Lewis, Gilman & Kynett, a Philadelphia subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding, has become the ad agency for Silo Inc., a retail discount appliance chain that is a division of the Universal-Cyclops Corporation of Pittsburgh.

title: CAR BOMB HITS AN ISRAELI CONVOY IN SOUTHERN LEBANON, KILLING 12
description: A suicide bomber slammed a car into an Israeli Army convoy in southern Lebanon today, killing 12 soldiers and wounding 14.

title: Myra Lillian Jacobson Marries Cantor
description: Myra Lillian Jacobson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis H. Jacobson of Selinsgrove, Pa., and William Charles Lieberman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Lieberman of Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, were married yesterday. Rabbi Joseph Herman performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Passaic, N.J., where the bridegroom is the cantor.

title: SAVING IN FARM AID VETO QUESTIONED
description: President Reagan's veto of emergency farm credit legislation will save the Government far less money than his veto message last Wednesday implied, according to two leading agricultural economists.

title: Jersey Officials Weigh Restricting Water Use
description: State officials say it may be necessary to restrict the use of water if there is not enough rain in March to replenish reservoirs, lakes and rivers.

title: Carl Albert, Former Speaker, Undergoes Coronary Bypass
description: Carl Albert, former Speaker of the House, underwent triple coronary bypass surgery Saturday night and was described today by his surgeon as alert, ''markedly improved'' and recovering satisfactorily.

title: Bucks 110 Trail Blazers 94
description: Sidney Moncrief led six Milwaukee players in double figures with 27 points.

title: 'KICKS,' AN ABC MOVIE STARRING SHELLEY HACK
description: Pop culture's tut-tut school of morality is given yet another exploitative whirl in ''Kicks,'' tonight's television movie on ABC at 9 o'clock. What we get is about an hour and 45 minutes of terribly naughty behavior supplemented with a few moments of the obligatory, almost smirky warnings that one shouldn't do such things if one doesn't want to pay the consequences. For the most part, of course, one couldn't care less.

title: IN MET CAMP, ALL IS EUPHORIC
description: ''A year ago,'' Ron Darling said, marveling at the upheavel on the Mets since he was a rookie, ''when we took the team picture in spring training, I was in the back row. When we took it yesterday, I was in the front row.''

title: OIL PRICES CLIMBED LAST MONTH
description: Bolstered by decreased oil production in the Persian Gulf states and a decline in worldwide oil inventories, key crude oil prices increased substantially on the spot market and futures market during the last month.

title: BUSH, IN GENEVA, BIDS WORLD UNITE ON FAMINE
description: Vice President Bush appealed today for immediate world assistance to overcome the African famine, saying cooperation was required that went beyond ideology and age-old political conflicts.

title: Dr. Ilene Kasloff Weds Dr. W.A. Gold
description: The marriage of Dr. Ilene Merle Kasloff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Kasloff of Philadelphia, to Dr. William Alan Gold, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard R. Gold of New Rochelle, N.Y., took place yesterday in Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi Melvin Sirner, assisted by Cantor Lawrence Avery, performed the ceremony at the Bonnie Briar Country Club.

title: MEXICO BATTLES JAPAN'S MITSUI
description: All Rafael Alkon wanted, when he ordered his advanced Japanese textile machines four years ago, was to make a new type of high-quality flocked fabric - the suede-like cloth used in clothing and upholstery. His ambition, he said, was to become the only export-quality flocked-fabric manufacturer in Mexico.

title: KELLY STARS AS GAMBLERS WIN
description: Jim Kelly, the Houston quarterback, threw four touchdown passes today as the Gamblers routed the Oakland Invaders, 42-7.

title: MALPRACTICE SUIT GIVES MILLIONS BUT NOT HOPE
description: Financially strapped for years, Marjorie and David Grossman suddenly are millionaires.

title: Protecting Charity in Tax Reform
description: Is the right to deduct charitable contributions from taxable income an undesirable loophole? The Treasury apparently thinks so and would sharply limit donors' benefits as part of its tax simplification plan. Fearing large losses, religious, cultural and educational institutions and the United Way are fighting back. They contend the deduction is an incentive to giving. Without it, they warn, hundreds of worthy causes would be forced to cut back.

title: A False 'Scream'
description: Five physicians were invited by CBS Morning News last week to see the film that President Reagan hopes will persuade Americans to deny women the abortions he feels they shouldn't have. If every member of Congress could see ''The Silent Scream,'' he said recently, ''they would move quickly to end the tragedy of abortion.''

title: YEARLY MEETING NOT ALL GLOOM
description: AS the Futures Industry Association concluded its 10th annual meeting this past weekend at the Boca Raton, Fla., Country Club, the mood of most of the 1,200 people was somber.

title: U.S. LOBBIES BRAZIL ON COPTER DEAL
description: The Reagan Administration is pressing Brazil to review its decision to purchase $140 million worth of military helicopters from France's Aerosp atiale Aircraft Company rather than from the United Technologies Corporation's Sikorsky Aircraft.

title: Do They Also Serve Who Sit and Wait?
description: To the Editor:

title: Debt Issues
description: Allied Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $300 million debt securities or warrants to issue debt securities.

title: F.D. RICH AT CENTER OF DOWNTOWN BOOM
description: No one knows better how it all came to be.

title: NAZI WHITEWASH IN 1940'S CHARGED
description: American intelligence officials concealed the Nazi records of hundreds of former enemy scientists to try to get them into the United States after World War II, contrary to a Presidential order and against the objections of the State Department, according to declassified Government documents.

title: SPACE BURIAL REQUESTED
description: The sister of Thomas Creighton, the 33-year- old Arizona auto mechanic who received three hearts, including an unsanctioned artificial heart, in 46 hours last week, said Mr. Creighton would be cremated and his ashes would be saved so they might be launched into space.

title: IRAN REPORTS IT BOMBED BAGHDAD
description: Iran said its warplanes bombed the Iraqi capital of Baghdad today.

title: Linda Ellen Bernstein Is Wed to a Physician
description: At the Seaview Jewish Center in Brooklyn yesterday Linda Ellen Bernstein, the daughter of Sidney Bernstein of Glen Oaks, Queens, and Harriet M. Bernstein of Brooklyn, was married to Dr. Aaron Saul Greenberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin M. Greenberg, also of Brooklyn. Rabbi Max N. Schreier performed the ceremony.

title: TAKING WING IN THE EAST WING
description: There is an oasis in the White House where informed sources do not demand anonymity in print. H. M. Bigelow, for example, points to the grand staircase in the East Wing and candidly says: ''Yeah, the Reagans live up those stairs. Across the way there, behind Gerald Ford's portrait, there's an elevator Mr. Reagan uses to get to work.''

title: Letter: On Day Care ;   High-Grade Teachers Staff Centers
description: To the Editor:

title: RIGHETTI IS CHILLED BY YANKEES' ATTITUDE
description: Dave Righetti has heard about loyalty in baseball. He even has practiced it. He is not sure, though, that he has seen it practiced in return.

title: Rosanna Hertz Wed To Robert J. Thomas
description: Rosanna Hertz and Robert J. Thomas, professors of sociology at Wellesley College and the Boston College Graduate School of Management, respectively, were married yesterday in Waltham, Mass. Rabbi Albert Axelrad performed the ceremony in the Berlin Chapel at Brandeis University.

title: Southwest To Buy Muse
description: Southwest Airlines will buy its chief rival, the financially troubled Muse Air Corporation, for undisclosed terms, a Muse company official said today.

title: MET OPERA: CAST CHANGES IN 'PORGY AND BESS'
description: The Metropolitan Opera's ''Porgy and Bess'' offered not simply changes in cast at Saturday night's performance, but a massive resettlement of the production. I counted 13 new faces in Gershwin's ensemble of 23 principals; and though there was some strong singing around the edges of this fresh grouping, at its center lay some disastrous problems.

title: ST. JOHN'S GOES WEST
description: The 47th National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, the biggest and richest yet, took shape as one of the most dangerous when the pairings were announced late yesterday afternoon.

title: NATO CRITIC WINS WEST GERMAN VOTE
description: Oskar Lafontaine, standard-bearer of the left wing of the opposition Social Democratic Party, won an unexpected clear majority of seats today in elections to the state legislature in the Saarland, excluding the Green Party from representation.

title: Admiral Criticizes Dynamics
description: Vice Admiral Earl B. Fowler, head of naval shipbuilding, has accused the General Dynamics Corporation of violating security regulations by distributing within the company a document with 19 photographs of the Trident submarine, according to a Congressional aide.

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, MARCH 11, 1985 International

title: TOKYO RECALLS A FIERY NIGHT WHEN 100,000 DIED
description: This is not a city with an abiding memory.

title: Saatchi & Saatchi To Acquire Rowland
description: The London-based, publicly held Saatchi & Saatchi, since its acquisition of Compton Communications in the United States three years ago, has been on a buying rampage in this country. It has bought not only ad agencies but also all sorts of related communications companies, except for public relations.

title: Travel Is Curtailed In Northern Namibia
description: The authorities in South-West Africa, which is controlled by South Africa, have imposed new measures restricting access to the north of the country, where guerrillas have been fighting a low-key war for 18 years.

title: BUILDERS FEEL OPTIMISTIC ABOUT HOUSING FOR 1985
description: New construction has started strong, home sales are up and, with more economists changing their forecasts to a mild drop in mortgage rates by mid- summer, the housing industry anticipates a third consecutive year of modest success.

title: CINCINNATI THRIFT UNIT SEEKS SALE
description: Officials of the Home State Savings Bank of Cincinnati said over the weekend that they were trying to sell the institution. It suffered a run last week following the collapse of E.S.M. Government Securities Inc., a securities dealer based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article by United Press International Tuesday on the 10th annual French film awards misidentified the director and film that won top honors. The film is ''My New Partner,'' and the director is Claude Zidi.

title: AUSTRAILIA SETS GOAL OF EXPORT GROWTH
description: Australia has often been called a ''lucky country'' because of all its natural resources. With world commodity prices depressed, however, fear is growing among Australians that the era of easy prosperity has passed, that their country's luck may be running out.

title: Lawyer Is Named Head Of Home Group Inc.
description: Marshall Manley has been named president of Home Group Inc., a subsidiary of the City Investing Company. Mr. Manley, 44, has been co-managing partner of the law firm of Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Heine, Underberg, Manley & Casey since 1978.

title: JETS DOWN DEVILS, 7-1, AS STEEN SCORES 2
description: Thomas Steen scored two goals to lead the Winnipeg Jets to a 7-1 victory over the Devils today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atlantic City Electric Co., Pleasantville, N.Y., has appointed Douglas Huggard president and chief executive officer to succeed John D. Feehan, who is retiring.

title: Marschalk to Handle Braun Appliance Line
description: The Marschalk Company has been named to do advertising for Braun USA, a marketer of household and personal care electric appliances made in West Germany.

title: SOUTHERN: UNKNOWN QUANTITY
description: Lou Carnesecca was not surprised that his team had been sent West for the national collegiate tournament.

title: SHOEMAKER SHRUGS OFF RECORDS
description: ARCADIA, Calif.

title: MEXICO TOURIST TRAFFIC SLOWS A LITTLE
description: Michael and Nancy Jett of Richmond, Va., drove to this American town on the Mexican border today, but they sure were not going to venture very far into Mexico. After all, said Mr. Jett, an air- conditioning salesman, ''That's another country and there's no guarantee you're going to come home.''

title: A Question of Money
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's indoor track and field championships, which ended here Saturday, were the 21st annual. They may also have been the last, but not if the meet is moved to an arena where it will make money.

title: Aloise Buckley, Head Of Influential Family
description: Aloise Buckley, matriarch of the influential Buckley family and the mother of James L. and William F. Buckley Jr., died yesterday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. She was 89 years old and lived in Sharon.

title: DANCE: LOUISVILLE BALLET IN 'LA FETE ETRANGE'
description: There are some ballets that acquire a legendary aura - chiefly because they are rarely seen. For its New York debut, Kentucky's Louisville Ballet had the good fortune to present one of these mysterious ballets and in so doing make an excellent showing for a young regional company.

title: JAPAN INVESTS HUGE SUMS ABROAD, MUCH OF IT IN U.S. TREASURY BONDS
description: An enormous tide of money, rivaling the ''petrodollars'' from OPEC's profits amassed in the oil crisis years, is rolling through the world economy at a rate of $50 billion to $100 billion a year.

title: PAIRS GIVE WAY TO TEAMS AT SPRING NATIONAL EVENT
description: As the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League continued at the Hyatt Regency Hotel here this afternoon, attention turned from pair play to teams. There were 92 squads entered in the prestigious Vanderbilt knockout team championship, which is to end Friday.

title: All in Fun
description: Mayor Koch was portrayed as invincible, unbeatable, incorrigible. City Council President Carol Bellamy, who would like to lay claim to two of those adjectives, was portrayed instead as a spinner of fantasies.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Did Sandy Koufax have a losing record against any team during his career? What about in the World Series?

title: Bank's Move Stirs Dispute
description: The Federal Reserve, already feuding with the Comptroller of the Currency over his wholesale approval of consumer, or ''nonbank,'' banks, has a new area of contention with Comptroller C. Todd Conover: interstate banking.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: COAT OF MANY COLORS: Pages From Jewish Life. By Israel Shenker. 395 pages. Doubleday. $19.95.

title: How New York Designs a Housing Program
description: To the Editor:

title: COMING OF AGE IN THEATER
description: Ward Saxton is a 14-year-old who speaks precisely, dresses like a miniature version of a Yuppie and is possessed of a degree of self-assurance remarkable for his age. He has frequently been told that he is precocious and agrees that the description is not inaccurate.

title: WACHTLER FINDS COURTS LIMITED IN CRIME FIGHT
description: The judicial system may never have anything but a limited impact on crime, no matter how many judges are appointed or prisons built, the Chief Judge of New York State said yesterday.

title: MUSIC: BY CONTINUUM, CALIFORNIA RETROSPECTIVE
description: It's true what they say about

title: 3D TRIAL IN FATAL KLAN CLASH WITH LEFTISTS STARTING TODAY
description: The third trial growing out of a clash five years ago that brought the killing of five members of the Communist Workers Party opens Monday in Winston- Salem.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 11, 1985: *2*MONDAY None Reported *2*TUESDAY Fleetwood House of Fabrics Fluor Corp Nortek Inc Harsco Corp Toro Co *2*WEDNESDAY NICOR Inc Southern New Engl Tel Nutri-System Inc Vestaur Securities Quaker Oats *2*THURSDAY Adams Express Petroleum&Resources Idaho Pwr Trinity Industries INTERCO Inc *2*FRIDAY Arkansas Best Corp Mony Mtge Investors CTS Corp Piedmont Natural Gas Media General Inc Tidewater Inc

title: Cindy Arth, a Saleswoman, Weds Keith Warren Rabin
description: Cindy Arth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Arth of Yonkers, was married yesterday to Keith Warren Rabin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Rabin of New York. Rabbi Jerry H. Heller performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Hotel in Manhattan.

title: OUTDOORS: LAKE POSES A CHALLENGE
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y.

title: REBUFFED BY LEFT, CARAMANLIS QUITS GREEK PRESIDENCY
description: The veteran Greek statesman Constantine Caramanlis resigned tonight as President, a day after Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou unexpectedly withdrew a pledge to support his re-election.

title: MUSIC: MIRELLA FRENI AND PAVAROTTI AT MET
description: The term ''gala concert'' has come to be suspect. Too often it means an event at which several famous opera singers get together on one stage and attempt to goad undiscriminating fans into vulgar frenzy. Musicianship and even normal good taste go out the window.

title: IN HIS 2D TERM, HE IS REAGAN THE LIBERATED
description: For President Reagan, the start of a second term has proved buoyant and, according to many of his aides, liberating.

title: Girl Dies in Gun-Filled Home
description: Officers investigating the fatal shooting of a teen-age girl said they found 152 firearms, most of them loaded, in the house where she was killed. The girl, Nancy Boltin, 15 years old, was killed Thursday when a boy visiting her home picked up a .44- caliber magnum pistol lying on a coffee table and it accidentally fired, officers said.

title: the region;   Kean Assails Cuts In Reagan Budget
description: Governor Kean said yesterday that President Reagan's proposed budget cuts were unfair and he urged Congress to come up with a more equitable plan of its own.

title: Collaborations
description: Giving credit to someone who has not asked for it - particularly on awnings and billboards - is an unusual gesture and worth noting.

title: CONFERENCE DISCUSSES PARENTAL JOB LEAVE
description: After hearing from experts in the fields of child development and social policy, a conference of the Association of Junior Leagues today added its voice to the chorus calling for a national policy that would give working parents the right to take some form of infant care leave without loss of job security.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, MARCH 11, 1985

title: STAMFORD'S RENEWAL: SUN BELT IN CONNECTICUT
description: There may be no prouder example of urban renewal in the Northeast than this city's downtown.

title: Soviet Power Passes, Slowly The Soviet system of government churns with no more flexibility than freedom, a huge and graceless dreadnought riveted with bolts of steel. But the system also possesses the stability of a dreadnought. It functions. Now, for the third time since 1982, it has managed a rapid change of command. Even before Konstantin Chernenko's burial this morning, the Soviet leadership has named his successor, Mikhail Gorbachev, the youngest member of the Politburo and the first Soviet leader in years whose health is not an issue.
description: Still, if the generations are starting to change in the Kremlin, the dreadnought is not. The Soviet Union remains an amalgam of secretive bureaucracies, its policies shaped by a collective of old men. Survivors of Stalin's tyranny, they revile even hints of one-man rule, the brash adventurism of a Nikita Khrushchev. Continuity, caution and consensus are the hallmarks of a system revolutionary in doctrine but deeply conservative in practice. Whatever his ambitions, Mr. Gorbachev is unlikely soon to make waves.

title: OPERA: HILDEGARD BEHRENS SINGS FIRST MET TOSCA
description: THE two most pressing questions about the Metropolitan Opera's much-heralded new production of ''Tosca'' can be quickly answered. Would Hildegard Behrens, one of the foremost German singers of our day, make a great Tosca? (No, at least not yet.) And would Franco Zeffirelli deliver another of his chic, overdressed spectacles disguised as an opera production? (Yes, oh my, yes.) Miss Behrens sang admirably in her own exciting style, with the bright tone and house-filling penetration that we have come to expect of this artist. The voice, however, tended to hit individual notes precisely and then let them go, rather than connecting them in legato phrases. The result was a lack of the Italianate warmth of sound that many a lesser soprano can provide in this role.

title: GREGORY HARRISON STARS IN 'SEDUCED,' A FILM ON CBS
description: GREGORY HARRISON is an ambitious actor. He has transformed his weekly role as Dr. Gonzo Gates in ''Trapper John, M.D.'' into, among other things, a production company in which he fills the dual roles of executive producer and star. In that capacity, he has handled himself not spectacularly but nicely in such television-movie vehicles as ''The Fighter'' and ''For Ladies Only,'' both of which allowed him to exploit his boyish pinup potential. This time, however, Mr. Harrison takes a tumble. ''Seduced,'' on CBS at 9 o'clock this evening, proves to be thoroughly resistible.

title: Gorbachev: In His Own Words Negotiations between the Soviet Union and the United States of America will open in Geneva tomorrow. The approach of the U.S.S.R. to these negotiations is well known. I can only reaffirm that: We do not strive to acquire unilateral advantages over the United States, over NATO countries, for military superiority over them; we want termination, and not continuation of the arms race and, therefore, offer a freeze of nuclear arsenals, an end to further deployment of missiles; we want a real and major reduction of the arms stockpiles, and of the development of ever new weapon systems, be it in space or on earth. We would like our partners in the Geneva negotiations to understand the Soviet Union's position and respond in kind. Then agreement will be possible. The peoples of the world would sigh with relief. - From a speech yesterday to the Communist Party Central Committee after being appointed General Secretary.

title: Seat Richard McIntyre With a margin of 70 seats, Democrats in the House would hardly seem threatened by one more Republican. Yet that's how they are behaving in refusing to seat Richard McIntyre, even temporarily, as representative of Indiana's Eighth District. In the process, they are depriving 500,000 citizens of full representation and inflicting on themselves a wound more serious than any Republican could cause.
description: On election night last November Mr. McIntyre, a lawyer and state legislator from Bedford, wound up 72 votes short of his Democratic opponent, the one-term incumbent Frank McCloskey. But there was an admitted error in one county, and correcting it gave Mr. McIntyre a lead of 34 votes. A later recount of all the ballots by special county commissions expanded his margin to 418.

title: AUTOPSY DISCLOSES SEVERAL DISEASES

title: THE DANCE: CUNNINGHAM NATURE WORK
description: LIKE fish in an aquarium, the dancers in Merce Cunningham's ''Inlets 2'' are fascinating for the way they move. Granted they propel themselves through space, not water. But the qualities that draw us to sea life on display - the surprising trajectories and intersecting paths, the apparent still moments superseded by flickers and accelerations of propulsion - find their counterpart in ''Inlets 2.''
