description: The stock market, stifled by continued interest rate fears and uncertainty over the course of the economy, ended lower yesterday, continuing the pattern of declines that marked most of last week.

title: AROUND THE WORLD WASHINGTON, March 11 (Reuters) - Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger made a sharp attack on Greece's leaders today over what he called the unceremonious dropping of President Caramanlis.
description: Mr. Weinberger called the President's resignation a disappointment and said: ''Our understanding was that there had been a full promise made to Mr. Caramanlis of another term and that it was rather rudely and abruptly halted and reversed.''

title: GREAT AMERICAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $4,007,000. The company said that effective Aug. 1, 1984 it acquired Chemold Corp., a manufacturer and distributor of refrigeration equipment and women's sportswear and Chemold's operations included in the latest fourth quarter and year resulted in after tax losses of $200,000 and $900,000, respectively.

title: Vietnamachtsman's Case
description: The father of a yachtsman who has been held prisoner in Vietnam for eight months said today that he had been told the case would be brought before the Vietnamese Prime Minister.

title: EQUITY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Corrected from Saturday, March 9, editions.

title: COLECO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A.N.R. QUESTIONS CONNALLY TRADING
description: The American Natural Resources Company of Detroit, the big gas pipeline operator, yesterday accused John B. Connally, a former Secretary of the Treasury, of buying stock in the company at a time a ''good friend'' was trying to take it over.

title: Greek Presidential Vote To Be Held Sunday
description: The Greek Parliament will vote for a new President next Sunday, opening the way for Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's ruling Socialist Party to push ahead with major policy changes.

title: Comings and Going
description: Ron Low may return to action in goal for the Devils tonight against the Winnipeg Jets or Thursday against Vancouver after missing a total of 32 games because of an injury and subsequent arthroscopy on his right knee. . . .

title: SHRED THE TREASURY'S TAX REFORM
description: The smart money here says there is no better than a 50-50 chance that the Treasury's tax-reform proposal will pass even in modified form this year. Let's hope it doesn't.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: AFRICAN LOOK One of the more elegant additions to New York's long roster of museums in the last year or so has been the Center for African Art, handsomely ensconced in a mansion at 54 East 68th Street (861-1200). It supplements an assortment of other international exhibition spaces on or near Park Avenue in the area from the Asia Society, at 70th Street, by way of the Spanish Institute and the Center for Inter-American Relations at 68th Street, to China Institute at 65th Street.

title: RESULTS OF PRESIDENT'S MEDICAL EXAMINATION
description: Following is the text of a statement issued by the White House on the results of the medical examination of President Reagan last week:

title: Outlaws Romp
description: Doug Williams threw for three touchdowns, and Reggie Brown ran for three tonight to lead the Arizona Outlaws to a 41-21 victory over the Jacksonville Bulls in the United States Football League.

title: U.S. Position Unchanged
description: A high- ranking State Department official, briefing NATO allies here today on the American negotiating approach at the Geneva nuclear arms talks, said he expected a mood of ''business as usual'' when the talks start tomorrow.

title: COMSTOCK GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings were restated to reflect the issuance of 1 million common shares Oct. 19, 1984, as if such issue had occurred as of Jan. 1, 1983.

title: QUEERS
description: Claude Allen, who served as Senator Jesse Helms's campaign press secretary last year, has been appointed press spokesman for the Senate Foreign Relations Committee by the panel's chairman, Richard G. Lugar of Indiana. Mr. Allen, who is black, said he was recommended for the job by Mr. Helms, a conservative Republican from North Carolina who led the fight against making Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday a national holiday.

title: MAHLER WORKS IN VOGUE AMONG CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: The music that dance companies dance to these days is surprisingly often music by Mahler. Today, the Hamburg Ballet opens at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with ''Mahler's Third Symphony,'' choreographed by the company's Milwaukee-born director, John Neumeier. Later, two other works to Mahler by Mr. Neumeier will be shown: ''Mahler's Fourth Symphony'' and ''Mahler's Sixth Symphony.''

title: Western Union Offers Discounts
description: The Western Union Corporation said it was offering discounts of up to $1,000 a month on its long-distance telephone service for users of its Easylink and telex message services.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in New York Day by Day in some editions yesterday about Texarkana, the Cajun restaurant in Greenwich Village, misidentified the owners. They are Abe and Al ene de la Houssaye.

title: Arnell/Bickford Wins Neiman Marcus
description: Arnell/Bickford of New York is going to be doing the television advertising for the Neiman Marcus department store chain.

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS ;   Soybean Prices Climb; Feeder Cattle Mixed
description: Commodities markets in New York and Chicago reacted calmly today to the death of the Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko.

title: Al-Fayeds Control Fraser LONDON, March 11 (Reuters) - Three wealthy Egyptian brothers today won control
description: of the group that owns Harrods,

title: Robbie's Son Arrested
description: J. Michael Robbie , general manager of the Miami Dolphins and the son of the team's owner,

title: Lexicon
description: With increasing attention being paid to the pollution of water supplies by toxic waste, a specialized vocabulary is evolving to describe the symptoms of and solutions to this growing national problem. Some examples:

title: CONSUMERS BENEFIT FROM UPHEAVAL IN SOFTWARE
description: SOFTWARE publishing is undergoing some major upheavals, the most publicized one being the collapse of many companies, even such major ones as VisiCorp.

title: Judge Delays Order Against Teacher Strike
description: A judge today promised not to carry out a no-strike order this week while the Legislature tries to come up with a salary package to end wildcat teacher walkouts. Meanwhile, Gov. Bill Allain told 1,000 teachers at a union meeting their raises should be held to 10 percent.

title: Church Tribunal Bans Homosexual Ordination
description: The Presbyterian Church has upheld the church's ban on ordination of practicing homosexuals, church officials announced today.

title: STORE SALES SHOW 5.4% RISE IN CITY
description: New York City retail sales improved in February over the weak January showing by rising an average 5.4 percent from February 1984, a spot-check found yesterday. Sales in January were down 3.7 percent from a year earlier.

title: 2 Plead Guilty
description: Two former Clemson University coaches accused of giving steroids and other prescription drugs to student athletes at the school pleaded guilty yesterday and were placed on probation.

title: THE OPERA: PAVAROTTI AND FRENI AT THE MET
description: THE term ''gala concert'' has come to be suspect. Too often it means an event at which several famous opera singers get together on one stage and attempt to goad undiscriminating fans into vulgar frenzy. Musicianship and even normal good taste go out the window.

title: Mexico Pact On Debt Mexico and its committee of
description: bank creditors have agreed on

title: Albert Off Respirator
description: Carl Albert, former Speaker of the House, recovering from triple bypass heart surgery, was removed from a respirator today and left his hospital bed briefly. Mr. Albert, who is 76 years old, underwent the surgery Saturday night.

title: People
ISRAEL'S TROOPS KILL 24 IN A RAID
description: Israeli troops stormed across their new defense line today and killed at least 24 people in a raid against this southern Lebanese village.

title: Bucks in Playoffs
description: Sidney Moncrief and Terry Cummings each scored 26 points tonight as the Milwaukee Bucks downed the Atlanta Hawks, 121-115, and clinched a spot in the playoffs. Alton Lister opened the third period with a layup that put the Bucks, the Central Division leaders, ahead to stay at 59-57.

title: COSMO COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
DANCE: MARK TAYLOR
description: MARK TAYLOR started with a disquisition on the tango and ended up with one on childhood fantasies of flying - with a scarf dance for men along the way - in a program of his work on Sunday at the Emanu-El Midtown Y Dance Center. It was a concert crammed with a wide variety of distinctive highlights.

title: THOUSANDS REMAIN HOMELESS AFTER BIG EARTHQUAKE IN CHILE
description: Thousands of Chileans here and in other cities hit hardest by last week's earthquake are still living today in parks, schools and on sidewalks, and are not sure when they will have permanent housing.

title: CHIC WIFE STEPS OUT WITH STYLE
description: Wives of Soviet leaders have often been inconspicuous figures. Until the widow of Yuri V. Andropov appeared at his funeral in February 1984, outsiders were not certain she was alive. Raisa Maksimovna Gorbachev, wife of the new Soviet leader, is a different sort.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   A 'Change of Pace' In Central Park
description: The sun shone brightly in Central

title: EXUBERANCE KEYS OPENING OF MILAN FALL SHOWINGS
description: This week, this is a city intoxicated by fashion. The mood is exuberant. The clothes are extravagant. Instead of one party for several hundred people every night, there are two or more. Ever since the ready-to-wear openings began over the weekend, the shops have been crowded and so have the restaurants.

title: 2 NEW COMPUTERS FROM I.B.M. RIVAL
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation yesterday announced its most powerful computers yet - two mainframe machines for business designed to compete directly against the International Business Machines Corporation's new Sierra line.

title: IN WEST, NO RAPID CHANGES ARE SEEN
description: The death of Konstantin U. Chernenko and the appointment of Mikhail S. Gorbachev to succeed him as Soviet leader will produce little or no immediate change in East-West relations, Western officials predicted today.

title: Unusual
description: A group of prominent Americans concerned that the trans-Atlantic dialogue is fading has founded an organization to work toward better Anglo-American relations. It is called the Chatam House Foundation, and its board of directors includes Averell Harriman, a former Ambassador to Moscow; Elliot L. Richardson, a former Attorney General; John Brademas, president of New York University, and John Bradshaw, president of RCA Corporation.

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ACCIDENT SPURS A DEBATE ON FAULTY MILITARY PRODUCTS
description: Col. Earnest L. Coleman's promising career ended at 11:18 on the morning of Oct. 8, 1982, when he ejected from his out-of-control Air Force F-111A jet over an Idaho wheat field. The bag intended to cushion him from the impact of landing failed to inflate, and Colonel Coleman suffered paralyzing injuries.

title: Bridge:A Top-Ranked U.S. Team Is Upset in Knockout Play
description: A major upset left a top-ranked American team on the sidelines in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship, which continued here this afternoon at the Hyatt Regency Hotel.

title: REAGAN'S DOCTORS FIND A GROWTH, BUT STRESS HIS HEALTH IS EXCELLENT
description: Doctors discovered a second small growth in President Reagan's intestinal tract in his annual physical examination Friday, but the growth was not a precursor of cancer, the White House announced today.

title: CANADA'S TRAPPERS CLING TO AN ENDANGERED CALLING
description: Phillip Husky, a wiry Dogrib Indian, brought six lush marten pelts into the Rae Cafe and laid them out carefully on the worn yellow linoleum floor. He wanted 50 Canadian dollars apiece for them.

title: CAMBODIAN REBELS DRIVEN FROM BASE
description: Vietnamese troops breached the defenses of the last major Cambodian rebel base today, forcing the guerrillas to regroup inside Thailand, according to a resistance spokesman.

title: EXECUTIVES
Mass Penguin Fatalities
description: Nearly 500,000 young penguins have died in one of the worst mass fatalities ever recorded in a penguin colony, according to a scientist who just returned from Patagonia in the southernmost region of Argentina.

title: EQUITABLE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Evans Stock Dips
description: The Evans Products Company's stock price dropped 50 cents, to $2.25 a share, in New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday following reports that the financially troubled building products company is on the verge of filing for protection under the Federal Bankruptcy Act. Evans, which is controlled by Victor Posner, the Miami financier, said last week that it might be forced to make a bankruptcy filing if it could not agree with its lenders on repayment of $600 million in debt that came due Jan. 15.

title: JOAN BARON, 38, A PRODUCER OF 'THE CBS EVENING NEWS'
description: Joan Barone, who produced the CBS News program ''Face the Nation'' from 1979-84, died of cancer Sunday in Washington. She was 38 years old.

title: SONESTA INTERNATIONAL HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,150,000. c-Net loss.

title: France and Soviet Plan Space Project
description: Soviet and French scientists will soon launch into orbit a space observatory carrying a large gamma-ray telescope in an effort to solve the mysteries of cosmic radiation, the Government newspaper Izvestia has reported.

title: Beatrice Credit
description: The Beatrice Companies Inc. is arranging a $1.3 billion backup line of credit to support its existing commercial paper program in the United States and to enable the company to gain access to the Euronote market. Bank of America International Ltd., which is arranging the line of credit, said today that the three-year facility was a restructuring of an existing financing arrangement, and would allow Beatrice to issue Euronotes with maturities of up to six months.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: DISNEY HIRES ANOTHER PARAMOUNT AIDE
description: Walt Disney Productions scooped up another former Paramount executive today in its crash program to turn itself into a major movie and television production company.

title: MARCUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 7

Shiite Seeks Americans' ReturnBEIRUT, Lebanon, March 11 (AP) - A ranking Shiite Moslem militia leader has called for American troops to return to southern Lebanon and vowed to protect United Nations peacekeeping forces in the Israeli-occupied region, newspapers reported today.
description: ''I appeal to the civilian and military Americans serving with the U.N. force to return to their posts, and we shall protect them because they are true witnesses to what's happening,'' the official, Daoud Daoud, was quoted as saying. He is a member of the political bureau of the Shiite militia Amal.

title: Yankees Now 0-4
description: The Yankees suffered their fourth loss in four games Monday night, losing to the Atlanta Braves, 3-0, in a game televised in New York. Claudell Washington hit a two-run home run against John Montefusco in the first inning, and the Braves scored a run against Dave Righetti in his first spring appearance.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA NATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in January.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: PIERRE CARDIN says he shows

title: Dominelli Plea Accord
description: J. David Dominelli has agreed to plead guilty to bankruptcy fraud charges related to the collapse of his multimillion-dollar international money-trading firm, a Government spokesman said today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;  $915 Million in Offerings Planned by Freddie Mac
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, announced plans yesterday to offer $575 million of two-year debentures and $340 million of collateralized mortgage obligations.

title: The Communist Leadership in Moscow
description: The Communist Party of the Soviet Union holds all political power, centered in the Politburo and the Secretariat of the Central Committee. All the important decisions - on foreign policy, the economy, and social affairs - are made there and carried out by the Government, which is directed by the Council of Ministers. The nominal legislature, or Parliament, is the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R., which meets perfunctorily twice a year. Its Presidium represents state authority between sessions and performs the functions of the nation's collective presidency.

title: OF POKER, THE SHAD AND BILLS
description: All the Pennsylvania Legislature meant to do, apparently, was change the liquor laws to let Pocono Mountain resorts serve champagne brunches.

title: RAISES OF NEW TEACHERS MUST WAIT, MAYOR SAYS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the issue of higher salaries for beginning teachers would have to wait until after a contract settlement was reached with the teachers' union.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary last Saturday of Ralph Ingersoll, the journalist and publisher who founded the newspaper PM, misstated a reason for the resignations of James Wechsler and other members of the paper's Washington staff in 1946. They accused Mr. Ingersoll, PM's editor, of illiberalism, not liberalism.

title: GENERAL NUTRITION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
AMERICAN BAKERIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-After extraordinary tax benefits of $282,000, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,876,000, or 73 cents a share, for the year. c-After extraordinary tax benefits of $202,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,002,000, or 40 cents a share, for the year.

title: WORK OF LAWYERS FOR 'MOB' STUDIED
description: A small number of ''mob lawyers'' have become ''integral parts'' of organized crime and narcotics conspiracies, according to a staff study released today by a Presidential commission.

title: J.F. Thorning, Jesuit Teacher And Pastor, Dies in Maryland
description: The Rev. Joseph F. Thorning, a Roman Catholic priest, educator and lecturer on Latin American affairs, died Friday at Mercy Hospital in Baltimore after a brief illness. He was 88 years old and lived in Frederick, Md.

title: Inland Begins Offer for J.M. Tull
description: The Inland Steel Company said that it had begun a tender offer to acquire J.M. Tull Inc., a manufacturer of metal products, for $19 a share, or about $97.3 million.

title: GENERAL DEVICES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $114,000. c-Net loss

title: NOAH HITS OFFICIAL IN DAVIS CUP MATCH
description: Paraguay eliminated France in the first round of the Davis Cup today, but not before violence had marred the deciding match.

title: ACTIVIST PASTOR'S BID TO TAPE HIS HEARING ENDS IN CHURCH BAN
description: The suspended Lutheran minister whose social activism led to conflict with his bishop and a recent jail term was barred today from a church disciplinary hearing on his case when he sought to tape- record the session.

title: TRADE HAS SPARKED AMBITION IN CERONE
description: After hitting .227, .220 and .208 in consecutive seasons, Rick Cerone seemed to be bogged down in a career that not long ago seemed so promising. He desperately needed something to shake him out of his doldrums, and he got it last Dec. 4 - a trade to the Atlanta Braves.

title: ADVERTISING ;   Good Food Magazine Revived
description: A decade after ordering its death, Walter H. Annenberg, chairman and chief executive of Triangle Publications, is bringing Good Food magazine back to life.

title: KONSTANTIN CHERNENKO, A BREZHNEV PROTEGE, LED BREIF REGIME
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, who died Sunday at the age of 73, was the caretaker of an interim regime awaiting the ascent of a new generation of Soviet leaders. In poor health and only 13 months at the helm, he nevertheless scored some advances in the pursuit of goals previously set by Moscow.

title: AFGHAN IN HOSPITAL AS 18 REFUGEES PRESS THEIR HUNGER STRIKE
description: A 24-year-old Afghan refugee was hospitalized yesterday as he and 17 other Afghans detained in New York City by the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service were in the seventh day of a hunger strike.

title: Computerland Owner Loses
description: A jury today ruled that the owner of the Computerland Corporation, the nation's largest chain of computer stores, must give up a 20 percent stake in his company.

title: TRIANGLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: WEIMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-The company broke even after a charge of $42,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-Net loss after a charge of $158,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. d-Includes a tax credit of $228,000. e-Includes a tax credit of $67,000. Year-ago results include the retail furniture store operations which were closed in August of 1983.

title: CANTY, CITING THREATS, WON'T TESTIFY ON GOETZ
description: The lawyer for Troy Canty, one of the four men shot by Bernhard H. Goetz on a subway train last December, said yesterday that Mr. Canty had withdrawn his offer to testify before a new grand jury because of anonymous threats against him and his family.

title: MOSCOW'S ALLIES EXTEND CONDOLENCES
description: In the countries of the Soviet bloc, flags were ordered flown at half-staff today while radio eulogies for Konstantin U. Chernenko were interspersed with somber music.

title: PEKING HAILS CHERNENKO AS AN 'OUTSTANDING LEADER'
description: China moved promptly today to express its condolences over the death of Konstantin U. Chernenko, calling him ''an outstanding leader of the party and the state'' and noting that relations between the two Communist nations had improved ''noticeably'' in the 13 months that Mr. Chernenko was in power.

title: DANCE: LOUISVILLE BALLET IN 'THE TROJAN WOMEN'
description: ALTHOUGH some ballet companies appear content to dance nothing but frothy divertissements, the Louisville Ballet boldly offered a choreographic adaptation of an ancient Greek tragedy Sunday afternoon at Brooklyn College. Alun Jones, the company's director and the work's choreographer, turned for inspiration to ''The Trojan Women,'' a play by Euripides that is one of the greatest antiwar protests ever written.

description: contemplating more than just which defense to use, or who to play off

title: TECHNOLOGY AND THE THIRD WORLD
description: Extravagant rhetoric about the Communications Revolution and the Information Society has been of no help in solving the developing countries' awesome problem of educating their teeming masses of children, training their unemployed youths and teaching their illiterate adults. In education as in agriculture, the industrial nations' prescriptions for developing countries, even when accompanied by aid, have always been costly, and frequently useless.

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
THE VALUE OF PRESSING NICARAGUA
description: There is a widespread perception that United States pressure on the Sandinistas - including its support for the ''contras'' - undermines the Contadora countries' effort to make peace in Central America. In fact, the opposite is true. Without such pressure, United States security interests are sure to be ignored. With it, they are much more likely to be reflected in talks that could lead to an acceptable negotiated settlement.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 12, 1985 SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Blacks Boycott Classes In Johannesburg Area
description: Thousands of black students boycotted classes today after a weekend of riots left six people dead and at least 79 under arrest.

title: THE LAWYERS CHOSEN BY INDIA
description: The courtroom lawyers at the big Wall Street and Washington law firms were dealt a surprise last week when the Government of India passed up better-known counsel and picked a Minneapolis law firm to pursue its claims arising out of the Bhopal tragedy.

title: BID TO OPEN NEGOTIATIONS IS SEEN
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, in an apparent attempt to open negotiations with the Sikhs, ordered the release today of eight prominent Sikh leaders imprisoned last year on sedition charges.

title: ERICSSON, LM TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Operating results for 1983 and 1984, reported in Swedish krona, have been translated to U.S. dollars at the rate of SKR 9.00 to one U.S. dollar.

title: SCOUTING ;   Change of Clothes
description: The colors were the same as usual when Manhattan College's 1,600- meter relay team donned green and white for the national collegiate indoor track and field championships at Syracuse last weekend. But you didn't need a microscope to see that there was something different about those jerseys, and that's because they belonged to Dartmouth.

title: MEM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for 1984 include the operations of Aristocrat Leather Products which was acquired in August 1984.

title: Mulroney Going to Moscow
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said today that he was leaving for Moscow tonight to attend the funeral of Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader. He is to return in time for a scheduled meeting with President Reagan in Quebec City on Sunday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A good deal is to be done.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev. (A1:4.)

title: RUSSIANS TELL SAGA OF WHALES RESCUED BY AN ICEBREAKER

title: Affection for Eagles
description: Norman Braman grew up in West Philadelphia and says that his ''affection for Philadelphia is something that's hard to describe.'' Now, he says, he has shown that affection the best way he knows how - by buying the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Debt Issues
description: Chesapeake Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of $50 million of debt securities, through various underwriters.

title: 2 Trampled to Death Before Menudo Concert
description: Screaming fans charged the gate of a soccer stadium where the adolescent pop group Menudo was to perform on Sunday, and trampled two women to death, the police said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Mother and Child
description: The tiny figure walking along the

title: DEMOCRATS CRITICIZE STATE'S RENT-CONTROL AGENCY
description: State Senate Democrats today issued a highly critical report on the state agency that oversees rent control and rent-stabilization laws covering 1.2 million apartments in New York City.

title: Freighter Evacuated in Fire
description: Fire broke out today aboard a Honduran freighter in the Gulf of Mexico, forcing its 21 crew members to abandon the listing ship, the Coast Guard said.

title: Tanzania-I.M.F. Talks
description: Tanzania and the International Monetary Fund failed to reach agreement on a standby credit from the I.M.F. to help Tanzania pay its debts, Edwin Mtei, a director of the fund, said today.

title: Seven Bombs Explode In 2 Portuguese Cities
description: Seven bomb explosions rocked French, West German and British businesses and homes in Lisbon and the central city of Evora today, causing extensive damage but no injuries, Portugal's public security police said.

title: Kraft Acquisition
description: Kraft Inc., a unit of Dart & Kraft Inc., said it had acquired the closely held Frusen Gladje Ltd., an ice cream company.

title: Abuses Reported In State Agency
description: The State Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities should stop the abuse of sick leave and the excessive use of other employee benefits, reports of three state audits said today.

title: SENATE G.O.P. PROPOSES BOOSTING AID TO COUNTIES
description: Senate Republicans today proposed a local-aid formula directing more money to county governments and small communities than Governor Cuomo is seeking.

title: FORD WILL SPEND $117 MILLION TO IMPROVE PARTS PLANT NEAR BUFFALO
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that it was investing a record total of $117 million in improvements to its stamping plant near here, partly to retool to produce parts for a new line of mid- sized cars.

title: YOUNG TEAM TAKES REINS
description: With the naming of Mikhail S. Gorbachev as its new leader, the Soviet Union has finally begun its long-awaited shift to a new generation of leadership. The speed with which the announcement of his appointment was made and the fast pace of scheduled funeral rites suggested that plans for the succession had been firmly in place before the death of Konstantin U. Chernenko on Sunday.

title: ARMS CONTROL TALKS TO BEGIN AS SCHEDULED TODAY
description: The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today that a new round of negotiations on nuclear and space arms would begin Tuesday morning as scheduled despite the death of Konstantin U. Chernenko.

description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $530,000.

title: WHY THE U.S. MUST END ITS WAR
description: President Reagan asks the American people and Congress to continue financing the Central Intelligence Agency's covert war against Nicara gua. He says his aim is to make Nicaragua cry ''uncle,'' to bring about a ''restructuring'' of our Government. Here are four reasons why the American people and their representatives should say no, and should demand an end to efforts to overthrow Nicaragua's popularly elected Government.

title: Capitals Get Help For Stretch Drive
description: The Washington Capitals, challenging the Philadelphia Flyers for the Patrick Division title, acquired a former Ranger, Mikko Leinonen; a former Flyer, Mark Taylor, and a former United States Olympian, David A. Jensen, in separate deals before the National Hockey League's trading deadline yesterday.

title: Rasmussen Aims to Avoid the Long Ball
description: His team, Dennis Rasmussen was saying, ignored young pitchers in the organization. ''They just didn't use the minor league system,'' he remarked.

title: South Korean Output
description: Industrial production in South Korea fell 2.3 percent in January from December but was up 6.3 percent from January 1984, the Government said today. Exports of textiles, footwear and steel declined.

title: 7 ARE INDICTED IN BOMBINGS AT OFFICES AND MILITARY SITES
description: Seven people said to be members of a group called the United Freedom Front were indicted yesterday on Federal charges of bombing 10 corporate buildings and military installations in the New York metropolitan area from 1982 to 1984.

title: Bridge:Top-Ranked Teams Remain In VanderbiltKnockoutPlay
description: When the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship resumed here this afternoon at the Hyatt Regency Hotel, almost all the top-ranked teams were in play, but some were breathing hard after tough fights last night.

title: Mets, City Agree To Revamp Shea
description: Portions of Shea Stadium will get a new steel and glass covering as part of a $36 million renovation plan announced yesterday by Mayor Koch and Nelson Doubleday, the Mets' chairman.

title: Blazers Lose Paxson
description: Jim Paxson , the Portland Trail Blazers' all-star guard, dislocated a finger while practicing in Kansas City on Monday and will probably be out for the rest of the season, according to the club's trainer. ''We expect him to be out for six to 10 weeks,'' the trainer,

U.S.-Soviet Dialogue Includes Many Issues
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have maintained a diplomatic dialogue even during periods of tension.

description: White House officials said tonight that President Reagan was extending a ''personal invitation'' to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the new leader of the Soviet Union, to meet in the United States in hopes of improving relations between the two countries.

title: UNITED TOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $164,950 from discontinued operations and a gain of $151,571 from a tax credit.

title: Capital for Mission
description: Mission Insurance Group Inc. said that it had reached an agreement under which its principal shareholder, the American Financial Corporation, would provide $75 million for Mission's insurance subsidiaries. Mission's stock rose 75 cents a share, to $8.75. It was the third-biggest percentage gainer on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: ADVERTISING ;   People

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: TWO of life's chief passions for Christopher Mount, an art history student at Columbia College, are art and a properly made martini. These days, what with the number of black-tie soirees being held at museums and catered by outside services, Mr. Mount's two loves have been coinciding with blissful frequency. Recently the young man found himself at two elegant openings within a few evenings of each other. At the Metropolitan, for a party celebrating the Caravaggio exhibition, Mr. Mount stopped off at the bar. As is the custom in that institution, he says, he was offered the choice of olive or onion with his martini. Several days later, at the Museum of Modern Art's Rousseau show, he joined the formally attired crowd at the bar, where his martini arrived unadorned. Mr. Mount asked if an olive or onion might be available. The bartender - clearly, Mr. Mount says, a representative of a catering service and not an institution that prides itself on understanding the esthetic importance of the proper decorative touch - looked askance.

title: The Shultz Cardigan
description: Guests at a State Department reception last week to show off $5.5 million worth of architectural improvements at Foggy Bottom had no trouble figuring out where Secretary Shultz does his real work. His newly renovated formal office was resplendent with Corinthian pilasters incorporating the Great Seal of the United States, carved mantel, marble hearth and draperies woven to a French pattern first imported by Jefferson. But in his smaller paneled study nearby, touring visitors found a blue-and-white cardigan sweater draped over the desk chair, left there when Mr. Shultz reluctantly reassumed his proper dark suitcoat and went upstairs to anchor the receiving line.

GUARDIAN OF 'THE PHILADELPHIA SOUND'
description: Eugene Ormandy was the last of the old-fashioned conductors in the style of Serge Koussevitzky, Frederick Stock or Leopold Stokowski. Through his career he was, like them, primarily associated with one orchestra. Today a conductor of a major orchestra holds two or three jobs simultaneously, and his resident orchestra is lucky to get him for half the season, if that. But Ormandy was dedicated to the Philadelphia Orchestra and devoted his entire life to that great organization.

title: No Headline

The cholesterol level was 206 and the alkaline phosphatase level was 65, both ''within normal ranges,'' the White House said. The figure of 102, initially reported as Mr. Reagan's cholesterol level, was his triglyceride level, the White House said.

title: Ciao
description: On the widely held theory that Congressional staff members are at least as influential as the members of Congress themselves, the National Italian-American Foundation is planning a reception on Capitol Hill tomorrow for all Senate and House aides of Italian descent. The foundation, which is dedicated to combating discrimination and stereotyping, assembled its invitation list by telephoning all 535 lawmakers' offices in search of those with appropriate ethnic credentials. This census produced 600 to 700 names, and more than 400 have accepted the opportunity to sample assorted pasta and zabaglione and wash it down with Bardolino and Asti Spumante.

description: American teen-agers become pregnant and give birth and have abortions at significantly higher rates than do adolescents in other industrialized nations, according to a study released yesterday by the Alan Guttmacher Institute. Moreover, the United States is the only developed country where teen- age pregnancy has been increasing in recent years, the study reported.

title: Skeleton Found in Seattle
description: Human skeletal remains were found Sunday near Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, the police said. A police group has been set up to determine whether the latest finding is one in a series of killings of women that have occurred near Green River in King County over the past three years.

title: BRIEFS
description: Crescent Oil and Gas Corp., Denver, said that it had agreed to a merger with a group of closely held oil and natural gas companies but that present Crescent shareholders would retain only 14 percent of the company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: What You Get Is What You See
description: So you want to settle in front of the TV and watch the St. John's-Southern game tomorrow afternoon in the first round of the national collegiate basketball tournament. Well, N.C.A.A. Productions, the television arm of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, is fully willing and able to sell the game to a New York outlet. But you can forget about seeing it. Why? Let us count the ways:

title: GLEANINGS FROM THE TABLE REVEAL SOCIAL PATTERNS OF THE PAST AND PRESENT
description: ''GARBAGE is really - eloquent!'' said Nan Rothschild, with a smile at her own enthusiasm. Dr. Rothschild, an anthropologist, archaeologist and associate professor at Barnard College, has experienced directly the eloquence of garbage. From the dust heaps and middens of early English and Dutch settlements in lower Manhattan, to Sanitation Department gleanings from 20th-century high-rise cooperatives on the Upper East Side, she studies the food New Yorkers ate and eat. From her data she tries to draw conclusions about social patterns and relationships that will improve our understanding of who we are and how we live.

title: Township Fails in Effort To Secede From County
description: Voters today defeated a proposal that would have allowed the mostly white township that includes this community to secede from a predominantly black county.

description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced a tentative settlement today in a lawsuit that charged the company with reneging on promised pension benefits for nearly 20,000 retired supervisory workers.

description: The Soviet Union and Intelsat, the international satellite communications consortium, have reached a tentative information-exchange agreement that is expected to lead to Soviet membership, an Intelsat official said today.

title: Peru Rebels Kill 2 Officers
description: Maoist rebels shooting from a speeding car killed two police officers and wounded two others in daylight attacks in central Lima, the police said today. They said the Shining Path guerrillas killed a 28-year-old policewoman and a civil guard member and wounded two other guard members in three attacks Monday. The police said it was the first time Shining Path rebels had killed police officers in daylight in the capital.

description: In Australia, a beer price increase is front-page news. Prime Minister Bob Hawke is the only head of state who has ever held a world beer-drinking record. In 1954, while a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford, Mr. Hawke earned mention in the Guinness Book of World Records by guzzling two and a half pints of beer in 12 seconds.

title: A New Formula For P.&G.'s Crest
description: The Procter & Gamble Company announced that it was introducing a new formula for its Crest toothpaste that it said produces the first toothpaste clinically proven to retard the growth of tartar - the hard mineral deposit that builds up on teeth. The company said the new formula removes tartar through nonabrasive action, whereas tartar must now be removed by a dentist or hygienist.

title: ST. JOHN'S TO FACE GOOD-SHOOTING FOE
description: If St. John's has had a problem this season - and at 27-3 the Redmen have not had many - it has been with mobile, hot-shooting teams. But a review of the seven other teams in the Redmen's opening bracket in the West Regional of the National Collegiate tournament shows that their potential opponents have not exactly been shooting the lights out.

SEXUAL IDENTITY IS PRIVATE
description: Why can't gay rights be discussed without the speaker's sexual preference becoming an issue? In the last few months, I have been asked to appear on a number of television and radio programs around the country to discuss the constitutional rights of homosexuals. These media appearances followed my being quoted in an article about a case pending before the Supreme Court concerning an Oklahoma law that prohibits teachers from advocating homosexuality. The interviews have been a disquieting experience that have told me a lot about society's attitudes towards homosexuals.

title: Evacuation Plan Is Rejected
description: A proposal recommending the complete evacuation of southern Lebanon by the end of May was defeated today in the Parliamentary Foreign Affairs and Security Committee in Jerusalem.

description: b-Includes a DISC credit of $225,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: WORKDAY DINNERS: FAST AND NUTRITIOUS
description: SPEED. That is the operative word for daily cooking chores these days. It may even rival taste in importance for people who work all day but are still expected to put a meal on the table in the evenings. According to one survey at the beginning of this decade: ''The 'perfect housewife' ethic is quickly being supplanted by that significant consideration, 'saving time.' For the household of the 1980's faster meal preparation and cleanup will be critical.''

title: PESTICIDE SCARE LAID TO COMMUNICATION GAP
description: A year ago millions of Americans were turning on their television sets or poring over their newspapers trying to find out if they were going to get cancer from pesticide residues in breads and breakfast cereals.

description: Major league baseball clubs suffered 1983 losses totaling $66.6 million and project losses this year of $58 million, according to financial information the clubs' labor representatives gave to the players' negotiators today.

title: LIST OF FOREIGN OFFICIALS WHO WILL ATTEND THE FUNERAL
description: Following are officials who were designated to represent their countries and international organizations at the funeral Wednesday of Konstantin U. Chernenko. The list is based on information from the governments and organizations and Tass, the official Soviet press agency.

title: PARADYNE PENALTY PROPOSED
description: The Department of Health and Human Services proposed today to bar the Paradyne Corporation from getting Government contracts for up to three years, on the ground that the company had ''misrepresented'' equipment it sold to the Social Security Administration.

title: WORLD LEADERS GATHER IN MOSCOW TO PAY CHERNENKO LAST RESPECTS
description: Leaders from around the world gathered in Moscow today to pay their respects at the bier of Konstantin U. Chernenko, who is to be buried beside the Kremlin wall on Wednesday.

title: Relief Time
description: Earl Foreman has been trying for months to step down as commissioner of the Major Indoor Soccer League, and now his relief appears to be at hand. In fact, it could come as early as tomorrow, when the league's executive committee meets in Chicago for the sole purpose of choosing a successor. Paul Martha, a committee member who is vice president of the Pittsburgh Spirit, is clearly a candidate, and sources report that there are three others as well: Francis Dale, the publisher of The Los Angeles Herald Examiner; Robert Caporale, a Boston attorney, and Edward Hammerle, an executive of International Marketing Services, a marketing-research concern.

title: Harcourt Acquires 4 Medical Publications
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Publications will be increasing by four, to 132, the number of its titles serving special audiences when it acquires Murray Communications in New York for an undisclosed sum today.

title: BANK SUED BY UNOCAL ON PICKENS
description: The Unocal Corporation yesterday sued the Security Pacific National Bank, its principal bank, in connection with loans to a partnership controlled by T. Boone Pickens, the chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company. Unocal said it had sued ''for breaches of contract and fiduciary duty and for deceit and misrepresentation'' in making the loans and asked for more than $555 million in punitive damages.

title: REAGAN REJECTS MUBARAK'S PLAN FOR MIDEAST TALKS
description: President Reagan praised President Hosni Mubarak today for trying to revive interest in Middle East diplomacy, but rebuffed the Egyptian leader's proposal that the United States meet with a joint delegation of Jordanian and Palestine Liberation Organization representatives.

description: Yannick Noah, the French tennis star, denied yesterday that he had struck a linesman during the France- Paraguay Davis Cup series. ''I never touched the guy,'' he said in a telephone interview with The Associated Press.

description: The Senate Budget Committee today rejected President Reagan's proposal to end revenue sharing with cities in the next fiscal year. But in its first vote on taxes, the committee lined up with Mr. Reagan against raising taxes.

title: Ouster Effort Fails in Miami
description: A group angered by the dismissal last year of City Manager Howard Gary, the city's highest-ranking black official, failed to gather enough signatures to force Mayor Maurice A. Ferre to resign or face a new election, officials said Monday. The group, led by Willard Fair, president of the Urban League of Greater Miami, gathered 19,751 signatures on petitions last month, but only 15,506 were valid, an election official said.

title: PUPILS' PARENTS MAY GET CREDIT ON STATE TAXES
description: Tax credits that could be used by parents of children in private and parochial schools were approved by a State Senate committee today.

title: Gulfstream Stops Research on Plane The Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation said it had suspended research on its new single-engine fanjet Peregrine aircraft. The company, based in Savannah, Ga., said the suspension of the Peregrine program, along with the previously announced discontinuance of its Commander line of aircraft, would help earnings this year.
description: Gulfstream reported yesterday that income from continuing operations for 1984 fell 17.6 percent, to $48.4 million, or $1.43 a share, from $58.8 million, or $1.79 a share.

description: A bomb was discovered at a United States Army officers' club near Stuttgart today and defused, the local police said. A spokesman said the bomb, a fire-extinguisher packed with explosives, was in a satchel outside the club at the First Infantry Division's base at B"oblingen.

FPL, based in Juno, Fla., is a holding company formed in December. It owns the Florida Power and Light Company, the W. Flagler Investment Company and Fuel Supply Service Inc.

description: The next space shuttle mission will be delayed until mid-April because of the time needed to repair damage done to the Discovery by a falling work bucket, officials announced today.

description: Levy, Flaxman & Associates, billing not quite $20 million, is acting like an agency 10 times its size - establishing subsidiaries in other disciplines of the marketing game.

description: Senior Reagan Administration officials said today that they were irritated by what they saw as a casual reaction by Mexican officials to Secretary of State George P. Shultz's concerns about Mexico's drug traffic.

title: Debt Issues

description: A Bank of Boston vice president told a Senate panel today that he had received a Government notice in 1980 requiring the reporting of large international cash transfers, but that he had misinterpreted it and failed to make the required reports.

title: Trying Again

description: The Marriott Corporation has called off plans for a $100 million project to redevelop this once-thriving mountaintop resort in Ulster County.

title: NIXON DROPPING PROTECTION BY SECRET SERVICE
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon has decided to do without the Secret Service detail that has accompanied him since he left the White House in 1974, and he plans to choose protection that will not by paid by the taxpayer.

title: Market Place;   LIFO Index And Retailers
description: AFTER a tough year, America's retailers have finally got a break. The Government's recently released LIFO department-store price index, on which retailers base their year's inventory evaluation, has come in at the lowest level in at least six years.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   The Redemption of Wilbert Rideau
description: A free press in prison? That unlikely idea flourishes at a Louisiana penitentiary. It has brought national recognition to a convict named Wilbert Rideau - and raises a hard question about rehabilitation.

description: Eleven people, including two activists from the Charter 77 human rights group, have been detained since the Czechoslovak police raided a private home on the outskirts of Prague Monday, emigres in Vienna said today.

title: HERS
description: THE one thing I envy certain religious groups for is their ability to see the bright side of nuclear war. The Moral Majority, for example, offers some pamphlets entitled ''Nuclear War and the Second Coming'' and ''Armageddon and the Coming War With Russia,'' in which it is explained that Armageddon (nuclear or otherwise) will usher in the millennium. Some of their optimism may have spread to the President, who admitted in one of the campaign debates to being interested in Armageddon, much as you or I might be interested in chess or the return of Halley's comet. A sentence or two later he referred, even more cheerfully, to ''Armageddon and so forth.''

title: TELEPHONE FOR THE DEAF USES TELEVISION IMAGES
description: Prof. Morton Nadler of the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University hopes to succeed with the telephone where Alexander Graham Bell failed - by creating a means of communication for the deaf.

description: Manuel A. Bustelo, the former publisher of El Diario-La Prensa, has been appointed Commissioner of the city's Department of Employment, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

description: Bishop George Leech, who was the nation's oldest Roman Catholic bishop when he retired in 1971, died Tuesday night at Holy Spirit Hospital.

title: 6 Arrested in Protests Backing U.M.W. Strike
description: Protesters turned back a train and rocks were thrown at coal trucks today as supporters of the United Mine Workers tried to block shipments at subsidiaries of the strikebound A. T. Massey Coal Company, according to the police.

title: ARMANI'S DEFT CLASSICS BRING CHEERS
description: In the middle of a week when highly ornamented, decorative clothes were the norm, Giorgio Armani brought cheers with his showing of strictly tailored coats and suits. There were indeed some fanciful evening styles, but it was mainly the fabrics that were ornate. The evening cuts were simple and the designer maintained that they should be worn in a casual manner, much like his daytime styles.

title: TANGLED WEB OF FINANCES
description: It took the investigators looking into the collapse of E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. less than hour to discover that, for nearly a decade, the firm had hidden hundreds of millions of dollars in losses in an affiliated dummy company. But trying to determine precisely how the money was lost - and how E.S.M. operated - has led the investigators into a complex tangle of records providing no clear answers.

title: UPSTAGED BY SOVIET EVENTS, GENEVA ARMS TALKS FADE
description: Eclipsed by the transition in the Kremlin leadership, the Soviet-American arms negotiations that opened here Tuesday have faded from the public spotlight even more quickly than usual. American officials encouraged this move. In the initial meeting, Max M. Kampelman, the head of the American negotiating team, and Viktor P. Karpov, the chief Soviet delegate, agreed on a ''principle of confidentiality'' to minimize unauthorized disclosures and grandstanding and let the negotiators get down to business. ''We are not trying to make any points,'' Mr. Kampelman later told reporters. ''We are trying to proceed with a serious negotiation.''

title: Mall Chic
description: For nearly 20 years now we've been knocking about San Francisco's Ghirardelli Square, Boston's Quincy Market, Pittsburgh's Station Square and many - wow, so many - similar converted wharves and factories. And, oh, the memories.

title: THEATER: 'HAVEN' DRAMATIZES HOLOCAUST SURVIVORS' GUILT
description: ''HAVEN,'' Joel Gross's earnest, plodding drama about survivors' guilt, tries to build up an atmosphere of hushed suspense before unleashing its purgative floodgates of remorse and fury. Like the old-fashioned television dramas it resembles, the play, at the South Street Theater, creaks along at a very solemn pace. When its revelations at long last arrive, we have anticipated them by at least an hour.

description: One of the casualties of the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan in 1979 was an exchange program for young Soviet and American politicians that was halted after tensions rose between Moscow and Washington. The program was created in the hope of seeding some human relationships between future leaders of both countries, and now there is an effort to revive it.

title: LILCO IS BLAMED FOR $1.2 BILLION OF SHOREHAM OVERRUN
description: Two administrative law judges of the State Public Service Commission ruled yesterday that $1.2 billion of the cost overrun on the Shoreham nuclear plant was the fault of the builder, the Long Island Lighting Company. They said the extra cost should therefore be paid by Lilco's stockholders, not its customers.

description: The mournful strains of Chopin's Funeral March echoed across Red Square once again today as Konstantin U. Chernenko was laid to rest beside the Kremlin wall.

title: BRAZIL TRIES TO STOP SPREAD OF COCAINE TRAFFICKING
description: Alarmed by evidence that Colombian narcotics traffickers are expanding their activities into western Brazil, the Government has begun its largest operation to date against major producers and smugglers of cocaine.

The giant food and consumer products company also said it expected to name Mr. Lipson an executive vice president next month.

title: Playing With Fire in Greece Demagogue, like democracy, is a word of Greek origin, defined by our desk dictionary as a leader ''who uses the passions and prejudices of the populace for his own interests; an unprincipled popular orator.'' The term seems to fit Greece's Socialist Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou, who provokes ominous passions for mean gains. How tempting for the United States to fire back in kind at each outrageous salvo. And how easy to overdo it.
description: Mr. Papandreou's latest shocker is the humiliation of President Constantine Caramanlis, the principled conservative who restored Greek democracy after the colonels were ousted in 1974. Just days ago, the Prime Minister encouraged the belief that he would support a second five-year term for the President in a parliamentary vote on Sunday. But Mr. Papandreou reversed himself, and the 77-year-old President has withdrawn. The Socialist candidate to succeed him is a judge, Christos Sartzetakis, who has evidently agreed to yield the few real powers the President possesses.

title: STAGE: PAUL ZALOOM, SATIRE
description: PAUL ZALOOM, who manipulates toys, miniature appliances, garbage and other found objects in his satirical sketches, suggests a cross between the manic pitchman in a Crazy Eddie commercial and Jonathan Winters. In ''Return of the Creature From the Blue Zaloom,'' his one-man show at the Judith Anderson Theater, 422 West 42d Street, the comedian goes after the Pentagon, New York real- estate speculators and local tourism in set pieces that are conceptually interesting but need to be sharpened and given an internal momentum.

title: HEAD OF DRUG RING GETS LIFE IN PRISON

description: Canada announced details today of an agreement that it has reached with the United States to modernize North America's obsolete air defenses.

title: Strong Quake Hits Oregon
description: A strong earthquake rumbled through western Oregon shortly before noon today. There were no reports of injuries or damage. John Minsch of the National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo., said that the earthquake was centered in the Pacific Ocean about 140 miles west of Coos Bay.

title: 14 CORPORATIONS SUED BY THE CITY ON TOXIC WASTE
description: The city said yesterday that it had sued 14 major corporations, seeking compensation for the cost of cleaning up five municipal landfills that it says were polluted by the companies' toxic wastes.

description: MORE space, differently organized space, one's own space - it seems to be the universal litany of the city dweller today. In apartments of fixed size, people want more: they want to have both work and living areas yet maintain separate public and private spaces.

description: Time Inc., which has been testing ideas for several new magazines, said yesterday that it would concentrate its efforts on market-testing one of them, a news and photograph weekly called Picture Week.

title: Buyout of Walco
description: The Walco National Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a definitive agreement to be acquired by Newgen Sub Inc., an investment company controlled by Eli Jacobs, a New York executive. Walco, a New York supplier of electric motors and other capital goods, said the price was $16.50 a share, or about $65 million. Under the agreement, which must be approved by Walco shareholders, Newgen Sub would merge into Walco.

description: Aberdeen Proving Ground will be the site of an expanded program to test antidotes and devise medical therapies for soldiers who might one day be exposed to deadly gases in chemical warfare, Army officials say.

title: South Africa 'Regrets' U.S. Action at U.N.
description: The Government expressed regret today at the United States backing of a resolution by the United Nations Security Council that condemned this racially divided nation for the killing of black people and the detention of its opponents.

title: Korea's Exports Shrink
description: South Korea's exports were the lowest in two years during January and February, the Government said today. Exports in January fell 19.5 percent from a year earlier, to $1.64 billion, and they fell 10.5 percent in February, to $1.79 billion.

description: RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: BET PLANS TO SPOIL BIG HOLMES FINALE

title: ISRAELI PLANES CARRY OUT RAID

title: SOME COOLIDGE PAPERS WERE KEPT IN AN ATTIC

title: WRESTLING ON TV A KIND OF VIRTUOUS DOCUDRAMA
description: YOU may not like professional wrestling on television (for a while, only small children would admit they even watched it) but twist the dial and there it is, especially on cable, where wrestlers are now more ubiquitous than Gospel preachers. Wrestling matches are morality plays, broadly acted, in which very large men try to destroy one another with the clothesline, Irish whip or elbow smash. Women and midgets also appear, but not to great effect.

title: Munitions Blast in Bandung
description: An ammunition dump in the west Java city of Bandung exploded today, killing ''several'' soldiers and civilian workers, an Indonesian military statement said. It was the third ammunition dump explosion in Indonesia in five months but authorities said it was accidental.

title: SBE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MEXICO'S WAYWARD WASTE: U.S. IS UNHAPPY HOST
description: To many residents and officials of southern California, the most irritating thing about Mexico is not illegal immigration, or its foreign policy, or even the drug trade that has made headlines recently. It is an environmental complaint over sewage.

title: Norwest to Sell Mortgage Offices
description: The Norwest Corporation said it had agreed in principle to sell its mortgage-servicing portfolio and offices in two cities to the General Motors Acceptance Corporation.

title: BRIEFS
description: American Airlines, Dallas, said it had asked the Transportation Department for permission to start nonstop flights between Chicago and Manchester, England, in the spring of 1986.

title: 12 Killed in Fiery Crash Of Army Helicopter
description: An Army UH-60 Black Hawk helicopter crashed and burned today at Fort Bragg, killing all 12 people on board.

title: CATHOLIC BISHOP WON'T JOIN SCRANTON HONORS FOR O'NEILL
description: The Bishop of Scranton has told two Roman Catholic organizations that he will not attend their functions because of the presence of two Catholic Congressmen who support the right to abortion.

title: Escape Found Possible In Airliner Test Crash
description: Some passengers and crew would most likely have survived the crash of a test aircraft in the California desert in December, even though the plane erupted into a fireball, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: HYTEK INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income c-After a tax credit of $90,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Debentures Priced By Freddie Mac
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, priced its previously announced $575 million offering of two-year debentures at par with an interest rate of 11.05 percent.

title: CARDS CAUTIOUS ON MOVE
description: Despite indications that he might move his Cardinals here from St. Louis, Billy Bidwell, the owner of the team, has given no hint of his intentions to the owners of the other 27 National Football League teams.

title: COAST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $680,000 from a special dividend on Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred stock. c-Includes a $3.2 million gain from the sale of real estate.

title: BRIEFS
A WRONG WAY TO SEE THE AGED
description: A new stereotype of the nation's elders is sweeping Washington, with ominous implications for public policy. The old stereotype lumped senior citizens into a homogeneous mass - frail, impotent, poor, dependent. The new one is equally misleading: carefree, buoyantly healthy elders sallying forth from Florida condominiums every morning to frolic on the golf course.

title: ITT Awaits S.E.C. Ruling
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission would soon decide whether to permit a proposal to liquidate the company to be included in the proxy material for its annual meeting.

title: MUSIC: STEIN'S 'MAKING OF AMERICANS'
description: IT'S a brave composer indeed

title: THE 60'S LIVE ON A YELLOW BRICK ROAD IN JERSEY
description: A generation or so ago, before ''yuppies'' chased a dollar and singers ''rapped'' a song, people talked about ''commitment'' and were enchanted with the sound of a lone guitar.

title: VARIATIONS IN WOOD
description: VISITORS at the opening of a show of the work of Izhar Patkin at the Holly Solomon gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, could not help but notice that the Israel- born artist was using wood in different ways. In the entrance, left, was a wall made of old Vermont barn wood, there was wood around the painted doors, wood used as a source in many of the paintings, a parquet wood floor, as well as the pi ece de resistance - a trompe l'oeil wood patterned rug.

title: VISTA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $856,156 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $462,134 from discontinued operations.

title: MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
U.S. and Southland At Odds on Obstruction
description: The Justice Department official whose office gained a criminal conspiracy conviction against the Southland Corporation has charged that in investigating the case, ''the Government encountered a code of silence that rivaled anything seen in its experience with organized crime.''

title: Despite Huge Losses, E.S.M. Paid Well
description: While E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. was losing nearly $200 million since 1976, its senior officers enjoyed large loans from the company, generous salaries and bonuses. They also drove luxury cars at company expense.

title: CBS Doubtful of Turner Bid Thomas H. Wyman, chairman and chief executive of CBS Inc., said yesterday that there appeared to be ''no financial substance'' behind reports that Ted Turner, the cable television operator, was planning a bid for the giant broadcasting company.
description: Speaking to securities analysts in New York, Mr. Wyman also reiterated the network's opposition to efforts by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, and the Fairness in Media group to seek control of CBS with the stated goal of ending the ''liberal bias'' of its news reporting.

title: BUCHANAN 1, ROLLINS 0
description: In the first battle for turf within the

title: RESTO INTERVIEW ON GLOVES IS DISCLOSED
description: Carlos (Panama) Lewis, who has steadfastly denied tampering with the gloves worn by his fighter, Luis Resto, for a bout at Madison Square Garden in 1983, disappeared with the gloves into the dressing room's bathroom shortly before the boxer put them on, according to an interview Resto gave investigators a year ago.

title: TIME 1, JUSTICE 1
description: For some time now it has taken

title: MELRIDGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Nebraska Wins, 79-66
description: Dave Hoppen, the Nebraska center, made 13 of 16 free throws and scored 21 points tonight to lead the Cornhuskers to a 79-66 victory over Canisius in the first round of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: U.S. Team Plans Dublin Talks
description: A Congressional delegation led by the House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., left for Dublin today for talks with Irish leaders on Northern Ireland. The 11-member group is due to meet Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald, Foreign Minister Peter Barry and the opposition leader, Charles J. Haughey, among others.

title: SOVIET-INTELSAT PACT RAISES CONCERNS
description: The Soviet Union wants to become a major force in the development and use of communications satellites for television broadcasting, high-speed data transmission and other telecommunication services, American officials and other analysts said today.

title: TRADE ISSUES WORRY JAPANESE
description: Japanese officials have expressed strong concern in the last few days that relations with the United States are deteriorating as a result of stubborn two-way trade problems.

title: Regent Air Extension
description: The Transportation Department said today that it had told Regent Air it could fly for another 90 days, but that the airline would then be grounded unless it comes up with a better plan to put distance between itself and its founders, Clifford and Stuart Perlman.

title: DANCE: HAMBURG BALLET IN 'MAHLER'S THIRD'
description: LOOKING good and dancing well, the Hamburg Ballet opened a two-week season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday night with ''Mahler's Third Symphony,'' by the company's Milwaukee-born director, John Neumeier. The work is an interesting choreographic sign of the times.

title: SIMCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: b-After a gain of $367,567 on the sale of real estate. c-Net income.

title: 2 CHARGED IN 5 ARSON MURDERS
description: Two men were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday and charged with murdering five people who perished in a fire the men had set at a Williamsburg social club last month, the police said.

title: TRIAL OF EX-WALL ST. JOURNAL REPORTER RESUMES
description: The trial of R. Foster Winans, a former reporter for The Wall Street Journal, resumed yesterday with the final Government witness testifying that Mr. Winans initially denied receiving payments for disclosing advance information about stock market articles he was writing.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: OF RUNNING, STUDY AND WOMEN IN PRAYER SHAWLS
description: A rabbi here told an old joke about rabbinical conventions: The rabbis bring a $10 bill and the Ten Commandments - and they don't break either.

title: SEAVER AND GOODN MAKE NICE PITCHES
description: Tom Seaver pitched against Dwight Gooden today as nearly 20 years of Met history unfolded on a sunny little ball park 1,100 miles from New York.

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
STARTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: HCW INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Let them be forewarned: No matter how well intentioned they may be, no matter what their illusions may be, I have my veto pen drawn and ready for any tax increase that Congress might even think of sending up. And I have only one thing to say to the tax increasers: Go ahead and make my day.'' - President Reagan. (B28:3)

title: Bridge:Top Teams in Quarterfinals InVanderbiltKnockoutPlay
description: The quarterfinal stage of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship began here this afternoon at the Hyatt Regency Hotel with nearly all the top- ranked teams still in contention. The team that wins Friday will be eligible for world championship play next year.

title: HODGSON HOUSES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $306,000 for the latest year and $161,000 for the earlier period. The company is listed on the Boston Stock Exchange.

title: BRITAIN PLANS TO ABOLISH ITS OIL TRADING CONCERN
description: The British Government said today that it would seek to abolish the British National Oil Corporation, the state-owned oil trading company through which it has tried to stabilize world oil prices.

title: Anheuser Campaign Stresses Moderation
description: Against a background of growing pressure in Washington to ban alcoholic beverage advertising altogether, Anheuser-Busch, the nation's leading brewer, uncapped its new moderation campaign with the theme ''Know when to say when.''

title: BEL FUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $18,000.

title: WRATHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,396,000 for the quarter and $9,928,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,398,000 for the quarter and $775,000 for the year.

title: PRUDENTIAL HAS LOSSES AT 2 UNITS
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America yesterday reported substantial losses last year in two subsidiaries, including Prudential- Bache Securities, but said that over all its income had risen significantly.

title: IS HOPEFUL ON TIES
description: Vice President Bush met today with the new Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and came away saying he believed ''we can move forward with progress.''
