title: APPLE APPOINTS FINANCIAL OFFICER
description: Apple Computer Inc. yesterday named David J. Barram, an executive at a small Silicon Valley enterprise, to be its chief financial officer.

title: Canadian Truce Unit Sought
description: Israel's Foreign Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, asked Canada today to take part in the multinational peacekeeping force in the Sinai Peninsula. Mr. Shamir, starting a six-day visit to Canada, made the request in a 90- minute meeting with External Affairs Minister Joe Clark.

title: WOLVERINE WORLD WIDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income of $229,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $2,236,000 for the quarter and $5,139,000 for the year.

title: MAGNETICS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. Year-ago losses have been restated to reflect a phase-out of Perfection Electric Inc.

title: PLAYWRIGHTS DEBATE STAGING
description: If the collaboration between playwright and director is a kind of wedlock, as some have suggested, then what took place at New York University the other night was like a visit to the marriage counselor.

title: Teachers in Mississippi Asked to Expand Strike
description: The 13,000-member Mississippi Association of Educators called today for teachers to expand wildcat walkouts into a statewide strike next week to force the State Legislature to come up with ''a reasonable'' raise.

title: TERRANO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MARGARETTA SALINGER, A CURATOR EMERITUS AT THE MET MUSEUM
description: Margaretta Salinger, curator emeritus of the Department of European Paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died last Friday at Memorial Hospital in New Britain, Conn., after a long illness. She was 77 years old and had lived in Weston, Conn.

title: UNITED DOMINION REALTY TRUST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of investments of $141,902 for the quarter and $2,182,072 for the year. c-Includes gains on the sale of investments of $599 for the quarter and $523,086 for the year.

title: CONSTITUTION, 0-23
description: In 1983 Congress authorized the

title: STEINBRENNER TURNS HIS IRE ON MURRAY
description: After staring at the field for several minutes and making a couple of telephone calls, George Steinbrenner emerged from his rooftop box, calmer and more composed than he was in similar circumstances in previous springs. He had just watched the Yankees maintain their perfect record, suffering their sixth loss in six exhibition games by giving the Texas Rangers six runs in the final two innings.

title: P.L.O. Aide Warns on Situation
description: A senior P.L.O. official warned today of an ''explosive situation'' in the Middle East because of President Reagan's refusal to deal with the organization.

title:
GARDENING ;

BALCONY AND TERRACE PLANTINGS: A GUIDE
description: TALK to a New Yorker about terraces and balconies and odds are someone in the crowd will have an anecdote about a fracas with a landlord over plantings. But until there is a problem, few city gardeners are aware of either their own or their landlord's rights and responsibilities. At issue most often are a damaged roof, a clogged drain or a leak.

title: EMPLOYERS GET TOUGH ON SMOKING AT WORK
description: Every week, Leon Lowenstern pays half the employees who work in his New Jersey plumbing and heating- supply business a $2 bonus as a reward for not smoking.

title: F.D.A. GIVES MILD REBUKE ON USE OF UNAUTHORIZED ARTIFICAL HEART
description: Two investigators from the Food and Drug Administration are to visit the University of Arizona Medical Center in Tucson on Thursday to determine what, if any, further action the Federal agency will take on the use of an unauthorized artificial heart last week. David Duarte, a spokesman for the Federal agency, said it had sent a letter of ''mild rebuke'' to officials of the medical center regarding use of the ''Phoenix heart'' in a desperate attempt to save the life of Thomas Creighton, a 33-year-old automobile mechanic.

title: CAPITOL HILL GETS A NEW PLEA ON MX
description: The Secretary of Defense and the senior adviser on arms control urged Congress today to approve continued production of the MX missile, both to encourage a new agreement on reducing nuclear weapons and also because such offensive power will be needed long after a proposed defense against missiles begins to take shape.

title: INFORMATION SCIENCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss from the reversal of a tax benefit of $2,195,900 for the quarter and a tax benefit of $552,900 for the 9 months. c-Net income. d-After a tax benefit of $44,000.

title: IRAN SAYS IRAQ USED POISON GAS AGAIN
description: Iran accused Iraq Wednesday of using chemical weapons as each side said it had inflicted heavy casualties on the other.

title: Black Aide to Bush Resigns; Rift Over African Trip Denied
description: A top aide to Vice President Bush, one of the most prominent blacks in the Administration, is quitting to return to the business world, officials confirmed Tuesday.

title: People Air Has Deficit In 2 Months
description: People Express Airlines said yesterday that it lost $20 million to $25 million in January and February. But it forecast a smaller loss for all of the first quarter because of recent fare increases.

title: READING MIKHAIL'S MIND
description: Now everyone in the West knows my name is accented on the last syllable and I have a birthmark on top of my head. But not everyone knows what I have had to do to produce the illusion of solid consensus in the Kremlin.

title: Roffe Triumphs
description: Diann Roffe of Williamson, N.Y., swept from 10th place to first in her second run today to capture the women's giant slalom World Cup event at Whiteface Mountain.

title: Bomb Wounds 8 in Colombia
description: Two men riding a motorcycle threw a bomb at a police station here Tuesday, wounding eight people, including seven officers, the authorities said today.

title: C.D. Yields Advance
description: Money market yields showed a slight upturn this week while yields on six-month certificates of deposit advanced for the third consecutive week.

title: MEGADATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DOWNTOWN: A MONUMENTAL PROBLEM
description: If, as the urban critic Lewis Mumford suggested some years ago, New York had become so congested that good architecture would ''cease to matter,'' for it could hardly be seen, then Washington's problem might be said to be the opposite.

title: HORIZONS RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains of $4,974 for the quarter and $24,804 for the year from early payment of debt.

title: U.S. Officials Examine Leak at Carbide Plant
description: Federal officials are investigating the leak of mesityl oxide, a ''moderately toxic'' industrial solvent, from a Union Carbide plant in South Charleston, W.Va., according to Dave Ryan, a spokesman for the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: On Busyness TO THE HOME SECTION:
description: I showed Barbara Ehrenreich's column on busyness (Hers, Feb. 21), which referred to the truly successful people as being ''childlike, easily distractable, fey sorts,'' to my 14-year- old academically talented students. Anything that makes them feel more comfortable about their ''peculiarities'' at an age when they want nothing more than being normal is greatly appreciated.

title: TECHNODYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $1,829,000 on the sale of a subsidiary.

title: EMBASSY PROTESTER CALLS CHARGES 'SELECTIVE'
description: A woman facing criminal charges for protesting peacefully outside the Soviet Embassy here says she is a victim of ''selective prosecution'' because her case is being pursued while those against hundreds of protesters arrested outside the South African Embassy have been dropped.

title: NETS WITHSTAND BULLET SURGE
description: In his pre-game talk, Stan Albeck avoided a salient point: The Nets, buried under a discouraging slump, were about to engage in a critically important game. But the players didn't have to be told the obvious.

description: b-Net income

title: ON BUSYNESS
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Oliver Hopes to Stay
description: Al Oliver may not be baseball's most peripatetic player, but he does get around. The veteran outfielder- first baseman, who spent nine seasons with the Pittsburgh Pirates, four with the Texas Rangers and three with the Montreal Expos, has been traded three times since last March, when the Expos sent him to the San Francisco Giants, who sent him to the Philadelphia Phillies, who sent him to the Los Angeles Dodgers, for whom the breathless Oliver hopes to settle down in the outfield.

title: 'THE LAST POLKA,' ON HOME BOX OFFICE
description: YOSH AND STAN SHMENGE, polka players extraordinary, are retiring. The two legends are hanging up their lederho sen. And like most popular music stars, they are having a final concert for their devoted fans, most of them now over 50. ''The Last Polka,'' a zany ''documentary'' sendup of that concert and a review of the career of the Shmenges, makes its debut on Home Box Office tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: New Taiwan Minister
description: Taiwan's ruling Nationalist Party today appointed Li Ta-hai, chairman of the China Petroleum Corporation, to the post of Economics Minister. Mr. Li replaces Hsu Li-teh, who resigned Monday after depositors withdrew more than $600 million in a run on banks of the Cathay Group.

title: EIKONIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REX-NORECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

F.A.A. Investigates Flight
description: A jetliner bound for apparently flew into restricted airspace near the Capitol on Tuesday, the Federal Aviation Administration said today. Fred Farrar, a spokesman for the agency, said the Government was trying to determine if the Boeing 727 was off course.

title: TIMES CORRESPONDENT GIVEN COMMENDATION FROM SHULTZ
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz believes that Leslie H. Gelb, national security correspondent of The New York Times, is ''an able journalist and a patriotic person,'' a State Department spokesman said today.

title: Some Bad News About Belcher
description: The news coming out of Phoenix yesterday wasn't at all good for the Giants.

title: Libya Calls It a Humiliation
description: Libya said today that Mr. Reagan's rejection of Egypt's Middle East initiative was a humiliation for Mr. Mubarak. The Libyan press agency said Mr. Reagan's remarks made him a ''judge of Egypt's policy.''

title: CONCERT: 'BELSHAZZAR'
description: HANDEL'S ''Belshazzar,'' a magnificently theatrical dramatic oratorio composed in 1744, was given a fine and sometimes splendid revival Tuesday at Tully Hall by the Pro Arte Chorale and Orchestra.

title: MOTHER OF FORMER CHOATE STUDENT ASKS JUDGE TO DROP DRUG CHARGES
description: A Queens judge heard testimony yesterday on a move to drop charges against a former Choate-Rosemary Hall student accused of smuggling cocaine.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aviall Inc., Dallas, involved in aircraft services, has named John L. Wallace to the new post of executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: EQUIPMENT FOR IRONING
description: FROM West Germany comes a new ironing board with a built- in revolving iron rest. The rest can be turned to accommodate left-handed people and a hot iron can be placed in it vertically or horizontally. Made by Polder, Inc., the board also has a flexible contraption that lifts the iron's cord, keeping it out of the way during ironing. Available with a cotton cover in a red and white grid design, the ironing board costs $65 at West Town House, 2276 Broadway, at 82d Street.

title: TECHNOLOGY ;   Supercomputer Facing a Rival
description: Supercomputers have long been the heavyweights of number crunching, their terrific speeds achieved by an equal mix of artful design and brute force. Most have relied on a single, state-of-the-art processor that goes about its tasks methodically, bringing down even the most intimidating chore with a barrage of lightn ing-quick punches.

title: Spotlight On Deposit Brokering
description: In a new assault on brokered deposits, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today identified banks, thrift institutions and credit unions that had placed funds through money brokers in two banks that failed last month.

title: ANALOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CHRISTIAN FORCES IN LEBANON RISE AGAINST LEADER
description: Christian militia leaders revolted today against Lebanon's President, a Maronite Catholic who is their ostensible leader.

title: 4 Families Will Pay $585,000 For Newark Water Vandalism
description: The families of four Pequannock youths charged with vandalizing Newark's water supply will pay the city $585,000 in an out-of-court settlement. Lawyers for the youths say the money will come from their parents' homeowners insurance.

title: BESICORP GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day on Saturday listing publicly traded funds carried incorrect figures supplied by Baker, Fentress & Company to the Association of Publicly Traded funds. Baker, Fentress's net asset value on Friday was $41.51 a share, and the percentage difference between it and the stock price was minus 13.9.

title: INQUIRY FAULTS ELECTION BOARD IN BALLOT SNAGS
description: Employees of the New York City Board of Elections who were charged with supervising the printing of election ballots last fall showed an ''almost embarrassing lack of understanding'' of their jobs, a city investigation has concluded.

title: EX-HEAD OF BROOKLYN COLLEGE
description: Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, who presided over a period of wide growth and new prominence as president of Brooklyn College from 1939 to 1966, died Tuesday at the Port Jefferson (L.I.) Nursing Home. He was 83 years old and lived in East Setauket, L.I.

title: THEOLOGIAN NAMED BY RICE UNIVERSITY
description: Rice University, known for its science and engineering programs and widely regarded as the most academically select college in the Southwest, chose a theologian today as its new president.

title: ASTROCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $37,000 for the quarter and $280,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $105,774 for the quarter and $192,000 for the year.

title: IN SUFFOLK, SUCCESS FOR SMOKING LAW
description: Suffolk County's new smoking restrictions, which went into effect last year, are generally working well, according to county officials and residents.

title: FROM TWAIN, A LETTER ON DEBT TO BLACKS
description: A letter by Mark Twain, written in the same year that ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' was published in the United States, describes his offer to provide financial assistance to one of the first black students at Yale Law School and suggests that Twain was vigorously opposed to racism.

title: America, Debtor Nation The United States has just become, or is about to be, a debtor nation. That's no reason to panic; it's not as dreadful as it sounds. We were a debtor nation for most of our history. But there's good reason for intense concern.
description: For the last 60 years, as befits the world's largest and richest economy, ours has been a creditor nation, a provider, Not now. Now we are siphoning off the savings of other countries, inhibiting their growth, while committing billions of dollars worth of our own future growth to debt service.

title: NUGGET OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said results for the latest quarter include a writedown of $333,775 for the company's investment in Standard Energy Corp. Result for 1984 are restated to reflect the discontinuance of the contract drilling segment.

title: CONCERT: ANCIENT MUSIC MAKES NEW YORK DEBUT
description: THE first half of the Academy of Ancient Music's New York debut Sunday had to come as a slight disappointment to the orchestra's many local admirers. In a concerto and an orchestral suite of Bach, its playing was attractive and stylish enough, but distinctly less polished, less technically secure than its superb recordings had led one to expect. Opening night nerves, perhaps; after intermission came Handel's ''Water Music,'' and all was more than well.

title: PAPANDREOU'S SHADOW PLAY
description: The resignation this week of President Constantine Caramanlis, in effect pushed out of office by Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, raises troubling questions about the political future of Greece.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss after net from discontinued operations of $429,000. c-After net from discontinued operations of $805,000.

title: POTVIN'S 35-FOOT GOAL WINS FOR ISLANDERS
description: Sliding on their bellies, the Islanders survived the last 22 seconds tonight and defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 4-3. It was their most exhilarating finish of the season.

title: INSITUFORM OF NORTH AMERCA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $147,965 for the quarter and $326,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $25,900 for the quarter and $33,900 for the year.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Chicago Bulls , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Michael Jordan has averaged 28 points and Orlando Woolridge 23.2 in the five games against the Knicks this season, of which the Bulls have won four. In their last meeting, on March 1, Jordan had a ''triple double'' - 21 points, 10 rebounds and 10 assists - in a 109-104 Chicago victory. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WPAT 930, WFAS 1230, and WGBB 1240, 7:20 P.M.)

title: Poland's Leader Meets West German in Soviet
description: The Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, met today in Moscow with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, marking apparent new progress in a rapprochement between the two nations after nine months of severe diplomatic strain.

title: LIMITED SURGERY GAINS IN BREAST CANCER STUDY
description: A major new study indicates that many women with breast cancer in its early stages can be treated just as well by small- scale surgery with little disfigurement as by removal of the breast, the study's authors announced today.

title: STATE UNIVERSITY LOSING INSURER ON MALPRACTICE
description: The Insurance Company of North America said yesterday that it was dropping its medical malpractice insurance coverage at three large teaching hospitals and three clinics operated by the State University of New York.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch in The Living Section on March 6 about studies of black women's role in American history misstated the number of black Americans who have appeared on United States postage stamps. The Postal Service says 19 have been so honored.

title: The Hole in New York's Gas Tank New York's gasoline wholesalers operate on razor-thin margins. A couple of cents a gallon makes the difference between boom and bankruptcy. That explains why some are so tempted by opportunities to evade state gasoline taxes, which run 18 to 20 cents a gallon. New York may now be losing as much as $200 million a year as a result. Happily, a simple measure awaiting approval by the Legislature could close the widest loophole in the collection system.
description: Under current law, distributors may import gasoline into the state and sell it to other distributors without paying state and local taxes. The tax need only be collected when the fuel is sold to a service station. The distributor then has until the middle of the next month to pass on the money to Albany.

title: Tull Industries Rejects Inland Bid
description: J.M. Tull Industries said that its board recommended that shareholders reject the Inland Steel Company's $19 dollar-a-share tender offer. Tull said that, after consulting with its investment advisers, Kidder, Peabody & Company, it decided to write a letter to shareholders saying the offer was inadequate and not in their best interests.

description: Trans World Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it would offer to exchange its common stock for up to $30 million of its 4 percent subordinated debentures, due 1992, and up to $11 million of its 5 percent subordinated debentures, due 1994.

title: MURDERER OF THREE WOMEN IS EXECUTED IN TEXAS
description: Stephen Peter Morin, convicted of murdering three women and accused of two other slayings, was executed today after technicians took more than 40 minutes searching the drug user's limbs for a vein in which to insert the lethal needle.

title: Language Specialists TO THE HOME SECTION:
description: The article on translators and interpreters (''Business Climate Alters Translator's Job,'' Feb. 14) did not mention the two professional associations of language specialists that have the most stringent admission requirements for their members: Taals, The American Association of Language Specialists, and AIIC, l'Association Internationale d'Interpr etes de Conference. Taals groups interpreters, translators, editors, reviewers and precis writers and has recently added the specialty of machine translation, while AIIC only accepts interpreters.

title: RETAIL SALES RISE SPURS RATES
description: Interest rates surged and bond prices retreated yesterday after the Government reported a larger-than- expected increase in retail sales activity last month.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS ;    Debt Issues
description: Aeroflex Laboratories is offering $25 million of 9 3/8 percent convertible subordinated debentures, due 2005, at a price of 100 through Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: Washington Post Gets Cowles Stake
description: The Washington Post Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 17 percent of the Cowles Media Company of Minneapolis. Analysts said the move might set the stage for the Post Company eventually to take control of the newspaper company and its principal asset, The Minneapolis Star and Tribune.

title: Three Island Officials Indicted in Drug Case
description: Three Government officials of the Turks and Caicos Islands and a Canadian business executive were indicted today on 19 Federal drug and conspiracy charges in an alleged plot to use the islands as a drug stopover point.

title: Holmes Looking for Winning 'Finale'
description: The march of time continues. Larry Holmes got on the scales today, perhaps for the final time in a 13-year professional boxing career that will surely be weighed highly by history.

title: ENGINEER ENTERS GUILTY PLEA TO TWO COUNTS OF ESPIONAGE
description: An aerospace engineer today pleaded guilty to espionage, confessing that he tried to pass Stealth bomber secrets to Soviet agents for $55,000 because he needed money.

title: AIDS Virus Inhibited In Test With a Protein
description: The antiviral protein interferon has been found effective against acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, in the test tube, and researchers said today that they thought it might be effective in humans if used soon after infection.

title: STANDOUTS OF THE SPRING SEASON
description: WHAT is it that makes one dancer in a stageful suddenly grab our attention? It isn't necessarily the star, or even the performer who does the steps the best.

title: COASTAL BID IS ACCEPTED BY A.N.R.
description: The American Natural Resources Corporation today accepted the Coastal Corporation's cash offer of $65 a share and said it would complete a friendly merger that includes curbs on Coastal's freedom to break up American Natural or move its headquarters.

title: MEESE DOESN'T FAVOR SANCTIONS ON LANDS THAT PRODUCE DRUGS
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that he did not favor imposing blanket economic sanctions on countries that produced or shipped narcotics, although he said he viewed the ''objective'' as ''a good one.''

title: SOVIET AIMS IN GENEVA
description: Nearly all the experts agree that the Soviet-American talks on nuclear and space-based weapons will be difficult and long. They have ample reason to say so because too many differences divide the Soviet Union and the United States.

title: STERLING EXTRUDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Pennsylania Heart Approved
description: A doctor at a medical center here received Federal approval today to use an artificial heart that he and others developed to keep patients alive while they await a suitable human heart, a spokesman said.

title: MILITARY RULE YIELDS TO CIVILIANS IN BRAZIL TODAY
description: Brazil's armed forces step down Friday after 21 years in power, leaving the country's new civilian Government with the unenviable task of imposing unpopular austerity measures in order to tackle an acute economic crisis.

description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, yesterday priced its $365 million offering of collateralized mortgage obligations yesterday.

title: Piano at Freddy's
description: The pianist Ellis Larkins is performing early shows at Freddy's Supper Club, 308 East 49th Street, tonight and tomorrow at 8. There is a $10 cover charge and a two-drink minimum. Information: 888-1633.

title: BROADWAY COMPOSER SINGS HIS HITS IN CCLUB STINT
description: -running musicals on Broadway, Henry Krieger, a self-described ''late bloomer'' and former ''jack-of-all-trades,'' communicates the joy of someone who has unexpectedly found his footing after years of being tugged in different directions. Recently, the 40- year-old composer of ''Dreamgirls'' and ''The Tap Dance Kid'' decided to perform in a club for the first time in more than a decade.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 15, 1985

title: ST. PATRICK'S DAY: BEYOND THE PARADE
description: THERE has always been more to St. Patrick's Day in New York City than the parade, although the parade, now grown to more than 200,000 marchers and 195 bands, was something many people, and certainly elected officials, did not dare miss.

title: Japan-U.S. Steel Pact
description: Japan has agreed to limit its sale of steel to the United States - the last of this country's major suppliers to do so, the office of the United States trade representative, Bill Brock, said today.

title: SOVIET ECONOMIC STUPOR
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the new Soviet leader, has come to power pledging to rouse the Soviet economy from its stupor.

title: PEOPLE
description: * Joseph Reiman has been elected executive vice president of D'Arcy MacManus Masius, Atlanta.

title: Reuters-Instinet Pact
description: Reuters will market the Instinet equity trading service outside North America under an agreement in principle signed today by Reuters Holdings P.L.C. and the Institutional Networks Corporation. Reuters supplies news and information to business subscribers, the press and broadcasters. Instinet is a computer system established in 1969 that provides market information and automated trading of equities and other financial instruments.

title: SAFEGUARD HEALTH ENTERRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DEVILS' SLUMP IS EXTENDED BY BRUINS
description: The home team's defense as well as its ice-cleaning machine broke down early tonight at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: TEXAS PROSECTOR QUICKLY CLEARED AFTER LONG TRIAL OF BRIBERY CASE
description: After a five-week trial, a state jury took three hours tonight to find the Texas Attorney General, Jim Mattox, a self-styled ''people's lawyer,'' not guilty of a felony charge of commercial bribery.

title: Judge Bars Promotions In Capital Fire Service
description: A Federal district judge today barred the District of Columbia from promoting anyone in its Fire Department before April 1 while he considers charges that the department discriminates against whites.

title: OF PRESIDENTIAL IMAGE AND PRESIDENTIAL FOCUS
description: Michael Evans, who this weekend ends more than four years as personal photographer to the President, tells of the day he was ''in hog heaven, shooting away with my little Leica with a 90-millimeter lens.''

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Ford Names President Of Its Aerospace Unit
description: Donald B. Rassier has been named president of the Ford Aerospace and Telecommunications Corporation, the defense and satellite communications subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company.

title: Diner's Journal
description: -cultural experience may want to try the special Shanghai-style breakfast recently begun at Pig Heaven, the winsome Chinese restaurant with a barnyard decor at 1540 Second Avenue (corner of 80th Street). Served from noon to 3 P.M. on Saturdays and Sundays - which makes it more of a brunch, really - it consists of two kinds of soybean milk soup, one slightly sweet, the other on the sour side. The soups are eaten with two kinds of traditional Shanghainese bread.

title: BROADWAY
description: HOW is a script guided to the stage? How do costume and stage designers work? What's the director's role? And what trends are developing in American theater? These are just a few of the subjects to be discussed starting next month when ''Collaborations in the Theater,'' a seminar series providing a backstage view of New York theater, will be conducted by the Alliance of Resident Theaters-New York.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   A Display of Gratitude
description: The jammed hallway at La Guardia

title: Testimony Set In Goetz Inquiry
description: A new Manhattan grand jury will begin hearing testimony today or Monday against Bernhard H. Goetz, lawyers involved in the case said yesterday. Mr. Goetz's lawyers said they had notified a judge that Mr. Goetz might want to testify.

title: PUBLISHING: DELL BOOK CLUB SEEKS A SCHOOL NICHE
description: DELL PUBLISHING, a division of Doubleday, will launch a book club in September aimed at putting more of its Yearling and Laurel-Leaf paperback books into the hands of fourth-, fifth- and sixth-graders. In doing so, Dell will pit itself against Scholastic, Troll and Weekly Reader, the three major book clubs intended for elementary school students.

title: Minnesota Paper Has Had Series Of Crises
description: In his cluttered office at The Minneapolis Star and Tribune, a deputy managing editor was describing one legacy of the series of crises the newspaper has endured in the last three years.

title: DAYTON-HUDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: The latest quarter consisted of 14 weeks compared with 13 weeks a year earlier.

title: LIST CONTAINED THE CITY'S 8 MOST WANTED
description: Ten days ago, New York City began distributing F.B.I.-style posters in a new program to bring in its 100 most- wanted criminals.

title: Mexican Linked to Death Of Agent Dies in Custody
description: A top Mexican police officer held for questioning, reportedly about the kidnapping and murder of a United States drug agent, died in custody, the Government announced today. It said a second man had confessed to taking part in the abduction.

title: JANUARY SALES OFF A SHARP 0.7%
description: Sales of manufactured goods fell sharply in January while inventories continued to rise, the Government said today.

title: Instant Replays: Confusion Still
description: Here we are, headed into the fourth weekend of the spring football season, and the way that the instant-replay reviewer has been turning down coaches' appeals left and right is enough to make some folks wonder what all the fuss was about when the United States Football League announced its innovation last month. The score: officials 7, coaches 0.

title: ROYAL DUTCH/SHELL GROUP OF COS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Royal Dutch Petroleum, which owns 60 percent of Royal Dutch-Shell Group, had net income of $2.48 a share for the latest quarter compared with $3.37 a share for the year-ago quarter. For the full year periods, net income was $11.14 a share for the latest year compared with $9.59 a share for the 1983 year. Shell Transport & Trading, which owns 40 percent of Royal Dutch-Shell Group, had net income of $1.56 a share for the latest quarter compared with $2.01 a share for the year-ago quarter. For the full year periods, net income was $6.82 a share for the latest year compared with $5.79 for the 1983 year.

title: AT MIDTOWN GALLERIES, GOOD SHOWS ABOUND
description: IT is difficult to believe that even

title: Con Edison Customers Paid Highest Rates Last Summer
description: The Consolidated Edison Company charged more for electricity last summer than any other major investor- owned utility in the country, a survey by the National Association of Regulatory Commissioners showed.

title: IN THE NATION ;   'STAR WARS' VS THE MX
description: As Soviet-American talks get more

title: BUSH TELLS GRENADA U.S. WILL PROTECT IT
description: Vice President Bush, arriving here today from Moscow, told thousands of cheering Grenadians today that even though the United States would soon be withdrawing its military police from the island it would ''not leave you unprotected.''

title: WINANS DEFENSE CHALLENGES LEGAL BASIS FOR CASE
description: The Federal Government yesterday rested its case against R. Foster Winans, a former Wall Street Journal reporter, and the spotlight turned to a challenge by defense lawyers to the legal foundations for the criminal charges.

title: ART: A 3-WORK SHOW OF SERRA'S SCULPTURE
description: THE Richard Serra exhibition at the Galerie Maeght Lelong, 9 West 57th Street, through April 13, is useful precisely because it is so small. It contains just three works, all 4-foot-tall models for 40-foot-tall vertical sculptures. But each work is a kind of Serra concentrate. Together they are enough to suggest why so many prominent artists and art professionals from around the world have rallied around Serra and his ''Tilted Arc,'' a 112-foot- long sculpture that was commissioned by the General Services Administration in 1979 and installed in Federal Plaza in 1981. There was a three-day hearing about the work last week in Manhattan, provoked by vociferous complaints by some Government officials working in the Jacob K. Javits Federal Building and by some residents of the neighborhood who want to have the work removed.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on March 7 about Asarco Inc. misstated the amount of stock held by Robert Holmes a Court in Broken Hill Proprietary Ltd. Mr. Holmes a Court and concerns controlled by him own less than 5 percent of Broken Hill, an Australian company.

title: WHEELING LOSS
description: National Intergroup, Inc. said 12.2 million shares of 60.9 percent of the total outstanding had been voted in favor it its merger with the Bergen Brunswig Corporation. The company said last Friday that the merger had been approved, but exact totals were not avilable. It said the merger should be effective by April 30, pending regulatory approvals.

title: Market Place;   Technology Sector Slump
description: Many technology stocks emerged from a prolonged slump to stage a rally between mid December 1984 and early February. But lately, in response to a series of disappointing disclosures by managements, some leading technology issues have run into a severe selling squall.

title: Tenneco Reaffirms Harvester Plan
description: Tenneco Inc. reaffirmed its intention to buy the International Harvester Company's subsidiaries in France, Denmark and West Germany, if discussions being carried out with the French Government and private lenders are successful.

title: GORBACHEV IMPRESSES VISITING CHIEFS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev plunged into his new role today, meeting a series of foreign leaders, sometimes at half-hour intervals, and impressing them with his knowledge and air of command.

title: Motion, at Last, on the Budget The Senate Budget Committee's Republicans deserve praise for a valiant attempt to break the budget deadlock. They've finally put together a credible deficit reduction plan. And they haven't shied from reasonable limits on spending for the military and Social Security. The resolution suddenly leaves them looking much better than either their Democratic colleagues or the President.
description: The Republicans claim the resolution would cut $55 billion from spending programmed for fiscal 1986, starting next Oct. 1, and almost $300 billion over three years. Committee Democrats say the savings would be 20 percent smaller.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''With those one or two, we have to slap them along the head with a piece of stove wood.

title: Semiconductor Net Tumbles The National Semiconductor
description: Corporation reported yesterday that earnings, depressed by a

title: SIZZLER RESTAURANTS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
McEnroe Is Balking
description: John McEnroe , who passed up last weekend's Davis Cup series against Japan to give other players a chance to excel, said he might not play in any Davis Cup matches this year because of a controversial ''code of conduct,'' that the United States Tennis Association is requiring all Davis Cup players to sign at the insistence of a team sponsor. ''I don't see why I should have to sign it simply because they were backed into a corner by some sponsor who wasn't even involved the first six years that I played,'' McEnroe said, referring to the sponsor, Louisiana Pacific.

title: Procurement Expertise Is Sought in Admirals
description: The Secretary of the Navy, in a sweeping assault on promotion policies, said today that he had created a special ''career path'' for officers that will provide the Navy with management specialists who can deal effectively with contractors.

title: EX-AGENT ADMITS HE TOOK BRIBES IN UNDERCOVER F.B.I. DRUG DRIVE
description: A former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation pleaded guilty today to charges of taking $850,000 in bribes and payoffs from a drug ring he was investigating as an undercover agent, the United States Attorney's office reported.

title: Yankees Beat Florida State
description: The Yankees, losers of all six games against major league teams this spring, defeated Florida State University, 7-3, Thursday in Tallahassee.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Economist to Head Minneapolis Fed
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis said yesterday that it had named an economist, Gary H. Stern, as its new president.

title: U.S. AIDE CALLS ARIZONA HEART IMPLANT 'UNIQUE EMERGENCY'
description: Implantation of the Phoenix artificial heart ''was a unique emergency'' and ''it may well not have been possible'' for the doctors involved to call the Food and Drug Administration for prior approval, an official of the Federal agency said here tonight.

title: THE GENUINE ITEMS SHOW UP AT 'MAYOR' AUDITIONS
description: Both Mayor Koch and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin showed up yesterday morning at the Village Gate for auditions being held for ''Mayor.'' The musical, based on Mr. Koch's book, will concentrate on activities at City Hall and is scheduled to begin previews late next month.

title: GETTING READY FOR FISHING
description: As certain a harbinger of spring as

title: THEATER: 'NOT WAVING,' ABOUT A COMIC'S ORDEAL
description: IN ''Not Waving,'' that good actress Frances Cuka has an exceptionally fiendish assignment. Miss Cuka plays Jill Jeffers, a broken-down, middle-aged English comic who is rapidly discovering that her career is over: Audiences no longer find her funny, and the dive where she's appearing wants to give her the hook. But Jill insists on finishing her booking anyway, and in Act II, we get to see her stand-up act. For 35 unbroken minutes, Miss Cuka must deliver Jill's frantic farewell performance - an unbroken string of hoary jokes, many of which are tasteless and all of which bomb.

title: UNIVERSITY PATENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
7 CITY CAR-POUND WORKERS ACCUSED OF BRIBERY SCHEME
description: Workers at the city's car pound on the West Side were charged yesterday with soliciting and taking bribes from people who wanted to retrieve their cars without paying outstanding tickets.

title: Stocks Off Slightly In Nervous Market
description: Stock prices closed slightly lower yesterday as the sagging equities market continued to be hounded by nervousness about the money supply, the economy and corporate profits.

title: BURRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: b-Net income.

title: BIG RACE EXPECTED FROM RHOMAN RULE
description: In the future-book odds for the Kentucky Derby on May 4, set earlier this week by Mike Battaglia of Churchill Downs, Irish Sur is the third choice at 6 to 1 and Rhoman Rule is in a six-way tie for 15th at 30-1. But at Hialeah Park here Saturday, those two 3-year- old colts are likely to be co-favored in the Everglades Stakes, and the sharpies are touting Rhoman Rule.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption from The Associated Press on Wednesday with an article about drug-smuggling charges misidentified an official of the Turks and Caicos Islands. He was Aulden L. Smith, a member of the Legislature, not Norman Saunders, the Chief Minister.

title: K MART INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results include a pre-tax LIFO credit of $19,600,000 for the latest year and a pre-tax LIFO charge of $45,600,000 for the 1984 year. Both items resulted from both a higher markup due to the company's changing its merchandise mix and a low rate of inflation.

title: BRIEFING;
description: Order of Merit

title: Nonunion Truckers Smash Striking Miners' Roadblock
description: Nonunion drivers today smashed their coal trucks through a roadblock set up by the United Mine Workers, damaging the cars of striking miners, who retaliated by burning one truck and pelting the others with rocks, officials said.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: I SENSED something was up when a captain came over to our table and announced with a beaming smile, ''Good evening. My name is Tom. If there is anything you need, please call me.'' Could this be the hallowed La Grenouille, the discreet, Gallic home away from home for the fashionable elite? It looked the same: a palatial room with pale green walls, wraparound mirrors, glittering place settings and those legendary flower arrangements in every corner. One still experiences that kinetic rush upon entering the restaurant and seeing a platoon of starched waiters standing at attention and the self-possessed men and women nonchalantly sipping apertifs at the front bar.

title: COKE TO OFFER DRINK FOR EXERCISERS
description: The Coca-Cola Company, continuing an aggressive series of new-product introductions, will begin to test-market next month a beverage designed for heavy exercisers.

title: 20-STORY TOWER SET FOR CITY SITE IN KEW GARDENS
description: Plans for a 20-story, $75 million office building near the Queens Borough Hall were announced yesterday by city officials.

title: SYRIANS WARN RIVALS OF GEMAYEL
description: Syria today warned Christian militiamen who are in revolt against President Amin Gemayel's pro-Damascus policies that it would not tolerate the rebellion.

title: U.S. IS CHALLENGED ON SOVIET RADAR
description: Reagan Administration charges that a Soviet radar system violates the treaty limiting antiballistic missile systems are being questioned by British and American intelligence experts, according to Administration officials.

title: MELISSA GILBERT IN 'SYLVESTER'
description: ''SYLVESTER,'' which opens today at the Guild and other theaters, is about a pretty, 16-year-old Texan nicknamed ''Charlie'' (Melissa Gilbert), who's obsessed by horses. She likes to break them in, train them, ride them and care for them. When other girls her age are working as supermarket checkers or learning how to type or worrying about their hair, Charlie is hanging out with horses. ''It's just a phase, Charlie,'' says Mr. Foster (Richard Farnsworth), a crotchety but lovable trainer. ''All girls go through it.''

title: SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $76,000 for the quarter and $217,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $669,000 for the quarter and $1,104,000 for the 6 months.

title: Delay for OPEC Panel
description: An OPEC monitoring committee has postponed a meeting scheduled for next week because of talks in Saudi Arabia between Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi Arabian oil minister, and his Norwegian counterpart, Kaare Kristiansen, industry sources said today.

title: 3 Children Killed In Jersey City Fire
description: Three children were killed in a two- alarm fire here late Wednesday night, fire officials said.

title: HOUSE UNIT ASSAILS S.E.C. CONTRACT
description: Representative John D. Dingell and other members of a House oversight subcommittee today lambasted the Securities and Exchange Commission chairman, John S. R. Shad, and his staff for their handling of the initial stages of the agency's computerized filing system, known as Edgar, an acronym for electronic data gathering, analysis and retrieval system.

title: NEW RULES PROPOSED ON EXPORTS
description: The Commerce Department, in a potentially significant concession to exporters, today proposed changes that might make it easier for American companies to sell to the Soviet bloc.

title: SPY LEAK RULED TO APPLY TO DISCLOSURES TO PRESS
description: A Federal district judge in Baltimore has ruled that officials who make unauthorized disclosures of military or intelligence secrets can be prosecuted under laws barring espionage and theft of Government property.

title: EX-TENANTS FONDLY RECALL A HAVEN IN HARLEM
description: ''Negroes and whites don't mix. Perhaps they will in 100 years, but not now.'' - Frederick H. Ecker, chairman of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, in a 1943 interview, defending his proposal to rent Stuyvesant Town apartments to whites only.

title: Dining Out Guide: Roast Chicken
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: Associated Ends Altman Talks
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation said that it was ending its discussions on acquiring the retail operations of B. Altman & Company. Associated operates such retail divisions as Lord & Taylor, Loehmann's, Caldor and a number of department- store groups.

title: Account
description: Baltimore Honda Dealers Association to Needham Harper Worldwide, Washington.

title: WILLIAM
description: William Roxburgh Rennie, a Milwaukee manufacturers' representative for 45 years, died last Saturday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Anti-U.S. Feelings
description: The decision to evacuate some American personnel from Beirut comes at a time when anti-American sentiment has noticeably increased in Lebanon and other Arab countries.

title: LAWMAKERS CALL IT A DREARY SESSION
description: Like a soft, gray fog, a lethargy of sorts has seeped around corners, crawled down the hallways and filled the committee rooms here. Or so virtually everybody says.

title: AIRLINES' DLAYS REPORTED DOWN BECAUSE OF PACT
description: The Federal Aviation Administration says the airline accord that brought schedule changes last fall has reduced delays at airports and that no need to renew the agreement is foreseen so long as the airlines live up to the spirit of the pact.

title: VICTORIA STATION INC reports earnings for 16wks to Jan 6
MUSIC: ISRAEL PHILHARMONIC
description: IT is now 34 years since the Israel

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about the Gannett Center for Media Studies at Columbia University misstated the site of the dedication address. It was delivered at Low Library.

Kosar Volunteers For N.F.L. Draft
description: Bernie Kosar, the quarterback who led Miami to the final No. 1 ranking for the 1983 season, said today he would make himself eligible for the National Football League draft next month.

title: IONA KNOCKED OUT BY LOYOLA
description: What began as a haunting flashback became a crushing reality tonight for Tony Hargraves, Iona's senior co- captain.

title: Top 2 Advance In Regionals
description: Andrea Lloyd had 21 points and 12 rebounds tonight to move top-ranked Texas into the women's National Collegiate Athletic Association Mideast Regional semifinals with an 84-62 victory over Western Michigan.

title: Haitian Official Disputes Human Rights Report
description: -AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 14 (AP) - A Government official today denounced an Amnesty International report of human rights abuses in Haiti as ''complete lies.''

title: OKLAHOMA ADVANCES BY 96-83
description: Wayman Tisdale scored 28 points and had 12 rebounds as Oklahoma shook off persistent North Carolina A&T for a 96-83 victory in the first round of the Midwest Regional tonight.

title: LYNCH AIMING HIGH IN METS' ROTATION
description: The ''phenoms,'' those hot rookies of spring, come and go on the Mets in great numbers. But Ed Lynch seems to keep rolling along, unsung, almost unnoticed, the spot starting pitcher, long relief, the 10th man on a 10-man staff, the team intellectual. The bridesmaid but never the bride, people tell him.

title: BIG GAME FOR BAILEY AS KNICKS TRIUMPH
description: The Knicks waited 66 games for James Bailey to produce. Last night, the 6-foot-9-inch center-forward did what the Knicks were hoping he could do when they paid the San Antonio Spurs $650,000 for him before the season.

title: WORLCO DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: AUDREY E. CONNALLY
description: Audrey Elizabeth Connally, a member of the Dance Theater of Harlem, died March 11 in a car accident in West Palm Beach, Fla., while on tour with the company.

title: Thrift Units Cause Worry
description: Long lines of depositors were reported at several savings and loan associations in the Cincinnati area today as the State of Ohio moved to put into effect a $90 million emergency insurance fund for state-chartered thrift units.

title: A TRIBUTE TO A HERO, RAOUL WLLENBERG
description: In an emotional outpouring of admiration and affection for the remarkable Swede who saved tens of thousands of Hungarian Jews from the Nazis in the final days of World War II, 1,200 people gathered at the Sheraton Centre last night to pay tribute to Raoul Wallenberg.

title: CAUSE IN DISPUTE
description: The Government-owned central bank in Baghdad was heavily damaged in a huge explosion today, according to reports from the Iraqi capital.

title: BRIDGE: WORLD-FAMOUS STARS BATTLE IN THE VANDERBILT SEMI-FINALS
description: Many world-famous stars were involved in the semifinal stage of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship at the Hyatt Regency Hotel here today. When play in the event ends Friday night, the winners will not only collect a title that has been much prized for more than a half century but also qualify to represent the United States in world play next year.

title: ACMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Army Defends Safety Of Black Hawk Copter
description: The Army defended the safety of its UH-60 Black Hawk helicopter today, despite a crash Wednesday that killed 12 soldiers, bringing total deaths associated with the aircraft to 34 in four years.

title: APOLOGY TO SEARCHED STUDENTS
description: James L. Powell, president of Franklin and Marshall College, has apologized to students for a search of all dormitory rooms by campus security guards who were looking for violations of health and safety regulations and for missing property.

title: SHULTZ, IN ICELAND, IS SAID TO DISCUSS ARMS DISPUTE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz made an unscheduled stop here today for talks that were said to have included discussions of a controversy over reported American contingency plans to station nuclear arms in Iceland.

title: CHURCHES ON CUTTING EDGE OF THE APARTHEID BATTLE
description: At a recent mass meeting in Soweto at which the intent was overtly political, the proceedings were opened by a black cleric who offered, amid the clenched-fist salutes and cries of ''Amandla!'' or ''Power!'' a prayer for ''those who subvert the system.''

title: PEP BOYS, MANNY, MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
Blues Lose Center
description: Doug Wickenheiser , a center for the Blues, was struck by a car during a team outing in a St. Louis suburb Wednesday night, and yesterday, after he underwent surgery to repair ligament damage to his left knee, the club said the 25-year-old player would be out for the rest of the season. Coach

title: A State Law on Prayer In School Is Overruled
description: A Federal district judge today struck down West Virginia's school prayer law as unconstitutional.

description: League clung to life yesterday

title: SPECIALISTS SAY 'STAR WARS' IS KEY TO ARMS TALKS
description: A group of non-Government specialists in Soviet affairs told Congress today that it was highly unlikely that the Soviet Union would agree to significant reductions in nuclear arsenals if the United States refused to bargain over the concept of a space-based defensive shield against nuclear missiles.

title: Jacobs, Castle
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, filed a complaint with the Securities and Exchange Commission over the proposed acquisition of Castle & Cooke Inc. by the Flexi-Van Corporation. Castle & Cooke, the financially troubled food and real estate company, said that it would not comment on the complaint. Mr. Jacobs, who is president and chief executive of Minstar Inc., said an investment group he heads had been ignored in its effort to bid for Castle & Cooke. Mr. Jacobs and his group own 12 percent of the company's shares. Flexi-Van's proposed merger was announced Tuesday.

title: UNITED STOCKYARDS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said results are reported on a pro forma basis to reflect the elimination of management fees charged to the United Stockyards by its former parent, Canal-Randolph Corp., prior to a June 1, 1984 spin-off from Canal-Randolph.

title: U.S. REDUCES STAFF AT BEIRUT EMBASSY
description: The United States said today that it had temporarily withdrawn some of its embassy employees from Lebanon because of the worsening security situation there.

description: a New York agency that specializes in what it calls special-

title: All-Star Trio Performs
description: The pianist Monty Alexander is appearing at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, in a rare engagement, through Sunday.

title: Jazz Trio in Concert
description: The jazz pianist Steve Cohn will lead a trio that includes the bassist Reggie Workman and the percussionist Chuck Fertal in a concert at Cooper Union's Great Hall, Seventh Street between Third and Fourth Avenues, tonight at 8. Admission is free.

title: OVEROPTIMISM ON BABY FAE CITED
description: Doctors who implanted a baboon heart in an infant informed her parents of the risks and alternatives adequately but overstated the baby's chance for survival, according to a Federal report.

description: In today's world, there is no way that we can

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 15, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: RIVERS SPARKS NOTRE DAME
description: It is a relatively new concept at Notre Dame, which had been a pickup truck among college basketball teams - sturdy, dependable, built to last, but not particularly fast. David Rivers, however, has given the Fighting Irish an element of speed and quickness they have been lacking and is the reason why tonight marked a continuation and not the end of Notre Dame's season.

title: ITT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $10,200,000 from the sale of tax-exempt securities. The company is a unit of ITT Corp.

title: JAMAICA WATER PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $482,000 from the early retirement of debt. The company said results for the latest year have been restated to reflect a consolidation of Broadway Maintenance Corp. which was previously carried on the equity method of accounting and includes the results of Eastern States-Kahn Electric Inc. since the date of acquisition.

title: Day-Care and Public-School Teachers, Unite
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Share Lead on 68's
description: Fighting blustery winds and rain, Pat Bradley and Jane Crafter tied for the lead with five-under-par 68's today after the first round of the $300,000 Women's Kemper Open golf tournament.

title: Brazil Becomes Still More Special Today the number of South Americans liberated from military rule since 1979 triples. During the last six years some 65 million South Americans regained civilian government. Now, with the inauguration of President Tancredo Neves, they are joined by 130 million Brazilians.
description: The new Brazilian administration inherits some difficult problems from two decades of military rule. The best known is economic, a $100 billion external debt. But there is a sociological problem that's probably just as difficult: the gulf between the newly affluent, largely white, industrial South, and the desperately poor, black, agricultural Northeast. Nonetheless, President Neves also begins with some bright prospects for success.

title: AUCTIONS
description: through 18th-century Japanese armor, acquired in Osaka at the turn of the century by an unidentified American, will be exhibited this weekend before their sale next week at Christie's.

title: New Roach Killer In Disk Form
description: A seminar on debugging in Washington does not sound too unusual. Except in this particular case it has less to do with electronic eavesdropping than it does with killing roaches.

title: 2 New Comedy Series Beginning on ABC Tonight
description: Television being a modern medium that traffics largely in established arts and forms, it comes as no surprise to discover that the two new comedy series starting tonight on ABC are constructed of familiar materials.

title: Rockcor Plan
description: Rockcor Inc. said that it had instructed Dillon, Read & Company, its investment banker, to pursue the possible sale of the company, a producer of rocket systems and gas generators. Rockcor, based in Redmond, Wash., said a sale would thwart the efforts of a group headed by N. Norman Muller, a New York investor, to win control of the company.

title: TELESCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $344,000 for the quarter and $1,318,000 for the year. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $2,921,988 for the quarter and $7,646,988 for the year.

title: BRAINTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: During the year-ago quarter and 9 month periods, Braintech was in its development stage.

National-Bergen
description: National Intergroup Inc. said 12.2 million shares, or 60.9 percent of the total outstanding, had been voted in favor of its merger with the Bergen Brunswig Corporation. The company said last Friday that the merger had been approved, but exact totals were not available. It said the merger should be effective by April 30, pending regulatory approvals.

title: SCREEN: 'CAMILA,' STORY OF LOVE IN ARGENTINA
description: IN 1847, when Argentina was

title: A MAN WITHOUT ENEMIES OR SECRETS
description: Ever since Ambassador Jose Luis Fernandes Lopes of the Republic of Cape Verde arrived here on Embassy Row he has been emigrating, in a way, to the middle-American dictatorship of Yuppiedom.

title: MINNESOTA JUDGE TO LEAD INQUIRY
description: A special judge was appointed today by Gov. Rudy Perpich to investigate allegations of misconduct against the district attorney who pressed charges against 24 people in Jordan, Minn., in a case involving the sexual abuse of children. Most of the charges were subsequently dropped.

title: So Far, So Good
description: Note from Sun City, Ariz.: Yutaka Enatsu, the 36-year-old pitcher who is trying to become only the second Japanese player in history to stick with a major league club, made his exhibition debut Wednesday, and nobody could have asked for more. Working two innings in the Milwaukee Brewers' game against the San Francisco Giants, Enatsu walked one batter but retired all the others, two of them on strikeouts. Stay tuned.

title: F.C.C. ALTERS ITS RUE ON FM LICENSING
description: The Federal Communications Commission today adopted by a 4-to-1 vote a rule change that gives daytime-only AM radio station owners special consideration in competing for some 689 new FM broadcast licenses.

title: REFUGEES HELD BY U.S. STOP HUNGER STRIKE AFTER 10 DAYS
description: Eighteen Afghan refugees ended a hunger strike yesterday after 10 days without gaining either political asylum or their release from detention.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SENDS TWO OFFICIALS TO MOZAMBIQUE
description: Two senior South African Cabinet ministers flew to neighboring Mozambique today in an effort to rescue a faltering nonaggression pact that appears threatened by collapse just a year after it was signed.

title: DANCE: HAMBURG BALLET, IN BROOKLYN
description: LIFE is not simple and choreographers have a way of complicating it further. As illustration, we have John Neumeier's dance interpretation of the Tristan and Isolde story and Maurice Bejart's treatment of Eug ene Ionesco's play, ''The Chairs.'' Along with Mr. Neumeier's ballet, ''Bach Suite No. 3,'' on Wednesday night, all these New York premieres made up the Hamburg Ballet's first mixed bill of the season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: STUDY FINDS BLACKS' ENGLISH INCREASINGLY DIFFERENT
description: Contrary to expectations, the form of English spoken by many black Americans is becoming more different from standard English rather than more like it, a study by linguists at the University of Pennsylvania suggests.

title: ARSON FATAL TO 5 AT CLUB IS LAID TO DEBT DISPUTE
description: A longstanding dispute over a $500 debt was apparently the motive for an arson fire that killed five people in a social club in Brooklyn last month, the police said yesterday.

title: Royal Dutch Net Dips 23%
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said today that fourth-quarter net earnings fell 23 percent, to $1.1 billion, from $1.44 billion in 1983.

title: NORTH ATLANTIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
'GREAT PERFORMANCES' PRESENTS VERDI'S 'RIGOLETTO'
description: THE advertisements and promotion for tonight's ''Great Performances'' presentation of Giuseppe Verdi's ''Rigoletto,'' on Channel 13 at 9 o' clock, are proclaiming the appearance of Luciano Pavarotti as the Duke of Mantua. Mr. Pavarotti does indeed turn in an impressive performance. But the star of the production is Jean-Pierre Ponnelle, the director-designer whose stage and television work has brought a new and grandly colorful vitality to opera interpretations. An announcer exaggerates only slightly when he declares that ''no major opera house would think of being without a Ponnelle staging.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
NEWS SUMMARY;
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 15, 1985 International

title: U.S. AND SOVIET NEGOTIATORS OPEN NUCLEAR ARMS TALKS
description: United States and Soviet arms negotiators outlined their opening positions on nuclear and space weapons today in an exchange that was said to have left the Americans encouraged about the ultimate prospects for an agreement.

title: 22 G.O.P. SENATORS PRESSED TO BACK REAGAN PROGRAMS
description: White House officials said today that Republican senators up for re-election in 1986 were being informed that President Reagan's involvement in their campaigns would be limited unless they supported Administration programs.

title: Acid Rain to be Issue
description: Canadian officials said today they expect this weekend's meeting between President Reagan and Prime Minister Mulroney to achieve progress on cleaning up acid rain.

title: CALIBRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
French Will Bolster Guadeloupe Forces
description: -A-PITRE, Guadeloupe, March 14 (AP) - France said today that it was sending 60 paramilitary policemen to bolster security forces in Guadeloupe, where a bomb attack Wednesday killed one person and wounded 11, including four Americans.

title: Deere Cutbacks
description: Deere & Company said that because of lessened production requirements for large tractors and combines, it would reduce its salaried work force in East Moline, Ill., and Waterloo, Iowa, by 600. The reductions, which amount to 5 percent of Deere's salaried employees in North America, would be achieved through ''special early retirements, layoffs and voluntary and involuntary separations,'' said the farm equipment manufacturer, which is based in Moline, Ill.

title: SENATOR WARNS ON MAIL COSTS
description: Saying ''economy should begin at home,'' Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr. of Maryland urged his colleagues in Congress today to severely restrict their mass mailings to constituents.

title: City Gallery to Be Open Six Days During Week
description: Starting tomorrow, the City Gallery at 2 Columbus Circle, will be open Saturdays, as the result of a grant from R. H. Macy & Company.

title: 'GOOD NEWS' AIN'T HARD TO HEAR
description: Senator Jesse Helms's attempt to organize a takeover of CBS is based on the idea that the national media are not giving a fair shake to conservative views. This happens, the North Carolina Republican said, because the people in charge of producing the news are ''men and women who, if they do not hate American virtues, certainly have a smug contempt for American ideals and principles.'' Translate that as ''East Coast liberals.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Spy in the Sky Finds Water - and Money
description: When the city deployed spy aircraft on reconnaissance missions over covert installations, they didn't come back with pictures of ICBM silos.

title: Ex-Minnesota Governor Dies
description: Elmer A. Benson, a lifelong critic of capitalism who served one term as Governor in the 1930's, died Wednesday. He was 89.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   What to Do About Crime: The Theory
description: The five panelists at the forum on

title: Argentine Senate Backs Beagle Channel Treaty
description: The Argentine Senate approved the Beagle Channel treaty with Chile today. The vote was 23 to 22, with 1 abstention.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: FOR Manhattan moviegoers, today is a day of plenty. On the block bounded by 83d and 84th Streets on Broadway, two theaters housing 10 auditoriums will beckon. Four of the 10 are in Loews 83d Street Quad, which first opened as an ornate movie palace on Oct. 12, 1921. And six are right next door at the new Loews 84th Street Six, where the doors open for the first time today with three attractions - ''Mask,'' ''Lost in America'' and ''Into the Night.''

title: Money Laundering Charge
description: David Gould, a New York businessman, has been charged with trying to launder about $1 million in cash through the British West Indies, the Customs Service said yesterday.

title: BRIEFING
description: Men Only

title: A BROADWAY PROJECT, ZECKENDORF-STYLE
description: It may be that no developer in the city has more projects in various stages of planning and execution than William Zeckendorf Jr.

title: PHILHARMONIC: BEETHOVEN'S 'EGMONT'
description: THE overture that Beethoven wrote for Goethe's ''Egmont'' is a concert staple, but the incidental music that follows it, like the Goethe drama itself, does not turn up very often. Erich Leinsdorf, who led the New York Philharmonic in a performance of the Beethoven score last night, has long campaigned to bring the work into more general circulation, which it certainly deserves. Though the ''Egmont'' music may sound at times like rejected material from ''Fidelio,'' it can add up to a rousing three-quarters of an hour when dealt with as affectionately as it was this time.

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA WATER CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SCOA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
BELGIUM SAID TO APPROVE MISSILES
description: Belgium will deploy 48 NATO cruise missiles on schedule, and the first 16 could be in place by the end of this month, Government sources said today.

title: Ramirez Wins
description: In an impressive tune-up for a title defense against Hector Camacho, Jose Luis Ramirez, the World Boxing Council lightweight champion, scored a fourth-round knockout over J. T. Walker in a non-title bout Wednesday night.

description: b-After refunds of real estate taxes paid in prior years amounting to $50,434 for the 6 months, and a reduction for professional expenses related to management's opposition to a tender offer for the company's common stock and related litigation of $420,919 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income which includes a gain of $1,488,938 from the sale of the company's Massapequa, New York shopping center property and refunds of real estate taxes paid in prior years of $536,783.

title: DYNAMICS' BILLING PRACTICES TERMED NOT TYPICAL
description: Deputy Secretary of Defense William H. Taft 4th told a Congressional panel today that the billing practices of the General Dynamics Corporation were not typical of other military contractors, but some of the Congressmen questioned whether billing irregularities were industrywide.

title: PENSION FREEZE VOTED IN SENATE DIVIDES PARTIES
description: The Senate's Republican and Democratic leaders split today over a proposal to drop next year's cost-of-living increase in Social Security benefits. The split indicated that the issue would be hard- fought in the Congressional budget debate and perhaps in next year's campaign for control of the Senate.

title: Atomic Plant at Capacity
description: The $5.4 billion nuclear power plant at Diablo Canyon generated electricity at its full capacity of 10.1 megawatts Wednesday for the first time, its operator, the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, reported. The plant has had technical problems and faced legal challenges through most of its 15 years.

title: Bond Rating Unit Planned in Japan
description: A number of Japanese banks and research departments of Japanese securities firms will set up a bond rating agency on April 25 to help liberalize the capital market, an Industrial Bank of Japan spokesman said today.

title: Deterrence Is the Heart of U.S. Defense Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Navy Approves Fleet for S.I.
description: The Navy gave final approval today to a plan that would make Staten Island the home port for the battleship Iowa and six other Navy vessels. Money for the base must still be approved by Congress.

title: N.F.L. Sets Sites Of 2 Super Bowls
description: The National Football League owners voted today to award Super Bowl XXIII in 1989 to Miami and the next year's game to New Orleans.

title: Doctor Says That Schroeder Will Miss His Son's Wedding
description: Dr. William C. DeVries says that William J. Schroeder, who has an artificial heart, is not healthy enough to fulfill his goal of attending his son's wedding Saturday, according to Mr. Schroeder's hometown physician.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bill Walsh, head coach of the San Francisco 49ers, has been given a raise after leading his team to its second Super Bowl victory in five years. The owner,

title: Treasury Bond Futures
description: The Chicago Board of Trade said today that it would submit an application to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission on Friday to list zero coupon Treasury bond futures. Delivery will be in zero coupon bonds, and will feature a trading month cycle and price quotations identical to the existing Chicago Board of Trade contract in Treasury bond futures, the exchange said.

title: Money Supply Off; Rates Rise
description: The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that the basic measure of the nation's money supply fell by $400 million in the week ended March 4.

title: STUDY SAYS REAGAN'S CUTS IN AID TO POOR AFFECTED SOUTH THE MOST
description: Reductions by the Reagan Administration in Federal aid to the poor have taken their greatest toll in the South, reducing the Government welfare rolls by about 1.4 million people since 1980, according to a study released here today.

title: A WELCOME START
description: GENEVA President Reagan has invited Mikhail Gorbachev to a summit meeting, apparently without the precondition of a nearly completed agreement, which was set for the three previous Soviet leaders since Mr. Reagan has been in the White House.

title: Friday A DIFFERENT DRUMMER
description: A contemporary opera that exists on records in Walloon - a French dialect spoken in southern Belgium - and that has not been seen in New York since its premiere in 1959, will be performed tonight, Saturday and Sunday by the Center for Contemporary Opera. The opera, Robert Kurka's ''Good Soldier Schweik,'' is based on the Czechoslovak novel by Jaroslav Hasek. It tells the story of a World War I soldier who is expelled from the army for being simple- minded, is redrafted, and is forever turning left when the other soldiers turn right. Bill Nabel plays Schweik. The performances, in English, are at the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Theater, 122 Amsterdam Avenue at 65th Street, at 8 tonight and Saturday and at 3:30 P.M. Sunday. Tickets are $10, or $8 for students and the elderly. Information: 874-0245. CAMERA ON COURAGE

title: PAN AM AND UNION MEET ON A KEY ISSUE IN FIRST STRIKE TALKS
description: Negotiators for the Transport Workers Union met yesterday with C. Edward Acker, chairman of Pan American World Airways, and discussed a key issue in the strike against the airline.

title: 'Greenmail' Culprits ;   Inside the Corporation
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Fund Assets Decline Assets of the nation's money
description: market mutual funds declined

title: Books of The Times
description: When John Self comes to dinner, he is liable to begin by drunkenly dropping a few bottles of champagne, so that the kitchen floor looks like a Jacuzzi. When he is out on the town, and he is not gobbling down junk food or throwing it up, he tends to spend much of his time sampling the pleasures of unspeakable clip joints and dismal sex emporiums. Among his major cultural accomplishments, he lists an addiction to video nasties - ''diabolism, carnage, soft core'' - and along with some unwholesome personal habits his chief form of exercise is getting into fights. One way and another he embodies - all 225 pounds of him - just about everything your mother told you not to play with.

title: GALVESTON-HOUSTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: America's Pregnant Children
description: According to legend (and a song lyric from ''Gypsy''), to sell something you've gotta have a gimmick. In the United States, the tried-and-true gimmick is sex.

title: NUCLEAR AIDES ASK CAUTION ON RISKS
description: The technical staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission urged the five members of the commission today to be cautious in easing official estimates of the public health risk from accidents involving nuclear reactors.

title: AN EMPTY ARENA, A DIFFERENT WORLD
description: They shared a hallway for just a few seconds. Bill Wennington, the senior center from St. John's, had just completed his day of work, and the Iowa Hawkeyes were just beginning theirs.

title: Municipalities In E.S.M. Suit
description: Four municipal governments that were customers of the failed E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. intervened today in the Securities and Exchange Commission's suit against the securities firm, but their position was limited by a judge.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: A CROWD of 260 benefactors of the

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. 76ers, at Philadelphia, 7:30 P.M. The 76ers' Moses Malone leads the league in rebounding with an average of 12.9 a game. The Knicks defeated Philadelphia, 131-129, in double overtime last Saturday and they can even the season series at 3-3 with another victory tonight. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WPAT 930, WFAS 1230 and WGBB 1240, 7:20 P.M.).

title: LEHIGH OUT WITH PRIDE INTACT
description: Mike Polaha, the 6-foot-1-inch point guard for Lehigh, said it best moments after his woefully outmanned team was eliminated, 68-43, by Georgetown today in the first round of the East Regional in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Water Levels Rise In City Reservoirs
description: The levels in the reservoirs of the Delaware River basin, which supply New York City with about half its water, have risen significantly in recent weeks, officials said yesterday.

title: NO ECONOMIC QUARRELS FACE REAGAN IN CANADA
description: Almost four years ago, President Reagan visited Canada on his first official trip abroad. He came to complain to Pierre Elliott Trudeau, then Prime Minister.

title: ST. JOHN'S ROUTS SOUTHERN BY 83-59 IN FIRST ROUND
description: Ever since they arrived here, the St. John's players have said that fresh surroundings would help erase the bitter memory of last week's loss to Georgetown. A good game in the opening round of the West Regional, they said, would put them in gear for a successful tournament.

title: Poly-Tech Shifts
description: Campbell-Methun, Minneapolis subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide, has the Poly-Tech account in the bag.

title: INNOVATIONS IN URBAN CYCLING AT NEW YORK SHOW
description: Mel Barron brought his hand- welded pedicab all the way from Oakland, Calif., to the International Cycle Show at the New York Coliseum a few days ago, and he contends it is the best of all possible vehicles for navigating the city's traffic-clogged streets.

title: FILM: 'HEARTBREAKERS,' THE STORY OF A FRIENDSHIP
description: ''HEARTBREAKERS'' is a contemporary comedy, set in Los Angeles, that seriously contemplates the ups and downs in the friendship of two men who themselves aren't terribly interesting.

title: ART: CSERNUS IN NEW YORK EBUT
description: TIBOR CSERNUS makes his New York debut at Claude Bernard Gallery trailing a certain amount of mystery. A painter who was born in Hungary in 1927, he moved to Paris in 1964, but since then has had only six solo exhibitions. His reputation was confined to Europe until last year, when he was featured at an international art exposition in Chicago.

title: Jersey Lawmaker Switching Parties
description: Assemblywoman Angela L. Perun of Plainfield announced today that she was switching her party affiliation from Democratic to Republican because, she said, Middlesex County Democrats had tried to deny her the organization's support in the June 4 primary.

title: SIMMONS AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.
