description: b-Includes after-tax writedowns of $26,460,000 on certain energy assets. c-Net income.

title: MOR-FLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $273,000.

title: RIDERS ON L.I.R.R. RACING 2 MONTHS OF DELAYS
description: Riders of the Long Island Rail Road will face at least two months of last- minute track changes, delays, diversions and train cancellations begining Monday, according to railroad officials.

title: Dioxin Warning Rescinded Upstate
description: In a reversal of an earlier finding, the State Department of Environmental Conservation has announced that traces of dioxin found in Tonawanda Creek are not alarmingly high.

title: 2 Killed as Truck Flips Onto Auto
description: A dump truck loaded with broken asphalt, apparently unable to stop at a traffic light here today, swerved and flipped onto an auto, killing two Long Island women inside, the Nassau County police said.

title: Ohio Legislator Fights To Protect Deposits
description: As majority whip of the Ohio Senate, Richard H. Finan spent last weekend in marathon talks with other officials trying to protect depositors in Ohio's state-chartered thrift units from losses after a run on the Home State Savings Bank of Cincinnati.

title: VIDEO GAME'S FALL SURVIVED
description: When the Bally Manufacturing Corporation began diversifying in the late 1970's, spending the jackpot it had won selling pinball and Pac-Man machines, its aim was to expand into less cyclical businesses. The company was not seeking a life preserver in case the then-thriving video arcade games business collapsed.

title: ART: DIVERSE REPERTORY OF MARSDEN HARTLEY
description: ''MAINE is a strong silent country and so I being born there am able to express it in terms of itself with which I am familiar,'' wrote Marsden Hartley (1877-1943) in 1939, with more conviction than syntax. And it was as a passionate painter of Maine - its people and its rugged, sometimes majestic landscape - that Hartley wound up, after many style shifts in a restless, peripatetic career that had begun with European modernism. Although other high points are represented from Hartley's varied body of work, it's his late New England themes that are emphasized in ''Marsden Hartley: Paintings and Drawings,'' at the Salander-O'Reilly Galleries, 22 East 80th Street, through April 27.

title: Conrail Tries TV Campaign
description: Conrail, the mostly Government-owned railroad freight operation serving the Northeast, is going to television advertising for the first time with a highly competitive campaign offering companies a free analysis of their shipping needs.

title: Chevron-Gulf
description: The Federal Trade Commission gave the Chevron Corporation the go- ahead to complete its $13.3 billion merger with the Gulf Oil Corporation.

title: REAGAN SEES HOPE IN SOVIET OUTLOOK
description: President Reagan asserted today that the Soviet Union was in ''a different frame of mind'' about arms talks with the United States. But at the same time, the White House cautioned against expecting an early Soviet-American summit meeting.

title: GEORGE ZAIMES
description: George Zaimes, the State Transportation Department's chief civil engineer for New York City, died of a heart attack Monday while vacationing at Lake Worth, Fla. He was 57 years old and lived in North Massapequa, L.I.

description: the New York financier, said

title: DAYTON-HUDSON UP 4.6%
description: The K Mart Corporation, citing the negative impact of heavy markdowns, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1985 ended Jan. 30 fell 17.8 percent as sales increased 21.1 percent.

title: No Headline
description: Since the oil refineries opened in Aruba and Cura,cao half a century ago, the fortunes of these two sparkling Caribbean islands have largely followed the demand for oil. Now their prosperity is threatened, a casualty of the worldwide glut in oil refining capacity, and the islands face their severest economic predicament in memory.

title: Graphics Union Rejects Merger With Printers
description: A merger agreement between the International Typographical Union and the Graphic Communications International Union has collapsed, the labor groups said today, giving the teamsters' union a new opportunity to move into the printing industry.

title: Coast Guard Arrests Crew
description: The Coast Guard found marijuana residue Wednesday aboard a Honduran freighter that had burned at sea for two days, and the ship's crew was arrested, a spokesman said. The vessel, the 350- foot Tepora, had been abandoned by her crew of 21, who were plucked from lifeboats by the Coast Guard.

title: Central Soya Offer From Shamrock
description: Shamrock Holdings Inc. of Burbank, Calif., which is owned by the Roy E. Disney family, said today that it was proposing to acquire for $23 a share the approximately 90 percent of Central Soya Company stock that it does not control. The total price could reach $290 million.

title: Klammer's Last Season
description: Franz Klammer , the Austrian downhill skier who won five World Cup championships and a gold medal at the 1976 Winter Olympics, has decided to retire after this season, according to his American agent,

title: OSHMAN'S SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-Includes an after-tax LIFO credit of $407,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and an after-tax LIFO charge of $15,000 for the year. c-Includes after-tax LIFO charges of $251,000 for the quarter and $659,000 for the year. Periods of reporting are based on 14 weeks compared with 13 weeks and 53 weeks compared with 52 weeks.

title: Something Better
description: Last winter Jeff Shepherd, then a junior at John F. Kennedy High School in the Bronx, spent late afternoons working in the mailroom of a midtown Manhattan messenger service. This winter he has found something else - and, he's sure, something better - to do: leading Kennedy's basketball team into the Public Schools Athletic League's championship game.

title: Aramco, Bechtel
description: Aramco has canceled a deal with Bechtel Group Inc. to build two oil refinery projects valued at $2 billion.

title: SERIES HAS A 'TYPICALLY BRITISH' START
description: SHE had a sympathetic voice, a ''brilliant smile which starts at the eyes and is expressed in every feature'' and ''a perfect poise on all occasions.'' The secret of her success, wrote her director - and future husband - Herbert Wilcox, was that she had ''qualities of charm and womanliness so typically British that scarcely one Hollywood star has ever managed to give them adequate expression.''

title: FILM: MELISSA GILBERT IN 'SYLVESTER'
description: ''SYLVESTER,'' which opens today at the Guild and other theaters, is about a pretty, 16-year-old Texan nicknamed ''Charlie'' (Melissa Gilbert), who's obsessed by horses. She likes to break them in, train them, ride them and care for them. When other girls her age are working as supermarket checkers or learning how to type or worrying about their hair, Charlie is hanging out with horses. ''It's just a phase, Charlie,'' says Mr. Foster (Richard Farnsworth), a crotchety but lovable trainer. ''All girls go through it.''

title: Briton Kidnapped
description: Gunmen kidnapped a British scientist today as he walked from his home to his office in West Beirut, the police said. The scientist, Geoffrey Vernon Nash, was stopped by three gunmen in the seaside residential area of Manara as he walked to work at a research institute, a police spokesman said.

title: PARADE TOMORROW
description: The St. Patrick's Day parade will be held tomorrow (a day before the actual holiday), starting at noon and moving north on Fifth Avenue from 44th to 86th Streets, then east to Third Avenue. The march has usually ended about 5:30 P.M.

title: ANTISMOKING CLIMATE INSPIRES SUITS BY THE DYING
description: Rose Cipollone started smoking in 1942, when she was 16 years old. Each morning, on her way to Washington Irving High School in Manhattan, she bought three Chesterfields at the candy store near the el station at 116th Street and Third Avenue. Smoking them, she would later explain, made her feel like the movie stars she read about in True Story and Photoplay.

title: Officer Is Shot in Head By a Man Holding Her
description: A Plainfield, N.J., police officer was shot in the head and seriously wounded last night by a man who had held her at gunpoint for about 30 minutes.

description: Miranda v. Arizona threaten to cloud two aspects of the famous decision. They may blur the safeguards for defendants against use of confessions obtained without proper warning. Just as important, they risk blurring the clear rules that tell the police exactly where they stand.

title: Canadian Hostages Freed
description: Three Kingston Penitentiary inmates who barricaded themselves in a prison hospital with five hostages have released them all unharmed, officials at Canada's oldest jail said today. The release ended a 16- hour siege at the maximum security prison, which houses 400 convicts. A nurse in the prison hospital was released late Thursday night and the other four hostages were freed this morning, officials said.

''Women, Work and Babies: Can America Cope?'' seems to be looking at a grievous problem in a serious way, but it's really not. Its gaze is misdirected. The NBC ''White Paper'' will be seen on Channel 4 at 10 tonight.

Mr. Mulroney wants to increase military spending in the belief that Canada's contribution to NATO is ''embarrassingly low.'' He has reversed economic policies designed by his predecessors to bolster Canadian independence at United States expense.

title: GORBACHEV HINTS TO OPENING TO CHINA

description: Health officials in the Allentown- Bethlehem area, where at least four cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, have been reported, will soon begin screening blood donors for a virus that has been linked to the disorder, officials said today.

title: A MATTER OF FAT
description: After meeting for two days, a panel of experts convened by the National Institutes of Health recently announced its consensus that ''overweight'' of any degree is a disease. The chairman, declaring ''obesity is a killer,'' warned against weighing even five or 10 pounds too much. This proclamation is baffling and depressing - baffling because it serves no medical purpose, depressing because it makes quasi-official doctrine out of shaky science and unwarranted speculation.

description: The most recent ruling in the case of the Shoreham nuclear power plant - that its owner mismanaged construction and should be penalized financially - is based on an enormous inquiry by lawyers, engineers and accountants, who over months of work provided an encyclopedic wealth of details about why the reactor has already cost 15 times more than it was supposed to.

title: BEHIND ZABAR'S COUNTERS, 3 FEUDING PARTNERS
description: At the moment, the three partners who own Zabar's, one of New York's best-known delicatessen and cookware stores, are in complete agreement on a number of things. They are feuding, but they are not feuding. They will sell Zabar's, but they will not sell Zabar's. A cookie mogul has the inside track to buy Zabar's, but he may not be able to buy Zabar's.

title: 2d Briton Is Abducted By Gunmen in Beirut
description: Five gunmen dragged a British businessman from his car in West Beirut today and abducted him, the British Ambassador said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page yesterday incorrectly tallied the number of Ivy League graduates in President Reagan's Cabinet. It is seven, including Samuel R. Pierce Jr., Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, whose alma mater is Cornell.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $664,000 for the quarter and $4,106,000 for the 9 months, losses from the disposal of discontinued operations of $7,954,000 for the quarter and 9 months, and an extraordinary gain from the termination of a retirement plan of $9,500,000 for the quarter and 9 months. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective Dec. 1, 1984.

title: Canadian Prices Rise
description: OTTAWA, March 15 (Reuters) The consumer price index rose six-tenths of 1 percent in February, to 125.4, compared with a four-tenths of 1 percent rise in January and a six-tenths of 1 percent rise in February last year, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. The base year is 1981. The February year-to-year rise was 3.7 percent, unchanged from January.

title: MISSING WOMAN IN MURDER CASE IS FOUND DEAD
description: The body of a Mount Vernon woman who was presumed abducted by a man accused of killing of a Westchester County police officer was found yesterday in a heavily wooded area in the Catskills, the police said.

title: Students Are Warned In Measles Epidemic
description: With at least 20 new cases reported this week in its measles epidemic, Boston University today warned students to get vaccinations or face a ban on campus activities that could extend to classes.

title: BALLET: JOFFREY PREMIERE
description: The three works the Joffrey Ballet presented Wednesday night in the New York State Theater made the occasion one big party. The dancers in Philip Jerry's ''Hexameron,'' which received its New York premiere, might have been at a formal ball. There was a welcome revival of ''Le Beau Danube,'' Leonide Massine's comedy about a holiday outing in Vienna. And Paul Taylor's ''Cloven Kingdom'' depicted the elite at play.

title: HOLMES BATTERS BEY TO DEEP TITLE
description: Larry Holmes, creaking old bones and all, waved goodbye tonight with an injured right hand and a sore left arm and apparently exited boxing undefeated, untied and unquestionably one of the finest heavyweight champions in history.

title: CONCERT: BERG QUARTET
description: Goethe once defined chamber music as a discourse between reasonable individuals. That handy summation crossed this reviewer's mind several times Monday night while listening to the Alban Berg Quartet at Carnegie Hall. For the members of this quartet - the violinists Gunther Pichler and Gerhard Schulz, the violist Thomas Kakuska and the cellist Valentin Erben - are not only reasonable, but also felicitous, impassioned and elegant musicians.

title: Meese Is 'Somewhat Encouraged'
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that he was ''somewhat encouraged'' by the detention in Mexico of 12 suspects in the drug agent's kidnapping and killing, and he said he planned to ''increase our own efforts'' in working with Mexico against drug trafficking.

description: b-Includes a gain of $1,159,000 on the divestiture of the company's commercial finance business.

title: CHANGING PATTERNS IN PRESCRIPTIONS IN U.S.

Powell Jr. of the Supreme Court, recuperating from surgery Jan. 4 for a cancerous prostate gland, was admitted to the Bethesda Naval Medical Center Thursday, a spokesman said today. title: GOING ROUND THE MOUNTAIN NOT AS EASY AS IT USED TO BE
description: Life here has not been the same since the mountain fell in. The loggers say it takes three times as long to get their rigs to the Tennessee line, the Midway Truck Stop closed a week ago for lack of traffic and Nancy Rogers says her business is off by half.

title: THE JAPANESE MUST FIND US UNSCRUTABLE
description: To the Editor:

title: DIRECTED DECADE OF ACQUISITIONS
description: Shelton Fisher, the retired chairman of the board of McGraw-Hill Inc., died yesterday of respiratory failure at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: Taiwan Inquiry Extended
description: Military prosecutors extended for two months today an investigative period to determine if three military intelligence officers were involved in the slaying of a Chinese-American writer, Henry Liu, who was shot dead at his home in Daly City, Calif., last Oct. 15, official sources said. The three officers were implicated by an informer.

title: SPIRITED STUDENTS BRING 'CARMEN' TO THE BRONX
description: ''Oh, no! Opera!'' cried Diana Tauder, an eighth grader in the chorus, when it was announced that the spring musical would be ''Carmen.''

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Warren Tanner, 42, Founded Independent Artists Group
description: Warren Tanner, the founder of the Organization of Independent Artists, a not-for-profit group that organizes temporary art exhibitions in public spaces in New York City, died March 1 at Mt. Sinai Hospital of leukemia. Mr. Tanner lived in Manhattan and was 42 years old.

title: TALE OF HORROR BREATHES LIFE INTO BILL-SIGNING CEREMONY

title: PLAY BALL! SANDINISTAS DELIVER SLIDERS AND SLOGANS
description: The national baseball stadium here reopened a few weeks ago, newly rebuilt after five years and with a new name. The former Anastasio Somoza Garcia Stadium is now called Rigoberto Lopez Perez Stadium, after the poet who assassinated the founder of the Somoza family dynasty in 1956.

title: IRRIGATION WATER CUT OFF BY U.S. TO PROTECT BIRDS
description: The Interior Department said today that it would close a polluted national wildlife refuge and cut off water to 42,000 acres of bountiful California farmland whose irrigation wastes were drained into the refuge.

title: NAVY STUNS L.S.U.
description: Navy basketball, which had been in dry dock for most of the last quarter century, has returned to national attention this season, and today the Middies posted the biggest upset of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament so far when they trounced Louisiana State University, 78-55.

title: Ties of the Old School
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is a strong advocate of a free- market economy, as underscored by his curious choice of neckties. Mr. Meese owns 15 Adam Smith ties of various colors and rarely wears anything else under his collar. The tie design includes horizontal stripes and small busts of Adam Smith, whose book, ''The Wealth of Nations,'' is still regarded as a rock of laissez-faire economic theory.

title: OSCARS GO TO WRITERS FOR 'KWAI'
description: An epilogue will be written this week to the blacklist that Hollywood directed against Communists, suspected Communists and their supporters in the movie community almost three decades ago. On Saturday, in a public ceremony in the theater of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the widows of the screenwriters Carl Foreman and Michael Wilson will be given the Oscars withheld from their husbands 27 years ago for the screenplay of ''The Bridge on the River Kwai.''

title: CORNELL PREPARES TO ENTER THE SUPERCOMPUTER ERA
description: With more than $70 million in Government and corporate support for a new supercomputer center, Cornell University is trying to forge one of the nation's closest working relationships between a major university and high-technology companies.

title: Snake in the Budget
description: As previously reported in this space, rubber snakes are in increasing demand in this city as a bird deterrent. A few months ago a Commerce Department official purchased 10 rubber snakes from Al's Magic Shop, a major purveyor of the items, and scattered them on the roof of the Commerce building to scare off birds.

title: TEXT OF BISHOP'S LETTER TO CONGRESS ON MX
description: Following is the text of a letter sent today from the United States Catholic Conference to each member of Congress. It was signed by Bishop James W. Malone, president of the conference and of the National Conference of Bishops, and Bishop of Youngstown, Ohio.

PATENTS;

Meat Calibrator
description: A device for the automatic calibration of meat, such as the proportion of fat it contains, is disclosed in patent 4,504,963, issued this week to Lloyd D. Johnson of Davenport, Iowa. The process described includes sending X-rays through two standard samples of meat and the unknown sample being calibrated, and examining the detected radiation. The weight proportion of fat in the sample is then calculated and displayed.

title: BOSTON COLLEGE GAINS BY 55-53
description: Michael Adams's 25-foot jump shot with 5 seconds to play gave Boston College a 55-53 victory over Texas Tech in an N.C.A.A. Midwest Regional first- round game tonight.

title: U.S. AIDE TO VISIT MIDEAST FOR TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States would send the State Department's top Middle East official to the region later this month ''to maintain momentum toward peace in the Middle East.''

title: JUDGE REFUSES BID TO DISMISS DONOVAN CASE
description: A State Supreme Court Justice yesterday refused to dismiss larceny and fraud charges against Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan and nine other men.

title: EX-F.B.I. AGENT COOPERATES IN DRUG INQUIRY AFTER GUILTY PLEA
description: The former Federal agent who pleaded guilty to drug-related charges Thursday is continuing to cooperate with the authorities in an investigation of a large drug ring, the Federal authorities said today.

title: SYRACUSE THWARTS DEPAUL WITH ZONE
description: They huffed and they puffed, but try as they might DePaul's Blue Demons could not blow down the Syracuse zone defense tonight. Nor could the Orange blow out DePaul, despite getting 23 points, 15 on free throws, from Dwayne (Pearl) Washington. And when it was over, Syracuse had a 70- 65 victory in an East Regional first- round game in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: JERSEY OFFICER, TAKEN HOSTAGE, IS FATALLY SHOT
description: A Plainfield police officer died early today after being shot in the head ''for no apparent reason'' by a man who was holding her hostage, authorities said.

description: Pat Bradley increased her lead during the second round of the $300,000 Women's Kemper Open today, shooting a 67 and emerging with an 8-under-par 138, two shots ahead of the field.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, an obituary of Joan Barone of CBS in some editions on Tuesday omitted her most recent assignment. She was a producer of ''The CBS Evening News.''

description: Mayor Koch yesterday released an exchange of letters with the Mayor of Johannesburg over a decision to end the investment of New York City pension funds in companies that do business in South Africa.

description: Unhappy farmers went to Washington last month to lobby against President Reagan's budget plan and for emergency measures that they contend are necessary to head off widespread farm foreclosures.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 16, 1985 International

title: French Prices Up 0.5%
description: French retail prices rose a provisional five-tenths of 1 percent in February, matching the rise in January, the National Statistics Institute said today. The institute's retail price index rose 6.4 percent from February 1984, compared with a 6.5 percent rise in January over the previous year.

title: Italian Strikes Affect Hospitals and Airports
description: Several labor strikes started in Italy today, shutting down airports, closing doctors' offices and crippling hospitals and some national news organizations.

description: The collapse of the Pontiac Silverdome's dome has created such a rush at the box office that officials have had to establish a waiting list, but not for tickets, according to the stadium's executive director,

description: SATURDAY, MARCH 16, 1985

title: Sindona Gets 12-Year Term
description: Michele Sindona, a former chief adviser of the Vatican's bank, was convicted of bank fraud and sentenced to 12 years in prison, the state-run television network reported today.

title: SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 9
description: b-Includes a capital gain of $4,493,953.

title: Nuclear Test in Nevada
description: An underground nuclear device was detonated at the Nevada Test Site today, the Department of Energy announced. The agency said the explosive power of the device, which was detonated at a depth of 1,396 feet below the surface of Yucca Flat, was 20 to 150 kilotons. It was the first announced nuclear test this year, the department said.

title: Philadelphia Sued on Order Barring Military Recruiting
description: The Justice Department said today that it has sued the city of Philadelphia for issuing an order that bars the military from recruiting at a local university because the armed services reject homosexuals.

description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland today urged the news media to give an aggrieved individual a middle ground between writing a letter to the editor and starting a long, costly libel suit.

title: TV: A CELEBRATION OF RODGERS AND HAMMERSTEIN
description: At a time when the Tony Awards are frantically scurrying to find enough nominations to fill this year's Best Musical category, it is unsettling to recall how, not that long ago, the Broadway scene was so very different. Season after season, the musical was the toast of Broadway and one of this country's more celebrated exports. Some of the flavor of those years is evoked in ''Rodgers and Hammerstein: The Sound of American Music,'' a celebratory scrapbook being presented on Channel 13 tonight at 8.

title: MALONE DOMINATES DESPITE SORE ANKLE

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: GUARDIAN ANGEL & Other Stories by Margery Latimer. (The Feminist Press, $8.85.) This collection of nine stories was published in 1932, the year Margery Latimer died after giving birth to her first child at the age of 33. A reviewer wrote in these pages: ''Throughout the whole book one feels the bewildered growing of a woman in various stages. The tragic note underlying it is the absence of the things she wished for and could never find.' In addition the reviewer said ''to plots of unusual character, it inculdes analysis which goes beyond the superficial -- and skillful writing.''

title: DEBATE GROWS OVER PARKING AT RAIL STATIONS

But less than a year later, increased ridership on the line has magnified what county and Metro-North officials see as a serious transportation problem: the availability of, and access to, railroad-station parking.

title: CAPE TOWN CAMP BURIES RIOT DEAD

description: To the Editor:

title: WILDLIFE IS FAR FROM ENDANGERED ON PUBLIC TV
description: What is there about nature programs that continues to delight us, and whatever it is, where would public television be without it? Birds, animals, fissures in the earth, fish in the sea, flowers in meadows, trees on savannahs - striking images flourish. They exist in our minds as a great montage. A ''National Geographic Special'' reminds us of a ''Nature,'' which, in turn, touches the same chord as a ''Living Planet.'' Granted that ''The Living Planet'' is grander, and that it deals in majesty. The rubric is the same: The world is a wondrous place, full of enchantment, but often in peril. Pandas, whooping cranes, rain forests and salt marshes, whole swaths and spectrums of life, are threatened. Nature programs sound warnings, although as a rule they say that help is on the way. They alarm and comfort us simultaneously. At the same time, they almost always look good. Consider ''Rhino on the Run,'' the ''Nature'' episode on Channel 13 at 8 tonight. The rhinoceros is a singularly unlovely beast, but here he doesn't look bad. Moreover, he is endangered, but good people stand ready to protect him.

title: HONORING RICHARD RODGERS
description: Richard Rodgers meant more to my professional life than any other one person. He gave me my first directing job on a musical (''I Married an Angel''). He used me as director immediately following a mental breakdown when I thought I had lost the trust of the entire theatrical world (''By Jupiter''). And after I was away from the theater for four years in the Air Force, he offered me before I left Europe the direction of Rodgers and Hammerstein's production of ''Annie Get Your Gun'' starring Ethel Merman, with Irving Berlin's score. After the war came ''South Pacific,'' on which I collaborated with Dick and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, and directed as well.

title: A NEW WAY OF CREATING MIXED-INCOME DEVELOPMENTS
description: THERE is nothing startling architecturally about the apartment house now going into construction on the west side of Columbus Avenue between 95th and 96th Streets in the West Side urban-renewal area.

title: CONNECTICUT OPINION ;   NATURE ABOUNDS IN WASTEFULNESS
description: New Haven Hospital expects to start freezing human embryos. As I read the details, I recalled two experiences I recently had with students of mine.

title: FIRST TASTINGS
description: Food experts recall their introductions to a menu of delicacies, from white truffles to tripe, stone crab to barbecued pig, and vanilla ice cream. A BOWLFUL OF LITTLE SURPRISES

title: IOWA WRESTLER WINS 3D TITLE
description: Barry Davis of Iowa, who won an Olympic silver medal last summer, wrapped up his third national title at the National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling finals today.

title: Memories in 'I Wish I'd Asked Her'
description: Creativity is one of the basic principles of existence. Wilma Breit's article, ''I Wish I'd Asked Her'' (Opinion Page, March 3), showed me that there is deep joy in creation but that somehow there was an undeveloped situation that produced regret and sadness.

title: Luring the Big Leagues
description: Frank Smith , a member of the District of Columbia Council and the chairman of the district's Commission on Baseball, has proposed a novel way to attract a real major league team to Washington - selling season tickets to a phantom team's games. Under the Smith plan, purchasers would deposit $560 in an interest-bearing escrow account, agreeing to leave the money there for three years.

title: OFFICER IS WOUNDED IN CAMDEN SHOOTOUT DURING DRUG ARREST
description: A Camden police officer and two suspected drug dealers were wounded today in a gun battle during a drug raid at a bar here.

title: DAUGHTER IS BORN TO WOMAN IN COMA
description: Doctors at the Albany Medical Center Hospital yesterday successfully delivered the daughter of a woman who was left paralyzed after being improperly injected with a cancer treatment drug two weeks ago.

title: WOODY ALLEN JOURNEYS FROM PAGE TO SCREEN
description: In Woody Allen's ''Kugelmass Episode,'' a short story contained in his collection, ''Side Effects,'' Kugelmass, an unhappily married, lovesick City College humanities professor, dumps his analyst in favor of ''the Great Persky,'' a shabby Brooklyn magician who owns a time machine made out of raw plywood. With the help of Persky and his wonderful box, Kugelmass, for a small fee, spends a couple of euphoric hours every day in the company of an amorous Madame Bovary, making sure that he enters the Flaubert novel before page 120.

title: Q & A
description: My trust officer advised me to change the title of our home from ''joint tenancy with right of survivorship'' to ''tenancy in common'' to minimize taxes. Would this change make a real difference? . . . R. D. McK., Ridgefield, Conn.

title: BUSH, VISITING HONDURAS, ATTACKS SANDINISTAS
description: Vice President Bush harshly criticized Nicaragua's Sandinista leaders today for creating a ''Marxist-Leninist totalitarian Government'' and said there would be ''no letting up'' in Administration efforts to secure renewed funding for Nicaraguan anti-government guerrillas.

title: Lori Shapiro Is AffiancedTo Neal Glazer, a Lawyer
description: Dr. and Mrs. David Shapiro of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lori Donna Shapiro, to Neal M. Glazer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Glazer of the Bronx.

title: SENATOR HUNTS A TEXAS RELIC
description: Senator Phil Gramm of Texas is on a search that has him rooting around in other people's desks on the Senate floor in Washington.

title: FIRST SIGHTINGS
description: From an artist's street in Rome to the pull of the African bush, correspondents of The Times report on some memorable discoveries. TURGENEV AMID THE LINDENS

title: ORDERING BOOKS OVER THE TELEPHONE
description: WHEN a customer comes into the New Canaan Bookshop looking for ''The Raj Quartet,'' novels about India by Paul Scott, he or she is not directed to the music section. That is because Thomas P. and Marguerite Whitney, owners of that bookshop and of the Hickory Stick Bookshop in Washington Depot, ask that their employees read books, know books and be able to talk knowledgeably with customers about books.

title: A 'Conspiracy'On Concrete?
description: Concrete costs a lot more in New York City than in other Northeastern cities, and State Attorney General Robert Abrams thinks he knows one reason why. An ''illegal conspiracy'' of contractors, he charged in an antitrust suit last week, had rigged bids on all big public and private construction projects here since 1978, threatening competitors with labor and supply problems.

title: HOYAS BEATABLE, BUT NOT TOO OFTEN
description: Perhaps the ingenuity of America's college basketball coaches has been overrated all along. Ever since the U.C.L.A. Invitational was abolished when the Bruin dynasty reached its end, we have been led to believe that in the category of competitive resourcefulness the big-time college basketball coach should be ranked up there with international mercenaries, light-fingered jewel thieves and fast-talking used-car salesmen.

title: RHOMAN RULE WINS EVERLADES STAKES
description: Rhoman Rule, who ran faster than Kentucky Derby favorites Chief's Crown and Proud Truth two weeks ago at Gulfstream Park, proved that was no fluke of the stopwatch today with an impressive eight-length victory in the $110,800 Everglades Stakes at Hialeah Park.

title: WRITING THE SECOND NOVEL-A SYMPOSIUM
description: The Book Review asked a number of first novelists how it feels to be writing a second novel. Their replies follow:

IT'S A GIRL-AND MAYBE A TAX SHELTER

title: FIRST TASTINGS
description: Food experts recall their introductions to a menu of delicacies, from white truffles to tripe, stone crab to barbecued pig, and vanilla ice cream.

title: CONCERT: JOAN LA BARBARA, SOPRANO
description: The front of the flier for Joan La Barbara's concert series that began at Symphony Space Tuesday identifies her as a soprano; the back of it refers to her as ''a composer, performer, writer and media artist.'' Call her what you will, Miss La Barbara, who teaches at the California Institute of the Arts in Valencia, is well established on the avant-garde scene. In concerts, recordings (five devoted to her own compositions alone) and residencies, she has worked for more than a decade to expand the possibilities of the voice as a musical instrument.

title: BELLADONNA WINS
description: Take a group of average bridge-players and ask each of them to describe the ideal vacation and then assemble all the suggested elements. The total picture would probably be something like this: a private villa in a warm climate with a private beach; surfing, sailing, golf, tennis, swimming pool, gymnasium and nightclub; restaurants and a supermarket; 160 bridge tables with regular tournaments, duplicates and rubber bridge; lessons at all levels by world- famous celebrities.

title: ART PROGRAMS FOR PRISONERS EXPANDING
description: -security Youth Reception and Correction Center here, he is just Carlos, but in the makeshift art studio he becomes C. Anthony Matos, and he signs that ''nom d'art'' with a flourish to his portraits of Malcolm X and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: STYLE TAKES THE SPOTLIGHT
description: SAVVY style is everything at the West End Cafe in Carle Place. It has dictated the setting, which cleverly blends high tech and Art Deco, and determined the free-wheeling menu, with choices from Buffalo chicken wings and pizza to steak au poivre. Your glass can be filled with a white zinfandel, a fine California cabernet sauvignon, a sophisticated Bellini (champagne and peach juice) or, for those just celebrating legal coming of age, a liqueur-spiked ice cream cooler.

title:
MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF;

Pierre Amoyal, on Violi n, Offers French Works
description: Pierre Amoyal, a student of Jascha Heifetz and a teacher of violin at the Paris Conservatory, came to Carnegie Hall for a recital of mostly French music Friday night.

title: NAVY, VILLANOVA RATE UPSET CHANCE
description: There is a good possibility that Navy and Villanova, instead of Maryland and Michigan, will be the winning teams in the second round of the Southeast Regional at the University of Dayton Arena Sunday. That conjecture is based on the performances of the Terps and Wolverines, both of whom were favored but narrowly won in the first round Friday.

title: Cable TV
description: Calling all red-blooded mystery buffs and Alfred Hitchcock fans - and who isn't? - for this week's cable debut of ''Rear Window.'' It plays on Thursday at 11 A.M. and 9 P.M. over WHT (SelecTV).

title: THE WHITNEY BIENNIAL - ART'S CUTTING EDGE?
description: ''Oh, god! It's here again,'' one prominent figure in the art world blurted out when reminded that it is Whitney Biennial time. No exhibition in the United States unleashes as much emotion as the Whitney Museum of American Art's ongoing effort to make some order of the confusing, chaotic and inspiring world of contemporary art. Some art professionals love the show. Others hate it. One of the few generalizations that can be made about the Biennial is that almost no one is indifferent to it.

title: SuperSonics 108, Hawks 99
description: Jack Sikma of Seattle center scored 12 of his 24 points in the third quarter to spur the SuperSonics, who virtually led all the way. The Sonics posted their biggest lead, 82-66, at the end of the third period.

title: Builder's Statement Called Misleading
description: Misleading and inaccurate statements concerning government regulations were made by David Jackson, president of the New Jersey Builders Association, as reported in a Jan. 20 article about the Mount Laurel II decision.

title: REFINING THE MILITARY
description: Not long ago you expressed some of your irritation that anyone should even dream of putting the Services into the same uniform. I won't quarrel with the idea, but I will attempt to give you a slightly different viewpoint toward the Services than you probably have.

title: GUNMEN IN BEIRUT KIDNAP AMERICAN
description: The chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, Terry A. Anderson, was kidnapped today by armed men in mainly Moslem West Beirut as more American diplomats were evacuated from Lebanon to Cyprus.

title: Charis Elliot Nuti-de Biasi Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Charis Elliot Nuti-de Biasi to Peter Davenport Fuller Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Pierluigi Nuti-de Biasi of Darien, Conn., and Palm Beach Point, Fla., parents of the future bride. Mr. Fuller is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fuller of Brookline, Mass., and North Hampton, N.H., and a grandson of the late Alvan Tufts Fuller, a former Governor of Massachusetts.

description: WASHINGTON THROUGHOUT his Presidency, Ronald Reagan has viewed a meeting with the Soviet leadership like a bridegroom reluctantly contemplating marriage to an ungainly bride.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;

WAR PICTURES THAT GO BEYOND HISTORICAL FACT
description: Larry Burrows, whose color photographs of the Vietnam War are currently having their first gallery exhibition, had the good and bad fortune to work for Life magazine. Life was part of a rich and powerful organization that gave its favorite photographers access to interesting subjects and a high degree of financial and logistical support - that was the good part of the job. The bad part was that Life had its own way of looking at things, and there was no point in taking and sending in pictures that Life would not publish.

title: R.P.I. Ties Record
description: Adam Oates set up one goal and scored the game-winner in the third period tonight as Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute defeated Harvard, 3-1, to win its second straight E.C.A.C. hockey championship. The victory enabled the Engineers to tie the Division I record of 29 straight victories set by Cornell in 1969-70. R.P.I. (32-2) also won an automatic berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: ENCHANTERS AT FIRST ENCOUNTER
description: Cynthia Ozick is the author of ''Cannibal Galaxy,'' a novel, and ''Art & Ardor,'' collected essays.

title: Kenyan Patrols Find 924 Elephant Tusks
description: Game Department and army patrols have recovered 924 elephant tusks valued at more than $300,000 in a 60-day poacher sweep in northeastern Kenya, the official Kenya News Agency said today.

title: J.S. BACH'S BIRTHDAY IS OFFICIALLY HERE
description: CONCERT observances of the Bach tricentennial have been under way for at least a year now, but Johann Sebastian's actual birthdate, March 21, is upon us - so, for those who have not reached a saturation point, a number of fine listening opportunities await.

title: MOVING ONA BUDGET
description: A hard-driven Senate Budget Committee last week approved by party-line vote a budget resolution for 1986, which if adhered to would bring the Federal deficit down by half in three years. But the bargains struck to make the $966.1 billion spending package possible guarantee trouble in the next stages of the budget process.

title: Woodruff Charity Bequest
description: The bulk of the estate of Robert W. Woodruff, the Coca-Cola executive, will go into a charitable foundation he established 48 years ago. According to Mr. Woodruff's will, filed Friday in the Fulton County Courthouse, assets valued at $250 million will go to the Trebor Foundation, set up in 1937 to benefit health, welfare and youth activities. Mr. Woodruff, who died March 7 in Atlanta at the aae of 95, contributed about $350 million to education, medicine and the arts.

title: STABBING BLAMED IN UPSTATE KILLING
description: A Mount Vernon, N.Y., woman believed to have been abducted by the man accused of killing a Westchester County police officer was killed by a single stab wound in the chest, the Greene County Medical Examiner's office ruled yesterday.

title: L.I. Bowler Wins
description: Don Genalo of North Merrick, L.I., picked up his fourth career title by rolling nine strikes in the final of the $130,000 King Louie Open Pro Bowlers Association tournament today. He beat Jim Miller, 258-246, and earned $21,000. Mark Roth of Spring Lake Heights, N.J., finished third.

Rusack of the Episcopal Diocese of Los Angeles and Mrs. Rusack of Pacific Palisades, Calif. A May wedding is planned.

Therefore the performances of the Juilliard Dance Theater are always interesting for revealing what kinds of lessons the dance students have been learning.

title: NOW FOR A LOOK A SOME ARTISTS NOT WELL-KNOWN

Still, this is no reason not to pause once in a while and contemplate the majority that suffers from this necessary discrimination. Many are amateurs, of course, but a much larger proportion are skilled and dedicated enough to warrant some thought as to why they haven't received critical attention.

title: THE STATE NEEDS TO CAP ITS SPENDING
description: IT IS axiomatic that government spending will rise to meet and eventually exceed available revenues. In 1976, when the State Legislature enacted a new tax - the gross income tax - it recognized this maxim; it also approved a ''cap'' law to limit increases in state government spending and thereby restrict the growth of the state's bureaucracy.

title: SEOUL SAID TO BALK ON PAYMENTS TO U.S.
description: A Defense Department audit shows that the South Korean Government has refused to pay its full share for combined military operations in South Korea.

description: A. W. DePorte, a visiting scholar at New York University, was an office director in the State Department's Bureau of Intelligence and Research. His most recent book is ''Europe Between the Superpowers - the Enduring Balance.''

title: Broadcast TV
description: One of the more memorable of last year's ''issue'' TV movies was ''The Burning Bed,'' based on a true story of a battered wife who killed her husband and later was declared not guilty by reason of insanity, which is about as close to justifiable homicide as is legally possible. The film is being rebroadcast by NBC on Sunday at 9 P.M.

description: THE Great Adventure amusement park in Jackson Township will make a three- pronged effort tomorrow to improve its position before going on trial on May 13.

title: Lilco Told toPay the Bill
description: The Long Island Lighting Company wasted $1.2 billion through misjudgment, inefficiency and unnecessary engineering work in the past 12 years as it struggled to complete its Shoreham nuclear plant, two administrative law judges ruled last week. As a result the company's stockholders, not its customers, should absorb that much of the total of nearly $2 billion in cost overruns, the judges decided after 10 months of hearings.

title: PLAIN TALK WITH DAVIS MAY SIGNAL A SHIFT IN N.F.L.
description: In a tense moment in a meeting on Wednesday, Al Davis, the managing general partner of the Los Angeles Raiders, delivered what he called ''a tough talk'' to the owners of the other 27 National Football League teams, warning them that they had better ''get me straightened out.''

De Luca of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, was married yesterday to Fouad Chartouni, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Najib Chartouni of Beirut, Lebanon. The Rev. Richard Pendergast performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

description: President Hosni Mubarak said today that he saw no alternative to his latest Middle East peace initiative, adding that it had been neither accepted nor flatly rejected by President Reagan.

description: With determination glinting in her eye, Eileen Donovan planted her feet on the carpet. She sighted down her right arm, cocked her left wrist, flicked a forefinger - and snapped a rubber band through a target 10 feet away.

title: NOTRE DAME LOSES;   TEMPLE IS OUT
description: For all the talk of intimidation and strong- arm tactics that had shadowed them throughout their reign as the nation's most formidable team, the Georgetown Hoyas proved today that they can win just by playing better basketball.

title: WHY IT'S EASIER TO SCRATCH A BACK THAN BITE A BULLET
description: Last Wednesday, Republican members of the Senate Budget Committee were struggling to craft a compromise. Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the panel's chairman, proposed a spending package that would eliminate a program called Urban Development Action Grants, or UDAG. But Senator Robert W. Kasten of Wisconsin, who faces a tough re-election fight next year, refused to support the package unless money for UDAG was continued.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: March 17, 1985 FICTION

title: STUDENTS WEIGH THEIR OPTIONS
description: ''HARVARD may be fine for undergraduate work if you don't plan to go any further,'' suggested Heather Campbell, who ranks fifth in her 503-member senior class at Baldwin Senior High School, at a recent luncheon at the State Uiversity of New York at Stony Brook. ''But if you think of $20,000 a year for medical school, you can't go into debt $100,000 and then apply for that.''

title: KENNEDY SEEKS DOBLE TITLE
description: A walk through the corridors of John F. Kennedy High School this week made it clear that something special was in the works. The hallways buzzed with lively conversation, and all of it centered on one topic.

title:
DINING OUT;

IN RINGOES, IT'S ALL IN THE FAMILY
description: AN OLD farmhouse smack on Route 202 in rural Ringoes, near Flemington, is the unexpected setting for an elegant little restaurant called Muirhead. The house and out buildings, with portions dating from the 18th and 19th centuries, is the home of Edward and Doris Simpson, and for the last 11 years they have opened it for dining on Friday and Saturday evenings.

description: A public high school has become a focal point of racial tension in this community, leading the city to impose a nighttime curfew and the school board to schedule a public meeting that it hopes will clear the air.

title: ACCOMMODATIONS IN ASIA, NORWEGIAN MUSICAL TOUR
description: Tour of Norway For the Fans Of Grieg On a mountainside just outside the city of Bergen stands the estate known as Troldhaugen that was home to the Norwegian composer Edvard Grieg. There, on May 23, in ceremonies expected to be attended by King Olav V, a new chamber music concert hall will be opened.

title: CONSULTANTS AND HOW TO CHOOSE ONE
description: HARDLY a week goes by without my receiving a query from some small- or medium-sized business about finding a good consultant. An experience all too typical of the business scene - as presumably enhanced by the presence of one or more personal computers - is recounted by Colin MacKinnon, editor of the Washington-based monthly Middle East Executive Reports.

title: NeverMind
description: In announcing two weeks ago that New York City would begin distributing F.B.I.-style posters of its most wanted criminals, Mayor Koch and Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said that they needed the public's assistance. It became clear last week just how badly.

description: River views sell. That's an old story in New York, but river views also sell fast, and that is what made Manhattan Place, a condominium overlooking the East River at 37th Street, exceptional.

description: NORTH BRANCH ALTHOUGH Somerset County College's new theater has come through its acoustic baptism of fire, some minor adjustments will have to be made.
