description: A strong earthquake was reported off the coast of Puerto Rico today, the United States Geological Survey said.

title: Amy Beth Stern WedTo Lawrence Dantus
description: At the South Huntington (L.I.) Jewish Center yesterday Amy Beth Stern, the daughter of Thelma Stern of Williston Park, L.I., and the late Irving Stern, was married to Lawrence Dantus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Dantus of Melville, L.I. Rabbi Morris Shapiro performed the ceremony.

title: 'SPIDER' TAKES SPIN ONSTAGE
description: THE THEATER IN THE PARK in Flushing Meadows is struggling to establish a creative voice of its own. It has been offering standard revivals of Broadway hits, such as Neil Simon's ''Last of the Red Hot Lovers,'' without arousing any noticeable audience interest. In a slight change of pace, it is currently producing Robes Kossez's ''Along Came a Spider,'' an original mystery thriller.

title: TOWNS ATTACK LAW ON BUILDERS' WAGES
description: LEBANON First Selectman Edward O. Clark had been told by contractors that a new firehouse could be constructed for less than $400,000.

title: DIFFERENCES WIDEN BETWEEN BLACKS AND THE WHITE HOUSE
description: America's black leadership is being sharply criticized these days from a variety of sources - by militants and conservatives within the black community and by outsiders including, most recently, the White House and Clarence Pendleton Jr., chairman of the United States Civil Rights Commission.

title: Bucks 125, Suns 96 MILWAUKEE (UPI) - Terry Cummings scored 17 first-half points to power Milwaukee to their sixth- straight victory. The Bucks surged to a 63-45 halftime lead and rested their starters for most of the second half. Milwaukee opened the third quarter with four reserves and led, 87-53, with 4:39 remaining in the period.
description: Randy Breuer led the Bucks with a career-high 18 points. Charles Jones scored 19 to lead the Suns while Maurice Lucas added 16. Cummings and Sidney Moncrief, who scored 15 points, did not play the second half.

title: FIRST TASTINGS
description: Food experts recall their introductions to a menu of delicacies, from white truffles to tripe, stone crab to barbecued pig, and vanilla ice cream. BLEND WITH PERFECT LIGHT

title: Jameson French,Priscilla Stevens To Marry in May
description: A May wedding is planned by Priscilla Ames Stevens and Jameson Stevens French. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ames Stevens Jr. of Concord, Mass., who have announced her engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. V. French of Hopkinton, N.H., and Andover, Mass.

title: SHE GOT HER WISH: SEAT ON CRIMINAL COURT
description: ALTHOUGH a couple of months have passed since the day when Mayor Koch swore in Renee White as a judge of the Criminal Court of the City of New York, her reaction remains the same.

title: MANY OF THE NATION'S STATEHOUSES ARE SMOKE-FILLED NO MORE
description: The lobbyists had been busy, and the head-counters were not sure how the tally would turn out. But when State Representative David Hollister's four-year crusade in the Michigan House for a mandatory seat-belt law ended, Mr. Hollister was elated. The Lansing Democrat knew how much effort had gone into winning the 64 yes votes, eight more than were needed for passage. ''I feel like I have just birthed an elephant,'' he said.

title: Military Pensions
description: To the Editor:

title: On-the-Job Telephonitis Reflects on Supervisors
description: To the Editor:

title: RENTALS FOR BERGEN
description: Bergen County, N.J., has seen no lack of residential construction projects. But most developers in the county have been favoring condominiums and single-family houses over rental apartments.

title: DRUG CENTER AWAITS RULING
description: PLANS to expand a Hauppauge residential drug treatment facility, and to construct an alcoholism treatment facility for the homeless at the same site, are on hold until the Islip Town Planning Board decides whether to relax parking and sidewalk requirements at the site.

title: INSTITUTE CONCENTRATES ON SOCIAL PROBLEMS
description: -story rectangular building on a secluded side street, is crowded with cubicles and not especially impressive. Hundreds of people pass near the building every day on their way to the Westchester County Airport, but while some may notice its sign, probably few give it a second thought.

title: GORBACHEV'S ASCENT OFFERS CHANCES FOR A FRESH START
description: MOSCOW AS if on command, the Russian winter began to break the day after the funeral. The thaw seemed a happy convergence of nature and politics as Mikhail S. Gorbachev, young, healthy and self-confident, plunged into the affairs of state. For two days he received a stream of world leaders and they emerged impressed. Vice President Bush spoke of his ''self-confidence and assurance,'' West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl marveled at his ''easy and free'' style, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada found a man ''very much in control and very knowledgeable.''

title: ;   The Great Nicaragua Postage Stamp War
description: To the Editor:

title: MEMORY OF SMELLS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Team Jeopardized A South African runner who competed in an exhibition race during the United States Olympic Trials last year could have jeopardized the Olympic eligibility of the entire American track and field team, according to American and international track officials. The runner,
description: Patsy Sharples , a University of Idaho student, competed in the women's 10,000-meter exhibition at the trials.

title: A Clean BillFor Bendectin
description: Between 1956 and 1983, 33 million pregnant women took the prescription drug Bendectin to relieve nausea. Then its maker voluntarily removed it from the market because of hundreds of lawsuits charging that it had caused birth defects.

title: THE DANCE: JOAN MILLER
description: Joan Miller and her dancers very seldom perform in Manhattan. What most people know of her is a frequently used and singularly unattractive poster photo of herself with her mouth stretched open in a yell. But Miss Miller, head of dance at Lehman College, established herself as a choreographer with a fresh and intriguing point of view by the end of a program on Friday at the Joyce Theater, where Joan Miller's Dance Players perform again tonight.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

GOLD COIN CHALLENGES
description: South Africa's Krugerrand is facing perhaps the sternest challenge to its dominance in the bullion coin market. Although it remains the best-selling bullion gold coin in the world, its market share has fallen. What's more, there seems to be a growing sense of nervousness regarding a possible ban that would halt the flow of Krugerrands into the United States marketplace.

title: CUOMO ASKS PANEL FOR BRAIN DEATH PROPOSAL
description: Governor Cuomo has asked a special commission on medical ethics to recommend legislation that would define brain death and give hospitals the statutory authority to withhold emergency life-saving measures in certain cases from terminally ill and dying patients.

title: N.C.A.A. Surveys Drug Use
description: A survey of about 2,000 college athletes throughout the United States shows that 27 percent smoke marijuana and 12 percent use cocaine, according to the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: On the Trick Of the Matchsticks
description: By moving a matchstick in the equal sign to create a ''less than'' symobl, Professor Abert Wilansky of Lehigh University pointed out in a letter to The New York Times another solution to Phil Nierko's matchstick trick. Several letters were received that indicated that one matchstick from ''VII'' could be moved over the equal sign to change it to the symbol ''is not equal to.'' However this violated Niekro's rule that no match could lie on any other.

title:
PROSPECTS;

Japan's Autos: A Calm View
description: A Toyota or Nissan in every American garage? With the quotas lifted on Japanese car imports, that possibility is giving American auto makers - and auto workers - the jitters. But Harald B. Malmgren, president of Malmgren Inc., a Washington consulting firm, takes a calmer view. Mr. Malmgren said that ''a sudden surge'' in Japanese car imports ''is very unlikely.''

title: No Headline
description: I could have wished to see the treasures of Tutankhamen under better circumstances than these: peering over a throng of tourists while our officious Egyptian guide shouts, ''Hurry up, please! Keep together!'' She rebukes me sternly when I veer off toward an exquisite figurine, recognized from an art book. It's not on our tour of ''highlights,'' and I might lose touch with the group. I could get lost in the labyrinthine museum, and there is no time for the bus to wait for stragglers. Trapped in Cairo, I would be yet another victim of Tutankhamen's curse.

title: VICTOR BANERJEE - INDIA PERSONIFIED
description: Victor Banerjee, with his electrifying performance as Dr. Aziz in David Lean's screen adaptation of E. M. Forster's ''Passage to India,'' has become the first Indian actor since Sabu, the ''elephant boy,'' to win world fame in a Hollywood movie. It is not at all likely that he will fade away and end, as Sabu did, a pauper in his native land.

title: WHAT SHARON WROUGHT
description: BOSTON When a country is misled by its government on fundamental issues of war and peace, it may take years to learn the price of folly. The decisions that took America step by step into Vietnam had their reckoning 10, 20, 30 years later.

title: OSLO: MEET ME AT THE CAFE
description: Joseph Heller's most recent novel is ''God Knows'' (Knopf).

title:
GARDENING;

OF SHAMROCKS AND POTATOES
description: IT is St. Patrick's Day, and there

title: NOTRE DAME LOSES
description: Even within the framework of a team there is a place for a soloist, a player who can dance alone when the time is right. And with only a minute and a half to play today and the score tied, Digger Phelps, the Notre Dame coach, told David Rivers that he had the floor to himself. Let the music play.

title: BHOPAL: A LESSON FOR THE STATE
description: LIKE the Chemical Control Corporation in Elizabeth and the Kin-Buc Landfill in Edison, the name Bhopal has become both a rallying cry for New Jersey environmentalists and a source of deep concern for the chemical industry.

title: LET'S UPDATE COUNTY GOVERNMENT
description: IN AN Opinion Page article on Jan. 20, Matthew Kauffman of the Princeton-based Center for Analysis of Public Issues argued that counties must be given more power to make policy.

title: NUPTIALS PLANNED BY PETER ENDICOTT AND MISS WILDER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Throop M. Wilder Jr. of Rockport, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carola Wilder, to Peter Bradford Endicott, a son of Bradford Maxwell Endicott of Dedham, Mass., and Birgit Carstensen of Mill Reef, Antigua. A September wedding is planned.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: The Princeton Pro Musica, conducted by

title: HEALTH SHOWS SEEK SPECIFIC AUDIENCES
description: ''I think any educational effort

title: RONDO DANCE SEASON TO OPEN
description: ''These dances fit together in spite of their contrasts,'' said Elizabeth Rockwell, director of the Rondo Dance Theater, as she discussed the Westchester-based company's 14th season, opening next weekend with performances in Yorktown, Tarrytown and Purchase. ''They cover a wide range of feeling - starting with a dance that is so up, so electric, so full of joie de vivre, that it looks like a court dance hyped up to 1980's tempo.''

title: SOUTHAMPTON EYES LAND IN 1783 GRANT
description: TO many lawyers, real-estate practice is mundane, dull and highly lucrative. One helps developers get their subdivisions approved, pockets handsome fees and seldom dines with environmentalists.

title: MANUAL FOR CHILDREN OF DRINKING PARENTS
description: TWO area residents have written a book that is believed to be the first one addressed specifically to the estimated 28 million adults in this country who grew up with an alcoholic parent.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CHICAGO GIRLS. By Edith Freund. (Poseidon, $16.95.)

title: Man Is Wounded by Brother During Fight in Copacabana
description: Three men accosted an off-duty officer early yesterday at the Copacabana nightclub in Manhattan, setting off a scuffle during which one of the men accidentally critically wounded his twin brother, the police said.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: The most unusual of the week's debut recitals was that of Joan Benson last Sunday afternoon at the Frick Collection. It was unusual partly because the Frick rarely solicits news coverage of its concerts, given their popularity and the small room in which they transpire, but mostly because Miss Benson is such a distinctive artist.

title: THREE SAXOPHONISTS BLOSSOM IN THE SPOTLIGHT
description: The ability of a jazz musician to blossom under a particular band leader and to reblossom in different terms when he is on his own is pointed up on three albums featuring tenor saxophonists - Paul Gonsalves, who was in Duke Ellington's band for 24 years, Charlie Rouse, a member of Thelonious Monk's Quartet for 11 years, and Buddy Tate, who spent a decade with Count Basie.

title: Mrs. Kriegsman,Architect, Is Wed
description: Betsey Wells Kriegsman, an architect with Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, and Samuel Farber, president and founder of Copco Inc., a manufacturer of kitchenware, were married at their New York apartment yesterday in a nondenominational ceremony performed by the Rev. Brewster Beach, an Episcopal priest.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: No Headline
description: SUNDAY, MARCH 17, 1985 International

title: Lab Into Offices-Space For Less
description: Rents for top-of-the-line office space in mid-Westchester County, which now hover around $25 a square foot, have prompted some space users to head for towns in the northern reaches of the county. In one of those communities, Yorktown Heights, a former I.B.M. laboratory and research facility has been converted into an office building with rents $10 or so below the rate in White Plains and other midcounty areas.

title: Candy Threat
description: Katsuhisa Ezaki was taking a bath at his home in the central Japanese city of Nishinomiya when three intruders kidnapped him a year ago this week. The event triggered a string of further deeds that became known as the Great Japanese Candy Caper.

title: LONG PENINSULA: THE SHAPE OF THINGS TO COME
description: ON Feb. 19, the United States Supreme Court decided by a 9-to-0 vote that Long Island legally is not an island. It is part of the mainland of New York and, therefore, a peninsula.

title: IRAQ SAYS ITS JETS HIT 11 CITIES
description: Iraq said its jet fighters attacked ''selected targets'' in 11 Iranian cities today after a powerful explosion shook Baghdad, the Iraqi capital. Iran said it retaliated with air raids and artillery attacks on 10 Iraqi cities.

title: YIDDISH POET CELEBRATES LIFE WITH HIS LANGUAGE
description: Abraham Sutzkever wrote poems as an underground fighter crawling through the sewers under the Vilna ghetto to elude the Nazis. He wrote them fighting with the partisans in the forests of Lithuania outside Vilna. He even remembers writing a poem while hiding inside a coffin.

title: Eliza J. Helman WedsEdwards M. Quigley 3d
description: Eliza Jane Helman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Helman of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to

title: Nancy C. MarksAnd Steven SilverTo Marry in June
description: A June wedding is planned by Nancy Carol Marks and Steven J. Silver, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alan D. Marks of Greenwich, Conn., have announced.

title: DONOVAN QUITS AND PREPARES TO STAND TRIAL
description: WHETHER Raymond J. Donovan jumped or was pushed is still a matter of dispute. But there is little doubt that the White House heaved one of its not always unanimous sighs of relief when the Labor Secretary last week offered President Reagan a resignation that was accepted ''with deep regret.''

title: PLAYING THE EXPLOSION IN V.C.R. SALES
description: AS the entertainment revolution has spread, one of the most conspicuous phenomena of the past year has been the explosion in sales of video cassette recorders. Americans alone are expected to buy 10 million to 12 million of these machines in 1985, up from 7.3 million last year.

title: NO. 2 GREEK GETS HIS WALKING PAPERS
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou further shook the confidence of Greece's allies last week by effectively eliminating from office the man they trusted to keep Mr. Papandreou from turning his anti-Western pronouncements into actions.

title: Article 099210 -- No Title
description: The Legislature ratified a $197 million increase in state spending this week and considered a 20-fold increase in the fine for killing a moose.

title: GANDHI'S AGENDA, NOW THAT HE REALLY NEEDS ONE
description: From the day he took office in November, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi has been campaigning to establish political legitimacy. He scored an extraordinary victory in the parliamentary election in December and a respectable, if somewhat shaky, success in this month's state assembly elections. Last week. he shifted gears, turning his attention to even tougher problems. ''With the elections out of the way,'' said Suman Dubey, an editor of India Today magazine, ''he is finally free to govern.''

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;

 QUILTS AND MORE
description: Although usually suspicious of art, the Amish have indulged in one creative pursuit: traditionally they have quilted, producing quilts of nonrepresentational and geometric designs in deep and brilliant colors. Focusing on Lancaster County, Pa., the site of the first Amish settlement in the United States, but also including examples from Ohio and Indiana, ''Amish Quilts,'' an exhibition of quilts, dolls and rare crib, buggy and coffin quilts, begins a two-month run today at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art. On loan from private collections and such institutions as the Museum of American Folk Art in New York, the display can be seen from 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays and 1 to 5 P.M. weekends through May 12. The museum is off Northern Boulevard in Roslyn Harbor. Admission is free.

title: FIRST TASTINGS
description: Food experts recall their introductions to a menu of delicacies, from white truffles to tripe, stone crab to barbecued pig, and vanilla ice cream. MAKE MINE FRENCH VANILLA

title: Miss SchmidlappPlanning to WedPeter Dembergh
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Carl J. Schmidlapp of Oyster Bay, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Barbara Sheafe Schmidlapp to Peter Jonson Dembergh, a son of Robert C. Dembergh of Ocean City, N.J., and the late Mrs. E. Rotan Sargent of Gladwyne, Pa. A July wedding in Sun Valley, Idaho, is planned.

title: THE WAYS OF A WIMP
description: Actually Thomas Flanagan is not as much of a wimp as he is a loser.

title: BOSTON DOCTORS SAY NEW THERAPY EASES ARTHRITIS SYMPTOMS
description: Doctors say they can temporarily ease the pain and swelling of rheumatoid arthritis and help victims walk again by injecting a radioactive element directly into the damaged knees.

title: 'Brooklyn Landscape'
description: Brooklyn's diverse neighborhoods are depicted in an exhibition of artwork and photographs at the Rotunda Gallery, Brooklyn War Memorial, Cadman Plaza West and Orange Street, through April 20. Works by 14 artists are in the show, titled ''The Brooklyn Landscape.''

title: Conner Virtually Out Of Congressional Cup
description: Dennis Conner of San Diego, who lost the America's Cup to Australia in 1983, is virtually out of the race for the Congressional Cup.

title: No Headline
description: BEST SELLERS

title: Victoria RhodesIs to Marry in '86
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Rhodes Jr. of Waverly, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Victoria Lammot Rhodes, to Owen David Gutfreund, a son of Joyce Gutfreund and John Gutfreund, both of New York. The wedding is to be in the spring of next year.

title: Battling Hydrilla
description: For years the Potomac River was so polluted that plant life all but vanished. But after a cleanup effort, the Ecological Services Laboratory of the National Parks Service put test plantings in the river in 1980 to see if they would thrive.

title: BABBITT OF ARIZONA EYES 'DARK HORSE' BID FOR PREESIDENCY IN '88
description: Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona, his ambition stoked by a burst of interest by fellow Democrats and the national press, is meeting with advisers this weekend to discuss making what he calls ''the darkest of dark horse'' bids for the Presidency in 1988.

title: CAMBRIDGE THROUGH OXFORD EYES
description: A. L. ROWSE is Emeritus Fellow of All Souls College, Oxford, and the author of many books on British history, including several on Shakespeare and the Elizabethan period.

title: M.M. Stichnoth WedTo Neele-Banks Cohe
description: Neele-Banks Cohe, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. S. Robert Cohe of Westwood, N.J., was married yesterday to Matthew Miller Stichnoth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Stichnoth of Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. Anita Schell-Lambert, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel of Trinity Parish in Manhattan.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Togs and Price Tags To Attract Browsers Sue Ullrich Inc., has been a Tuckahoe source for discounted and full- price dresses and sportswear, leather and evening purses, belts and costume jewelry for 35 years - a casual, browsing place that takes no credit cards, but will accept personal checks, with identification.

title: COUNTY REPUBLICANS PREPARE FOR KEY '85 RACES
description: RYE BROOK WESTCHESTER'S Republicans, celebrating the electoral triumphs of last November, went to dinner together last week and initiated a drive to improve their control over key offices in a county that has a new Democratic majority in party enrollment.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: VY COTTAGETWritten and Illustrated by E. J. Taylor TUnpaginated. New York: Alfred A. Knopf, $7.95.

title: RETURN OF THE IMMORTAL DETECTIVE
description: LONDON

title: IRISH LETTERS
description: In a cerebral celebration of St. Patrick's Day, Thomas Flanagan, a professor whose first novel, ''The Year of the French,'' won the National Book Critics Circle Award in 1980, and Seamus Heaney, the Irish poet, will share a three-day residency at Seton Hall University in South Orange this week.

title:
DINING OUT;

A 'TIME CAPSULE' IN MILLWOOD
description: THE Langner family chose an appropriate name when it took over an early 19th-century coach stop in Millwood 25 years ago and called it Travelers Rest. Dark oak paneling, soft lighting and wine-dark carpeting give the place the soothing, hushed quality of a theater lobby, although deep, padded dining room swivel chairs are alone a restorative for the travel weary.

title: NORTH FORK WATER: CAN ALL BE SERVED?
description: GREENPORT'S water may not be too good, says the Suffolk County Department of Health Services, but the agency wants more people to drink it.

title: Investing in Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Angola MIG Reported Down
description: The Angolan rebels said Friday in a statement here that they had shot down a MIG-21 fighter-bomber near Bie, killing the Cuban pilot, Capt. Garcia Ortega Gonzales. The Angolan Government press agency said that the plane had crashed while trying ''a difficult maneuver'' and that the pilot was an Angolan.

title: WHERE BIRDS AND BEASTS BEWITCH
description: William F. Buckley Jr. is the author of ''The Story of Henri Tod'' (Doubleday).

title: Wendy A. Peshkin Engaged to Stanley D. Forkner
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Peshkin of Weston, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Ann Peshkin, to Stanley Delafield Forkner, a son of Mrs. William A. Cameron of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and Dr. Claude E. Forkner Jr. of New York and Sharon, Conn. The wedding is planned for April 21.

title: Linda Carol Friedman Marries James M. Lippman
description: Linda Carol Friedman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee J. Friedman of Sands Point, L.I., was married yesterday to James Michael Lippman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lippman of Oyster Bay, L.I. Rabbi Samuel Geffen performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan.

title: EXPLORING THE MUSEUMS OF BERLIN
description: MICHAEL RATCLIFFE is theater critic of The Observer in London.

title: DINING DELUXE
description: I DON'T THINK IT IS UNnecessarily chauvinistic to say that New York is the ultimate city for all things relating to food. There is scarcely an herb, spice or arcane ingredient that cannot be found on the island of Manhattan. You may have to travel to Chinatown, to the Indian section on Lexington Avenue or uptown to Harlem, but your search will probably be fruitful.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A PEOPLE'S ARMY: Massachusetts Soldiers and Society in the Seven Years' War. By Fred Anderson. (University of North Carolina, $25.)

title: RESORT TOLD TO RAZE 10 UNITS
description: A DECISION handed down recently by a State Supreme Court justice concerning a resort in Montauk may have far-reaching effects on the way developers operate in the East End.

title:
ART;

WHAT FOUR WINNERS HAVE CREATED
description: AN exhibition of work by the winners of Northport Galleries' fourth national juried competition is on view at the cooperative's headquarters on Woodbine Avenue. Four artists were selected from slides by the art critic and curator Phyllis Braff, who judged 138 entries.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER/A SPECIAL ROUTE
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: DIRECTIONAL SIGNALS FROM MILAN
description: The reason fashion designers and their work have seemed so exuberant this week is probably related to the fact that sales of Italian fashion were up 20 percent in 1984 over the previous year. There is nothing like success to create confidence.

title: India to Import 10,000 Cows
description: India, with one of the largest cattle populations in the world at 182 million, will import 10,000 cows from the European Economic Community, the Press Trust of India said today.

title: MUSIC SET TO WORDS
description: BLUES, IDEOLOGY, AND AFRO-AMERICAN LITERATURE A Vernacular Theory. By Houston A. Baker Jr. 227 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $19.95.

title: PORT AGENCY PREDICTS GROWTH FOR NEW YORK REGION
description: The New York metropolitan region experienced strong economic growth in 1984 that should continue this year, though at a slower rate, according to an annual report issued by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Data Update
description: * Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: FIRST SIGHTINGS
description: From an artist's street in Rome to the pull of the African bush, correspondents of The Times report on some memorable discoveries. HUCK FINN'S TWO RIVERS

title: FROM A RAINY MIAMI DAY TO FINAL 4 IN LEXINGTON
description: In two weeks, when the nets are cut

title: TABLE HOPPING IN HOLLYWOOD
description: BRYAN MILLER is the restaurant critic of The New York Times.

title: Frann Bilus Marries Richard Scott Feldman
description: Frann Bilus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Bilus of Bloomfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard Scott Feldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Feldman of Wynnewood, Pa. Rabbis Marshall Maltzman and Steven Kushner officiated at the Chanticler restaurant in Short Hills, N.J. The bride is an assistant product manager for Welch Foods Inc. in Concord, Mass. Mr. Feldman is a vice president of the Stanmar Company, a real-estate development company in Brookline, Mass.

title: ECHOES OF LONIGAN, 50 YEARS AFTER
description: THE last time I was in Chicago, I went looking for Studs Lonigan. I drove to the South Side, to the corner of 58th and Prairie, searching for Gus the Greek's greasy spoon and Charley Bachelor's pool hall, the places where Studs and Red Kelly and the rest of the 58th Street Gang misspent their youths. What I found was the Chuck & Terry Resale Shop, Rocky's Food-Liquor and the New Life Church. The kids lounging on the curbs didn't look very Irish Catholic; Studs' old neighborhood is now part of a sprawling black ghetto.

title: GANDHI, SHIFTING TACTICS, PURSUES SIKH CONTACTS
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, in a shift of tactics, is trying to renew contacts with Sikh leaders and is exploring ways to accommodate some of their demands.

title: METAMORPHOSES
description: MR. AND MRS. BABY

title: NINA MCNEELY ENGAGED TO WED
description: Mrs. Edgar B. Coale of Philadelphia and George H. McNeely 3d of Gladwyne, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nina Warren McNeely, to David Peter Diefenbach, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Diefenbach of Rye, N.Y.

title: APARTMENT-OFFICE COMPLEX PROPOSED FOR FORT LEE TRACT
description: -RISE condominium apartment

title: Lutheran DefrockedThe Lutheran Church in America wants its pastors to speak out on public issues - so long as they do not destroy their congregations in the process. That point was crossed by the
description: Rev. D. Douglas Roth, the church decided last week, when his campaign to help the unemployed in smokestack Pennsylvania divided his parish in Clairton.

title: Bank Holiday in Ohio
description: With more and more depositors lining up to withdraw their money from Ohio savings institutions, Gov. Richard Celeste late last week declared a three-day holiday at 70 of the state-chartered savings and loan associations.

title: LANDFILLS IN HISTORY
description: HAMMOND INNES is the author of ''The Black Tide'' (Doubleday).

title: THE ADVENTURES OF PINFOLD AND FUZZY
description: FUNNY PAPERS By Tom De Haven. 368 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: S.R.O. Freeze
description: To the Editor:

title: Pierce and Page Gain Semifinals in Squash
description: Mike Pierce and Tom Page, the top-seeded players in a $10,000 professional squash doubles tournament at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn, advanced to the semifinals yesterday.

title: RUNNING RCA FROM BEHIND THE SCENES
description: HANGING on the wall in the hall leading to his office are 12 black-and-white photographs, fastidiously arranged in two rows, one above the other. They signify 65 years of leadership - the 12 chieftains, starting with Owen Young in 1919, of the RCA Corporation.

title: Bank AuditorsOn the Carpet
description: It was the Federal banking regulators' turn for a public flaying last week as a Congressional subcommittee began asking why some American banks have been processing large cash transactions and failing to file required reports with the Government.

title: CHEMICALS CITED IN DISPUTE ON ZONING
description: AN effort by Tetko Inc., a Swiss company that imports filtering and screening materials for industrial use, to move to a residential neighborhood in Briarcliff Manor has roused residents' fears of toxic poisoning from chemicals that would be stored and demonstrated at the plant.

title: THE GREAT NICARAGUA POSTAGE STAMP WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Carter First American to Get World Methodist Peace Prize
description: Former President Jimmy Carter has received the World Methodist Peace Award, honoring him as a champion of human rights, a negotiator for peace and arms control, and a carpenter who builds houses for the poor.

title: HIGHER RATES CREATE A FLURRY OF NEW ISSUES
description: Seven stamps in four separate issues will be released by Saturday. The new-issue flurry meets the needs of the United States Postal Service to have stocks of stamps and postal stationery to cover the new postal rates and to continue the normal run of commemoratives.

title: CLINIC HELPS STUDENTS OF LAW OBTAIN FIRSTHAND EXPERIENCE
description: Two floors above Church and Leonard Streets in downtown Manhattan, several law students recently faced each other across tables cluttered with papers. At each table, one student played the role of an attorney and another played a client.

title: Seaway to Open by April 1
description: The St. Lawrence Seaway will open by April 1 for the 1985 shipping season, according to Dennis Deuschl, a spokesman for the agency that adminsters the waterway. ''April 1 will be the latest,'' Mr. Deuschl said Friday. ''We could possibly open earlier if the weather continues to cooperate and if there are ships to move.''

title: Marmalade: Yes...
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM SELZNICK TO VIVALDI AND BARRY MANILOW
description: Vivaldi: The Four Seasons Featuring Isaac Stern, Pinchas Zukerman, Shlomo Mintz, Itzhak Perlman, violinists; with the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Zubin Mehta Pacific Arts Video 45 minutes. $39.95

title: Jersey Boxing Bill
description: Governor Kean has signed legislation designed to reform New Jersey's boxing industry by replacing the single athletic commissioner with a three-member Athletic Control Board and creating a seven-member Medical Advisory Council. The measure grew out of a finding by the State Commission of Investigation last year that the one-man commission had been ''demonstrably unable to cope with its regulatory obligations.''

title: Suspended Worker Kills 4 at Plant and Himself
description: A worker in a glass factory, ''furious'' at being suspended today, returned to the plant and shot five supervisors, killing four of them, before he shot himself to death, the authorities said.

title: Miss Murray to Marry John Sargent Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert K. Murray of State College, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Constance Lane Murray to John Turner Sargent Jr., the son of Mr. Sargent of New York and Neltje of Banner, Wyo. A September wedding is planned.

title: Arleen Auger Sings At Alice Tully Hall
description: Arleen Auger's song recital at Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night was less a concert than a conversation - its good sense and exquisite sentiments couched in the quietest of tones. In five songs by Brahms, five by Wolf, a recitative and aria by Haydn, a new piece by Judith Lang Zaimont and then other songs by Ravel and Rodrigo, Miss Auger extolled the powers of intimacy and, by implication at least, rejected the hard sell.

description: A. H. Raskin comments on the ''solidarity the strikers showed in their long battle with Yale.'' The caption accompanying the photograph of Lane Kirkland addressing the Yale workers states, ''the workers won substantial pay increases after a 10-week walkout.''

title: WESTCHESTER OPININION ;   PRESERVING THE PAST IS A COMMUNITY JOB-NOT ONE ONLY FOR HISTORIANS
description: WHEN an animal species is endangered people rush to its defense. A warm, furry thing seems to bring out the best in us. We protect it from its worst predator, usually man, and once again when the animal multiplies its survival is assured. But there is another endangered species that does not often share an animal's good fortune: the old house and property with historic value.

title: No Headline
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Klein of New Rochelle, N.Y., announce the engagement of their daughter Susan Nancy Klein to John Paul Echeverria, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Echeverria of Fresno, Calif. A May wedding is planned.

title: SHERIFFS PRESS FOR SAFER COURTS
description: COURT officials are hoping that the fatal shooting of an East Lyme woman in a crowded Norwich courtroom will prompt the state to increase security at courthouses.

title:
CAMERA;

COMPUTERS CAN HELP TO LIGHTEN MANY TASKS
description: Peggy Sealfon is a freelance writer who specializes in photography. Computers have found their way into the photographers' studios and darkrooms. Not only are they taking care of business details to enable photographers to keep on top of expenses, mailings and other paperwork that robs time from the creative process, they are also becoming valuable ''assistants'' in the shooting and processing of photographs.

title: Pouring OilThe Attorney General of Texas was claiming a victory over big business last week.
description: Jim Mattox was found not guilty of commercial bribery in a case that he characterized as a battle between him and Mobil Oil Company. Mr. Mattox was alleged to have threatened to destroy the bond business of a Houston law firm because one of its partners was trying to question his sister about a $125,000 loan to his campaign. The loan, the Texas press reported, came from an oilman who had sued Mobil, with the Attorney General's help, over an oil lease. Mr. Mattox's aim, his lawyers argued, was to ''protect the people of the state and the children of the state from Mobil Oil Company.'' ''We have proven,'' Mr. Mattox said after the verdict, ''that they can't run over the Attorney General.''

title: IN LEBANON, THE WORST IS ALWAYS YET TO COME
description: For a decade, Lebanon has been a synonym for anarchy and violence. At almost any time, it has seemed impossible for things to get worse, but last week they did. It was every man for himself as chaos appeared to turn into disintegration.

description: Margarett Loke is an editor of this magazine.

title: GENERALS VS. STARS: A WHOLE NEW GAME
description: When they met in the playoffs last June, the Stars routed the Generals, 28-7. Nearly nine months later, the Stars' uniforms are the same and the players almost all the same but the circumstances for today's contest will be quite different.

title: UNIONISTS FORESEE TENSION WITH U.S.
description: Whoever succeeds Raymond J. Donovan as Secretary of Labor will inherit a desk piled high with unfinished business, including two seemingly contradictory agendas. One is to improve the Reagan Administration's frayed relations with organized labor. The other is to relax a broad spectrum of laws designed to protect the wages, hours and working conditions of millions of workers.

title: LASTING LASHES
description: THICK, DARK LASHES FORM A SEDUCTIVE FRAME for the eyes, accenting their shape, luminosity and color. And where nature hasn't provided them, women have found a way: mascara. More than two-thirds of American women between the ages of 10 and 64 use the product, according to the Maybelline Company, the nation's leading marketer of the cosmetic. Most apply it daily. Yet mascara can be one of the trickiest cosmetics to apply safely, especially for those who wear contact lenses. Mascara has generated the largest number of injuries treated in emergency rooms - 2,390 last year - of all eye cosmetics, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: JENNIFER DUPONT SAGE TO WED ROBIN EVETTS

description: After Neil Simon moved from New York to California a few years ago, he looked for a West Coast analogue to the Plaza, the Manhattan hotel in which he set his successful play, ''Plaza Suite.''

title: LEARNING TO LIVE WITH THE ARTIFICIAL HEART
description: William J. Schroeder didn't attend his son's wedding yesterday, but he did attain a medical milestone. Despite extreme physical weakness and damage from a severe stroke, he reached his 112th day on a Jarvik-7 heart, thus tying Dr. Barney Clark, the first human to receive the mechanical device.

Her fiance is a son of Jessie Leigh Hunt Wood of Water Mill, L.I., and Spetsai, Greece, and Albert Cabell Bruce Jr. of Hilton Head Island, S.C. A June wedding is planned.

SEEKING PEACE IN MIDEAST

To the outsider, the recent statements and ''initiatives'' by Egyptian, Jordanian, Israeli and Palestine Liberation Organization leaders may seem to be nothing more than a confusing cacophony that has produced a few headlines and flutters of diplomatic activity, but nothing more.

title:
MEN'S STYLE;

STAYING DRY
description: A GOOD UMBRELLA CONSISTS OF SEVERAL ELEMENTS: shank, or shaft; collapsible steel frame; fabric, and handle. Standard hardwoods, such as ash and maple, are generally used for shanks, although, according to retailers, roughly an equal number of wood-shank and steel-shank umbrellas are sold each year. Each has its advantages. An opened umbrella looks better with a thick wood shaft, and steel shanks, no matter how well set in the handle, tend to loosen. Moreover, you can't lean on them the way you can lean on wood. On the other hand, steel-shank umbrellas weigh less and can be wrapped more tightly.

title: BETTER LEFT UNSAID
description: WHILE POLISHing my skin the other morning to uncover its best-looking surface, I fell to thinking about my father, long dead, and how I might explain to him, if the need arose, what I was up to at that instant. Whether any men at all polished their skin during his lifetime, I do not know; certainly it was not done in circles he frequented.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Going Out Guide yesterday on a poetry reading today by Abraham Sutzkever at the Institute for the Advancement of Judaism gave the wrong address. The reading at 2 P.M. will be at the institute, 15 West 86th Street, between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue.

title: WESTCHESTER OPININION ;   PATIENCE THIN? ENTER THE PUSHOVER

''If you can't sit here quietly while your parents eat their breakfast I'm afraid you'll have to spend the rest of the meal upstairs in your crib.''

title: On Course forStaten Island
description: After an on-again, off-again courtship, the United States Navy and Staten Island made a match last week. John F. Lehman, the Secretary of the Navy, approved a plan to make Staten Island home port for a fleet of seven ships led by the battleship Iowa.

title: BUTTONING DOWN A BUILDING: A GUIDE TO SECURITY
description: SOME New York apartment houses bristle with security. Closed-circuit television cameras peer down from every corner like unblinking, ever-vigilant owls. Electronic locks buzz and click and television monitor screens flicker under harsh lights. Uniformed guards are posted round the clock at every portal. Hallways are mirrored and fire escapes wired with alarms to detect intruders - some so delicate that even overfed pigeons can set them off.

description: Archbishop John J. O'Connor of New York, a former military chaplain who is an outspoken advocate of a strong military, has urged Congress to vote down funds for the MX nuclear missile.

title: LIFE ON THE LIST, OR MY STRUGGLE WITH 'MOSES THE KITTEN'
description: A LOT of bad things that have nothing to do with writing start happening to an author once a book is published. The pinnacle of good times for the writer is the instant the book is completed. It's all downhill from there no matter what honors the book gets or how much money it brings in. Nothing makes an author feel as good as he felt when he finished the book.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart accompanying an article on the foreign exchange rate in the Feb. 17 issue gave incorrect information regarding the price of a dinner at the Tandoori Restaurant in New Delhi's President Hotel. Dinner for two, including wine, is 330 rupees, or $26. Without wine, the cost is 192 rupees, or $15.

title: Last of Expo Nucleus Eyes Future
description: ON PAPER, the Montreal Expos do not look like they will prevent the Mets or the Chicago Cubs or anyone else from winning the National League East title this year. But then, as Steve Rogers noted, ''The nucleus that people called the team of the '80's never compared with what we had on paper.''

title: Randi Greenberg Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Greenberg of Allentown, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Randi Beth Greenberg, to Assif Rozovsky, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Eliezer Rozovsky of Cherry Hill, N.J. An August wedding is planned. Miss Greenberg is a student at Rollins College and Mr. Rozovsky, a Lehigh University graduate, is attending medical school at Hahnemann University in Philadelphia. The future bride's father is president of Hess's Department Store in Allentown.

title: THE SOUND OF THE OPEN ROAD GROWS CLEARER
description: At the sight of the first crocus, I got carried away by vernal euphoria and took off the snow tires. In New England, this is a deeply optimistic act of faith. My other springtime ritual is to check out developments in car stereo. The first green reminds me of the approaching travel season, and these days the song of the open road is built into the dashboard.

title: Jacqueline S. Freed to WedDavid E. Simon Next June

The singer, who opened a five-night engagement at Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday, sharing the bill with Dionne Warwick, hasn't changed markedly since the late 1950's.

title: PLAYS THAT SUFFER FROM THEIR PAST LIVES
description: With four openings in as many days, three on Broadway and one at the Public Theater, it looked as if the slumbering season might emerge from hibernation. Instead, one was overcome by the feeling that, in one form or another, we had been on these journeys before. In my own case, this knowledge was confirmed by the fact that I had seen three of the plays, ''The Octette Bridge Club,'' ''Anatol'' (retitled ''The Loves of Anatol'') and ''Virginia,'' in other, recent productions. The fourth, ''Requiem for a Heavyweight,'' was new to the stage, but the story was familiar from its television and film incarnations. Furthermore, in all but ''Anatol,'' there were aspects - in the dramaturgy, subject matter or performance styles - that were decidedly dej a vu. Each of the four was burdened by an overloaded bank of memory.

title: Q & A: WHAT'S RIDING ON THE MX VOTES
description: Congress has taken up the question of whether production of the intercontinental MX nuclear missile should continue, On Tuesday, a House appropriations subcommittee endorsed the spending of $1.5 billion on 21 of the 10-warhead missiles. This week the Senate is scheduled to vote on whether to continue production of the intercontinental MX missile; the full House is due to vote the following week. Last year, the MX was kept alive only after Vice President Bush broke a 48-to-48 tie. Questions and answers on the MX debate follow.

title: Art

Always interested in new techniques, he tried, at this point, the relatively crude but powerful medium of linoleum block.

title: ACCOUNTANTS CAN REGULATE THEMSELVES
description: THE current Congressional hearings on the accounting profession have pointed up the common misconception that a ''clean opinion'' by an auditor on a company's financial statements is a guarantee that the company won't subsequently fail. In fact, such an opinion provides the public with reasonable assurance that the representations of management reflected in the company's financial statements comply with generally accepted accounting principles.

title: EXPLORING MARKET FOR ISRISH WHISKY
description: WHEN people think of businesses setting up headquarters in Westchester, the names that come to mind are big corporations like International Business Machines, Texaco and General Foods. They don't generally think of Irish whisky. But since 1981, White Plains has been the United States base for the marketing of Irish whisky in North America.
