title: OHIO THRIFT UNITS DEAL WITH A CRISIS
description: Ohio officials moved quickly to try to quell a crisis in state-chartered thrift institutions. Depositors, frightened by the collapse of Home State Savings a week ago, which all but depleted the private insurance fund covering the units, lined up at other thrift institutions to withdraw their savings. A three-day banking holiday for the 71 institutions declared by Gov. Richard F. Celeste - the first such declaration in recent memory - and enactment of an emergency insurance fund gave the institutions some breathing room, but it was not clear whether the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation would be willing or able to take over the insurance duties. The vulnerability of other state and private insurance funds for banks and thrift institutions is also under scrutiny.

title: Lauren L. FaxonWed in California
description: Lauren Louise Faxon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Faxon of Palo Alto, Calif., was married yesterday to Torrey Dexter Brooks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. B. V. Brooks of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Dr. James Emerson, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Auberge Soleil, a restaurant in Rutherford, Calif.

title: CONTADORA GROUP TO RESUME TALKS
description: The Contadora group of nations announced today the resumption of its Central American peace efforts after a six-month interruption marked by growing tensions in the region.

title: Towing for Disabled Boats Is Planned
description: Relief may be in sight this summer for people whose boats break down on Long Island Sound and who find, to their dismay, that the Coast Guard refers them to a private towing company.

title: FATHER AND SON IN AN AGE OF CHANGING ROLES
description: MY son and only child will be graduating from high school this year, and when I saw his senior pictures, I felt the need to record this moment in time for myself, too. I called a friend of mine to take the photographs.

title: THE AGINH OF TRAVIS MCGEE
description: THE LONELY SILVER RAIN By John D. MacDonald. 232 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: I-95 SELECTED FOR WORK ON BARRIERS
description: MOTORISTS on the Connecticut Turnpike will find travel disrupted in seven locations between Greenwich and New Haven this summer, when the first sections of the so- called Jersey barriers are installed to divide the northbound and southbound lanes.

title: HUSSEIN SAYS U.S. MUST TAKE A ROLE IN PEACE PROCESS
description: King Hussein of Jordan says he can move no further toward reviving the long- stalled Middle East peace process unless the United States agrees to meet with a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation. He has also ruled out any peace talks that do not include the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: The New Soviet Man
description: Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev vows to get the Soviet Union moving again, even to produce a ''profound transformation'' by the year 2000. A bare five years after becoming the Politburo's youngest member, he is its undisputed leader. He promises to redesign the economy and ''the entire system of social relations'' so as ''to enter the new millennium as a great and flourishing state.'' Better learn the name; it's pronounced

title: DELAYED DEBUT AT CARNEGIE
description: What famous string quartet has kept its membership intact for 38 years, is said to have sold nearly three million recordings and has had a book written about it? It's the Amadeus Quartet, of course, and on Friday night, the London-based ensemble will make its Carnegie Hall debut 32 years after it first began to tour here. The Amadeus remembers well the days when string quartets would never have considered performing in large halls, but seems content now to be adding Carnegie to its list of conquests.

title: H.U.D. JOB FOR D'AMATO ALLY?
description: CHARLES GARGANO is apparently about to get his reward for managing President Reagan's New York State campaign last year.

title: Sound Editor Receives Special Oscar Award
description: Kay Rose, sound editor of the film ''The River,'' was awarded an Oscar for special achievement Wednesday by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

title: Neo-Liberals Have a Message for the Democats
description: To the Editor:

title: M.J. Finnegan, Miss YonkmanExchange Vows
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Margriet E. Yonkman, a daughter of Mrs. Raymond B. Rudy of Greenwich and Fredrick A. Yonkman of Ridgefield, Conn., and New York, was married to Michael Joseph Finnegan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John Gerard Finnegan of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Richard H. Stearns performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. James T. McGuire, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: GOING IN STYLE: AN UPDATE
description: BERNADINE MORRIS reports on fashion for The Times.

title: FIRST TASTINGS
description: Food experts recall their introductions to a menu of delicacies, from white truffles to tripe, stone crab to barbecued pig, and vanilla ice cream. BARBECUE IN GEORGIA

title: Legal Fees At Risk
description: In Federal court in Manhattan, meanwhile, a lawyer was ordered to disclose the legal fees that he was receiving from a client in a narcotics case. ''Fees paid to attorneys cannot become a safe harbor from forfeiture of the profits of illegal enterprises,'' said Judge David N. Edelstein, adding that the Government might try to confiscate the fees as profits from a crime if the client was the prosecution was called ''outrageous'' by the New York Civil Liberties Union, which charged that Federal prosecutors were ''attempting to put the prosecution in control of who a defendant hires.''

title: LET'S HEAR IT FOR HEALTHY SKEPTICISM
description: Earnest program annotators regularly warn us that listening to music is not nearly so enjoyable as it seems. Sit up straight and pay attention, they say. Be serious. Concentrate. Remember Brahms's warning: ''A symphony is no joke.'' Above all, refrain from trying to decide whether you like the work you have just heard. Doesn't everyone know that serious music cannot be sensibly judged until it has been in the standard repertory for 40 or 50 years? Didn't audiences boo ''Le Sacre du Printemps'' at its premiere?

title: FARM'S SEEDS: TOIL, DEBT AND DARING
description: Men like Dale Hermreck are hard to find in the Middle West nowadays. But when the United States Jaycees found him, it named him one of its four Outstanding Young Farmers of 1985.

title: AUTO MAKERS TAKE LEMON LAW TO COURT
description: HARTFORD STATE officials and representatives of the automobile industry spent last week preparing for a showdown over the ordinance known as ''Lemon Law II.''

title: White Sox Take No Chances
description: A year ago, Tony LaRussa recalled today, he made a point of talking to his players about the division title they had won the previous season.

title: BURNING OF TOXIC WASTE DEBATED
description: Environmental groups are preparing their final challenges to a plan to test the burning of toxic wastes aboard ships in the Atlantic Ocean 160 miles southeast of here.

title:
ANTIQUES;

POLITICAL ITEMS FROM OUR PAST
description: EPHEMERA collectors are among those few dealers who can carry in one small container all the merchandise needed to set up a complete show exhibit.

title: PUPPETS ARE NOT JUST FOR CHILDREN ANYMORE
description: BART P. ROCCOBERTON Jr. works in a barn with Lady Elf, Oedipus Rex, a formally attired mole and dozens of other puppets.

title: MILITARY PENSIONS
description: * To the Editor:

title: KENTUCKY UPSETS LAS VEGAS, 64-61 SALT LAKE CITY, March 16 (AP) - Kenny Walker scored 23 points, including a key slam dunk with 21 seconds left, to lead Kentucky to a 64-61 upset over Nevada-Las Vegas in a second-round West Regional game today.
description: Las Vegas (28-4), the Pacific Coast Athletic Association champion, was forced by Kentucky's zone to play an unfamiliar half-court game and scored 21 fewer points than its average for the season.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: -awaited decision by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency on whether to relocate a sewage- sludge dump site now 12 miles off Sandy Hook will apparently not be issued on April 1, as most people had expected.

title: Oklahoma Gains; La. Tech Triumphs
description: Wayman Tisdale used his left-handed jump shot to near perfection for 29 points today as Oklahoma held off Illinois State, 75-69, in the second round of the N.C.A.A. Midwest Regional.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: UPSTREAM: A Voyage on the Connecticut River. By Ben Bachman (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.)

title: FIRST SIGHTINGS
description: From an artist's street in Rome to the pull of the African bush, correspondents of The Times report on some memorable discoveries.

title: FIRST SIGHTINGS
description: From an artist's street in Rome to the pull of the African bush, correspondents of The Times report on some memorable discoveries. THE TRIUMPH OF PRAGUE

title: Helistat Dream
description: Two years ago at this time Frank N. Piasecki, a helicopter pioneer, was at the Naval Air Engineering Center in Lakehurst, N.J., putting together a strange aircraft called the Helistat.

title: SO YOU WANT TO GET AWAY?
description: John Vinocur is chief of the Paris bureau of The New York Times.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION ;   CUISINE CHEZ NOUS JUST GOT TOO HAUTE
description: HERE is my dream. I have had it since I was a teenager: I am wearing a casually elegant hostess gown. My friends, chattering and laughing but seriously impressed, are seated around my dining room table somewhere in suburbia devouring a truly haute-cuisine dinner that I have whipped up for them. Effortlessly. And the wonder of it all is that I have a full-time career and two children and am about to publish my first novel.

title: R. F. Rock to WedMiss Wolf in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Wolf of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marcy Lynn Wolf, to Randy F. Rock, the son of Mrs. Morris D. Rock of Long Beach, L.I., and the late Mr. Rock. A May wedding is planned.

title: ETHIOPIA DENIES FORCED RESETTLEMENT REPORTS
description: A senior Ethiopian Government official says reports about forced resettlement of famine victims are either misunderstandings or the work of the Central Intelligence Agency and other foreign agents who he says have ''intentionally spread false propaganda.''

title: 3 Guards Are Slightly Hurt In a Disturbance at Attica
description: Three guards at the Attica Correctional Facility were slightly injured last night in putting down a disturbance between inmates in a prison mess hall, authorities said.

title: 2 IN MEXICAN POLICE CHARGED IN SLAYING OF U.S. DRUG AGENT
description: The authorities charged two police officers today with the kidnapping and murder of a United States Drug Enforcement Administration agent and said four other policemen and a former officer were charged with lesser offenses in the case.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A BIT OF SINGING AND DANCING. By Susan Hill. (Hamish Hamilton/David & Charles. $16.95.)

title: WAYS TO SAVE ON ATLANTIC FLIGHTS
description: As Donald L. Pevsner sees it, Americans are being discriminated against by the prices they must pay to fly round trip to Europe. The crux of his argument, as contained in a complaint to the United States Department of Transportation, is that the dollar prices that Americans pay are up to 80.2 percent more than what Europeans pay in local currencies for trans-Atlantic round trips that begin abroad.

title: IN 85,000 BRITISH PUBS, IT'S CIDER TIME
description: The quest for lighter, more ''natural'' and healthful-seeming beverages so popular in the United States is also bubbling up in the deeply established drinking habits of the British. The movement is particularly effervescent here in the heart of the world's largest cidermaking enterprise, H. P. Bulmer Ltd., a 98- year-old company that has prospered mightily from changes in Britons' drinking habits.

title: ...And No
description: To the Editor:

title: WLIW'S ROLE DEBATED
description: WHITHER Channel 21? Who is watching and when, and what impact is WLIW-TV, the Long Island public television station, having on its audience?

title: THINGS LOOK UP ON THE GROUND
description: Because the skies over six major airports grew friendlier in the past four months, delays on the ground became more manageable, the Federal Aviation Administration said last week. Cooperation among airlines serving the three New York airports and Atlanta, Chicago, and Denver led to a drop in the number of delays from 1,600 per day to 900.

title: Drunken Driver Gets Jail Term And Visit to Comatose Victim
description: A judge has sentenced a drunken driver to a six-month jail term and to pay a hospital visit to a woman he left comatose.

title: The Ways Of a Wimp
description: My thanks to Thomas Flanagan for his essay, ''The Ways of a Wimp,'' (About Men, Feb. 10). It is the unyielding zealots of both right and left who frighten this unrepentant wimp. WILLIAM S. WEINBERG

title: Salley Has Grown At Georgia Tech
description: Bobby Cremins halted a preseason practice and turned to an observer on the sidelines. ''What were those things you were telling me about John Salley?'' he called. ''Come on out here and tell the team,'' said the Georgia Tech coach.

title: THE THEATER OF DOCUDRAMA AND 'TREASON CHIC'
description: Has docudrama - that highly selective blend of fact and fiction - invaded all the dramatic arts? Can powerful acting and clever writing blur an audience's perceptions? Is treason chic?

title: No Pedestal Just Yet For Peter Ueberroth
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Tese Formally Named To Take Over U.D.C.
description: Governor Cuomo has formally nominated Vincent Tese, the State Banking Superintendent, to head the Urban Development Corporation.

title: Kahn and Donaldson In Lyricists Retrospecti ve
description: Trying to fit Gus Kahn and Walter Donaldson into the context of the ''Great Songwriting Teams Remembered'' series that is the theme of the ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' concerts at the 92d Street Y proved difficult in the performances devoted to their work last Sunday and Monday.

title: A Second JuryConsiders CaseAgainst Goetz
description: A new grand jury last week began to assess the evidence against Bernhard H. Goetz, the subway gunman, to decide whether he should stand trial on charges more serious than illegal possession of firearms. The reopening of the case is based in part on the appearance of a secret new witness who was aboard the subway train in Manhattan when Mr. Goetz opened fire on four teen-agers, according to the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE MOLDING OF A BUDGET PLAN
description: Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, returned from Geneva Wednesday evening and found that Senator Pete V. Domenici had wrestled a package of spending cuts out of his Budget Committee.

title: MONEY COULD MAKE A ZOO A STAR, ADVOCATES SAY
description: THE Beardsley Zoological Garden in Bridgeport, which has had its share of problems in the past, needs only an influx of cash to make it a prime educational and tourism facility, according to zoo advocates.

title: WHEN A PASTIME BECOMES THE STUFF OF METAPHOR
description: One of the most rewarding of this season's exhibitions is also by a long way the smallest. ''Winslow Homer: The Croquet Game'' at the National Academy of Design consists of exactly five paintings and a handful of engravings. Of the paintings in question, the largest measures 19 by 30 inches, the smallest 8 by 12. You could put the whole show in a suitcase and still have room for a change of clothes.

title: HOW TO REPAIR A DRIPPING FAUCET
description: A DRIPPING faucet not only is a nuisance, but also can waste sizable amounts of water (critical during a water shortage) and can waste substantial amounts of energy if it is hot water that is dripping or if your water comes from your own well. It can cause ugly staining in the sink. Fortunately, most leaking-faucet problems are not hard for the do-it-yourselfer to repair without calling in a plumber.

title: Suffolk Official Vetoes Bill on Crime Victims
description: The Suffolk County Executive has vetoed a bill on crime victims' rights, saying it was illegal and unnecessary.

title:
A 1956 LETTER SENT BY THE WHITE HOUSE;

IT IS STILL RELEVANT
description: In an Aug. 20, 1956, personal letter to a close friend, Everett E. (''Swede'') Hazlett, excerpted on this page, President Dwight D. Eisenhower set down his thoughts on prevailing demands for reorganization of the top military command structure - thoughts that are relevant today.

title: Miss Gray and Christopher W. CareyAre Planning to Marry in September
description: The engagement of Lucinda H. Gray to Christopher W. Carey has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John B. Gray of Dover and South Dartmouth, Mass., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mrs. John P. Carey Jr. of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., and the late Mr. Carey.

title: FIGHTER FOR 'ECONOMIC JUSTICE'
description: FOR more than a year, Auxiliary Bishop Peter A. Rosazza of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hartford has been traveling around the nation listening to stories of economic hardship - hunger, homelessness and unemployment. Earlier this month, events struck closer to home when the General Products Division of Century Brass Products Inc. closed its brass production plant in Waterbury, laying off at least 600 people.

title: HOME VIDEO ;   NEW CASSETTES: FROM SELZNICK TO VIVALDI AND BARRY MANILOW
description: Gone With the Wind Starring Vivien Leigh, Clark Gable, Olivia de Havilland, Leslie Howard, Hattie McDaniel; directed by Victor Fleming, 1939 MGM-UA Home Video 3 hours, 51 minutes. $89.95

title: The UnorthodoxActivities ofMob Lawyers'
description: ''Mob lawyers'' appeared last week on a tentative hit list of President Reagan's Commission on Organized Crime. A staff study charged that a small number of ''renegade attorneys'' are laundering money, orchestrating perjured testimony, bribing court officials, informing on Government informers and even planning crimes in cahoots with their clients, the crime bosses.

title: BALLET: HAMBURG IN 'MAHLER FOURTH'
description: Mahler mania continues apace at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where the Hamburg Ballet presented the New York premiere of John Neumeier's ballet, ''Mahler's Fourth Symphony'' on Friday night.

title: NEW ART, NEW MONEY
description: So Jean Michel Basquiat had a ''taste of Picasso''? How does that help to validate his work? Picasso got to where he did by patient years of study. A serious artist cannot merely mimic the fury and boldness of modern art without an honest personal evolution in that direction.

title: NEW ART, NEW MONEY
description: I read with interest Cathleen McGuigan's article, ''New Art, New Money'' (Feb. 10). There is more to the economic excitement than an insatiable rich public.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We must not miss this opportunity. This is the last chance.'' - King Hussein, on Middle East peace initiatives. (1:6.)

title: EVENTS MARK 20TH YEAR FOR CONSERVATION GROUP
description: THE Federated Conservationists of Westchester County turns 20 this year, but instead of receiving gifts the group is giving them.

title: Headliners ;   Doing His Share
description: Richard M. Nixon is not one to fall behind the times. The former President made that clear last week when he said he would give up his Secret Service protection to save the Government some money.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL ;   DOWN HISTORIC LANES
description: The Gould family used to bowl there, and the spacious second-floor pavilions once welcomed neighborhood women, who came to sew and to delight in the majestic views of the Hudson River. Now, a much different use is being explored for the rustic Queen Anne shingle-style building at Lyndhurst, the national historic landmark property in Tarrytown.

title: NEW ART, NEW MONEY
description: Cathleen McGuigan's profile of Jean Michel Basquiat raised one question about the art world that she failed to deal with head on.

title: MANAGING CRIME
description: LAW AND DISORDER Criminal Justice in America. By Bruce Jackson. 324 pp. Chicago: University of Illinois Press. 9.95.

title: CHANGES ARE DUE FOR IMMIGRATION
description: The Reagan Administration is preparing extensive changes in the rules and procedures for granting asylum to aliens.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A CHANGING ISRAEL. By Peter Grose. (Council on Foreign Relations/Vintage Books, Paper, $4.95.)

title: Photo Licenses, Out of Focus In Connecticut, New Jersey and more than two dozen other states it takes only an hour or so to get a finished driver's license, including a color photograph. New Yorkers, however, have to wait as long as 45 days to get a permanent picture license in the mail. The photo is likely to embarrass the driver. The inefficiency ought to embarrass the Department of Motor Vehicles.
description: New York debated 12 years before joining the rest of the nation in putting photos on driver's licenses. Now it's having trouble doing it right. The Department of Motor Vehicles has offered to re- shoot the pictures of about 100,000 persons who have received new licenses since last July. Either their eyes were closed when the shutter snapped, or the lighting was bad, or there was dust on the lens, or the camera didn't advance the film.

title: CONNECTICUT OPINION ;   DANGEROUS TIMES
description: TO appreciate that we live in perilous times, one has only to observe the security precautions surrounding the President's recent inauguration. Closer to home, the average American worries about cancer, pollution, drunken drivers and crime in his neighborhood. As the country singer Johnny Cash warbles so succinctly, ''Life ain't easy for a boy named Sue,'' and it is not much smoother for the rest of us these days.

title:
Review;

LESSONS FROM THE GAME OF LIFE
description: THE RECURSIVE UNIVERSE Cosmic Complexity and the Limits of Scientific Knowledge. By William Poundstone. Computer consultation by Robert T. Wainwright. Illustrated. 252 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95.

title: 'THE NOSE' - BIZARRE, TRAGIC, COMIC
description: Noses have always played an important role in literature, from ''Pinocchio'' to ''Cyrano de Bergerac.'' But arguably the greatest ''nose story'' of them all is Nikolai Gogol's odd and haunting tale of a vain civil servant who wakes up one morning to discover that his ''olfactory organ'' - which only the day before had sprouted a healthy new pimple - has disappeared from his face. Where it once proudly protruded is now a ''place as flat as a freshly cooked pancake.'' Before it finally returns to the protagonist's face as inexplicably as it vanished, the nose enjoys a glamorous independent existence as a Petersburg dandy, causing its envious owner unspeakable despair and embarrassment.

title: AT ELIZABETH SETON, LEARNING TO LEARN
description: WHEN Mary Ellen Burns began college two years ago, she left after the first two weeks and came home. ''I was so overburdened with work,'' explained the 19-year-old student from Eastchester, ''I didn't know where to start. I tried another college near my home, but that was confusing, too. Then I decided to come to Seton. I went right in and did really well.''

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM SELZNICK TO VIVALDI AND BARRY MANILOW
description: Rock-and-Roll: The Early Days Written and directed by Patrick Montgomery and Pamela Page, 1984 Archive Films 60 minutes. $29.95

title: Miss Price PlansAugust Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Price of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eileen Marcia Price, to Steven Adam Farbman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Farbman of Sarasota, Fla. An August wedding is planned.

title: WESTCHESTER OPININION ;   MOVING, MOVING, AND THE DAY COMES WHEN IT'S THE LAST
description: MOVING has always been difficult for me. Even when we lived in our first apartment in Washington Heights, with the kitchen in a closet and the bathroom walls cracking so badly we had to cover them with enameled metal sheets, I resisted moving. Wherever I live, I tend to snuggle down and get comfortable, like a bird nesting among twigs and twine. I become blind to the drawbacks that were so obvious to me when I first saw the space.

title: BRINGING BACK 'THE IMMORTAL HOUR'
description: Frank Corsaro, who has directed numerous productions for our big opera companies, the New York City Opera and the Metropolitan, makes his debut with a smaller troupe this week. He has directed the Bel Canto Opera's revival of Rutland Boughton's ''Immortal Hour,'' which will be presented at Joan of Arc Junior High School, 154 West 93d Street, Saturday, next Sunday and the following weekend.

title: Thousands in Portugal Assail Economic Policies
description: Tens of thousands of workers called for the resignation of Portugal's Socialist-Social Democratic Government today as they marched through Lisbon and other cities to protest Government economic policies.

title: CONSUMER RATES
NEW INSIGHTS INTO FREUD
description: Daniel Goleman reports on psychology for The Times. Excerpts from Freud's letters are from ''The Complete Letters of Sigmund Freud to Wilhelm Fliess, 1887-1904,'' translated and edited by Jeffrey Moussaieff Masson; Cambridge, Mass., and London, England: The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press, c 1985 Sigmund Freud Copyrights Ltd. and J. M. Masson; to be published in April 1985.

title: MUBARAK'S WELCOME DIPLOMACY
description: Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak's recent proposals for direct talks between Israel and a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation do not bring an Arab-Israel peace into early prospect, but they have at least induced mobility in what had been a frozen situation.

title: BALLET: JOFFREY IN FOUR ASHTON WORKS
description: The Joffrey Ballet honored one of England's greatest living choreographers Friday night by devoting its program in the New York State Theater to works by Frederick Ashton. A master of both comedy and lyricism, Mr. Ashton was represented by four ballets that exemplified his choreographic range. Two of them were restored to the repertory after an absence of several seasons.

title: ALASKA'S NATIVES TRY A TASTE OF CAPITALISM
description: Andrew L. Yarrow is a researcher on the staff of this magazine.

title: CONTRASTS ILLUMINATE TWO MODERN OPERAS
description: Igor Stravinsky and Arnold Schoenberg count as the two most influential, critically admired composers of the first half of the 20th century - not necessarily the ''best,'' mind you, nor the most admired by audiences, but their dominant status remains no matter how you qualify it. Neither man was best known for his operas. Yet each produced one major operatic score, and coincidentally both operas have just been released in new versions by the same record company, with the same principal tenor.

title: GUILD ISN'T GIVING ON BROADWAY'S TAKE
description: In a Broadway season this bleak, the arrival of a lavish new musical should be cause for rejoicing. But whatever the critics say about ''Grind,'' the Hal Prince show about a Chicago burleseque house that begins previews a week from tomorrow, the reaction inside the industry is already mixed.

title: EARTH, FIRE AND LIGHT IN GLASS AND CLAY
description: FAIR LAWN

title: Failure to Use Seat Belt Ends in Homicide Charge
description: A man was charged with vehicular homicide today after his 3-year- old son, who was not wearing a seat belt, died in a car crash, the police said.

title: Strike at Supermarkets In Oregon Is Ended
description: Members of a retail clerks' union overwhelmingly approved a new three- year contract today, ending a walkout by 5,000 supermarket workers less than 24 hours after it began.

title: Honor Schnurr to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. William T. Schnurr of Garden City, L.I., and Sheffield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Honor Marie Schnurr, to Douglas Blume, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Blume of Sheffield, Mass.

title: Iran-Iraq WarClaims MoreCivilian Victims
description: Iraq's nasty war with Iran got even nastier last week. Each side went after the other's civilians harder than at any time since the beginning of the war 53 months ago and Iran again accused Iraq of using poison gas against its troops.

title: DRINKING-AGE CHANGE CLOSE TO APPROVAL
description: HARTFORD LEGISLATION to raise Connecticut's legal drinking age, a hotly contested topic in past years, appears to be moving smoothly toward approval at this year's session of the General Assembly.

title: HIS DANCES ARE FOOD FOR THOUGHT
description: ''Looking way ahead to a distant time, maybe someday,'' the choreographer Kenneth King earnestly suggests, ''there will be a dancing philosopher.'' In the meantime, the veteran dancemaker celebrates two decades of his own multi- media invention with a special anniversary concert, this Thursday through next Sunday evening at St. Mark's Church on the Lower East Side.

title: U.S. Immigrants And Changing Times
description: It is difficult to avoid applauding the warmth of William Powers's essay ''New Americans: Making the Most of Opportunity'' (Opinion Page, Feb. 3), but Professor Powers's sense of empathy obscures the changing nature of American history. The willingness of immigrant Americans to work hard for a better life has not changed, but America's response certainly has.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Taste and Its Limitations

title: Flat Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ARE YOU THERE, BEAR?

title: THE FLESH IS WILLING, BUT THE SPIRIT IS ANALYZED
description: Nancy Ramsey is on the editorial staff of The New Yorker.

title: Zelda Krell Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer G. Krell of Tenafly, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Zelda Debi Krell to Neil Bruce Becourtney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Becourtney of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for January. Miss Krell is a merchandising manager for Gimbels in Bay Shore and Commack, L.I. Her fiance is a certified public accountant with Ernst & Whinney in New York.

title: North Park Wins Title
description: Earnest Hubbard scored a game-high 29 points tonight to help North Park of Illinois to a 72-71 victory over Potsdam (N.Y.) for the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III basketball title. The victory gave North Park a record four national titles in the division.

title: Mary O'Grady Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. William O'Grady of Centereach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Lou O'Grady, to Warren S. Meigs, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter S. Meigs of Danville, N.H.

title: Poverty and Richard Nixon
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Programs
description: Of State Move Along

title: Alvin Singleton's Music In 'Perspectives' Series
description: While one admires Carnegie Recital Hall's efforts to present some contemporary music in its ''Different Perspectives'' series, the fact remains that Wednesday night's program of works by Alvin Singleton left a lot to be desired.

title: PROPOSED COLLEGE AID CUT UPSETS STUDENTS
description: PAUL COHEN, a senior at Massapequa High School, sat in the End of the Bridge restaurant recently in the Student Union at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. He felt, he said, like a king.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:

title: THE DANCE: THREE BY CUNNINGHAM
description: There is a curious serenity to ''Locale,'' a group work performed by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company on Thursday at City Center, where the company plays through today. Though Mr. Cunningham's dances tend to be filled with handsome visual imagery, the sense of them is usually of continuous movement and traveled paths. Here, the dancers seem to move toward preordained niches in space like objects to same-shaped cutouts that, toward the end, are even etched in the upper air.

title: 37 Food Outlets Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 37 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: AFTER SURGE OF CHANGE, CHINA IS RETRENCHING
description: After one of the most ambitious years of change China has seen since 1949, an air of caution has begun to set in, suggesting opposition to the drive to free the nation's life from ideological rigidities.

title: OFFICERS BLAMED IN VIETNAM DEFEAT
description: A recent book by a retired Army general rejects the thesis that the Vietnam War was lost because civilian policy makers ''tied the hands'' of the military and refused to ''go all out.'' He says that senior officers must share the ''onus of failure.''

title: HOW CUTS COULD AFFECT STATE

title: Music

title: PASSPORT TO A HERITAGE IN IRELAND
description: MY mother had been dead for 15 years, but I recognized her meticulous handwriting even without putting my glasses on. Her words were written on a small square of yellowing paper that I had found accidentally in a drawer where I kept important papers. I'd been looking for my passport there because I was leaving on a trip to Ireland the following week. I couldn't believe my wonderful luck as I read the words in faded ink: Patrick Joseph Harrington Lickeen East Glengariff, County Cork Ireland

title: THERAPY NOTES AT ISSUE IN MEDICAL FRAUD CASE
description: For years court proceedings involving medical fraud have moved steadily closer to the most sensitive and protected area in modern medicine, the conversations between psychiatrist and patient. Now, on the poor streets of this old New England mill town, that privacy has been breached.

title:
ABOUT MEN;

A QUESTION OF HAPPINESS
description: WHEN I WAS 35, MY ELDEST daughter, then 12, asked me a question I have never forgotten: ''Are you happy, Daddy?'' We were standing alone on Connecticut property, facing Long Island Sound. She looked at me expectantly, her face full of hope. I was sure that she was inquiring about my work. I was on a fast track, and she knew it. I worked long hours; I traveled; there was stress. What my daughter was asking, in part, was ''Is it worth it?'' The other part of her question was simpler. I had an idea that she felt that if I were happy she could be happy, too. So I put on an air of contentment for the moment by smiling in her general direction and mumbling something or other to distract her. I didn't want her to know about the doubts and anxieties I was beginning to experience.

The colloquialized, often humorous dialogue gives an epic story human proportions and, more important, the author has created two enviable roles for actresses.
