title: NOT-SO-VITAL STATISTICS ON THE WARRING RICHARDS
description: Richard N. Perle, Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Policy, and Richard R. Burt, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, the two chief strategists for their respective departments, have clashed so often over arms control issues that their disputes have come to be known as ''the war of the Richards.''

title: Baird-Maier Rules Platform Tennis
description: Regaining their winning ways after stumbling a year ago, Steve Baird and Rich Maier defeated the defending champions, Doug Russell and Bob Kleinert, in four sets here today to capture the 51st annual American Platform Tennis Association's men's national championship at the Fox Meadow Tennis Club. The scores were 6-1, 6-7, 6-1, 6-3.

title: Nothing for a Party
description: To the Editor:

title: At Home in Italy
description: The scene is straight out of suburban America - the young father comes home, kisses his wife, greets his children, then heads to the driveway to shoot a few baskets with the neighborhood kids.

title: LONG WANTS TO RETIRE WITH GARTERS SNAPPING
description: Russell B. Long, a Senator for 36 years, has exercised vast power and influence in Washington over the last generation. But when he searched for a crumb of wisdom to explain his recent decision to retire in 1986 at the end of his current term, Mr. Long reached back to the political heritage of his native Louisiana and his legendary uncle, Earl Long.

title: MUSIC: 33 PRELUDES ATTRIBUTED TO BACH
description: A professional publicist could hardly have timed it better: A few months before the 300th anniversary of Johann Sebastian Bach's birth, a distinguished Bach authority announces the discovery of 33 apparently authentic Bach chorale preludes for organ previously unknown to modern Bach scholars. Then, just a few days before the actual birthday itself, the first 20th-century performances of these works are given in a chapel not far from the library where they were found.

title: THATCHER 1, MINERS 0
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher prevailed over Britain's striking coal miners because it was as unthinkable for her to suffer a defeat as it was for her to surrender the Falkland Islands to Argentine aggression. This was not merely a matter of pride or principle: in either case, defeat would have spelled political disaster. When Arthur Scargill ordered his miners into battle on March 6, 1984, the authority of the state was on the line. It could not afford to lose.

title: Oil Currency Shift Weighed
description: The European Economic Community's executive commission has been holding meetings with oil-producing countries and with oil market operators since the start of the year to promote use of the European Currency Unit as a reference currency for crude oil and oil product transactions, commission officials said Friday.

title: Jets 5, Sabres 3
description: Thomas Steen and Paul MacLean scored less than three minutes apart late in the third period to cap a four- goal rally for Winnipeg.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, MARCH 18, 1985

title: RADICALS FOUND GUILTY BY JURORS IN FEDERAL TRIAL
description: A Federal jury today found two self-styled revolutionaries, Susan Lisa Rosenberg and Timothy Blunk, guilty of eight counts each of possessing explosives, weapons and fake identification cards.

title: Nicaragua Loan Battle Shifts
description: The battleground over a $58 million loan to Nicaragua is expected shortly to shift from Washington to Vienna, where the Inter-American Development Bank will be holding its annual meeting next Monday and Tuesday.

title: Briefcases
description: - William C. Triplett 2d, an expert on China and Japan, has left the Office of the United States Trade Representative to join the Senate Foreign Relations Committee as a Far Eastern specialist.

title: YANKS VS. RED SOX: BOMBS AWAY
description: If the people who populate the lineups of the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox ''are on their games opening day,'' Don Baylor predicted, ''you're going to see some bombs go off right away. If not that day, sometime during the year we're going to meet each other and there's going to be such an offensive display, we'll see if there are enough balls to finish the game.''

title: PENTAGON STUDY EXPLORES PROFITS FOR CONTRACTORS
description: With Congress hungry for painless ways to cut military spending, the Pentagon is examining whether defense contractors make too much profit or not enough.

title: Topics Dubious Deals
description: Crazy Like a FoxJohn Hinckley was acquitted of shooting President Reagan because the jury accepted his plea of insanity. But he apparently is fully competent to handle his business affairs.

title: Israeli Prices Up by 13.5%
description: Israeli prices rose by 13.5 percent last month following two months of single-digit monthly inflation achieved under a three-month wage and price freeze that ended at the beginning of February.

title: What Public Schools
description: Cannot Do Alone

title: A TIMES REPORTER AND EDITOR
description: William E. Farrell, a reporter whose assignments ranged from the joy of life in New York to the terror of death in Beirut, died of cancer yesterday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Center. He was 48 years old.

title: CABARET: MEL TORME IN TOWN
description: Mel Torme, singing in a New York club for the first time in two years, has arrived at Park Ten, a restaurant at the corner of Park Avenue and 34th Street, with a briskly moving, balanced performance that is cleansed of most of the gushiness that had crept into his appearances in recent years.

title: SLUGGISH ISLANDERS BEATEN
description: If this is life without Brent Sutter, the Islanders are in trouble.

title: BUCK WILLIAMS ISSUES HIMSELF NEW CHALLENGE
description: The words had a touch of Ali to them, but this was Buck Williams talking. Quiet, thoughtful, introspective Buck Williams.

title: HOSPITAL SHUTS ABRUPTLY AND STATE PLANS INQUIRY
description: A 66-year-old private hospital in the Bronx that had been regarded as an anchor of community renewal suddenly shut down this weekend and transferred or discharged more than 100 patients in violation of state law, a spokesman for the State Department of Health said yesterday.

title: Biblical Family Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire on Ice
description: Skating to an original composition couldn't give Judy Blumberg and Michael Seibert more than third place in the world championship ice-dancing event in Tokyo the other week. But Miss Blumberg thinks the three-part, four-minute piece, ''Fire on Ice,'' written especially for them by a New York composer, Joel Silberman, is an accurate reflection of their skating personalities.

title: D'Arcy Is Involved In Challenged Claims
description: The unusual aspect of the February report from the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus is that of the six advertisers who either changed or dropped challenged claims, half had the same agency: D'Arcy McManus Masius.

title: Stallions Victorious
description: Cliff Stoudt passed for 247 yards and two touchdowns to lead Birmingham to a 34-19 victory over Memphis today, creating a three-way tie at the top of the United States Football League's Eastern Conference.

title: STARS STOP FLUTIE TO WIN, 29-9
description: The Baltimore Stars today showed how to stop Doug Flutie. The rookie quarterback had his least productive performance and failed to generate a fourth-quarter rally as the Stars beat the Generals, 29-9, in their first home game at the University of Maryland's Byrd Stadium.

title: Whalers 4, Penguins 3
description: Greg Malone's goal 1 minute 7 seconds into the third period snapped a 2-2 tie and lifted Hartford to its first home victory in 13 games.

title: Freeze Cost $253 Million
description: Florida citrus growers suffered almost $128 million in fruit losses and $125 million in costs of harvesting, hauling, packing and processing damaged fruit in the January freeze, a University of Florida researcher estimates. The $253 million figure compares with an estimated loss of $692 million that resulted from freezing weather in 1983, Evan Drummond of the university's food and resource economics department said Friday.

title: ROCKCOR WELCOMES BID BY OLIN
description: Rockcor Inc., a maker of aerospace and military systems that has been fighting a group of dissident shareholders for control of the company, said yesterday that it had agreed to merge with the Olin Corporation in a transaction valued at $97.2 million.

title: Swiss Ski Victor; Cup Title to Figini
description: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland took advantage of a slip by Diann Roffe and won a women's World Cup giant-slalom ski race today. Miss Schneider's teammate, Michela Figini, clinched the overall cup title.

title: PROVING GROUND FOR FLEET WOMEN
description: There is a smile on Fred Thompson's face. ''Mary, get in with them and run,'' he scolds a 14-year-old.

title: BRIDGE ;   WORLD CHAMPIONS ARE UPSET IN A WOMEN'S TEAM MATCH
description: After a major upset that sidelined the reigning world champions, the semifinals of the women's knockout team championship began here this afternoon at the Hyatt Regency Hotel. This is the last major event of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, and it will conclude Monday after thousands of other players have departed.

title: High-Tech Squadron Delivers for Pacific Bell
description: It was a ''cadre of very high-tech people'' who were responsible for the news last week that Pacific Bell had filed for a patent on a technology that would allow a single telephone line to carry two voice conversations and five streams of data at the same time.

title: SENATOR FINDS ILLNESS KEY TO A NEW LIFE
description: On Jan. 4, Paul E. Tsongas, the ambitious United States Senator from Massachusetts, became Paul E. Tsongas, lawyer and dedicated family man.

title: OHIO THRIFT UNITS WILL STAY CLOSD THROUGH MIDWEEK
description: Seventy-one privately insured thrift institutions in Ohio will remain closed at least until Wednesday, but the Governor said a plan had been formulated for reopening them ''in a matter of days rather than weeks.''

title: THIRD WORLD EXERTS A GROWING INFLUENCE ON WESTERN MUSIC
description: The sighing, fluttering, delicately nuanced sound of a north Indian bamboo flute reverberated through the American Museum of Natural History's auditorium recently, like a gentle breeze from the East. The concert was the first in a month-long series, ''Reeds, Horns, Drums and Gongs: A Spring Festival of World Music,'' which will conclude with two Tuesday evening concerts, tomorrow and March 26, at 7.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: CRIME CAREERS Yesteryear's mobsters probably never imagined that their careers were the stuff that history is made of, but they didn't reckon with the Municipal Archives. The archives have been sifted for a big new exhibition, ''The Cops and the Combination,'' which opens today in the imposing lobby of the Surrogate's Court, at 51 Chambers Street, just north of City Hall Park (566-5292).

title: WHO GETS 5/ DEPOSITS UNCLAIMED BY BUYERS?
description: It's only a nickel, but it's at the center of one of the sharpest debates of the state legislative session.

title: THEATER FESTIVAL FOR OLDER WOMEN AT THE PUBLIC
description: At a party 10 years ago, Elsa Rael, a playwright, saw a woman sing, dance and act her way through Stephen Sondheim's ''Company.'' Mrs. Rael called her ''mesmerizing, unbelievably talented.'' And when she asked the performer afterward why she wasn't working, the woman replied, ''I hit 40.''

title: Navratilova Sets Back Lloyd
description: Martina Navratilova put pressure on Chris Evert Lloyd's serve today and won the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Dallas tennis tournament, 6-3, 6-4.

title: Navratilova Not Infallible
description: For two years, Martina Navratilova's hold on women's tennis was as firm as her grip on a racquet. The combination of natural ability and a zealous commitment to physical fitness enabled her to toy with most of her opponents.

title: GERMANY FIGHTS FOR CAR POLLUTION LIMITS
description: West Germany is slugging it out with other Common Market governments over ways to tighten automobile pollution controls, but until now Germany's powerful automobile industry has taken most of the lumps.

title: Ogilvy Creates Contest For Cable's Lifetime
description: Elsewhere in the vast halls of Ogilvy & Mather, where winning Hardee's does not mean all that much, the excitement concerns the debut of a traffic-building consumer game being used to beef up an audience for a cable television network. It is a first, according to Robert M. White, managing director of O.& M. Promotions, and Laurence E. Rebich, vice president-marketing of the Lifetime network.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Mar. 18, 1985: *2*MONDAY Horizon Bancorp *2*TUESDAY Ames Dept Stores Citicorp Anderson Greenwood Federal Paper Board CPC International Upjohn Company *2*WEDNESDAY Acco World Corp National Serv Indus Amer Nat Resources St Joseph Lt&Pwr Bank of Virginia Co Savannah Elec&Pwr Carolina Pwr&LtService Corp Intl Fairchild Indus Stone & Webster Inc General Host US Shoe Corp Keystone Intl USAir Group May Dept Stores *2*THURSDAY Acme-Cleveland Corp Flight Safety Intl Ahmanson(HF) & Co Fruehauf Corp Air Products & Chem Russ Togs Central Maine Pwr Southern Cal Edison Cincinnati Gas & Elec Texas Oil & Gas Dixico Inc Transamerica Corp Dow Chemical *2*FRIDAY American Stores Pacific Telesis Central Hudson G&ETaft Broadcasting

title: Burke's Peerage Sold
description: Burke's Peerage, a listing of British nobility, was purchased Friday for several million dollars by an unidentified American, said Harold Brooks- Baker, publishing director. The 3,000- page book, first published in 1826, lists the family histories of 45,000 peers and baronets. It competes with Debrett's Peerage, which concentrates on living aristocrats and their relatives, but has not published a new edition since 1970.

title: CITY PLANS NEW EFFORT TO CURB DROPOUT RATE
description: Shaken by high dropout rates and public outrage over teen-age crime, New York City school officials are launching a new drive to prevent students from leaving high school before graduation.

title: Coalition Report Urges Halt To Converting S.R.O. Hotels
description: The Coalition for the Homeless, saying that the number of single-roomoccupancy hotel units in the city has dropped to 14,000 from 127,000 in the last 13 years, yesterday called for a permanent moratorium on converting S.R.O. hotels.

title: BIRD'S 48 LIFT CELTICS OVER THE ROCKETS
description: Larry Bird scored 48 points and Robert Parish scored 38 today as the Boston Celtics beat the Houston Rockets, 134-120.

title: IN BOSTON, A SYMPOSIUM ON CONTEMPORARY ARTS
description: It was, as one of the participants pointed out, ''a very postmodern symposium,'' as more than 100 American and international producers, presenters and artists in various creative disciplines gathered here for a three-day conference that began Thursday. The Contemporary Arts Symposium, sponsored by the Massachusetts Council on the Arts and Humanities and two other local organizations, was designed partly as an act of Boston boosterism, in order to encourage avant-garde artists to work in the state.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have made an important start. We have broken a three-year deadlock by agreeing to our common and shared responsibility to preserve our common environment.''

title: Elliott Wins Stock Race Despite Injury to Leg
description: Bill Elliott won the Coca-Cola 500 Grand National stock car race today despite the pain of a recently-broken leg.

title: Democratic Decisions
description: The Democratic National Committee, which finally has its direct-mail fund-raising machinery in gear after years of idling, is facing a major tactical decision: should party appeals for funds run a considerable political risk and focus on attacking President Reagan now that he is a lame duck?

title: Favorites Upset In Squash Match
description: Dave Johnson and Ned Edwards scored a three-set victory over the top-seeded team of Mike Pierce and Tom Page yesterday to capture the $1,500 first prize at the $10,000 Xerox squash-racquets doubles tournament at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn. The scores were 16-15, 15-8, 17-16.

title: NETS TOP PACERS BUT BIRDSONG IS OUT
description: The news really came as no surprise to Stan Albeck. By now, the Nets coach has become immune to the seasonlong misfortune.

title: OPPOSITION RISES TO MANDATORY RETIREMENT LAWS
description: In Congress, in the courts and before Federal agencies, advocates for the elderly are mounting a campaign against laws that permit employers to set mandatory retirement ages.

title: MARRIAGE, MONEY AND RISK
description: Between them, the 30-year-old Boston couple had $10 million. They spent their winters skiing in Switzerland and their summers sailing off Cape Cod. They had two lovely daughters and a large circle of wealthy friends. Everyone presumed that they had the perfect marriage, but in fact they longed for a divorce. Why?

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: REAGAN, IN QUEBEC, AGREES TO A STUDY OF ACID RAIN ISSUE
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, seeking to ease a contentious dispute between the United States and Canada over acid rain, announced the appointment today of a joint team to examine the issue.

title: Hoyas Haunting Looie's Fun
description: SALT LAKE CITYNo matter where St. John's travels in the N.C.A.A. tournament, it's as if Georgetown, especially Patrick Ewing, is lurking there, too. Even as the Redmen were celebrating their entry to the West Regional semifinals with a 68-65 victory over Arkansas here last Saturday afternoon, Lou Carnesecca was suddenly asked by a stranger to discuss the problems of coping with the Hoyas' 7-foot center.

title: Problems With Matching-Grant Charity
description: To the Editor:

title: MIKE FARRELL, AGAIN A DOCTOR, IN 'PRIVATE SESSIONS'
description: Mike Farrell has to be one of the nicest Mr. Nice Guys on television. For years, he held his own engagingly in ''M*A*S*H'' opposite Alan Alda, the undisputed king of affability. Mr. Farrell always manages to project a sweet seriousness about the myriad plot problems he must confront, whether they are personal or environmental. He seems to be genuinely sincere. He has even let his hair go gray.

title: All Together: MAN-well
description: Many people have a first or a last name that strangers often mispronounce.

title: Jackson Takes P.S.A.L. Title
description: Andrew Jackson won its first Public Schools' Athletic League title yesterday by following its standard operating procedure - getting the ball to Greg (Boo) Harvey, and letting him operate.

title: BALLESTEROS POST 68 AT NEW ORLEANS, TOPS MAHAFFEY BY 2
description: Severiano Ballesteros carded three birdies on the back nine and survived a bogey on his final hole to win the $400,000 U.S.F.& G. Golf Classic by two strokes today.

title: Serving Up Cigarettes With Your Tennis
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAN EMERGING ON CURRENCY RATES
description: Major Western nations are moving toward a new monetary agreement intended to promote greater currency stability in the world. The agreement would give the International Monetary Fund an enhanced role in coordinating the domestic economic policies of the Western nations through a new body that some officials have dubbed the International Open Market Committee.

title: Pinkett's Ploy
description: He has become one of the better running backs in the country, but all his press clippings notwithstanding, Allen Pinkett of Notre Dame failed to get favored status when he sought to attend the opening-round games of college basketball's Southeast Regional last week. What made that more remarkable was that the games he wanted to see were on Notre Dame's Athletic and Convocation Center in South Bend, Ind.

title: LURE OF CHINESE MARKET DRAWS JAPAN
description: For centuries, China's size and population have beckoned to traders. Textile manufacturers in 19th century England dreamed of making their fortunes by supplying every Chinese with just one shirt, and American merchants dazzled by similar visions helped force China's door open.

title: ;   The Revolution
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumer Banks Delayed
description: The Federal Reserve Board, citing a Federal court ruling against the Comptroller of the Currency, announced Friday that it was suspending the processing of pending applications from bank holding companies to acquire or establish limited-service, or nonbank, banks.

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, MARCH 18, 1985 International

title: GROWTH OF 4% SEEN IN QUARTER
description: Strong consumer spending is propelling the economy to a robust 4 percent growth rate this quarter, just what the Reagan Administration ordered, according to many economists.

title: GOODEN IS SHARP AGAINST CARDINALS
description: Dwight Gooden pitched four more shutout innings for the Mets today, reported that he was ''a little ahead of schedule'' and predicted that on opening day in three weeks ''I should be right where I want to be.''

title: Policeman Wounds Himself Unloading a Gun He Found
description: A police officer shot himself in the finger yesterday while trying to unload a gun he found on a Harlem street, the police said.

title: McLain's Request For Bail Denied
description: A Federal judge denied Denny McLain bail and ordered him jailed today, a day after he was convicted of racketeering, conspiracy, extortion and cocaine possession.

title: NORWAY'S NEW STRATEGY AFTER LOSING GAS DEAL
description: When the British Government said in February that it would veto the British Gas Corporation's preliminary agreement to buy $30 billion worth of gas from Norway's Sleipner Field in the North Sea, Norway winced.

title: WOLFPACK TRIUMPHS
description: Bobby Lee Hurt, an intimidating 6-foot-9-inch, 240-pound senior center, scored 19 points, had 13 rebounds and controlled the inside like the town bully as Alabama upset Virginia Commonwealth University, 63-59, today.

title: Services Held for Man Struck by a Police Car
description: Funeral services were held yesterday for a man who was struck by a police car Friday night and a second victim was reported in improved condition. Investigators, meanwhile, sought to determine who was driving the patrol car that fled after striking the two men at Park Avenue and 72d Street.

title: Chief Wants Diversity At Shamrock Holdings
description: As president and chief executive of Shamrock Holdings Inc., which is owned by the Roy E. Disney family, Stanley P. Gold sees last week's proposal to acquire Central Soya Company as a logical departure from Shamrock's other holdings in broadcasting and real estate.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Mets , at St. Petersburg, Fla., 1:30 P.M. This is the first meeting of the teams in spring training this season.

title: People
description: Nelson de Mello was appointed senior vice president and Latin America area director at Y.&R. International.

title: ABC, ONCE A LAGGARD, ROSE TO PROMINENCE
description: RICHARD W. STEVENSON

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
COURT VOIDS LIMIT FOR PAC SPENDING
description: The Supreme Court today struck down the $1,000 legal limit on spending by political action committees on behalf of Presidential candidates in general elections.

title: Control Data Stock Down
description: Trading in the Control Data Corporation's stock soared yesterday to 640,800 shares, double the normal volume, and its price fell $1.375 a share, to $32.625, amid concern about the deposit crisis in Ohio.

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
2 HELD AS MAJOR DRUG SMUGGLERS
description: Two Peruvians accused of controlling a fifth of the cocaine entering the United States have been arrested, the Federal authorities said today.

title: EDDIE SHORE OF BOSTON BRUINS, 82
description: Edward W. (Eddie) Shore, the legendary defenseman for the Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League, died Saturday at Mercy Hospital in Springfield. He was 82 years old, and had been in failing health for some time. He entered the hospital Feb. 28.

title: GRAND JURY HEARS TESTIMONY OF A MAN GOETZ SHOT
description: One of the four young men shot by Bernhard H. Goetz on a subway train last December testified yesterday before a new grand jury as it began investigating the shootings.

title: Insure Confidence as Well as Banks ''Is my money safe?'' That's the question aroused in depositors all over the country by Ohio's temporary closing of 71 privately insured savings institutions.
description: The answer is an unequivocal ''yes'' for the great majority, everyone with deposits up to $100,000 in banks covered by Federal insurance. Federally insured accounts are, for all practical purposes, backed by the Government's power to create money.

title: Greater U.S. Role In Insurance Seen
description: Private systems of deposit insurance will come under increasing pressure to be absorbed by the Federal system in the wake of the Ohio banking crisis, Government banking officials said today.

title: Flight Attendants Cross Transport Picket Lines
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that about 500 members of the Union of Flight Attendants were now crossing picket lines and that it had hired about 400 trainee attendants on a temporary basis to expand flights to 52 percent of its full operations.

title: Brown Faces Charges
description: Jim Brown , the former National Football League great, will be formally charged with rape, sexual battery and assault, all stemming from an incident last Month at his Hollywood Hills home, Los Angeles prosecutors said yesterday. ''We believe we have a strong case based on the interviews with our victim and other evidence that we have generated from our investigation,'' Deputy District Attorney

title: LEADERSHIP ROLE FOR WILLIE GLASS
description: It was late in the game Saturday and Arkansas was making a run, so St. John's called a timeout. When the Redmen broke from the huddle, there was an unusual sight: Willie Glass, a sophomore forward known for his reserve and stoic attitude, clapping his hands, urging his teammates to dig in and hang tough. He kept up the chatter for the rest of the game.

title: Davis Cup Aug. 2
description: The United States will face West Germany in the second round of the Davis Cup tennis competition in Hamburg on clay Aug. 2. Arthur Ashe, the captain, said yesterday he would not select the team until after Wimbledon in July.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Amerifirst Plans Issue Of Mortgage Obligations
description: The Amerifirst Capital Corporation, a subsidiary of the Amerifirst Federal Savings and Loan Association, Miami, is expected to offer $431.19 million of collateralized mortgage obligations today through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: REAGAN, IN QUEBEC, SAYS HE IS HOPEFUL ON TIES TO SOVIET
description: President Reagan, ending a meeting with Canada's Prime Minister, said today that he hoped the change in Soviet leadership ''will open up new possibilities'' for better East-West relations. But he also strongly criticized past Soviet policies.

title: 'Hollywood Opera' Spoofs Film Classics
description: ''Hollywood Opera,'' the new lighter-than-air cabaret musical at the Ballroom Theater (253 West 28th Street), spoofs eight classics of the silver screen by transforming them into farcical quasi-operatic set pieces. ''Whoever you are, I have always depended on the wine lists of strangers,'' announces the singer-actress Mary-Cleere Haran, in ''D'Oyly Carte Blanche,'' a Gilbert-and-Sullivan-style parody of ''A Streetcar Named Desire.''

title: UNIVERSITY GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $17,275.

title: Governor Tours Tornado Site
description: Gov. Bob Graham today toured the destruction left by a weekend tornado that killed two people, injured at least 41 others and destroyed 55 homes.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Official Is Quitting Continental Illinois
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation said yesterday that James D. Harper Jr. had resigned as executive vice president and head of the real estate department of its Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company ''to pursue other interests.''

title: Transactions
description: Hired Gary Hartwig, secondary coach, and Art Seymore, receivers coach. LOUISIANA TECH - Sonja Hogg, women's basketball coach, announced she will resign at the end of the season.

title: MEDICAL ELECTRONICS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
WORRIED WAYNE RESIDENTS AWAIT SPRING'S RAINS
description: The flooding from last spring's heavy rains, the worst here in years, destroyed Kenneth and Maureen Hay's home near the Pompton River. They lost $12,000 worth of furnishings and had no insurance coverage.

title: PENNSYLVANIA ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nordiques Win And Tie for First
description: Michel Goulet scored three goals and Wilf Paiement scored two as the Quebec Nordiques beat the Boston Bruins, 8-4, tonight, and moved into a tie for the Adams Division lead.

title: CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PCA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
ACME GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Includes income of $57,000 from discontinued operation.

title: SUSPECTS IN U.S. SLAYING FACE HEARING IN TAIWAN
description: Judicial proceedings are scheduled to begin Wednesday in Taipei against two Taiwan nationals indicted on charges of murdering a Chinese-American journalist, Henry Liu.

title: HELPING TO EASE THE LATINS' DEBT
description: In recent weeks, the nation's press has flip-flopped wildly, with some commentators heralding the end of Latin America's debt crisis and others forecasting the collapse of the international financial system. In fact, both simplistic assessments are wrong - and could seriously jeopardize the recovery process.

title: Communists Waited to Join the Resistance To the Editor:
description: Danielle Jaussaud (letter, March 13) says that French Resistance Fighters were largely members of the French Communist Party. This is a very misleading statement.

title: AW COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed on March 1, 1985 to shareholders of record Feb. 15, 1985.

title: ASSOCIATED DRY GOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: Results for the latest year are for a 53-week period compared with 52 weeks a year earlier.

title: NETS' RICHARDSON TO SEEK TOP PAY
description: Micheal Ray Richardson leads the National Basketball Association in steals, ranks seventh in assists (7.90), is averaging 19.3 points a game and is among the top rebounding guards in the league. The Nets' playmaker, who conquered a serious drug problem, is in the final year of his $427,000- a-year contract. By comparison, Otis Birdsong, Richardson's backcourt mate, earns $1 million a year.

title: Junior Player's 2-Fisted Attack
description: It's one thing to have heard about Luke Jensen, as people who follow the amateur ranks of tennis most certainly have. But, even if you believe what you've heard, to watch him at his game is enough to make you wonder whether you ought to believe what you're seeing: Here comes a left- handed serve, and now, at equal velocity, here comes one right-handed. And, more than that, both are being delivered with a marvelous variety - flat, offspeed, kick and slice.

title: SUMMIT ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $715,801 on the sale of a Denver, Colo., office building.

title: Women's Coach Quits
description: Sonja Hogg, who started Louisiana Tech's women's basketball team and turned it into one of the nation's most successful athletic programs, announced yesterday that she was quitting at the end of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. Mrs. Hogg, 39 years old, gave no reason for her resignation, other than that she is going into private business in marketing. In Mrs. Hogg's 11 years as coach, Tech's women are 306-54.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a computation error, the Weather Records and Forecasts printed in February incorrectly listed the rising and setting times for Venus and Mars. Setting times for Venus were two hours later than those shown. For Mars, times ranged from about two hours later to about half an hour later - for example, rising 59 minutes later on Feb. 1 and setting one hour and six minutes later, and rising 35 minutes later on Feb 27 and setting one hour and 41 minutes later.

title: NATIONAL CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results for the last two months of 1984 include results of the Electroscale Corp., which was acquired in October 1984.

title: MAYS, MANTLE REINSTATED BY BASEBALL COMMISSIONER
description: They were told they could have nothing to do with organized baseball after accepting jobs with Atlantic City gambling casinos, but yesterday Willie Mays and Mickey Mantle returned. The new baseball commissioner, Peter Ueberroth, reversed the decision of his predecessor, Bowie Kuhn, by reinstating the two Hall of Fame members immediately.

title: CSP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
A Brief Truce On Music's Behalf
description: For two hours tonight, the Association for Classical Music will show that music, indeed, hath charms.

title: Players Union Asks More Data
description: The Major League Baseball Players Association received additional financial information from the club owners today, but union representatives said they wanted more detailed accounts.

title: 2 U.S. Envoys Nominated
description: President Reagan today nominated Faith Whittlesey, a White House public affairs aide, to serve as ambassador to Switzerland, where she served once before, from 1981 to 1983. Another ambassador, Fernando Rondon, now serving in Madagascar, is to be sent to Ecuador.

title: JAPANESE SEE NO LIGHT AT END OF LONGEST TUNNEL
description: Much of Satoshi Maruyama's life is spent 328 feet beneath the floor of the roiling Tsugaru Strait.

title: Belgian M.P.'s to Vote Today On Deploying Cruise Missiles
description: The Belgian Parliament is scheduled to vote Tuesday on the Government's decision to deploy United States cruise missiles in Belgium.

title: IMREG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is in the development stage and thus reported no revenue.

title: A DILIGENT VICTIM HELPS UNEARTH CLUES TO MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS
description: IT all started with the peristence of Sylvia Hall, now 59 years old, who was diagnosed in 1980 as having multiple sclerosis, the incurable muscle disease. Her sister died of the disease the next year.

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $267,000 for the quarter and $394,000 for the 6 months.

title: U.S. Lists Dates For Cup Soccer
description: The dates for the United States to play World Cup soccer qualifying series against Trinidad and Tobago and Costa Rica were announced yesterday by the United States Soccer Federation.

title: SANDINISTA FORCING THOUSANDS OUT OF WAR ZONE
description: The Nicaraguan Government has begun the forced evacuation of thousands of peasants from the countryside in a drive to deny local support to rebels operating in the north, according to evacuees and international relief agency officials.

title: GREAT AMERICAN MANAGEENT & INVESTMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Austria of Today Is Not Responsible for Nazi Crimes
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruling on Getty Trust
description: A Superior Court judge today ordered Gordon Peter Getty to pay $1.1 billion in capital gains taxes from the income of the $4 billion Sarah C. Getty trust, of which he is sole trustee and an income beneficiary.

title: A Sporting Revival for Shea Stadium
description: New York's agreement with the Mets to invest $36 million in Shea Stadium will not guarantee the team a baseball pennant or lure back the Jets football team from New Jersey. But it is a reasonable plan for rescuing the city's 21-year- old stadium from its shocking neglect and deterioration.

title: California Bill Aids Savers
description: The California Senate will consider a bill on Thursday that would use state funds, at least temporarily, to repay depositors in a privately insured thrift and loan association that closed last April.

title: S.E.C. Advises House to Wait The Securities and Exchange
description: Commission, which earlier this

title: FINDING ENLIGHTENED TALK ON THE AIR
description: Talking - no, arguing - about

title: Heart Patient Is Treated For Ailment
description: Murray P. Haydon, who received a permanent artificial heart one month ago, was returned the coronary care unit of Humana Hospital Audubon this afternoon because of a breathing problem, but was in no apparent danger, a spokesman said.

title: PRETORIA PLANS TO CUT ARMS SPENDING AND RAISE EDUCATION BUDGET
description: South African authorities, moving to cope with a profound economic crisis, announced an austerity budget today in which military spending was held down while the education budget - regarded as critical in efforts to placate disaffected blacks - was increased by 19 percent.

title: SUNOCO TO OFFER TO BUY HOUSES NEAR GAS LEAD
description: The Sun Refining and Marketing Company has offered to buy 17 homes near a Sunoco service station in North Babylon, L.I., that leaked gasoline from an underground storage tank in May 1983.

title: NICARAGUAN HAILED IN BRAZIL
description: Brazilian legislators greeted President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua with a standing ovation today. Later he told them that the United States wanted Latin Americans to be ''slaves.''

title: CRIMINAL LAWYERS AND LAWYERS WHO TURN CRIMINAL
description: Why do some lawyers become criminals? What should the legal profession do about them? And where is the line that separates good criminal lawyers from lawyer-criminals? These were some of the questions debated at a symposium on legal ethics held by President Reagan's Commission on Organized Crime. It centered on a staff study asserting that a small but significant number of lawyers had become ''integral parts'' of organized crime and narcotics conspiracies.

title: UNCLE SAM'S CONTRAS
description: Nothing could have disclosed more clearly the sheer arrogance of Ronald Reagan's policy toward the recognized Government of Nicaragua than his news conference statement that its ''present structure'' would have to be removed unless ''they'd say uncle.''

title: Lead is Found In Mexican Pottery
description: Mexican pottery containing dangerous levels of lead in the ceramic glazing is being sold in the United States and could be hazardous to health, the Food and Drug Administration says.

title: EX-COMMANDANT OF COAST GUARD
description: Adm. Edwin J. Roland, a former commandant of the United States Coast Guard, died Saturday while on vacation in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 80 years old and lived in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: Politicizing a Political Protection The enforcement arm of the Merit Systems Protection Board, the Office of Special Counsel, is supposed to protect Federal workers from politics. Its recent behavior makes it look more interested in protecting Government from politically active workers.
description: The counsel charges that three employee union leaders violated Federal law by endorsing Walter Mondale for President last year. The three surely did that, but to call that a Hatch Act violation is to insist on a strained, technical reading of the law. The charges, issued in the name of political purity, themselves smack of politics.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: ROLLING BONES The skeletons that the American Museum of Natural History, 77th Street and Central Park West, has taken out of the closet for the exhibition that opens today are lively reconstructions of animals, in skeletal depiction of them in lifelike pursuits.

title: By Any Name
description: You'd think that people - especially track people - wouldn't have trouble remembering the name of a runner who was accomplished enough to become the IC4A 1,500- meter outdoor champion and an Olympic semifinalist.

title: School Bonds Set By Texas District
description: The Mesquite Independent School District, in Dallas County, Tex., is offering $62.9 million of bonds through underwriters led by Rauscher Pierce Refsnes Inc. They set tentative yields ranging from 6.70 percent for bonds maturing in 1987 to 9.25 percent for bonds due in 1995 and 9.90 percent for the 2002 maturity.

title: OXOCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $217,868 for the quarter and year. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest year.

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
GLOSSER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
LIBERTY HOMES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
HECHINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: Results for the latest quarter are for a 14-week period compared with 13 weeks a year ago.

title: Shipping Executive Appeals for Support
description: Robert J. Pfeiffer has spent a lifetime in the shipping business. But the 65-year-old chairman and chief executive of Alexander & Baldwin, the shipping, sugar and real estate company based in Honolulu, said he had never faced anything quite like his troubles with a disgruntled shareholder named Harry Weinberg.

title: Figure in Manson Trial Decides to Stay in Prison
description: A member of the Charles Manson ''family'' says she has strong personal and political reasons for wanting to stay in prison when her mandatory release date comes up later this month.

title: Mitsubishi-Daimler Tie
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation of Japan and Daimler-Benz A.G. of West Germany agreed to jointly develop a small van for distribution in Europe, both companies said today. Mitsubishi said that under the agreement it would export some components to the German auto maker, which will start producing the diesel-engined van in 1987 at a plant operated by its subsidiary in Spain. Daimler-Benz will market the vans and hopes to sell about 10,000 the first year.

title: Mosquitoes Rise In Urban Areas
description: Urban areas have become prime breeding grounds for mosquitoes attracted by lights atop skyscrapers and pools of water created by slipshod construction, a scientist told the American Mosquito Control Association here today.

title: Westchester Working ;   To Save the Bluebird
description: To the Editor:

title: SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The share earnings reflect 50 percent stock dividend paid Feb. 4.

title: MAY PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COST OF SOME COLLEGES TO EXCEED $15,000 NEXT YEAR, WITH MOST UP 7% TO 9%
description: College students from the New York metropolitan area setting off for school this fall will face costs as high as $15,000 or more, largely because of the need to raise faculty salaries, update curriculums and compensate for government cuts in student-aid funding.

title: MUBARAK VISITS JORDAN FOR TALKS, THEN HE AND KING GO TO BAGHDAD
description: King Hussein of Jordan and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt met here today for talks on the stalled Arab-Israeli peace process, then made a surprise visit to Baghdad to express support for Iraq in its new fighting against Iran.

title: 120 Held in Drug Raids
description: Police officers and sheriff's deputies arrested more than 120 people and seized drugs valued at more than $200,000 in weekend raids in Los Angeles and several suburbs. More than 100 Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies raided nine places in Compton, Lynwood and parts of South Los Angeles on Friday and Saturday, Deputy Mason Kenney said.

title: Burford's Rubicon
description: Anne McGill Burford, former administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, is threatening to sue Justice Department officials, including former Attorney General William French Smith, unless the Government pays the $211,000 legal bill she incurred defending herself in investigations of misconduct inside her agency.

title: WILSON, H J CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-Net income

title: A WALK ON THE TAME SIDE
description: People in Washington walk. They don't run, they don't charge. They walk - put one foot in front of the other and proceed at a civilized pace. They go to the corner to cross the street, and even if they do go against the light, they never jaywalk in the middle of the block.

title: WILL ABC BOUNCE BACK?
description: Until recently, a change in the overall alignment of the commercial broadcasting industry was unthinkable. ABC, CBS and NBC were perceived as monolithic entities, beyond the ordinary tides of business. But since early this year - when assorted interests cast acquisitive eyes on CBS - a sense of impending upheaval has been growing in the industry. And yesterday, when Capital Cities Communications Inc. moved to take control of ABC, the unthinkable happened.

title: Baltimore Wins Round
description: Baltimore's lawsuit seeking the return of the Colts appears headed for a Federal court hearing. The Supreme Court yesterday rejected a bid by

title: Turner Deposition in CBS Lawsuit
description: Ted Turner, the broadcasting entrepreneur, gave a deposition today to attorneys for CBS, which subpoenaed him in connection with the network's lawsuit against a conservative group trying to take it over.

title: Krupin's Cadillac
description: Mel Krupin, a transplanted New Yorker whose Washington restaurant is a gathering place for capital celebrities, has decided he can't go home again, at least not in his Cadillac.

title: WEST HOLLYWOOD ACTING ON PLEDGES
description: The City Council here passed an ordinance early this month making it illegal for bars to turn away patrons wearing open- toed shoes. Earlier, it passed a law establishing for its residents an alternative to marriage called a domestic partnership.

title: EARLY STAGES OF STELLAR EXPLOSION
description: ASTRONOMERS at an observatory in Chile have reported obtaining the first detailed observations of a star passing through early stages of a supernova, or gigantic stellar explosion. It is hoped that such supernova ''life histories'' will provide a new yardstick for the universe by making it possible to use their observed brightness to assess their distances.

title: EXCERPTS FROM RULING ON POLITICAL SPENDING CURB
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court decision today striking down the $1,000 limit on Presidential campaign spending by political action committees. Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the 7-to-2 opinion. Associate Justices Byron R. White and Thurgood Marshall wrote the dissenting opinions.

title: Chess:Pawn Sacrifice Works W
description: ''Who steals my pawn, steals trash,'' is the motto of the gambit player. His strategy is to discover and exploit that type of situation where the normal value of a pawn is nullified by the attacking chances its capture promotes.

title: U.S. Considers Proposal
description: A State Department spokesman reaffirmed today that the United States was looking ''into the possibilities of the construction'' of a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation that could meet with American officials.

title: ANGUISH, HOPE, A MOMENT OF FAME: A HEART'S STORY IS TOLD
description: PHOENIX ''IS your heart ready to be implanted?'' Dr. Kevin Cheng was asked. It was 6 A.M. His first reaction, Dr. Cheng said later, was that the caller, Dr. Cecil Vaughn, a heart surgeon, was ready to implant the Phoenix artificial heart in a calf that day in an experiment that had been put off several times for various medical emergencies. But it was not a calf Dr. Vaughn had in mind.

title: ABC-TV'S GOLDENSON, STILL AT THE TOP
description: At the age of 79, Leonard Goldenson, chairman of American Broadcasting Companies Inc., has been the subject of endless retirement rumors. But last December, he brushed aside any idea that he was slowing up.

title: Whitbread Unit Wins Injunction
description: The Whitbread Company said its American subsidiary, the Buckingham Corporation, had won a preliminary court injunction preventing a former employee, Stephen Karp, from distributing Mouton Cadet wines and Finlandia vodka. Whitbread bought Buckingham, which distributes Scotch whisky and various wines and spirits in the United States, including Mouton Cadet and Finlandia vodka, for $110 million last year.

title: EXECUTIVES
Clow Is Looking To Be Acquired
description: The Clow Corporation, a producer of plumbing and heating products, said that it was looking to be acquired for about $12 to $12.50 a share, or a total of $39.4 million to $41.1 million.

title: MOSCOW CHARGES BAD FAITH BY U.S.
description: The Soviet press accused the United States today of seeking to block progress in the Geneva arms talks with a view to pressing ahead with the arms race.

title: Icahn to Buy Stake in Jacobs Concern
description: Irwin L. Jacobs did Carl C. Icahn a favor during Mr. Icahn's recent bid for the Phillips Petroleum Company, and Wall Street analysts believe Mr. Icahn may now be repaying the debt.

title: BOY IN HIT-RUN CRASH IN COMA
description: An 11-year-old boy remained in critical condition yesterday after he and three of his brothers were struck Sunday by a hit-and-run motorist in Brooklyn.

title: CUOMO AND 2 KEY LEGISLATORS AGREE TO TARGET FOR SPENDING
description: Governor Cuomo said today that an agreement on a spending level of $22.7 billion for the next fiscal year had been reached with legislative leaders. Mr. Cuomo also said for the first time that he would endorse a one-time amnesty plan for tax evaders if his proposed ''omnibus tax enforcement'' bill was approved by lawmakers. Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink, Brooklyn Democrat, and Warren M. Anderson, Republican of Binghamton, the Senate majority leader, emerged from a half-hour meeting with Mr. Cuomo and said that they had agreed on a spending target of $22.7 billion for the next fiscal year, which starts April 1. The target represents only a portion of the overall proposed state budget of $38.8 billion, a figure that includes Federal aid.

title: Fine Arts Quartet
description: The Hebrew Arts School will present the Fine Arts Quartet in its first solo recital on March 26 at 2 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street. The program will include Haydn's Quartet No. 1 in G; Shostakovich's Quartet No. 3 in F (Op. 73); and Schubert's Quartet No. 14 in D minor. Tickets are $5 and may be reserved by calling 362-8719.

title: BRAZIL PUTS STRESS ON INFLATION FIGHT
description: Brazil's new civilian Government has announced that it will give priority to fighting inflation and reducing the budget deficit, even at the risk of prolonging an economic recession.

title: Arizona Governor Tells Plans
description: Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona announced today that he would not seek re-election or make a bid for the Senate in 1986, leaving open the possibility that he might run for President in 1988.

title: Governor of Mississippi Vetoes Teacher Pay Bill
description: Gov. Bill Allain vetoed a bill today that would have given a $4,400 raise to the nation's lowest paid teachers.

title: EAGLE-PICHER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
ANACOMP COMPUTER CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
BROOKS RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: GALAPAGOS BLAZE CONFOUNDS EFFORTS OF FIREFIGHTING TROOPS
description: Fire officials say they have given up hope of putting out a three- week-old blaze fanned by strong winds that is threatening the exotic animals on the largest island in the Galapagos group, the home of giant tortoises and once the base for the British evolutionary theorist Charles Darwin.

title: Those Who Study Peace Also Study War
description: To the Editor:

title: Change of Heart
description: Auburn's basketball coach,

title: Sconiers Has Problem
description: Daryl Sconiers, the first baseman of the California Angels, who has been absent from training camp for more than two weeks, told team officials he was late because of a ''substance problem.''

title: Gulf Broadcast Plan Proceeds
description: The Gulf Broadcast Company yesterday affirmed its intention to seek shareholder approval of the sale of its broadcast properties and 6,400 acres of Texas land, despite the objections to the liquidation from the American Continental Corporation, its largest shareholder.

title: CROWLEY, MILNER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
I.B.M. Agreement In Rolm Unit Sale
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, modifying a statement it made last week, said it had signed a ''conditional agreement'' to sell the Rolm Corporation's Mil-Spec Computer division to a employee group in a leveraged buyout.

description: Against the Generals Sunday, the

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE HIGHER
description: Interest rates rose for short- and long-term maturities yesterday as securities dealers cut prices of Treasury issues to attract more investors.

title: AMTRAK WINS CASE ON FARES OF EMPLOYEES
description: The Supreme Court today upheld a Federal law that requires private railroads to reimburse Amtrak for the free or reduced-fare travel that the national rail passenger system provides for more than a million railroad workers and their families.

title: SPARTAN MOTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extrarordinary gains of $3,000 for the quarter and $215,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: A BALANCED U.S. BUDGET DEBATED IN CONNECTICUT
description: A procession of prominent political and academic figures went before a legislative hearing here today with sharply conflicting views on whether Connecticut should ask Congress to call a Constitutional Convention to require a balanced Federal budget.

title: They're Back on Baseball's Streets
description: In the glitter of the Astor Salon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, three microphones had been placed

title: SOME MISSIONS TO U.N. LAG IN PAYING LOCAL BUSINESSES
description: Diplomatic missions to the United Nations owe hundreds of thousands of dollars to landlords, the Consolidated Edison Company, New York Telephone and a variety of other businesses, according to the New York City Commission for the United Nations.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 19, 1985

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 19, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Bolivian Unions Spurn Offers to End Strike
description: Bolivian labor unions said today that they had rejected Government offers intended to end an 11-day-old general strike and threatened to step up pressure with power cuts.

title: NATIONAL PATENT DEVELOPENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $109,000 for the quarter and $1,471,000, or 13 cents a share, for the year. c-After a gain of $7,496,000 on the sale of stock by a subsidiary, a loss of $661,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $260,000. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,669,000 and a tax credit of $1,121,000, or 10 cents a share. The prior year results include a gain of $7,496,000 on the sale to the public of about 10 percent of the common stock of International Hydron Corp., a former wholly owned subsidiary.

description: b-Net income.
