description: GORBACHEV. A BIOGRAPHY. By

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: ATLANTA'S EFFORT TO COPE WITH CUT IN FEDERAL AID
description: When Federal money for social welfare, low-income housing and other assistance was sharply cut three years ago, agencies providing such services here were among the hardest hit in the country.

title: Underground Art
description: These days the subway inspires

title: Watch on the Mormons
description: To the Editor:

title: HARD WORK VS. SUCCESS
description: NEW YORKERS tend to equate success with money. Which is one reason they've made such a fuss over the entrepreneurial Korean grocers while paying scant attention to their Hispanic counterparts. But Hispanic store owners are successful, too. It's just that being one's own boss and an integral part of a familiar neighborhood is more important to them than money.

title: Debt Issues
description: Caterpillar Financial Services Corp. filed a shelf offering of $100 million of debt securities.

title: HOWELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $388,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes a gain of $1,049,000 from discontinued operations.

title: TRANSACT INTERNATIONAL-DIVISION OF GRAM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $140,000 in the 9 months.

title: Required Reading;   Hands Off
description: In his years in the Senate, Sam J. Ervin Jr. was regarded as the foremost constitutional expert in Congress. Now 88 years old and practicing law in his hometown of Morganton, N. C., Mr. Ervin recently wrote a letter to President Reagan, criticizing the Administration as trying to circumvent the freedom of religion clause of the First Amendment.

title: GAP STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
Continental to Get 4 More Aircraft
description: Continental Air Lines said it had received the approval of a Federal bankruptcy court to acquire from the Texas Air Corporation, its parent company, four Boeing 737-300 aircraft. But the court stopped short of approving the purchase of 18 planes, initially sought by the Houston-based carrier as part of its expansion plan.

title: BOGGS IN CROWING ABOUT CHICKEN
description: In Wade Boggs's first time up against the Yankees today, he hit a pop-up down the left-field line that fell fowl. That spelling - which would have wrung cries of anguish from Webster - is from Wade Boggs's own lexicon, as taken from his book, ''Fowl Tips,'' a collection of his favorite chicken recipes that was published last October.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Acton Corp., Acton, Mass., said it had sold a 13,000-subscriber cable television system in eastern Los Angeles County to Daniels & Associates, a closely held firm based in Denver, for at least $15 million and possibly as much as $17 million.

title: IS IT FAIR TO HAVE SELECTIVE SCHOOLS?
description: WHEN the winners of the annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search were announced earlier this month, Stuyvesant High School and Bronx High School of Science once again captured a disproportionate number. The two schools together provided 3 of the country's 10 winners, in addition to 3 other students who wound up among the 40 finalists. Another winner attended City Honors High School in Buffalo.

title: MT. SINAI HAS PICKED INVESTMENT BANKER TO BE ITS CHAIRMAN
description: Frederick A. Klingenstein, chairman and chief executive officer of the investment-banking concern of Wertheim & Company, was elected chairman of the boards of trustees of the Mount Sinai Medical Center yesterday.

title: Concert: Forrester
description: THE contralto Maureen Forrester chose an unusual and uncompromising program for her Thursday evening recital at the 92d Street Y, accompanied by the pianist Derek Banptom. Schumann's song cycle ''Liederkreis'' (Op. 39) was the only work that could have been considered familiar; the remainder of the concert was devoted to some contemporary music from Miss Forrester's native Canada.

title: HEMOTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OPEC Group Gathers
description: OPEC ministers have begun assembling here for a meeting of the group's ministerial executive council, which will monitor the 13 members' production levels. The meeting's precise agenda is still confidential, and sources in Geneva indicated that officials of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries were upset that news of the meeting had leaked out.

title: A TRIUMPH FOR CAPITAL CITIES
description: Capital Cities Communications, long one of publishing and broadcasting's more aggressive acquirers, is making a notable addition to its collection of media properties. With its proposed takeover of ABC - four times its size and many times its renown - Capital Cities is joining the major leagues.

title: NATIONAL WESTERN LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses on investments of $419,387 for the quarter and $507,006 for the year and includes a $19,983,833, or $5.75 per share, one-time tax benefit from the 1984 Tax Act for the quarter and year. c-After a loss on investments of $480,843 and an extraordinary charge related to reversal of tax capital loss carryforwards of $125,000. d-After losses on investments of $220,834.

title: BRACKEN EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss after a writedown of $4,437,254 relating to the company's drilling equipment for the quarter and year.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Maureen Forrester, Contemporary Program
description: The contralto Maureen Forrester chose an unusual and uncompromising program for her Thursday evening recital at the 92d Street Y, accompanied by the pianist Derek Banptom. Schumann's song cycle ''Liederkreis'' (Op. 39) was the only work that could have been considered familiar; the remainder of the concert was devoted to some contemporary music from Miss Forrester's native Canada.

title: 'NOVA' STALKS ANNUAL MIGRATION OF ELK
description: THERE are wildlife documentaries and there are wildlife documentaries, and ''Monarch of the Mountains'' is better than most. For one thing, it looks terrific. For another, it tells a story - beginning, middle and end. The ''Nova'' production will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 tonight.

title: Morocco's King Vows To Buy More Weapons
description: King Hassan II, warning that the guerrilla war over Western Sahara could drag on for years, says Morocco will spend $1 billion on modern weapons in the next five years.

title: APPLE MIGHT LEARN A THING OR TWO FROM I.B.M.
description: WHITHER the Macintosh? It has been a little more than a year since ''the computer for the rest of us'' came trumpeting out of Cupertino, Calif., with a fanfare outplaying even I.B.M. The hype came through. More than 250,000 Macs sold in the first year, and 500,000 more are expected to be pushed out of Apple Computer's superautomated factory in 1985, according to the market research concern Future Computing.

title: DANCE: JUILLIARD ENSEMBLE PERFORMS
description: THE Juilliard Dance Ensemble series this past weekend was the last to coincide with the tenure of Martha Hill as director of the Juilliard School's Dance Division.

title: HARVARD'S CORE: A SUCCESS SO FAR
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: WOOING THE PRESS IN GENEVA
description: For a world accustomed to the dour public personas of Soviet diplomats like Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, the opening of the arms control talks last week included a startling sight: a Soviet diplomat on television who performed with a Western politician's sense of the camera.

title: WINANS DENIES SCHEME WAS DEVISED BY HIM
description: R. Foster Winans, the former Wall Street Journal reporter on trial for conspiracy and securities fraud, testified yesterday that at the time he gave out advance information about stock market columns he did not believe that he was committing a crime. He also contended that the plan to share that information with others was not his idea.

title: A Bee Sees
description: The ability of honeybees to remember the shapes and patterns of flowers seems to be more sophisticated than scientists had realized.

title: BRODKIN HAILED BY OLD TV FRIENDS
description: Ruddy, peppery, 73-year-old Herbert Brodkin, who produced 35 years of socially significant television drama, stood in the Versailles Room of the St. Regis Hotel recently and looked out at a room full of old friends and adversaries.

title: LIFE STILL BEAUTIFUL AFTER LAST BUZZER
description: Not long after the final game of his college career, a 3-point loss in which his shot was blocked in the last half-minute of play, Richie Adams still managed to wear a smile. On his red University of Nevada-Las Vegas jacket, he also wore a button. ''Super Person Award. Lester E. Rowe,'' it said. The button had been presented to Adams by students at a school in Nevada as a thank you for the time he has spent with them. The smile would have to be surgically removed.

title: WEEKEND INJURIES CLAIM TWO RANGERS
description: Even as they moved nearer to clinching the last playoff spot in the Patrick Division, the Rangers learned yesterday that Barry Beck, their captain and strongman, would probably be sidelined for two weeks with an aggravated left shoulder, and Robbie Ftorek would be out for the rest of the season with torn ligaments in his left knee.

title: THEATER: 'THE FANTOD,' A PLAY BY AMLIN GRAY
description: WATCHING ''The Fantod,'' Amlin Gray's laborious new play at the Perry Street Theater, one might be tempted to conclude that a talented writer has been stymied by an unyielding subject. ''The Fantod'' is an elaborate pastiche of Victorian literature - from the epistolary novel to the Gothic melodrama - and its message is predictable: Mr. Gray is out to expose the sexual neuroses, moral hypocrisies and social inequities that festered just beneath the rectitudinous veneer of 19th-century England. Given the number of times we've been down this path, one wonders whether any playwright, however clever, could possibly make the journey lively.

title: SELIGMAN & LATZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Book Offers Guidance On Careers in the Trade
description: For many young people a job in the agency business is a much-desired thing.

title: A NEW THEORY POINTS TO MODEL FOR KING ARTHUR
description: A BRITISH scholar has uncovered evidence that he says establishes the identity of the man who may well have been the model for the mythic Arthur, the once and future king of legend. The real Arthur, according to the new findings, was probably a fifth-century ''high king'' of the Britons known as Riothamus.

title: Jersey Officer Charged With Suspect's Murder
description: A rookie police officer was charged with murder today in the shooting death of an unarmed teen-age suspect after the youth had surrendered, officials said.

title: INFORMATION SOLUTIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
DALI AT 80, OUTRAGEOUS AS EVER
description: His beloved wife, model and muse, Gala, is gone now. But after five years of living in virtual public silence, and more than two years of mourning in the dark, Salvador Dali, surely the greatest showman of 20th century art, has decided to talk.

title: UNIFORCE TEMPORARY PERONNEL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings were adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in September 1984.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm pleased to welcome back to baseball Willie Mays and Mickey Mantle, effective immediately.'' - Peter Ueberroth, commissioner of baseball. (B7:1.)

title: POLICE SERGEANT IS ARRESTED IN HIT-AND-RUN DEATH
description: A police sergeant was arrested yesterday on charges that he was the driver of a patrol car that struck and killed a 70-year-old pedestrian and injured another man Friday night in a hit-and-run incident on Park Avenue.

title: ALTAIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Market Place;   Broadcasting Stock Eruption
description: BROADCASTING and media stocks erupted yesterday in response to the announcement that Capital Cities Communications had agreed to acquire the American Broadcasting Companies, one of the nation's three major television networks. Under the agreement, each share of ABC common will be converted into $118 in cash, plus one-tenth of a warrant to buy common stock of Capital Cities.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THE FAT IN COLLEGE BUDGETS
description: This is the time of year when high school students peer eagerly into their mailboxes and their parents peer glumly into their wallets. Meanwhile, anxiety created by college tuition bills is, as usual, providing fuel for the debate over Federal student aid programs. Advocates argue that families can't pay what the colleges are asking, while budget-cutters argue that the Federal Goverment can't either. Left out of the debate altogether is the party that created the problem to begin with - the colleges themselves.

title: 344 Atomic Reactors
description: By the end of 1984, according to the International Atomic Energy Agency, there were 344 atomic reactors delivering electric power in 26 countries. Thirty-three new ones had come on line that year.

title: NCNB to Sell Unit
description: The NCNB Corporation announced the sale of its Transouth Financial Corporation subsidiary to First Nationwide Savings for $85 million.

title: ALLIED STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: Results for the latest quarter are for a 14-week period compared with 13 weeks a year ago.

title: By John Gross;
description: THE LAST ROMANTIC. A Biography of

title: BERKLEY, W R CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized gains on investments of $1,222,000 for the quarter and $2,260,000 for the year. c-Net loss after underwriting losses from discontinued product lines of $1,547,000 for the quarter and $2,808,000 for the year and realized investment gains of $153,000 and $3,586,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: On the Air
description: CBS Sports, which passed up a chance to televise the St. John's basketball team's game in national first- round coverage of the N.C.A.A. tournament last week, won't do so again. The Redmen will be shown live by the network the rest of the way, for as far as they go, starting with their third- round matchup against Kentucky this Friday night. The telecast begins at 10 P.M. New York time.

title: PENRIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Delivering Frustation
description: A woman ordered four dinette chairs

title: Better Mass Transit Will Help Cab Availability
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising;   Creation Of HCM Completed
description: YESTERDAY was the day when

title: GROMYKO'S SPEECH ON LEADER IS AIRED
description: The Soviet Union today published the text of Andrei A. Gromyko's speech that nominated Mikhail S. Gorbachev as the new Soviet leader last week. The document offered an intriguing glimpse into the transition of power in the Soviet Union.

title: Costa Rica Debt Ruling
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday reversed its earlier decision in a case involving Costa Rica's debt. Bankers had feared the original ruling, handed down last April, might give defaulting debtor countries protection from creditor banks.

title: GOVERNOR CONFIDENT THAT RUN IS OVER
description: Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio said today that he was confident there would be no further runs on deposits when some of the 71 state-insured savings and loan associations are allowed to reopen even before they are covered by Federal deposit insurance.

title: DISLIKE OF OWN BODY FOUND COMMON AMONG WOMEN
description: OF all the ways people experience themselves, perhaps none is so primal as the sense of their own bodies. Yet that sense, researchers are finding, is prone to psychological distortions that can have profound effects on how people view themselves and their world.

title: Key Computer Editor In Ziff-Davis Talks
description: In the computer industry, Esther Dyson holds something of a charmed post: part newsletter publisher, part influential critic, part advocate for new technologies. Now, Miss Dyson, 33, appears ready to sell her rights to RELease 1.0, her erratically published and sometimes irreverent newsletter, to the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company and head up a new daily newspaper there covering the computer business.

title: Time to Regroup
description: Princeton's basketball season had many of the earmarks for which the Tigers had long been noted: second in the nation in team defense, victories against two teams - Penn and Lehigh - that qualified for the N.C.A.A. tournament and five defeats by 3 points or fewer. On the other hand, the 63-30 blowout loss to Cornell in the final game of the season left the Tigers at 11-15.

title: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
LEBANESE GEMAYEL MOVE ON REBELS
description: Prime Minister Rashid Karami said today that a Christian militia revolt could lead to the downfall of the Christian President, Amin Gemayel, and threaten ''the very existence of Lebanon.''

title: Bridge:Women's Knockout Series Features Two Close Battles
description: Two East Coast-West Coast sextets contested the final of the Women's Knockout Team Championship at the Hyatt Regency Hotel here this afternoon after surviving close battles Sunday night. After 16 deals, the team led by Roberta Epstein of South Orange, N.J., led by 25 international match points against Rama Linz of Beverly Hills, Calif., and her squad.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: The year-ago results were restated to reflect certain inter-company transactions.

title: Kim Dae Jung Takes Post in Seoul Opposition
description: Kim Dae Jung joined a fellow dissident, Kim Young Sam, today as joint leaders of the group behind a new opposition faction that finished a strong second to the Government party in parliamentary elections last month.

title: 1ST NETWORK SALE
description: The American Broadcasting Companies agreed yesterday to be sold to Capital Cities Communications Inc. for more than $3.5 billion.

title: TAKEOVER'S IMPACT IS UNCERTAIN
description: Throughout television, executives and producers reacted with expressions of outward calm and general assertions of enthusiasm yesterday to ABC's agreement to be taken over by Capital Cities Communications.

title: No Headline
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 19, 1985 International

title: KELLY RALLIES GAMBLERS
description: Jim Kelly threw four touchdown passes, and Toni Fritsch kicked three field goals to rally the unbeaten Houston Gamblers to a 36-17 victory over the Denver Gold tonight.

title: OHIO CONSIDERS EMERGENCY BILL FOR THRIFT UNITS
description: The Ohio State Senate was debating early today an emergency bill that would require Federal deposit insurance for all Ohio savings and loan associations.

title: WEINBERGER REMARK ADDS FUEL TO CANADA DEBATE
description: A remark made today by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger added fresh fuel to a debate among Canadians over whether a new agreement on joint air defense might lead to the eventual stationing of United States weapons on Canadian soil.

title: VALUE LINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
UNIVERSAL-RUNDLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes an after-tax gain of $789,000, or 47 cents a share, on the July 1984 sale of its Redlands, Calif., vitreous China plant. The year-ago net was adversely affected by one-time charges of $618,144 after taxes related to the closing of the company's New Castle, Pa., vitreous China plant and the writeoff of customer accounts receivable and inventories of the Osborne Computer Corp. totaling $669,600 after taxes.

title: THOSE WHO STUDY PEACE ALSO STUDY WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Up 2.32, to 1,249.67; Volume Off
description: Broadcast stocks were in the spotlight yesterday on Wall Street, after the proposed merger of the American Broadcasting Companies with Capital Cities Communications Inc. as the rest of the market closed mixed, on lighter trading volume.

title: Shamrock Joins Firms in Soya Bid
description: Shamrock Holdings Inc., a privately held investment firm owned by Roy E. Disney and his family, said it had formed a limited partnership with two other firms in a bid to take over the Central Soya Company of Fort Wayne, Ind. Shamrock late Friday announced its intention to buy out the Indiana food company in a $23- a-share offer, worth about $292 million.

title: A LEADER IN HARDWARE TURNING TO SOFTWARE
description: MANY companies would like to become ''the I.B.M. of software,'' establishing dominance in the lucrative but fragmented personal computer software field in the same way that the International Business Machines Corporation has dominated in hardware. The most formidable of these contenders is often overlooked: I.B.M. itself.

title: Tyco, the Toy Maker, Seeks A New Agency
description: Tyco Industries, the Moorestown, N.J., toy manufacturer, is looking for a new agency and is welcoming solications for its $6 million account.

title: LITTLE IN NICARAGUA ESCAPES WAR'S ONSLAUGHT
description: After four years of fighting, the increasingly fierce war between the Nicaraguan Government and the rebels seeking its overthrow is the dominant factor in the country's political and economic life, according to Nicaraguans and diplomats here.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WHAT'S new about old clothes? Right now, a great deal. Both Reminiscence and the Antique Boutique are spreading their wings. Reminiscence has moved to a new location, and the Antique Boutique is expanding in several directions. After 10 years on Macdougal Street, where there were waiting lines on weekends for the five dressing rooms, Reminiscence has moved to 74 Fifth Avenue (near 13th Street), where there are 16 dressing rooms and plenty of space for the old clothes and jewelry, military surplus and new clothes for which the store is famous.

title: VIDEO CONNECTION OF AMERCA reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-After tax credits of $53,594 for the latest year and $91,000 for the earlier period.

title: Stephen Spender at Adelphi
description: The British poet Sir Stephen Spender will lecture and read from his own work during a two-day program at Adelphi University, South Avenue, Garden City, L.I. The program, part of a series celebrating Shakespeare's influence on the arts, will begin April 12, with a lecture by Mr. Spender on ''Shakespeare and the Literature of the 20th Century,'' at 8 P.M., in the Ruth S. Harley University Center.

title: INDUSTRY'S CAPACITY USE FELL TO 80.7% LAST MONTH
description: The nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 80.7 percent of capacity in February, down seven- tenths of a percentage point from the January rate and the lowest level in a year, the Government said today.

title: ROYAL PALM BEACH COLONY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
JOHNSON ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Salvador Rebels Disrupt Electric Power
description: Guerrillas cut electrical power to two northern provinces and toppled electricity towers along the coastal highway on Sunday, officials said today.

title: Justice White Grants Stay of Execution
description: Justice Byron R. White of the Supreme Court today stayed the execution of Willie Watson, who had been scheduled to be electrocuted early Tuesday.

title: LOUIS STONE, 74, AUTHOR OF INVESTMENT LETTER
description: Louis Stone, an investment analyst and financial writer and a vice president of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., a financial services concern, died of heart and kidney failure Saturday at Doctors Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Ansel Adams
description: No, they do not plan to hang James G. Watt in effigy. Rather, in celebration of its 50th year, officials of the Wilderness Society have hung 75 signed photographs of the late Ansel Adams, the pre-eminent landscape photographer, in the gallery of the society's new national headquarters in Washington.

title: NEWCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: BRITISH FASHION: A QUIETER MOOD
description: Drawn by last season's antic shows of some avant-garde designers just a few years out of school as well as by the audacious dress of the young people on streets such as King's Road, retailers and journalists swept into this city in huge numbers. Not since the swinging 60's has British fashion been such a strong magnet. More than 10,000 buyers, according to trade estimates, began arriving at the end of last week to inspect the new fall designs. This represents an increase of 20 percent over last year.

title: RINALDI AND LINDQVIST VICTORS
description: Someday, it may be just a footnote in her career. But until Kathy Rinaldi begins winning tournaments, or until a precocious third-grader decides she is ready for the women's tennis tour, Miss Rinaldi will be preceded on the court by the distinction that she is the youngest woman ever to turn professional.

title: SOUTHERN HOSPITALITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Chopin Is Highlight Of Byron Janis Recital
description: When was the last time you heard a pianist close a recital with a mixed Chopin group - a nocturne and a mazurka, say, with an etude and a clutch of quick waltzes - and get the audience really caught up in the fun of it? Byron Janis did that Saturday night at the 92d Street Y (the scene of his local debut in 1945) at the end of a program far more enjoyable than most of its kind these days.

title: Business and the Law;   Unequal Rights In Voting Stock
description: ''ONE share, one vote'' has long been a bedrock notion in corporate America. In recent months, however, several blue-chip giants and scores of small new companies have adopted bylaws that allow for unequal voting rights. For example, one class of common stock, usually controlled by management, may allow 10 votes per share, while another class, owned by nonmanagement investors, may have just one vote per share or perhaps no vote at all.

title: JAPAN PLANS TO PROVIDE PROTECTION FOR SOFTWARE
description: The Japanese Government told United States trade negotiators here today that Japan plans to grant long-term copyright protection to computer software.

title: CHAPMAN ENJOYING COMEBACK AS A MET
description: George Foster remembers the five years when Kelvin Chapman was, in his words, ''a lost man, forgotten by the club, lost in the shuffle.''

title: DOLE SAYS HE EXPECTS MX TO SURVIVE VOTE TODAY
description: As the Senate began debate today over continued financing for the MX missile, Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, said he was confident that the weapon system would survive a critical vote scheduled for Tuesday.

title: CUOMO, LAUDING REGAN, COMPARES HIM TO LEVITT
description: At 5:30 A.M. the day after Comptroller Edward V. Regan cut the legs from under his fellow Republicans in the budget battle - annually Albany's biggest political- governmental fight - Governor Cuomo started a new page in his diary.

title: Coaches Pick Team

title: ROCK: PRIBCE AT THE NASSAU COLISEUM
description: PRINCE and his band, the Revolution, who have been touring America since shortly after the release of the ''Purple Rain'' album and film some months ago, finally made it to the New York area Sunday night, for the first of six scheduled shows at Nassau Coliseum. And Prince's fans were ready. ''We want Prince,'' they chanted in roaring unison through much of the intermission after Sheila E.'s well-received opening set.

title: Emerson to Buy Automatic Switch
description: The Emerson Electric Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Automatic Switch Company in a stock transaction valued at about $373.5 million.

title: CURRENCY PLAN STIRS SKEPTICISM
description: American and international monetary officials here voiced skepticism today over plans reported in Paris aimed at generating greater currency stability by concentrating more international pressure on domestic American economic policy.

title: British Output Up 1.3%
description: Industrial production in Britain rose 1.3 percent in January from December, as increasing energy output offset a weather-related decline in manufacturing output, the Central Statistics Office said today.

title: BIG DEFICIT IN CURRENT ACCOUNT
description: The broadest measure of United States foreign trade, the current account, which measures trade in merchandise and services, posted a record deficit of $101.6 billion in 1984, more than double the old mark, the Commerce Department reported today. The previous record deficit, $41.6 billion, was set in 1983.

title: SHULTZ PLANNING TO MEET GROMYKO
description: The State Department set the stage today for a meeting between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union in mid-May in Vienna.

title: HOUSTON HOUSING AUTHORITY ACCUSED OF RACIAL STEERING
description: Houston's public housing authority has systematically funneled Vietnamese refugees into an inner-city housing project to lessen opposition to a plan to clear and develop the property, a prime piece of downtown real estate, a court document suggested today.

title: Annette Hanshaw Dies at 74; Singer in 1920's and 1930's
description: Annette Hanshaw, one of the most prolific recording singers in the late 1920's and early 30's, died of cancer on Wednesday at New York Hospital after a long illness. She was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: WHITE HOUSE INTRUDERS: MENTAL ILLNESS FOUND
description: Imaginary problems ranging from secret invasions to aliens from outer space motivated many of the people who have tried to gain unauthorized entry to the White House, says a psychiatrist who has studied hundreds of them.

description: The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, met today with David A. Stockman, the budget director, and later with Republican committee chairmen in an effort to reach a compromise on the 1986 fiscal plan approved by the Senate Budget Committee last week.

title: MCFADDIN VENTURES reports earnings for Qtr to March 3

On the Death of Poor Babies Dr. Edward N. Brandt Jr., until recently the Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services, finds some new public health data ''disquieting.'' He had thought America's declining infant mortality rate would reach 9 deaths for each 1,000 births, almost as low as that of Japan and six European countries. ''My prediction was wrong,'' he says, ''flat wrong.'' The rate seems to be leveling off at 11 deaths per 1,000.
description: That may come as a surprise to Dr. Brandt, but not to many health professionals aware of the Reagan Administration's continuing approach to basic health services: Cut them. What elevates the infant mortality rate? Figures like these: 21 of every 1,000 babies born in the Bronx's Morrisania section will die before their first birthday (compared with 6.2 in Astoria, Queens). So will 17 of those born in New Haven; 22 in Trenton; 55 in the Avalon Park section of Chicago. What these places have in common is poverty.

title: '84 Oil Output Up in Mexico
description: Mexico's oil production rose in 1984, but its oil reserves drifted lower, the director of the Government's oil monopoly, Pemex, said today in delivering his annual report.

MICRON TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: The year-ago shares outstanding include 30 million shares which the company repurchased and retired on May 31, 1984.

title: Missing Student, 26, Found Shot to Death
description: A 26-year-old Norwegian student, who was last seen entering his apartment house in Manhattan three weeks ago, was found shot to death Sunday in a wooded area of Rockland County, the police said yesterday.

title: MIDEATS MOVES: AWKWARD U.S. ROLE
description: After years of urging the Arabs to take a more active role in the search for a Middle East peace, the United States finds itself in the uncomfortable position of seeming unwilling to run with the diplomatic ball given it by Jordan, Egypt and the Palestine Liberation Organization. Senior officials at the State Department say the reasons for Washington's reluctance to move energetically are both substantive and personal.

title: 'FIRST STEPS,' ON CBS, FACTUAL DOCUMENTATION
description: ANYONE curious about the connections between television entertainment and television news should be fascinated by ''First Steps,'' the television movie being presented on CBS tonight at 9. The story of Dr. Jerrold Petrofsky, a bio-engineer who developed computer electrodes to stimulate the leg muscles of paraplegics, has served as the basis for three separate reports on CBS's ''60 Minutes.'' Now, what the network calls a ''factual drama'' has been produced by Ellis A. Cohen for CBS Entertainment Productions, and one of the characters, played by an actor, is a ''60 Minutes'' producer.

title: MX AND THE NEW GUNS-AND-BUTTER ARGUMENT
description: Representative Matthew G. Martinez is a third-term Democrat from the industrial suburbs northeast of Los Angeles. His heavily Mexican-American blue-collar district, hit hard by major plant closings in recent years, is aching for new business.

title: SUFFOLK'S STANCE ON NUCLEAR UNIT UPHELD IN COURT
description: A Federal judge yesterday upheld Suffolk County's decision not to participate in emergency planning for the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: JOSEPH BROWN
description: Joseph Brown, a sculptor and visual arts professor who taught at Princeton University for 38 years, died Thursday at Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia after a long illness.

description: Ogilvy & Mather Direct, at age 12, is laying claim to the title ''World's Largest Direct Marketing Agency,'' long held by Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, in recent years a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam.

title: WHITE HOUSE IS SEEKING CINVERTS TO G.O.P. CHIEFLY IN STATEHOUSES
description: White House political officials have begun a drive to convert Democratic officeholders, particularly state legislators in the South, to the Republican Party.

title: THEATER: OPENING OF 'DIGBY'
description: WHEN Anthony Heald and Roxanne Hart are together center stage - as they are roughly half the time - it is nearly impossible to resist Joseph Dougherty's ''Digby,'' the new play at the Manhattan Theater Club. ''Digby'' is a concerted, though wildly uneven, attempt to recreate the kind of snappy romantic New York comedy that writers like Jean Kerr and George Axelrod once supplied regularly to Broadway. Mr. Heald and Miss Hart are so winning a pair that, with a stronger script, they could well bring the genre back into fashion again.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

Doctors for Brazilian Leader Report Intestinal 'Alterations'
description: Doctors attending Brazil's President-elect, Tancredo Neves, said today that he is suffering from ''alterations'' in his intestinal movements following the emergency surgery that prevented him from assuming office last Friday.

title: New Budget for Britain Focuses on Adding Jobs
description: In the face of growing hostility toward the British Government's handling of the economy, Chancellor of the Exchequer Nigel Lawson today disclosed a budget for the next fiscal year that holds Britain to the economic policies laid out when Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher came to power in 1979.

A.T.&T. said the device could significantly improve quality-control methods in such operations as automobile assembly lines.

description: Ask Robert Novak about his favorite lunch spot, the Maison Blanche, and you get a paradox.

description: The national office of the Veterans of Foreign Wars has revoked the charter of its Santa Cruz post for publicly opposing the V.F.W.'s official position on Central America.

title: MUSIC: HANDEL ANTHEMS
description: HANDEL'S operas and oratorios have spoken to wide audiences since their inception, but his anthems lead a more secluded life within the church. The New Amsterdam Singers brought three of the latter to Merkin Concert Hall Sunday night. All were for chorus and orchestra; two involved soloists, and they ranged in length from the three brief movements of ''Let Thy Hand Be Strengthened'' to the elaborate 10-part ''Funeral Anthem for Queen Caroline.''
