description: N.C.A.A East Regional, semifinals, at Providence Civic Center: Georgetown vs. Loyola of Chicago (Television - Channel 2, 9 P.M.); Illinois vs. Georgia Tech (Television - Channel 2, 11:30 P.M., tape.)

title: EXCERPTS FROM PAPER ISSUED BY THE VATICAN
description: Following are excerpts from a document on the Rev. Leonardo Boff issued by the Vatican Congregation for the Doctine of the Faith today and translated by The Associated Press from the Italian:

title: MURDOCH IS BUYING 50% OF FOX
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher who has bought up numerous American newspapers and magazines, entered the motion picture business yesterday with an agreement to buy 50 percent of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation.

title: 4 MEN INDICTED BY GRAND JURY ON S.I. IN CREDIT CARD SCHEME
description: Four men have been indicted by a grand jury on Staten Island on charges that they fabricated bogus credit cards, sold some and bought thousands of dollars worth of merchandise with the rest, the authorities announced yesterday.

title: Beached Ship to Be Sunk
description: The Mercedes I, the freighter that was beached for 104 days at the Palm Beach home of the millionaire Mollie Wilmot, will be sunk off the coast here. The 190-foot Venezuelan freighter will be used as an artificial reef to attract game fish. She was purchased Tuesday for $29,450 by the Broward County Commission.

title: COMPUSCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Including tax credits of $194,000 for the quarter and $664,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $400,000 for the quarter and $918,000 for the 9 months.

title: Eastman Kodak Getting Eikonix
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said that it would acquire the Eikonix Corporation for $16.12 a share, or a total of about $56.3 million. Eikonix, which makes digital image-processing equipment and optical systems, will be operated as a Kodak subsidiary, retaining its name and management, the companies said.

title: MOSCOW CRITICIZES SENATE ON THE MX
description: The Soviet press today denounced the Senate vote to release $1.5 billion for 21 MX missiles, saying that President Reagan had twisted senators' arms to get his way.

title: F.A.A. Grounds Helicopter Service
description: The Federal Government, citing numerous violations of safety rules, said yesterday that it had ordered the emergency grounding of a New Jersey-based air-taxi helicopter company for at least 45 days.

title: PIC 'N' SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. OFFICIAL DEMANDS DETAILS ON CUOMO REGISTRATION DRIVE
description: A Federal investigator made an unannounced visit to the State Capitol in Albany last week to demand detailed information on Governor Cuomo's voter-registration drive in state offices.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Pepitone's Lawyer Denies All Charges
description: Joe Pepitone's lawyer said yesterday that the former New York Yankee had told him that he did not know there were drugs and a loaded gun in the car in which he was a passenger when it was stopped by the police Monday night.

title: CHILDREN'S FILM WINS ACCLAIM FOR PRODUCER
description: Morton Schindel, a producer of animated films, has spent 30 years pursuing an unusual objective.

title: CHURCH CLEARS SOUTH AFRICAN
description: The Rev. Allan Boesak, president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches and a prominent foe of the white South African authorities, was reinstated as pastor of his local congregation today after church elders dismissed reports that he had been embroiled in an adulterous relationship.

title: The Spice of Strife
description: Parks Commissioner Henry J.

title: A 'Hill Street' Creator Is Leaving Show
description: Stephen Bochco, co-creator of NBC's ''Hill Street Blues'' and the man who guided the police show to an unprecedented 25 Emmy awards, said Wednesday he is leaving the show after being asked to resign as producer by MTM Enterprises.

title: GOETZ TO SPEAK TO GRAND JURY, DEFENSE ASSERTS
description: Lawyers for Bernhard H. Goetz said yesterday that they would allow their client to testify - without immunity from prosecution - before a second grand jury investigating his shooting of four youths on a subway train last December.

title: YANK MORALE LIFTS DALE BERRA
description: Dale Berra, who was traded last winter from the Pittsburgh Pirates to the Yankees, said he had seen no evidence of the antics that gave rise to the Yankee clubhouse once being called The Bronx Zoo. In contrast, the Pirate clubhouse was, to Berra, the Monongahela Menagerie.

title: Toys 'R' Us Net Advances Toys ''R'' Us Inc., the country's largest toy specialty retail chain, reported yesterday
description: that earnings in the quarter

title: Harvester Plans More Spending
description: The International Harvester Company plans capital spending of $70 million in 1985, up from $54 million last year, the company's president, Neil Springer, said after the annual meeting. Mr. Springer said the company would spend $50 million on research and development, ''slightly better'' than in 1984.

title: BEIRUT TELLS ARMY TO CRUSH MILITIAS
description: The Lebanese Cabinet instructed the army today to put an end to factional clashes in southern Lebanon.

title: VOLCKER PLEDGES SUPPORT TO OHIO THRIFT UNITS
description: In an effort to calm financial markets, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that it was prepared to lend funds to 70 Ohio savings and loan associations closed last week.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: FOR years it was common practice to change the thermostat setting on the home heating or central air-conditioning system manually, as comfort needs dictated. Raising and lowering the thermostat became an issue 10 or 12 years ago when energy costs were soaring. People began to install clock- controlled thermostats that adjusted automatically each day on a predetermined schedule. In theory a clock- controlled thermostat will not save any more energy than manual changes, but it eliminates human error - it won't forget.

title: MANOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
COMMISSION URGES STATE TO TAKE UNCLAIMED NICKEL BOTTLE DEPOSITS
description: The commission reviewing New York State's bottle-deposit law recommended today that all unclaimed deposits go to the state instead of to bottlers and distributors, who now are allowed to keep them. The state should use the money, the panel decided in the same 5-to-4 vote, to pay for redemption centers where consumers could return empty beverage containers. If any money is left over, the commission added, it should be used for environmental programs. The findings of the panel, the Temporary State Commission on Returnable Beverage Containers, will be submitted to the Legislature. To become effective, they would have to be passed as legislation.

title: SOME UNITS TO OPEN ON A LIMITED BASIS
description: Ohio banking officials said today that they hoped many of the 70 state-insured thrifts that have been closed since last week would reopen on a limited basis as early as Friday to allow up to a half million depositors to withdraw as much as $750 each to meet necessities.

title: Soccer Group Picks Dale
description: Francis L. Dale, publisher and chief executive officer of the Los Angeles Herald Examiner, was named commissioner today of the Major Indoor Soccer League at a meeting of the league's 13 owners.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Goldome Florida to Sell 750 Preferred Shares
description: The Goldome Florida Funding Corporation, a subsidiary of the $1.7 billion-asset Goldome Savings Bank, St. Petersburg, Fla., announced plans yesterday to sell a type of money market preferred stock through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: SANDINISTA IS PRESSING PEACE PLAN
description: No sooner had Daniel Ortega Saavedra finished attending funeral services for Konstantin U. Chernenko in Moscow last week than the Nicargauan President was back on an airplane. But instead of heading home, he was winging his way to Brasilia for the inauguration of Brazil's new civilian Government and the start of a weeklong visit.

title: The Bear Is a Wildcat
description: Long ago, Bret Bearup realized that his basketball existence was not going to work out the way it was

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports of The Times column on March 7 incorrectly described the base hit on which Enos Slaughter of St. Louis scored the winning run of the 1946 World Series. It was officially scored a double.

title: THE DANCE: 'JAMBOREE' BY THE JOFFREY
description: GERALD ARPINO'S ''Jamboree,'' which had its New York premiere Tuesday night with the Joffrey Ballet, was commissioned by the City of San Antonio and the San Antonio Performing Arts Association.

title: U.S. APPEALS TO IRAN TO FORSAKE A MILITARY SOLUTION
description: The United States appealed to Iran today to acknowledge that a military victory could not be achieved in the four-and- a-half-year-old war and to accept a negotiated settlement.

description: The latest quarter and year results were for 14 weeks and 53 weeks, respectively, compared with 13 weeks and 52 weeks for the year-earlier quarter and year, respectively. The 1984 figures were restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effected Jan. 8, 1985.

title: STOOLS FOR STEPPING UP
description: STEP stools, which are often useful for those hard-to-reach places, can be found in a variety of styles from classic to high tech. Service Hardware, 1338 Lexington Avenue, at 89th Street, carries a one-step aluminum stool that is 28 inches high and sells for $14.95. A smaller 11-inch stool made of solid oak is available for $32.

title: Penguins on Galapagos Flee; Flamingoes Are Said to Pale
description: Penguins are fleeing flames and pink flamingoes are paling irreversibly from the effects of smoke and ash from a blaze raging on the largest of the Galapagos Islands, scientists said today.

title: Mississippi Teachers Return After Pay Rise
description: The last of the Mississippi teachers who had been striking returned to their classrooms today, ending nearly a month of wildcat walkouts after they gained part of their wage demands.

title: Taiwan Admiral Named At Murder Trial
description: A reputed gang leader testified today that the chief of Taiwan's military intelligence had ordered him to murder a Chinese-American journalist on the ground that the journalist had been a ''double agent'' who had spied for both Taiwan and China.

title: A Princely Performance
description: ''I felt the vibrations,'' said 20-year-

title: FRIAR SAYS HE PREFERS 'TO WALK WITH THE CHURCH'
description: The Brazilian theologian Leonardo Boff said today that he accepted the Vatican's criticism of his work because ''I prefer to walk with the church rather than to walk alone with my theology.''

title: Stock Exchange
description: A breeding share in an outstanding thoroughbred stallion can set you back hundreds of thousands of dollars. But, if you'd like to set your sights lower - a lot lower - then you can.

title: Cancer Victim's Siblings May Have Been Found
description: A leukemia victim whose chances of living are slim without a bone marrow transplant may have found a brother and sister he has never seen, and both say they are willing to provide the life- saving tissue if they prove compatible.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Financial Briefs column in Business Day Monday about a debt offering by Hercules Inc. misstated the offering's size. It is 50 million principal amount of European Currency Units, which are a composite of the currencies of the 10 members of the European Economic Community.

title: WOMAN ACCUSES OFFICER ON ANTI-ABORTION ATTACK
description: A woman accompanying a friend at a Brooklyn abortion clinic has charged that she was assaulted by an off-duty police officer who was participating in anti-abortion picketing.

title: WINANS SEES ETHICS VIOLATION
description: R. Foster Winans, the former Wall Street Journal reporter charged with conspiracy and securities fraud, admitted yesterday at his trial that he had violated his sense of journalistic ethics when he engaged in a stock trading scheme based on advance information of his columns.

title: Avon Seeking An Acquisition By Reuters Avon Products Inc. said it
description: plans to make at least one substantial acquisition this year

title: MORGENTHAU ASKS FOR A SUBWAY CRIME UNIT
description: The Manhattan District Attorney said yesterday that he wanted to establish a new unit to prosecute subway crime and that he thought publicity from the Bernhard H. Goetz case might help him get the money to do it.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ILLITERATE AMERICA. By Jonathan Kozol. 270 pages. Anchor/Doubleday. $15.95.

title:
HOW SOON WILL GORBACHEV HAVE REAL CLOUT?;

HE'LL MOVE SLOWLY
description: The middle levels of the Soviet elite to which I belonged until I broke with Moscow in 1978 have had their first victory at the top: the election of Mikhail S. Gorbachev as the party's General Secretary. But it is not a total victory and while changes in style may come quickly, significant changes in policy are unlikely to. Half the Politburo is still composed of the old guard, and in key areas of Soviet affairs - especially foreign policy - they will probably dominate Moscow's decisions at least for quite some time.

title: THE ART OF PAINTING A SURFACE TO LOOK LIKE WOOD
description: WITH the current revival of Victorian furnishings and antiques and the restoration of Victorian homes comes a renewed interest in wood graining and other faux finishes such as marbleizing, leafing and lacquer.

title: TROOPS ARE CALLED OUT IN BOLIVIAN STRIKE
description: President Hernan Siles Zuazo deployed troops and riot police in the capital today to maintain order as a general strike entered its 13th day.

title: House Panel Approves Cambodia Rebel Funds
description: The House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asia voted today, for the first time, to allocate $5 million in funds for the non-Communist Cambodian rebels who are fighting against Vietnamese forces.

title: ARMS TALKS STRATEGY: BARGAINING RANGES WIDELY
description: As the Reagan Administration and the Soviet Union gear up their strategies for the current arms control negotiations, the bargaining goes well beyond the the exchanges behind closed doors in Geneva to the political arenas of the United States and Western Europe. ''This is going to be fought out in Western newspapers and legislative bodies,'' said an Administration official. ''It will not be settled by the force of logic and reason in Geneva.''

title: French Output Down
description: Industrial production in France fell 1.6 percent in January from the month before, the National Statistics Institute said today. In a separate report, the Labor Ministry said the unemployment rate fell to 10.9 percent in February from 11.4 percent in January.

title: THE WASTED COUNTRY
description: -five years ago today, several thousand blacks gathered in the town of Sharpeville, South Africa. They were there, unarmed, to protest against the apartheid pass laws. Suddenly, from behind a fence, police fired into the crowd; 67 were killed and 186 wounded, most of them shot in the back.

title: THE CURIOUS CRASSULA CLAN
description: THE ubiquitous jade (Crassula argentea) is a mainstay of the indoor plant collection. It is easy to propagate and simple to grow if it has enough sun. Mature plants that receive abundant light in summer will even put out a late fall indoor show of flowers, long-lasting clusters of pink-white stars.

Rollins, Jr. (''Ragtime,'' ''A Soldiers Story'' plays opposite William Smith in''Wildside,'' which premieres at 8 this evening.

The latest quarter and 6 months results included expenses for a proxy contest of $2,771,000.

title: MEESE FAVORS REDUCING TOTAL OF CLASSIFIED DATA
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that any Government decision to prosecute journalists for making secrets public would ''depend on the circumstances of the case.''

title: Legislators Upheld On $10,000 Raise
description: The Legislature acted constitutionally on Dec. 6 when it approved a raise for members, Justice Harold Hughes of State Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

description: Marriott Hotels and Resorts, based in Washington, yesterday assigned its domestic advertising account to Lewis, Gilman & Kynett, the Phildelphia subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding.

COSMIC PARTICLES PUZZLE SCIENTISTS
description: Astrophysicists say they believe a cosmic power source far out in space may be bombarding the earth with subatomic particles different from any known to science.

title: Peru May Order Emergency To Curb 'Political Agitation'
description: The Government threatened today to declare a nationwide state of emergency in the midst of the election campaign because of ''political agitation'' by 400,000 striking workers.

title: Reagan News Session To Be on TV Tonight
description: President Reagan will hold a news conference tonight, to be broadcast live at 8 P.M. Eastern standard time on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, and on CNN, the Cable News Network.

title: NEW CHANCE FOR A WORTHY LITTLE MAN
description: Even winning was no fun when it finally happened. Albert Davila had just about given up on becoming a world champion. Three times he had tried, and three times he had failed, although he appeared to have been robbed of the decision in 1978 against Jorge Lujan.

description: Milton R. Britten, the last editor of The Memphis Press-Scimitar, died Tuesday at his home.

description: Anne Morrow Lindbergh, who has been a Harcourt Brace Jovanovich author for 50 years, has retired from the company's board of directors after serving for 10 years, the publishing company announced.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Cuomo Nominates State Banking Chief
description: Until two weeks ago, Jill M. Considine had never met Mario Cuomo. But Miss Considine, president of the First Women's Bank in Manhattan, said her nomination by the Governor yesterday as state superintendent of banks did not come as a complete surprise.

description: Abortion rights activists today began a public relations campaign designed to emphasize the emotional traumas faced by women with unwanted pregnancies.

description: President Raul Alfonsin of Argentina told a joint meeting of Congress today that the debt crisis of Latin America threatened peace and stability in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Funeral Is Held for a Woman Mengel Is Accused of Killing
description: More than 200 friends, family members and I.B.M. co-workers attended a funeral service here today for Beverly Capone, the woman the police said was stabbed and mutilated by Alex J. Mengel, who is also accused of killing a Westchester police officer.

title: BRAZIL CHIEF HAS NEW OPERATION
description: Brazil's President-elect, Tancredo Neves, underwent new abdominal surgery today just five days after an emergency operation for an intestinal inflammation prevented him from taking the oath of office.

description: The Vatican today condemned the teachings of a Brazilian exponent of liberation theology, saying the theologian's views endangered ''the healthy doctrine of the faith.''

title: G.M. TO ACQUIRE COLONIAL COMPANIES
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would make its second acquisition in the mortgage-servicing field by buying the Colonial group of companies, based in Philadelphia. The terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: BIG FAMILIES OUT OF FAVOR
description: The desire for large families in the United States is at an all-time low, according to a recent Gallup Poll. In a national survey last month, only 11 percent of those polled said they wanted to have four or more children.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Rates Continue to Decline
description: Interest rates declined for the second consecutive day, and Government securities dealers said there was fair demand at the Treasury's regular monthly auction of two-year notes.

title: WOMAN, FOR FIRST TIME, WINS ALASKA SLED RACE
description: Libby Riddles mushed her weary dog team into Nome today and became the first woman to win the arduous 1,135- mile Iditarod Trail Dog Sled Race.

title: Troops Are Deployed For Bangladesh Election
description: Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, the President of Bangladesh, deployed troops at stations where the people will vote Thursday on whether they approve of his continuation in office until national elections can be held.

title: Janet Rutherfurd Dies at 39; Half-Sister of Mrs. Onassis
description: Janet Auchincloss Rutherfurd died last Wednesday at a Boston hospital of cancer at the age of 39.

title: Ban Is Appealed
description: The manufacturer of the chemical chlordane, used to kill termites, has gone into State Supreme Court to try to block an emergency ban against the use of such chemicals in the state.

S.E.C. SUES ACCOUNTANT FOR E.S.M.
description: The accountant who audited the books of the defunct E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. was charged today by the Securities and Exchange Commission with knowingly filing false and misleading auditing reports and with receiving secret payments from E.S.M. officers totaling $125,000.

title: British Earnings Climb
description: Average earnings in Britain rose 1.2 percent in January from December and were up 7 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today.

title: U.S.-Soviet Trade Talks
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that the United States and Soviet Union had agreed to hold a meeting of the Joint Commercial Commission on May 20 and 21 in Moscow.

title: UNION CARBIDE'S INQUIRY INDICATES ERRORS LED TO INDIA PLANT DISASTER
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said today that the chemical accident at its pesticide plant in Bhopal, India, in December stemmed from a variety of operating errors and procedural violations that would never be tolerated at the company's similar plant in the United States.

title: ADVANCED COMPUTER TECHIQUES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary pretax gain of $305,000 from the settlement of Iranian claims.

title: RESEARCHERS CRITICIZE CBS FILM 'FIRST STEPS'
description: A number of scientists, doctors and biomedical engineers expressed sharp criticisms today of a CBS television movie, aired Tuesday night, in which a paraplegic was hooked up to a computer and taught to walk her first few steps in years.

title: Military Bases to Comply With Drinking Laws
description: Starting June 1, the nation's military bases will have to comply with the drinking age laws of the states in which they are situated.

title: Hair, Hair
description: A 20th anniversary party is planned next month for Washington's most famous barber, Milton Pitts.

title: POST AT LINCOLN CENTER IS OFFERED TO DIRECTOR
description: Gregory Mosher, the artistic director of the Goodman Theater in Chicago, has been offered the position of artistic director of the Lincoln Center Theater Company, John V. Lindsay, its chairman, said last night. The company will operate both the Vivian Beaumont and Mitzi Newhouse theaters.

title: 2 of 3 Are Lost By Chiat/Day
description: agency appeared three times in

title: IRAQI JETS STAGE RAIDS ON IRANIAN CITIES
description: Iraqi jets were reported to have attacked six Iranian cities and Kharg Island today, raising the death toll at the Persian Gulf oil terminal to 18 in two days.

title: OLD TOWN ALEXANDRIA: EEK! CHIC!
description: The kaffeeklatsch begins gathering in Anne Richardson's parlor about 5 o'clock every afternoon. Under the light of the gas-lit chandelier - ''the only one in the metropolitan area,'' Mrs. Richardson boasts - the women of Old Town banter about who is getting divorced and which houses are on the market.

title: SOUTH AND EAST CLASH IN WEST
description: In recent years, the peculiar chauvinism that has grown up around East Coast basketball has been challanged by Southern coaches and players, tired of hearing that basketball rises and sets in the East.

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: BETTER LATE? The Baker's Wife'' is a musical that was out of town and headed for New York in 1976 but, what with one thing and another, got derailed in Washington. Tonight, the show, with music and lyrics by Stephen Schwartz (''Pippin,'' ''Godspell'') and book by Joseph Stein (''Fiddler on the Roof,'' ''Zorba''), finally starts its New York performances, at the York Theater, 2 East 90th Street (534-5366).

title: PAN AM SAYS UNION WILL DEFY STRIKE
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that the president of the Independent Union of Flight Attendants had told the airline he was ordering the 6,000 members of his union to cross the picket lines of the Transport Workers Union beginning today.

title: Johnson Is Upset By Absentee Mets
description: The serenity of the Mets' spring training was broken today when four regular members of the team were excused for various reasons and Manager Dave Johnson complained that the club's progress was being disrupted by absences.

title: Oil Minister Sees Stability
description: Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, the oil minister of the United Arab Emirates, said today that he thought the world oil market had stabilized after the steep price declines of late 1984 and early 1985.

title: No Headline
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 21, 1985 International

title: Skiing Brouhaha
description: He won a gold medal in the downhill at the 1984 Winter Olympics, but you couldn't tell it by watching

title: Ohio Thrift Merger Talk
description: Ohio offficials are telling out-of- state bankers that, if they want to enter Ohio by acquiring smaller savings and loan associations that are too weak to get Federal deposit insurance, a number of thrift units would have to be bundled into packages with combined assets of at least $500 million, according to Ohio banking sources.

title: Dispute Halts London Paper
description: The Sun, Britain's largest-selling daily newspaper, was not published today because of a labor dispute stemming from plans to move printing to a new plant and introduce new technology. The management of the paper, which is owned by Rupert Murdoch, said that the day's press run was canceled when two print unions that on Tuesday called branch meetings during production time would not promise to put out all of today's editions.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
THE NEW BREED OF BUSINESSLIKE YOUNG ARCHITECTS
description: LISTENING to members of the 1984 class of Columbia University's Graduate School of Architecture and Planning talk about their work recalls young business-school graduates discussing Wall Street mergers. Lofty design is of less interest than a project's cost figures. The young architect as struggling idealist has been replaced by a well-tailored professional with more practical ambitions.

title: Girl Guest at White House
description: Jennifer Ledbetter, a child who was told by a Reagan campaign aide last year that she was not welcome at the White House Easter egg roll because she supported Walter F. Mondale, was a special guest Tuesday at an official White House ceremony honoring the President of Argentina. Nancy Reagan issued the invitation after reading news accounts that Jennifer, then 11 years old, had been told she would not be invited to Easter festivities because of her support for the President's Democratic opponent.

title: THEATER: 'THE MUGGER'
description: SINCE most muggers are supposed to do their stuff quickly and make a fast getaway, the idea of having a talkative mugger as a central character presents certain difficulties for a playwright. A mugger who has to speak comically and philosophically while hanging out for two acts isn't like any of the ordinary muggers that we muggees usually encounter on the sidewalks of New York.

title: Texas Air Forms Western Division
description: The Texas Air Corporation, the Houston-based holding company that owns Continental Air Lines and New York Air, said yesterday said that it had formed a subsidiary and petitioned the Government to permit the subsidiary to offer air service to Western cities from Los Angeles.

title: DISPUTE AT WALDEN
description: Walden Pond, immortalized by the naturalist Henry David Thoreau, should be saved from the '' mobs'' who trample its steep banks and foul its waters by swimming, a legislative committee has been told.

title: Flood Disaster Declared
description: President Reagan declared a major disaster in upstate New York because of storms and flooding last December, the White House announced today. The storms, on Dec. 29 and 30, caused extensive property damage in Lewis and Oswego Counties. The President's action permits using Federal money for relief and recovery.

title: Study of American Catholics Is Misleading
description: To the Editor:

title: Hanoi Returns Remains Of 5 It Says Are M.I.A.'s
description: United States military officials flew to Hanoi and returned to the Philippines today with what Vietnam identified as the remains of five Americans missing in action since the Vietnam War.

title: Damage in Florida Tornado
description: The tornado that swept Venice before dawn Sunday, killing two people and injuring 42 others, caused $14 million in insured damage to homes and businesses, an insurance executive said Tuesday. The executive, Bill Davis, southeast regional director of the Insurance Information Institute, said the initial damage estimates were more than triple the $5 million needed for the insurance industry to designate the tornado losses as a catastrophe.

title: FOR CRAFTSMAN,A BEVY OF WORKSHOPS
description: Workshops, Crafts Students League/

title: EXCERPTS FROM REPORT AND COMMENTS ON COMPANY'S INQUIRY
description: Following are excerpts from the report by the Union Carbide Corporation on the accident at Bhopal, India; from the presentation of the report by Ronald Van Mynen, Union Carbide's director of occupational health and personnel safety, and chairman of the company's Bhopal investigation team, and from Jackson B. Browning, Union Carbide's vice president for health, safety and environmental affairs.

title: CARDIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $136,900 for the latest first quarter and $162,700 for the year-ago first quarter. Shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: NAVRATILOVA BEATS BONDER BY 6-1, 6-1
description: The thought of it must be depressing to the women in the tennis community. Imagine, Martina Navratilova has dominated the tour for two years, winning 74 consecutive matches at one point last year, and she couldn't see. Well, not as clearly as she would have liked to, anyway, she said.

title: AMERICAN PHYSICIANS SERVICE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $32,838 for the quarter and $232,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $108,113 for the quarter and $204,176 for the year.

title: Books: After the Horror
description: THE FIFTH SON. By Elie Wiesel. Translated from the French by Marion Wiesel. 220 pages. Summit Books. $15.95. THE story that Elie Wiesel tells in his latest novel, ''The Fifth Son,'' would seem to be about the generation of Holocaust survivors' children, the offspring of his own tortured generation, the one that left the extermination camps with no belongings other than the intolerably burdensome luggage of remembrance. It would seem to be about this new generation, born into a different world, but it is not altogether so.

title: ITT Makes Sale To Southern Bell
description: The ITT Corporation said that it had sold two of its System 12 signal-transfer point switches to Southern Bell, a unit of the BellSouth Corporation.

title: NAVY FACES SHORTAGE OF OFFICERS TO RUN SUBMARINES
description: In the midst of a major submarine construction program, the Navy is facing a worsening shortage of officers trained to run its nuclear-powered submarines, service officials say.

title: ASA LTD reports earnings for As of Feb 28
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: A SHOW TO LEARN ABOUT DEER
description: If you would like to learn more about

title: Market Place;   Taking a Look At Oil Stocks
description: -related stocks have benefited lately from takeover speculation and corporate restructuring plans, along with increases in the spot-market price for oil.

title: UNUSUAL POLITICAL HARMONY FOR BACH'S 300TH
description: The music of Johann Sebastian Bach will leap across the world today when his ''St. Matthew Passion'' is broadcast from Leipzig and into homes throughout the United States and East Germany. Today is the 300th anniversary of Bach's birth, and the public radio networks of both countries are celebrating with an unusual harmony befitting the occasion.

title: DEATH PENALTY AND HALT TO RUNOFF VOTE ADVANCE
description: Restoration of the death penalty and an end to New York City's runoff primary elections were voted in separate houses of the Legislature today.

title: OPERA: 'BORIS' IN JERSEY
description: The New Jersey State Opera has specialized in the standard repertory, predominantly Italian, and in the production style that is sometimes derisively called ''instant opera'' - that is, opera put together with minimal rehearsal and only rudimentary provision for the visual and physical aspects of the presentation.

title: Pan Am's Negotiator No Stranger to Strikes
description: C. Raymond Grebey Jr. is no stranger to tense labor negotiations. As head of major league baseball's Player Relations Committee, he represented team owners in the bitter 50- day strike in the summer of 1981.

title: CONTRACEPTIVES:WOMEN'S CHOICES
description: The distilled wisdom of two and a half decades of research on safety and effectiveness in contraception comes to this: A woman should start with the pill, use it about four years to get the maximum protection of the pill's progestin against cancer, have all the children she desires by her mid-20's and then persuade her husband to have a vasectomy. But for the estimated 36 million American women who, this year, will want to avoid pregnancy, life is unlikely to permit a progression this tidy.

title: E.S.M. Failure Prompts Study The Government Accounting
description: Standards Board yesterday announced plans to study the accounting and reporting standards for repurchase and reverse repurchase agreements. The move was prompted by

title: That 'Last Chance' in the Middle East
description: In the high-stakes diplomacy of the Middle East, the hardest thing is to stand alert while doing nothing. For a change, the United States is doing that very well.

title: LACK OF FUNDS AND FACTIONALISM HURT DEMOCRATS, LABOR CHIEF SAYS
description: The Democratic Party is chronically underfinanced and must shoulder the blame for its current troubles, including its defeat last fall in the Presidential election, Lane Kirkland, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, says.

title: G.M. CUTS SMALL-CAR LOAN RATES
description: The General Motors Corporation, which has watched its share of the domestic automobile market dwindle in recent weeks, said today that it would offer cut- rate financing for some of its small models.

title: Chinese Grain Exports
description: Chinese grain exports in 1985 should rise threefold from last year's level to 5 million metric tons, the International Wheat Council said today. It cited China's bumper crops in 1983-84.

title: SHARPEVILLE, 25 YEARS LATER, RECALLS A FATEFUL DAY
description: They remember it like this: They had gone to the police station to protest the laws that require blacks in South Africa to carry passes that determine where they may live. They had not, the survivors now say, expected bloodshed.

title:
HOW SOON WILL GORBACHEV HAVE REAL CLOUT?;

GIVE HIM 6 MONTHS
description: By all indications, the struggle for power against Mikhail S. Gorbachev is essentially over. As a consequence, the United States does not have the luxury of waiting three or four years to think about Mr. Gorbachev's foreign policy strategy and what to do about it.

title: THE BUNGALOW, FROM RAJ TO CALIFORNIA
description: ANYONE who watched ''The Jewel in the Crown,'' or has seen David Lean's film version of E.M. Forster's ''A Passage to India,'' has no doubt observed that the bungalow originated in India - not in southern California. The name itself gives it away, from the Hindustani word ''bangla,'' meaning ''of Bengal.''

title: Market Off Despite Merger Rumors
description: Takeover speculation drove a number of stocks higher on Wall Street yesterday, but the disappointing outlook for corporate profits tempered investor enthusiasm and caused the overall market to end lower.

title: Chronology of Ohio Banking Crisis
description: March 4: A court orders E.S.M. Government Securities Inc., a securities dealer based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., put into receivership amid allegations of fraud.

title: OHIO SAY BANK DANGER IN '82
description: State banking regulators expressed concern as early as September 1982 about the unusually large transactions that the Home State Savings Bank engaged in with E.S.M. Government Securities Inc., according to current and former Ohio banking officials.

title: Italian Chamber of Deputies Ratifies Accord With Church
description: The Italian Chamber of Deputies ratified a revised concordat tonight regulating church-state relations that ends Roman Catholicism's status as the state religion.

title: 9,000-YEAR-OLD OBJECTS TO BE SOLD AT ISRAEL MUSEUM
description: The Israel Museum in Jerusalem yesterday said that it would place on view next week a cache of 9,000-year- old objects and textiles, among them what scholars believe to be the oldest painted stone mask and the earliest piece of woven cloth.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The San Diego Chargers have signed

title: MILKY FINISHES GIVE AN AUTHENTIC LOOK
description: THERE was a time not too long ago when even those who should have known better thought that getting down to the wood and applying a clear finish was the ultimate in achieving the ''Early American'' look. Thus many old original paint finishes have disappeared in the stripping bath.

title: Debt Issues
description: Hasbro Bradley Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $60 million offering of senior convertible debentures, due 2010, and for an offering of 2.25 million common shares, through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: PRESIDENT SELECTS BROCK TO SUCCEED DONOVAN AT LABOR
description: Bill Brock, a former Republican Senator who has served as United States Trade Representative since 1981, was picked by President Reagan today to replace Raymond J. Donovan as Secretary of Labor.

title: Sinatra Plans Sale Of Casino Stock
description: Frank Sinatra plans to sell 675,000 shares of Golden Nugget Inc., or nearly 2 percent of the company's common stock outstanding, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: BHOPAL IS STILL A MYSTERY
description: At their news conference today to issue a report on what happened in the Bhopal accident last December, senior officials of the Union Carbide Corporation provided detailed and highly technical information on operations at the plant but were unable to answer some of the most important questions about the cause of the disaster.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I prefer to walk with the church rather than to walk alone with my theology.'' - The Rev. Leonardo Boff, responding to criticism from the Vatican. (A18:4.)

title: Transactions
description: Reassigned to minor-league complex: Porfi Altamirano, Kelly Faulk, Bert Bradley, Mark Silva and Kevin Hickey, pitchers; Bobby Johnson and Mike O'Berry, catchers, and Juan Bonilla, infielder. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Cut Lester Strode, non-roster pitcher.

title: CRAFTING BOATS, BANJOS AND IRREPRESSIBLE STORIES
description: Sam Hunt lives alone in a cluttered cedar-shingle house by a small stand of trees on the edge of the great natural preserve known as the Pine Barrens.

title: BELGIAN PARLIAMENT BACKS DEPLOYMENT OF MISSILES
description: The Belgian Parliament approved the deployment of cruise missiles today after an all-night debate, and NATO officials said the decision should push the Dutch Government to do the same.

title: Reagan Begins Using A Second Hearing Aid
description: President Reagan, who has worn a hearing aid in his right ear for the last 18 months, has begun using a similar device in his left ear ''to achieve balance,'' Dr. T. Burton Smith, the White House physician, said today.

title: South Africa Puts Wall On Zimbabwe Border
description: South Africa is building an experimental electrified wall along a nine-mile stretch of its border with Zimbabwe, Defense Minister Magnus Malan told Parliament Tuesday.

title: Flower People
description: ''Isn't that your cyclamen?'' we heard a man, obviously her husband, say to a woman, obviously his wife. They were standing in front of a display at the New York Flower Show, and no, it was not her cyclamen.

title: EXPERIENCED POLITICIAN FOR LABOR POST
description: Unlike Raymond J. Donovan, who was virtually unknown in political circles here before being named by President Reagan as Secretary of Labor, Bill Brock has been making headlines for almost two decades as part of the Washington establishment that seems to float effortlessly from one Administration to another.

title: THE DANCE: POSIN
description: MOST of the right ingredients were present in Kathryn Posin's ''Hard Steps,'' performed by the Kathryn Posin Dance Company on Saturday at the Joyce Theater. There was an affecting theme of alienating loneliness, rendered by Miss Posin's typically fine dancers. The piece was set to interesting music by Paul Winter, Tina Turner, the Cars and A. Marcello in a balance of driving and contemplative sound. And there was some stylish, chillingly disaffected and hard-driving dancing from the performers. What was missing in this calculated-looking new work was choreographic spirit and commitment.

title: HOW GAMES GREW IN U.S. HISTORY
description: -jongg to Monopoly, tiddlywinks to Trivial Pursuit, the challenges and rewards associated with playing games have traditionally appealed to people. An exhibition called ''Games New Yorkers Play,'' at the Museum of the City of New York, traces the history and the artistry of popular board games from the 19th century to the present.

title: LEAVING OFFICE? DO NOT PASS GO
description: On first thought, it would seem that closing a Senate office would be a relatively easy task: just clean out the desk drawers, throw out the trash, vacuum if you have the time and, last one out, turn off the lights.

title: INSIDER REPORTS
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: Advertising;   Controlling Production Expenses
description: ''PRODUCTION costs are the biggest single problem in advertising today,'' said Jay Schulberg, the new creative director of Ogilvy & Mather, in a most uncompromising statement.

title: HERS
description: LAST spring we returned from a year away to find that the forest across the road from our home had been more or less razed. Two-hundred-year-old oak and spruce no longer existed. Trees had been felled, smashing smaller trees, and then inexplicably left there. It looked less like the mindless, sloppy logging job it was than like the aftermath of a particularly mean and capricious tornado, and even our neighbor - a professional bulldozer man who believes that nature exists to be tamed into septic fields - was appalled.

title: Revolutionary
description: Legislation is before Congress to authorize the construction of a memorial to the estimated 5,000 blacks who fought in the Revolutionary War. The memorial would be built in Constitution Gardens, a piece of Federal property a block from Constitution Hall and within view of the Lincoln Memorial, according to Maurice A. Barboza, who helped organize the Black Revolutionary War Patriots Foundation to raise funds for the project.

title: BANKERS TO DISCUSS PHILIPPINES
description: Bankers from around the world will meet in New York today to discuss a Saudi bank's refusal to join them in rescheduling the Philippines' foreign debt. Bankers said the refusal jeopardized both the rescheduling agreement and fresh credits from the International Monetary Fund.

title: PHOTO EXHIBIT OF SWISS DESIGN
description: AN exhibition of the work of the Swiss architect Mario Campi opens Tuesday in Avery Hall at the Columbia University Graduate School of Architecture and Planning. The 70 black- and-white photographs and the architectural drawings illustrate 10 of the architect's buildings, including five houses, in Ticino, an Italian-speaking canton of Switzerland. The undecorated buildings - many with classical forms, such as columns and pediments, that are reduced to their barest simplicity - are examples of the increasingly influential, neo-rationalist school of architecture originating in northern Italy and practiced since the early 1970's in this area of Switzerland.

title: KNICKS BEATEN
description: ''That's life in the N.B.A.,'' Stan Albeck likes to say. And perhaps he's right. One night, the Nets are being devoured by the Milwaukee Bucks. The next, they're crushing the hottest team in the league.

title: JURY EMPANELED FOR EMIGRES' TRIAL ON SPY CHARGES
description: A jury was empaneled today for the espionage trial of two Russian emigres after a screening process in which questions of the influence of pretrial publicity were overshadowed by questions about the right of immigrants to be vocally critical of America.

title: HITLER YACHT STIRS FIGHT
description: A town official said this week he would fight ''tooth and nail'' plans by a local developer to turn Adolf Hitler's yacht into a museum in Plymouth, where the Pilgrims landed in the Mayflower.

title: BRENNER COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
CURRENCY MARKETS ;   Gold Falls, Dollar Rises In Day of Calm Trading
description: The dollar recovered yesterday, and gold prices sagged. Trading was quiet and nervous after one of the currency markets' most volatile days in the last decade.

title: 2 DETECTIVE SERIES HAVE PREMIERES
description: THE darting of detectives onto the television schedule shows no signs of abating. Tonight at 9:05 on WNET/Channel 13's ''Mystery!'' series, English literature's biggest know-it-all is being resurrected once again in a new Granada TV adaptation of ''The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes.'' And at 9 o'clock on ABC, a new weekly series entitled ''Eye to Eye,'' stars Charles Durning and Stephanie Faracy as still another unlikely pair of private investigators, these inspired by the characters Art Carney and Lily Tomlin played in a movie called ''The Late Show.''

title: Gulf Applied Names Geneen Harold S. Geneen, chairman
description: emeritus of the ITT Corporation, has been named a director

title: RURAL SOUTHERN TOWNS FIND MANUFACTURING BOOM FADING
description: What used to be the Melville Shoe factory now sits empty and abandoned on a bluff above the little mountain town of Hot Springs, N.C. Until last summer, when the plant shut down, it employed 435 workers and had a weekly payroll of nearly $100,000.

title: CHEMICAL TIE TO CANCER HINTED
description: Scientists plan a formal review of animal studies indicating a possible link between cancer and a chemical that is used in aerosol cans and left in minuscule portions in decaffeinated coffee, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
Vienna or Bust
description: The Inter-American Development Bank, the Washington-

title: C.D., FUND RATES RISE
description: The compound yields of money market funds advanced strongly, for the second consecutive week, in the seven days ended yesterday. Banks' money market yields remained steady, and yields on six-month certificates of deposit rose for the fourth week in a row.

title: HEAD OF F.C.C. INDICATES NO BAR TO ABC MERGER
description: Mark S. Fowler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, today told a Senate panel that he has no objection to the recently proposed merger of the American Broadcasting Companies and Capital Cities Communications as long as standard F.C.C. procedures are followed.

title: UNITED FIRE & CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Operating loss c-After capital losses of $143,348. d-Net loss after a capital loss of $84,502. e-Operating earnings f-After a capital gain of $1,247,574. g-Net income after a capital gain of $95,511.

title: PLENUM PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter and year revenue included gains of $172,615 and $186,650, respectively from sales of marketable securities. The year-earlier periods' revenue included gains of $80,151 for the quarter and $1,012,793 for the year from sales of marketable securities.

title: Baker Planning Study Of Currency Markets
description: In the Administration's strongest indication of concern to date over the behavior of the dollar, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said today that ''I think we will want to take a look'' at ways to remodel the world's currency markets.

title: KNOWN FOR METAL SCULPTURES
description: Jose de Rivera, an artist whose exquisite metal sculptures have been displayed in museums and public spaces across the United States for 30 years, died Tuesday at Lennox Hill Hospital from complications of a stroke that he suffered five weeks ago. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Polish Gang Leader Seized
description: Zdzislaw Najmrodzki, Poland's most wanted criminal and leader of a gang that stole goods worth $1.6 million, has been recaptured after his sixth prison escape 50 days ago, the official press agency said today. Mr. Najmrodzki, who faces up to 25 years imprisonment, led a gang that robbed luxury apartments and hard currency shops.

title: AMERICAN CONTROLLED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes after-tax charge of $600,000 reflecting previously announced change in inventory accounting to LIFO method. c-Includes gain of $1.9 million, or 4 cents a share, for change in accounting for inventory to LIFO method, a gain of $13.8 million, or 32 cents a share, primarily from the sale of the American Beauty Pasta division, and an $8.6 million writedown related to barge transportation and other businesses d-Includes gain of $2.8 million, or 6 cents a share, on sale of Stokely-Van Camp stock.

title: INMATES' PLEA ON LETHAL DRUG REJECTED
description: The Supreme Court ruled 9 to 0 today that the Food and Drug Administration's refusal to investigate the drugs used to carry out executions by lethal injection may not be challenged in court. As a general rule, the Court said, a Federal agency's decision not to take a particular enforcement action is beyond the scrutiny of the courts.

title: MURDERER ELECTROCUTED IN GEORGIA SAID HIS RACE 'WAS AGAINST HIM'
description: John Young, saying ''being born black'' was against him, was executed in Georgia's electric chair early today for killing three elderly people in a drug-induced robbery rampage in 1974.

title: AIRLINES DISPUTE COMPUTER SYSTEMS' FAIRNESS
description: Officers of medium-size airlines charged Tuesday that computerized airline reservation systems continued to steer passengers toward flights of the airlines that ran the computers.

title: Dole Reports G.O.P. Senators Will Meet Reagan on Budget
description: The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, said today that he and other Republicans would meet with President Reagan this week to begin negotiations on the budget.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   On Truffles and Truces
description: Officially, it was billed as the

title: Familiar Stranger In Central Park
description: A robin stopped in its tracks, and so did about a dozen joggers. They all wore that curious, half-cocked look of someone who has just seen a rare butterfly float past.

title: Letter: On 'Greenmail' ;   Fending Off Unwelcome Raiders
description: To the Editor:

title: A Museum for Touching
description: Awakening from hibernation, the

title: RALPH F. COLIN, 84, A LEADER OF ART DEALERS ORGANIZATION
description: Ralph F. Colin, administrative vice president and counsel to the Art Dealers Association of America, which he organized in 1962, and known for the collection of 20th-century art that he formed with his wife, died in London Tuesday. He was 84 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 21, 1985

title: Wake-Up Calls
description: Ken Landreaux, who hit only .251 last season after the Dodgers had given him a four-year contract, reflects on the Landreaux-is-gone trade talk that came out of Los Angeles this winter: ''Maybe they were just trying to wake me up. It served its purpose. I'm definitely awake.''

title: CUOMO'S BUDGET ROAD SHOW PACKS HOUSE AT A WAY STOP
description: Snow still blankets the fields here, but people were at the airport with signs - ''Owl's Head N.Y. Says Hello to Gov. Cuomo,'' said one. A cold west wind blew, but they waited outside St. Joseph's School anyway. And a brass band in red and white uniforms played on.

title: SMALL TALK
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: JAZZ:PRESERVATION HALL
description: THE annual visit of the Preservation Hall Jazz Band of New Orleans has taken on the hallmarks of a ritual and, like any ritual, it stays very close to an established format.

title: AGRICULTURE DEPT. EASES LOAN RULES
description: The Agriculture Department, in an attempt to liberalize and speed up procedures for guaranteeing loans to debt-ridden farmers, announced changes today in its $650 million farm credit program.

title: HUNT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
HOUSE PANEL JOLTS REAGAN'S MX PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration's drive for 21 additional MX missiles was jolted today when the House Appropriations Committee voted narrowly against a resolution to release $1.5 billion to buy them.

title: THE DANCE: 'AG NATURE'
description: IT was all in her head. No, not

title: Chophouseclassics on West 36th St.
description: One hundred years ago, a celebrated theatrical figure named Albert Keen took over a private men's club on West 36th Street and opened a chophouse that carried his name. It became well known for its gregarious, masculine atmosphere and fist-size mutton chops. In the early decades of this century, gentlemen made a habit of enjoying a good pipe and glass of port after dinner in front of one of the many fireplaces in the rambling, two-story restaurant. The ''Pipe Club,'' as it was called, included such luminaries as Theodore Roosevelt, Albert Einstein, J. P. Morgan and Babe Ruth.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Interest Rates Move Down;    Money Falls $2.1 Billion
description: Short- and long-term interest rates fell yesterday as traders were encouraged by signs of slower than expected growth in the economy and the nation's money supply.

title: BALLET: ON SOCIAL DANCING
description: ''Dance Through Time,'' which opened on Wednesday at the Theater of the Riverside Church, billed itself, with an ominous hint of pedantry, as covering ''five centuries of social dance.'' But it was a spring romp of a show, filled with lively, evocative dancing, costumes and wigs and comic conversation that had the audience chuckling, murmuring nostalgically and even calling out comments.

title: WHY CHARITY SHOULD NOT BEGIN IN WASHINGTON
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place ;   Semiconductor Stocks Backed
description: Semiconductor stocks are not for the fainthearted investor. They often display sharp swings, and some companies pay no cash dividends. Lately, the group has suffered from earnings disappointments and curtailed work schedules. Prices of some products, reflecting intense competition from Japan, have collapsed 50 percent since last summer. ''You could say,'' one industry source said yesterday, ''that the group has fallen out of favor.''

title: Celebrating Twain
description: ''What ought to be done to the man who invented the celebrating of anniversaries?'' Mark Twain inquired. ''Mere killing would be too light.''

title: ASTRO-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $78,000 for the quarter and $335,000 for the year and income of $1,374,000 for the year from the sale of stock. c-Including a gain of $164,000 from discontinued operations.

title: TALL IS NOT HIGH
description: PARIS The laws of supply and demand

title: COMCAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ALBANY MOVING TO HELP AGED PAY FOR DRUGS
description: Programs that would help needy elderly people in New York State pay for prescription drugs have been proposed by Governor Cuomo and key Democrats in the Assembly and the Senate.

title: DR. LEONARD S. COTTRELL JR., 85, PSYCHOLOGIST AND PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Leonard Slater Cottrell Jr., a social psychologist who specialized in research on marriage and the family, died Wednesday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 85 years old.

title: A FIRM ON COMEX IS CLOSED
description: The soaring price of gold on Tuesday brought to grief three professional traders who held short positions in the gold options market. As a result, the Volume Investors Corporation, a member firm of the New York Commodities Exchange responsible for handling their trades, found itself in receivership yesterday.

title: PEOPLE
AN INDEPENDENT COURSE SEEN FOR DOME CANADA
description: In a move that may signal a gradual dissociation of the two companies, Dome Canada Ltd., the oil and gas company that is 48 percent owned by Dome Petroleum Ltd., has named H. Earl Joudrie president and chief executive officer.

title: PHILHARMONIC: KUBELIK AND BACH
description: How should a symphony orchestra go about celebrating the 300th birthday of Bach, all of whose music was composed with a different sound in mind than modern instruments can produce? The New York Philharmonic faced the problem last night by turning the celebration over to a guest conductor, Rafael Kubelik, who led a concert of old-fashioned Bach that simply ignored most of the historical and stylistic issues. That was probably wise of him, since Mr. Kubelik is not known as a Bach specialist but as an honest and sincere musician who puts his stamp of sturdiness and warmth on every piece he conducts.

title: FLEET OF FOOT AND METAL DETECTOR
description: Security is causing a lot of problems these days for the messengers of this city.

title: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: b-After tax credits of $407,000 for the quarter and $1,416,000 for the year. c-After a gain of $663,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. d-After a tax credit of $48,000 for the quarter and $733,000 for the year. The previous year's net includes a pre-tax gain of $348,000 from the disposal of certain operations. The latest quarter had 12 weeks compared with 13 weeks for the period a year ago.

title: 'I Want Taxes Raised'
description: To the Editor:

title: TECHNICAL TAPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results include pre-tax writedowns of $1,639,000 in the latest quarter and year and $502,000 in the 1983 quarter and year in connection with the company's oil and gas drilling activities. The latest year net also includes a DISC tax credit of $592,000.

title: LAG IN RAIL SAFETY IS CRITICIZED
description: The Government should ''get off the siding'' and impose Federal regulations, under consideration for more than a year, that would prohibit the use of alcohol or drugs by railroad crews while at work, a top Federal safety official said today.

title: NICARAGUAN EX-REBEL IS ACCUSED OF ROLE IN SALVADOR DEATH SQUADS
description: A former top official of the Salvadoran Government charged today that a man who was a senior officer in the largest United States-backed Nicaraguan rebel group ''played a key role'' in organizing and training El Salvador's death squads.

title: Antique Auction
description: The Bronx County Historical Society will hold its annual antique and collectible auction on Sunday at 1 P.M. at the Gillet Auditorium, Gate 6, Lehman College, Goulden Avenue and Bedford Park Boulevard.

title: JUSTICE FOR ONE
description: On Oct. 21, 1971, a young widow

title: AFA PROTECTIVE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: SPRING arrived on the calendar

title: Afghans Protest Soviet Presence
description: Yesterday marked the New Year in Afghanistan, but there was little celebration at Dag Hammarskjold Plaza. More than 200 people gathered there to condemn the December 1979 Soviet military intervention in their country.

title: The CBS Protest
description: Officials of CBS News underscored their protest of the killing of two free- lance television crewmen yesterday by canceling plans for weeklong television programming from Israel before Easter.

title: Compooter Browser
description: Nearby at the Library of Congress, the advance of the computer age has not entirely replaced the familiar language of dusty antiquarianism. What the national librarians now refer to as their ''online information retrieval system'' includes an electronic feature that gives a researcher simultaneous access to a half-dozen files; it is called Crossfile Browse.

title: Saturn Bidders Swamp G.M. DETROIT, March 21 (AP) -
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it might

title: ALEXANDER GRANT IS DIGGING IN
description: A not-so- funny thing happened to Alexander Grant & Company, the nation's 11th- largest accounting firm, on its way to the altar to merge with Fox & Company, the nation's 13th-largest.

title: 'Under One Roof,' New Comedy on Channel 4
description: ''Under One Roof,'' the new half- hour situation comedy that starts on Channel 4 tomorrow night at 9:30, is a perfectly innocuous example of the genre, except that the cast is so personable that one wishes it had something to get its teeth into. This is a family of two teen-agers and one mother that has been deserted by the father, who has run off with a 23-year- old woman.

title: ART: THOMAS HART BENTON DISPLAY SEEKS TO REVIVE DEBATE OVER HIS WORK
description: It's been 10 years since the death

title: Ex-U.S. Official Gets Two Years for Bribery
description: The former deputy regional administrator of the Federal General Services Administration was sentenced yesterday to two years in prison and fined $30,000 for taking bribes.

title: FILM: SCHULTZ DIRECTS 'LAST DRAGON'
description: ''Berry Gordy's The Last Dragon'' is a multimedia movie of sorts, designed for those who can't bear the monotony of only one thought or sound or activity at a time. It is crammed with kung-fu, singing, rapping, dancing and video art, and no moment goes by without at least three of these things transpiring simultaneously. Berry Gordy, who is the film's executive producer, and Michael Schultz, the director of ''Car Wash'' and ''Cooley High,'' have attempted to load the film with every imaginable form of contemporary flash. In spite of that, the film's street smarts are minimal.

title: INFOTECH MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CRITICS PICK TOP FILMS FROM A HUGH '85 CROP
description: The number of New York movie openings since the first of the year is up nearly 50 percent over the similar period last year. Because of the volume, some exceptionally good films might tend to get lost in the shuffle. Therefore, the New York Times critics have sifted through the lot and come up with eight choices you might not want to miss.

title: Winans Denies Money Offer Prompted a Column
description: R. Foster Winans, a former Wall Street Journal reporter, denied in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday that the offer of money was one of the reasons that he wrote a particular column. That contradicted a sworn statement that he gave a year ago.

title: Bush Shifts Press Aide And Adds 5 Assistants
description: In a major staff shakeup, Vice President Bush today named a new press secretary and appointed five new assistants.

title: Death by Robot Brings Call for Improved Safety
description: A Michigan man who died last summer was the first worker killed by a robot in this country, and his death suggests the need for new approaches to factory safety, a Federal safety expert said today.

title: 'ANTOINE' REFLECTS ON TRUFFAUT
description: Antoine Doinel is almost 41 years old. Or, rather, Jean-Pierre Leaud is entering middle age. It is difficult to separate the two. Antoine was the sensitive, rebellious boy of 14 immortalized by Fran,cois Truffaut in his first, semiautobiographical film, ''The 400 Blows,'' in 1959. Mr. Leaud played Antoine, giving a heartbreaking and memorable performance.

title: ART: A VIEW OF NEWS MANIPULATION
description: ''Disinformation - The Manufacture of Consent'' is the brainchild of Geno Rodriguez, the director of the Alternative Museum. Mr. Rodriguez, ''angered'' and ''disillusioned'' with his ''peers' seeming lack of interest and/or commitment to geo- political problems,'' wanted to organize a ''meaningful'' and ''controversial'' exhibition that could provide an example of what daring curators could do. His theme is ''disinformation,'' which he defines as ''a technique used by the printed and electronic media in order to create national opinion and dissent.''

title: KIDDIE PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Expanded Playoffs Proposed (AP) - Major league owners formally proposed today that baseball expand its league playoffs from five to seven games and asked for a speedy reply from the players' union.
description: ''We're going to have to make a decision on this soon,'' Lee MacPhail, president of the owners' Player Relations Committee, said.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Finding a tranquil and elegant spot for breakfast in New York is not always easy. Dining rooms in luxury hotels such as the Carlyle, the Mayfair Regent and the Polo restaurant in the Westbury come to mind. A luxurious new choice is the renovated Cafe Pierre in the Pierre Hotel at Fifth Avenue and 61st Street.

title: PAN AM BUOYED BY A UNION'S MOVE TO RETURN
description: Top executives from Pan American World Airways worked yesterday to revive the airline's system further in the wake of a decision by leaders of the Independent Union of Flight Attendants to order their 6,000 members to cross the Transport Workers Union's picket lines and return to work.

title: Cable Officer for Times Co.
description: David K. MacDonald, director of The New York Times Company's cable television system, has been named the company's vice president for cable, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman, announced yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:Four From New York Area Won on Teams in Montreal

title: METS WILL ALLOW JOHNSON A TIGHTER GRIP
description: Dave Johnson won his fight for sticter control over the Mets today when the front office agreed that the manager could veto any commercial or promotional dates for players that might interfere with baseball.

title: CHINA'S POLITICAL FAST TRACK: YOUTH IS ON THE INSIDE
description: While the Soviet Union was marking the transition to a new generation of leadership last week, China used the occasion to show that it, too, is grooming younger, better-educated leaders able to guide the country into the 21st century.

title: 2 MEMBERS OF CBS CREW DIE
description: Hundreds of Israeli soldiers swept into a group of Shiite Moslem villages in southern Lebanon today, killing what the Israelis described as 21 ''terrorists.''

title: OKLAHOMA AND GEORGIA TECH ADVANCE IN N.C.A.A.
description: They dominated with a combination of intimidating big men and a wily, street- wise point guard. But they were not Georgetown.

title: ART: WHITNEY PRESENTS ITS BIENNIAL EXHIBITION
description: The 1985 Biennial has duly arrived at the Whitney Museum, though not all of it is completely installed at the time of this writing, and it occupies the whole of the second and fourth floors, together with the Lobby Gallery, the Lower Gallery and the Whitney's second-floor screening room. Painting, sculpture and photography, as well as a large and gaudy environmental installation by Kenny Scharf, make up the bulk of the Biennial, but there is also an elaborate and ambitious program of film and video. There is, furthermore, a noise-piece, by Liz Phillips, that is activated by sensors on the roof and broadcast by four loudspeakers in the sculpture garden. The show can be seen and heard through June 9, except for the part on the second floor, which closes on June 2.

title: JAPANESE DESIGNERS LOWERS HOCK QUOTIENT
description: The Japanese designers who disturbed the Western world with their wild, barbaric clothes just a few years ago offered another kind of surprise today as the fall ready-to-wear openings got under way. They have proved themselves adaptable. When the brutal look did not take over, they changed their tune. Many of their designs are no longer shocking.

title: STUARTS DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: The company said all results are pro-forma and it went public in June 1984.

title: H.H. Robertson
description: The H.H. Robertson Company said it had filed suit in United States District Court in Pittsburgh seeking to prevent a shareholder group led by the Belzberg family of Canada from acquiring additional stock in the company or gaining seats on its board.

title: 'NOTHING TO TALK ABOUT' AFTER FIRST DAY BACK
description: For all the furor over Ohio banking, Bunies Stephens was greeted in the usual manner when he entered the Century Savings Bank's Oakley branch here at 11:45 this morning, as one of only two customers at its three teller windows. ''How're you doing today?'' called Amy Whited, one of the tellers. ''Never bad,'' Mr. Stephens replied, as he made a small withdrawal.

title: LANGER BIOMECHANICS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
WINNEBAGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
description: The latest six-month period consists of 27 weeks compared with 26 weeks a year ago.

title: Heavenly Jazz Series
description: The jazz cornettist Ruby Braff will perform with the Scott Hamilton Quintet as part of the Heavenly Jazz series on Sunday at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street (874-5210 ). Showtime is 5 P.M. and tickets are $7.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC ISSUES

description: Two musicians carrying instruments greeted each other in front of the Juilliard School at Lincoln Center Plaza yesterday morning.

description: President Reagan tonight opposed any extension of a special unemployment compensation program that is due to expire at the end of this month.

description: The Mesa Petroleum Company filed a lawsuit today against the Unocal Corporation and its chairman, Fred L. Hartley, contending that Unocal had used ''coercion and intimidation'' against the Security Pacific National Bank in an attempt to interfere with business arrangements between Mesa and the bank.

title: Germans of War Era Gone, Reagan Asserts
description: President Reagan, asked tonight why he had decided against visiting the site of a Nazi concentration camp during his visit to West Germany in May, said that few Germans who were adults during World War II and took part in it were alive today.

title: Hearst Picks Publisher For Town & Country
description: Frederick W. Jackson 3d, who joined Hearst Magazine's Town & Country magazine last July as associate publisher and ad director, has been named its publisher, replacing Charles J. Kennedy, who died New Year's Eve.

title: 2 CBS NEWSMEN ARE SLAIN IN LEBANON BY ISRAELI TROOPS
description: An Israeli tank shelled a group of journalists in southern Lebanon today, killing a cameraman and a soundman working for CBS News and wounding several other people.

title: BROADWAY ;   Lerner and Carr are conjuring up My Man Godfrey.'
description: Put together Alan Jay Lerner and Allan Carr, add a few ingredients like a director and a couple of stars, bake for seven or eight months and the confection that emerges should be ''My Man Godfrey,'' a musical comedy based on the 1936 film classic.

title: Lonnie Smith in Scuffle
description: Lonnie Smith , the St. Louis Cardinal outfielder, was involved in an altercation with umpires after being ejected from an exhibition game against the Boston Red Sox on Wednesday. Smith was ejected in the ninth inning after arguing with

title: Special Aide Weighed In Furor on Chief Judge
description: The State Commission on Judicial Tenure and Discipline may hire a ''special assistant'' to deal with the case of the Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court and allegations that he has improper ties to organized crime.

title: Statement Suppressed In Case on Spy Photos
description: A judge today threw out a statement by a Navy intelligence analyst admitting that, without authorization, he had disclosed to a British military journal three classified photographs of Soviet ships under construction.

description: b-After nonrecurring merger costs of approximately $18.1 million, or 21 cents a share.

description: * Skyr Ski Apparel to Janklow Bender.

title: ISRAELIS OFFER LITTLE INSIGHT INTO THE 21 SLAIN 'TERRORISTS'
description: An Israeli Army spokesman said tonight that he could not provide any definitive information on the identities of 21 ''terrorists'' reported slain today in an armored sweep in southern Lebanon.

title: Dominelli Pleads Guilty
description: J. David Dominelli and an associate pleaded guilty today to Federal charges stemming from the collapse of Mr. Dominelli's investment empire last year, formalizing a plea bargain agreement reached earlier this month. Mr, Dominelli pleaded guilty to two counts of mail fraud, one count of bankruptcy fraud and one count of income tax evasion. He faces 20 years in prison and $107,000 in fines.

title: HEAD OF ACTING CLAN WAS 77
description: Sir Michael Redgrave, one of Britain's preeminent stage actors and a leading film star since his hero's role in Alfred Hitchcock's 1938 classic ''The Lady Vanishes,'' died yesterday, a day after his 77th birthday.

title: U.S. TO PUBLICIZE DRUG SMUGGLERS
description: The United States Customs Service announced plans today to make public lists of people who are caught smuggling small amounts of illegal drugs into the country but are not arrested or prosecuted.

title: Constance Ernst Bessie, 67, Letters Editor at Newsweek
description: Constance Ernst Bessie, the editor of the letters column in Newsweek magazine and for many years a producer and director in radio, television and on the stage, died of cancer Tuesday at the New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Tampon-Maker Offered Trade on Damage Award
description: A Federal district judge offered today to set aside part or all of a $10 million punitive damage award in a toxic shock case if International Playtex Inc. altered or stopped selling its tampons.

title: VISIT RESULTS IN A VIRUS SEARCH IN LYMPH CANCERS
description: Doctors are investigating the possibility that a virus caused lymph gland cancers in four people in three states within 11 months after a visit by a South African woman infected by the virus, researchers said today.

description: Despite President Reagan's defense of his Pentagon budget tonight, pressures are mounting on him to decide whether to continue to hold his ground or to begin forging a compromise budget package with Senate Republican leaders.

title: Clark Center Reception
description: Clark Center for the Performing Arts, which has nurtured and developed black and avant-garde choreographers for 26 years, will celebrate the start of construction of its home on Theater Row with a benefit ''champagne and cinderblocks'' party and performance tomorrow at the new center, 450 West 42d Street.

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Including tax credits of $135,000 for the quarter and $725,000 for the 9 months and a gain of $373,000 for the 9 months from the sale of real estate. c-Including tax credits of $148,000 for the quarter and $495,000 for the 9 months.

title: DYNAMICS' FUGITIVE ACCUSER
description: For more than a year, a steady stream of Federal investigators has sought audience with Panagiotis Takis Veliotis. Though he was first viewed with skepticism, many visitors to his villa in Ekali, this city's richest suburb, have now come to believe that he holds evidence of vast corruption in the United States defense industry.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Robert H. Helmick , a lawyer from Des Moines, was formally named president of the United States Olympic Committee yesterday, succeeding the late John B. Kelly Jr. . . .
