title: Greece to Investigate Political-Spying Charge
description: The Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou announced today that technical experts would examine the election headquarters of the opposition New Democracy Party after it had complained that its telephones were being tapped.

title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
4 Charged in Burning Of the Lendl Mansion
description: The Greenwich police yesterday charged two men, a woman and a 15- year-old girl in connection with the March 3 fire that destroyed an 81- year-old vacant mansion belonging to Ivan Lendl, the tennis star.

title: THE JOINT CHIEFS SHOULD REMAIN JOINT
description: The current effort to reorganize the Joint Chiefs of Staff and greatly increase the powers of the Chairman is a little like the latest version of Trivial Pursuit: generally esoteric, uninformed by history and very trendy. It also raises the possibility that we may soon see a military officer endowed with powers unprecedented in our history.

title: Victory in the Bronx, Toasted With Champagne
description: If it had not worked out, executives of the Farberware Corporation would have been in Concordia, Kan., yesterday to announce the construction of a new warehouse.

title: NAVY CHIEF SEES GAIN IN SPACE SHUTTLE FLIGHT
description: A Navy oceanographer who traveled on a space shuttle flight last fall brought back ''some fantastically important'' information that will make it easier for American submarines to hide in the oceans, the Chief of Naval Operations said today.

title: Goldsmith Filing On Zellerbach
description: The British investor Sir James Goldsmith told W.T. Creson, chairman of the board of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, that ''he should not be regarded as a passive investor'' in the San Francisco-based forest product concern, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Sir James, who owns 8.5 percent of Zellerbach's shares outstanding, met with Mr. Creson Tuesday to discuss ''various alternatives thath, in Mr. Goldsmith's view, Zellerbach currently faced,'' the filing said.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Storer Is Expected To Resist Challenge
description: Peter Storer began his career in broadcasting in 1946, as a student at the University of Miami. He worked part time as a control engineer at radio station WGBS, whose call letters are the initials of his father, George B. Storer, who founded what is now Storer Communications Inc.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Old Clothes, New and Old
description: There's nothing new about buying old. People have long sought bargains in flea markets, found beauty in antique stores and paid dearly for reproductions and distressed wood. What's new is new old clothes.

title: Is It Really a Good Idea to Prolong Dying?
description: To the Editor:

title: Depositor Bill Gains on Coast
description: A bill that would enable the state to make a temporary loan to 12,500 depositors of the failed Western Community Money Center of Walnut Creek, Calif., passed the state Senate by a vote of 31 to 4 today.

JUPITER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $401,000 for the quarter and $363,000 for the year and a gain of $2,904,000 for the quarter and year on the sale of discontinued operations.

title: American Who Swam Into Laos Is Released
description: The Government of Laos today freed an American who accidentally crossed into Laotian territory while swimming in the Mekong River last week, according to Thai officials and an associate of the freed man.

title: Credit Card Fraud Case
description: Three Bank of America workers were arrested today in connection with a reported credit-card theft ring operating out of the bank's Southern California credit card center in suburban Pasadena, authorities said. Although this is the third investigation of credit card fraud at the center, it is the first time that Bank of America Credit Card employees have been implicated. Al Joaquin, a Secret Service spokesman, said credit cards and confidential card information on about 10,000 bank customers was stolen and sold.

title: AIR CARGO EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KOCH 'OUTRAGED' BY PROBATION IN BRIBERY
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he was ''outraged,'' ''absolutely shocked'' and ''incensed'' by a Federal judge who gave a probationary sentence, rather than a prison term, to a city sewer inspector who pleaded guilty to soliciting and receiving bribes.

title: They Meet Again
description: Joan Benoit and

title: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, MARCH 22, 1985
description: The Economy

title: GALAXY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: FILM: BRONTOSAURUS STARS IN 'BABY'
description: The top of any list of beloved, cuddly creatures would probably be occupied by puppies, kittens, gerbils, rabbits and maybe even newly hatched chicks, once their sticky fuzz has dried to downy yellow softness. The bottom of the list? Baby garter snakes, tadpoles (which can't be easily cuddled anyway) and, I'm afraid, the man-made, 10-foot-long baby brontosaurus, or ''hatchling,'' that is the centerpiece of the new fantasy-adventure ''Baby . . . Secret of the Lost Legend.''

title: Seaver Stays Humble
description: Tom Seaver was assigned a promotion in the baseball record books yesterday when he was named starting pitcher for the Chicago White Sox's season opener against the Brewers in Milwaukee April 9. It will be the 40- year-old Seaver's 15th opening-day start, breaking a tie with Walter Johnson, the legendary fastballer for the Washington Senators from 1907 through 1927.

title: Zaccaro Puts Off License Hearing
description: John A. Zaccaro has been granted a one-month postponement of a state hearing on his fitness to hold a real- estate license after his plea of guilty to a charge of participating in a real- estate fraud, the New York Secretary of State's office has announced.

title: WHY CHARITY SHOULD NOT BEGIN IN WASHINGTON
description: To the Editor:

title: INACOMP COMPUTER CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $714 million, to $210.08 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: ARGENTINE PRESIDENT IS HONORED
description: President Raul Alfonsin of Argentina said in New York yesterday that the United States cannot expect Latin American nations to share its national security concerns unless they have political democracies of their own to defend.

title: Northeast Utilities
description: The Northeast Utilities Company's stock price dropped 75 cents, to $14.50 a share, in heavy trading yesterday following the company's disclosure that it may have to write off $40 million to $50 million of fuel expenses this year.

title: BACH'S BIRTHDAY CAKE: SOME WEEKEND SLICES
description: H. L. MENCKEN once provided brief verbal descriptions of his favorite composers. Some were rather flowery. Of Haydn, for instance, he wrote: ''A seidel on the table . . . a girl on your knee . . . another and different girl in your heart.'' Or of Johann Strauss: ''Forty couples dancing . . . one by one they slip from the hall . . . sounds of kisses . . . the lights go out.'' But with Bach, he came right to the point. ''Bach - Genesis I, 1,'' he wrote, and let it stand.

title: SERVAMATIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $191,000.

title: Dow Up 2.98 Points As Volume Eases
description: A Government forecast that the economy is growing at a slower pace than experts expected caused trading to slow yesterday on Wall Street, but prices managed to finish slightly higher in a final push.

title: Greek Celebration
description: To commemorate the 164th anniversary of Greek independence from the Ottoman Empire, the Greek Independence Day Parade will march up Fifth Avenue from 61st to 79th Street on Sunday, starting at 1 P.M. Sponsors include the Greek Archdiocese and the Federation of Hellenic Societies of Greater New York. Information: (718) 335-2468.

title: Compushop Inc.
description: Compushop Inc. of Dallas said it had reached a definitive agreement to merge into the Bell Atlantic Corporation in an exchange of one Bell Atlantic share for 14 Compushop shares.

title: Continental Buy
description: Continental Telecom Inc. said it had agreed in principle to acquire Northern Data Systems Inc. It said it would pay $11 per share of Continental Telecom stock to outside shareholders and $7 in stock plus additional payments over the next three years based on performance to founding shareholders and employee shareholders. Northern has 3,200,00 shares outstanding, including 2,250,000 held by inside shareholders.

title: $200 Million State Mortgage Issue
description: The State of New York Mortgage Agency is offering $200 million of revenue bonds, rated Aa by Moody's, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Leopold Tyrmand, 64, Editor Who Emigrated From Poland
description: Leopold Tyrmand, a Polish editor and novelist who wrote for anti-regime newspapers in Poland before emigrating to the United States in 1966, died of a heart attack Tuesday night in Rockford, Ill. He was 64 years old.

title: Rinaldi Topples Jordan
description: The test of will came in the very first game, which lasted 13 minutes and went to deuce seven times. It was the type of game that used to earn Kathy Rinaldi a pat on the back and ''see you later, kid.'' But that was not the case last night when Miss Rinaldi defeated Kathy Jordan in a tournament that will conclude on her birthday and possibly mark her coming of age as a tennis player.

title: REAGAN ASSERTS HE WOULD STUDY SENATE'S BUDGET
description: President Reagan expressed willingness tonight to discuss a compromise with Senate Republican leaders on his 1986 budget. But he rejected any reduction in his proposal for the military.

title: REAGAN SAYS TIME IS RIPE FOR TALKS WITH SOVIET CHIEF
description: President Reagan said tonight that it was ''high time'' that the United States and the Soviet Union held a summit meeting in an effort to improve relations.

title: RESTAURANT ASSOCIATES INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-After tax credits of $91,000 for the quarter and $200,000 for the year.

title: BIG BOARD SHORT INTEREST UP IN MONTH TO A RECORD
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest was up 801,324 shares in the month ended March 15, to a record 250.2 million shares. The previous high was set last month, when short interest totaled 249.4 million shares. The short interest for the period a year earlier totaled 182.7 million shares.

title: First Black Woman Elected To Legislature in Mississippi
description: Alyce Clarke has become the first black woman elected to the Mississippi Legislature, winning a special election to represent a House district here.

title: PUBLISHING: DOING RIGHT BY A BOOK
description: ''Telling Right From Wrong'' by Timothy J. Cooney, the book of moral philosophy that Random House rejected after it learned the author forged a letter of recommendation, will be published this summer by Prometheus Books, a leading publisher of books on philosophy and science.

title: MEMPHIS STATE EDGES EAGLES; GEORGETOWN GAINS
description: The Loyola Ramblers boasted that they were not going to be intimidated, and they were not. And they claimed they were going to prove that a team of free- spirited jump-shooters could challenge imposing Georgetown. They accomplished that, too.

title: No Headline
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 22, 1985 International

title: A JUDY GARLAND SPECIAL ON CHANNEL 13 TONIGHT
description: Surrounded by some puzzling flimflam, the phenomenon that was Judy Garland is brought back to television tonight at 9 on Channel 13 in ''Judy Garland: The Concert Years.'' In segments culled primarily from her 1963- 64 television series, the incomparable star offers 36 songs from her very personal and distinctive repertory, nearly half in their entirety. There is, needless to say, an uncommon abundance of thrilling moments.

title: GTE Study Asks Changes A study commissioned by the
description: GTE Corporation released yesterday indicated that competition among long-distance telephone companies would diminish unless there are changes in

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Denver Nuggets , at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. Dan Issel, who is retiring at the end of this season, is making his last regular-season visit as a Nugget to the region. Issel trails Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Wilt Chamberlain, and Julius Erving in career pro scoring. (Television - Sports Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.

title: K-TRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $160,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net losses.

title: INTERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-Net income. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: ISLANDERS AND DEVILS DEFEATED
description: The Islanders' lack of shooting power, obscured by five victories in their previous six games, caught up to them tonight as the Quebec Nordiques outshot them badly and handed them a 5-1 loss before 15,683 fans at Nassau Coliseum.

title: INDIA SAYS CARBIDE ITSELF IS RESPONSIBLE
description: A senior Government official said today that India was prepared to prove in court in the United States that the Union Carbide Corporation bears direct responsibility for the toxic gas leak at its pesticide plant in Bhopal last year.

title: Walking Contests
description: The New York Walkers Club will sponsor walking contests of 5 and 10 kilometers on Sunday at 10 A.M. in Central Park, at 90th Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: Book Bug Bites Burns
description: Arthur F. Burns, who is retiring as Ambassador to West Germany this spring, is not returning to the United States because he is tired of Bonn or feels burdened by diplomatic duties or because of his age, now 80. The veteran economic adviser to Presidents has told friends he wants to write two books on monetary policy and feels this is the time to get started. All the Ambassador will say about the books is that one will be historical and the other will not.

title: BOYS, 14 and 12, ARRESTED IN FIRE AT A WAREHOUSE
description: Two boys, 12 and 14 years old, were arrested today and accused of setting a warehouse fire that forced more than 200 residents from their homes, authorities said.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Moody's Sees Losses For Mortgage Insurers
description: The mortgage insurance industry, plagued by rising foreclosures and low premiums on many outstanding policies, may face another four years of heavy underwriting losses, according to a report published yesterday by Moody's Investors Service.

title: Ashe Is Honored
description: Arthur Ashe , the current captain of the United States Davis Cup team and a past winner of the Wimbledon and United States Open titles, was named to the International Tennis Hall of Fame yesterday, along with

title: Musical Embassies
description: The State Department has set up

title: NATIONAL HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $782,000 for the quarter and year. The latest year loss includes a $2,100,000 provision for plant closings and start-ups, a gain of $847,000 from the sale of property and a gain of $643,000 from the purchase of its 4 3/4 percent convertible debentures. The prior year loss includes a $1,234,000 gain from the purchase of the 4 3/4 percent convertible debentures.

title: Compooters
description: Congress, having survived transition from the quill pen to the typewriter not too long ago with its record for efficiency unimpaired, is finally edging into the computer age. As with any such radical change, the arrival of the new equipment in those venturesome offices that have requested it is raising questions as well as answering them.

title: By John Gross;
description: INVENTING IVANOV. By Roberta Smoodin. 295 pages. Atheneum. $15.95. Roberta Smoodin's new novel opens with a list of publications - the writings of the late Ivan Ivanov, who died in Los Angeles in 1983. They include a volume of poems, a study of Chekhov and two early novels, all written in Russian, and a number of later novels written in English. One of these, ''Annette,'' we are subsequently told, made Ivanov ''nearly- rich'' - countless readers who had never heard of him before were intrigued by its account of an idyllic love affair between ''an old pedantic professor and his young girl student who dresses as a boy to titillate him.''

title: CARBIDE WORKS TO REOPEN U.S. PLANT
description: A tall crane, construction crews and hundreds of old valves and machinery parts on the ground are evidence that the Union Carbide Corporation is busily preparing to resume making the toxic substance that leaked at its sister plant in India last December.

title: Rolling Stone Parody Is Scheduled for June 25
description: Now that its fourth parody, Penthouse Parody, is ready for distribution on April 1, it is time for TSM Publishing at 226 East 54th Street to start thinking about No. 5.

title: MEDICAL CARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest year results include a loss of $6.7 million for discontinued activities and the expensing of certificate of need development costs of $4.3 million.

title: MISSILE STRENGTH IN SOVIET DISPUTED
description: Senator James A. McClure, Republican of Idaho, and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, have got into a dispute over tactics intended to win support for the MX nuclear missile, according to a staff aide for the Senator.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: It's like a party - you want to invite different kinds of people to make the party exciting,'' said Susan Seidelman, who did exactly that in directing ''Desperately Seeking Susan,'' which opens next Friday. Among those in the large and varied cast Miss Seidelman assembled are a rock star (Madonna), an up-and-coming young Hollywood actress (Rosanna Arquette), key figures from the best recent American independent features (John Lurie and Richard Edson of ''Stranger Than Paradise'' and Anne Carlisle of ''Liquid Sky''), talented stage actors (Laurie Metcalf, Mark Blum, Robert Joy), a comedian (Steven Wright) and assorted others. A taxi driver is played by Rockets Red Glare, who was once a bodyguard for Sid Vicious. And a jail matron is played by Shirley Stoler, whom Miss Seidelman admired in both ''Seven Beauties'' and ''The Honeymoon Killers.''

title: CONCEPT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $51,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $100,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months and tax credits of $136,000 for the quarter and $180,000 for the 6 months.

title: COMPREHENSIVE CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Why Charity Should Not Begin in Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: FILLING OF JOB BY ADAMS IS CHALLENGED BY CUOMO
description: Upset that Attorney General Robert Abrams appointed a special prosecutor without consulting him, Governor Cuomo has raised the possibility of abolishing the job and today told the state's Budget Director to withhold money for it.

title: Rocket Launching Delayed
description: The delayed launching of an Atlas Centaur rocket was postponed again today because of heavy clouds and high winds, and the space agency rescheduled it for Friday.

title: Dutch War Criminal Is Banned by Ireland
description: The Irish Government today barred a millionaire Nazi war criminal, Pieter Menten, from coming to Ireland, where he has owned a country mansion since 1964.

title: RELIABLE LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Donald R. Wright, 78; Was California Justice
description: Donald R. Wright, a retired Chief Justice of the California Supreme Court, died of heart disease today at Huntington Memorial Hospital, hospital officials said. He was 78 years old.

title: BASE TEN SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PLAN FOR MIAMI STADIUM COMPLEX DRAWS FIRE
description: The Miami Dolphins have faced many tough opponents in their 20 seasons, most of them over 200 pounds. Now the organization faces a determined lineup of people like Madeline Kemp, who weighs in at 112, trying to block the franchise's plan to put a 72,000-seat stadium and a high- density office park in their backyard.

title: Senators Urged To Fill U.S. Bench
description: The chief judge of the Federal District Court in Manhattan sent a letter to the state's two Senators yesterday expressing ''urgent concern'' that three openings for judges on the busy court had not yet been filled.

title: WRISTON TRADE POST HELD LIKELY
description: Walter B. Wriston, retired chairman of Citicorp, has emerged as the leading candidate to succeed Bill Brock as United States trade representative, White House and other Government officials said today.

title: EAGLE TELEPHONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
G R I CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Rozier Gains 199 As Bulls Triumph
description: Mike Rozier gained 199 yards on 38 carries and scored four touchdowns as the Jacksonville Bulls edged the Orlando Renegades, 34-31, in overtime tonight.

title: WOOLFOLK IS TRADED TO OILERS
description: The mystery of Butch Woolfolk, who in his three seasons with the Giants went from star running back to benchwarmer, may be solved next fall, but not with the Giants. In a trade that was no surprise, the Giants sent him to the Houston Oilers yesterday for a third-round choice in the National Football League draft April 30.

title: CHARLES A. SIEPMANN, A PROFESSOR AND EARLY CRITIC OF BROADCASTING
description: Charles A. Siepmann, professor emeritus of communications at New York University and one of the early and influential critics of the quality of radio and television broadcasting, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in London. He was 86 years old and also lived in Brookline, Vt.

title: Dow Plans to Buy Some of Its Shares
description: The Dow Chemical Company said it planned to buy about 2.5 million of its common shares on the open market or through negotiated purchases during the remainder of 1985.

title: CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Angicor Ltd., Minneapolis, a maker of medical devices, said it was under investigation for possible violations of Federal statutes related to purported use of ''intellectual proprietary information'' belonging to competitors in the heart valve industry.

title: MINIMAL ERA OF ART AT BARD COLLEGE
description: How many different ways can you make a single straight line into a work of art?

title: Pennzoil Find
description: The Pennzoil Company said its Duval Mining Ltd. subsidiary of Australia had made a gold find at its Pajingo Prospect in northern Queensland, and would resume exploration there soon. The company said assays along a 1,400-foot strike had averaged 0.23 ounce to 45.97 ounces a ton. The company said it had acquired exploration rights covering 2,000 square miles of the region.

title: Dining Out Guide: TriBeCa
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: SLUGGISH 2.1% ECONOMIC GROWTH FORECAST BY U.S. FOR FIRST QUARTER
description: The economy, burdened by intense international competition, is now growing less than half as fast as it did in the final three months of 1984, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Choosing Chairmen For a Campaign
description: Brooklyn Borough President Howard Golden's re-election crew, Committee for a Golden Future, draws on the past for mayoral chairmen: Robert F. Wagner, John V. Lindsay and Abraham D. Beame.

title: POLITBURO BACKS GORBACHEV POLICIES
description: The ruling Politburo, holding its first regular weekly meeting since Mikhail S. Gorbachev became the Soviet leader last week, declared today that it was ready for improved relations with the West.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday MUSIC FOR AN EQUINOX

description: b-Includes $141,294,000 of after-tax dividend income from Du Pont & Co. and $141,352,000 from equity in unremitted earnings of Du Pont. c-Includes $117,130,000 of after-tax dividend income from Du Pont and $96,847,000 from equity in unremitted earnings of Du Pont.

title: FILIBUSTERS, MOM AND APPLE PIE?
description: There are plenty of games played in Washington, from lawmaking to log-rolling, from filibustering to betting on a dark horse.

title: A CONVERSION'S IMPACT ON CLINTON HILL
description: The red brick of the sprawling 1,200-unit Clinton Hill Apartments complex in Brooklyn stands out starkly amid the old converted mansions that line Clinton Avenue just east of Fort Greene Park. But the conversion of the 12-building complex to a co-op has melded more smoothly than many had expected into this rapidly changing section of Brooklyn.

title: On Overtime
description: Well, here we go. St. John's plays Kentucky tonight in the West Regional semifinals, which means that the ultimate, a trip to the Final Four, is only two victories away. And while the Redmen players prepare for more glory, what are their support people doing? Working like Wildcats.

title: BROKERS MORTGAGE SERVICE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Co Hoedeman Films
description: The films of Co Hoedeman, the Oscar Award-winning animator, will be shown tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. and 5:30 at the Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2 at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. Mr. Hoedeman, who will be at the 5:30 presentation, won an Oscar in 1977 for ''The Sand Castle,'' which is included in the 5:30 program. The programs are free with museum admission of $4.50 ($3 for students with identification; $2 for the elderly and free for children under 16 when accompanied by adults). Information: 708-9490.

title: More TV of Any Kind Won't Help Johnny Read
description: To the Editor:

title: Journalists Sport Red To Catch Reagan Eye
description: This city's clothes tend toward black or muted grays, but tonight journalists bedecked with red greeted President Reagan at his news conference.

title: Iraq Reports an Assault On Iranian Lines
description: Iraq said today that its ground forces staged a lightning strike on Iranian lines, seizing enemy positions and killing hundreds of soldiers. Iran said Baghdad's warplanes bombed the border city of Ilam, killing 12 people.

title: Farmer Fined $341,000 In Grain Elevator Raid
description: A farmer who raided a bankrupt grain elevator to take 33,000 bushels of soybeans was in contempt of court and should pay more than $341,000, a Federal judge says.

title: OHLAHOMA AND GEORGIA TECH ADVANCE IN N.C.A.A.
description: With 6 seconds remaining in overtime, Wayman Tisdale's shot hung in the air, then bounced five times on the rim, finally plopping through to give Oklahoma an 86-84 victory over Louisiana Tech tonight.

title: RRANGERS DEFEATED AGAIN BY FLYERS
description: The Rangers arrived in the Spectrum tonight to find a familiar taunting sign, ''1940,'' tacked to the the first balcony. And in a short time the indignities they suffered were heaped almost as high.

title: Bolivia Offers to Accept Church Role in Strike
description: The Government said today that it would accept the mediation of the Roman Catholic Church to end a 14-day general strike, a day after troops and tanks were deployed throughout La Paz to counter social unrest.

title: HOUSE PANEL AGAIN LECTURES STRIP MINE REGULATORS
description: The Office of Surface Mining has made little progress in unsnarling an enforcement program described last year as being in ''virtual collapse,'' officials acknowledged today.

description: b-Net loss.

description: March 22, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SOME THRIFT UNITS REOPENED IN OHIO
description: Several state-insured savings and loan institutions reopened today with no run on deposits such as the runs on other institutions that led to the closing of 71 last Friday.

title: Marchers in Istanbul Protest Sofia's Rules on Ethnic Turks
description: Thousands of people carrying Turkish flags rallied here today to protest Bulgaria's policy on ethnic Turks.

title: GLASSON UP BY 1
description: ''I wouldn't be playing golf here if it weren't for that first knee operation in 1976,'' said Bill Glasson, who kept a one shot lead over Tom Watson after two rounds of the $950,000 Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational.

title: SURGE IS ON TO FORM BETTING SYNDICATES
description: Advertisements like this one might well start springing up at the races, and many racegoers would stand on line to reply:

title: Baseball Adopts Open-Door Policy
description: At hand is a two-page directive, addressed to all major league clubs, from Commissioner Peter Ueberroth and the two league presidents. It is titled ''Club/Media Procedures - 1985,'' and like similar memorandums issued in earlier years each spring by Ueberroth's predecessor, Bowie Kuhn, it notes that baseball's coverage by the press, radio and television is important for the success of the sport, and sets guidelines for the news media's access to players. Not much new in that.

title: Labor's New Communicator As United States Trade Representative, Bill Brock has been resisting pressure for protectionism, much of it from organized labor. Yet when Mr. Brock was nominated on Wednesday as Secretary of Labor, it was the leaders of organized labor who cheered the most. ''We have worked with him in many areas over the years,'' said Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. ''While we have not always agreed, he has earned our respect.''
description: That respect, a tribute to Mr. Brock's ability to get along in Washington, is the best reason to welcome his selection by the President. Another is that it suggests a softening of Mr. Reagan's rigid views on labor issues.

title: OVERLAND EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and year results are after charges of $2.1 million relating to the consolidation and the cost of moving the corporate headquarters from Minneapolis to Indianapolis.

MUSIC: TAYLOR AND SOUNDS
description: A few minutes after 9 Tuesday evening at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation, Joseph Paul Taylor popped open a beer, switched on a tape recorder, sat down, back to the audience, and fiddled with a small television set. The room filled with sounds - shouting sportscasters, gravel-voiced bluesmen, insistent countdowns - woven into an ominous tapestry of overload.

title: NATIONAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
17 BLACKS KILLED BY POLICE GUNFIRE IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The police opened fire on a crowd of up to 4,000 black people near a southeast coastal town today, killing at least 17.

title: Where is Mexico's Pride?
description: The United States is rightly alarmed by evidence that drug traffickers are corrupting Mexico's law enforcement. Why are Mexican officials so reluctant to share that alarm?

title: MEMPHIS STATE EDGES EAGLES; GEORGETOWN GAINS
description: A scramble for a loose ball, the sort of play that had helped make Boston College an overachiever this season, was their undoing tonight.

title: Plan to Slow Ocean Oil Hunt
description: The Interior Department today proposed a slowdown in offshore oil and gas exploration. The plan was immediately criticized by both industry and environmentalists.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. WANTS INFORMATION NETWORK ON WHITE-COLLAR CRIME
description: The Justice Department has informed Congress that it wants to develop a computerized system through which thousands of police agencies can exchange information about white-collar crime.

title: ERAZO ENTERS THE RACE FOR CITY COUNCIL PRESIDENT
description: Joseph R. Erazo, an official in three city administrations, announced his candidacy yesterday for the Democratic nomination for City Council President, saying he wanted to make the Council ''part of the solution, not part of the problem.''

title: JOHN B. LIS
description: John B. Lis, a former Democratic State Assemblyman from the Buffalo area, died of cancer Wednesday at Sisters of Charity Hospital in Buffalo.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think it's high time that we did this.'' - President Reagan, referring to a possible meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the new Soviet leader. (A1:6.)

title: BELLAMY FAULTS CITY ON FACILITIES TO AID HOMELESS MOTHERS
description: More than 600 pregnant women and mothers with newborn babies are being housed in ''decrepit, substandard facilities'' in violation of a commitment by the Human Resources Administration to keep them in hospitals until appropriate housing is found, City Council President Carol Bellamy said yesterday.

title: 30 Charged in Cocaine Case; Total Under Indictment Is 98
description: Thirty more people have been indicted in what the Federal authorities say was a major cocaine smuggling ring, bringing the number charged to 98, it was announced today.

title: MAGIC OF TWO FUNNY IMPROVISERS
description: Inspired comic improvisation is a kind of theatrical magic that seems almost snatched out of thin air. With just a snap of the fingers, Jeanette Collins and Mimi Friedman, the virtuosic comedy duo whose show has become a fixture at the Ballroom Theater, can conjure and animate any one of a dozen miniature worlds.

title: Dinnertime Chat
description: Doug Flutie, who paid a visit to the White House a few months back in the wake of some miracle or other in Miami, made an encore appearance the other night, and darned if the occasion this time wasn't a full-fledged state dinner. Seems the President of Argentina was in town.

title: GAIN MADE BY BLACKS AS MAYORS
description: Last year's elections brought the number of black mayors to 286, with the biggest one-year increase yet recorded, according to a political study group.

title: A TALE OF TWO HOMES
description: DENVER

title: SOVIET DIPLOMAT SHOT DEAD IN NEW DELHI
description: An unidentified gunman on a motorcycle shot and killed a Soviet diplomat as he sat in a car near his embassy today. The assailant and an accomplice escaped.

description: b-Includes $314,000, or 20 cents a share, after-tax nonrecurring loss from the writeoff of previously deferred computer costs. c-Net income

title: MILTOPE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Everett L.Conklin,77; Created Floral Designs
description: Everett Lawson Conklin, a horticulturist and award-winning floral designer, died Tuesday at his home in Rutherford, N.J. He was 77 years old.

title: 22% Drop Reported In Crime on Subways
description: Major subway crime dropped 22 percent last month from the level in the same month a year ago, the transit police announced yesterday.

title: ABC Effort To Improve TV's Image
description: Even before he assumes the title of president of communications/ABC Broadcast Group in June, James E. Duffy will deserve it. He'll be communicating all over the place.

title: DOCTORS CITE EMETIC ABUSE
description: A group of physicians and psychotherapists who specialize in treating young women with the eating disorders anorexia nervosa and bulimia called on the Food and Drug Administration yesterday to ban over-the- counter sales of syrup of ipecac.

title: Boesky Said to Buy A 7% Stake in CBS
description: Ivan F. Boesky, the investor and arbitrager, has acquired a 7 percent to 8 percent stake in CBS Inc., for an estimated $240 million, reliable financial sources said yesterday.

title: System Evil, Shultz Says
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, in his strongest attack to date on South African Government policies, said today that the killing of 17 black demonstrators by the police ''only underlines how evil and unacceptable that system is.''

title: GAPS SEEN IN REPORT ON BHOPAL
description: Chemical industry experts today described the results of the Union Carbide Corporation's investigation of the Bhopal disaster as far from complete but said the company had been severely limited by constraints placed on it by the Government of India.

title: PACIFIC GAMBLE ROBINSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mementoes of women.
description: Historic autographs and manuscripts of famous American women - Betsy Ross, Abigail Adams, Dolly Madison, Mary Todd Lincoln, Barbara Fritchie and Harriet Beecher Stowe - are among the 280 documents from the collection of Elsie O. Sang that will be on view this weekend before their sale next Wednesday at Sotheby's.

title: IN SUBWAYS, A CLEANER CLEAN
description: Standing like sentries along the subway platform at the end of the No. 4 IRT line in the Bronx, five Transit Authority cleaners waited for a train to pull in.

title: Nurse Is Said to Admit Mercy Killing of Woman
description: A nurse admitted she gave an elderly woman a lethal dose of drugs to save the patient ''from further pain and suffering,'' the police said today.

title: VATICAN AND FRIAR: NOT A JUDGEMENT ON NEW THEOLOGY
description: A Vatican decision to condemn the teachings of an exponent of liberation theology grew out of an elaborate process of review that the Roman Catholic Church applies to what it considers to be offenses by parish priests as well as widely-known theologians. And, according to the Vatican's chief spokesman, the statement Wednesday concerning the Rev. Leonardo Boff, a Franciscan priest, should not be viewed as an overall critique of liberation theology, but rather as a specific criticism of Father Boff's views about the structure of the Church.

title: APARTHEID'S SO-CALLED LAW
description: Shame: that is what a white man, a Jew like me, feels while visiting Soweto in South Africa.

title: WHEN NOTHING HAPPENS AND THEY CALL IT NEWS
description: In this city of pomp and ceremony, where politics and stagecraft combine to create shades of illusion and reality, the staged nonevent has become an art form.

title: Sonics Lose Sikma
description: Jack Sikma, the Seattle SuperSonics' high-paid center, said the recurring finger injury that knocked him out of a game against the Golden State Warriors would require surgery that will probably keep him out for the rest of the season. Sikma, who first injured the finger in January, said it had never had a chance to heal properly and that he would undergo ligament surgery when the swelling subsides, in a week or so.

title: RIZZOLI OPENS NEW SHOP
description: Hundreds of book-lovers, authors and notables turned out last night for a champagne reception given in two shifts to mark the opening of the new Rizzoli bookstore at 31 West 57th Street, just around the corner from the showcase Rizzoli bookstore that closed last month after 21 years on Fifth Avenue. Judging from the oohs and aahs, most of the guests liked what they saw.

title: S.E.C. DAYS BURROUGHS OVERSTATED ITS EARNINGS
description: Continuing its efforts to restrain aggressive accounting practices, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had charged the Burroughs Corporation with overstating its earnings from September 1981 to September 1982 by more than $60 million.

title: FILM: LIV ULLMANN AND JEREMY IRONS IN IBSEN'S 'WILD DUCK'
description: In 1897 George Bernard Shaw,

title: Debt Issues
description: Foxmeyer Corp. , a drug wholesale distributor, is issuing $100 million, up from $75 million, of 8 3/4 percent, 25- year convertible subordinated debentures at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers. The debentures are convertible into common stock at $34.16 a share.

title: The Lines Are Very Busy
description: The telephone company cannot seem to get the lines uncrossed at Fremantle International, a television production company at 660 Madison Avenue, near 61st Street.

title: OPTIMISM AMONG FOX EXECUTIVES
description: At 11 A.M. Wednesday, an hour and a half before 20th Century-Fox announced that Rupert Murdoch had bought 50 percent of the company from Marvin Davis, Fox's chairman, Barry Diller, called a staff meeting of his 10 top executives. ''I have very good news for everyone here,'' he said. He paused and added, ''That's a pun which you will now understand. The News Corporation has purchased 50 percent of 20th Century-Fox.''

title: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Six Sugar Plants to Be Sold
description: The Great Western Sugar Company, one of the many trouble spots in the financial empire of the Hunt brothers of Texas, agreed yesterday to sell about half of its processing plants and some of its inventory to Tate & Lyle Inc. for about $60 million.

title: Geneva Arms Envoys To Form Work Groups
description: American and Soviet arms control negotiators agreed today to divide into working groups on strategic, intermediate and space weapons next week for the first time since negotiations began March 12.

title: GOETZ'S COUNSEL GIVEN DEADLINE BY GRAND JURY
description: A Manhattan grand jury yesterday gave Bernhard H. Goetz until Monday to testify before it votes on whether to indict him in connection with his shooting of four teen-agers on a subway train in December.

title: NEW HAVEN TRYING TO KEEP AILING SHUBERT OPEN
description: Mayor Biagio DiLieto announced an emergency fund-raising campaign today to try to revive the Shubert Performing Arts Center here. The center has floundered in the 14 months after its gala reopening.

title: Tandy Purchases Electronics Chain
description: The Tandy Corporation said it had entered into a contract to buy the assets of a 24-store audio-video appliance chain, operating under the names Scott Appliances, Santa and McDuff's.

title: HIGH SCHOOL DEFENSE-BUSTER
description: They were playing right into Greg (Boo) Harvey's hands, or at least his legs.

title: HALLWOOD GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $548,000 for the quarter and $741,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $164,000 for the quarter and $346,000 for the 6 months.

title: Mr. Gandhi's Almost Bright Start
description: In five months as India's Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi has earned some solid grades. Since the day his mother was murdered, he has led the Congress Party astutely to impressive election victories. He has raised hope for reform of a crony-ridden system and made himself the apostle of efficiency. But the blot on a promising start is that he has failed so far to deal with the most dangerous threat to India's unity - the Sikh rebellion in the Punjab.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day on March 12 about Kraft Inc.'s acquisition of Frusen Gl"adje Ltd. misidentified the previous owner of the trademark and formula for Frusen Gl"adje ice cream. It was Frusen Gl"adje, not Kraft.

title: AS VON BULOW RETRIAL NEARS, TAPE RECORDINGS ARE EAGERLY SOUGHT
description: Last fall, after a CBS broadcast about the von B"ulow case, the network was told by a Massachusetts man that he had fresh evidence, hours of tape-recorded conversations with the accused, Claus von B"ulow.

title: HI-PORT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RULING BARS STATE POLICY ON INSERTS TO UTILITY BILLS
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that the state cannot compel utilities to insert opinions and information from consumer groups in billing envelopes.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for 16 wks to Feb 9
I.M.F. Delay For Argentina
description: Argentina said today that necessary adjustments in Argentina's economic austerity program would delay disbursement of the first two tranches of a $1.42 billion International Monetary Fund stand-by loan. But it insisted that a substantial agreement with creditor banks on conditions for the release of a $4.2 billion loan package had been reached.

title: SANDINISTA GOVERNMENT VIEWED AS LEFTIST HYBRID
description: When Konstantin U. Chernenko died last week, the Nicaraguan Government declared three days of national mourning for the Soviet leader. To sorrowful strains of Chopin and Tchaikovsky, nightly news broadcasts praised ''Comrade Chernenko'' as a ''great statesman and untiring fighter for the cause of world peace and solidarity.''

title: AIDS VICTIMS ARE TARGETS OF NEW RULES IN BRITAIN
description: New Government regulations give British magistrates broad authority aimed at protecting the public from AIDS, including in some circumstances the power to order a person to be taken to a hospital and kept there if the local authorities consider him a risk to others.

title: FILM: A NEW 'FRIDAY 13TH'
description: Friday the 13th - a New Beginning,'' which opened yesterday at Loew's State and other theaters, is the fifth in the series of phenomenally profitable slash-and-hack horror films. The principal appeal of these movies is the spectacle of new, fresh- faced Hollywood actors, most of whom are in their early 20's though they play teen-agers, as they get chopped up by a masked fiend who, most of the time, uses a machete.

title: The Crisis at Krasnoyarsk President Reagan is negotiating for arms control yet at the same time, most recently in Quebec this week, accusing the Russians of violating the treaties they've already signed.
description: The President's ambivalence does not end there. He has refused to ratify the SALT II treaty yet pledged to do nothing to undercut it. He refused at first to use the special SALT channel for resolving disputes; now he's using the channel but also publicly prejudging Soviet transgressions. The price of these actions is that disputes that used to be resolved now stew and fester, eroding confidence in the whole arms control process.

title: AMERICAN BUILDING MAINTEANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
U.N. Troops Confront Israelis
description: Irish soldiers from the United Nations peacekeeping force blocked the road in front of an Israeli convoy today to protest what the Israelis said was ''preventative gunfire.''

title: U.S. Negotiator to Lobby for MXWASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI) - President Reagan has recalled Max M. Kampelman, the chief United States arms negotiator, from the Geneva talks to try to persuade the House of Representatives to approve 21 MX missiles and ''stand united at Geneva,'' the White House announced today.
description: Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said in a written statement that Mr. Kampelman will meet with Mr. Reagan on Monday morning ''to give him a private assessment of the progress of the talks'' and probably will not make it back to Geneva for Tuesday's negotiating session.

title: N. CAROLINA HEIGHT OVERCOMES AUBURN
description: North Carolina built a 15- point first-half lead, and Joe Wolf scored 8 points down the stretch to stave off a rally for a 62-56 victory over Auburn tonight in the Southeast Regional semifinals.

title: POLISH NEWS: PROVIDED (AND MADE) BY JERZY URBAN
description: In terms of public exposure and public debate, the chief representative of the Communist Government of Poland is not Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski - or, for that matter, any of his Cabinet ministers or party lieutenants. The distinction is held by an elfin, 52-year-old man who has never been a member of the ruling party.

title: YOUR MONEY
description: AMONG the many investments with tax advantages offered to individuals today, one of the least known is the simplified employee pension, or SEP. Yet this type of plan allows some workers to set aside as much as $30,000 a year of tax-deferred funds, with the income from the investment also compounded on a tax-deferred basis.

title: LITTLE ROCK A SYMBOL AGAIN: THE RESEGREGATION OF SCHOOLS
description: Just as integration here has become respectable, the public schools are threatened with becoming racially segregated again.

title: FRENCH DIPLOMAT IS SEIZED IN BEIRUT
description: The French vice consul in Lebanon was abducted by gunmen in West Beirut today, and another French Embassy official and his daughter were reported missing and feared kidnapped.

title: PATENTS ;   System to Protect Offshore Oil Rigs
description: A Japanese engineer has designed a protection system for offshore oil drilling rigs anchored in hazardous ice-bound waters. Patent No. 4,505,618, designed by Nobuyoshi Yashima of Funabashi, Japan, was financed jointly by the Atlantic Richfield Company of Los Angeles and the Mitsui Engineering and Shipbuilding Company of Tokyo.

title: NEW REGENTS CHAIRMAN: MARTIN CHARLES BARRELL
description: Martin C. Barell was elected Chancellor of the State Board of Regents yesterday in Albany, capping a long and tenacious effort that was unusual for this clubby and genteel panel of unpaid citizens. Mr. Barell, a New York City lawyer, made his first bid to get in line for the chancellorship of the panel that sets educational policy in 1978, two years after being named to the board by the Legislature.

title: Books of The Times;   Edwardian England
description: THIS REAL NIGHT. By Rebecca West.

title: Time for Reflection
description: To mark the 40th anniversary of the Arab League, the league's representatives at the United Nations did something people here rarely do - they canceled a celebration.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ICI ON PARLE It's by Eugene Ionesco and it's in French and it might be fun for anyone who has taken French in school and then tried to speak it in life. What it is, is ''Parlons Fran,cais II: un exercice de style,'' a new one-act comedy that will play tonight at 8 and tomorrow at 3 P.M. in New York University Theater, 15 West Fourth Sreet.

title: A Balance for St. Bart's The three-year effort of the vestry of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church to demolish one of its landmark buildings at Park Avenue and 50th Street has produced a confrontation that New York City Hall should now energetically resolve by compromise.
description: The church's governing body asserts that changes in its environs, speeded by changes in zoning, have reduced the financial strength of a once- wealthy congregation. The income from its $11 million endowment supposedly can no longer both maintain the elaborate and expensive landmark complex and fulfill the congregation's spiritual and social needs. It seeks to cash in on the value of its land by erecting an office tower.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Customers say to us, 'We had divestiture in '84, then we had to learn to handle a new bill two times as thick as the old one, then we were asked to choose between leasing and buying, then you told us to get used to a 718 area code for Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

title: ASHFORD AND SIMPSON: LIVING THEIR LOVE SONGS
description: They met in 1964 at the White Rock Baptist Church in Harlem. She was a 17-year-old high school student who sang in the choir. He was a 21-year- old penniless newcomer from Willow Run, Mich., who had been sleeping on a bench in Central Park.

title: Centronics Data
description: The Centronics Data Computer Corporation said that to reduce overhead and to take advantage of more favorable wage rates it would move some operations to its main plant here from plants in Rochester, Minn., and Drogheda, Ireland.

title: DRAMATIC SIGN-OFF FOR HALL
description: After a season of speculation and 13 seasons of enduring one of the most pressurized positions in sport, Joe B. Hall, the basketball coach at the University of Kentucky, announced his resignation tonight after his team's loss to St. John's in the West Regional semifinal.

title: MX FINDS AN IMPROBABLE CHAMPION
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill is a politican who knows he should not underestimate an adversary. He is not doing that with Representative Les Aspin, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, who is a leader of the fight in the House to save the MX missile.

title: 3 NEW TAX BREAKS OFFERED BY CUOMO FOR STATE BUDGET
description: Three new tax breaks - for one-income families, low- income homeowners and people with income from dividends and interest - were proposed by Governor Cuomo today in negotiations over the proposed state budget.

description: The slogan that Brooklyn College utilizes in an effort to encourage enrollment is this: ''If you want to go far, go to Brooklyn.''

description: Six men have been charged with conspiring to produce and distribute millions of dollars of counterfeit currency and passing $422,000 of it to unwitting merchants and others, mostly in the New York City and Miami areas, Federal authorities said yesterday.

description: Doctors are ready to implant a Penn State artificial heart at Hershey Medical Center here as a bridge to keep a patient alive until a human heart can be transplanted, they said today.

description: A speaking engagement was one thing. But Premier Rene Levesque of Quebec said that a stay in New York would be too much.

description: Four weeks after they opened spring training, the Yankees were in a worse position today than they were before they began.

description: Some 40 men and women active in Save the Theaters Inc., and a sprinkling of spectators who didn't quite know what was going on, gathered yesterday in Duffy Square to commemorate the third anniversary of the Morosco Theater's demolition.

description: Mayor Koch went campaigning yesterday.

description: A much-delayed event will be played today at Bridge and Games East, 227 East 56th Street. It is the final of the New York Grand National Teams, Flight A, and the winners will earn a free trip to Las Vegas, Nev., to compete in national playoffs in August.

description: Playing one of its most physical games of the season, St. John's moved a step closer to the Final Four tonight, defeating Kentucky, 86-70, in a West Regional semifinal.

description: The top law enforcement officials of the United States and Mexico agreed today to meet this summer to discuss the drug trafficking problems that have caused friction between the two nations.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day on Thursday about appointments at Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. misstated the office to which Peter Jovanovich was elected. He will be executive vice president and a director.

title: Dual Title
description: Xavier McDaniel, the Wichita State all-American, has become the first Division I player to capture both the season scoring and rebounding titles, according to the National Collegiate Athletic Association. McDaniel, whose team was knocked out of the N.C.A.A. playoffs last week, ended the season with an average of 27.2 points and 14.8 rebounds over 31 games.

title: J. H. Alessi Wed To Diane Caruso
description: Diane F. Caruso, the daughter of Judges F. Michael Caruso and Marilyn Loftus of the New Jersey Superior Court in Essex County, was married yesterday to Joseph H. Alessi, a son of Leonarda Alessi of South Orange, N.J., and the late Harry Alessi. The Rev. Philip D. Morris performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Sorrows Roman Catholic Church in South Orange.

title: CHARLES W. MACLEAN, BISHOP IN EPISCOPAL DIOCESE, IS DEAD
description: Charles W. MacLean, retired Suffragan Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, died yesterday at Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L.I., after a brief illness. He was 81 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

description: Assemblyman Albert Vann of Brooklyn resigned yesterday as chairman of the Coalition for a Just New York, according to his spokesman, Audrey Bynoe.

description: The police raided the homes of Afghan and Iranian refugees today, detaining 14 people and questioning hundreds of others in a hunt for the killers of a Soviet official.

title: RED WINGS DEFEAT RANGERS
description: The Rangers' sputtering drive toward a playoff berth stalled again tonight, this time with a 5-3 loss to the Detroit Red Wings at Joe Louis Arena.

description: Clara Peller, the star of Wendy's highly successful ''Where's the Beef?'' commercials, has lost her job with the fast-food chain.

title: ISRAEL'S IRON MESSAGE
description: The chief objective of Israel's new aggressive military policy in southern Lebanon, military analysts here say, is to make Israel's northern border secure. In adopting what has been called an ''offensive defense,'' the analysts say, Israel has finally turned its back on the idea of improving its security by installing a more stable or sympathetic government to the north.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 40.

title: Cowles Stake Seen As Gannett Target
description: The Gannett Company is reportedly seeking to purchase shares in the Cowles Media Company, which is owned by the Des Moines Register and Tribune Company. The Register and Tribune board in January accepted Gannett's bid to purchase three of the company's newspapers, including The Des Moines Register.

description: b-Net income including a special gain of $82,806,000.

description: Babies of mothers with hepatitis B infections may become lifetime carriers of the virus if not vaccinated shortly after birth, researchers reported yesterday.

title: Watson Leads by 3 In Las Vegas Golf
description: Tom Watson, who has won $3,657,887 on the PGA Tour, moved into the lead today in the richest tournament in the tour's history. He stood at 199, 14 under par, through three rounds of the $950,000 Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational, three shots in front of Mike Smith and Bill Glasson.

Bernhard Goetz's Double Exposure Bernhard Goetz's lawyers argue that he's being subjected to double jeopardy as the prosecutor resubmits the subway shootings to the grand jury. But what are the lawyers doing if not putting New Yorkers through the wringer a second time?
description: The unseemly exposure of their client worked handsomely to his advantage the first time. On television and in the press, the community from which the grand jurors are drawn was shown the episode through the eyes of an allegedly frightened passenger defending himself against marauders.

title: Andersen Loses Suit by Hanover
description: Arthur Andersen & Company has lost a $17 million lawsuit brought by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company over the collapse of the Drysdale Securities Corporation.

title: Harry Wolf Wed To Amy K. Moss
description: Grace Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Amy Kathryn Moss, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Moss of Malibu, Calif., to Harry Charles Wolf, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Wolf of Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. Kenneth Swanson, assisted by the Rev. James Fenhagen, performed the ceremony.

title: TEACHERS IN ARKANSAS FACE COMPETENCY TESTING TODAY
description: Despite protests by more than 3,000 teachers that closed some schools last month, Arkansas becomes the first state in the nation Saturday to test its teachers on their competence in basic skills.

title: FORSTMANN IN PACT FOR MCGRAW
description: The McGraw-Edison Company, a Chicago electrical and industrial equipment manufacturer, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Forstmann Little & Company, the leveraged buyout specialists, in a transaction valued at $1.3 billion.

title: Jackson Gains In State Playoffs
description: Greg (Boo) Harvey scored 25 points and Ron Edwards added 18 as Andrew Jackson of Queens defeated Long Island Lutheran, 64-58, in a Class A playoff game of the New York State basketball championships tonight.

title: Mingus Dynasty
description: A new eight-man edition of the jazz ensemble Mingus Dynasty is performing at Lush Life, 184 Thompson Street (228-3788) through tomorrow. Shows today are at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M., and tomorrow at 8:30, 10, and 11:30 P.M. There is a $10 music charge and a $6 minimum.

title: Son of U.N. Executive Charged With Murder
description: The son of a United Nations executive was charged today with second-degree murder in the killing of a modeling student from Norway, according to the Rockland County District Attorney.

title: BALANCE COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $481,030 for the quarter and $710,189 for the 9 months.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Friars Join Movement Offering Haven to Aliens
description: A group of more than 300 Franciscan friars has joined the alien sanctuary movement, promising to offer haven to Central American refugees in defiance of the law and Federal policies.

title: BELDEN & BLAKE ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFS
description: AMR Corp.'s American Airlines unit, Dallas, said it might apply for nonstop authority between Dallas/ Fort Worth Airport and Madrid if such a route was established.

title: Pitino to Providence
description: Rick Pitino, the Knick assistant coach who had been looking for a head coaching job in the pros, has left the team and is heading back to the college ranks. Pitino, a former Boston University coach, was named head coach at Providence, replacing

title: HULTZ CONSIDERS MEETING ON MIDEAST
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz is considering meeting with the Foreign Ministers of Egypt and Jordan to discuss the makeup of an Arab delegation to negotiate peace with Israel, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: OHIO THRIFT UNITS PAID HIGH RATES
description: The 72 savings and loan associations in Ohio that have operated with private deposit insurance - and without the guarantees of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation - are largely outgrowths of 19th-century neighborhood institutions that have been offering higher interest rates than federally insured thrift units.

title: Tesoro Terminates Funk Agreement
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said it had terminated its previously announced agreement to buy Funk Exploration Inc., a privately held oil and gas producing company, for $160 million.

title: Moxness Leads by 3
description: Barbara Moxness, who has not won in seven years on the women's golf tour, shot her second consecutive 70 today to open a three- shot lead over Jan Stephenson after two rounds of the $250,000 GNA tournament. Pearl Sinn, a 17-year-old high school senior who had shared the opening-day lead, had a second-round 75 that put her five strokes off the pace. Miss Stephenson followed a 70 with a 73 today for a 143 total.

title: MemorialServiceforDancer
description: A memorial service for Audrey Elizabeth Connally, a member of the Dance Theater of Harlem, is planned for 2 P.M. today at St. Luke's A.M.E. Church, 1872 Amsterdam Avenue, at 152d Street. Miss Connally, 20 years old, died in a car accident on March 11.

title: REAGAN IS CRITICIZED OVER SOUTH AFRICA
description: The leader of the Congressional Black Caucus criticized President Reagan today for his suggestion that rioting by blacks was at least partly responsible for the police slayings of 18 black people in South Africa on Thursday.

title: GREENSBORO TRIGGERS
description: A Federal lawsuit that goes to trial Monday in district court in Winston- Salem, N.C., seeks to insure that government in the United States cannot get away with murder. What's involved is irresponsible use of two paid informants - an abuse that the nation learned about all too vividly in the 1960's.

title: DAHLBERG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: PARIS COLLAGES REFLECT PEKING ARTIST'S FREEDOM
description: An exhibition of gentle, whimsical paper collages on distinctly Chinese themes has opened at the James Mayor Gallery on the Left Bank here.

description: b-Including gains of $4,649,000 for the latest first quarter and $1,789,000 for the year-ago first quarter on the sale of investments.

title: ISRAEL DEFENDS ACTION INVOLVING CBS
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel yesterday defended the judgment of an Israeli tank crew in southern Lebanon whose shellfire killed a cameraman and a soundman employed by CBS News.

title: FEBRUARY PRICES FOR CUNSUMERS UP A SLIM 0.3%
description: The Consumer Price Index rose three- tenths of 1 percent in February, extending the trend of modest inflation that has kept price increases to 4 percent or less since 1981.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Court Limits Veterans In Challenges to V.A.
description: Veterans who are unhappy with the handling of their disability claims by the Veterans Administration cannot appeal those rulings to higher authorities, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: NEW YORK'S TURTLE PACE
description: An old story is told in certain New York watering spots about Joe Frisco, the late vaudeville comedian. It seems that Joe was coming out of a Sixth Avenue bar one night and came upon a big hole in the ground with men working in it. What were they doing down there, Joe wanted to know. ''Building the subway,'' answered one of the workers. ''How long will it take?'' asked Joe. ''About five years,'' came the answer. ''The hell with it,'' said Joe, ''I'll take a cab.''

title: Grand Jury Calls Lifeguards Lax in 3 Drownings in Jersey
description: A Cape May County grand jury has charged that the beach patrol here covered up one drowning and inadequately investigated two others to avoid embarrassment, authorities said today.

title: IPL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOUTH AFRICA ORDERS INVESTIGATION INTO KILLING OF 18 BLACKS BY POLICE
description: The South African Government ordered a judicial inquiry today into the incident Thursday in which the police opened fire on a crowd of black people, killing 18.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A theater review of ''The Conduct of Life'' on Wednesday misidentified three characters. Crystal Field played the wife, Alba Oms played the housekeeper and Sheila Dabney played a young woman who is raped.

title: HIGH DEATH RATE PERSISTING FOR BLACK INFANTS
description: Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human Services, said today that it was doubtful that the rate of death among black infants could be reduced enough in this decade to meet the national goal for the year 1990.

title: Roger Gambill Is Dead at 42; Tenor With the Kingston Trio
description: Roger Gambill, a tenor with the Kingston Trio since 1973, died on Wednesday at St. Joseph's Hospital here after having had a heart attack on March 2. He was 42 years old and lived in Roswell, Ga.

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
DOW SLIPS BY 0.77 POINT DESPITE MERGER FERVOR
description: Stock prices fell slightly yesterday, hurt by another set of weaker-than- expected economic numbers. Professional traders, however, were kept busy in a dull session by an inordinate number of takeover rumors.

description: As the Transit Authority begins a four-year effort to rebuild its aging tracks and structures, riders on the city's subways will be facing increasing delays and detours.

title: SEGMENTED CIGARETTE MARKET
description: The smoker of the new Ritz cigarette, created by the designer Yves Saint Laurent and sold by the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, is a fashion-conscious woman, Reynolds says. It adds that she is probably single, owns a designer handbag, reads Vogue and spends a high percentage of her income on clothes. The name Ritz, the tobacco company hopes, will suggest an opulent life style.

TV: '20/20' EXAMINES GOETZ SUBWAY SHOOTINGS
description: ABC's ''20/20'' took a spooky step forward Thursday night. It re- enacted the subway shootings by Bernhard H. Goetz. This was a little like ''Rashomon,'' with everyone having a slightly different version of what happened, or what it all means. As Mr. Goetz himself said at the conclusion: ''The same person can - can be two entirely different people to other people, depending on their experiences.''

title: PAN AM FLIGHT AIDES RETURN
description: Pan American World Airways agreed yesterday to reinstate 157 flight attendants it had dismissed when they would not cross picket lines. After Pan Am's action, many flight attendants crossed the picket lines of striking ground workers to return to work.

title: Not Giving Up
description: Mike Torrez on June 21 of last year, taking a swipe at the Mets for releasing him only two months after they had made him their opening-day starter: ''They did the same thing with Kingman. They gave up on me like they gave up on him.

Joe Pass in Concert
description: The jazz guitarist Joe Pass is performing this weekend at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Shows are at 8 and 10 P.M. and midnight today and at 9 and 11 P.M., tomorrow. There is a $10 music charge and a $5 minimum.

title: DANCE: 'AFTER VENICE,' PREMIERE FROM SYDNEY
description: Surely you remember Dirk Bogarde's choleric death, hair dye streaming down his face, in Luchino Visconti's 1971 film of Thomas Mann's ''Death in Venice.'' Or perhaps you recall Benjamin Britten's opera of the same name, especially the Metropolitan Opera production with Bryan Pitts - then of the New York City Ballet - as the angelic blond object of the protagonist's desire.

title: Orders for Durables Slip
description: Orders for durable manufactured goods dropped a slight two-tenths of 1 percent in February as a record increase for civilian capital goods was overshadowed by a steep drop in demand for military hardware, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: GOETZ'S LAWYERS TRY TO GET MESSAGE ACROSS TO GRAND JURORS
description: As Bernhard H. Goetz's lawyers decide whether their client should testify without immunity before the grand jury, they have found other ways to send their messages to the panel.

title: Navy to Test Cruise Missiles
description: Cruise missiles will make test flights over Florida and Alabama later this year, the Navy announced today. The unarmed Tomahawk missiles will be launched from ships or submarines in the Gulf of Mexico and will fly over the Florida Panhandle into Alabama and then back into Florida, where they will land by parachute or crash at the Eglin Air Force Base test range.

title: SOVIET CALLS FOR MISSILE FREEZE
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, urged NATO today to stop its deployment of Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in Europe in order to hasten an agreement at the Geneva arms talks. In return, he said, the Kremlin could freeze Soviet ''countermeasures.''

title: EX-BLAZERS LEAD NUGGETS OVER NETS
description: Coach Stan Albeck of the Nets studied the box score after his team had been beaten, 123-111, by the Denver Nuggets at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight and said: ''That was one heck of an off-season trade they made. It gave them so many things they needed and didn't have.''

description: A strategy of prosecuting corrupt New York City inspectors in Federal rather than state courts has generally failed to produce the stiffer prison sentences expected, officials said yesterday.

title: OHIO THRIFT REOPENINGS SET ON A LIMITED BASIS
description: Ohio banking officials tonight gave formal clearance for the state-insured thrift institutions that were ordered closed one week ago today to reopen on a limited basis to allow customers to withdraw up to $750 from their accounts to meet necessities.

description: Dr. Aaron Feder, a New York internist and educator, died Tuesday at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Basses in Cookie Deal
description: Bass Brothers Enterprises of Fort Worth has acquired a majority interest in Famous Amos Chocolate Chip Cookies, according to the founder of the cookie company, Wally Amos. He said on Thursday that the Basses bought a 51 percent stake under an agreement signed last month. A spokesman for Bass Brothers Enterprises confirmed that the Basses had ''an interest'' in the cookie company, but declined to elaborate.

description: When Triangle Industries this week announced its $420 million offer to acquire the much larger National Can Corporation, the little-known maker of coin-operated video games, vending machines and jukeboxes was catapulted into the territory of high- stakes corporate takeover drama.

description: The United Mine Workers yesterday announced a tentative agreement that would end strikes against a Pennsylvania coal company that refused to sign the national contract last fall.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in SportsMonday this week about the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship won by Andrew Jackson High School reported the school's record incorrectly. Andrew Jackson won two previous titles - in 1942 and 1944.

description: A new Federal law that permits students to set up Bible-study clubs in public schools is creating disputes in many towns on Long Island and in several other communities in the New York metropolitan region.

description: A passenger in a small airplane, aided by air traffic controllers and a flight instructor, made a ''perfect landing'' after the pilot apparently suffered a fatal heart attack, officials said today.

The girls just want to have fun.

description: Manager Jim Frey of the Chicago Cubs shipped six players to the minors the other day, including the former Met pitcher Scott Holman, and then delivered a possibly unwitting but nonetheless certain put- down: ''The next cut is going to be the toughest, because we're running out of the obvious names.''

title: DR. PHILIP REICHERT
description: Dr. Philip Reichert, a cardiologist, died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan.

description: A Chinese military vessel whose crew apparently mutinied entered South Korean waters today and was taken into port, according to the American Embassy in Seoul.

title: Business Digest;   SATURDAY, MARCH 23, 1985
description: The Economy

title: COOKING FOR ONE MADE EASIER
description: It has been a long time since singles have had to open a can of pork and beans and call it dinner because they hated cooking for one. With carryout food available on almost every block in Manhattan and salad bars threatening to take over the center aisle of corner vegetable stands, the single diner now has lots of choices.

title: Free Car Rides Stir Protests
description: A funeral home operator who gives elderly people free rides to the hospital has been charged with running an unlicensed ambulance service.

title: Draft Resisters LoseThe free speech of 18 avowed resisters to draft registration was not violated, the Court said in another 7-to-2 opinion, when they were singled out for prosecution.
description: At issue was the ''passive enforcement'' policy, used in the first few years after President Carter reinstated draft registration in 1980, under which the Government did not actively seek out violators but waited for them to identify themselves. The Court upheld the indictment of David A. Wayte of Pasadena, Calif., who wrote protest letters to the White House, and said the policy did not amount to selective prosecution. ''Those prosecuted in effect selected themselves for prosecution,'' Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. wrote, ''by refusing to register after being reported and warned by the Government.''

title: Women's Income
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: When David Larson returns from Vietnam, he is alone. His parents have died in a car crash; his sister and her hippie husband want nothing to do with a former soldier.

title: IN CENTERPORT, A BATTLE OVER CHANGE
description: FROM the windows of his home above Centerport Harbor, Leonard T. Stevenson keeps watch on what happens below. Since he arrived here in 1948, the 73-year- old retired New York City police detective has seen the tide in the narrow harbor go in and out many times. Looking past the shoreline home of his friend, United States Representative Robert J. Mrazek, he has smiled at the sight of swimmers and boaters making use of the waterway and bristled at the sight of raucous behavior. He has sprung into action to stop illegal filling, unauthorized dredging and the pumping of sewage into the old Mill Pond from harborside restaurants that have come and gone.

title: Lynn Piccirillo Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Piccirillo of New York, formerly of Huntington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynn A. Piccirillo, to William R. Boccio, the son of Mrs. Francis J. Martell of Brookville, L.I., and the late Emilio Boccio of Old Westbury, L.I. The wedding is planned for June. The future bride is an assistant New York City corporation counsel. Mr. Boccio is an associate with the Garden City, L.I., law firm of Murphy & Bartol.

title: Mullin Worthy Of His Honors
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: AND NOW, THE MEDIA MEGA-MERGER
description: IN the 1960's, regional conventions of newspaper publishers were like reunions of old friends - social events in which the prosperous scions of long-held family businesses played golf, compared notes on union troubles and speculated about what their dailies might be worth.

title: Belgium Shakes a Nuclear Allergy
description: At no little political risk, Belgium's Prime Minister Wilfried Martens has wrested parliamentary approval for the deployment of cruise missiles in his country. Narrowly construed, this means Belgium has complied with a NATO decision in 1979 to deploy new American missiles in response to the excessive buildup of Soviet SS-20's. But what tipped the balance was an act of faith - the belief that President Reagan's team has a realistic brief in the new arms control talks. If that faith crumbles, so will support for deployment in the nervously ambivalent Low Countries.

title: 'No' to Jobless Aid
description: One such program provides benefits beyond the usual six months for the long-term unemployed. It would expire this week, and Democrats, especially in the House, have been pushing for its extension.

title: Polio Victims React To Doctor's Comments
description: The Westchester Post-Polio Group is grateful to Dr. Eugene Moskowitz (Letters to the Editor, March 3) for providing the public with a concrete demonstration of the negative and patronizing attitude many of us have encountered from physicians.

title:
EMERGING CAREERS;

A NEW WORLD OF TELECOMMUNICATIONS JOBS
description: WITH last year's breakup of the Bell System, companies that once provided strictly local phone service are now in effect data-processing companies too. Equipment companies that used to manufacture telephone sets have turned to building sophisticated electronic switchboards that can remember numbers and route calls over the least expensive circuit. Long distance, which was the exclusive preserve of A.T.& T. is now brimming with competitors large and small.

title: U.S.O.C. TO SEEK MORE TESTS FOR DRUGS
description: Concerned about reports of increasing drug use in sports, top United States Olympic officials say they want to conduct drug tests on American athletes at every major competition between this summer and the 1988 Games.

title:
CAMERA;

A PRACTICAL APPROACH GETS CLOSE TO THE SUBJECT
description: Lou Jacobs Jr. has written several books on photography.There's a kind of magic in taking close-ups of stamps, flowers, insects or even part of a person's face. When the enlarged print or slide is viewed, details are greatly enhanced. In some cases portions of a subject are converted into abstract patterns with overtones of mystery.

title: 7 Electrocuted in Florida By a Fallen Power Line
description: Seven people were electrocuted today when 7,260 volts of electricity shot through a car as they were getting into it, the authorities said.
