title: DR. H.C. TAYLOR JR., GYNECOLOGIST, DIES
description: Dr. Howard C. Taylor Jr., a former chairman of obstetrics and gynecology at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and an authority on family planning and cancer research, died Friday in his home in Manhattan. He was 85 years old and had been ill for many months.

title: CORRECTION
description: The story about oil industry strategies in last Sunday's Business section misstated the status of two of the Exxon Corporation's non-petroleum divisions. Parts of Exxon Office Systems have been sold and Reliance Electric has been paid extensively. Both divisions remain part of Exxon.

title: After the 'Flash'
description: The Commerce Department's ''flash'' estimate for growth in the first quarter, released late last week, was weaker than expected - only 2.1 percent annual growth in the real gross national product, compared with 4.3 percent during last year's fourth quarter. Some economists, citing soaring imports and lackluster exports, are predicting a few more quarters of sluggish growth.

title: JACK KEEPS THEM JUMPING
description: THE ONLY DAUGHTER

title: The Courage Of Smokers
description: Where have all our heroes gone? The Duke is dead. Athletes are businessmen. Astronauts are politicians. Are there any Americans left who fit the classic daring, courageous, heroic image that has all but faded from public adoration? Yes. But unfortunately, the members of a large segment of our population who deserve hero status are not given credit for their daily, sometimes hourly heroic deeds.

title: SOME CONTRA LEADERS ARE THEIR OWN WORST ENEMIES
description: Less than a year after the Sandinistas seized power in Nicaragua in 1979, 60 exiled officers of the defeated National Guard met in Guatemala. With little hope of success, some of them recall, they vowed to drive out the Sandinistas.

title: 36 FOOD OUTLETS LISTED FOR HEALTH VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 36 food establishments cited for violations of the city's health code.

title: 19TH-CENTURY SCULPTURE AS SEEN BY A NOBLE SPIRIT
description: When I tell people that for the last 10 days or so my dreams have been haunted by August Kiss, they back away. But, as it happens, August Kiss is neither a perfume nor a seasonal mode of embrace. It is the name of one of the many largely forgotten sculptors who appear in the late H. W. Janson's ''19th Century Sculpture,'' just published by Harry N. Abrams, Inc., at $45.

title: Poland IndictsThree Dissidents
description: One of the most sensitive political issues in Poland is the cost of food. In the checkered post-war history of Polish Communism, anger over price increases has led to strikes, riots, deaths and overturned governments. It was not surprising, therefore, when the Government last week sought to halt agitation over another round of increases by indicting three dissidents for promoting public unrest.

title: DEMOCRATS ISSUE O'ROURKE 'REPORT CARD'
description: THERE are no announced candidates yet, but this year's County Executive race heated up considerably last week.

title: MOTHERS, FATHERS, AND FRIENDS
description: WHEN a business or organization gives away a book as a premium, in exchange for a subscription or commitment, the book is usually innocuous enough to appeal to the widest possible audience: a dictionary, a popular history of philosophy or a ''classic'' of some kind. Many of the books offered as premiums have no content at all, as in the case of appointment or address books.

Such is the case with various discount programs that charge an annual fee and offer a certain amount off normal hotel, restaurant, entertainment and sightseeing rates - or sometimes offer two of whatever you are buying for the price of one.

But instead of supercharged automobiles, there are gigantic multihulls with decks the size of tennis courts and masts that look like airplane wings. And in addition to the usual silver yachting trophy, winners receive substantial cash prizes. New York is scheduled for the finish of one of these Grand Prix regattas in late October.

title: Curse, Prayer and Whoop
description: Almost everyone underestimates the pervasiveness of language and William H. Gass sees it as one of the first functions of the literary critic to make us respect and even admire these half-animal, half-human sounds that control, inspire or frustrate us. In ''Habitations of the Word'' (Simon & Schuster), he reminds us of the almost unlimited moods, the theatrical changes of costume, of which language is capable.

title: On Language;   NEW NAME FOR 'STAR WARS'
description: WE ARE A NATION of acronymaniacs. A piece in this space a few weeks ago, pointing to the President's unhappiness with the derisive nickname ''Star Wars'' and asking for suggestions of a new name for the global shield he intends to protect us from incoming missiles, has elicited 600 responses - not all signed ''Best, Mirv.''

title: SOME PLAYERS LET CATS OUT OF BAGS

title: DEFENSE RESTS IN PUERTO RICO POLICE PERJURY CASE
description: The defense rested today in the trial of 10 police officers accused of perjury in connection with the shooting deaths of two advocates of Puerto Rican independence at the hands of the police more than six years ago.

title: NORTHWEST TERRITORIES PONDERS ITSELF AS TWO
description: An ambitious plan to split Canada's vast Northwest Territories into two to make it more manageable has been raising more problems lately than it promises to solve.

title: USING FEAR AND AFFECTION TO QUELL DRUG ABUSE
description: Enter David Toma, walking onto the stage of what looks like a theater in the round. There is applause, and Mr. Toma takes off his jacket. Carelessly he throws it aside and rolls up his sleeves. The movements are calculated, meant to indicate that Mr. Toma is a no-nonsense guy. Actually, we're sure of that as soon as we see him. Mr. Toma, the inspiration for two television series - ''Baretta'' and ''Toma'' - looks like Johnny Cash with some of Charles Bronson's creases. He doesn't have to throw his jacket away; that's artifice - unnecessary because Mr. Toma has presence. He is in the great tradition of television evangelists, only his message is not God but drugs. They'll kill you, he says; look at me and believe what I say. He scowls; he glares. Once or twice, he seems almost weepy. On television, Mr. Toma is terrific.

A EULOGY FOR MA BELL;

KEEP THE COURTS OUT OF REGULATION
description: MAJOR changes in regulatory policy are media events something akin to Presidential nominating conventions - there is an announcement, a flurry of speeches, a parade, a floor littered with confetti, and then everyone departs without worrying much about the cleanup.

title: IN THE MARAIS, BOUTIQUES CREATE A FASHION DISTRICT

This area, which includes the old Jewish quarter of Paris with its kosher butchers and delicatessens, has become a desirable place to live as the fine 17th- and 18th-century buildings are renovated. And more and more it is becoming a place to go for fashion.

title: EVERY MAN FOR HIMSELF
description: Enid Nemy is a columnist and culture reporter for The Times. Only yesterday, it seems, talking about men and fashion was just about as ridiculous as pairing bacon and ice cream, or Elizabeth Taylor and rhinestones. In my neck of the woods, which was northern Manitoba, men wore clothes; they weren't into style, unless they were foreigners, fops or dandies. Real people - meaning fathers, brothers, husbands, boyfriends and neighbors - had dark suits, white shirts and black shoes, chinos and loafers, flannels and blazers, and formal evening clothes, a wardrobe that covered every occasion. The one touch of masculine glamour (at least it seemed so to the big-city people who came up our way) was a raccoon coat, which came in mighty handy when the temperature dropped to 30 below and the wind, which we hoped was en route to the United States, howled over the prairie like a sick timber wolf. At times, particularly when I was certain that my social life would be ended if I didn't have a new dress, I envied my brother; he could wear the same old suit until the pants became knickers, and he would still be wildly popular.

title: Burford's Bill
description: Anne McGill Burford got into legal hot water with Congress when she was head of the Environmental Protection Agency. Last week, she said she may make some trouble of her own for the Government. Mrs. Burford, who resigned under fire in 1983, is angry because the Reagan Administration has not paid $211,000 in legal fees she ran up while defending herself in connection with a contempt of Congress citation involving her refusal to turn over subpoenaed documents. Mrs. Burford, who was never charged with any wrongdoing, said she was acting under orders.

title: ZEFFIRELLI'S CROWDS OVERWHELM 'TOSCA'
description: Poor Franco Zeffirelli. As the opera world has known for some time, the designer and director of the Metropolitan Opera's new ''Tosca'' suffers from theatrical agoraphobia, a strange malady that causes him to live in constant fear of seeing open spaces on the stage. Faced with the possibility of a sparsely peopled scene, he feels compelled to fill the area with the bodies of supernumeraries whose chief function is to mill about in colorful costumes and confuse anyone in the audience intent on listening to the music or following the story line. Similarly, when he is in this mood, selling the glitter instead of the gold, his scenic designs fill space the way coronation ceremonies and Presidential inaugurations do: they are meant to create awe and, at great expense, they do.

title: 2 DUTCH FORTS THAT RETIRED GRACEFULLY
description: For travelers who are intrigued by the evolution of military sites into cultural and architectural attractions, there is a sensible day trip to be made from Amsterdam. Just 15 miles southeast of the city stands Naarden, an elaborate hexagon of earthwork fortifications that contains a military museum in its outer embankments and a quaint yet living town within. Then, less than half the distance back to Amsterdam, one comes upon the Muiderslot, meaning the castle of Muiden, a medieval fortress that has been the favorite gathering place for Dutch literati ever since the early 17th century.

title: ANGLER'S ROOST A LURE TO THE END
description: BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y. ritt BuLIKE salmon resting momentarily in their upstream spawning run, a large crowd of eager devotees of angling, its equipage and its literature, milled in front of Bedford Historical Hall shortly after dawn Friday, waiting for the doors to open at 8. The occasion was the start of a two-day tag sale and auction of the contents of the late Jim Deren's Manhattan-based Angler's Roost, an establishment whose siren call to anglers from all over the world belied its cramped quarters. Part of the public's fascination with the affair - the earliest customers, John and Maureen Liberati of White Plains, were on hand at 5:20 A.M., and by noon about 500 more had followed them inside - is a tribute to Mr. Deren's reputation as a first-class angler, raconteur and salesman. Also responsible is a burgeoning interest in collecting antique fishing gear. Only a small percentage of the material at the sale could properly be called old or antique, but the possibility of such a find clearly brought many to the hall, which is an antique itself. Formerly a church at Bedford Four Corners, it was hauled to its present location in 1837 by 20 yoke of oxen. The hall was filled with an astonishing array of rods, reels of all types, fly lines, old fishing magazines and books, canvas and wicker creels, leaders, waders, trout and salmon flies, fly-tying materials and vises, fresh- and saltwater lures, knives, arrows, bows, filing cabinets, fly books and boxes, studs for wading shoes, shirts, jackets, foul-weather gear, fishing caps and a few undistinguished cork-bodied duck decoys. The Angler's Roost was first situated at 207 East 43rd Street, then in the Chrysler Building and, finally, at 141 East 44th Street near Grand Central, where Mr. Deren held forth until shortly before his death in 1983. Space was limited in each of those locations. At the last place, one felt crowded if more than two other customers were present. The room was jammed with fishing gear, in the midst of which Mr. Deren presided, usually in a sitting position. Frequent visitors to the shop were aware that much more stuff was stored in large back rooms, but they could only conjecture what was there. Admitting that they and their co- workers were overwhelmed by the number of items unearthed, the key people in organizing the event, Hoagy Carmichael Jr. and Judith Bowman, both of Bedford, N.Y., speculate that. for many, part of the appeal of the sale and auction was the long-awaited chance (an angler's most valuable trait is patience) to finally see what was in those other rooms. Although there were hundreds of valuable items and splendid bargains - salmon and trout flies fly rods and fly-line reels notable among the last-named - in Friday's tag sale, most of the truly choice and expensive items were disposed of in yesterday's auction. They included handmade split bamboo rods by such legendary makers as Edmind Garrision, E. F. Payne, Harold (Pinky) Gillum and Hiram Leonard. The auctioneer, Paul Wight of Plattsburgh, N.Y., had a somewhat unresponsive audience with the beginning items - old magazines and catalogues - but the bidding picked up when books and trout and salmon flies went on the block. In one instance, a single Whirling Dun trout fly sold for $90. The bidding for reels was spirited. A Hardy 12/0 Zane Grey big game reel went for $2,000. Handmade split bamboo fly rods also fetched handsome prices. An 8-foot Garrison was purchased for $1,900. Among those who traveled the farthest to get to the sale was Art Warner, who described himself as "a trout-fishing nut from Southern California." "When I told some friends that I was taking some time off for a trip, they assumed it was an angling adventure and were astonished to find that I was flying to New York City," Mr. Warner said. "Although I grew up in Binghamton, N.Y., I never had the good fortune to meet Mr. Deren, but, of course, I knew of him." As he spoke - he had already bought more than $100 worth of gear - he was fondling a leather case for a revolving-spool reel. Another customer, Frank Almquist, of Woodstock, N.Y., had visited the Angler's Roost. Mr. Almquist, who is the president of the Catskill Mountain Chapter of Trout Unlimited, and his wife, Wendy, had purchased a seven-foot South Bend split bamboo fly rod, 15 boxes of dry fly hooks down to No. 26, which are so tiny a sneeze would send dozens of them flying, and a bag full of fly-tying materials, including an excellent blue dun saddle hackle and a good supply of wood duck feathers. The lure of the Angler's Roost to fishermen who either lived in or visited Manhattan was intense. In his "Catskill Rivers," published shortly before Mr. Deren's death, Austin Francis said that the Angler's Roost "is the only decent tackle shop left in Manhattan that caters to Catskill anglers." Some of Mr. Deren's fishing companions recall that as he grew older (he was in his 60's when he died) he was possessed by the fascination of what is difficult and would devote the better part of a day, sometimes unsuccessfully, in working a fly over the lairs of truly large and wise trout, while smaller and less sophisticated fish nearby would hit almost anything. Those who visited his shop included Presidents or their emissaries, captains of industry from this country and abroad and figures from the world of entertainment and sports, Ted Williams among the last-named. NMr. Carmichael expressed astonishment at the interest in the liquidation. "It's incredible," he said, "If you announced that you had five union suits once worn by George LaBranche, you'd have 100 buyers in 24 hours." Mr. LaBranche is the famous Catskill fly-tyer who was a key figure in adapting the techniques practiced on England's sedate streams to their turbulent American counterparts. The aforementioned $90 Whirling Dun was tied by Mr. LaBranche. - OUTDOORS

description: Rajiv Gandhi, making his first trip as Prime Minister to the Punjab, announced measures today that are intended to rejuvenate the state.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Chester Soling of New York and Williamstown, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Caytha Ann Soling to Michael Irwin Jentis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Jentis of Livingston, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: LEVEL OF ACTIVITY CALLED NORMAL
description: Forty-six more savings and loan institutions reopened in Ohio today to a steady stream of customers who had access to their accounts for the first time since Gov. Richard F. Celeste ordered 71 state-chartered, privately insured thrift units closed March 15.

title: CHICAGO
description: When Carl Sandburg called Chicago the ''city of the big shoulders,'' he was referring not to a penchant for pads, but to a ''stormy, husky, brawling'' town on the move.

title: CASINOS SEEK CURB ON OVERSATURATION
description: ATLANTIC CITY THE casino industry, currently in the throes of what it calls a ''market softening,'' will try to convince the city's new master planner to include a provision to prevent construction of a new casino if it ''jeopardizes'' established properties.

title: DISPUTE COULD HALT RIDE-SHARING VANS
description: EACH workday morning, Betty Thomas leaves her home in Far Rockaway at 7 o'clock, boards a 15-passenger van and arrives at her office in Jericho at 8:20. The ride costs her nothing - in fact, she also has free use of the vehicle on weekends - because on the way to Jericho, Mrs. Thomas picks up 12 passengers and takes them to work.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: FEMININITY, by Susan Brownmiller. (Fawcett Columbine, $7.95.) Femininity, Susan Brownmiller says, ''in essence, is a romantic sentiment, a nostalgic tradition of imposed limitations.'' Our reviewer, Carol Gilligan, commented last year that femininity ''defines a way of looking and a strategy for containment. The critical questions are of perspective, power and judgment. By attaching these questions to the details of femininity and extending her description through an extraordinary range of historical example and literary illustration, Miss Brownmiller has turned a treacherous subject into a lively and compelling book.''

title: THE ART OF PACKING
description: R. W. Apple Jr. is the London bureau chief of The Times.For more than 25 years now, I have been traveling for a living and for pleasure, and I have had an incurable case of wanderlust, which is still with me, for a good bit longer than that. I guess it started when I was about 10 years old. My Uncle Ivan, who was something of a tosspot and therefore irresistible to a small boy growing up amid the middle-class verities of Akron, Ohio, showed me one day some faded photographs of his prewar trip across the Gobi Desert, and I was hooked. As simple as that.

title: MY SINCERE PLEDGE: A NEAT BASEMENT
description: BASEMENT clutter: That dread condition known to homeowners throughout modern times has befallen my house.

title: Frank Lloyd Wright, We'll Keep the Porch
description: When I read in a Feb. 3 article (''An Absorbing Introduction to Wright's Usonia,'') that ''this observer could appreciate . . . Wright's vaunted dislike for that American standby, the front porch,'' I took a moment to think about our own porch and realized how favored we have been to inherit it, along with our late 18th-century clapboard Colonial house. It runs along the whole front so may have been constructed only when an addition was built in the 1830's.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE Presidential conferences that Hofstra University has sponsored annually since 1982 are designed to offer scholarly assessments of the careers and programs of the men who held office. They are not, insists Dr.

title: Nicaragua Opposition Paper Tells of Sandinista Warning
description: The editor of Nicaragua's only opposition newspaper has been warned that the Sandinista Government ''will watch him closely'' for ties to armed rebels, the newspaper said.

title: COLORFUL JACKETS
description: The sport coat has been a popular item in men's wardrobes for years.

title: Reagan to Honor Truman
description: President Reagan has selected Harry S. Truman and Elie Wiesel to be honored with the Congressional Medal, the highest civilian award authorized by Congress, it was announced Friday. Mr. Wiesel, an author, teacher and expert on the Holocaust, will receive the medal in April. The medal for President Truman will be given Tuesday to Margaret Truman Daniel, his daughter.

title: IMPRUDENCE DECISION: IMPACT ON LILCO UNCERTAIN
description: TWO State Public Service Commission judges this month found that the Long Island Lighting Company had committed acts of ''imprudence,'' a sin that the typical Lilco customer might have thought ranked with blasphemy and witchcraft on a list of forgotten threats.

title: FLAG DAY SPURS AN ISSUE FEATURING THE CAPITOL
description: The first ''double-width'' United States booklet stamp, depicting the United States flag flying over the Capitol, will be released Friday at Waubeka, Wis. Five booklet stamps will make up a pane to be sold only from vending machines. A stamp with similar design in sheet and coil versions will be released at the same time in Washington, D.C.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CRANES AT DUSK. By Hisako Matsubara. Translated by Leila Vennewitz. (Dial, $15.95.)

title: LIVING WITH A BLUEBERRY PATCH
description: Patricia Taylor is a freelance writer and amateur gardener.

title: A GREENWICH ARTIST BUILDS HER CAREER IN 'ART FURNITURE'
description: JUDY HENDERSON of Greenwich has been serious about her art for a long time - struggling with illustrations for children's books and greeting cards as well as textile designs and ceramic wall hangings. It was not until last summer, though, with the introduction of her ''art furniture'' that her career really took off.

title: 12 MONOLOGUES ON BEING A WOMAN
description: ''TALKING WITH...,'' the latest offering from the Studio Theater, is a collection of monologues written by Jane Martin, each detailing one aspect of various women's lives.

title: LAUREATE OF CULTURAL CONFUSIONS
description: BEYOND THE DRAGON'S MOUTH Stories and Pieces. By Shiva Naipaul. 424 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: MAYOR'S RACE STARTS EARLY IN YONKERS
description: early in an election year -

title: Foyt-Wollek Wins Sebring
description: A. J. Foyt and Bob Wollek, sharing one of the intimidating Porsche 962 prototypes, outdistanced a strong field today on the way to a four-lap victory in the Coca-Cola 12 Hours of Sebring.

title: LOOKING THE PART
description: John Vinocur is the Paris bureau chief of The Times. Apart from the historical references to his schoolyard, the author is indebted to ''Le Costume Image de l'Homme,'' by Yvonne Deslandres, for some of the article's erudition. qsf9963wqcc17.6,18,9,11wqif.9wqxrqahqef In my schoolyard, there was a guy named Cookie. Cookie came in costume. Perfectly pressed chinos, sweatshirt rolled meticulously above the elbows, and the right sneakers: Spaldings for a while, because that was what the guys wore at Loughlin and St. Ann's and Madison and Jeff, and then Converse, when they somehow seized the market, and you weren't a ballplayer if you didn't have a pair. High-tops, low-cuts, white, black - Cookie maintained a full selection. He changed them with his mood, his fantasies. When he had his black low-cuts on, Cookie used to elbow and scramble, his being transmogrified into Jim Loscutoff, the Celtics brawler. White high-tops meant a different persona: Cookie would flop around shouting, ''Ron Bontemps, the bounding Ron Bontemps,'' his brain filled with incantation, certain it could will his body some grace. Ron Bontemps was a thin blond who played for Beloit in the Garden once and left an imprint on Cookie. He was less a person than a concept, and Cookie, like a man disguised in a suit of feathers and flapping his wings, must have thought that if he dressed like Bontemps and howled his name, he could fly too.

title: 47,000 Corvettes Recalled
description: The General Motors Corporation has day recalled 47,000 of its 1984 Chevrolet Corvette sports cars for repair of the cruise control systems, which it said could cause ''unexpected engine acceleration.'' Some customers in colder climates had complained that their cruise controls were acting up and a check showed that a part in the solenoid, an electrical coil, could corrode, Ed Lechtzin, a spokesman for General Motors, said Thursday. Dealers will replace the part and relocate it under the hood so it is not as exposed to the elements, Mr. Lechtzin said.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: From a recent commencement speech by Najeeb E. Halaby, former chief executive officer of Pan American World Airways and Federal Aviation Administrator and now president of the Halaby International Corporation, at Dowling College in Oakdale:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WIER & POUCE. By Steve Katz. (Sun & Moon, Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $10.95.)

title: TEXAS HILL COUNTRY, MACHU PICCHU TREK
description: Cowboy Artists Hold Benefit With a longhorn cattle drive, including chuck wagon food and a chance to sleep under the stars in a cowboy bedroll - as well as such less rugged events as a dance and a champagne brunch - the Cowboy Artists of America Museum will mark its second anniversary May 9 through 11.

title: GULF BATTLE: A WINNER, BUT NO VICTOR
description: Although Iraq apparently won the largest battle of its long war with Iran last week, neither army performed with great skill, according to experts, who added that they did not see it as a decisive victory that was likely to turn the war completely in Iraq's favor. An analyst of Middle East military affairs said one of the main lessons of the fighting was that both sides find it difficult to exploit success, to react rapidly to unforseen events and to coordinate airpower, artillery and ground forces. An American official called it ''the slow-motion war.''

title: OLD HABITS DON'T DIE, THEY DON'T EVEN FADE AWAY
description: THERE are some things you never get over. I don't mean things lke deaths, divorces and other major disasters. Oddly enough, those are the things that you eventually do get over. I mean simple things. Like the eating habits, for instance, that you learned in childhood. I still never eat the doughy insides of a roll or a piece of bread. I can see my father now, sitting at the head of the table, slowly pulling out the soft white stuff from a roll, while we three girls watched and listened with awe as he made his dire pronouncement.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

COINAGE PROPOSALS WILL HONOR MISS LIBERTY
description: Prospects are bright that Congress will authorize three special coins to honor the Statue of Liberty on its centennial. The House of Representatives approved the proposal in a voice vote March 5 and early passage also is expected in the Senate. Indications are that the coins could be ready for issuance as early as this fall.

title: FLYERS OUTLAST SLUMPING DEVILS
description: The Philadelphia Flyers today demonstrated once again why they have the most victories in the National Hockey League.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE GERMAN JEW: A Synthesis of Judaism and Western Civilization, 1730-1930. By H. I. Bach. (Oxford University, $24.95.)

title: Article 115842 -- No Title
description: ''high hopes'' that his offer to purchase Monmouth Park for an estimated $35 million would soon be accepted. Acquiring Monmouth would give Brennan's International Thoroughbred Breeders ownership of the three major tracks in the South

title: START NEARS ON PLAN TO CURB TEEN-AGE PREGNANCIES
description: A year after Governor Cuomo proclaimed a new approach to combating pregnancy among teen-agers - stressing jobs and self- awareness instead of birth control - the state is about to pick ''finalists'' among private agencies to put the program into effect.

title: CITY STYLES ;   WASHINGTON
description: The chairman of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Roger L. Stevens, confesses to occasionally donning walking shorts when he heads for his office on a summer Saturday. And even the more staid members of Congress, who normally embrace the uniform look of dark suits and blue ties, have been known to break out the pink shirts and sport jackets when they are called in for a late-night or Saturday session. But for the most part, summer or winter, this city is pretty buttoned-down when it comes to men's fashions.

title: Managing The Mets: The Future Is Now
description: DAVEY JOHNSON, THE MANAGER OF the New York Mets, has just been asked what managers do in the off-season. It turns out, in this particular case, not to be much. This is spring training and Johnson has spent the last several months fishing, traveling and tending to his private real- estate interests, while the real work concerning the ball club was getting done elsewhere. The right fielder Darryl Strawberry was shaking off the effects of a disappointing sophomore season, the front office was dickering with the Montreal Expos, eventually wangling a deal for the catcher Gary Carter, perhaps the most significant trade in the Mets' history. "I'll tell you what;" Johnson says, "this was one of those winters when I didn't have to worry much."

title: Defense Expenditures
description: To the Editor:

title: SIPPING AND SNACKING
description: In recent years New York City's public atriums have become more than merely places to study urban architecture or pick up a newspaper - they have become comfortable places to enjoy a glass of wine, a cup of espresso with a pastry, or a full meal. Following are a few of the more pleasant places to take a break for a snack or a meal.

title: WHAT'S IN A (STREET) NAME?
description: ARRIVING in the outer reaches of Fairfield County (also called upcountry or back country), is not easy. I am not referring to arriving economically or socially. That aspect of life has been done to death by people far more qualified than I, who are no doubt living in Hoboken, N.J. I mean physically arriving, showing up someplace, getting there.

title: NEEDED: EXPERTS TO SERVICE OUR ELECTRONIC WAY OF LIFE
description: AS the consumer-electronics industry hums ahead into the age of high technology, it adds fuel to the nationwide demand for more and better-trained service technicians. The sophisticated new products taking over the living rooms of America - stereo and digital televisions, video-cassette recorders and compact disk players, for instance - need the same tender loving care that the old radio console did. And they are being churned out and snapped up at such a tremendous pace that service technicians will find no shortage of job opportunities.

title: Medicare's Broken Promise
description: I congratulate Andrew Stein for his article, ''Medicare's Broken Promise,'' (Feb. 17). Indeed, Medicare does not satisfy the economic aspect of health-care need.

title: 200 Feared Drowned In Bangladesh River
description: A ferry capsized in the Burhi Ganga River today, and a fire brigade official said it was feared that more than 200 passengers had drowned.

title: Strange Campaign Against Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Ferryboats
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A Postings item Feb. 17 on a new office development at 527 Madison Avenue omitted the name of one architect. It is the WZMH Group.

title: SUDAN LETS U.S. FLY 800 ETHIOPIA JEWS TO ISRAELI REFUGE
description: The United States, in a secret operation, today completed the evacuation of virtually all the Ethiopian Jews who were left in the Sudan after an Israeli-sponsored airlift was halted, Administration officials said.

title: OUTLOOK FOR THE GERMANYS: A WARMING TREND
description: Encouraged by the improvement in relations between the Soviet Union and the United States, East Germany's Communist leadership has signaled that it is ready to resume stepped-up exchanges with West Germany.

title: BLACK DRIVER PLANS TO BE FIRTS AT INDY
description: Willy T. Ribbs is one of the hottest names in motor sports right now. And if the 28-year-old Californian succeeds this May in his plan to become the first black dirver to race in the Indianapolis 500, his name may become as well known to the public as those of Mario Andretti and Rick Mears.

title: Heavy Mail
description: Brooklyn residents of the Park Slope section were upset over uncertain mail deliveries, with magazines and newspapers sometimes arriving 10 days late. Assemblyman Melvin H. Miller, who represents the district, called a protest meeting last summer.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Interesting, variegated music weaves through some choice film fare on cable this week, starting with ''Sapphire, '' which will be shown on Sunday at 10 A.M. on WHT. In this excellent 1959 whodunit about racial tensions in London, a jazzy pulse heightens the suspense and umderscores the city's night-life background.

title: OFFICERS ASSAILED IN HIT-RUN CASE
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said in an interview to be broadcast today that he was having difficulty obtaining testimony from the two police officers who were passengers in the patrol car that struck and killed a psychologist on Park Avenue at 72d Street.

title: Bhopal's FatalChain of Events
description: What went so deadly wrong in Bhopal, and why? The results of a post-mortem released last week by Union Carbide, the chemical giant that is the majority-owner of the Indian plant where the world's worst industrial accident occurred, laid the blame not with American technology but rather the Indians whose job it was to run it.

title: ROOKIES' DREAMS THRIVE IN THE SUN OF YOUNG SEASON
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.

title: MARKETING THIRD AVE. AS A CHIC ADDRESS
description: AT the intersection of Third Avenue and 60th Street are the rear entrance to Bloomingdale's, several movie theaters, four brownstone tenements, a 16-story, off-white brick apartment building, and shops selling pizza, bagels, antiques and shoes. The commercial and architectural jumble is typical of this part of Third Avenue, which once was a back alley for the Upper East Side.

title: HOW ALEX KATZ PUTS POWER ON CANVAS
description: A typical paradox of the artist Alex Katz's career is that a critic once approvingly referred to his reputation as ''a visionary of the shallow, glossy side of life.'' Another time an admiring critic proclaimed that his paintings project ''modesty, bluntness, awkward striving and a desire for suavity.'' Indeed, even the artist himself describes his paintings as ''big and bland with great technique.''

title: 4-DAY WEEK AT SKI FACTORY WINS PRAISE
description: There is little to distinguish the Olin Ski Company's factory here from many others.

title: SUPPORT FOR CANCER PATIENTS
description: DR. BERNARD S. SIEGEL, a New Haven surgeon, said the advice he gives to his cancer patients applies to all people and should be incorporated into medical training.

title: THE SIDEWALKS OF NEW YORK -- INDOORS
description: When Chemical Bank announced a few years ago that it was going to upgrade its new headquarters, a 1960's skyscraper on Park Avenue, by adding a glass-enclosed public park onto the building's front, the architect, Michael Maas, spoke of his task as ''turning a frog into a prince.''

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN RIDGEWOOD
description: RIDGEWOOD has traditionally been a closely knit ethnic community, where houses are passed down from generation to generation, where European languages can be heard in the streets and where, in the summer, neighbors sit on their front stoops and chat.

title: USING THE MX AS A LEVER ON MOSCOW, AND VICE VERSA
description: WASHINGTON WHEN the United States and the Soviet Union embark on major arms negotiations the action unfolds in two arenas, the private world of negotiators grappling with arcane nuclear calculations and the public world of political leaders grappling with the moods of mass opinion. Experience has taught both superpowers that they can gain bargaining leverage if they can swing world opinion to their side with a show of strength and assertions of good faith and serious intent.

title: CEMETERY FOR VETERANS TO OPEN IN FALL
description: NORTH HANOVER TWP. THE scheduled opening of a state-owned and -operated veterans cemetery here this September, at the site of a former corrections work farm, is being hailed by veterans groups and Veterans Administration officials.

title: Pakistan's Parliament Reopens After 8 Years
description: Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq reopened Parliament today after a nearly eight-year hiatus and was sworn in as President for another five years.

title: COOL AND CORRECT
description: Some spring and summer, a man's thoughts generally lead to vacations, long weekends away from the city and other matters that pertain to leisure time. These are idyllic subjects, but reality remains. And in the real world of most men, there is the Monday-to-Friday business of business. In addressing the needs of a wardrobe for summer, it is every bit as important that clothing be appropriate and comfortable as it is in winter. The weight and coloration of business attire may, of course, be adjusted to the season, but attention to detail and the projection of executive polish remain essential.

description: GREENWICH, which has 10 golf courses, four yacht clubs and a Rolls- Royce dealership, is about to lose its only factory.

title: GEMAYEL MEETS ASSAD ON LEBANESE CHRISTIAN REVOLT
description: President Amin Gemayel held talks in Damascus today with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria amid signs that Syria is reassessing its role in Lebanon.

title: Catherine Clifford Engaged to Marry Nicolas Koechlin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Clifford of Montclair, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Catherine Clifford to Nicolas Baker Koechlin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard A. Koechlin, also of Montclair. A September wedding is planned.

title: TEAR-OUTS, PULL-OUTS, FILL-OUTS - HOW CAN WE READ?
description: HAVE you noticed that insert cards are threatening to take over our magazines? Cards of all shapes and sizes - tear-out cards, pull-out cards, loose cards, fold-out cards - and now the final intruder: the perfume sample cards.

title: ENOUGH HAND-WRINGING BY THE DOMOCRATS
description: Surely, many Americans are weary of hearing and reading about the Democrats' self- flagellation. Like me, they are fed up with pundits' themes of doom and gloom. What's alarming is that we Democrats are adding credibility to the political obituaries that appear steadily in the media. Let's put the Democrats' situation in better perspective.

title: FUTURE UNCERTAIN, SIKHS CAMP AT GOLDEN TEMPLE
description: In small rooms blackened by fire and smoke in the Golden Temple complex here, scores of Sikh refugee families who fled anti-Sikh violence after the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi have set up temporary homes as they try to settle in the Punjab or await word that they can return home.

title: SOIL THREAT PERSISTS
description: -contaminated soil from 16 residential properties here and in neighboring Rochelle Park did much to ease residents' anxieties, but state and Federal environmental officials say the problem will remain for years.

description: The Rockefeller University in New York and the Weizmann Institute of Science in Israel are forming a collaborative foundation for biomedical research with a multimillion-dollar gift from a New York industrialist and his family.

description: Control of two of the biggest companies in communications shifted dramatically last week, with uncertain consequences for the nation's big and little screens.

title: Deborah R. Keeshan Marries David Peirce
description: Deborah Ryan Keeshan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Keeshan Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to David Christopher Peirce, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Peirce Jr. of Amherst, Mass. The Rev. Charles Stubbs performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Ridgefield, Conn., with the Rev. Lawrence Bernier Law, the concelebrant of the nuptial mass.

title: Bail Denied in Clinic Blasts
description: A Federal judge on Friday again denied bail for two men charged with bombing abortion clinics, saying they might take freedom as a sign to bomb again. The two men, Matthew Goldsby and James Simmons of nearby Cantonment, who are both 21 years old, have admitted bombing four clinics last year, but have pleaded not guilty to Federal charges of conspiracy and violating explosives and firearms laws.

title: U.S. LOSING GROUND IN ELECTRONICS
description: LOS ANGELES NO ONE seems certain exactly when, but some time last year, for the first time, the United States began to import more electronics products than it was selling abroad.

title: MANY IN POLL PREFER SMALL TOWNS
description: Although most Americans live in or near cities, nearly half of them would move to places with 10,000 people or fewer if they had the chance, according to a recent Gallup Poll.

title: SIOUX PASTOR SEEKS YOUTH CENTER AID
description: HENRY GOOD BEAR preaches at a different church every Sunday. As pastor-at-large of 14 Sioux churches spread over 300 miles and eight reservations in three Great Plains states, it is not unusual for this Congregational minister to drive 10,000 miles in a month.

description: Yankees vs. Mets , at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 1:30 P.M. This is the second exhibition meeting between the teams this spring. Last Tuesday in St. Petersburg, the Mets raked Ed Whitson for 6 runs on 10 hits in 2 innings in an 8-2 victory. (Television - Channel 11, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770 and WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.)

title: Rites of Spring,Albany-Style
description: Closed-door budget negotiations and impassioned legislative debates over capital punishment - two rites of the season - marked the date last week in Albany more decisively than did the weather. Spring had arrived.

title: ZOOT SIMS, 59, SAXOPHONIST RENOWNED IN JAZZ
description: Zoot Sims, a saxophonist who played in the bands of Benny Goodman, Woody Herman and Stan Kenton, and who for more than 30 years traveled the world as an internationally acclaimed jazz star, died of cancer yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 59 years old and lived in West Nyack, N.Y.

description: TRENTON

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Italy Appoints Official To Lead Mafia Fight
description: The Italian Cabinet has appointed a new High Commissioner to coordinate the fight against the Mafia.

title: SUFFOLK LIFE PAPER SET FOR EXPANSION
description: THERE'S no sign on the large renovated building on Route 58 (Old Country Road) in Riverhead. It used to be a discount department store, but now, because of the lack of identification, the size of the building and the number of cars parked in front of it, most visitors mistake it for the Riverhead Motor Vehicle Office.

title: DEVELOPMENT PUSHES NORTH
description: With the exception of a modest amount of light industry and a strip of bedroom communities along the Hudson River, Dutchess County has remained, for the most part, rural.

title: Correction
description: Because of erroneous information supplied by UPI/ Bettmann Newsphotos, an incorrect photograph and caption accompanied the review of ''Geneen'' March 10. The photograph was of Francis J. Dunleavy, a former president of the ITT Corporation.

title: BREAKING AWAY FOR WEEKENDS
description: Among the pleasures of summer is time away from work when a man can do whatever he wants: sail, golf, entertain, or just relax. For these casual occasions, there are many new variations on classic clothes that are comfortable and look correct. Several examples are shown here and on following pages.

title: Jean Lint Engaged
description: Jean Elizabeth Lint, a senior media planner with Young & Rubicam, and Edward Clay Mason, a commercial real-estate broker with Helmsley- Spear, plan to be married in June, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Phillip E. Lint of Westport, Conn., have announced. Miss Lint is a graduate of Franklin and Marshall College, as is her fiance, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Mason of Wayne, N.J. Her father is a partner in the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse in New York. Mr. Mason's father is a senior communications consultant with the Allied Corporation in Morristown, N.J.

title: Court Lifts LidOn PAC Money
description: The right to free speech also includes the right to spend freely, the Supreme Court said last week. By 7 to 2, the Justices struck down the $1,000 legal limit on the amount that independent political action committees can spend on behalf of Presidential candidates.

title: Inquiry Ordered
description: Dick Tamburo, the Arizona State athletic director, ordered an investigation into a report that Sun Devil baseball players had been using a prescription antidepressant to improve their stamina and performance. Tamburo acted after The Arizona Republic reported that at least eight members of the team had used or been prescribed the drug Nardil. The drug is not banned by Pacific 10 Conference rules.

title: THE FADING ENTREPRENEUR
description: AMERICA'S BUSINESS By James Oliver Robertson. 277 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $17.95.

EMERGING CAREERS;

TECHNOLOGISTS THRIVE IN FINANCIAL WORLD
description: -earnings ratios or mortgage lending rates are not the only ones in demand today for jobs in financial services. Securities firms and commercial banks are also hungry for those with a variety of technology-related skills.

title: More Blacks DieIn South Africa
description: South Africa's police have given blacks a new reason to remember March 21, the date that 69 anti-apartheid demonstrators were shot to death at Sharpeville in 1960. Last week, perhaps because of fear of new unrest on the 25th anniversary, the police fired again.

title: CHECKING THE MIRTH RATE
description: WASHINGTON For exactly 100 years, the Gridiron Club has been trying to improve the mirth rate in Washington, but it's a hard assignment.

title: Katherine Reynolds Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Richard Samuel Reynolds 3d and Sally Owen Reynolds, both of Richmond, of the engagement of their daughter Katherine Louise Reynolds to George Paul Barsness, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Erling Ormseth Barsness of Ligonier, Pa.

title: FOR THE WOMEN, STILL A LONG WAY TO GO
description: Although a gowing number of young women are studying the quantitatively-based disciplines that prepare them for careers in science, engineering and computer science, their prospects for employment and advancement in industry and academia drag woefully behind those for men. ''Ten years ago, many us thought that merit would be recognized and rewarded in these fields regardless of a person's gender, but we've been proved totally wrong,'' said Betty Vettor, Executive Director of the Scientific Manpower Commission, ''I don't expect opportunities to equalize within the next twenty years,'' she added. Still, Dr. Vettor and others point out, women have been making inroads into scientific, engineering and computer fields. Between 1965 and 1982 (the latest year for which figures are available), there was a 10 percent increase in the number of women majoring in the physical and life sciences, engineering, mathematics and computer science, according to ''The Professional Women and Minorities'' report of the Scientific Manpower Commission. On the graduate level, the growth was somewhat higher: a 12 percent increase in master's degrees and a 15 percent increase in doctoral degrees. These increased percentages do not, however, point to a change in women's preferences about career fields, according to Sue E. Berryman, a resident consultant with the Rand Corporation in Washington, D.C. They simply reflect the growing representation of women in all fields in college. ''As long as girls expect to assume the major child-rearing responsibilities of their families, they will be less likely than boys to choose quantitative occupations that require major educational and labor force commitments,'' said Dr. Berryman, who conducted the study, ''Who Will Do Science?'' for the Rockefeller Foundation.

title: THE HARSH VOICE OF THE FRENCH RIGHT
description: What will make Jean- Marie Le Pen and his racist National Front go away? These days, after the party's showing in the French regional elections over the past two Sundays, there are not many promising answers for those whom the question worries. For the time being at least, the party has a bit of unpleasant sociology working for it, and the good possibility of riding into the National Assembly next year under a proportional representation plan that President Fran,cois Mitterrand is expected to write into an electoral reform bill. In the regional contest, Mr. Le Pen did somewhat less well than he might have liked, electing only one regional council member, Jean Roussel, who was fined last week for signing a racist leaflet in a southern district. But Mr. Roussel could point to the more than 8 per cent of the electorate that backed his candidates. Amid much vague rhetoric, the Front's single unmistakable thesis is that immigrants, essentially Arabs and Africans, are equivalent to crime and disruption, and should be sent home. The rest of the party line appears to depend on the audience; it can include anti-Semitic innuendo, the Vichy regime's gospel of family, work and nationhood or talk of denationalizing French industry. A worrisome aspect of the National Front is that it is more than a remake of the traditional extreme right in France. That element, with its classic components of monarchists, authoritarians and Roman Catholic traditionalists, detested the republic, capitalism, and the parliamentary system.

title: MANAGING THE METS: THE FUTURE IS NOW
description: Bruce Weber is a lifelong Yankee fan who is rooting for a subway series. DAVEY JOHNSON, THE MANAGER OF the New York Mets, has just been asked what managers do in the off-season. It turns out, in this particular case, not to be much. This is spring training and Johnson has spent the last several months fishing, traveling and tending to his private real- estate interests, while the real work concerning the ball club was getting done elsewhere. The right fielder Darryl Strawberry was shaking off the effects of a disappointing sophomore season, the front office was dickering with the Montreal Expos, eventually wangling a deal for the catcher Gary Carter, perhaps the most significant trade in the Mets' history. ''I'll tell you what;'' Johnson says, ''this was one of those winters when I didn't have to worry much.''

He is 14 months old.

A three-year investigation found that two-thirds of all Tank watches, lighters, bracelets and the like were purchased without benefit of New York City's 8.25 percent sales tax. Not a penny was paid on more than 90 percent of the items worth $10,000 or more.

SPIRIT OF THE 60'S REVISITED IN SHOW

In retrospect, it seems shortsighted to have thought that quality and originality progressed in a straight line. It was neat to have theories so nicely packaged, but that was clearly an oversimplification.

title: POLO SHIRTS-THE NEW BREED
description: Emblematic or not, polo shirts are now worn by more men to play the ponies than to ride them. It wasn't always so. The first polo shirt - a white, short-sleeved, wool-jersey pullover with a turned-down collar - was designed in the early 1900's to allow freedom of mallet-swinging movement. Form followed a polo player's function. Back then, no tennis player, self-respecting or otherwise, would ever have presumed to appear courtside in other than a normal white shirt, sleeves only occasionally rolled.

The first - passage by Congress and then ratification by three- fourths of the state legislatures - is the path that has been used for all 26 amendments. The second, which allows for two-thirds of the state legislatures to call upon Congress to convene a Constitutional Convention, has never been used successfully.

title: WHYS AND WHEREFORES OF DEPOSIT INSURANCE
description: For a week, Ohio's privately insured savings and loan associations have been closed by Gov. Richard F. Celeste. In the first bank holiday called to stem a run on financial institutions since the Great Depression, only a handful of the 71 savings and loans has reopened. It remains uncertain when the rest will, and some may never open their doors again. Some of the S&Ls' 500,000 depositors may lose money. The run was sparked by the failure of the Home State Savings Bank of Cincinnati earlier this month. Home State went under. It did so after losing an estimated $150 million when an obscure Florida-based firm, E.S.M. Government Securities, went bankrupt at least partly because of fraud. That wiped out the $136 million reserve of the Ohio Deposit Guarantee Fund.Ohio's difficulties raise the issue of the stability of the entire banking system. Questions and answers on that subject follow.

title: TOWNS NEED AID FOR LOCAL ROADS

In his book ''The Octagon House, a Home for All,'' Fowler proposed a campaign against the square as the basic form for architectural thinking.

title: A POCKET TALISMAN
description: To get my first pocket knife, I had to resort to theft, I was 10. I sold my soul for my second pocket knife when I was 12; gave my third away, as a token of thanks, at age 23; and constantly tap my hip pocket to this day, 14 years later, making sure I've kept possession of my fourth pocket knife. No easy thing. You possess a pocket knife, but only for a time. I suspect they are a breed of possession that all of us must own in common. Like gloves,umbrellas,eye glasses and all manner of writing instruments, short of word processors, they are difficult to hold on to; they tend to fly off and relocate, seemingly of their ouwn accord.They belong to the world, and domesticated as they appear to be, they are wild. The low fence of memory can't corral them.

There, on a Sunday afternoon not long ago, these are some of the people who passed by in the course of an ordinary lunch:

title: 10 YEARS LATER, LESSONS OF THE VIETNAM WAR
description: Ten years after the fall of Saigon, the debate over American involvement in Vietnam remains unresolved. Was it a ''noble cause,'' as President Reagan has said, or an immoral adventure in imperialism, as some of the antiwar activists contended at the time? Was it an honorably intended but strategically misconceived stand against the forces of aggression, or was it a misbegotten manifestation of the arrogance of American power?

description: MARY PAT BURTON has backpacked in Ecuador and Greece, sunbathed in Hawaii and Rio de Janeiro, walked in the Everglades, and flown hot-air balloons. Since she is ''happiest when I'm flying,'' she asked herself last year, ''why not'' try to go to outer space?

description: LOS ANGELES

title: LETTING IN MORE LIGHT
description: Few architectural devices have captured the imagination of designers and developers in the last decade as has the atrium. Yet another example is being created at Kensington Plaza, a 39-unit condominium under construction at 123 Middle Neck Road in Great Neck, L.I. Here the atrium is being employed to draw in natural light and add architectural interest to the building's lobby.

title: A ROOT OF GOODNESS
description: IF I WERE to name my favorite herbs, the list would certainly include horseradish - a pungent root that, in a relative sense, is little used in American kitchens. Asked what it is used for, the home cook is most likely to answer, ''In a cocktail sauce'' or ''With roast beef.''

title: THE COURTS, THE LAW AND CHILDREN'S RIGHTS
description: Shocked by a seeming epidemic of crimes against children, state legislators across the country are churning out bills aimed at dealing with missing, abducted and sexually abused youngsters. According to the National Conference of State Legislatures, 265 such bills have been introduced so far this year, twice the total for all of 1984.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

NOBODY PLASTIC IS ALIEN TO HIM
description: Duane Hanson's extraordinarily lifelike sculptures - of washerwomen, football players, janitors - provoke astonished reactions in viewers, who frequently walk past them several times before realizing they are inanimate. Two questions usually follow this realization: But is it art? And how does he do it? In DUANE HANSON (Abrams, Cloth, $37.50, Paper, $16.95), Kirk Varnedoe, an associate professor of art history at New York University's Institute of Fine Arts, tries to answer both questions. An interview with the sculptor, in which he explains his artistic goals, and Mr. Varnedoe's thoughtful introduction, linking Mr. Hanson's work to the traditions of realist art, persuasively recommend the sculptor for more serious critical consideration than he has thus far received. There is also an illustrated step-by-step guide in which Mr. Hanson explains his method of working. After taking plaster casts from a human model and filling the casts with a polyester resin mixture, he solders together the body parts, retouches the whole and paints it a flesh tone. He then injects hair in clumps into the figure's ''skin,'' paints in features and dresses the sculpture with the appropriate accessories. Some 60 color illustrations of Mr. Hanson's work - most in private collections and museums - from the last two decades demonstrate his developing mastery of this technique, as well as a steady shift in focus. From overtly political subjects in the late 1960's and early 70's - a war scene, a race riot - he has turned to more subtle commentary on the quality of lower-middle-class American life.

title: GETTING VANDENBERG OFF THE GROUND
description: On a windy knoll bristling with huge towers and concrete bunkers, technicians assigned to the new space launching complex at Vandenberg Air Force Base last week completed a dress rehearsal of sorts.

title: LEFT'S PRESIDENTIAL CHOICE GAINS GROUND IN GREEK PARLIAMENT
description: The Greek Parliament failed today for a second time to elect the Government's candidate as President. But it appeared that a coalition of Socialists and Communists would succeed on the final ballot next week.

title: POLLON LEAVING MUSIC CONSERVATORY POST
description: -SIX years ago a newly trained pianist and conductor named Michael Pollon arrived in the United States from Czechoslovakia. Having studied with George Szell in Prague, the young man hoped to find a position here as a conductor. But the exodus from Europe on the eve of World War II had included many fine and experienced musicians. The audience for classical music was much smaller than today's, and many conductors and pianists were out of work.

title: THE BIRTH AND SLOW ACCEPTANCE OF 'JOE EGG'
description: A comedy involving a child about as seriously brain- damaged as any human being could be? When Peter Nichols's play, ''A Day in the Death of Joe Egg,'' first appeared on Broadway 17 years ago, that seemed a pretty gruesome contradiction. The critics, though generally appreciative, were clearly nervous about the play, as were its producers; they sold it to the New York public as a vehicle for the leading man, Albert Finney, sometimes omitting to mention its author's name in advertisements. The result was inevitable. ''The theater was packed every performance for 11 weeks,'' remembers Mr. Nichols, ''but then Albert left the cast, and the audiences simply disappeared.'' Not long afterward the play closed.

title: Patricia Forenza Wed To Theodore Howard
description: Patricia Ann Forenza, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aurelio G. Forenza of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Theodore Sherwin Howard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Howard of Orinda, Calif. The Rev. Edward Roos performed the ceremony at SS.

title:
THE MARKET;

A DOWN TIME IN TECHNOLOGICAL INDUSTRIES
description: EARLIER this month Apple Computer, in its first production shutdown, announced it was closing four factories for a week because of an oversupply of computers brought about by sluggish sales. Last month the Intel Corporation, one of the largest semiconductor manufacturers in California's ''Silicon Valley,'' announced it was laying off 900 employees, its first job cutback in 10 years. It joined several other computer-chip manufacturers, including Texas Instruments, National Semiconductor, which is trimming 400 jobs, Monolithic Memories, Zilog Inc., Seeq Technology and Micron Technology, which recently announced that it would cut up to half its work force of 1,250 employees.

description: Having sampled what Norway has to offer in the way of cross-country skiing at such popular areas as the Hardanger plateau and the Rondane and Jotenheimen mountains, we decided it was time to try something different. So last Easter we signed up for an 11-day ski trip to Norwegian Lapland, which is sometimes called the ''top of the world.''

Always a job where negotiating skills are in order, the Labor post at the moment much requires them.

title: EXECUTIVE EDUCATION'S UNCONVENTIONAL SIDE
description: EXECUTIVE education grows into a bigger business every year. In 1984, corporate America wrote checks for about $71.5 million to colleges and universities for post-degree courses that ranged from two- hour quickie seminars to multiyear programs. And this year, predicts Ray Watson, assistant dean of Duke University's Fuqua School of Business, that figure will hit nearly $83 million.

title: IN BOLIVIA, LABOR PEACE TAKES A BIG CHECK

ART;

SEEKING PLEASURES IN SHOW OF 77 WORKS

The three jurors - Berta Walker, director of the Graham Modern Gallery in Manhattan; the artist Burt Silverman and Laura Rosenstock, an assistant curator at the Museum of Modern Art - selected 77 pieces from more than 650 entries, and their choices echo the sedateness and conservatism that characterized the show last year.

title: FROM NEIL SIMON: A NEW FILM, A NEW PLAY
description: Six young soldiers make a bet early in ''Biloxi Blues,'' the new Neil Simon play. Each soldier says what he would do in his last week on earth and the one with the best fantasy takes the $30 pot. Most of them talk about women or money or combinations involving both, but a recruit from Queens named Arnold Epstein wins: he wants to see the platoon's sergeant do 500 push-ups. ''It never fails,'' Wykowski, one of the other soldiers, then says. ''It's always the Jews who end up with the money.''

title: CHILDREN'S FUNDING TERMED STINGY
description: HARTFORD AN analysis of state spending has concluded that although more money is being allocated, children's programs are receiving a shrinking share of the state budget.

title: THE MARKET ;   EVERY REGION GETS INTO THE TECHNOLOGY ACT
description: WHEN Ann Gleason scouted for a job as a design engineer, she decided to go West. All her life she had lived in the East - Virginia, Massachusetts, New Jersey - and she wanted to sample the Western life-style. ''I didn't want to deal with 'Silicon Valley,' with its high cost of living and its congestion,'' she recalled, so she picked Portland, Ore. Six months ago, Miss Gleason began work at the Lattice Semiconductor Corporation in Portland, and she delights in both the job and the location.

title: COOL AND CORRECT-SUMMER SUITS
description: Today, pale brown, banker's gray and blue business suits are appropriate for spring from Wall Street to the Sun Belt. In both single-and double-breasted versions, they often have textural interest and lend themselves to a variety of furnishings that keep a man looking cool and confident-even on sweltering days.

title: PamelaStehli Plans to Wed
description: Peter Henry Stehli of Westport, Conn., and Joan Thompson Gilmour of Alexandria, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Hays Stehli, to Paul Gregory Hearne, a son of Mrs. Peter R. Hearne Jr. of Floral Park, L.I., and the late Mr. Hearne. A September wedding is planned.

title: ADMINISTRATION SEEKS A STRONGER LOCK ON 'CLASSIFIED' FILES
description: Presidents have complained for decades about Government secrets showing up in the morning paper or on the evening news.

title: Cromwell's Career
description: To the Editor:

title: DALLAS
description: This is a city where summer days with temperatures below 90 degrees are about as common as liberal politicians, which is to say they are very rare indeed. But given a choice between comfort and propriety, Dallas businessmen invariably choose the latter, even if it means some long, uncomfortable afternoons.

title: Marjorie Rawl Arnold Plans to Marry May 17
description: Marjorie Rawl Arnold, an account executive at Benton & Bowles, the advertising agency in New York, and Eugene Dorr Biddle Jr., a partner in K. S. Sweet Associates, a real-estate and financial advisory firm in Princeton, N.J., plan to be married May 17.

title: Speaking Out On D.H. Rule
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FILM FORUM: Thirty-Five Top Filmmakers Discuss Their Craft. By Ellen Oumano. (St. Martin's, $15.95.)

title:
CAREER DEVELOPMENT;

MEET THE 'HEADHUNTERS' OF THE SILICON JUNGLE
description: THE ritual of finding employment in the silicon jungle is enough to try the patience of even the most accomplished executive, engineer, data processor and systems analyst. As a result, many high-technology candidates leave their career moves in the hands of ''headhunters,'' whose business it is to know both where the jobs are and what they're really worth.

title: Scott Janzen Wed To Sara Gordon
description: Sara Beth Gordon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon S. Gordon of New York, and Scott David Janzen, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Curtis J. Janzen of Baltimore, were married yesterday at the Hotel Pierre. Judge Richard M. Palmer of Family Court officiated.

title: CALIFORNIA ADDICTS USE LEGAL, SYNTHETIC NARCOTICS
description: One or more chemists working in secret California laboratories are turning out synthetic versions of heroin and cocaine that addicts say are indistinguishable from the naturally derived drugs.

title: PLANS TO BUILD ALONG RARITAN GATHER SPEED
description: THREE and a half years ago, Assemblyman David C. Schwartz took a group of people on a boat ride up the Raritan River ''to see the beauty and the tragedy of this waterway.''

title: Ann Worth Oberrender Plans to Wed Nicholas Blancke Noyes, Bank Officer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Girard Franklin Oberrender Jr. of Ithaca, N.Y., and Bridgehampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Worth Oberrender, to Nicholas Blancke Noyes, a son of Mrs. Blancke Noyes of Darien, Conn., and the late Mr. Noyes.

title: Choosing Prison
description: Even the prosecution conceded that Fayette Mount had a good chance of being acquitted of murder charges if she went to trial. But the unemployed mother of two chose prison in Pennsylvania last May because she wanted shelter and job training.

title: Galoshes And Changing Times
description: I read Gerald Eskenazi's column, About Long Island, entitled ''Sneakers in the Snow, Galoshes in the Past'' (Feb. 17) with much amusement. My own two children are the same age as those of Mr. Eskenazi, and they share similar views on the extinction of the need for galoshes, gloves, hats and buttons.

title: Topics ;   Long Runs
description: MushThe real news, of course, will be the day that a woman's being the first of her sex to do such and such will no longer be news.

title: WHY GOLD STILL LACKS REAL LUSTER
description: DESPITE the widespread feeling among professionals that gold is not likely to outperform other investments, at least one large investor in gold stocks is quite bullish about the prospects for the metal over the next few years. ''I think we're heading for a long-term bull market in gold,'' said John van Eck, chairman of the $800 million International Investors mutual fund. ''This is just the beginning. It looks as though we've seen the bottom.'' In fact, he even went so far as to venture that the price of gold ''could exceed its old high'' of $850 an ounce within the next three years.

title: Votes in Congress;   Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Passed by identical votes of 55 to 45, March 19 and 20.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: The unmarried, devoutly Roman Catholic Agatha McGee, a 68-year-old retired schoolteacher from Staggerford, Minn., nightly sleeps alone in the same bed in which she was born; she loves ''the Church of her girlhood above everything else in the world.'' Bravely, this sheltered woman leaves her hometown and embarks on a 10-day charter trip to Ireland.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS FACES COST QUERY
description: Officials of the General Dynamics Corporation attempted to mask the extent of excess costs for work on Navy attack submarines in the 1970's so as to protect the company's financial status, a former General Dynamics shipyard manager says.

title: 'BARCODES' COME INTO THEIR OWN
description: THERE are a number of ''great ideas''

title: WHERE THE SUSHI BAR STANDS OUT
description: -style Japanese restaurants established on the Island, recently opened a branch in Wantagh. The original location, in New Hyde Park, continues in operation.

title: RESERCH AND DEVELOPMENT: A RECORD PACE
description: WITH its space telescope, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration will search for planets beyond the solar system. At its new biotechnology complex, the Monsanto Company is trying to develop seeds that will be resistant to drought. The Defense Department is looking into the Strategic Defense Initiative - commonly called Star Wars - that President Reagan says could render nuclear weapons obsolete.

title: Giants Sign Blue
description: He was old and for all

title:
THE COMPUTER;

WHAT EVERY DATABASE NEEDS: A MANAGER
description: VIRGINIA DELCONTE joined the commercial insurance division of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company in 1981 as a database administrator. On a typical day the division, in Windsor, Conn., churns out piles of data that have to circulate from one division to the next and from one user to another. It is Miss DelConte's job to store that information in one or more of the commercial division's eight databases, which are like electronic card catalogues.

title: BRITISH M. P.'S DEBATING USE OF AMERICANS
description: The previously little-known American presence in the House of Commons, in the form of unpaid interns from universities in the United States, has suddenly become a cause cel ebre.

title: RICKEY HENDERSON VS. THE ROUND MAN
description: BECAUSE my father played for the Yankees back in the early years of the franchise, and because I have been covering baseball for The Baltimore Sun both as beat reporter and columnist since the Orioles joined the American League in 1954, I have always followed Yankee developments with considerable interest. This season I will have even more incentive to do that.

title: ;   An Artistic Tradition That Lives On
description: To the Editor:

title: VERBATIM: LAST WORDS
description: 'Being born black in America was against me. You all cry out that America was built on Christianity, I say it was built on slavery.

title: CHURCH OFFERING TWOFERS FOR LENTEN MUSICAL
description: A Roman Catholic church on the West Side has come up with a different approach to attracting people to observances of Lent, which began on Feb. 20 with Ash Wednesday and ends with Easter on April 7.

title: OPEA: 'THE NOSE,' BY DMITRI SHOSTAKOVICH
description: The Nose,'' performed Wednesday night at the Manhattan School of Music, is excellent evidence that Dmitri Shostakovich's sadness and despair were not congenital but learned. Shostakovich wrote his opera on Gogol's famous tale at 23, and there are in it wit, energy and high spirits enough to battle the world and all its vagaries. The misery and bitter humor in his music came later, as accompaniment to the difficulties of his life.

title: A GARDENER'S QUANDARY
description: IT is that time of year again. The

title: Backs and Beds
description: To the Editor:
