description: To the Editor:

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Toys to Furniture At Donations Sale The 10th annual Treasures and Trivia Garage Sale and Auction of the Junior League of Central Westchester will display and sell donated china, silver, art, housewares (including pewter, rugs, stoneware, English ironstone and antique lamps), sporting goods and toys, but no clothing, at the American Legion Hall Post 52 in Scarsdale March 29 from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and March 30 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. A large tent will be installed on the grounds to encompass the year's collection of functional family furniture.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ''Masters of Mischief: The Irreverent Spirit in Current Painting'' is the title of an exhibition that can be seen at the Allen Frumkin Gallery, 50 West 57th Street, through Saturday. It is a theme well suited to the Frumkin Gallery, in which mischief in one form or another is in more or less continuous residence, and the artists concerned are Red Grooms, Robert Colescott, Peter Saul, Rafael Ferrer, Peter Dean, Dan Freeeman, Jim Gingerich, Charles Parness and Peter Warrens.

title: Miss Fruchtman Plans To Wed in September
description: The engagement of Janet Ann Fruchtman and Steven Jay Samuels, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Samuels of Plainview, L.I., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Fruchtman of Brooklyn, the parents of the future bride. The wedding is planned for Sept. l7.

title: AFLOAT IN AN EXOTIC WILDERNESS
description: It was the silence that made the noise so

title: REPORT EXAMINES HEALTH PROBLEMS IN NEW JERSEY
description: A yearlong compilation of health statistics has found that New Jersey meets or exceeds most Federal health goals but still has higher than average rates of infant mortality and sexually transmitted diseases.

title:
EMERGING CAREERS;

THE NEW MODERN TIMES: CARS BY THE COMPUTER
description: IT is no secret that America's automobile industry

title:
CAREER DEVELOPMENT;

FOR ENGINEERS: THE M.B.A. VS. THE M.S.
description: AFTER a few years on the job, which postgraduate degree should an ambitious young engineer go for - in engineering or in business administration? The increasing trend in recent years has been for them to matriculate for an M.B.A. degree in order to put themselves in line more quickly for management jobs. Some opinion makers decry the drift toward the M.B.A., some make a case for it, while still others contend that it depends on the individual case.

title: THE PETIT CHATEAU
description: -GROWTH BORdeaux wines is like trying to get reservations at the Paris restaurant called Jamin. It doesn't matter how much money you have; there simply are not enough to go around. Fortunately, there are other places to eat - and other wines to drink.

title: Elizabeth Wiener Planning to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Janet Wiener of Great Neck, L.I., of the engagement of her daughter Elizabeth Wiener to David Lesser, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Lesser, also of Great Neck. An October wedding is planned.

title: Rosemary Ackerman To Wed Andrew Rupp
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Rosemary Ackerman, a daughter of Marilyn Swyer Ackerman of New York and Judge Harold A. Ackerman of Springfield, N.J., to Andrew Stephen Rupp, a son of Theresa Della Russo of Westfield, N.J., and Henry Rupp of Lake Mohawk, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Talking Co-op Boards;   Dealing With the Investors
description: UNTIL recently, the boards of most cooperatives knew the owners of apartments occupied by rental tenants and could deal with them directly. Often these owners were residents or the sponsor of the conversion.

title: June Wedding Set For Dr. Levenson
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Stetson Boal Jr. of New York and Carmel, N.Y., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Risa Catherine Levenson, to Dr. Kenneth David Gold, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rubin S. Gold of Plainview, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Ways to Avoid Court Delays
description: The simplistic answer to civil-action delays is money, according to William B. Fitzgerald (''Justice's Cost, and Paying for It,'' Feb. 17). I suggest we should also look elsewhere, in this age of a litigation-conscious population aware of broad insurance coverage.

title: Officer ArrestedIn Hit-Run Death
description: Three days after a police patrol car struck and killed a 70-year-old pedestrian and injured another man at Park Avenue and 72nd Street, a police sergeant was arrested last week and charged with having driven the hit-and-run car. Frederick G. Sherman, a nine-year veteran, was charged with second-degree manslaughter, criminally negligent homicide and leaving the scene of an accident.

title: AN ADVENTURE IN SCIENCE
description: Richard A. Muller is a professor of physics at the University of California and the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory.

title: Ellen Lubell Weds Dr. David Nathan
description: Ellen Carol Lubell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lubell of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. David Matthew Nathan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ira Nathan of New York. Rabbi Sanford Saperstein performed the ceremony at the Harkness House at 4 East 75th Street.

title: Big Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: MANY THINGS MAKE LIVING IN A VILLAGE BETTER THAN LIVING SOMEWHERE ELSE
description: RUNNING errands in the village on a Saturday morning with a car is much like driving an obstacle course, considering the flurry of other motorists with their packages from the grocery store, the hardware store, the corner store for the paper and Lotto and the fresh fruit and fish stand.

title: DEBATING THE FILM OF ORWELL'S '1984'
description: To the Editor:

title: SAN DIEGO'S FINEST
description: COP WORLD Inside an American Police Force. By James McClure. 343 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $16.95.

title: V.A.T. Refunds
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER RATES
CANADA'S SENATE: EITHER WAY, IT IS CRITICIZED
description: What costs Canadian taxpayers $19 million a year, gets ridiculed by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney as ''a retirement home'' for superannuated Liberals, and then comes under attack whenever it stops doing nothing?

title: ELSA RECKMAN KERR, EX-DEAN OF WOMEN AT SCHOOL IN BEIRUT
description: Elsa Reckman Kerr, a former dean of women at the American University of Beirut who spent 40 years in Lebanon promoting higher education for women, died last Sunday in Hightstown, N.J. She was 89 years old.

title: AS FRENCH AS TARTE TATIN
description: How does a single dish become legend? In the case of the French apple pie known around the world as la tarte des Demoiselles Tatin, the trail begins in the agricultural village of Lamotte-Beuvron, a quiet town of 4,400 inhabitants 100 miles from Paris in the forested hunting region known as the Sologne.

title: FOR NICARAGUAN GUERRILLAS AT A BORDER BASE, THE WAR IS NEVER FAR AWAY
description: A tropical evening settled over the clandestine guerrilla headquarters on the Honduran-Nicaraguan border, the silence broken only by the sound of a woman's voice reciting coded radio messages to rebel patrols inside Nicaragua.

title: TEXTILE DISPLAYS IN THE SPOTLIGHT AT STATE MUSEUM, RUTGERS-CAMDEN
description: A CLUSTER of textile shows in central New Jersey prompts the wish for a shortcut between the State Museum in Trenton and the Camden campus of Rutgers University.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Second Fire Is Spotted On Galapagos Islands
description: Ecuadorean Air Force pilots said Friday that they had spotted another fire in the Galapagos Islands even as the blaze on Isabela Island continued to spread, officials said.

title: Condo Leasing
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTMENT FRAUD ABOUNDS ON COAST
description: An investment counselor in Sacramento, California's capital city, committed suicide the other day, and with his death came disclosures that he had swindled hundreds of clients out of $15 million.

title: For Israel,Getting Out IsThe Hard Part
description: Israel met little resistance when it swept into Lebanon in 1982. But on the way out, it seems trapped in a small war impossible to win. Hitting back at Shiite Moslem guerrillas who have kept up a drumfire of attacks on its forces this month, Israel last week sent hundreds of soldiers and dozens of tanks to destroy houses and cars of suspected enemies in southern Lebanon villages near Sidon, an area the Israelis had left less than five weeks before. The army said 21 people it described as terrorists were killed.

title:
THE COMPUTER;

THE HOME ROBOT IS STILL IN TODDLER STAGE
description: The star of the show in the middle of Stephen Iavarone's living room is singing ''America.'' The pitch is off and the projection is lacking, but then the singer is only 19 inches tall and about the size of a portable vacuum cleaner. The audience, Mr. Iavarone's family, is appreciative.

title: A RANGERS COACH WITH 'SOFT' TOUCH
description: TEACHING the New York Rangers to skate may call to mind bringing coals to Newcastle, but that is what Laura Stamm does. Miss Stamm, a Westchester resident, is the hockey team's power-skating coach. She meets with players at the Playland ice rink, where the team practices, and, as she puts it, teaches ''them how to get down the ice faster and how to stand on the skates once they get there - how to use skates, legs and body weight.''

title: The Cause and Defect of Orangemail The case of the morning sickness drug Bendectin shows how the American legal system has twisted itself into a contradiction on cases involving science and health. There are more and bigger such cases ahead and unless something is done, there will be more contortions.
description: A Federal jury in Cincinnati decided last week that Bendectin is not the cause of birth defects. That accords with the best available scientific evidence. But consider how narrowly, and at what cost, the legal system cranked out the same verdict.

title: STATE STARTS TAKING STOCK OF TIMBER SUPPLY
description: THE roar of chain saws and the crash of felled trees are more frequently heard in Connecticut woodlands these days, as more wood is cut for lumber and fuel.

title: CAMDEN COUNTY LOSES CONSUMER OFFICE
description: CAMDEN WHAT makes the Camden County Consumer Affairs Office different from the 67 other locally run consumer agencies in New Jersey is that it seems to be the only one on the wrong side of the budget ax.

title: INDIAN ART FROM THE NORTHWEST
description: Tlingit, Haida, Tahltan, Tsimshian, Kwakiutl, Salish, Nuu-Chah-Nulth are just some of the Northwest Coast Indian tribes responsible for an art tradition as rich and varied as their names. Northwest Coast Indian art does not just consist of arresting, two-dimensional graphics of bold, flowing line in red, black and blue but also includes a diverse collection of ceremonial and household objects ranging from bentwood boxes to intricately carved ceremonial masks.

title: World Cup Mark Tied By Luxembourg Skier
description: The World Cup overall champion, Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg, capped a brilliant season today by winning a record-tying seventh World Cup slalom ski race.

title:
STAGE VIEW;

WHEN THE POLITICAL MESSAGE IS SUBMERGED
description: The speedy Broadway demise earlier this season of the American adaptation of ''Accidental Death of an Anarchist,'' Dario Fo's improvisational political cartoon on the brutal police defenestration of a suspect in a terrorist bombing in Milan, leads to the larger question of the precarious union of politics and drama.

title: A NEW TEAM CHECKS IN AT THE GREAT WALL HOTEL
description: PEKINGJohn Kapioltas smiled when someone suggested that the Sheraton Corporation's entry into the hotel business in China was like the cavalry riding in.

title: CARBIDE EXPLAINS DISASTER AT BHOPAL
description: Union Carbide laid the blame for the disaster at Bhopal, India, firmly at the feet of its Indian employees. In lengthy reports and presentations Carbide and its chairman, Warren M. Anderson, said the release of deadly methyl isocyanate was caused by the entry of water into a tank, aggravated by a series of human and equipment failures that Carbide said would not be tolerated in its United States plant. But the Indian Government maintained that Carbide, not its Indian subsidiary, was responsible.

title: DEBATING THE FILM OF ORWELL'S '1984'
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;

'A NEW BEGINNING' AT THE HUDSON EXPLORES RECENT PAST
description: FOR those of us who thought we knew what painting and sculpture should look like, watching the art of the 1970's manifest itself was like watching the underpinnings of our art education being removed. Boundaries were broken and the major art of that decade challenged established art. One was a little wary of venturing into the galleries of SoHo then, because there was the feeling that the artists knew something the rest of us didn't.

title: KOREANS HOLD CHINESE BOAT ON WHICH 6 DIED
description: South Korea continued tonight to hold a Chinese torpedo boat that drifted into its waters with six dead crew members, killed in what some reports described as a mutiny after some crewmen tried to defect.

title: CYNICISM IS SOURING TODAY'S COMEDIES
description: The trend began in the late 70's with the huge hit of ''The National Lampoon's Animal House,'' a good-natured farce in which variations on rude fraternity- house behavior became the entire point of the film, which might otherwise have been set on Mars. The trend picked up momentum with the various spin-offs of ''Animal House'' and then reached a zenith of sorts - or maybe a nadir - with the astonishing popularity last year of ''Ghostbusters.'' That laboriously dizzy, inane comedy is about nothing much more than special effects and a bunch of guys making a spectacular success in their own small, eccentric business, which is busting ghosts.

title: MUSICIANS HONOR AUSTRIAN THEORIST
description: Carrying scores, tape recorders and treatises, more than 200 musicians and scholars from around the world gathered last weekend at the Mannes College of Music to pay tribute to a seminal musical philosopher whom many of their fellow professionals had never heard of.

title: The Eyes of the Beholder
description: If Robert Burns knew then what April Fallon and Paul Rozin of the University of Pennsylvania know now, he would never have written ''Oh wad some power the giftie gie up/To see oursels as others see us!'' Not if he cared about the self-confidence of his fellow males. Because while women have a lot to gain from seeing themselves as others see them, men have a lot to lose.

title: Q AND A
description: My husband and I are black and were the first to apply for an apartment in a four-family house. It was rented to a white couple who applied after we did. We have been told that in houses of six or fewer apartments where the owner also resides antidiscrimination law does not apply. True or false? . . . E.W., Brooklyn

title: FLOWER SHOW STIRS MEMORIES OF PAST EXHIBITIONS
description: THE page from the local Westchester paper is frail now, yielding little brown and brittle pieces of itself at the slightest touch. On it are recorded some events of Sept. 14, 1939: the state is auditing the county government's health expenditures; Mrs. Ralph Leonard of Pleasantville, formerly of Briarcliff Manor, accepts the presidency of the Scarborough Music Club; ''Magnificent Obsession,'' with Irene Dunne and Robert Taylor, is having its last showing that day at the Embassy in Dobbs Ferry.

title: Another View On Campaign
description: The Long Island Weekly section of Feb. 17 contained a letter to the editor from Ralph G. Caso, former Nassau County Executive. Mr. Caso's letter is right in only the use of one word, ''ego.''

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS March 24, 1985Fiction*1
description: THE AQUITAINE PROGRESSION, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $4.50.) A lawyer finds himself caught in a conspiracy to take over the world. *2

title: THE BLAZER
description: John Duka, formerly a style reporter for The Times, is now a freelance writer and media consultant. qsf9982wqcc17.6,18,11,13wqcd4wqka1wqif.9wqxrqah qef The history of men's clothing is filled with all manner of apocrypha guaranteed to make the lay person (who owns two suits and one sport jacket) feel inferior and the expert (who has no fewer than six Macclesfield ties) wink because he knows the punch line to every tale attached to the clothes on his back.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Nicaraguan Leader Reports Aid Offers
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that Brazil and Ecuador had offered to help Nicaragua resolve its acute shortage of fuel oil.

title: Katharine Wiley To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Bradford Wiley of Convent Station, N.J., and South Hero, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katharine Laura Wiley, to Paul J. Laud, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Laud of Garden City, L.I. The wedding is planned for June.

title:
GARDENING;

SOME SPRING-PLANTING PROBLEMS
description: SPRING planting season has arrived. Retail nurseries already have a stock of plants on hand, and more are arriving each day. The sooner one gets the plants in the ground, the better. Early planting allows them to get established before the arrival of hot and dry summer weather.

title: Miss Plank Weds Harrison Higgins
description: Linda Suzanne Plank and Harrison Scott Higgins were married yesterday at the Burden Mansion on East 91st Street. The Rev. Carl Nelson, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: NAVRATILOVA TOPS MANDLIKOVA
description: This is another challenge round in her tennis career, a time when Martina Navratilova steps on the accelerator and pulls away from the women who thought they were catching up to her. Her unexpected losses fueled their hopes, giving rise to a collective speculation that the tour was not her private domain.

title: Cotto Battles to Come 'Home'
description: Henry Cotto was born in the Bronx, but if he arrives at Yankee Stadium as a member of the Yankees next month, it won't exactly be a homecoming.

title: THE THEATER: 'RESPONSIBLE PARTIES'
description: Jeffrey Sweet's ''Responsible Parties'' is a play whose carefully balanced observations and meticulous crafting work against it. Set in the lobby of a seedy Los Angeles motel, the play traces a day in the lives of Randolph (Larry Block), a portly, meddlesome motel owner, and Cornell (Matthew Penn), the sullen young ex-convict he has hired as a manager and whom he treats as a surrogate son.

title: VIOLIN VIRTUOSOS COME IN MANY STYLES
description: Edward Schneider writes frequently about recordings.

title: DOCTORS DEBATE SURGERY'S PLACE IN THE MATERNITY WARD
description: In 1983, the most recent year for which figures are available, one out of every five newborns in the United States was surgically removed from its mother's uterus. The rate for Caesarean sections (or C-sections) is four times higher than it was a generation ago. That dramatic rise has become a source of controversy among doctors and new mothers.

title: A SELF-HELP GROUP FOR HELPING HANDS
description: -help groups for people with drug and alcohol problems, and self-help groups for people with eating disorders. There are groups for gamblers, for families that have lost a child to illness or to murder, for stutterers, for widowed persons, for families of homosexuals and for parents who want to teach their children at home. There is a group for nearly every category of disease listed by the World Health Organization.

title: NOT ALWAYS IN A WHEELCHAIR
description: I HAVE just returned from a small trip to the supermarket. I bought only a few items, spent little in

title: Carolyn W. Churchill Marries TV Producer
description: Carolyn Whittier Churchill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Churchill of Jensen Beach, Fla., formerly of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to William Ogden Wheatley Jr., the son of Marguerite Wheatley of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Wheatley. The Rev. Edward R. Danks performed the ceremony at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien.

title: Trial Set in Writer's Death
description: The trial of two reputed gangsters accused of murdering a Chinese-American writer in California will be held April 2, the Taipei District Court said Friday. The court president, Wu Shu-li, said a three-judge panel would hear the case. Chen Chi-li, 41 years old, said to be the leader of Taiwan's Bamboo Gang, and Wu Tun, 35, identified as his lieutenant, have been charged with killing the writer, Henry Liu, 52, in Daly City near San Francisco on Oct. 15. Mr. Liu's writings were critical of the Chinese Nationalist Government on this island, and of its president, Chiang Ching-kuo.

title: REPEALING DATED LAWS: THE NAVEL COULD SHOW
description: It is 3,150 pages long and weighs 32 pounds. It has been 10 years in the making, has involved more hours of work than anyone can guess, and - if it is approved - New York City would be a new kind of town.

title: Timothy P. Daly Exchanges Vows With Miss Cross
description: Martha Tiffany Cross, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William John Cross of Somers, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Timothy Peter Daly, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Daly of Windsor Locks, Conn. The Rev. Robert B. Hybel performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FOOD HUNT FOR NEEDY

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER/THAT SPECIAL SOMEONE
Nancy Gifford Is Engaged to Thomas J. Hallowell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Genung Gifford of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Elizabeth Gifford, to Thomas Jewett Hallowell, the son of Peter Sand Hallowell of Mahwah, N.J., and Mrs. Meredith Evans Hallowell of Alpine, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: Data Bank;   March 24, 1985
CURATORS, GIVE IT BACK TO THE INDIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: A FLAT LOUDSPEAKER DELIVERS WELL-ROUNDED MUSIC
description: One of the most exotic of all loudspeakers is, in fact, a thoroughly homespun product from the town of White Bear Lake, Minn. But except for their northwoods provenance, the Magneplanar speakers - affectionately known as ''Maggies'' in the trade - are surely as offbeat as any speaker ever made.

title: BRAZILIAN CITY WITH AFRICAN ECHOES
description: She sits radiant on a bluff by the sea, painted in pastel colors, dressed in white lace, holding fruit, spices and lean children. Rudyard Kipling called her ''the hearth of all that flaming energy when Brazil was being born.'' If Brazil has a mother, Bahia is her name.

title: U.C.L.A. Gains
description: Brad Wright scored 16 points and tied his career-high of 15 rebounds tonight to lead U.C.L.A. into the semifinal round. The Bruins (19-12), who have won 10 of their last 11 games and are 19-12 over all, next play at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday.

title: CHINESE FLIER, JAILED IN 1949, WINS REDRESS
description: A Chinese Air Force flier who served 20 years in prison and 15 more years under restriction at a Manchurian state farm has finally been able to persuade the authorities that compass failure, not treason, caused his transport plane to stray into the Soviet Union in 1947 during the Chinese civil war.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ;   Tracing Scofflaws
description: New York City's Transportation Department planned a surefire way to nail traffic scofflaws: Sidney.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Gilbert Amy might seem at first glance - to those who recognize the name at all - to be a worthy but faceless foot soldier in the now-passe European modernist movement. A disciple of Pierre Boulez and a longtime regular at the hard-liners' command post, the Darmstadt summer music festival, he never really made a profound impression on the international music world.

title: A LITTLE BIT OF LUCK
description: The result of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship in Montreal a week ago was no surprise, but there are several morals to be drawn: Established partnerships have an edge over casual ones; professional teams with amateur sponsors are finding the going harder nowadays; and winners need a little luck.

title: MUSIC: BY BUDDHIST MONKS
description: Tibetan Buddhist ceremonial music that is rarely heard in the West was presented by the Gyuto Tantric Monks, one of the oldest Tibetan orders, at the American Museum of Natural History on Wednesday and Thursday. The Gyuto Monks, who are considered one of the most esoteric and exalted Buddhist orders, were founded more than 500 years ago.

title: INDIFFERENT LUCK AND HUNGRY GODS
description: ''CONTINENTAL DRIFT'' has only metaphorically to do with grinding tectonic plates that slowly bend subcontinents and heave mountain ranges toward the sky. The novel charts, in alternating chapters, the eventually intersecting paths of two people desperately on the move: Bob Dubois, a 30-year-old native of Catamount, N.H., who decides one cold December night in the late 1970's that he wants something better than the life he has had so far and takes off with his wife and two daughters for Florida - and Vanise Dorsinville, a Haitian woman living in a tiny cabin in the hill country near Port-de-Paix, who leaves the poverty and bitter hopelessness of her island life for the bright promise of America. Telling these powerful stories, Russell Banks has fresh things to say about a certain kind of American masculinity and some failures of the American dream. He also says problematical things about telling stories.

title: LASER-RELATED JOBS ARE AMONG FASTEST GROWING
description: DANIEL HARRIS considers his career choice serendipitous. Halfway through his first semester at the Georgia Institute of Technology in 1981, he ran out of money and was forced to drop out. Then he applied to the laser program at Camden County College, in Blackwood, N.J., and three semesters later graduated as a laser technician. Mr. Harris is now employed as a laser/electro-optic technician at General Electric and is just a year away from completing his engineering degree at the State University of New York at Binghamton.

title: HOME CLINIC: REPAIRING A WASHERLESS FAUCET
description: WASHERLESS faucets cost more than compression faucets, but they are much less likely to develop leaks or drips; most will last for many years before any repairs are required. One reason is that, unlike faucets with washers, nothing is under compression and thus subject to lots of wear - like the washer in a standard compression faucet. This means there is much less chance that a leak will develop because parts wear out.

title:
ANTIQUES;

BOWLS BY ANY NAME HAD MANY USES
description: FOR many families of the 18th and 19th centuries, basins and bowls were the most common and useful of all the utensils for the preparation of food and for the serving and enjoyment of it. Most of the types of bowls made generations ago are still in use today. The difference is that over the years their names have been changed.

title: KLOSTERS
description: The Alpine village of Klosters lies in the shadow of the ''Magic Mountain'' of Thomas Mann, and with nearby Davos shares access to the great winter snowfields of Parsenn and the Weissfluhjoch. Though many consider the snowfields the single finest skiing area in the Alps, these fields become equally unrivaled hiking country in the summer.

title: TENTATIVE AGREEMENT IS REACHED IN PAN AM STRIKE
description: Pan American World Airways and representatives of its striking ground workers reached a tentative agreement yesterday to settle the 24-day walkout that has severely crippled the carrier's operations.

title: DENNY FARRELL IS RUNNING, BUT NOT ALONG THE EXPECTED ROUTE
description: When in a West Side Democratic club, do as West Side Democrats do: grumble about rapacious landlords. But at a recent meeting of the Ansonia Democratic Club, New York City's unexpected mayoral candidate, Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell, made it clear that surprise may be a recurrent theme of his campaign. After one of his fellow candidates compared developers like Donald J. Trump to Dracula, Mr. Farrell objected, saying that Mr. Trump's Grand Hyatt New York Hotel had helped save the eastern end of 42d Street.

title: Headliners ;   'You Coulda Made Us Proud'As anyone can tell you,
description: Joe Pepitone was one great ballplayer and one great guy. But the former Yankee never lived up to expectations on or off the field, and the fast life always caught up with him.

title: SUPERCOMPUTERS: SUPER-SHORTAGE OF EXPERTS
description: THEY are the biggest, the fastest, the most unconventional. They are easily the most complex machines coming out of major computer manufacturers, university laboratories and now even Silicon Valley start-up companies. They are supercomputers, machines that can run circles around the quickest mainframes now made.

title: NEW ORLEANS
description: It begins in the middle of

title: Future Events
description: To Benefit Many

title: Moon Tax Term
description: On beginning an 18-month tax-evasion term at the Federal prison in Danbury, Conn., last July, the Rev. Sun Myung Moon was assigned to menial work in the kitchen. A prison spokesman said the assignment had been made because the Korean-born leader did not speak English.

title: HEALING THROUGH THE ART OF DANCE
description: ''THE human body is our tool,'' said Geraldine Silk, ''and dance is our universal language. We are dancers who are also healers.''

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: TEACHING ARTS INSTEAD OF ACCOUNTING

title: Heather Thomas Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Thomas Thomas of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Heather Marie Thomas to Shawn Michael O'Connor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew John O'Connor of Florham Park, N.J. The wedding is planned for June 8. The future bride is a candidate for a doctorate in medical anthropology at the University of Pennsylvania. Her father is vice president of the Wayne Steel Company in Elizabeth, N.J. Mr. O'Connor is a personnel specialist at the RCA/ David Sarnoff Research Center in Princeton. His father is president of A. J. O'Connor Associates, an executive search concern in Morristown, N.J.

title: David Jones Engaged To Torii Heath Powers
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William R. Hudson of Bryn Mawr, Pa., of the engagement of Mrs. Hudson's daughter Torii Heath Powers to David August Jones, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John William Jones of Lynchburg, Va. The couple plans to be married Sept. 7.

title: REAGAN'S MARGIN IN HOUSE MX VOTE SEEN AS SLIPPING
description: As the House prepares to vote Tuesday on President Reagan's request for 21 new MX missiles, both sides say the Administration's once-comfortable margin is slipping.

title: SAVINGS BY NAVY POSING A PROBLEM
description: The Navy says it has saved $2.5 billion in shipbuilding costs over the last three years, but officials say the economy measures have caused a problem.

title: VILLANOVA IS FACING MATCHUP PROBLEMS
description: Two years ago, Rollie Massimino, the animated Villanova basketball coach, put his team on a bus and ordered the driver to negotiate some treacherous road conditions through a driving February snowstorm. The team had a game scheduled with North Carolina, then ranked No. 1, and Massimino had no intention of breaking the date.

title: MEDICARE'S BROKEN PROMISE
description: The original proposals for Medicare did, in fact, include generous provisions for home-health visits.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;

HOLST TO STEPHANE CRANE GRAPELLI MUSICAL RICHES, FROM GUSTAV
description: Steve Schneider frequently reports on developments in cable.

title: REMAKING AFGHANISTAN IN THE SOVIET IMAGE
description: Richard Bernstein is a correspondent in the Paris bureau of The New York Times.

title: HARTFORD TO RENEW ITS BURYING GROUND
description: AS Hartford prepares to observe the 350th anniversary of its founding next year, descendants of its original settlers are in the process of restoring its oldest cemetery, the Ancient Burying Ground, on Main Street.

title: WHAT CAN WE DO?
description: How can we help to stop the oppression and killing in South Africa? The question is on the American mind, and events make it urgent. Once again last week, 25 years after Sharpeville, South African police fired their guns into a crowd of blacks; 18 were killed.

title: BACH AT 300 WORDS, NOTES AND NUMBERS
description: Like Shakespeare, Bach is one of those giants whose work speaks differently, though powerfully, to every period. The esthetic assumptions of the 18th and 19th centuries imposed their limits on the interpretations of Shakespeare offered by Dr. Johnson or Coleridge, but those readings are alert to truths we may have forgotten. There is no guarantee that our readings of Shakespeare will seem any less limited to our grandchildren, who will reinterpret him for the 21st century and who will doubtless uncover aspects of his art to which we are blind. Coming generations will also be listening to Bach and remaking him in the image of their own time, though whether they will normally hear his music on synthesizers or antique instruments remains an open question. Perhaps they will even engage in loving reconstructions of the 19th-century style of Bach playing now thought to be discredited. Whatever their practice, Bach will survive it, as Shakespeare has survived all kinds of distorting productions. Unlike his lesser contemporaries - composers like Couperin or Telemann - Bach transcends his time and place.

title: ART: JOHN Q.A. WARD'S SCULPTURES AT THE MET
description: The World's Columbian Exposition of 1893 in Chicago confirmed the boom in American sculpture that began soon after the Civil War. But an event that did even more for the profession was the founding, in the same year, of the National Sculpture Society, which was dedicated to stimulating the public appetite for sculpture and whose members obtained the most prestigious and lucrative commissions.

title: KING INJURED AS KNICKS LOSE
description: The Knicks lost another game tonight, 113-105 to the Kansas City Kings, and in the process may have lost their star scorer, Bernard King, for the season.

title: FOR MANUFACTURING DESIGN, A GLITTERING NEW GLAMOUR
description: THE only way for the United States to meet its goal of putting a manned space station in orbit by 1992, a recent study for the National Academy of Sciences concluded, is if the major contractors on the project take an accelerated course in computer-integrated manufacturing.

title: CAMBODIAN REFUGEES HAVE A NEW PROBLEM: BANDITS
description: Well-armed and organized bandit gangs from the volatile Cambodian war zone are breaking into a lightly guarded Cambodian refugee settlement at night to rob and sometimes kill its unarmed inhabitants, according to residents and international aid officials.

title: 2 GROUPS WORKING TO RESORE STATUE
description: THE chairman of the Connecticut Centennial Commission of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island is concerned about confusion arising between her group and the Connecticut group raising money to restore the statue and the island.

title: Miss Black Plans A June Wedding
description: Deborah R. Black, a circulation coordinator for the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company, and Leonard A. Rodes, an associate in the law firm of Grutman Miller Greenspoon Hendler & Levin, plan to marry in June, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Black of Manhasset, L.I., have announced.

title: OLD FAVORITES STAY ALIVE ON C.D.'S
description: Cheers of appreciation greeted the massive compact-disk issue recently of Bruno Walter performances on imported disks from CBS/Sony in Japan. To many, this was a sign that the new technology of laser-played disks would not result in ignoring the treasures of the old catalogue. Many of the Walter performances remain definitive, and it was reassuring to have them in remarkably fine sound on compact disks.

title: GENEALOGY BY THE BUSLOAD
description: The place was County Kerry in southwestern Ireland somewhere between Killorglin and Glenfleske, the time was recent and we were careening down a narrow road with a marvelous view of Lake Leane in the distance - and a precipitous drop nearer to hand - when a broad- beamed bus swerved around a curve, the driver flanked by a bubbly guide with microphone in hand spinning her brogue over the scenic wonders.

description: MEN, are you tired of dressing for success? Are you sick of being told that clothes make the man and that you should array yourselves accordingly?

title: PROTECTING YOUR PENSION-AND SPOUSE
description: SINCE January, millions of workers across the country have been receiving notices from their employers asking them to make some tough decisions about retirement benefits. The questions stem from the Retirement Equity Act of 1984, which went into effect for most workers this year.

title: Deeper Debt in February
description: Some financial analysts have suggested that the delay in refunding Federal taxpayers would temporarily help the Government's balance sheet for February.

description: WASHINGTON

title: THE CUNNINGHAM COMPANY ENTERS A NEW PHASE
description: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company is entering a new and distinct phase, as its season at the City Center has just suggested. There are no major changes in store, but there are some differences from the recent past. One is that Mr. Cunningham has taken himself out of some works in which he used to dance, such as ''Duets.'' Another change is the number of new faces, replacing dancers who have departed. Even the size of the company - 16 members including Mr. Cunningham - is larger by old Cunningham standards although it reached this level a few seasons ago. There are also two new ''artistic advisors,'' William Anastasi and Dove Bradshaw - which means two new painters to create the decor, costumes and lighting. There is finally, a discernible change in the choreography - not through any compositional process but in the fact that Mr. Cunningham's role, or his absence, determines the final outcome, how the piece finally coheres before the viewer.

title: GOLDEN CITIES OF MINAS GERIAS
description: In homage to the new President of Brazil, Tancredo Neves, we'll begin our visit to the former gold-mining state of Minas Gerais with Sao Joao del Rei. On his frequent visits to his birthplace, Mr. Neves stays at his home - a magnificent manor house next to the Rosario Church, and one of the finest examples of colonial residences in a region rich in 18th-century mansions and churches.

title: Canada's New Economic Clout
description: Andrew Malcolm's article, ''Canada's New Economic Clout'' (Feb. 17), is surely a distinguished contribution to the popular literature about relations between that country and ours. In one respect, however, when he observed that ''Canadians' confrontations with each other have always tended more to the verbal than the violent,'' Mr. Malcolm was wide of the mark.

title: Kosar's First Pick He's been flirting with the United States Football League, but
description: Bernie Kosar, the former University of Miami quarerback, said the Natinal Football League had first call on his heart. ''If I had my choice,'' he said, ''I would still want to play in the N.F.L.'' Since he announced that he would turn pro, Kosar has been wooed by the Orlando Renegades of the U.S.F.L., but Kosar, who is from Ohio, has made no secret of his desire to play for the Cleveland Browns and suggested he was willing to take his chances in the N.F.L. draft rather than sign with Orlando. ''The U.S.F.L. right now is really just an option if things don't work out in the N.F.L.,'' he said.

The economy must become ''more competitive,'' the budget deficit must be cut sharply. ''Entrepreneurs,'' he insists, must be encouraged. The Italian bureaucracy needs reform.

description: Perhaps the principal points of contact between United States citizens and anything Canadian - even more than beer and real estate - are to be found in Harlequin romances and in the board game Trivial Pursuit.

title: A Woman and Her DogsAdversity has its advantages, even if you are mushing a dog team 1,135 miles from Anchorage to Nome, Alaska.
description: Libby Riddles , who last week became the first woman to win the Iditarod Trail Dog Sled Race, got the final jump on her competitors when she set out in a blizzard a few days earlier while the other mushers waited out the storm 130 miles from the finish line. It took the 28-year-old woman 17 days to make the trek through two mountain ranges and over the Yukon River.

GARDENING;

SOME SPRING-PLANTING PROBLEMS
description: SPRING planting season has arrived. Retail nurseries already have a stock of plants on hand, and more are arriving each day. The sooner one gets the plants in the ground, the better. Early planting allows them to get established before the arrival of hot and dry summer weather.

description: LAY BARE THE HEART An Autobiography of the Civil Rights Movement. By James Farmer. 370 pp. New York: Arbor House. $16.95.

title: On the Budget,Agreement toTry to Agree
description: After months of declaring their differences and days of heightened warnings about how far apart they were, President Reagan and 11 Senate Republicans sat down and reasoned together on the Federal budget late last week. Their two-hour White House lunch produced agreement to reason some more, through a small ''working group'' of Administration officials and Republican senators to tackle the specifics.

title: THE COOKIES ARE SAFE. THE CAR, HOWEVER ...
description: ''YOUR Girl Scout cookies were stolen? What? They got the cookies?'' I was asked a hundred times. No, no. The cookies are safe. Seventy-four boxes - enough to make my daughter, Abby, last year's top seller of Bridgehampton Girl Scout Troop 536 - were delivered to my Manhattan office on time, unchipped. It was my car that was stolen.

description: PELHAM THE Pelham Art Center plans to break ground next month for its $400,000 expansion at Fifth Avenue and Third Street and to begin construction shortly thereafter. Although completion is scheduled for October, an exact date is not firm because contractors' bids are still coming in, the center's organizers say.

Rabbi Seth Bernstein and Cantor Efraim Biran performed the ceremony at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York.

title: BOLIVIA UNIONS ACCEPT WAGE RISE AND END STRIKE
description: Bolivian workers today accepted the Government's offer to raise the basic minimum wage more than four-fold, and moved to end a 16-day-old general strike.

description: PETER WILL uses a computer to find oil. As director of systems science at Schlumberger Research in Connecticut, a division of the Schlumberger Corporation, he heads a team of experts who use artificial-intelligence systems to find oil throughout the world.

description: THREE months into a controversial new Federal program designed to save money and monitor the hospital care of Medicare beneficiaries, doctors, hospital administrators and patients are confused about how it works and worried that it will harm the elderly and disabled.

title: LAUGHTER WITH A ROCK BEAT
description: Over the past 15 years, a damp cloud of seriousness has settled onto rock- and-roll. Formerly fun, rebellious and sexy, the genre has become a vehicle for earnest thought about war and peace, racial injustice, universal love and the human condition. Musically, all manner of art-rock styles have ennobled or corrupted this formerly innocent form of popular entertainment. Where once everyone who picked up an electric guitar wanted to have fun or make money, now some rock musicians scorn the mainstream and aspire in a manner indistinguishable from a serious artist to make, through their own musical medium, an artistic statement. ''Roll Over, Beethoven,'' indeed.

title: THE COMPUTER AS A JOB MATCHMAKER
description: SUE KWIATKOWSKI, a communications major fresh out of college, needed an entry-level job - something within commuting distance from her Sayreville, N.J., home, preferably in public relations or advertising. She wanted anything, she said, except the sales positions she was finding.

title: JohnCorroonJr.,InsuranceExecutive, To Marry Julie Beth Baker on May 24
description: The engagement of Julie Beth Baker to John Aloysius Corroon Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Harold Paul Baker of Laurel Hollow, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Corroon of New York.

title: EXTEND FEDERAL INSURANCE TO ALL BANKS
description: After some semblance of normalcy is restored to Ohio's savings and loan industry, Congress and state and Federal regulators will have to figure out what to do about the private insurance of bank deposits, whose deficiencies were highlighted in last week's events. Clearly, the private insurance system cannot withstand the strains of today's financial market.

title: THERE'S A LOT OF LIFE LEFT IN THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT
description: The Endangered Species Act has generated much heat since its passage in 1973, particularly in the few cases where it has seemed to stand in the way of economic progress. A memorable example was the delay in construction of the Tellico Dam on the Little Tennessee River to protect a small fish called the snail darter. But the controversy has waned in recent years, in part because of a widening recognition of what is at stake - not simply the existence of a few rare creatures with names like the rhizome fleabane and the last chance townsendia, but the health of the biological systems that those creatures share with other species, including human beings. ''The Endangered Species Act is not concerned with esoterica, with odd names or with fossils about to go extinct,'' says Thomas E. Lovejoy, vice president of the World Wildlife Fund - U.S. ''We are talking about protecting the earth in all its variety, about the basis of biological science and about the ecological services that make life possible.'' A measure of how far the country has come in accepting the need for that sort of protection is the relative absence of opposition as Congress takes up reauthorization of the Endangered Species Act. There were no fireworks this month at the opening of Congressional hearings on extending the law, which expires this year. Instead, the Reagan Administration recommended that it be continued for four more years without change.

title: Term of Crime Unit Extended
description: President Reagan signed an executive order Friday extending the life of the President's Commission on Organized Crime until April 1, 1986. The commission was originally scheduled to terminate on July 28, 1985.

description: Benjamin DeMott's essay, ''Hanging Out With Horses'' (About Men, Feb. 17), was a revelation.

title: Susan Flanagan, a Lawyer, and Karl Maier Marry
description: Susan A. Flanagan, an associate with the law firm of Blodnick, Schultz & Abramowitz in Lake Success, L.I., and Karl A. Maier, a vice president and management supervisor at the Marschalk Company in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. John Dykstra performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church in Ridgewood, Queens, where the bride's grandfather, the late Rev. James J. Hoffman, had been pastor.

title: AN AMERICAN WOMAN CONDUCTOR ON THE WAY UP
description: Allan Kozinn is a frequent contributor of articles on music and musicians.

title: Eliminate Teachers' Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran Reports Air Attacks In Baghdad and Teheran
description: Iran said today that it had launched a missile attack on Baghdad and that Iraqi aircraft had hit Teheran.

title: WINNING IS A RELIEF FOR GEORGETOWN
description: Followers of the Georgetown Hoyas have grown accustomed to a few things - primarily, winning. The Hoyas do a lot of it. The team also has a consistent reaction to victory, displaying a quiet confidence that seems to say to the losers: ''Nice try. Maybe next time, but probably not.''

title: VOLUNTEERS JOIN EFFORT TO HALT MIGRATING CAPE COD SAND DUNES
description: A new effort is being made to stabilize the migrating dunes that have threatened a number of historic spots near here.

title: Missing
description: Broadway's lights inspire many

title: GOVERNOR'S CAPITOL OFFICE REGAINING FORMER LUSTER
description: Between appointments, and sometimes even during them, Governor Cuomo these days keeps poking into Room 202 of the Capitol. He hovers behind craftsmen working on the fireplace and runs his hand over the marble window frames.

title: USE OF NEW TECHNIQUES URGED IN VACCINE RESEARCH
description: Members of Congress and medical researchers are calling for a stepped-up effort to develop vaccines through greater use of new biotechnology techniques such as cloning.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Bucks, at Milwaukee. These teams have played twice this season, and the Knicks have lost both games. Now the Knicks play the Bucks in three of their last 11 games of the season, beginning tonight.

title: Jet's Acceleration Reported To Cause Pilots to Black Out
description: The Air Force's newest fighter plane, the F-16, is so agile that pilots are flying it into maneuvers that can induce potentially fatal blackouts, The Fort Worth Star-Telegram reported today.

title: TAX CUT PROPOSAL IN INDIA BUDGET RECALLS REAGAN PLAN FOR STIMULUS
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, in a notable break with past policies, has proposed a sweeping program to cut taxes for businesses and wealthy individuals and reduce government regulation of key parts of the economy.

title: COME OVER 'N' SEE US SOMETIME
description: Harpo Marx harping blurs into Dracula biting blurs into Clara Bow vamping blurs into Sean Connery shooting blurs into Marilyn Monroe sizzling blurs into Bette Davis making eyes.

title: 2 SHORT STORIES ON 'WONDERWORKS'
description: ''Wonderworks,'' a public television series for younger audiences, began impressively a few months ago with ''Booker,'' a dramatization of Booker T. Washington's childhood that provided an uncommonly astute look at the institution of slavery. Tonight at 8 on WNET/13, the series completes its first season with a couple of short stories presented under the umbrella title of ''Two Alone.'' It is an uneven finale, pointing up the strengths and weaknesses of the entire ''Wonderworks'' project.

title: COLLEGES RENEW EMPHASIS ON WRITING INSTRUCTION
description: One of the teachers would usually arrive with some beer, but apparently everyone had been too busy that afternoon to buy any. That added to their weariness as they sat in a creaky- floored office in Harvard University's Freshman Union, and for a minute they considered adjourning rather than talking about their classes.

title: 200 Strip Mines Break Rules For Permits, Kentucky Says
description: About 200 small strip mines are breaking rules that exempt them from certain environmental restrictions, say Kentucky officials who are reviewing the mines' permits.

title: KELLY'S PASSING BEATS BREAKERS
description: Houston's Jim Kelly threw two touchdown passes today and Sam Harrell scored the game winner with 54 seconds to play as the Gamblers beat the Portland Breakers, 27-20.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: BLACK ROBE. By Brian Moore. 246

title: ENCYCLOPAEDIA BRITANNICA REVISED
description: Eleven years after the 15th edition of the Encyclopaedia Britannica shattered a 200-year-old tradition by dividing its volumes into three interrelated parts, the oldest continuously published encyclopedia in the English language has again been revised.

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, MARCH 25, 1985 International

title: A NEW ALBUM BY PETTY AND THE HEARTBREAKERS
description: Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers have been keeping a low profile for a band whose two most recent albums sold several million copies each. Mr. Petty, thin as a rail, with a haystack of blond hair and a slurred Southern drawl, hasn't been heard from since the end of the Heartbreakers' last tour, two and a half years ago. Reports that the group is on the verge of breaking up have been widely circulated.

title: A History of Hedging Political Bets
description: Over the years, Dwayne O. Andreas has hedged his political bets, donating liberally to both Republican and Democratic candidates.

title: THE LAKES SEE A SHIFT OF SEASON
description: Three years ago January the city of Pontiac, about 25 miles north of here, proudly played host to the Super Bowl. It was the first time the game was played in a Northern location.

title: Cunningham, BBDM To Merge in Chicago
description: Cunningham & Walsh, a subsidiary of the Mickelberry Corporation, has reached an agreement to acquire BBDM Inc. of Chicago into which it will merge its own Chicago office to form BBDM/Cunningham & Walsh.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Black Leaders, Black Goals
description: Does Benjamin Hooks, president of the N.A.A.C.P., require an audience with the President at the White House to confirm him as a leader of the black community? Does John Jacob of the National Urban League? Of course not. The days are gone when a black leader's standing depended on access to the White House. Now, it is Presidents who need access to established black leaders. And to the extent this President cares about the climate of race relations, he will exert himself to gain it.

title: LAWYER SAYS GOETZ TO TESTIFY BEFORE GRAND JURY
description: A lawyer for Bernhard H. Goetz said yesterday that Mr. Goetz would testify before a grand jury tomorrow about his shooting of four young men on a subway train last Dec. 22.

title: SULTAN HAS FOSTERED RAPID GROWTH IN OMAN
description: When Oman's present leader staged a coup against his father in 1970, the country, an ancient, seafaring nation whose influence once extended throughout Africa and Asia, had less than six miles of paved roads and virtually no electricity or private cars.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: 3 SINGERS INTERVIEWED BY BARBARA WALTERS
description: As always, the most interesting thing about a ''Barbara Walters Special'' is Barbara Walters. What kind of mood will she lay on her guests? On tonight's special, on ABC at 8 o'clock, Miss Walters is a shade more serious than usual, trying to get Neil Diamond, Barbara Mandrell and Boy George to tell her what's important. Mostly, she does this by being their friend.

title: HALLOWS CAPTURES TITLE
description: All Hallows saved the best for last today, completing a surprising postseason with a come-from-behind 66-63 overtime victory over Binghamton for the Class A New York State High School Championship.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
Steel Dispute Brewing
description: A new steel dispute is brewing with the European Economic Community. The Administration is threatening to impose unilateral quotas on 17 steel products not covered under a 1982 steel restraint agreement.

title: Budd and Lopes Win World Titles
description: Zola Budd and Carlos Lopes won the women's and men's individual titles today in the world cross- country championships.

title: CITY POLICE HAVE CHANGED THEIR APPROACH TO FAMILY DISPUTES
description: A fundamental change has taken place in the last year in the way New York City police officers deal with family disputes, according to social workers, the agencies that work with victims of domestic violence and the police.

title: Big Hitter
description: Well beat the drum and hold the phone.

title: AIR TRAFFIC SHIFTS BEING SET BY F.A.A. AS ACCORD LAPSES
description: The Government will start new air- traffic procedures next month to help prevent a repetition of the record flight delays last summer.

title: FOLLOW TREATIES, DEMOCRATS URGE GORBACHEV
description: A group of powerful liberal and centrist Democrats in the House of Representatives have sent a private letter to Mikhail S. Gorbachev warning that the Soviet Union must comply with existing arms control treaties or risk the most ''serious consequences for the future of arms control.''

title: Bucks for the Bangs
description: There is no question that the Oakland A's pulled off the biggest bang- for-the-buck coup last season, signing Dave Kingman to a $40,000 contract, then watching him finish among the top three in the American League in home runs (35) and runs batted in (118). The A's got such a bargain in salary because the Mets had released Kingman, owing him $675,000 for the last year of a guaranteed contract.

title: GETTING AN EARLY START ON TROUT FISHING
description: Submerged in the brouhaha associated with the April 1 opening of the New York state trout fishing season is the inescapable truth that the timing of the event is highly arbitrary.

title: MOYNIHAN OPPOSES END FOR DEDUCTIONS OF STATE TAXES PAID
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today that a Reagan Administration proposal to end state and local tax deductions on Federal income taxes would ''work perversely'' and eventually enlarge the Federal Government's size and power.

title: Security
description: While being shown an apartment

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Chief Executive Resigns at Itel
description: William P. Twomey, president and chief executive officer of the Itel Corporation, the San Francisco-based capital equipment leasing company, has resigned.

title: Treasury Realignment
description: Now that the former Merrill Lynch chairman, Donald T. Regan, has gone to the White House, the Treasury is mounting a search for ''someone who would be seen by Wall Street and financial markets generally as a very strong addition,'' according to one official.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Former Head of Farah Takes Over at Salant
description: The Salant Corporation, the financially troubled apparel maker, has announced that the duties of Carl S. Forcheskie, its 58-year-old president and chief executive, would be assumed by Ray W. Williams. A former president and chief operating officer of the Farah Manufacturing Company, Mr. Williams, 52, was hired by Salant on March 8 as a consultant with broad authority over company affairs.

title: BELLAMY AND KOCH IN CLASH OVER CAMPAIGN FINANCING
description: -imposed moratorium on politics, accused City Council President Carol Bellamy yesterday of making ''outrageous,'' ''vile'' and ''clearly malicious'' charges about his campaign contributions from realty developers.

title: Debt Issues
description: British Columbia is issuing 125 million Canadian dollars of 12 percent non-callable Eurobonds due 1990 at a price of 100, through Swiss Bank Corp. International.

title: MEMPHIS STATE'S LEE A PRESSURE PLAYER
description: Keith Lee is an enigmatic all- American whose scoring this season has ranged from 6 to 39 points, whose rebounds have ranged from 3 to 18 and whose intensity level, if measured on a meter, would swing erratically.

title: REMAINING OHIO UNITS TO REOPEN
description: For the first time since Gov. Richard F. Celeste ordered 71 privately insured savings and loan institutions closed 10 days ago, all will be reopened for at least partial withdrawals on Monday, state banking officials said today.

title: Exciting Alternative
description: To Kiddie TV Found

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 25, 1985: *2*MONDAY American Express Roper Corp Ameron Inc SCM Corp Hormel & Co Sterchi Bros Strs Primark Corp Unocal Corp *2*TUESDAY Avondale Mills Northern Ind PS Cleveland Elec Illum Public Service Co Delmarva Pwr & Lt Toledo Edison Co MacNeil-Schwendler Walbar *2*WEDNESDAY Ducommun Inc Ocean Drill & Explor E G & G Inc Raytheon Co Electron Corp AmerWash DC Gas Lt Glatfelter (PH) West Point-Pepperell Hoover Universal *2*THURSDAY Boston Edison Curtice-Burns Inc Campbell Soup (US) Federated Dept Stores Clevepak Corp Ranco Inc Colgate Palmolive Richardson-Vicks C'monwealth Energy Rogers Corp Cox Commun Webb (Del E) *2*FRIDAY Ralston Purina

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Which National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I championship basketball game was the most one-sided? Which was the closest? Have any gone into overtime?

title: U.S. REPORT ON RAPE CASES CITES VICTIMS' FRUSTRATIONS WITH LAW
description: Only about half the rape victims in the United States ever report the crime to the police, as a result of frustration with the criminal justice system or fear of reprisal, according to a Government report issued today.

title: HOUSE PANEL TO SCRUTINIZE NUCLEAR SAFETY RULINGS
description: A Congressional subcommittee plans to hold hearings on charges by a member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that the agency's safety decisions have been hasty and overly favorable to the nuclear power industry.

title: KOMATSU INTENSIFIES U.S. MARKET EFFORT
description: With the rash of construction projects in the Middle East and some parts of South America slowed or halted by the decline in oil income, the United States has regained its position as the main growth market for heavy equipment.

title: UPSETS TRIP DERBY HOPEFULS
description: Year in and year out, favorites win about 33 percent of all thoroughbred races and 40 percent of stakes races. So when a son of Secretariat named Pancho Villa won the Bay Shore Stakes at Aqueduct Saturday and favored Spend a Buck finished third, an extraordinary streak was extended. The Bay Shore was the 12th graded stakes of the year among 3-year-olds prepping for the May 4 Kentucky Derby, and the 11th in which the favorite was beaten.

title: CITY BAR ASSOCIATION HAILS A LEGAL FOE OF ARPARTHEID
description: Arthur Chaskalson is soft-spoken, almost gentle. And in his native South Africa, he has used those traits to coax some measure of change out of his country's rigid racial laws.

title: Oil Outlook Of Norway
description: Norway, which has been accused by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries of increasing crude oil output at OPEC members' expense, expects its production to level off this year.

title: Ham Curing Change Delayed 17 Months
description: Country ham producers have been given a reprieve from a Federal rule to change curing methods that they said would have harmed the industry.

title: Garbage for Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: MILITIAS CLASH ANEW ALONG THE BEIRUT GREEN LINE
description: Moslem and Christian militiamen clashed with machine guns and rocket propelled grenades today on the old Green Line that divides Beirut. It was the worst flareup of violence between the two sides in nine months.

title: 9-Year-Old Hurt In Hit-Run Crash
description: A 9-year-old boy was critically injured yesterday when he was struck by a station wagon that crashed through a fence into a Bronx schoolyard, the police said.

title: JAPANESE PLAYERS' UNION IS AROUSED
description: TOKYO

title: Chadian Says Libya Is Reinforcing Positions
description: President Hissen Habre of Chad said today that Libya was reinforcing its positions in northern Chad but that many southern dissidents had rallied to the Government's side this year.

title: Hostages Rescued in Japan
description: The police stormed a Yokohama bank today and rescued four hostages held for 12 hours by two gunmen. The gunmen, disguised as police detectives, raided the bank Sunday night when three bank employees and a guard brought in $2.2 million in cash from an off-track betting shop.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 25, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: MUSIC: COMPOSERS GUILD
description: Arnold Schoenberg's ''Pierrot Lunaire,'' which was the highlight of a generally first-rate Guild of Composers concert at Merkin Hall on Thursday night, has long counted as a classic of 20th-century music. But it has not been a piece that, in this writer's experience, has actually

title: The Debt Sale Scheme
description: Senators Moynihan and Lautenberg are proposing a novel way to reduce the Federal deficit. They want the Government to sell its enormous portfolio of loans to private investors, realizing, by Congressional Budget Office estimate, $134 billion over the next three years.

title: WOMEN'S GROUPS STILL PUSH RIGHTS MEASURE
description: A few blocks from the White House stands an empty storefront with three panels of green letters across its windows. Each reads: ''E.R.A. Yes.'' In one window is a dead plant; in another hangs a canvas with a quotation from Susan B. Anthony that begins, ''Failure is impossible.''

title: Assurances Asked By State On Conrail
description: State officials are withholding endorsement of the proposed sale of Conrail to Norfolk Southern Corp. until the prospective buyer provides more assurances the deal will not hurt New York, said the director of the rail division of the State Transportation Department.

title: OPERA: NEW 'MEISTERSINGER'
description: The Metropolitan Opera's production of ''Die Meistersinger von N"urnberg'' is so straightforwardly attractive, so well conducted by Christof Perick and filled with such exultant music that Wagner's opera can cruise successfully along with a less than glorious cast. Thus Thursday night's new faces in the cast rarely thrilled, but they did not bitterly disappoint, either.

title: Compaq's Computer Phone
description: Entering a crowded market that has yet to show significant returns, the Compaq Computer Corporation is expected to introduce today a ''computer phone'' - a computer with a telephone attached.

title: FOR A RENEWED U.S. ROLE IN SOUTHEAST ASIA
description: Vietnam's recent brutal but effective military campaign against the Cambodian rebels fighting along the border between Thailand and Cambodia may have opened a window of opportunity for the United States and the Asean countries - a chance to settle the tragic conflict in Indochina and reduce Soviet influence there.

title: MOTE IN A GRINGO EYE
description: SAN DIEGO ''You don't bother them, they don't bother you.'' According to the confession of one of the Mexican policemen who helped abduct the U.S. drug enforcement agent later murdered by the ''narcomafia,'' that was the advice offered corrupt cops by a chief of police in Guadalajara. Fortunately for the drug peddlers and their partners in Mexico's Government, that particular police chief ''died under interrogation'' and cannot testify about corruption higher up in the police forces.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Miami last Friday on a proposal to build a new stadium there misidentified the court where Judge Wilkie D. Ferguson sits. It is the Third District Court of Appeals in the Florida state system.

title: MANAGING 'THE FUDGE FACTORY'
description: As Ronald I. Spiers tells it, he was happily at work as Ambassador to Pakistan when he complained offhandedly to Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who was passing through Islamabad, about the way the State Department was managed worldwide.

title: Sterling Drug Hires Marschalk and Jordan
description: Sterling Drug has added Marschalk and the Jordan, Case & McGrath agency to its roster.

title: F.C.C. GETS ADVICE ON NEW AM STATIONS
description: The Federal Communications Commission is receiving suggestions on how to allocate new radio stations that will be created as the AM band is widened at the upper end of the dial.

title: BENEFIT AT NEW HOME OF THE CLARK CENTER
description: The gutted interior of Clark Center's future home on Theater Row was adorned with balloons, potted palms and a mirror ball. The lights on its sign outside on West 42d Street had gone on for the first time - a good omen, Louise Roberts, the indomitable director of the 26-year-old institution, said as she greeted guests at the door for a ''champagne and cinderblocks'' benefit party Saturday night.

title: ISRAEL WITHDRAWS ARMY WOMEN
description: The Israeli military command has ordered all army women out of Lebanon, an officer at General Headquarters said today.

title: Shades of Balfour
description: The agreement signed this

title: NEW ANALYSIS OF DEFICIT MAY BE ECONOMIC CLUE
description: Economists may finally have found a clue to the mystery surrounding what they consider the most serious economic difficulty facing the nation - the red-ink sea of the Federal budget deficits and their accumulated totals, making up a national debt approaching $2 trillion.

title: INDIAN OFFICIALS SAY RUSSIAN FLED TO U.S.
description: A Soviet diplomat who disappeared a week ago was reported by Indian authorities tonight to have been granted political asylum in the United States.

title: Muir Tralongo Opening Madison Ave. Offices
description: There is a new ad agency opening its doors at 76 Madison Avenue by the name of Muir Tralongo Associates. The protagonists are Robert F. Muir, 56 years old, and Christine Tralongo, 36, and they are out of Muir Cornelius Moore, an agency that is heavy in financial-type clients.

title: He'll Take Belgrade
description: The United States has given up

title: Moving In
description: It is not clear what Gertrude Rhinelander Waldo had in mind upon the completion in 1898 of her East Side mansion, a diminutive but extravagant chateau. The society matron left it vacant and lived across the street with her sister.

title: Neighbors
description: Ka-thump. Forget about grinding garbage trucks, hammering steam pipes and ululating police sirens. A man we know in Greenwich Village is being awakened these days by squirrels landing outside his 16th-floor window.

title: Not the Third Reich of the New World
description: To the Editor:

title: Greenland
description: For those who may not have

title: Hawaiian Expansion Is Planned by D.D.B.
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach International is planning to acquire Mayfield Smith Park Advertising in Honolulu and combine it with its own Milici/ Valenti Advertising in the same sunny city, to become Milici/ Valenti/Smith/Park. The $8 million in billings contributed by the new agency will push the combined billings to more than $200 million in all agencies within D.D.B./West, which includes Los Angeles, San Francisco, Denver and Honolulu.

title: Which Public for Public TV?
description: After the triumphant 13-week run of ''The Jewel in the Crown,'' public television comes back to earth to realize that it cannot often find, or afford to produce, a smash hit. It has a public mandate but only paltry funding for ''alternatives'' to commercial programs. If it were able to afford to chase larger audiences, it might not often be a real alternative. But when it disdains popularity, it is called elitist and risks losing support from Congress, corporations and viewers.

title: FOR A RENEWED U.S. ROLE IN SOUTHEAST ASIA
description: Cambodia, the last country entrapped in the Indochina conflict and the one to suffer the most, can be rescued from its 15-year nightmare and restored to peaceful independence by America working with the Pacific basin countries. Such a rescue operation requires, first, that America find the political will to carry it out and, second, provide military support to nationalist groups led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk and by Son Sann.

title: U.S. JOB TRAINING PROGRAMS ROUSE BITTER DISPUTES
description: Sandra Williams, an alert 19-year-old who is studying building maintenance, has no doubts about what she would be doing now were it not for the training she has received at the Potomac Job Corps Center here.

title: Market Place;   Media Stocks: Dream' Week
description: BROADCASTING and media stocks gave their most spectacular performance in history last week on the Wall Street stage.

title: OFFICER SHOT IN BRONX DISPUTE
description: An off-duty Port Authority police officer was seriously wounded last night in the Bronx when he was shot in the chest in a dispute with the driver of another car on the Bronx River Parkway, the police said

title: WALKER PROPELS GENERALS
description: With 29 seconds left to play and the Generals at the Tampa Bay 13-yard line, the Bandits' defense set itself for Doug Flutie. That made sense because the rookie quarterback had been a dominating player in the Generals' fourth-quarter rally.

title: Professionals Seek To Teach in Jersey
description: Lawyers, writers, ministers, engineers, social workers, a certified public accountant and a former Congressional aide are among 475 people who are trying to receive provisional licenses as public-school teachers under a new state program.

title: RON STEWART ATONES FOR AN EMBARRASSING AIRBALL
description: If there had been a more embarrassing moment in the frustrating college basketball career of Ron Stewart, he could not think of it. With 2 minutes 45 seconds to play in the West Regional championship game today and North Carolina State clinging to within 6 points of St. John's, the St. John's tri-captain made himself a target.

title: NAVRATILOVA TAKES FINAL, 6-3, 7-5, 6-4
description: The only place Martina Navratilova will be seen going downhill in the near future is on skis in Aspen, Colo. Before leaving on a four-week vacation, she gave the women on the tennis tour something to think about. All those pep talks they have been giving one another about beating her is just talk, she said, until their performances back up their words.

title: CULTURE IN ITALY: WORLD OF CONTENDING CITY-STATES
description: The weather varies these days from delightfully clear and crisp to a bone-chilling damp cold. On weekdays the locals can bustle across St. Mark's Square without resorting to the feign-left, move-right maneuvers through summer crowds who clog up the piazza like so many tackles and defensive ends.

title: Moving Out
description: ''Over my neck.'' That's where

title: Conrail Lobbying Set
description: The Department of Transportation and the Norfolk Southern Corporation have started an intense lobbying campaign in several key Northeastern states to rally support for the company's bid to purchase the Consolidated Rail Corporation.

title: NEW LAW MAY HURT CHILD ABUSE CASE
description: An apparent oversight by California legislators may have jeopardized part of the state's case against seven former teachers at the McMartin Pre-School who are charged with sexually abusing dozens of children.

title: HIGH-RISE LIMIT ON THE EAST SIDE SOUGHT BY PANEL
description: The New York City Planning Commission has proposed new zoning rules that would seek to limit high-rise development on the side streets of the Upper East Side in an effort to maintain the neighborhoods' architectural character.

title: DR. NORMAN SIMON, A LEADER IN TREATMENT OF CANCER, DIES
description: Dr. Norman Simon, a physician and innovator in the radiological treatment of cancer, died Saturday at White Plains Hospital after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage last December. He was 70 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Advertising;   Cosmo Girl Campaign Expanding
description: FOR about 19 years Helen Gurley

title: SAVORY SHOPS GIVE AN ETHNIC FLAVOR TO A BRONX AVENUE
description: Alphonse Mieli double-parked his car on Allerton Avenue in the Bronx yesterday, took a number at Sal & Dom's Pastry Shop and bought a week's worth of pignoli cookies and zeppoli for himself and his deprived neighbors in Yonkers.

title: Radio Stations in Israel
description: The Government has agreed to allow Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty to broadcast to the Soviet bloc from a transmitter in Israel, United States and Israeli officials said today.

title: Yanks Beat Mets; Pitching Is Poor
description: If the Yankees and the Mets have one potential problem in common as they approach the start of the season, it is the state of their starting pitching. That was reflected today in the Yankees' 6-5 victory over the Mets in the second of their two spring exhibition games.

title: ST. JOHN'S AND VILLANOVA ADVANCE TO THE FINAL FOUR
description: St. John's finally fulfilled months of great expectations here this afternoon. Relying on the sort of crushing second-half surge that has become its trademark this season, St. John's defeated North Carolina State, 69-60, to win the West Regional and earn its first Final Four berth since 1952.

title: INDIANA WINS IN N.I.T.
description: Steve Alford scored 29 points tonight as Indiana beat Marquette, 94-82, in double overtime in a quarterfinal game of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: POLITICS OF TERROR
description: PARIS As Jordan edges warily toward

title: Rare Bird Is Missing From New Orleans Zoo
description: A rare toucan, the first of its kind hatched in captivity in this country, has apparently been stolen from the Audubon Zoo.

title: Helping Africans
description: To Till the Desert

title: CBS OFFICIAL IS GIVEN ISRAELI ACCOUNT OF CAMERAMEN'S DEATHS
description: A vice president of CBS News, Ernest Leiser, met today with senior Israeli officials and said he received a detailed explanation of how two CBS cameramen were killed by an Israeli tank shell in Lebanon last week.

title: DOCTORS: CLOSER TIES TO PATIENTS
description: MOST of the time, new medical students sit in classrooms or laboratories trying to absorb the facts of such subjects as anatomy, physiology, pathology and endocrinology. They have little if any contact with the people for whom they are learning all this: the patients.

title: APPROVAL UNCERTAIN
description: The tentative settlement reached by Pan American World Airways and the Transport Workers Union could help the ailing carrier cut labor costs and significantly increase productivity, financial analysts said yesterday. But the agreement's fate among the rank and file appeared uncertain.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, MARCH 25, 1985

title: Most Arkansas Teachers Took Certification Test
description: An expected boycott of the nation's first mandatory test of experienced teachers fell through because many educators feared they would lose their jobs, an opponent of the examination said today.

title: KOSAR CAN STUDY HIS PRO OPTIONS
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla.

title: 300,000 Danes Strike Over Wages and Hours
description: Three hundred thousand people went on strike today in a dispute over wages and hours.

title: RANGERS BOW TO ISLANDERS, 5-2
description: The Rangers and Islanders, two teams of promise before the start of this National Hockey League season, met last night at the Garden. And the outcome, a 5-2 Islander victory, showed that the Islanders still have some playoff promise, but the Rangers have little more than shattered egos and fading hope.

title: East and West Talk About Business
description: Shoes, conceded V.I. Gromeka in a weak moment, are not the Soviet Union's strong point.

title: Radioactive Soil May Stay in Jersey
description: Radioactive soil removed last year from 16 homes in Maywood and Rochelle Park may remain stored in the neighborhood for 10 years, state and Federal officials said.

title: ASSIST-PUMPS SUSTAIN MAN OVER 4 DAYS AS HEART HEALS
description: Two pumps supported a 60-year-old man's failed heart for more than four days last month while it healed after surgery, a newspaper reported today.

title: 4 Are Arrested In Cockfight Raid
description: Enforcement agents for the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and the police raided a South Bronx cockfighting arena last night, arresting four men and seizing 20 fighting cocks, according to authorities.

title: MX Has Bargaining Value at Geneva Talks
description: To the Editor:

title: STRANGE GETS BIRDIE AND EARNS $171,000
description: Curtis Strange, who claims he was not thinking of the money at the time, sank a 6-foot birdie putt on the 90th and final hole today to earn the PGA Tour's biggest purse in history - $171,000 - by a single stroke over Mike Smith.

title: WOMEN'S TAX COALITION
