description: A couple of weekends ago, several dozen lobbyists and Congressional staff members went down to the Homestead, the luxurious resort in the mountains of southwestern Virginia.

title: 2,000 Buses Are Recalled
description: The Neoplan U.S.A. Corporation is recalling about 2,000 buses nationwide because they may have cracks in suspension systems and defective defrosters, a company spokesman said Friday. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration urged in January that the German bus company, which has a manufacturing plant here, recall its buses because of cracked rear A-frames and electrical problems. The defects were first found in buses used in Washington, D.C.

title: REGAN SEES CHANCE FOR A COMPROMISE ON ARMS SPENDING
description: Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, said today that the Reagan Administration might be willing to compromise with Senate Republicans on proposals to curtail military spending.

title: Judge Under Fire Buys Pension
description: Chief Justice Joseph A. Bevilacqua of the Rhode Island Supreme Court, under fire for his associations with criminals, has bought credits in the state pension system, guaranteeing him an income of about $63,000 a year if he retires.

title: Senor Coelho
description: Representative Tony Coelho, a Californian of Portuguese descent, has broken a debatable ethnic barrier and joined the Congressional Hispanic Caucus. Some time ago, according to his staff, Mr. Coelho applied for caucus membership but, for reasons that are unclear, was not accepted.

title: U.S. ACTS TO FIX FLAWS IN COMBAT MEDICAL AID
description: The Defense Department's senior medical officer says the armed forces have embarked on a $2.6 billion, five-year program to overcome serious defects in combat medical care.

title: Futures/Options;   The Rising Price of Silver
description: IN the precious metal family, silver

title: MONEY IN POLITICS: THE LIFTING OF SPENDING LIMITS
description: Even though past ''independent spending'' by political action committees has gone overwhelmingly to Republicans, last Monday's decision by the United States Supreme Court barring limits on such spending in Presidential races appears unlikely to provide much additional help for Republican Presidential candidates. Nor is it likely to help Democrats much, either.

title: DOROTHEA PETGEN
description: Dorothea Petgen, a singer and actress, died at her home in Manhattan Saturday.

title: JOFFREY BALLET: 'TAMING OF THE SHREW'
description: John Cranko's ''Taming of the Shrew'' is pretty much a one-note ballet, and there is not much heart in the choreography or the score, by Kurt-Heinz Stolze after Scarlatti. But Beatriz Rodriguez and Jerel Hilding made the ballet shine with humor and poignancy on Saturday, when the Joffrey Ballet presented it at the New York State Theater.

title: Hefner Reported Well After a Mild Stroke
description: Hugh Hefner has a new outlook on life since his stroke early this month, his spokesman said today, and has given up his wild hours, ubiquitous Pepsi bottle and trademark pipe.

title: Bridge: Kahn Team Wins the Final Of the Grand National Meet
description: The New York final of the Grand National Team Championship, played Saturday at the Bridge and Games East club, at 227 East 57th Street, proved to be a pendulum match.

title: STRENGTH OF THE DOLLAR HURTS SALES OF U.S. FILMS ABROAD
description: The strength of the American dollar has hurt sales of American movies abroad just as it has hurt sales of American tractors and soybeans, a fact made obvious at the fifth annual American Film Market held here last week.

title: 100 Youths Go on Rampage On a Subway Train in Boston
description: More than 100 youths punched and robbed at least five other passengers on a subway train, sending the victims running to the driver's cab for protection, the transit police said today.

title: Providence Wins In College Hockey
description: Chris Terreri, the goalie, kicked out 50 shots and David Wilkie scored the eventual game-winning goal tonight, giving Providence a 4-2 victory over Michigan State to advance the Friars into the Final Four of the National Collegiate hockey tournament. Providence (22-16-5) captured the two-game, total-goals series, 6-5.

title: DEBATE OVER INTEREST TRENDS
description: The credit markets face a week of heavy supply in both Treasury and tax-exempt securities. The supply of corporate debt issues remains light, and is dominated by a $400 million offering of 30-year debentures of the Eastman Kodak Company.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: FLAGS Among the most universal of symbols is the flag, the token of a nation, a community, an organization, an army. The flags now on view at the African-American Institute, 833 First Avenue, at 47th Street (949-5666), are special ones, banners that were peculiar to the Fante people in south central Ghana. The Fante people are one of several culturally and linquiistically related groups known collectively as the Akan.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Debate Over Interest Trends
description: The Federal Reserve's monetary policy is not likely to be changed at tomorrow's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, analysts said.

title: Argentine Shift on Oil HOUSTON, March 24 (UPI)
description: President Raul Alfonsin of

title: Anti-NATO March in Spain
description: Tens of thousands of Spaniards marched from Madrid today to the nearby Torrejon Air Base, which is used by American forces, to demand that the United States withdraw its troops from four bases in Spain and that Spain pull out of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Slaying of Archbishop Marked in El Salvador
description: Thousands of people filled San Salvador's main cathedral and the square outside today for a mass marking the fifth anniversary of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero's assassination.

title: ;   Next, They'll All Be Reading 'Huck Finn'
description: To the Editor:

title: If Fderalism Is Obsolete, It's Better to Say So
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: NEW WORKS AT MERKIN HALL
description: Music Today, the Hebrew Arts School's contemporary music ensemble, gave first New York performances of works by Witold Lutoslawski, Karlheinz Stockhausen and Nicholas Thorne during a concert at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday night. The ensemble was led by Gerard Schwarz.

title: Chiat/Day Scores Two
description: Chiat/Day, New York, got a double play Friday. It picked up both the Trump Casino Hotel in Atlantic City and William Grant & Sons, the spirits importer.

title: STAGE: 'BEFORE THE DAWN' OPENS AT AMERICAN PLACE
description: In 1980, a small Jewish theatrical troupe in Moscow caused anenormous stir by performing a play about the 1941 Nazi massacre of more than 100,000 Kiev citizens at the ravines at Babi Yar. The play was ''A Ladies' Tailor'' by Aleksandr Borshchagovsky, and, to the astonishment of both Western journalists and Moscow audiences, it challenged the official Soviet version of history. For unsavory anti-Zionist purposes of its own, the Soviet Union has maintained that Jews suffered no more or less than any other group at Babi Yar. Mr. Borshchagovsky's play, which dramatizes a Jewish family's plight on the eve of the slaughter, sticks up for the truth: The vast majority of the Germans' victims were Jews.

title: New Hope for Clues In Italian Scandals
description: The arrest earlier this month of Francesco Pazienza by the United States Customs Service may shed some light on scandals that have rocked Italy in the past five years, including the collapse of the Banco Ambrosiano.

title: ULSTER PACT NEAR, NEWSPAPER SAYS
description: A London newspaper, The Mail on Sunday, reported today that Ireland and Britain are on the ''threshold of historic agreement'' to bring peace to Northern Ireland. Officials in London and Dublin said the report was very premature.

title: U.S. to End Some Racial Data
description: The Reagan Administration has ordered some of its housing officials to stop collecting racial and ethnic data on beneficiaries of Federal programs.

title: CRUSADING FOR GRAIN EXPORTS
description: Not every American business executive can boast of having had a private meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the new Soviet leader, but Dwayne O. Andreas is not your typical businessman.

title: SOLDIERS PROTECT A WHITE TOWN IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Army and police units threw a protective ring around white residential areas near this troubled black township today, where five black people were hacked and burned to death by blacks in revenge killings Saturday.

title: Ivor Wallace Hughes Dies; Headed Tobacco Company
description: Ivor Wallace Hughes, the chairman and chief executive officer of the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, died Friday night after several months of an undisclosed illness. He was 59 years old.

title: First Jersey Faces Challenge
description: The president of First Jersey Securities, Robert Brennan, having survived a S.E.C. investigation into his firm's high-powered sales practices, is now facing a renewed challenge to his operation.

title: SURPRISING SETBACK FOR BANK
description: Ben F. Love likes to rub shoulders with the rich and famous.

title: Washington Watch;   A Hard Line Against Japan
description: WASHINGTON THE Reagan Cabinet has rejected as inadequate moves taken so far by Japan to reduce

title: DANCE: JIM SELF PERFORMS AT THE KITCHEN
description: Jim Self was choreographically ingenious enough to make each of the three works that Jim Self and Dancers presented Saturday night at the Kitchen seem to occur in an entirely different world.

title: Stephenson First
description: Jan Stephenson became the Ladies Professional Golf Association's newest millionaire when she shot a 75 that was good enough for a one- stroke victory in the $250,000 GNA tournament today.

title: KING FEARED LOST
description: Bernard King, the Knicks' captain and the National Basketball Association's leading scorer, was scheduled today to undergo what Dr. Norman Scott, the team doctor, described as ''diagnostic arthroscopic surgery'' for what could be a season-ending injury to his right knee.

title: THE PRESS IN LEBANON
description: During 10 years of civil war, lawlessness, the Israeli invasion and anarchic danger, Western foreign correspondents based in Beirut have daily swallowed their fear to report on the situation in Lebanon. Two incidents in the last week have highlighted the risks for journalists, raising questions in many news organizations about how they can continue to report on events in the country adequately.

title: BAKER SHIFTS TAX PROPOSAL CHANGES
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d has begun to sift through alternatives for changing the Treasury's tax revision plan of last November, but it will be weeks before he and President Reagan decide what to propose to Congress, according to Administration officials.

title: Catching Up
description: * Chet Simmons, who resigned Jan. 14 as commissioner of the United States Football League, has become a man about his house in Greenwich, Conn. ''I'm taking things easy,'' he said, ''and spending time with my family. I took my kids skiing two weeks ago. I'm going away with my wife for two weeks in April. I'm enjoying this, because I haven't had a chance to do it the last five or six years.'' His plans? ''At this point,'' he said, ''I have no plans.''

title: G.O.P. DRAFTS NEW TAX PLAN AS A BUDGET DEADLINE NEARS
description: With Democrats and Republicans still split over tax cuts - their size and the form they will take - the Republicans said today that they had fashioned a counteroffer to an expanded proposal made by Governor Cuomo and legislative Democrats.

title: LOOIE MAKES THE FOUR
description: DENVER

title: FRANK ANDERSEN IS NAMED ROYAL DANISH BALLET DIRECTOR
description: Frank Andersen has been named to direct the Royal Danish Ballet. Mr. Andersen, a principal dancer with the company, succeeds Henning Kronstam. He will take over the post on Aug. 1, under a five-year contract.

title: FROM PARIS, A NEW EMPHASIS ON THE COAT
description: Despite luminous presentations by Claude Montana and Karl Lagerfeld, the fall and winter fashion openings passed the halfway mark over the weekend without radically changing the course of fashion.

title: FEBRUARY TOOL ORDERS ROSE 12.4%
description: Orders for American-made machine tools rose 12.4 percent in February from the month before and 17.1 percent from February 1984, the industry's trade association said in a report to be released today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It took me 35 years to get here, and you ask me about Georgetown.

title: SEOUL SAYS CHINESE CREW WANTS TO GO HOME
description: The South Korean Government said today that 13 surviving crew members of a disabled Chinese torpedo boat who are in its custody had expressed a desire to be sent back home.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO DEVELOP OMAN AS ITS MAJOR ALLY IN THE GULF
description: In the six years since the Iranian revolution, the strategically placed and isolated nation of Oman has emerged as Washington's most reliable ally in the Persian Gulf, according to Western, Omani and other Arab officials.

title: BALLET: 'MAHLER'S SIXTH,' BY HAMBURG
description: Like his choreography to Mahler's Third and Fourth Symphonies, John Neumeier's ''Mahler's Sixth Symphony,'' the final premiere of the Hamburg Ballet season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, sports a musical title. An essay upon the music, it is also an antiwar ballet. That is its incontrovertible message, and it is a message, not an implication.

title: SOUL: TEMPTATIONS AND 4 TOPS
description: The Temptations and the Four Tops, appearing together at the Gershwin Theater through last night, exemplify two aspects of a pop-soul vocal tradition that saw its finest moment in the mid-60's. Nearly 20 years later, however, that tradition still seems fresh, though hardly trend-setting.

title: 1 TO 4 STUDENTS AT EVERS SAID TO BE ON PROBATION
description: Nearly 400 students at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn have been dismissed or placed on probation in the last four months for failure to meet the college's academic standards, according to the school's president.

title: Los Angeles Explosion Ruins Store, Hurting 21
description: A gas explosion blew the roof off a department store in a shopping center today, injuring at least 21 people and possibly burying more beneath the rubble of the building, the officials said.

title: How E.S.M. Figured in Marvin Warner's Plans
description: The consequences of the dealings between companies controlled by Marvin L. Warner and the failed E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. have become clear in the stormy weeks since E.S.M. closed earlier this month. Now, some light is being shed on just what Mr. Warner may have been hoping to accomplish through the risky, and in one case ruinous, transactions.

title: Bear, Stearns Official To Lead Senate Panel
description: The Senate Budget Committee has selected Joseph M. Giglio, director of Bear, Stearns & Company's public finance department, to head a new advisory panel on financing the nation's infrastructure.

title: CBS Aide Sees Death Scene
description: A CBS News vice president looking into the deaths of two CBS News crew members viewed the area today at Kfar Melki in Southern Lebanon where they were killed last week.

title: Van Crash Kills College Sprinter
description: East Carolina University officials say they are ''stunned'' by the death of a sprinter in the crash of a van bringing the track team back from a Georgia meet.

title: FAMILIES ON AID JUGGLE BILLS AND MONEY TO LIVE
description: When Donna Keyes's youngest child, 16-month-old Eugene, accidentally swallowed dishwashing detergent, she grabbed him and, leaving her two other children alone, dashed out into the rain to find a cab to the hospital.

title: REAGAN ASSERTS SANDINISTAS USE 'STALIN'S TACTIC'
description: President Reagan accused the Nicaraguan Government today of using ''Stalin's tactic'' in relocating thousands of citizens who he said ''do not support their tyrannical regime.''

title: FINESSING A SHORT SHOT
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

title: Deportation Issue SlowsMengelCase
description: A Canadian judge agreed today to delay court proceedings against Alex J. Mengel, a fugitive who is accused of two killings in New York State, until immigration officials decide whether to deport Mr. Mengel.

title: Soviet Reported to Bug Embassy Typewriters
description: Soviet electronic bugs secretly planted in typewriters at the United States Embassy in Moscow may have seriously compromised highly classified information being handled by diplomats at the embassy, CBS News reported tonight.

title: FLORIO DECLINES TO RUN FOR GOVERNOR OF JERSEY
description: Representative James J. Florio, the Democrat who lost to Governor Kean by fewer than 1,800 votes in the 1981 gubernatorial election, said today he would pass up the chance for a rematch.

title: MCGUIRE TO LOU, A BIT OF DEJA VU
description: Thirty-three years later, the St.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;  $4.3 Billion Financing Heads New State Issues
description: Various authorities and local governments in New York State expect to sell nearly $6.3 billion of new securities in the quarter beginning in April, according to the State Securities Coordinating Committee.

title: Four Killed in Drag Race
description: A 20-year-old man was charged today with reckless homicide in the deaths of four youths who were killed in the course of what police say was a drag race on a winding street.

title: Some Bright Spots in City Housing Survey
description: To the Editor:

title: BILLS SEEK TO AID ELDERLY ON COSTS OF PRESCRIPTIONS
description: State Senate Republicans today introduced their own legislation designed to help the elderly poor pay for prescription drugs. Their measures came less than a week after proposals by Assembly and Senate Democrats and Governor Cuomo.

title: REAGAN SUGGESTS A MEETING IN FALL
description: President Reagan said today that the issue of American concern about Soviet violations of past arms agreements was ''a subject that would very definitely come up in a summit meeting'' with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, possibly this fall.

title: Costly Drama in Albany
description: Governor Cuomo and New York's legislative leaders present themselves as dramatically deadlocked over the state budget. Mr. Cuomo pleads for compassionate fiscal soundness, while Warren Anderson, the Republican Senate Majority Leader, declaims against governmental perfidy and high taxes. Stanley Fink, the Democratic Assembly Speaker, meanwhile, presents himself as the tough guy speaking out for the people's long-term interest.

title: MUSIC: STEPHEN SIMON LEADS OFFBEAT HANDEL 'ORATORIO'
description: Handel's ''Occasional Oratorio'' at the Kennedy Center Sunday night was a premiere, and then it wasn't. To explain: The piece may be new to this country - as the Kennedy Center Handel Festival says - but a lot of the music is not.

title: EX-INTELLIGENCE AGENTS ARE SAID TO HAVE MAJOR ROLES IN OMAN
description: Among the foreign advisers who have played a major role in the Persian Gulf nation of Oman is a former senior Central Intelligence Agency official who heads an American corporation that manages the country's most strategic region.

title: BROOKS, AN EXPO, MISSES NEW YORK
description: To put it simply, if he had the chance to answer the question again, Hubie Brooks would say no - loudly, clearly and unmistakably no. The problem is, he said yes when it counted, and his answer led to his departure from New York.

title: Inflation Up in Belgium
description: Consumer prices in Belgium rose eight- tenths of 1 percent this month and the annual average inflation rate rose to 5.7 percent from 5.3 percent, the Ministry for Economic Affairs said today. The most substantial price increases from the levels of February were for gas, electricity, gasoline and heating oil, the ministry said.

title: India Voices Concern On Russian's Defection
description: The Indian Government expressed ''serious concern'' today over the defection to the United States of a Soviet diplomat based here and urged Washington to give full details of the case.

title: BUDGET FREEZE URGED BY LEAGUE OF CITIES FOR MOST PROGRAMS
description: The National League of Cities called today for a Federal budget freeze that would keep all spending, except for the poor and the elderly, at current levels in the next fiscal year.

title: CANADIAN LEADER LINKS SPACE-ARMS ROLE TO JOBS
description: Canada may consider getting involved in President Reagan's research on a space-based missile defense system if it generates more employment, according to Prime Minister Brian Mulroney.

title: MINNESOTA ARCHBISHOP SENTENCED TO JAIL TERM FOR DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: The Archbishop of St. Paul- Minneapolis was ordered to spend 38 hours in jail after he pleaded guilty today to a charge of drunken driving and paid a $445 fine.

title: JUSTICES TO DECIDE A CASE ON REDRAWING DISTRICTS
description: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide, for the first time, whether a gerrymander violates the Constitution.

title: KIRK URGES LABOR TO DELAY ENDORSEMENTS IN 1988
description: Paul G. Kirk Jr., the Democratic National Committee chairman, asked organized labor today not to endorse a Presidential candidate early in the 1988 primaries.

title: IN ETHIOPIA'S BACK COUNTRY, AID WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: A few days ago an airplane landed here. It was the first ever to touch down on the plateau by this little village in the isolated heart of Ethiopia's central highlands.

title: Part of Jack Eckerd
description: Moves to Thompson

title: U.S.-BACKED GROUP DONATES $100,000 TO NICARAGUA PAPER
description: A federally financed foundation has given $100,000 to La Prensa, the opposition newspaper in Nicaragua that is heavily censored by the Sandinista Government.

title: No Headline
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 26, 1985 International

title: SYMPHONY: GIELEN LEADS CINCINNATI
description: GIVEN enough time, a competent conductor can mold an orchestra into something near to his heart's desire, an instrument for expressing his own musical esthetic. That has been happening to the Cincinnati Symphony under Michael Gielen, the distinctly competent German conductor who is now in his fifth season as the orchestra's music director. Mr. Gielen came to the post an acknowledged expert in the contemporary literature, particularly the music of Schoenberg, Webern and Berg. So it was no surprise to find his program last night at Carnegie Hall starting off with a concert version of Schoenberg's nerve- shredding essay in Expressionist agony, ''Ewartung.'' Considering the predictable fare that most visiting orchestras serve up, this sharp departure from the standard repertory was a relief.

title: JOY, ASTONISHMENT AND PAIN ARE PART OF OSCAR'S AFTERMATH
description: F. Murray Abraham, a mixture of triumph, joy and grace after winning the Academy Award as 1984's best actor, said he had had ''absolutely'' no inkling that he would win the Oscar.

title: PRESSURES AND REWARDS FACE HOUSE MEMBERS ON MX VOTE
description: Silvio O. Conte, an opponent of the MX missile, might lose an agricultural service office for his Congressional district.

title: H.R.A. CHIEF APPOINTS 6 TO HIGH POSTS
description: The Commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration yesterday appointed six people to top management jobs on his staff as part of a reorganization of the troubled agency.

title: COPPER SMELTER CLOSES ON COAST AS MARKET SHRINKS FOR METAL
description: George Purdy worked his last day today as a subforeman at the Asarco Copper Smelter here. Now he and his wife, Helen, will have to depend on unemployment checks and her small antique shop to pay the bills.

title: Ways to Reduce Infant Mortality
description: To the Editor:

title: Zaccaro Would Do It Again
description: Does John A. Zaccaro rue the day his wife agreed to run for Vice President, thus exposing him to court proceedings over his financial dealings? The answer, for the record at least, is no.

title: ON THE MAP
description: John Walker of New Zealand recently became the first runner to have posted 100 sub-four-minute miles in a career. But our story begins a bit earlier, as Walker neared the milestone.

title: Some in Union Back Accord With Pan Am
description: Some of the leaders of the Transport Workers Union recommended yesterday that the 5,800 striking workers accept the tentative agreement reached last Saturday with Pan American World Airways, saying rejection could lead to the loss of many jobs.

title: 'STUN GUNS' USED TO SUBDUE 3 MEN IN COURTROOM BRAWL
description: The arraignment of five people charged with bombing 10 sites in the New York area erupted into a courtroom melee yesterday in which Federal marshals in Brooklyn used battery-powered ''stun guns'' on three of the defendants.

title: Computer Magazines' Struggles
description: ''RIGHT now everyone is scrambling for position,'' Bartlett R. Rhoades said, surveying the warlike activities in the computer magazine field from a safe breakfast nook in the Parker Meridien Hotel.

title: People
Paper Ordered to Pay $1 Million in Libel Case
description: A judge ruled today that a newspaper and one of its former writers libeled a county official in an editorial that accused the official of lying.

title: Quotation System Starts Aggressively
description: Walsh, Greenwood Inc. is a brokerage house that developed a computerized quotation system of its very own and has now decided to go into business offering the service to others.

title: Efficient Redmen
description: Just how good are the Redmen of St. John's? And, while we're at it, just how bad are the Knicks? Consider:

title: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL CONCERNS AFFECT DECISION ON RISE IN AID
description: The issue of increasing the welfare allowance is a thorny one, both because of public resentment against those who receive government subsidies and concern by officials that a higher allotment would lessen incentive to get off the welfare rolls.

title: COURT UPHOLDS BAN ON WRIGLEY LIGHTS
description: A Cook County Circuit judge today upheld the constitutionality of state and local laws that effectively bar the installation of lights at Wrigley Field, the only unlighted stadium in baseball.

title: No Headline
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 26, 1985

title: Jest at Gridiron Dinner Backfires on President
description: President Reagan joked at the Gridiron Club's annual dinner that America ''should keep the grain and export the farmers,'' drawing the wrath of farmers and leading to a White House explanation.

title: GORBACHEV PUSHES CORRUPTION DRIVE
description: Today it was the Coal Ministry that came under attack in Pravda, and the head of the Bratsk city party committee who was dismissed.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 26, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: STUDY SAYS SPACE ARMS PLAN IMPERILS ABM PACT
description: A report prepared for a private group says that by 1989, President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative ''will come into conflict'' with the treaty limiting antimissile defenses.

title: STRUGGLE WAGED FOR DECISIVE MX VOTES IN HOUSE
description: The House began debate today on the Reagan Administration's request for 21 new MX missiles, but the real action took place in the back rooms of the Capitol and at the White House, as supporters and opponents of the strategic 96-ton, 71-foot weapon wrestled for the few remaining uncommitted votes.

title: TURNOVERS KEY TO GOLD VICTORY
description: Vince Evans scrambled 5 yards for a touchdown and passed for another as the Denver Gold capitalized on turnovers by San Antonio to defeat the Gunslingers, 16-2, tonight in a United States Football League game.

title: U.S. AGENCY DROPS ITS RULE ON MINES
description: The Interior Department has decided to withdraw a rule that eased conditions for exercising mineral rights in wilderness areas.

title: Sudan Leader to Visit U.S.
description: Gaafar al-Nimeiry, President of the Sudan, will arrive in the United States Wednesday for a 10-day private visit, the State Department said today. He will see President Reagan and other United States officials during the visit, according to a State Department spokesman.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Aquino Court Hears Tape From '83 Killing
description: An audio expert told a court here today that voices recorded on a video tape at the time of the murder of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. in 1983 said, ''I'll do it,'' ''Here he comes'' and ''Shoot him'' just moments before the shooting.

title: SENATE ARMS PANEL DRAFTING BILLS WITH 3 ALTERNATIVES FOR SPENDING
description: Over objections from the White House, the Senate Armed Services Committee has moved with unusual speed to begin writing a bill that would make substantial cuts in President Reagan's military budget.

title: Moss Coming Back
description: Stirling Moss, one of the most famous names in Formula One auto racing, is making a comeback at the age of 55 - in sports car endurance racing. Moss will race regularly in the United States this season beginning at Riverside, Calif., on March 30. It is 23 years since Moss crashed in a race in England and suffered broken bones up and down the left side of his body and a massive brain bruise.

title: An Omission
description: An editorial yesterday discussing the proposal that some public TV stations ''sell'' their VHF signals to commercial stations and move to the latter's weaker UHF channels in a swap inadvertently failed to mention an interest of The New York Times Company. The Times owns commercial television stations in two communities, Memphis and Fort Smith, Ark., where such signal swaps may become an issue.

title: GENERALS' VICTORY BUILDS CONFIDENCE
description: A consequence of the Generals' victory Sunday over the Tampa Bay Bandits was the players' changing perception of themselves as a team, a perception expressed today by several veterans in the locker room at Giants Stadium.

title: ACTED IN FILM, PLAYS AND YIDDISH RADIO
description: Zvee Scooler, an actor who appeared in the entire seven-year Broadway run of ''Fiddler on the Roof'' and spent half a century as a Yiddish commentator on WEVD Radio, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital in New York City after a short illness. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: WHY FEAR NICARAGUA?
description: The way President Reagan tells it, the Soviet Union and Cuba have turned Nicaragua into a superpower capable of overwhelming its neighbors - and even threatening the United States. But his assertion that the Sandinistas may have the ''largest and best-equipped military force in Central America'' rings hollow if you examine the military forces of United States-supported countries in the region.

title: SUPREME COURT TURNS DOWN CITY'S APPEAL ON WNYC-AM
description: The Supreme Court today refused to hear New York City's appeal of a ruling barring WNYC-AM, the city's municipally owned radio station, from operating at night.

title: G.E. IS EXPECTING TO BE INDICTED IN BILLINGS FOR NUCLEAR WARHEADS
description: The General Electric Company expects to be indicted today on charges of defrauding the Government during work on a nuclear- warhead system, a company spokesman said.

title: KOCH MEETS HIS 'MAYOR' COUNTERPART
description: They - meaning the director and producers - did exactly what he wanted them to do, Mayor Koch said yesterday, as he inspected the man selected to play him in ''Mayor,'' the musical based on his autobiographical book that is scheduled to begin previews April 25.

title: Dorothy Roe Lewis, 80, Dies; Ex-Columnist and A.P. Editor
description: Dorothy Roe Lewis, a former syndicated columnist who also covered women's issues for The Associated Press, died Sunday. She was 80 years old.

title: FRIENDS IN JAZZY TRIBUTE TO ZOOT SIMS
description: Benny Goodman, Woody Herman, George Shearing and Tommy Flanagan were among the 500 fans, friends and fellow jazz musicians who performed, spoke or simply appeared to pay tribute to Zoot Sims last night. The tenor saxophonist died of cancer on Saturday.

title: Sikh Council Urges Struggle for Rights
description: The main Sikh religious council called today for a mass struggle for restoration of civil liberties and withdrawal of the Indian Army from Punjab state, the main home of the country's Sikh minority.

title: TO KEEP LAWYERS FROM GOING WRONG
description: Rece ntly, I witnessed the admission of 100 young lawyers to practice before New York State's courts. They stood, right hands in the air, eager and perhaps somewhat frightened of what lay ahead, and swore to uphold the Constitutions and laws of the United States and New York State.

title: TWO PROJECTS FOR JACQUELINE BISSET
description: BORN in England, Jacqueline Bisset first gained some professional prominence playing a bit part in the 1967 film ''Two for the Road.'' Moving to this country, she has had a modestly successful career, ranging from pop potboilers such as ''The Deep'' to more ambitious productions like the recent ''Under the Volcano.'' Now, as she has been announcing in television and magazine interviews, she is in her 40's, which she considers to be treacherous waters for an actress, and she is attempting to establish a new, more mature image for herself. This week, as it happens, finds her starring in two new major productions: ''Anna Karenina,'' on CBS tonight at 8, and ''Forbidden,'' on Home Box Office at various times this month, including tomorrow night at 11:30. Miss Bisset, it would seem, is not about to have an easy time in her quest.

title: U.S. Details Evidence On Two Held as Spies
description: Two Soviet emigres charged with espionage were trying to ''earn'' their way back to the Soviet Union, prosecutors charged today.

title: Daniel F. Crowley, 69, Ex-Publishing Official
description: Daniel F. Crowley, retired executive vice president for finance of McGraw- Hill Inc., the publishing company, died Saturday at Yonkers General Hospital after a brief illness. He was 69 years old and lived in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: VERY HIGH LEVELS OF TOXIC MATERIAL ARE FOUND IN AIR
description: The first systematic survey of toxic chemicals being emitted into the nation's air has found hazardous materials at far higher levels and at many more locations than suspected, according to a Congressional survey to be released today.

title: Coach May Resign
description: The Arizona State University baseball coach,

title: 10.58% Top Yield For Georgia Issue
description: A $150 million issue of Municipal Electric Authority of Georgia revenue bonds was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of nearly 10.58 percent for bonds due in 2020, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 8 1/2 percent in 1992 to 10 percent in 2000 and 10 3/8 percent in 2005.

title: The Citrus Vote
description: Evelyn Weiser hates it when someone in an express checkout line checks out with excess items.

title: Deficit Soars $20.8 Billion
description: The Federal budget deficit expanded by $20.8 billion in February, the Government said today. That was three times the January increase.

title: Lobbyist on the Wing
description: Strike one name from the passenger list of the ''Fairness Express,'' a train bound for Washington today with hundreds of business, labor and other civic leaders who will spend the day lobbying in Congress.

title: Rising Numbers
description: Of Old and Poor

title: NEW TRIAL BEGINS IN CAROLINA CASE
description: -SALEM, N.C., March 25 - Opening arguments were heard this afternoon in a lawsuit stemming from the fatal shootings six years ago in Greensboro of five anti-Klan demonstrators.

title: CUOMO ATTACKS REAGAN ON HOLOCAUST COMMENT
description: Governor Cuomo today accused President Reagan of being ''extraordinarily insensitive'' about the Holocaust and said he had written a letter to the White House to express the view.

title: MASSIMINO 'FAMILY' REJOICES
description: In the bedlam of Villanova University's 56-year-old fieldhouse at 1 o'clock yesterday morning, Coach Rollie Massimino demanded silence. He got it.

title: HOW REAGAN PROMOTES ABORTIONS
description: Whatever one feels about the complex issue of abortion, Americans have reason to regret President Reagan's anti-abortion crusade. By eliminating United States aid to private family-planning organizations around the world, he is actually promoting rather than discouraging abortions.

title: COSTLY CO-OP CONVERSION PLANNED AT NORTH SHORE TOWERS IN QUEENS
description: A plan to convert the 1,850-unit North Shore Towers complex in Queens to cooperative apartments has been filed with the State Attorney General's office, and the proposed prices could make it the most expensive such conversion in the city, real-estate specialists said yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Briefing column on the Washington Talk page March 15 referred incorrectly to Clare Boothe Luce's residence. She lives in Washington.

title: 'Dazzling Dance' Series
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem will appear Saturday and Sunday at the Bush-Brown Concert Theater, Northern Boulevard, between Glen Cove Road and Route 107, Greenvale, L. I. The performances are part of a ''Dazzling Dance'' series sponsored by the Friends of the Arts.

title: Meryl Jaffe Weds Harvard Student
description: Meryl Jo Jaffe, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Jaffe of Lawrence, L.I., was married yesterday to Adam Gabriel Hurwich, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Baruch J. Hurwich of Jerusalem, formerly of New York and Boston. Rabbi Gilbert Klaperman and Cantor Marcus Ehrlich performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence.

title: Judge Enters Plea for Mayor
description: Mayor Roger Hedgecock refused today to plead to three criminal charges, saying he did not have a lawyer of his choice, so a judge entered a plea of not guilty for him. Judge Barbara Gamer set a May 8 trial date in Superior Court on the two charges of perjury and one misdemeanor charge involving a conflict of interest. A retrial also is to open that day on 13 conspiracy charges against Mr. Hedgecock.

title: MET SINGER KNOWN FOR 'BORIS'
description: George London, an American bass- baritone whose distinguished singing career was cut short by illness in the late 1960's, died Sunday night at his home in Armonk, N.Y. He was 64 years old and had been incapacitated for several years.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tim McCalister, a University of Oklahoma guard, has issued a formal apology for throwing water at a referee immediately following the Sooners' loss to Memphis State last Saturday. . . .

title: MOVE BY SHULTZ CASTS DOUBT ON STATUS OF U.N. NOMINEE
description: A conflict between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters has raised doubts about whether the general, newly appointed as American delegate to the United Nations, will accept the post, Administration officials said today.

title: 2 MORE WESTERNERS SEIZED IN LEBANON
description: A British journalist working for a United Nations agency was abducted by unidentified gunmen just outside the capital today, and a French official working in the northern port city of Tripoli was reported missing and feared kidnapped.

title: Strangers No More
description: President Nimeiry of the Sudan wanted no publicity for a simple act of decency - permitting the United States to airlift 800 stranded Ethiopian Jews to Israel. He deserves much credit for going ahead with the decision, but it is appalling that he felt compelled to downplay so modest a gesture.

title: PENGUINS TROUBLE RANGERS
description: The Rangers' practice ended quietly yesterday, much the way their season is ending. Coach Craig Patrick had only the obvious to say to his players. He thought he had said everything else.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: THREE RINGS, AND MORE The Arsenal, in Central Park at 64th Street and Fifth Avenue, is a dour and ancient building, now headquarters of the Department of Parks and Recreation. During the 1870's, it housed a natural-history museum that drew throngs who admired, among other things, the reproductions of animals in the collection. Nowadays, the Arsenal has a gallery on the third floor where, through this week, one may see an attractively displayed exhibition, ''This Way to the Big Show,'' that serves as apostrophe to the circus as it has appeared in New York since the city's early years.

title: INTEREST RATES SLIGHTLY LOWER
description: Interest rates for short- and long- term Treasury securities fell slightly yesterday.

title: Bank Rescue In Canada
description: The Canadian Government has put together a $255 million program to rescue the Canadian Commercial Bank, based in Edmonton, Alberta.

title: Ruland May Return
description: Jeff Ruland, the Washington Bullets' center who missed nearly half the season with a nagging injury to his right shoulder, says he may return as early as tonight against the Bucks, even though he says the injury limits his ability to fully extend his right arm without pain. . . . There were fears Portland's

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Tripucka Assailed
description: The Portland Trail Blazer coach,

title: ;   Court Guarantees Money's Right to Talk
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN OFFICER KILLED BY RUSSIAN IN EAST GERMANY
description: A United States Army major on a reconnaissance mission in East Germany was fatally shot Sunday by a Soviet guard near a Soviet military installation, American officials said today.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: If it's raining, it must be the fashion collections. That's what everyone in Paris is saying these days. That's what they say twice a year during the ready-to-wear shows because it always seems to rain at showtime. Until last week, the weather was sunny and cold, then poof! Today, at least there was a mixture of rain and sun. Oh, well, it gives the visiting retailers something to talk about when they meet competitors at the many parties they run around to at night. After all, they don't want to divulge too much about what they are buying for their stores or which hot new designers they have discovered.

title: New Standards On Asbestos Set
description: The State Department of Health released new standards today for the detection and safe removal of asbestos from schools and called them the most stringent in the nation.

title: GUARDING EWING KEEPS DALTON IN SHAPE
description: Don't ask Ralph Dalton to feel sorry for Don Henderson, Granger Hall, Andre Moore or Yvon Joseph, the four young centers who are sitting at home this week after they and their teams lost their battles against the indefatigable Patrick Ewing and Georgetown in the East Regional. He isn't. Not one bit.

title: That MX Cheerleader
description: Anyone who doubts that the White House is anxious about the House vote today on the MX missile may consult Representative Carroll Hubbard Jr., Democrat of Kentucky. Last Friday afternoon he was attending a statewide high school basketball tournament in Lexington, Ky., virtually a command performance for any Kentucky politician.

title: METS' PITCHING ROSTER IN FLUX
description: Frank Cashen conceded today that the Mets have some pitching problems, especially in the starting rotation, but said: ''We're committed to going with our young arms, and we'll have to go that way.''

title: THE LIVES OF THE CAVE DWELLERS
description: Janet Farr, an octogenarian who has lived in Washington all her life, cheerily acknowledges that she is ''a cave dweller,'' a term, indigenous to Washington, that defines a member of those families who have resided here for generations and whose bloodlines are woven into the warp and woof of the nation's capital.

title: APARTHEID FOE KEPT OUT OF TOWNSHIP
description: A leading cleric who is a prominent foe of white minority rule in South Africa was turned back at gunpoint by the police today when he sought to enter the township here where at least 19 black people were shot by the police last week.

title: SHULTZ AND BAGHDAD OFFICIALS MEET
description: United States intelligence analysts have concluded that Iraq used lethal chemical weapons in repelling Iran's latest offensive in the southern sector, Administration officials said today.

title: Without Regrets
description: -glitter-filled pitching career three years ago and who now farms and does a bit of acting on the side, reflects on the turns his life has taken: ''I never think about what might have been. I'm happy with what I achieved, and I think about what I've got now. For me, that's plenty.''

title: Gotbaum on City Politics
description: It was the anti-Koch coalition that wasn't, one of its key players now says.

title: No No. 2 for Regan?
description: When Donald T. Regan took over as White House chief of staff in January, he told some associates that in time he would like to name a replacement for Michael K. Deaver, the deputy chief of staff, who is leaving in May.

title: LAGERFELD BRIGHTENS CHANEL
description: The mood of the fall and winter fashion shows here shifted perceptibly this morning as the couture houses presented their ready-to-wear collections. The clothes were in the spotlight and there were no theatrical tricks. They were well made, attractive and honestly presented.

title: Let the Greeks Judge
description: Papandreou's Policies

title: RALPH B. MELLIX
description: Ralph B. (Lefty) Mellix, who pitched more than 1,500 games for Negro Baseball League teams, died Saturday after a heart attack.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball

title: Koch Would Limit Landlords' Markup On Electricity Cost
description: Mayor Koch called yesterday for a 12 percent limit on the markup that landlords of commercial buildings charge their tenants in reselling electricity obtained from the Consolidated Edison Company.

title: RECITAL: JARRETT AT AVERY FISHER HALL
description: -century pianist plays Bach and other Baroque composers, hunches over the keyboard humming ecstatically, and fills huge halls with devoted followers? The late Glenn Gould, you might guess, before he became a recluse? Yes, but also Keith Jarrett, who sold out Avery Fisher Hall Friday night for his first New York classical recital.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I feel a special responsibility now, having had to face my own flawedness, to invite everyone, especially young people, to join me in promising God, that with his help, we will never again risk the consequences of drinking and driving.'' - Archbishop John Roach of St. Paul-Minneapolis, after pleading guilty to drunken driving. (A14:6.)

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: -Century England. By Louis

title: REGIONALS FALL WAY SHORT IN EXCITEMENT
description: Thank goodness that's over. There's no reason

title: 'Fast Roll-Call' Passes Court Test
description: The United States Supreme Court today rejected a challenge to a New York legislative custom that permits the passage of bills with 5 of 60 state senators present.

title: The MX as Scarecrow
description: The Administration and Congress are interrupting their search for budget cuts this week by moving to commit the nation to a $40 billion mistake. It is called the MX or Peacekeeper missile, for which 10 years of discussion have produced no military rationale. President Reagan no longer insists on the MX as a necessary or even desirable weapon. It being militarily superfluous, he hopes to trade it away in a future arms agreement.

title: Seoul Says It Is Willing To Return Chinese Crew
description: South Korea signaled its willingness today to return a Chinese naval boat and crew that had drifted into its waters, but officials in Seoul appeared to be insisting first on a statement of contrition from Peking.

title: Offer to Sonny Smith
description: East Tennessee State University has offered the Auburn basketball coach,

title: 'AMADEUS,' IN SWEEP OF OSCARS, WINS BEST-FILM AND SEVEN OTHER AWARDS
description: ''Amadeus,'' a movie about a mediocre court composer's jealousy of Mozart, won the largest number of Academy Awards tonight. Its eight awards included those for best picture, best director - Milos Forman - and best actor - F. Murray Abraham, in the role of the envious Antonio Salieri.

title: CAPITAL CITIES' STYLE: CAN IT TRANSFER TO ABC?
description: When Capital Cities Communications agreed to take over ABC last week, the first thing most people wanted to know was: who are they? Even if those outside the television industry didn't know who ran ABC, they knew what it put on the air; Capital Cities seemed an unknown quantity.

title: Debt Issues
description: M.D.C. Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $75 million of convertible subordinated debentures due 2000, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: GREEN BOOK: SOCIAL 'BIBLE'
description: There are those who seemingly would do all but kill to get listed in a green felt-covered book that is considered ''the bible'' by many Washingtonians.

title: Koch Gets Challenge On Real-Estate Policy
description: Calling on Mayor Koch to ''come out from behind the smoke screen of personal attacks,'' City Council President Carol Bellamy yesterday offered to debate him on the tax abatements the city has given to housing developers in recent years.

title: CARNESECCA IS ALL SMILES AND HOPES AFTER VICTORY
description: His smile seemed to precede the rest of him through the door, and no sooner had Lou Carnesecca stepped into the Hall of Fame Club at Madison Square Garden yesterday then men stood waiting to hug him, embrace him, congratulate him for a job well done.

title: Anti-Arafat Forces in P.L.O. Start New Unit to Fight Israel
description: Six Palestinian guerrilla groups opposed to the policies of Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian Liberation Organization leader, said today that they had formed the Palestinian National Salvation Front to fight Israel.

title: BRIEFING
description: Hair, Hair

title: REAGAN'S UNINTENDED ELOQUENCE
description: Sometimes you have to wonder if

title: 4-Year-Old Decorum
description: The Capitol is not quite the awesome place it is sometimes pictured.

title: THE WASHINGTONIZATION OF NANCY REAGAN
description: After White House state dinners now, while coffee is being served, Nancy Reagan waits patiently while her husband answers several questions from reporters hovering on the side. At a signal, the flicker of her eyes, a staff member glides to the President's side and escorts him back to the dinner.

title: LEGISLATOR VISITS CLASS TAUGHT BY 1984 REVIVAL
description: After hammering home two cogent points, the guest lecturer thrust a finger skyward and advanced toward his scholarly conclusion.

title: Bridge:First New York Event Held For Flight B National Teams
description: In recent years, the American Contract Bridge League has made a successful effort to devise national competitions for players who are not in the top rank. The latest of these is the Flight B Grand National Teams, limited to players with fewer than 500 master points.

title: Arkansas Teacher Test Is Sold for $1,000
description: Tight security surrounding the state's teacher testing program may have failed, enabling a copy of the test to be stolen and sold for up to $1,000 a copy, investigators said today.

title: SURGERY IS URGED FOR KING
description: The diagnostic arthroscopic surgery performed yesterday on Bernard King at Lenox Hill Hospital revealed that the Knick captain had suffered a torn ligament and torn cartilage in his right knee. He will not play for the remainder of the season..

title: Clancy to Miss Opener
description: The Toronto Blue Jays have placed the right-hander

title: UNDERACHIEVING PISTONS FAIL ON DEFENSE
description: Isiah Thomas stood behind the basket at the Boston Garden last June watching a Celtic practice before the fifth game of the National Basketball Association championship series against the Los Angeles Lakers. As he watched the Celtics run a play, the Detroit Pistons' all-star playmaker flashed his infectious smile and said, ''We'll be here next year.''

title: Letter: On Hospices
description: Get a Second Opinion on Terminal Care

title: A WORD ON 'GERRYMANDER'
description: In 1811, Elbridge Gerry, a Democrat who was then Governor of Massachusetts, signed into law a bill redrawing a Congressional district in the state. His intention was to carve out a Democratic majority in a region historically loyal to the Federalist Party, thereby securing a political advantage for his party.

title: G.O.P. REVISES TAX PROPOSAL
description: Republicans in the Legislature today proposed a revised tax package in budget talks with the Governor and Democrats, but no progress was made.

title: Jerseyan Is Held As Peril to Reagan
description: A New Jersey man was ordered held in $1 million bail today on charges of threatening the life of President Reagan, Federal authorities said.

title: Cash Is Toppled In Milan Tennis
description: Gianni Ocleppo of Italy upset third- seeded Pat Cash of Australia, 1-6, 7-5, 6-4, in a first-round match of the $380,000 Fila Trophy indoor tennis tournament today.

title: Setting a Date For Tournament
description: Despite Chris Evert Lloyd's first- round loss and New York's concurrent preoccupation with the progress of the St. John's basketball team, the weeklong Virginia Slims Championships at Madison Square Garden drew a total of 80,584 fans, a record for a women's-only tennis event anywhere.

title: Recycled Blossoms
description: The primroses and lilies will bloom again at the Clinton Community Garden. The white rosebushes will grace the border of the La Guardia Corner Gardens in Greenwich Village.

title: PLANS DRAWN FOR ANTICIPATED COUNCIL LEADER RACE
description: Thomas J. Cuite, the City Council's majority leader, has not announced if he will seek re-election this year, but Democratic county leaders are already manuevering over his post, one of the most powerful in city government.

title: U.S. SAYS SHOOTING WAS NOT JUSTIFIED
description: The United States said today that the killing of an Army major by a Soviet sentry in East Germany was ''totally unjustified.''

title: Met Opera Auditions
description: The annual finalists' concert of the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions will take place at the Metropolitan Opera House on April 14, beginning at 2:45 P.M. The 11 finalists were among 2,000 applicants from the United States, Puerto Rico, Canada and Australia who were heard during the last year.

title: Stars' Late Rally Beats Canucks, 5-3
description: Dirk Graham and Neal Broten scored goals 13 seconds apart late in the third period tonight to rally the Minnesota North Stars to a 5-3 victory over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Industry's 60-Year Fight Against Getting the Lead Out of the Air
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess:Hard, Clear Facts of Reality Follow a Haze of Euphoria
description: There is nothing so destructive as overvaluing one's attack and nothing so disheartening as to discover the truth.

title: SALVADORAN REBLES WAGE ASSASSINATION CAMPAIGN
description: Leftist guerrillas have carried out a series of political assassinations and several attacks on municipal buildings as El Salvador prepares for national legislative and local elections next Sunday.

title: Bail Cut for Islands Official
description: A Federal magistrate today reduced bail to $1.1 million from $2 million for Norman Saunders, the former chief minister of the Turks and Caicos Islands, who recently resigned after being charged with conspiracy to import cocaine. Mr. Saunders remained in jail. A videotape that the Government said depicted Mr. Saunders receiving a $20,000 bribe from an undercover agent was made public today. The tape was shown at a previous hearing.

title: Saatchi & Saatchi Shifts Top Executives
description: Saatchi & Saatchi of London, which grew from nothing to join the world's top 10 advertising agencies in only 15 years, did it without its founding brothers, Maurice and Charles, ever taking on the mantle of a corporate title.

title: Skip the 'Charming'
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXANS WORRY ABOUT LOSING NATURE'S TOUCH
description: Bob Armstrong's ranch is only 35 miles out of Austin as the crow flies, a little over 50 if you have to walk.

title: HOW BIG EAST SEES REDMEN VS. HOYAS
description: Throughout its two-week stay in the west, St. John's handled practically everything thrown its way. But despite their best manuevering, the Redmen could not shake the presence of Georgetown. No matter how well they played, the question was always would the performance have been good enough to beat Georgetown?

title: Texas Utilities Rating Change
description: For the third time in a little more than a year, Texas Utilities Electric, a unit of the Texas Utilities Company, has been given a lower debt rating by Standard & Poor's. Until late February 1984, when S.&P. made its first reduction, the company was one of the few utilities in the country whose bonds were rated AAA.

title: KNICKS LOSE AGAIN, WILL FINISH LAST
description: Sidney Moncrief scored 23 points and the rookie Kenny Fields scored a career-high 21 points to spark the Milwaukee Bucks to a 126-106 victory over the Knicks tonight.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues
