NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
British Miners Reject A Fund for Comrades
description: Britain's coal miners today voted down a proposal by union leaders for a small weekly levy on their paychecks to help 500 miners who were dismissed during the 51-week strike.

title: FOR MOTHERS, JOY AND PRIDE
description: In addition to everything else it represents, the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament could stand as a monument to parenthood - a toast to the men and women who have spent years of weekends shuttling back and forth to games, nursing injuries and bruised egos.

title: Pope Asks Youth To Face Nuclear Issue
description: Pope John Paul II told young people today that the earth was in danger of becoming ''a graveyard of nuclear death.''

title: REAGAN'S WARRIOR DIPLOMACY
description: WASHINGTON In the fight over the MX missile, finally approved by the House 219 to

title: JESUIT COLLEGES STRIVE TO PRESERVE ELITE TRADITION
description: Mary Ellen Minnuto, a senior at Canisius College, a Jesuit institution here, will graduate this May having taken only one course taught by a Jesuit.

title: INDUSTRY CHIEFS BACK U.S. CURBS ON POLLUTED AIR
description: Officers of major chemical companies, reversing their longtime position, joined members of Congress today in calling for stricter Government controls over toxic air pollutants.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday, on evidence that Iraq recently used chemical weapons, at one point misidentified the nation cited in American accusations last March. The officials said Iraq had been using nerve gas and that it was developing a capacity for full-scale chemical warfare attacks.

title: OSROW PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
MILLER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
STOCKS GAIN MODESTLY IN SLOW DAY
description: Stock prices closed mostly higher yesterday on Wall Street, but disappointing earnings forecasts from several major companies kept investors out of the market and trading volume fell short of 100 million shares for the fourth consecutive session.

title: Advertising;   Ad Clutter And Cable Television
description: IN its war with broadcast television

title: PLAINS RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: STREAMLINING THE HIGH COURT
description: Is the United States Supreme Court facing a workload crisis that threatens its capacity to perform its constitutional function? A dramatic increase in the number of cases brought to the Court has prompted Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and others to propose creating a new national court of appeals that would promulgate nationally binding law in cases referred to it by the Supreme Court.

title: MICROPRO INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: TEXAS INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,315,000 for the quarter and year. c-After an extraordinary charge of $722,000 from early retirement of debt. d-After an extraordinary loss of $13,250,000.

title: A MAN GOETZ SHOT IS CHARGED WITH FAKING OWN ABDUCTION
description: One of the four young men shot by Bernhard H. Goetz was arrested last night on charges that he falsely reported his own kidnapping to the police.

title: STATE SAYS REPORTED CRIMES DROPPED 4% LAST YEAR
description: The number of reported crimes in New York State declined by 4 percent last year, reaching the lowest level in at least nine years, according to a report released today by the State Division of Criminal Justice Services.

title: U.S. ROLE ON SHOREHAM IS SHOWN IN DOCUMENTS
description: Officials of the United States Department of Energy have been actively conferring with each other and counterparts at other departments to find ways to help license the Shoreham nuclear power plant, according to department documents.

title: AN AMERICAN CHEF IN PARIS: CRAB CAKES AND CORN STICKS
description: Somewhere along the line, it was decided to turn the gastronomic tables and offer the French a real taste of America. So last week Leon Lianides, owner of Manhattan's Coach House Restaurant, flew to the French capital carrying Maryland lump crab meat, Great Lakes golden caviar and Minnesota wild rice, which he prepared for diners at Chiberta, the Michelin two- star restaurant just off the Champs Elysees.

title: KNICKS LOSE 3D IN A ROW
description: World B. Free scored 10 of his 16 points in the third quarter to spark the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 112-98 victory over the Knicks tonight.

title: Leontyne Price Sings In Solo Recital at Met
description: The soprano Leontyne Price was a regal presence at the Metropolitan Opera for nearly a quarter of a century, ennobling heroines from Leonora to Carmen, Ariadne to A"ida. Miss Price made her operatic farewell in the last role two months ago, but returned to the Metropolitan Sunday evening for a solo recital.

title: MEASURE TO EXTEND BENEFITS FOR JOBLESS IS STALLED IN SENATE
description: The Senate bogged down today, preventing consideration of a $1 billion proposal to extend for six months a program that provides 8 to 14 weeks of supplemental unemployment benefits.

title: DEFECTION AMONG HOUSE DEMOCRATS
description: The vote on the MX missile today was not only a crucial victory for President Reagan but also a serious setback for the Democratic Party, already riven by splits and internal disarray after Mr. Reagan's landslide last November. The House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., made the MX showdown a ''vote of conscience,'' rather than an issue of party loyalty, somewhat cushioning the jolt of defeat for the House Democratic leadership.

title: Self-Help
description: Charlie Hough, one of only three major leaguers who still use the knuckleball as their primary pitch, explains why a coach simply can't be of much help to them: ''It's difficult for us to go to somebody and say, 'Hey, I'm having a tough time throwing the knuckleball,' when I know more about it than him.''

title: A FAREWELL THAT ISN'T A GOOD BUY
description: Q. When is final not final?

title: DIVERSE GOALS HINDER JAPAN TRADE TALKS
description: Trade frictions between the United States and Japan are again at a critical point. In the last few weeks, both sides have hurled charges of inflexibility and arrogance. And senior American officials appear to be seriously considering retaliatory measures, a prospect that prompts protests from Japan.

title: WALKER TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Simple Freeze ;   Would Aid Stability
description: To the Editor:

title: WINE TALK
description: THE California Barrel Tasting Dinner, the wine trade's most glittering social event, is no more, at least not in New York. The elegant annual dinner, which celebrated its 10th anniversary Monday night at the Four Seasons restaurant, will move next year to San Francisco.

title: ARMY GAMES DUE WITH HONDURANS
description: About 7,000 G.I.'s will begin two large-scale military exercises in Honduras over the next two months, a United States military spokesman here says.

title: DOCUTEL-OLIVETTI reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
ORGAN TRANSPLANTS IN 'GIFT OF LIFE'
description: ''T HE GIFT OF LIFE'' is a fine piece of work - serious, relevant and moving. It has purpose. Medical technology is translated in terms of human hopes, fears and needs. This can be harrowing, even exhausting, but the ''CBS Reports'' documentary would not be nearly so effective if it were anything else. It will be seen on Channel 2 at 10 P.M.

title: Court Bars Local Tax Breaks by States
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, by 5 to 4, that a state may not give preferential tax treatment to in-state companies solely for the purpose of fostering local business and investment.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Warner Lambert Fills New Position
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said yesterday that it had named Charles Y.C. Tse, currently an executive vice president, to the new post of vice chairman.

title: CUOMO REJECTS G.O.P. PLAN TO PUT OFF TAX ACTION
description: Republicans threw negotiations on the state budget into confusion today by proposing to defer all action on taxes.

title: DEL-VAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LEGISLATORS MOVE ON ATOM EXPORTS
description: Congress took a first step today toward cutting off foreign aid for any country that smuggles equipment or technology out of the United States for use in nuclear weapons.

title: Athletic Director Quits at Arizona St.
description: Dick Tamburo, the athletic director at Arizona State University, has resigned effective Wednesday, J. Russell Nelson, the university's president, said tonight.

title: PARAPHRASE OF THE BIBLE A BIG SELLER
description: A 1,285-page paraphrase of the Bible has sold more than a million copies since last August, and by this summer a million more will have rolled off the presses. ''The Book,'' as it is called, is being backed by a $10 million advertising campaign, the single largest promotion in the history of book publishing.

title: Allnet Layoffs
description: Allnet Communication Services Inc. said that it had laid off about 260 workers or roughly 15 percent of its work force. Allnet, a Chicago-based provider of discount long-distance telephone service, said it had reduced its work force because regulatory decisions had reduced its profitability. It cited higher access charges to connect to local customers.

title: Helen Wolff Awarded 1985 Goethe Medal
description: Helen Wolff, the American publisher, has been awarded the Goethe Medal this year by Goethe House, the German cultural institute in New York, in recognition of her contributions to international publishing.

title: GOETZ BALKS AT FACING GRAND JURY AS LIMIT ON QUESTIONS IS REFUSED
description: Bernhard H. Goetz, after days of conflicting statements by his lawyers about whether he would appear before a grand jury, refused yesterday to testify.

title: New U.D.C. Chief Confirmed
description: Vincent Tese, Governor Cuomo's choice to head the State Urban Development Corporation, received unanimous Senate approval today. Mr. Tese, 42 years old, has been Superintendent of Banking for two years. He succeeds William J. Stern as U.D.C. chairman and chief executive officer.

title: U.S. PLANS TO SEEK CLOSER SOVIET TIES IN SPITE OF SLAYING
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they planned to continue negotiations on improving relations with the Soviet Union despite the slaying of an Army major in East Germany by a Soviet soldier.

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 27, 1985 International

title: CBS RELINQUISHES SHAREHOLDER LIST
description: CBS Inc. yesterday turned over its list of shareholders to Fairness in Media, a conservative group allied with Senator Jesse Helms that hopes to take over CBS to end what the group contends is the network's liberal bias in reporting the news.

title: Bridge:Massachusetts Player, at 83, Passes 10,000 Master Points
description: For half a century bridge players have enjoyed L.O.L. jokes, about the Little Old Lady who wins some battle of wits with a ranking expert.

title: METROMAIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
GRENADIANS REPORT SIGNS OF AN ECONOMIC REVIVAL
description: Geoffrey Thompson, who runs one of the leading importing houses here, leaned back in his office chair the other day, his face beaming with anticipation.

title: Casey Stake in Capital Cities
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, holds some 34,000 shares in Capital Cities Communications Inc., the company that agreed last week to acquire the American Broadcasting Companies.

title: KNIGHT TAKES THE FLOOR
description: Five college coaches attended a

title: D A B INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $150,000 for the quarter, a tax credit of $1,020,000 for the year, a gain of $325,000 for the year from the extinguishment of debt, and a pre-tax gain of $3,000,000 for the year on the disposition of assets. c-Net loss.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''America has sent a message, loud and clear, that we back our negotiators, and we will continue to do so.'' - President Reagan, after the House backed his MX plan. (A1:6.)

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SONGS WITH A TALE The newest entry at the Hudson Guild Theater, 441 West 26th Street (760-9810), has singing but it is by no means a musical. ''September in the Rain,'' which opens tonight at 8, has several songs, and they might all be familiar to you. The very name of this play, a romantic comedy by John Godber, is that of a popular 1940's tune.

title: SEAHAWK OIL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Canadian Wins Appeal on Anti-Jewish Book
description: A provincial court in Alberta ruled today that a small-town schoolteacher could keep a book that had been confiscated on the ground that it was anti-Semitic.

title: ISRAEL TO SPEED UP LEBANON PULLOUT
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today that Israel intends to get out of Lebanon ''as soon as possible,'' and Prime Minister Shimon Peres said this withdrawal may take place ''a lot faster'' than most people think.

title: A L LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NETS BEAT HAWKS IN OVERTIME
description: Micheal Ray Richardson said he didn't really get rolling tonight against the Atlanta Hawks until late in the game, but he was in time to help the Nets beat Atlanta, 109-108, in overtime.

title: Cooper Talking With McGraw CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -
description: Cooper Industries said that it is

title: FED BANK OVERSIGHT ROLE CRITICIZED
description: A top Federal bank regulator said today that the Federal Reserve Board should not be involved in the supervision and regulation of banks. He also suggested that any reshaping of the nation's banking laws should confine the Fed's role to traditional central bank functions such as setting monetary policy and clearing checks.

title: Clash Over Fraud Inquiries
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and Senator Charles E. Grassley tangled today over the Justice Department's record on prosecuting fraud cases involving the nation's largest defense contractors.

title: Reach Out and Touch . . .
description: At a caucus of the Florida House delegation the other day, a junior member rose without explanation and headed for the door. Challenged by a senior Congressman, he explained that he had been called to the telephone by a new kind of beeper that vibrates like the magic fingers in a motel mattress but does not make any noise. Motioning him on his way, the senior lawmaker observed: ''No wonder you were looking so relaxed.''

title: Philharmonic Ensemble Plays at Asia Society
description: The highlight of a Sunday afternoon concert at the Asia Society, featuring the New York Philharmonic Ensemble was the world premiere of David Noon's Serenade for English Horn and String Quartet (Op. 78). Mr. Noon has created a work in a distinctively American idiom (the movements sport titles such as ''Barn Dance,'' ''Prayer'' and ''Song'') that is directly expressive, even downright tuneful at times, but never devolves into vulgarity. Thomas Stacy played the English horn fluidly, although the strings sounded ragged and underrehearsed.

title: DANCE:'SOME ROOMS' FROM SYDNEY
description: ''AFTER VENICE,'' which has obviously become a hit during the Sydney Dance Company's current season, now has a companion piece in the Australian troupe's third and final bill at the City Center.

title: 'Useful,' Kirkpatrick Says
description: Dr. Kirkpatrick said here today that ''it has been very useful to me to be a member of the National Security Council.''

title: DAMAGES ARE DENIED FOR 'WRONGFUL' BIRTH
description: The birth of a normal, healthy child is not an injury for which parents are entitled to damages, New York State's highest court ruled yesterday.

title: Hoover, Johnson
description: Johnson Controls Inc., a manufacturer of building automation systems, and Hoover Universal Inc., an industrial products company, said that the Federal District Court in New York had denied a motion for a preliminary injunction against the pending tender offer of Hoover Universal shares by a Johnson Controls subsidiary. The motion was brought by the APL Corporation, a Miami producer of consumer goods. The Johnson subsidiary has offered to buy up to six million shares of Hoover Universal for $36.50 a share.

title: ORANGE-CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After tax credits of $10,000 for the quarter and $29,000 for the 6 months.

title: CLOSING ROAD IN FRONT OF WHITE HOUSE STUDIED
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d told Congress today that a section of Pennsylvania Avenue in front of the White House might be closed to traffic as a security measure.

title: Transactions
description: Asked waivers on Mike Squires, first baseman; placed Cliff Speck, pitcher, on 21-day disabled list; assigned Mark Gilbert, outfielder, to a Triple-A affiliate; assigned Kenny Williams, outfielder, and Ron Karkovice, catcher, to Glens Falls; returned Bart Johnson, pitcher, to his post as an advance scout; named Gene Honda public-address announcer. CINCINNATI (NL) - Cut Fred Tolliver, Mike Smith, Billy Hawley and Rob Murphy, pitchers. FOOTBALL DALLAS (NFC) - Herb Scott, offensive lineman, announced his retirement because of chronic knee problems LOS ANGELES RAMS (NFC) - Signed Dieter Brock, quarterback.

title: BRAMALEA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MGM GRAND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
BIO-TECHNOLOGY GENERAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SOVIET, VOICING REGRET, BLAMES U.S. FOR SHOOTING IN EAST GERMANY
description: The Soviet Union today called the shooting of an American officer in East Germany ''regrettable,'' but placed the entire blame on the American side.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: SEISMIC ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All share earnings reflect recapitalization of the company last July.

title: Return of Chinese Boat Delayed by High Seas
description: The Government announced today that high seas had caused a 24-hour delay in return of a Chinese torpedo boat that drifted into South Korean waters after a mutiny.

title: SELLING SOAP TO CHILDREN AND HAIRNETS TO WOMEN
description: Edward Bernays originated the field of public relations about 60 years ago, and when he looks about him now and sees all that he has wrought, sometimes he thinks maybe he should have gone bowling instead.

title: SAGE-ALLEN & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: The latest fourth quarter and year consisted of 14 weeks and 53 weeks, respectively, compared with 13 weeks and 52 weeks for the year-ago quarter and year, respectively.

title: Deaver to Leave May 15
description: The White House announced today that Michael K. Deaver, deputy chief of staff, would be leaving May 15 to open and manage a private consulting firm. Mr. Deaver, a longtime confidant of President Reagan's, indicated several weeks ago that he would leave this spring.

title: Quincy to Desegregate Its Public Housing Units
description: Officials in the nearly all-white suburb of Quincy, ending years of resistance, agreed today to place members of minorities in 25 percent of the city's public housing and to protect them from harassment.

title: Western Union To Sell Subsidiary
description: The Western Union Corporation, which is struggling to survive a severe cash squeeze, said that it had agreed to sell its E.F. Johnson subsidiary to Diversified Energies Inc. The beleaguered telecommunications company said it would receive $26 million in cash for Johnson, which makes mobile radio equipment, and would retain assets valued at $10 million.

title: Why There Is Need for a National Appeals Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Stevie Wonder Music Banned in South Africa
description: The Government-owned South African Broadcasting Corporation announced today that it would no longer play Stevie Wonder's music because of a remark the singer-songwriter made when he won an Oscar Monday night.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tony Phillips of the Oakland A's, who had been expected to start the season at second base, broke a bone in his left foot and will be out at least two months. . . .

title: Turnaround Specialist Joining Mohawk Data
description: The Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation has named Matthew E. Tutino president of the financially troubled computer company. He also becomes chairman and chief executive of its Qantel subsidiary.

title: Headaches In All Sizes
description: The pro-Bassett forces like the springtime, and the think-bigger Trump people are just as insistent on an autumn schedule - at least later if not sooner - and how could the United States Football League even begin to regard itself as a significant sports venture if it didn't have a little intramural squabbling to spice things up?

title: 3 OFFICERS INDICTED IN TAIWAN
description: Taiwan's former military intelligence chief and two of his deputies were formally charged today with involvement in the killing of a Chinese-American writer in California last year.

title: VICOM INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Rival for Ferragamo
description: Dieter Brock, a 34-year-old quarterback who was twice named the outstanding player in the Canadian Football League, was signed by the Los Angeles Rams yesterday. Brock, who played 11 seasons in Canada, ended his career there with the Hamilton Tiger-Cats last season.

title: Congressional Medal Bestowed on Truman
description: President Reagan, in a private White House ceremony, today presented the Congressional Gold Medal to Harry S. Truman posthumously.

title: AMERON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Free? Did You Say Free?
description: The journalistic breakfast, despite early-morning grumbling,

title: A.T.&T. Introduces Unix Computer
description: A year after it made its first and faltering start in the computer market, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday introduced its most sophisticated personal computer. The machine relies heavily on the company's expertise in communications.

title: Topics ;   Bench Warrants ;   Judicial ProsWhat is it about the big case that turns some judges into balladeers? Judge Richard Curry of Chicago just took 64 pages to explain why that city may block the Cubs from introducing night baseball. He referred frequently to ''Take Me Out to the Ball Game'' and other such authorities before arriving at this dictum: ''You're out, O-U-T. The Cubs are out. Justice is a southpaw and the Cubs just don't hit lefties.''
description: Judge Curry himself felt compelled to apologize for digressing: ''No one should be deceived by the light- hearted writing style,'' he wrote. ''The message is a serious one.''

title: BELLWETHER EXPLORATION COMPANY reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
RECIPES FOR SUCCESS IN NEW COOKBOOKS
description: COOKBOOKS have been more successful than ever in recent years, and while old standbys such as ''The Better Homes and Gardens Cookbook'' continue to lead in steady sales, books with fresh approaches are flying off the bookstore shelves. They include works by experts, such as the best- selling ''Chef Paul Prudhomme's Louisiana Kitchen,'' elegant guides such as Martha Stewart's ''Entertaining'' and a cultural foray, Diana Kennedy's ''Cuisines of Mexico.''

title: NEWPORT ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After a tax credit of $145,000.

title: 4-TO-4 VOTE UPHOLDS TEACHERS ON HOMOSEXUAL RIGHTS ISSUE
description: A deadlocked Supreme Court, ruling without a written opinion, today upheld a lower court's decision that Oklahoma cannot constitutionally dismiss public school teachers for speaking out in favor of homosexual rights.

title: Thrift Unit Sues Auditor The American Savings and
description: Loan Association of Florida

title: Boston Offering $51 Million Issue
description: The Boston Water and Sewer Commission is offering $51 million of revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company with an initial interest rate of 6 3/8 percent for bonds due in 2014, which may be ''put'' or redeemed at par by investors on Nov. 1, 1986, and 7 3/8 percent for bonds due in 2015, which may be redeemed Nov. 1, 1988.

title: ROBOT DEFENSE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
NEW NICARAGUA POLICY URGED
description: The chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence urged President Reagan today not to ask Congress for renewed aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, calling the policy an ''illogical and illegal absurdity.''

title: WELDED TUBE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: A.M.C. Discount
description: The American Motors Corporation said it had extended its discounted 8.5 percent financing on its new Renault cars through April. A.M.C., whose majority shareholder is the French car maker Renault, introduced discounted financing in February after sagging car sales. Earlier this month, it offered an extended five-year warranty. A.M.C. said the 8.5 percent finance rates applies to loans up to 36 months, with 9.5 percent offered on 37- to 42-month loans, and 10.5 percent on 43- to 48-month loans.

title: PERHAPS THE PENTAGON'S ENEMY NO. 1
description: One of the paradoxes of capital politics is that an overpriced Government coffeepot is just as likely to stir controversy and catch the public's eye as is the MX missile, the Hydra-like issue that endured yet another vote today in its endless Congressional tests.

title: South African Trade
description: South Africa's trade surplus widened in the first two months of the year, to 1.33 billion rand, or $668 million, the Government said today. In the period a year ago, the country had a surplus of 284 million rand.

title: LEWIS PALMER G CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: b-Includes a one-time writedown in excess of $700,000 before taxes. c-Net income

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
Avondale Mills Chooses Chief Executive Officer
description: Avondale Mills, a textile manufacturer based in Sylacauga, Ala., has named William T. King president and chief executive officer. He replaces Harold D. Kingsmore, 52, who left the company last month to become president and chief operating officer of the Cannon Mills Company.

title: Thai Jet Purchase
description: The Thai Cabinet gave its final approval for the state-owned Thai Airways Company to buy two new Airbus A310-200's, despite fierce competition from the Boeing Company, a Government spokesman said.

title: REAGAN'S CHOICE FOR U.N. POST SAYS HE'LL ACCEPT
description: Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters, recently nominated as the American delegate to the United Nations, told the White House today that he would accept the post even though it did not include a regular seat on the National Security Council.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: NICARAGUA IN ARREARS ON WORLD BANK LOANS
description: Nicaragua has become the first country ever to fall six months behind in repaying loans to the World Bank, according to information contained in one of the bank's publications.

title: SULPETRO LIMITED reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a $6.7 million gain on the sale of production equipment.Sales represent oil and gas figures.

title: MEDICARE REPORT MORE OPTIMISTIC
description: Reagan Administration officials said tonight that new projections showed the Medicare trust fund would not go bankrupt until late in 1990's.

title: MENGEL DEPORTATION IN KILLING OF WOMAN AND OFFICER ORDERED
description: Canadian immigration authorities today ordered the deportation of Alex J. Mengel, who is facing charges in Westchester and Greene Counties of murdering a police officer and a woman whose car he was driving when he was captured in Toronto.

title: Bad Day on the Barricade
description: Contrary to Soviet claims, the sentry who killed Maj. Arthur D. Nicholson Jr. in an East German town on Sunday apparently never even fired a warning shot. Indisputably, he left the uniformed American bleeding for 30 minutes before medical aid arrived. When the American sergeant on this legal surveillance team tried to administer first aid, he was ordered away.

title: MEDICAL SCHOOL FOR CITY U. RUNS INTO OPPOSITION
description: The medical school planned by the City University should not be establish and the $6.2 million sought for it should be eliminated from Governor Cuomo's proposed budget, according to the chairman of the State Senate's Higher Education Committee.

title: Maryland Mayor FailsIn Bid for Re-election
description: Mayor Donald Frush, who vanished from City Hall for a week and turned up in a hospital psychiatric unit, was defeated today in a bid for re-election.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: NATIONAL LAMPOON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CROWNAMERICA reports earnings for 6mo to Feb 28
2 AT TULANE HELD IN BASKETBALL FIX
description: A member of the Tulane University basketball team was under arrest tonight, accused of shaving points to affect the outcome of at least two games this season. One other student was under arrest and two other Tulane players were being sought.

title: GOODEN AND SISK CONTROL RED SOX
description: Dwight Gooden, the one sure thing about the Met pitching rotation, was typically spectacular today. But after the Mets' 1-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox at Al Lang Stadium, Doug Sisk's performance seemed to matter more.

title: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
AMTRAK'S SAFETY IS ASSESSED
description: A Government report said today that Amtrak's heavily traveled Northeast Corridor had a number of training and maintenance problems but was being safely operated.

title: ANTI-JAPAN TRADE BILL IN SENATE
description: The Senate Finance Committee, reacting to the growing trade imbalance with Japan, plans to take up legislation Wednesday declaring Japan an ''unfair'' trader and calling on the President to retaliate by curbing imports from Japan.

title: What Is Being Done to Improve Security at Homeless Shelters
description: To the Editor:

title: CATSKILL HIGH REOPENS AFTER RACIAL OUTBREAKS
description: As police officers watched, classes at Catskill High School resumed quietly this morning after fights between white and black students had forced the school to close for two days.

title: Bell Computer Center Planned in Philadelphia
description: Bell of Pennsylvania announced today that it would build a $25 million corporate computer center near the Temple University campus in the North Philadelphia area.

title: U.S. Asks Allies to Join Space-Weapons Effort
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger formally invited key allies today to join American research on space weapons to shield the Western alliance from a Soviet missile attack.

title: NEW CEREAL PITCH TO CHILDREN
description: Donkey Kong, E.T., Rainbow Brite and Gremlins. These characters from popular movies, cartoons, television shows and video games have not only won the hearts of children, but also influenced the marketing of all kinds of children's products, from wallpaper to roller skates. Now breakfast cereal companies are licensing these same children's heroes to bolster sales.

title: 2 CHILE SOLDIERS SEEKING REBEL RADIO DIE IN BLAST
description: The Chilean Government said today that two sergeants were killed when a bomb went off as they were searching for a leftist radio transmitter late Monday in a hotel room in Concepcion.

title: THE DANCE:KENNETH KING
description: KENNETH KING has often appeared to be dancing on some Planet X all his own. On Friday night he celebrated his 20th anniversary as a choreographer by dancing at St. Mark's Church, and one of the works Kenneth King and Dancers/Co. offered was ''Planet X,'' a medley of excerpts from his previous productions.

title: HOW TO BLOW HOT AND COLD AND INSPIRE WARMTH
description: Within a few hours of each other Monday, two pronouncements issued from 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue shed light as never before on the shrewd and carefully balanced political and ideological tableau of Ronald Reagan's Presidency.

title: Prime Time for Water Action
description: Now, when New York's reservoirs should be three-fourths full, they are barely halfway. The Catskills are empty of skiers and snow. The watershed area appears to be in another of those low-rainfall cycles that come every second decade. City Hall should mobilize the public to recognize that this summer's water emergency has begun.

title: FOOD NOTES BOX
description: Fresh Baby Lamb

title: STATUS GAME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

description: b-Net income. The company said losses for the latest fourth quarter and year include an inventory writedown of $1,784,000 on a pre-tax basis and pre-tax adjustments to accounts receivable of $320,000.

title: GULL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $117,000.

title: Car Exports May Be Limited
description: Japan may impose new restraints on car exports to the United States after the four-year period of voluntary curbs expires on Sunday, Japanese Government sources said today.

title: OILERS END COLISEUM SLUMP
description: It took the Edmonton Oilers six seasons and 10 appearances on Long Island, but tonight that scoring machine finally defeated the Islanders in a regular-season game at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: ALONE AT THE WALL
description: Morning was still new to Washington, and the muted violet of dusk still hung in the air. It was quiet and empty downtown, and there she stood, alone at the massive granite wall, with thousands of names and her one painful memory.

title: FOR A HISTORIC PLAZA, PEARS AND LIMES?
description: The talk was of Callery pear trees and pleached limes, of fluted columns and bluestone concrete, of street lamps and the probable intent of an architectural sketch dating back 72 years.

title: MARKS & SPENCER CANADA INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-After store closure costs of $102,000 for the latest year and $212,000 for year-earlier period.

title: Playoff Format Still Undecided
description: Negotiators for the club owners and the players' union failed today to reach an agreement that would expand the American and National league playoffs from a three-of-five series to a four-of-seven series.

title: Citicorp's Auction
description: Interest rates declined at Citicorp's regular weekly auction of commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $100 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 8.833 percent, down from 9.055 last week. A $50 million issue of 182-day paper sold at an average rate of 9.16 percent, down from 9.445 percent.

title: 17 Busloads Of Protesting Brooklynites
description: The Borough of Buses is what you

title: Berkshire Hathaway
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. said today that its profit rose 32.7 percent in 1984, to $148.9 million, or $129.82 a share, from $112.2 million, of $105.15 a share, in 1983. Revenue rose to $729.2 million in 1984 from $602.7 million in 1983, it said. Last week, Berkshire Hathaway's chairman, Warren E. Buffett, agreed to pay about $517 million for 18 percent of the stock in the company that would result from the proposed merger of the American Broadcasting Companies into Capital Cities Communications Inc.

title: I.B.M. ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: The debate over whether American companies should do business in South Africa has taken on new urgency. This is fueled by South Africa's continued resistance to all but the most limited reforms of apartheid and the continued suffering of blacks and other nonwhites. Some individuals say American firms there must now oppose apartheid more directly and publicly; others are pressing them to withdraw fully. As a result, I.B.M. has again re-examined its practice of doing business in South Africa. We have concluded we should remain there.

title: Japan Sees Growth Lag
description: Economic growth in Japan may weaken over the next few months, the Economic Planning Agency said today. The indicator that shows future trends slipped to 41.7 in January, below the ''boom or bust'' line of 50.

title: 219-213 HOUSE VOTE SUPPORTS REAGAN ON MONEY FOR MX'S
description: The House of Representatives gave President Reagan a narrow but significant triumph tonight when it voted 219 to 213 to release $1.5 billion for the purchase of 21 more MX missiles.

title: The 'Peacemaker' Exploded While President Tyler Was Aboard
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMERCIAL METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
TWO SOUTH AFRICA CLERICS ARRESTED DURING PROTEST
description: The South African police arrested two leading anti-apartheid churchmen in Cape Town today as the clerics knelt on the pavement singing ''Onward Christian Soldiers.'' More than 200 supporters were detained with them

title: MICHIGAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $510,000 and an extraordinary gain of $932,000. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $862,000 and an extraordinary charge of $6,204,000.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Rates Post Modest Decline
description: Interest rates declined modestly yesterday as Government securities dealers were encouraged by signs of renewed investor demand at the Treasury's auction of new four-year Treasury notes.

title: Grey Becomes Agency For Itokin America
description: Grey Advertising, in addition to being one of the largest national advertising agencies, is not adverse to grabbing hold of a retail account when the opportunity arises. As a matter of fact it has considerable expertise in that area.

title: Dr. Peter Charanis Dies at 76; Retired Professor at Rutgers
description: Dr. Peter Charanis, a scholar of Byzantium and a professor emeritus of history at Rutgers University, died Saturday of a stroke at Middlesex General University Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 76 years old and lived in Highland Park, N.J.

title: ROLL-CALL IN HOUSE ON THE MX
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 219 to 213 by which the House of Representatives today approved freeing $1.5 billion to build 21 MX missiles. A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of freeing the money. A ''no'' vote was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 61 Democrats and 158 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 189 Democrats and 24 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes those not voting. There are two vacancies in the 435-member House.

title: Fighter Released
description: Bruce Curry, a former World Boxing Council super-lightweight champion, was ordered freed from a state mental facility by a District Court judge yesterday. Judge

title: PUBLIC PUSH SEEN FOR TAX SHIFTS
description: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee said today that the political catalyst for revamping the nation's tax system was the public's perception that it is unfair for profitable companies to pay little or nothing in taxes.

title: MCA Acquisition
description: MCA Inc. said that it had reached agreement to acquire L.J.N. Toys Ltd. in a two-tiered transaction valued at about $67.5 million. MCA, a film and entertainment company, said it would acquire 63 percent of L.J.N.'s stock from Jack Friedman, the toy company's president. MCA will offer L.J.N.'s remaining shareholders MCA stock at a value of $14.26 per L.J.N. share, with the amount subject to change depending on MCA's stock price.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   MBS Depository to Aid Mortgage-Backed Area
description: The effort to modernize trading in mortgage-backed securities gained ground yesterday when the MBS Clearing Corporation announced the start of the MBS Depository, the first depository for mortgage-backed securities.

title: MORTGAGE BANKING'S ALLURE
description: Companies aggressively expanding into financial services are fast discovering mortgage banking, a niche of the financing world long regarded as mundane.

title: WESTERN STATES LIFE INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $34,302 for the quarter and $76,835 for the year. c-Includes a capital loss of $14,892. d-Includes a capital gain of $105,315.

title: Pittsburgh Sale Of Water Bonds
description: A $100 million issue of Pittsburgh water and sewer revenue bonds was offered at a price of 100 with an initial interest rate of 6 7/8 percent, through underwriters led by Paine Webber.

title: ATLAS CONSOLIDATED MINING & DEVELMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes a gain of $3,222,000 from gold hedging operations and the sale of an investment. All figures are translated from Philippine pesos to U.S. dollars.

title: TEAMSTERS SAID TO REACH ACCORD ON NATIONWIDE FREIGHT CONTRACT
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters has reached a tentative agreement with the freight industry on a new labor contract to replace one scheduled to expire Monday, a union source said tonight.

title: BBDO's Tracy-Locke Branching Out to Coast
description: Tracy-Locke, the BBDO subsidiary with $240 million in billings and offices in Dallas and Denver, will be branching out to Los Angeles Aug. 1.

title: FRIENDS REPORT SAKHAROV NOTIFIED SOVIET ACADEMY HE MAY RESIGN
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and rights advocate, has reportedly told the Soviet Academy of Sciences that he will resign as a member by May 10 unless something is done about his isolation in Gorky and about his wife's health.

title: ROBERTSON IS OUT
description: Only hours after the Yankees disclosed that Andre Robertson would undergo arthroscopic knee surgery Wednesday to remove torn cartilage, Don Mattingly played tonight for the first time since his knee operation a month ago and hit a home run and a double with his first two swings of the spring.

title: U.S.F.L. WILL FINE OWNER OF BANDITS
description: Harry Usher, the commissioner of the United States Football League, said yesterday that John Bassett, the owner of the Tampa Bay Bandits, would be fined for remarks he made about the U.S.F.L.'s intended move to a fall schedule next year.

title: COACH AT R.P.I. HAS ENGINEERED HIS TEAM TO THE TOP
description: The academic load at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., is harsh, far more demanding than at most schools that have top-flight hockey teams.

description: 26 (AP) - Top Soviet figure

title: PARIS PICK-ME-UP FROM VALENTINO
description: The French ready-to-wear shows for fall and winter finally sprang to life. Late Monday afternoon, after many hours of tedium, Valentino Garavani presented a collection that was chic and expensive looking. Valentino, as he has always been known professionally, takes himself and his clothes seriously. He believes the function of fashion is to make the figure look better, not to distort it. His clothes are varied, graceful and luxurious. There have been times in the past when these qualities gave them an old-fashioned look. But the clothes he showed Monday were completely up to date.

title: Fairness First for City Schools By national standards, New York State has been tight-fisted with aid to its local schools. Successive administrations have permitted upstate communities to grab more than their share of what's available, leaving the New York City school system especially starved. A reasonable city proposal for reform deserves support.
description: The $5.6 billion that Albany handed out last year financed only 42 percent of total education spending in the state, well below the national average of 49 percent. Though aid is supposedly distributed according to formulas that consider a school district's relative wealth and special needs, it is widely acknowledged that the lawmakers first decide on the amount New York City should get, then adjust the formulas accordingly.

title: BONN TO CUT STAKE IN 10 COMPANIES
description: The West German Government today approved plans to cut the Government's stake in 10 state-controlled companies, including Lufthansa, the national airline, and Volkswagen, the country's largest auto maker.

title: General Mills Sees A Deficit in Quarter
description: General Mills Inc. said yesterday that it would report a deficit in the current quarter because of its plans to sell its fashion business and spin off its toy business. At the same time, however, the packaged-food company, based in Minneapolis, said that it expected to receive about $400 million as a result of the transactions, which are part of a continuing asset redeployment program.

title: ON PASSOVER, SEDER DISHES OF FOREIGN LANDS
description: THERE is a certain comfort in the familiar, as in the Passover feast many American Jews will serve next week to mark the Exodus of their ancestors from slavery in Egypt. Every table will offer the ritualistic foods: symbols of spring and rebirth, of the bitterness of slavery and the sweetness of freedom, of the bread baked in such haste it did not rise. If there is an overriding rule of Passover, it is that no leavened foods may be eaten.

title: THE MX: HIGH-TECH ARMS
description: The MX is the latest generation of intercontinental missile in the United States nuclear arsenal and represents a considerable technical advance.

description: Workers were reported to have staged a four-hour stoppage at a key factory here today.

description: G. Wilson Knight, a Shakespeare scholar, professor and literary critic, died on March 20, according to a report in The Times of London.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE bodily hazards associated with vigorous outdoor activities such as running, tennis and skiing are all too familiar to most devotees. But many fitness enthusiasts assume that indoor exercises can be pursued without concern for injury. The recent enormous growth of aerobic dancing and workout sessions in exercise studios and at home, using video and audio tapes and illustrated manuals, has, unfortunately, proved them wrong.

description: Howie Evans, the sports columnist for The Amsterdam News and former assistant to Tom Penders at Fordham, now has his first season as a head college basketball coach under his belt, and, if it's all the same to everyone else, he'd just as soon consider it water under the bridge.

title: CBS EASES ITS TONE ON CREW DEATHS
description: A CBS News vice president said today that he now believed that an Israeli tank had not deliberately shelled a television crew in southern Lebanon. Two crew members were killed and a third was seriously wounded in the incident last week.

description: Iraq warned today that it was prepared to expand the Persian Gulf war to ''every corner of Iran'' unless Teheran agreed to a comprehensive peace settlement.

title: PRODUCER EXPECTS TO EARN A MILLION FROM 'CHICAGO 17'
description: NOWADAYS it's possible for a record producer to earn a million dollars from a single album. That's about how much David Foster, the Los Angeles-based producer, songwriter, keyboard player and arranger, stands to make from ''Chicago 17,'' the most successful album ever by the pop-jazz group whose career was considered finished five years ago.

title: Capitals Fined $7,000
description: The National Hockey League fined the Washington Capitals $7,000 yesterday and suspended their new center,

title: A 'STREAMLINED' EDITION OF 1985 OSCAR AWARDS
description: HOLLYWOOD presented its Lite Oscars on Monday evening, a trimmed-down version of the usual affair. The evening's traditional dawdling was kept to a minimum, as were jokes, idle remarks and lengthy acceptance speeches. The awards were presented by a revolving group of young actors, who were efficiently recycled so that each could reappear a couple of times. Even the baby elephant, on hand to show off the costume design for ''A Passage to India,'' managed to step lively.

title: HADSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Economic Scene;   Finding Deficit Compromises
description: SHORTLY before last November's election, President Reagan said the Federal deficit was ''shrinking'' and would amount to just $172 billion in the current fiscal year. But the Administration's latest estimate is that the deficit will amount to $222.23 billion, $50 billion higher than the last pre-election estimate.

title: No Surprise
description: Finally, mercifully, the Knicks assured themselves a season-ending spot in the Atlantic Division's cellar when they lost Monday night at Milwaukee.

title: Siblings' Marrow Fails To Match Cancer Case
description: Blood tests on the long-lost brother and sister of a leukemia patient show that their bone marrow is ''not suitable'' for a transplant to try to save his life, doctors said today.

description: -dressed little girl today may sport a swimsuit from Oscar de la Renta or a dress from Yves Saint Laurent. These well-known women's wear designers - along with Diane Von Furstenberg, Christian Dior, Mary McFadden and Liz Claiborne - have recently entered the children's apparel market.

U.S. Education Aide Named
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett today announced the appointment of Carol Pendas Whitten as director of the agency's Office of Bilingual Education and Minority Affairs. Mr. Whitten, 39 years old, a native of New York who has held several posts in the department, will replace Jesse Soriano, who recently submitted his resignation. Mr. Whitten is a former teacher.

title: FILM ABOUT AN APE WHO KNOWS SIGN LANGUAGE
description: ''A SUMMER TO REMEMBER,'' tonight's television movie on CBS at 8, tells the kind of story that the networks periodically schedule as an afternoon special. It's all about this boy and an orangutan named Casey. Young - very young - audiences should be delighted.

title: LANDMARK LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest quarter and year include about $27,000,000 of revenue and $14,000,000 of pre-tax income relating to the sale of a hotel.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S NEW MOOD
description: The wheel, it almost seemed, had come full circle. On the 25th anniversary of the Sharpeville massacre of 1960, the police guns blazed again, this time in Langa township, near Uitenhage, just back from South Africa's southern coastline. At least 19 blacks died and 35 were hospitalized.

title: THEATER: 'TROUSERS,' A MUSICAL
description: WILLIAM FINN is not only the most talented theatrical composer-lyricist to emerge in the 1980's; he's also the most uninhibited. In his show at the Promenade, ''In Trousers,'' Mr. Finn's words trail madly after stream-of-consciousness ruminations, not songwriting conventions. The limber music, racing in tandem with the helter-skelter thoughts, leaps through an eclectic variety of pop and Broadway styles.

title: Auburn Coach to Stay
description: Sonny Smith, who has been having second thoughts since he announced in February that this would be his last season as Auburn's basketball coach, changed his mind yesterday and said he had decided to stay. ''The support of Auburn people has been overwhelming, and that played a part in my decision,'' said Smith after a meeting with Athletic Director

title: JERSEY PANEL TO REOPEN HILTON CASINO HEARING
description: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission voted today to reopen a hearing on whether to license the Hilton Hotels Corporation to operate a casino in Atlantic City.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: AMONG the best of friends and home cooks, there can be a considerable difference of opinion on the subject of meats served with cooked fruits. For some people, duck a l'orange or roast duck Montmorency (with black cherries) are anathema. For others, these same dishes are among the finest in the French repertory. I belong to the latter group, in that I find certain fruits stand as perfect complements to certain meats: Swedish pork stuffed with prunes, for example, or that resolutely American preparation, roast turkey with cranberry sauce, or calf's liver, which I have enjoyed in a light raisin and wine sauce.

title: U.S. SELECTS THREE TO PRODUCE AND SERVICE NEW SECURE TELEPHONES
description: The Federal Government today chose three of the nation's largest communication companies to produce a new kind of secure telephone that the Government said would end most international and corporate telephone eavesdropping within the next few years.

title: LANDMARK STATUS REJECTED FOR EAST SIDE CONVENT
description: After several months of deliberations, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission last night declined to designate a 19th-century convent on the Upper East Side a historic landmark, which would allow the structure to be razed.

title: IMMIGRATION AGENT FOUND SHOT TO DEATH IN JERSEY CITY
description: A chief investigator for the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service in New Jersey was found shot to death last night in his parked car about eight blocks from his home here.

title: Man, 21, Is Arrested In a L.I. Rape-Murder
description: A 21-year-old unemployed landscaper was arrested yesterday and charged with the rape and murder of a 16-year-old girl whose body was found last Dec. 5 near the Long Island Railroad tracks in Lynbrook, L.I.

title: JURY SELECTION BEGINS IN STABBING DEATH OF TEEN-AGER IN NORTHPORT
description: Ending months of delay, jury selection began here today in the trial of James Troiano, accused of murdering a teen- ager whose body was found last summer in a shallow grave in the woods of Northport.

title: MILITARY ROLE WIDENED BY AN AGGRESSIVE G.E.
description: Although the General Electric Company is perhaps best known as the manufacturer of such consumer items as refrigerators, hair dryers and light bulbs, it has moved quickly in recent years to take a place as a leading Defense Department contractor, with military contracts representing nearly a fifth of its $28.9 billion in revenues for 1984.

title: Allan Weisenfeld, 75, Ex-Mediator in Jersey
description: Allan Weisenfeld, the first executive secretary of the New Jersey State Board of Mediation, died March 19 of a viral infection at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 75 years old and lived in West Orange, N.J.

title: Floods Ravage the Ukraine
description: Heavy floods from melting river ice have swept the southern Ukraine, swamping roads, threatening hundreds of settlements and forcing the evacuation of thousands of families, Izvestia said today. The Government newspaper said more than 12,000 families had been evacuated from their homes in Kherson Oblast, on the lower Dnieper River.

title: Olympic Committee Picks Consulting Firms
description: Still flushed with the financial success of the 1984 Olympics last summer, the United States Olympic Committee has taken the first steps toward matching or beating that performance in 1988.

title: BRAZILIAN PRESIDENT-ELECT HAS A THIRD OPERATION
description: Brazil's President-elect, Tancredo Neves, was rushed from Brasilia to Sao Paulo today to undergo new surgery for intestinal problems that prevented him from assuming office 11 days ago.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Boston Celtics , at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. The Nets have not won in four games with Boston.

title: Market Place;   Texas Banks Viewed Warily
description: BY March of last year some Texas bank stocks were being buffeted by problem loans stemming from the end of the oil and real estate booms in 1982. But Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. kept going strong. Its shares reached a record high of 48 1/4 a year ago and the Houston-based bank holding company was hailed as ''the Loan Star'' by an admiring Wall Street.

title: Montana Stands by Law On Insurance Rates
description: An attempt has failed to repeal the nation's first insurance law that prohibits setting rates on the basis of sex.

title: Topics ;   Bench Warrants ;   Frivolous PursuitsBruce Martin Ginsburg, a Philadelphia lawyer, should have known better than to appeal a partial judgment in an insurance case to the Supreme Court. But instead of promptly denying review, the Court used six months to argue internally whether to make him pay damages to his adversary. It finally decided no, 5 to 3, but not before Chief Justice Burger delivered a dissent demanding to make an example of Mr. Ginsburg. Four other justices took time to explain why the pursuit of the frivolous was frivolous.
description: The time will have been well spent if the Court now resolves not to create a new jurisprudence of the frivolous. It's hard enough to decide which ripe cases are important enough to hear. Trying to distinguish between the almost frivolous and the extremely frivolous would be an odd endeavor for a Chief Justice who already feels overburdened.

title: Jersey Pike Sets Records
description: The New Jersey Turnpike set records for traffic volume and tolls last year. The Turnpike Authority said in its annual report to Governor Kean that 156 million vehicles had traveled a total of 3.4 billion miles and paid $151.9 million in tolls on the 142-mile highway.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   American Symphony With JoAnn Falletta
description: The principal attraction at the American Symphony Orchestra's Carnegie Hall concert Sunday afternoon was the debut of JoAnn Falletta, winner of the 1985 Stokowski Conducting Prize. Miss Falletta led a program of Bach, Bach-Stokowski and Bartok with the assurance of one to whom leadership is no novelty.

title: Publisher for Savvy
description: Savvy, a magazine for women recently acquired by Family Media, has a new publisher. She is Talia Carner, a 36-year-old native of Israel who has been cosmetic marketing manager of Redbook since 1981. Before that, she worked for the Joseph Jacobs Organization, experts in marketing to the Jewish community, and was ad manager of Fine Dining magazine.

description: Jeffrey Woll, a Boston native currently serving as managing director of the Montreal office of Ogilvy & Mather, will be recrossing the border to return to New York and assume the same role at Ogilvy & Mather Partners on May 1. Mr. Woll, 41 years old, joined the agency 15 years ago in the media department but quickly moved into accoumt service. And he did that kind of work for seven years in the Chicago office, where he rose to senior vice president.

title: STATE LEGISLATURES HAVE MORE WOMEN
description: THE tally has been a long time coming, but the Center for the American Woman and Politics at Rutgers University says women now constitute 14.7 percent of the lawmakers in the 50 states, or 1,097 out of the total of 7,461 legislators. Ten years ago, 604 women were legislators, about 8 percent of all state representatives and senators.

title: DEALING WITH THE SENSITIVE ISSUE OF PCB-CONTAMINATED STRIPED BASS
description: Every spring for as long as anyone can remember, scores of fishing trawlers have set out along the coastline of Long Island searching for striped bass, a white, firm-fleshed and mild-flavored fish that appears on restaurant menus from SoHo to Syracuse. This year, however, the 340 commercial striped-bass fishers may be prevented from leaving port with their lines and nets because the fish in New York's waters have been found to contain levels of PCB's higher than those considered safe by the Federal Government.

description: Lou Carnesecca has made it to the Final Four after many years, but he still has not made it to Lexington.

title: TEAMSTER ACCORD SAID TO BE CLOSE
description: Negotiators for the trucking industry and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters were close to reaching agreement on a new labor contract today, according to industry sources, but had not reached settlement on a key provision that would mean permanently lower wages for new drivers and those recalled from layoffs.

title: CBS NEWS CLARIFIES STAND ON CANCELING OF BROADCASTS FROM ISRAEL
description: CBS News confirmed yesterday that, in the wake of the killing of two of its news crew members by Israeli tank fire in southern Lebanon last Thursday, the network was canceling a week of ''CBS Morning News'' broadcasts from Israel just before Passover and Easter.

title: Caesars Stake
description: Martin T. Sosnoff, a New York investor, has increased his stake in Caesars World Inc. to 2.83 million shares, or 9.56 percent of the hotel and casino company's stock outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Sosnoff said that between Feb. 20 and March 19, he bought 776,900 Caesars World shares, or 2.23 percent of the company's shares outstanding, for prices ranging from $11.75 a share to $12.64 a share, for a total of $9.52 million.

title: SENATE PANEL CURBS REBEL AID
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, in a surprise move, voted 9 to 8 today to prohibit the use of any foreign aid money for the rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   A Rush in Texas to Sell Mortgage-Backed Bonds
description: Local governments in Texas are scrambling to sell tax-exempt bonds backed by single-family mortgages before a state-imposed deadline of April 12. In the last two weeks, 10 local housing finance corporations have sold or are expected to sell more than $334 million of bonds to finance single-family home mortgages at interest rates between about 10 1/2 percent and 11 percent.

title: STRIKING TRANSPORT WORKERS RATIFY PAN AM CONTRACT
description: Members of the Transport Workers Union ratified a new three-year contract with Pan American World Airways yesterday, ending a month-long strike that shut down a large part of the line.
