title: LARGE U.S. DAIRY SURPLUS SEEN AS LOOMING
description: The Government's dairy program may have caused a temporary reduction in the cost of supporting milk prices but has set the stage for another large increase in dairy surpluses and much larger Government expenditures later this year, Agriculture Department officials testified today.

title: PANEL WOULD DENY FUNDS FOR C-17 PLANE
description: A key Senate subcommittee has voted to halt funds for the $40 billion C-17 transport plane program if Congress decides to cut deeply into President Reagan's military budget.

title: MESA ADDS BIG BLOCK OF UNOCAL
description: An investment group led by T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, confirmed late yesterday that it had purchased 6.7 million shares of the Unocal Corporation at $48 a share, or $321.6 million.

title: Ecuador Police in Clash
description: Policemen in Quito fired tear gas today to disperse students and workers who erected barricades of burning tires to disrupt traffic during a one-day general strike, witnesses said. Official sources said 60 people were arrested in the capital and Guayaquil, 250 miles to the southeast, but the left-wing United Workers' Front said hundreds had been detained. The front called the strike to demand a 131 percent increase in the basic monthly wage of about $100.

title: EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
D'Amato to Head Unit On Soviet-Bloc Rights
description: Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Republican of New York, was named today to head the Helsinki Commission, a group of senators and congressmen that monitors human rights abuses in the Soviet bloc.

title: Repair Pledged for Memorial
description: The chairman of the volunteer group that built the Vietnam Veterans Memorial said today that his organization would do whatever was necessary to fix hairline cracks that have developed in a few of its 140 polished granite panels.

title: India Adopts Bhopal Bill
description: Parliament passed a bill today that is intended to insure quicker compensation for victims of the Union Carbide gas disaster at Bhopal and to help the Government file claims for compensation on their behalf. Both houses passed the bill that replaces a presidential order issued five weeks ago dealing with the 2,500 dead and 125,000 injured in Bhopal on Dec. 3. The Indian Government has said it has not yet decided whether to file a lawsuit on behalf of all victims in either United States or Indian courts, or to pursue an out-of-court settlement with the Union Carbide Corporation.

title: Sterling Seeks Takeover Bars Sterling Drug Inc., the subject of strong takeover rumors
description: in recent weeks, is asking

title: U.S. and Soviet Delegations Hold Work Session in Geneva
description: United States and Soviet negotiators held their first working session on strategic nuclear weapons today as Moscow warned that Congressional approval of 21 more MX missiles presented ''new logjams'' at the talks.

title: SCOUTING ;   A Park Bench In the Sun
description: A Scent of Spring, Scene 1:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   A Lewis Challenge
description: After winning four gold medals at one Olympics, there's not much challenge left for a track star, but

title: Salvador Rebels Attack Barracks in the Capital
description: Guerrilla commandos launched a mortar attack on the national police barracks in the capital today, wounding four police officers and four civilians in the first such attack in 20 months.

title: TRANSIT UNION NOW WARNING OF A WALKOUT
description: The leader of the city's subway and bus workers raised the possibility yesterday of a transit strike at midnight Sunday, issuing the warning after he failed to get a commitment from state officials that his union's contract would be worked out through binding abitration.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Herrmann Traded
description: He was a hometown boy who got a hero's welcome when the Colts moved to Indianapolis last year, but

title: ELECTROSOUND GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Reflects an extraordinary charge of $131,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $148,000 for the 9 months. c-Reflects a tax credit of $2,000 for the quarter and $262,000 for the 9 months.

title: BRAZIL STRUGGLES TO ADJUST TO LEADER'S ILLNESS
description: Brazil appeared headed today for an extended period of government under an acting President as the 75-year-old President-elect, Tancredo Neves, struggled to recover from his third major abdominal operation in 11 days.

title: CONSUL RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $1,500,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income which includes a gain of $900,000 from life insurance proceeds for the quarter and the 9 months.

title: STAGE: 'WALK THE DOG'
description: ONE of the stranger reunions in contemporary drama takes place late in the second act of Robert Auletta's ''Walk the Dog, Willie.'' The setting is an animal hospital in which Ronnie Billins, a crazed young veterinary student, presides over the corpse of a dog he has just killed. Who should suddenly appear but Ronnie's brother, Willie. Missing an eye and an arm, but otherwise not much the worse for wear, Willie, we learn, has returned from the dead. Soon he and Ronnie have regressed into childhood games, sniffing each other and emitting shrill canine yelps.

title: GENEVE CAPITAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a realized gain of $267,955 from investments of insurance operations and minority interests and a non-recurring tax credit of $7,940,740. c-Includes a realized gain of $1,721,556 from investments of insurance operations and minority interests.

title: A PLACE REJUVENATE IN A BUSY CITY
description: A flower called Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow had made it through a bitter winter in this city of monuments and speeches. Donald E. Smith celebrated its fragrance and exquisite three-day blossoms that shift, in a life of a few mere sunsets, from deep blue to frail blue to the whiteness of extinction.

title: DEMOCRATS PUSH FOR EXTENSION OF JOBLESS BENEFITS
description: House Democrats said today that they would fight President Reagan and push for a three-month extension of supplemental unemployment benefits.

title: CAPTORS FREE BRITON IN LEBANON AFTER 13 DAYS
description: A Briton who was kidnapped here 13 days ago has been freed unharmed by his captors.

title: An Improving Image
description: Tulane University, a 150-year old private coeducational university with 10,000 students, is situated on 110 acres in a prime residential neighborhood of uptown New Orleans. Many of the city's most prominent lawyers, doctors and professionals have been educated there.

title: BILL SIGNED TO PERMIT VICTIMS TO OFFER VIEWS IN SENTENCING
description: Governor Cuomo today signed into law a measure that gives a victim of crime the chance to present a statement to the judge before the criminal is sentenced.

title: Best Idea Since Keynes These are the best of economic times for most Americans. But what of the eight million who, despite the boom, remain unemployed?
description: Policy makers are inclined to accept 7 percent unemployment as an unavoidable cost of stable prices. They fear that a concerted effort to reduce joblessness would trigger another round of inflation and recession. And their rationale has a point, or at least it once did. In what may be the most important contribution to economic thought since John Maynard Keynes's General Theory, Martin Weitzman, an M.I.T. economist, suggests an elegant way to break the link between employment and the business cycle.

title: BIRD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $10,838,000 for the quarter and year from the termination of pension plans. c-Includes an extraordinary charge of $417,000 from reversal of tax credits. d-Net income which includes a tax credit of $133,000. Results for the latest year include a provision for a loss of $15,900,000 related to the sale of certain assets and corporate restructuring costs.

title: World Bank Manager In Venture of His Own
description: After managing the World Bank's multibillion-dollar fixed-income portfolio for the last 12 years, Hugo Schielke is going into business for himself.

title: BRIEFING ;   A Cheery Goodbye
description: As director of public affairs at the Office of Management and Budget, Edwin L. Dale Jr. spends each day juggling figures. Now, it turns out, he can still cut quite a figure, just as he did when he was a cheerleader at Yale in the 1940's.

title: Judge Allows Abortion Despite Husband's Plea
description: A Texas judge today dissolved a temporary restraining order, clearing the way for a woman to have an abortion despite the objections of her estranged husband.

title: BRIEFING ;   Out of the White House
description: Still another Presidential assistant, Frank J. Donatelli, is

title: COLORADANS WEIGH SALE OF FIRE RIGHTS
description: The day may not be far off in Colorado's high-country ski resorts when someone who wants to install a wood-burning fireplace or stove may first have to find someone willing to sell him the rights to have such a facility in his new home.

title: British in Air Accord
description: Britain and Luxembourg reached an agreement that is expected to usher in sharply reduced air fares between the two countries, according to the British Department of Transport. Both Governments agreed on Tuesday to drop their power to unilaterally veto each other's proposals on air fares or flights between the two countries, the department said.

title: INDIANA AND U.C.L.A. REACH N.I.T. FINAL
description: Indiana's problem of becoming lackadaisical after a lead resurfaced last night in the semifinals of the National Invitation Tournament, but this time Indiana adjusted well and is now a game away from another major title.

title: CELTICS SHIFT LINEUP AND WIN 9TH IN ROW
description: Coach K.C. Jones of the Boston Celtics rested Larry Bird for 9 1/2 minutes in the second quarter of tonight's game against the Nets, something he rarely does. He experimented with Ray Williams and Quinn Buckner in the same backcourt.

title: Alexander Grant Sued POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 27 (AP) - City commissioners today voted to sue their auditing firm to try to recover almost $12 million invested with the collapsed E.S.M. Government Securities Inc.
description: The suit will charge the auditing firm of Alexander Grant & Company with negligence and fraud for telling them that E.S.M. was solvent. Based on an audit, the city said it had invested $11.9 million in E.S.M., which the Securities and Exchange Commission closed on March 4.

title: COLLEGE FACULTIES HAVE NOT BEEN GROWING FAT
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption yesterday with a dispatch about the House vote on financing for MX missiles misidentified Paul Simon. He is a Senator from Illinois.

title: TV CREW LEAVES SET OF AIDS VICTIMS INTERVIEW
description: -TV television crew walked off the set at a Manhattan studio yesterday rather than tape an interview with two victims of AIDS, station officials said.

title: New Banking Economics
description: BANK stocks in Texas came under a cloud this month as a result of heightened investor concern over energy and real estate loans in their portfolios. ''In a sense,'' one Wall Street analyst said yesterday, ''the Texas bank stocks have been impacted by deflationary forces in the domestic economy.''

title: THOSE $200,000-AND-UP CONDOS ARE SELLING BRISKLY IN MANHATTAN
description: The most breathtaking feature of many new Manhattan residences is the price. Condominiums and cooperative apartments, some no larger than a single room, are selling for sums that would buy sprawling houses elsewhere in the country.

title: South Korea Returns Chinese Vessel and Crew
description: KUNSAN, South Korea, Thursday, March 28 (Reuters) - A Chinese Navy torpedo boat and 13 crew members were returned to China today by South Korean authorities, officials said.

title: BRIEFING ;   Adding an Acronym
description: NARA will make its official debut on Monday in this city that abounds in acronymns.

title: Danes Seek Legislation To Settle Strike
description: The Government unveiled legislation today aimed at ending a three-day-old nationwide strike, the largest in state- run industry in 12 years.

title: CONSTRUCTIVE ENGAGEMENT IS A FAILED POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 PLAYWRIGHTS DEPLORE TURKISH RIGHTS RECORD
description: Arthur Miller and Harold Pinter, the playwrights, held a well-attended news conference on human rights in Istanbul recently, but not a word about it appeared in the Turkish press.

title: Books: Vietnam Debate
description: NO MORE VIETNAMS. By Richard

title: AMPAL-AMERICAN ISRAEL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary income of $947,000 from the second quarter.

title: LIGHTMOBILE, BULBS AND ALL
description: THE project is called Lightmobile and took Eric Staller, center behind car, five months and 1,637 light bulbs to make.

title: G.O.P. Retains Edge In Michigan Senate
description: A Republican victory Tuesday in a special election for a State Senate seat kept the party's 20-to-18 edge in the chamber. The Michigan House and Governor's mansion are controlled by Democrats.

title: ADVERTISING ;   Replacement Is Set For Co-ed Magazine
description: Scholastic Inc., the publishing home of a group of publications for schoolchildren, is killing off its 28- year-old magazine Co-ed, which skews to a female audience in the home economics field, and will replace it with Choices, a new classroom magazine for both sexes in the same field.

title: Runoffs Need No Fixing An attempt to eliminate New York City's runoff primary elections has fortunately died in the Legislature. The Democratic Assembly passed a repeal for 1989 in the mistaken belief that blacks and Hispanics would find it helpful in gaining high city office. But the Republican Senate does New Yorkers the favor of ignoring this bill.
description: New York City remains a one-party town, which usually guarantees the Democratic primary winners election to City Hall. When a notoriously weak candidate for Mayor, Mario Procaccino, won a five-candidate primary in 1969 with 32 percent of the vote, Democrats strayed from the fold and re- elected John Lindsay, a Republican running as an independent.

title: WHAT CAN WE DO? (2)
description: BOSTON Events in South Africa confront

title: OUR TOWNS
description: The danger was clear and present. No clouded circumstances, no uncertainty about motive or intent. The man on the other side of the counter was holding a long-barreled .22-caliber revolver and the muzzle was pointed between Bill McGilton's eyes.

title: Statement from Casey
description: William J. Casey, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, said today that his stock holdings in Capital Cities Communications Inc. were not included in a trust he set up in 1983 because they were too large to meet requirements for such a trust.

title: MUSIC: THE AMADEUS STRING QUARTER
description: THE Amadeus String Quartet has been playing together for 36 years, and judging from Friday night's concert - its first ever in Carnegie Hall - the ensemble's musical style has been as little altered as its personnel. Age, in other words, seems not to have dulled the Amadeus's big sound or tempered its headlong enthusiasms.

title: LINCOLN PHOTO IS AUCTIONED
description: The highest price ever paid for a photograph sold at auction was given yesterday by Malcolm Forbes Jr., who purchased a photograph of Abraham Lincoln and his son Tad at an auction at Sotheby's, a spokesman for the company said yesterday.

title: ARGO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COLLEGE FACULITIES HAVE NOT BEEN GROWING FAT
description: To the Editor:

title: ROUND 2 FOR THE 'REAGAN CLASS'
description: They were mocked as ''Reagan's robots,'' ''accidental Senators'' and, in an allusion to their political immaturity and many gaffes, ''the popsicle brigade.''

title: SOUTH AFRICAN WARNS AGAINST VIOLENT DISSENT
description: President P. W. Botha warned today that he would not tolerate violent dissent, and he said ''appropriate steps'' had been taken to restore calm after the police shootings of 19 black people near the southern automotive center of Uitenhage last Thursday.

title: 6TH IN 2 WEEKS
description: A huge explosion occurred in downtown Baghdad today soon after Iran announced that it had launched a surface- to-surface missile in an attack against the Iraqi capital.

title: WINDOW DESIGNS THAT ADMIT LIGHT BUT NOT BAD VIEWS
description: APARTMENTS in New York skyscrapers may be famous for spectacular views, but justifiably unsung and generally unmentioned are the bleak views into lightwells at the rear of many buildings. Even older buildings with gracious fronts often have mean prospects out the back. The problem of how to treat a window to cut out the bad view - but not the light, air and sense of outdoor space - is common in the city.

title: C.I.A. MOVE TO BAN DISCLOSURE OF SECRETS DROPPED
description: The Reagan Administration today decided to drop a proposal by the Central Intelligence Agency to make it a crime for Government employees to disclose national secrets without authorization, officials said.

title: GUMWOOD MIMICS HIGH-QUALITY LOOK
description: Most of those who work around antique furniture are capable of recognizing at least half a dozen prime cabinet woods without a second glance.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, a section of the Charlotte Curtis column on Tuesday was misplaced, and attribution was unclear for some statements. The 18 lines that followed the subheading in column 2 should have appeared at the top of that column.

title: 2 MORE AT TULANE CHARGED IN FIX
description: Two more Tulane University basketball players were arrested today in connection with a point-shaving scandal that has shocked the university.

title: THRIFT UNIT SALE BILL POSTPONED
description: An Ohio Senate committee today put off until next week consideration of legislation that would allow an out-of-state bank to acquire Home State Savings Bank of Cincinnati, which has been in the control of a state-appointed conservator since its collapse March 9. Citicorp, the giant New York-based bank holding company, has been negotiating to purchase Home State.

title: Lyon Metal Stock
description: Lyon Metal Products Inc. said it had authorized the repurchase of the 38 percent of its shares held by the investor Irwin L. Jacobs for $19 a share, or a total of $10.1 million. The repurchase clears the way for a previously announced leveraged buyout of Lyons through an employee stock ownership plan, company officials said. Mr. Jacobs has indicated to Lyon that he wants to sell his stake, the company said.

title: PRIVATE PRISON OPERATORS
description: A troubling industry is developing in response to the runaway demand for prison space. Private investors are eager to share in the $10 billion- a-year business of imprisoning the nation's almost 750,000 offenders. Like the military-industrial complex, this industry will capitalize on the public's fears to assure an ever-expanding system, while the basic insecurities remain.

title: WOMEN PUTTING DEGREES TO WORK
description: A survey of women who graduated from women's colleges in 1967 and 1977 has found that more than three-quarters are working outside the home, many in such male-dominated positions as lawyer, physician or business manager.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
ITALIAN UNION ADVISER SHOT DEAD
description: A prominent economist for a labor federation was shot and killed here today, and the Red Brigades terrorist group claimed responsibility.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
PROFESSIONAL INVESTORS INURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $832,589 from an accounting change. The company changed its name from the Professional Investors Corp. earlier this year.

title: British Change Oil Price Setup
description: Britain will stop setting an official price for buying North Sea oil as of Monday, the Department of Energy said today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 28, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ADVERTISING ;   Career Shift for Head Of Times-Mirror Unit
description: Thomas R. McCartin, who set up the Times-Mirror National Marketing Company in New York 14 months ago and has since served as its president and chief executive, confirmed yesterday that he would be leaving the company to return to Dallas, where he will be joining the Criswell Development Company, a real estate concern.

title: LOW-CHOLESTEROL DIET LINKED TO RETARDING HEART DISEASE
description: A vegetarian diet low in cholesterol but high in polyunsaturated fat may be able to stop the destructive advance of heart disease in some people, a new study suggests.

title: 2 WHO AIDED SALVADORANS GET JAIL SENTENCES
description: A Federal district judge today sentenced to prison two workers in a movement that provides sanctuary to Salvadoran refugees.

title: CURTISS-WRIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax writedown of $11,500,000 for the quarter and the year related to the company's investment in Western Union. c-Net income. Latest quarter and year results reflect the reversal for financial reporting purposes of $4,643,000 of dividend income from Western Union.

title: BRIEFING ;   Chili-Harmonica Double
description: Representative James H. Scheuer proved this week that he is as handy with the spoon as he is with the harmonica. The Queens Democrat defeated 13 House colleagues to win the ninth annual chili cookoff sponsored by the Congressional Club, then proceeded to entertain the crowd with a few tunes on the harmonica.

title: WELBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $33,000. c-Includes an after-tax gain of $971,984, or 43 cents a share, on the sale of plant and equipment for the quarter and year and after net from discontinued operations of $35,000 and $44,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Includes a net gain of $3,169,000, or $1.38 a share, resulting from the third quarter sale of real estate and after net from discontinued operations of $3,259,000, or $1.42 a share. The results for 1984 include 100 percent of Welmoore Industries earnings for the period from April 2, 1984 and reflect the 42 percent minority interest existing prior to that date. Results for the 1983 periods include pro-rata earnings for the company's 51 percent owned subsidiary, Welmoore Industries, which are accounted for under the equity method. The year-ago figures were restated.

title: Quake Shakes North Japan
description: An earthquake measuring 6.6 on the Richter scale shook northern Japan tonight, but no injuries or damage were reported. The Meteorological Agency said the quake was centered near the Soviet- held island of Kunashiri, off Hokkaido, Japan's northern island.

title: CALENDAR: BUILDINGS AND ART
description: America's Architecture: The City

title: WILSON'S ARM GETS FIRST TEST TODAY
description: Eventually, Mookie Wilson knows he will have to test his arm, to ''cut loose'' and see if his right shoulder can cope. But he has no apprehension, no outward concern that 1984 - a season of almost constant discomfort from his sore shoulder - will repeat itself in 1985.

title: Debt Issues
description: Air Canada is offering 15 billion yen of 7.3 percent, 10-year bonds in Japan at a price of 99.35, to yield 7.413 percent, through Daiwa Securities Company Ltd.

title: McEnroe Tested By Becker, 17
description: John McEnroe was severely tested by 17-year-old Boris Becker of West Germany tonight, winning his opening match in the $380,000 Fila Trophy indoor tennis tournament, 6-4, 6-3.

title: SOME NEW SMALL KITCHEN APPLIANCES UNCLUTTER THE COUNTER
description: KITCHEN counter clutter may become a thing of the past with the introduction of new under-the-cabinet, wall-mounted and cordless rechargeable small appliances.

title: ADVERTISING ;   People
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   '53d at Third' Tower Separates the Unseparable
description: The Seagram Building and Philip Johnson.

title: SIERRA SPRING WATER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOETZ IS INDICTED FOR THE SHOOTING OF FOUR ON THE IRT
description: Bernhard H. Goetz was indicted yesterday for attempted murder in the shooting of four young men on a Manhattan subway train last December.

title: Amana to Lay Off 160
description: Amana Refrigeration Inc. said that it will lay off 160 workers from its refrigeration plant by the end of this week because of softening sales of microwave ovens, refrigerators and freezers. The cutback is necessary to bring production into line with sales, a company spokesman said on Tuesday.

title: Armco Inc. to Cut 250 Jobs in Ohio
description: Armco Inc., the diversified steelmaker that has been struggling since 1982, said it would eliminate 250 jobs at its Middletown headquarters within the next week.

title: Queens Man, 27, Is Arrested In Hospital Attack on Nurse
description: A 27-year-old Queens man was arrested last night and charged with stabbing and seriously wounding a nurse at New York Hospital during a robbery attempt on March 14.

title: CHINA REIMPOSING CURBS IT RELAXED 5 MONTHS AGO
description: The Chinese Government announced today that it was moving to tighten bureaucratic controls it relaxed only five months ago.

title: SHOPWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $855,000 for the quarter and $1,936,000 for the year. c-Net income

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   A Dirty Windshield, A Free Cleaning
description: Some call them windshield muggers. The description is not far off: They seem to be everywhere, they strike vulnerable targets and they walk off with someone else's money.

title: IDLE WILD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: First Colony Life Insurance Co. of Lynchburg, Va., a subsidiary of Ethyl Corp., has elected Ronald V. Dolan president.

title: Santa Claus Phone Line Brings $10 Million Suit
description: Lawyers for two children who were charged 50 cents every time they called Santa Claus filed a $10 millon lawsuit Tuesday accusing the Pacific Bell Telephne Company of deceptive advertising. The suit says the advertisement was aimed at luring children into calling repeatedly and did not make clear there was a cost.

title: Judge Levies $200,000 Fine Against Striking Mine Union
description: The United Mine Workers Union was fined $200,000 today for contempt of court for violating an order limiting picketing in its strike against the A.T. Massey Coal Company.

title: Control of Punjab Extended
description: The Indian Parliament today approved two measures requested by the Government, extending direct federal rule of Punjab for six more months and amending the National Security Act to permit preventive detention without trial for up to two years.

title: To Trial With Mr. Goetz Did those four young men actually threaten Bernhard Goetz in the subway? Did he shoot them in self-defense or calculated revenge? The debate has disrupted dinners and classrooms and set strangers to arguing on the street. As long as Mr. Goetz stood indicted only for possessing guns, the ill-informed argument was itself committing injustice. Public officials, legal experts, too many of the media, Mr. Goetz himself - all were selfishly preying on public emotion.
description: His second indictment yesterday for attempted murder may finally break this fever. The case will finally get the reasoned examination it deserves, in court. Until the jury speaks, we are all on trial.

title: TECFIN CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: CANADA'S REVITALIZED OILFIELDS
description: An important agreement between Ottawa and Canada's oil producing provinces has given new impetus to an emerging revival in oil exploration and production.

title: BEGGING FOR A SUMMIT
description: -flop, President Reagan sent George (''You

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MILDEW is caused by simple fungi that will grow on almost anything from which they can derive enough food to survive. Mildew can grow wherever there is moisture and relatively mild temperatures, combined with a lack of ventilation and sunlight.

title: ADVERTISING ;   A New Agenda For Cable
description: KEITH L. REINHARD, chairman and chief executive of Needham Harper Worldwide, must feel deeply about finding the key strength of cable TV as an advertising medium because he is offering his people $10,000 if they can do it.

title: DOW ADVANCES BY 5.19 TO 1,264.91
description: Stock prices rose yesterday, with most investor interest in secondary stocks and special takeover situations.

title: RIOTS BREAK OUT IN SUDAN CAPITAL AS LEADER LEAVES FOR VISIT TO U.S.
description: Riots erupted here today hours after President Gaafar al-Nimeiry left the capital to meet with President Reagan. At least 2 people were reported killed by riot policemen and more than 100 others arrested.

title: FOES PRESS TO REVERSE MX APPROVAL
description: Opponents of the MX missile today mounted an ''all-out attempt'' in the House of Representatives to reverse the outcome of the vote Tuesday that barely approved funds for 21 additional weapons. But they said they had made little headway in a day of feverish lobbying and intense personal conversations with members holding possible swing votes.

title: G.I.'S GUIDE: USE NO FORCE
description: The Defense Department made public today the standing orders given American military personnel in West Germany on what they are supposed to do if they spot members of the Soviet military liaison mission team.

title: Slain Man Linked to Mob
description: A man in jogging clothes was found shot to death on Sprain Road at 6 A.M. Tuesday. He was identified as Alex Saccone, 33 years old, who had a criminal record, the police said today. The police said that they had no suspects, but that the slaying was probably mobrelated.

title: HEART PATIENT SEEMS TO BE MAKING GAINS IN SPEECH PROBLEMS
description: William J. Schroeder's spirits are improving and the artificial heart recipient appears to be overcoming speech problems caused by strokes three months ago, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: 'HILL STREET' TO TRIM ITS CAST AND PLOTS
description: ''Hill Street Blues,'' the NBC police series that has been acclaimed for its complex narratives and ambitious production techniques, will simplify its plots and reduce the number of characters next fall in an attempt to lower costs, according to the show's producers and writers.

title: DANCE: BARNARD COLLEGE
description: THE spring season isn't all that old, but it's hard to believe that the program presented by Dance Uptown on Friday won't prove to be one of the most enjoyable and well-produced events of the year. Held annually at Barnard College's Minor Latham Playhouse, this showcase was a model of its kind, from its wide range of vivid and unusual choreography and performing to its distinctive lighting by Rhonda Rubinson.

title: U.S. SAYS SLAIN MAJOR HAD PHOTOGRAPHED MILITARY SITE
description: The Army major who was killed in East Germany had been photographing the inside of a Soviet military building through a window in an area that had been officially off limits to Americans until last month, senior Army and State Department officials said today.

title: BARRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $3,727,000 from the sale of an affiliate for the quarter and 9 months and after-tax equity in earnings of affiliate of $70,000 for the quarter and $323,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes after-tax equity in earnings of affiliate of $234,000 for the quarter and $517,000 for the 9 months.

title: IDEA OF JOB WORTH IS CALLED 'FLAWED'
description: A new report from the United States Commission on Civil Rights unequivocally rejects the proposition that men and women should be paid the same for different jobs of comparable worth.

title: VOLCKER FOR BANK INSURANCE MERGER
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told a House panel today that he would favor merging the two Government agencies that insure deposits at the nation's banks and thrift institutions.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Van Note to Return
description: After 16 seasons in the N.F.L., a fellow gets to thinking about retirement, and so did

title: Forstmann Drops Its Bid for McGraw
description: Forstmann Little & Company, outbid by Cooper Industries, said yesterday that it was dropping its plan to acquire the McGraw-Edison Company in a leveraged buyout.

title: Gun in Gallery Linked To Murder of a Model
description: The police have identified a .22-caliber rifle found in a Manhattan art gallery as the gun used to kill a Norwegian man, a model whose body was found last week on a Stony Point estate, the Rockland County District Attorney said today.

title: Chicago Bank Loan Details
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation said today that during the fourth quarter it collected $145 million in principal and interest on the $3.6 billion in troubled loans that it had turned over to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation as part of the plan to rescue the bank.

title: 3d Trial for Terrorist Opens in a Miami Court
description: Eduardo Arocena, the reputed leader of the militant Omega 7 Cuban exile organization, went on trial today in Federal District Court on charges of bombing the Mexican and Venezuelan consulates and businesses in Miami.

title: Sears in Talks To Buy Bank
description: Officials at Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that the company was negotiating to buy a South Dakota bank to help expand its financial services activities.

title: The Broken Treaty What is Iraq's word worth? It is bound by the Geneva Protocol prohibiting the use of poisonous gases in war. Yet a group of Iranian soldiers is now under treatment in European hospitals for the effects of mustard gas. From this and other evidence, American officials conclude that Iraq is once again using chemical weapons, in violation of the treaty it signed in 1931.
description: When Iran complained of chemical attacks a year ago, a United Nations team detected mustard gas and the nerve gas Tabun on the battlefield. Evidently the use of these outlawed weapons had been long premeditated.

title: EAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income. Results for the full year include plant relocation and other non-recurring expenses of $361,000 for the latest period and $526,000 for the previous period.

title: American Natural
description: A group led by Ivan F. Boesky, the New York arbitrager, has reduced its stake in the American Natural Resources Company by 595,000 shares. or about 1.4 percent of the company's shares outstanding, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Hillary Is Envoy to India
description: Sir Edmund Hillary, one of the first two men to climb Mount Everest, presented his credentials today as New Zealand's new Ambassador. Since his 1953 ascent of Everest with Tenzing Norgay, Sir Edmund has maintained close ties with India and Nepal. He is also accredited to Bangladesh, Bhutan and Nepal.

title: Bridge:At Spring Nationals, Canada Had a Few Victories to Cheer
description: The bridge players of Montreal were rightly proud of their efficient organization of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals there.

title: THOMPSON'S STACK OF BLUE CHIPS
description: If the Final Four were to play poker

title: Girl, 5, Testifies on Coast In Molestation Case
description: A 5-year-old girl, the youngest pupil to testify at a hearing in the McMartin Pre-School molestation case, said Tuesday that she had been sodomized by the key defendant.

title: EXPERT URGES BAN ON BLOOD DOPING
description: A national expert in the field of blood transfusion strongly urged this week that the United States and International Olympic Committees ban the practice of blood packing, or blood doping, by athletes.

title: Freshman Center Learning to Wait
description: Rob Cornegy's first class at St. John's University Monday morning was scheduled to start at 11:15, but the start of this week held a special reason to arrive early. There were friends to see, games to talk about, and places to go. His friends had been on a basketball court at McNichols Arena in Denver, earning a trip to the Final Four, making history. Cornegy had been in front of a television set at home in Cambria Heights, Queens, annoying the other members of his family, making believe.

title: Michigan Utility Officer Plans to Retire Early
description: The Consumers Power Company, the troubled Michigan utility whose chairman announced his resignation three weeks ago, said yesterday that its chief financial officer, Walter R. Boris, would take early retirement in the first quarter of next year.

title: Penguins Stay Alive PITTSBURGH, March 27 (AP) - Mitch Lamoureux scored two
description: goals tonight to help the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 4-3 victory over the

title: 69 EMPLOYEES OF STATE TAX DEPT. REPORTEDLY FAILED TO FILE RETURNS
description: At least 69 employees of the State Department of Taxation and Finance, many of them tax enforcers, have failed to file state income-tax forms over periods as long as five years, an internal investigation by the agency has found.

title: German Jet Forced To Fly to Istanbul
description: A lone hijacker seized a Lufthansa jetliner en route from West Germany to Greece today and forced it to fly to Istanbul.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: BLACK WOLF: The Life and Times of Ernest Thompson Seton. By Betty Keller.

title: MAN LINKED TO NEO-NAZI GROUP IS ARRESTED
description: A man said to be the leader of a violent neo-Nazi group was arrested with an arsenal of weapons in northern Georgia and brought to Atlanta today under heavy guard.

title: Strange Going For Bonanza PONTE VEDRA, Fla.,
description: The two richest

title: TREASURY ISSUE RATES MIXED
description: After a day of erratic trading, interest rates on Treasury issues were mixed yesterday, with short-term rates falling modestly while note and bond yields rose slightly.

title: 3 AIRLINES TO END RESERVATION BIAS
description: Three of the nation's major airlines said today that they would end a bias in their computerized ticket reservation systems that steers passengers toward flights on the airlines that run the systems.

title: CUOMO'S BUDGET: POLITICS AND PEOPLE
description: When Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders sat down today around a long, shiny conference table in the Governor's outer office, the topic was finances but the reality was politics. Whenever it comes and whatever its form, the result will be a budget including cuts in the taxes that New Yorkers pay and changes in the services the state offers, the size and destination of the billions of dollars that Albany sends to schools and local governments.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Suspended Official Has Departed ITT
description: Edward J. Gerrity Jr., who was suspended last December from his position as the ITT Corporation's senior public relations official, has left the corporation, the company acknowledged yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: Frank H. Bartholomew, chairman emeritus of the news agency United Press International, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Sonoma, Calif. He was 86 years old and also lived in Glenbrook, Nev.

title: HENRY MOORE BRONZE IN DUCK POND
description: Mayor Koch rowed to the middle of the Central Park Duck Pond yesterday, and pulled an oversized red ribbon off the latest addition to the city's collection of public art: a bronze sculpture by Henry Moore that floats on an anchored raft in the pond near 59th Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: DOLLAR TUMBLES FOR A SECOND DAY
description: The dollar tumbled yesterday, losing almost 5 percent of its value against the British pound, and falling sharply against other currencies as well. Traders blamed snowballing concern in Europe about declining American interest rates and worries over the stability of the American banking system.

title: MUSIC: PREMIERE OF 'SAISON EN ENFER'
description: GILBERT AMY'S ''Une Saison en Enfer'' (''A Season in Hell''), a setting of extracts from the chaotic, engrossing and alarming work with which the 19- year-old Arthur Rimbaud ended a career that changed the face of poetry, had its American premiere Monday evening at the Great Hall of Cooper Union. Mr. Amy is a disciple of Pierre Boulez; his music partakes of the rigor, severity and complexity, and also in some measure of the assurance, invention and grace, of his mentor's.

title: U.S. HIGH COURT DEADLOCKS ON SCARSDALE CRECHE CASE
description: A 4-to-4 deadlock today prevented the Supreme Court from resolving the constitutional debate over the right of local governments to bar privately sponsored Nativity scenes from public land.

title: Helen B. Gay Is Dead at 63; Colchester First Selectman
description: First Selectman Helen B. Gay of Colchester, who donated her salary to sponsor town picnics and who rode aboard snowplow trucks during winter storms, died of cancer Monday night at Hartford Hospital. She was 63 years old.

title: KLEINERT'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $180,000 for the latest quarter and $255,000 for the year-ago period.

title: HIGH COURT LIMITS RIGHTS OF POLICE TO SHOOT TO KILL
description: The Supreme Court ruled today by 6 to 3 that the Constitution bars the police from shooting to kill fleeing criminal suspects who are neither armed nor dangerous.

title: 2 Kings Fly Planes in Spain
description: The Kings of Jordan and Spain, both exerienced pilots, flew combat training planes during a visit to a southern Spanish air base today. King Hussein of Jordan, who is on a four-day visit to Spain, and King Juan Carlos of Spain were accompanied by air force pilots in their 45-minute overflight of the base.

title: WINANS CASE WITNESS SAYS BROKER OFTEN LIED
description: A sales assistant to Peter N. Brant, a former stockbroker who was the Government's chief witness in the trial of R. Foster Winans, testified yesterday that Mr. Brant frequently lied when she worked for him.

title: RANGERS' OFFENSE FAILS AGAIN
description: Up and down they go. The Rangers tonight again failed to win a second game in a row as they dropped a well-played 3-2 decision to the Buffalo Sabres. It was the seventh time since early January that they have followed victory with defeat.

title: CENTURY FACTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects increased number of shares outstanding. c-Net income.

title: ADVERTISING ;   MORE DIRECT MARKETING FROM GENERAL FOODS
description: In the March issue of Bon Appetit magazine is an ad for Thomas Garraway Ltd. of Madison, Wis., a direct marketer of gourmet foods, promising to deliver to the homes of America special premium cheeses, coffees, pastas, jams, meat and dessert sauces, cakes and cookies. All made by independent companies throughout the Western world and then shipped by Garraway.

title: PERU CLEARS INDIANS IN KILLING OF 8 JOURNALISTS
description: The attorney general's office said today that it had dropped charges against 17 peasants accused of killing 8 Peruvian journalists two years ago in the Andean guerrilla zone.

title: TWO BANKS BROKE U.S. CASH RULES
description: The Irving Trust Company and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company said yesterday that they had violated the Bank Secrecy Act by having failed to report, to Federal authorities, hundreds of millions of dollars in cash transactions.

title: PRUDENTIAL REJECTS CONVERSION PLAN
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's biggest insurer, has decided against converting to public ownership, a course other insurers have also been considering.

title: SCOUTING ;   Splinter Softens
description: A Scent of Spring, Scene 2:

title: IN NEW PLAYS, MYSTICAL VISIONS AND BROKEN GLASS
description: In the Ninth Annual Humana Festival of New American Plays last weekend at the Actors Theater of Louisville, there was the customary quota of family traumas and good ol' boy cussin' comedies, but there were also visions of God in a number of unearthly disguises - in Normandy in 1832 as the vision of a teen-ager who thinks he can fly, in mid 20th-century America as a deformed infant with the E.S.P. of E.T.

title: MORGENTHAU SUSPECTS A COVER-UP BY POLICE IN HIT-AND-RUN DEATH
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said yesterday that there appeared to be a cover-up by police officers in connection with a hit- and-run accident in which a pedestrian was killed by a patrol car on the Upper East Side.

description: Would you believe that the Mets have been trying to sign a Harvard- educated, Buddhist-trained mystic named Sidd Finch whose fastball has been clocked at 168 miles an hour - that's right, 168 - and who is considered such a cinch to revolutionize the game that Frank Cashen makes him pitch out of a canvas-covered cage in spring training so that rival scouts and baseball writers can't get a glimpse of him?

title: U.S. ADAMANT ON JAPAN TRADE
description: The Reagan Administration warned Japan today that a limit on car shipments to the United States would not be regarded as a substitute for wider access to Japanese markets.

title: RELOCATING: KITCHENS ON THE MOVE
description: MORE often than not, when architects and designers are called in for renovation advice, they propose radical design changes, reorganizing spaces completely, pulling down walls and switching rooms around. Or as Lee Mindel described it, ''putting the kitchen where the bedroom is and the bedroom where the kitchen was and the bathroom in the former maid's room.''

title: NEW ORGANISMS FOUND IN CITRUS CANKER HUNT
description: The organisms at the heart of Florida's devastating citrus canker outbreak are genetically different from any canker experts have previously studied, scientist say.

description: George Welsh, the University of Virginia football coach, and

title: CUOMO WILL FILL HIGH COURT POST FROM A LIST OF 7
description: Governor Cuomo was given a list of seven candidates yesterday from which to fill a vacancy on the New York Court of Appeals, the state's highest court.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: The latest quarter and year had 14 weeks and 53 weeks, respectively, compared with 13 weeks and 52 weeks for the year-earlier quarter and year, respectively.

title: Aero Engines Sale
description: International Aero Engines of London said three more airlines had ordered its new V-2500 engines.

title: DEFENSE LAWYER, 52, FATALLY SHOT IN PARKING LOT NEAR BRONX COURT
description: A defense lawyer who practiced in the Bronx was fatally shot in a parking lot across the street from the Bronx Criminal Courthouse last night by a man in a blue jogging suit who fled on foot, the police said.

title: TAPE RECORDINGS AN ISSUE IN NEW VON BULOW TRIAL
description: In a plant-filled house in the suburbs of Wakefield, Mass., north of Cambridge, a lean, mysterious young man named David Marriott lives with his mother - and with the keys to a safe- deposit box containing tape recordings and documents that have become the focus of intense interest in recent days.

title: OPTIMISM ON MONEY AT HIGH
description: The optimism of American consumers about their personal financial outlook is higher now than at any other time in President Reagan's tenure in office, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: HOUSE PANEL HEARS PLEA FOR FOOD SULFITE BAN
description: A ban on sulfites in food was urged today by members of Congress, scientists and people who said they or loved ones had suffered from inadvertent exposure to the chemicals.

title: Jersey High Court Stops Simulcasts
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court halted today the simulcasting of races from the Meadowlands to other New Jersey tracks until voters had an opportunity to approve the expanded gambling system, which has been in effect 18 months.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   The Artist Of the Pediatric Wards
description: Three years ago, a commercial artist and cartoonist named Milton Lederman was dismayed to discover that the walls of the pediatric ward at the St. Luke's division of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center were bare.

title: I.B.M. Computer
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a new industrial computer yesterday, called the System 9003, that can control robots and other manufacturing tools used in factories. The new system, based on the Motorola 68000 microprocessor, is priced at $21,130. It will be marketed by I.B.M. Instruments, the subsidiary that is trying to secure a niche for the computer giant in a number of specialized manufacturing and scientific areas.

title: Fed's Worry Over Economy Cited
description: A member of the Federal Reserve Board indicated today that the central bank had again become worried about an economic slowdown, and that its monetary policy might need to be relaxed.

title: Heroin Found in Child's Bag
description: Police today accused William Butler, 18 years old, of hiding 13 bags of heroin that fell out of a bookbag his 4-year-old neice was carrying to school Tuesday. A parent volunteer saw the bags and notified school officials, who called the police. They said the girl knew nothing of the drugs. Mr. Butler was charged with possession of heroin and intent to distribute it.

description: To the Editor:

DEADLY FORCE: LAWS VARY
description: At least half the states permit the police to shoot unarmed fleeing felony suspects, but local police department regulations are far more restrictive on the use of deadly force, a survey of statutes and practices around the nation indicates.

title: Bomb Near Playground Kills Soldier in Ulster
description: A British soldier was killed in Belfast today when a bomb planted by Irish nationalist guerrillas exploded just yards from a school playground, the police said.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN CRASH KILLS 41 JOHANNESBURG, March 27 (UPI) - A double-decker school bus ran out of control and plunged into a reservoir today, killing 41 high school students and injuring 28, some critically, the police said.
description: Rescue workers continued the search in the silt and muddy waters of the Westdene Dam reservoir, but a police spokesman said no more bodies were expected to be recovered.

title: CAR BOMBS EXPLODE IN CHILE, BUT A DAY OF PROTESTS FIZZLES
description: A planned day of anti-Government protests failed to win widespread support today.

title: C.D., Fund Yields Rise
description: Money market fund compound yields continued to show strong gains in the week ended yesterday, while bank money market yields slipped slightly. Yields on six-month certificates of deposit advanced for the fifth consecutive week, although at a slower pace. Consumer interest remains strong in shorter-term C.D.'s of six months and one year.

title: WEST GERMANY COOLER TO 'STAR WARS'
description: The West German Government appeared today to be backing away from its endorsement of the American research program for a space-based missile defense.

title: HOODS AND MINIS AT SAINT LAURENT
description: ''Simple'' is the watchword for his new collection, Yves Saint Laurent was telling everyone after his fall and winter show today. ''Simple for evening too,'' he added. He might also have said ''sporty,'' since most clothes for day and evening are constructed in separate parts and have a casual look.

title:
GARDENING;

LEARNING ALL OF THE CLIMATES IN A PLOT
description: ''EVERYBODY talks about the weather,'' a remark attributed to Mark Twain goes, ''but nobody does anything about it.'' Obviously the author was no gardener. If so, he would have known that the experienced grower can moderate the effects of the elements just by the proper manipulation of microclimates. Acquiring this skill requires some effort, for a thorough mastery comes only with much observation and practice. Nevertheless, the investment is negligible compared with the dividends. Through an adept use of microclimates the garden can not only insure a flourishing landscape with reduced maintenance, he can also significantly extend his palette of plants.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   A Fantasy Come True On an Uptown D Train
description: ''This is weird!'' The young woman had just boarded an uptown D train when she uttered the opinion, to no one in particular.

title: BEVIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $73,000 for the quarter and the year. c-Includes extraordinary charges of $84,000 for the quarter and $217,000 for the year.

title: ISRAEL CANNOT AFFORD TO PULL 'IRON' PUNCHES
description: Israel's ''Iron Fist'' policy in southern Lebanon - responding to terrorist attacks against its military personnel with large-scale shelling, mass arrests and the razing of houses - is arousing considerable moral indignation in America and Western Europe, even among Israel's friends. Since Israeli military sources have suggested that the ''Iron Fist'' may soon look like a ''velvet glove,'' compared to what is in store if terrorism in and from Lebanon continues or heightens, a second look at what is actually happening on the ground would seem in order. Israel has a dual goal in Lebanon: to withdraw its military in an orderly fashion (although it does not intend to have the pace of the pullback dictated by terror) and to secure its northern border. This second concern - to protect the Galilee region, home to 10 percent of the country's population, from Katyusha-rocket attacks and other shelling from Lebanon - was, of course, the principal aim of the Israeli invasion in 1982.

title: 'GOSPEL AND GUATEMALA' A LOOK AT PROSELYTIZING
description: ''THE GOSPEL AND GUATEMALA'' examines, and implicitly condemns, the alliance between a Guatemalan President and a fundamentalist Christian church. The examination is fascinating; the condemnation may be unwarranted. Guatemala is seen as an arena of good and evil, with no middle ground. The documentary will be shown on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

title: DRIVER-HARRIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $795,000 related to the reduction of prior year's pension expense. c-Net loss. Results include losses of $358,000 in the year-ago quarter and $1,667,000 in the previous year from the company's British subsidiary.

title: EXPLORING USE OF COMPUTER IN WEAVING
description: HOME computers, which have been known to play chess and compose a symphony, have found a new application in weaving. Two lecture- demonstrations by professional textile designers who use computers to create weaving patterns will explore the ways the technology can be used to carry on the old-world craft.

title: CEDAR IN ITS MANY FACES
description: STORING and protecting winter woolens is most easily done in a built-in cedar closet, but for those without one, the fragrance of cedar can be found in many forms. L. L. Bean sells portable cedar closets of red cedar and cotton canvas, which can be hung on a closet bar. A suit-length closet costs $85; a longer one (52 inches long) is $95. Bean also sells adhesive red cedar liners ($10 each) that fit most drawers. These items can be ordered through the catalogue of L. L. Bean, Freeport, Me. 04033 (207-865-3111).

title: AIDS DEATHS PROMPT WAVE OF PLAYS
description: When William Hoffman began writing a play about the mysterious disease called AIDS nearly three years ago, he thought he was alone in the calling. He was writing out of a personal pain - the death of a friend who only months before had been robust enough to run a marathon - and he was facing a subject that seemed far too grisly for the stage.

title: AT THE ARMS TALKS: TIGHT SECRECY, TIGHTER SPACE
description: At the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency offices on the Avenue de la Paix here, Ambassador Max M. Kampelman has made a concession on the issue of space. The chief American arms negotiator will have the carpenters move his office wall, ceding a bit of territory to make more room for the secretaries.

title: FALL PLAY APPEALS TO ONLY ONE GENERAL
description: Playing in the fall, a subject reopened this week in the United States Football League, appealed to only one of the Generals' players among 20 who responded to an informal poll in their locker room today.

description: The patched-up space shuttle Discovery is scheduled to take off April 12 for a revamped satellite-launching mission with Senator Jake Garn on board, the space agency said today.

February's production, on a seasonally adjusted basis, was up seven-tenths of 1 percent from January.

In particular, we were interested in quantifying the amount of abuse of the FTS long-distance lines by employees and the costs associated with such abuse rather than identifying individual abusers.

title: MUSIC: RICHARD RODGERS
description: FOR 12 hours on Saturday, Symphony Space resounded with the melodies of Richard Rodgers along with the reminiscences of those who knew and worked with the great Broadway composer. The occasion was Symphony Space's 14th ''wall-to-wall'' concert since the concept of all-day free tributes to composers was inaugurated in 1977. For most of the day, the event drew long lines around the block, at 95th St. and Broadway. Though the waiting time for entrance was a much as an hour and a half, the mood both outside and inside the hall was orderly and festive. Inside, a gala event involving more than 100 musicians and guests proceeded like clockwork.

This weekend, and over the coming week, they will resonate through New York's churches and concert halls with the vibrancy that only a great musical city can offer.

title: HIT-AND-RUN DEATH DEBATE OVER POLICE OFFICERS' 'CODE OF SILENCE'
description: ''They call it the 'code of silence' or 'the blue wall of conspiracy,' '' John Guido, the Police Department's Chief of Inspectional Services, said. ''There's a natural affinity of cops to stick with one another. But I don't see that as different from any other profession. Hey, it's not the American way to be a rat.'' ''It's a major problem wherever unions are involved and because of the closeness of the uniformed services,'' said Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward. ''It's less of a problem today than it was 15 years ago,'' he said, however, before the Knapp Commission's investigation of police corruption.

title: THEATER: 'HENRY IV' IN WASHINGTON
