Of course, one need look no further than the New York Shakespeare Festival or Washington's own Folger Theater to find instances of American companies taking their own rewarding approach to Shakespeare.

title: THE COAST GUARD'S HIDEAWAY IN THE HARBOR
description: The ferryboat glides into her dock at Governors Island as easily as an ice skater turning on a pond, but on her short trip through New York Harbor, she travels from one world to another.

title: REAGAN MAY YIELD ON ARMS SPENDING
description: David A. Stockman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, said today that President Reagan was prepared to accept some reductions in the military spending proposal he gave Congress.

title: ART HISTORIAN AND ARCHIVIST
description: Edgar P. Richardson, a leading art historian and a co-founder of the Archives of American art, died Wednesday at the Cathedral Village Retirement Community in Philadelphia after having suffered several strokes in recent weeks. He was 82 years old.

title: RISE IN CAR EXPORTS CONFIRMED BY JAPAN
description: The Japanese Government confirmed today that it would let automobile exports to the United States grow to 2.3 million cars a year, an increase of 24.3 percent.

title: SHULTZ SAYS U.S. WILL BE FLEXIBLE AT ARMS TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States was ready to meet the Soviet Union halfway in finding ''a mutually acceptable approach'' to the arms issues under negotiation in Geneva.

title: Topics ;   Cool Heads, Warm Winds ;   Wrong Time and Place
description: The Reagan Administration has not competed strenuously for First Amendment trophies. But it deserves points for prudence by rejecting, at least provisionally, a C.I.A. effort to make leaks of Government secrets a crime.

title: 'CROSSOVER DREAMS,' WITH SALSA BEAT
description: RUDY VELOZ, played by Ruben Blades, the real-life Panamanian-born salsa star, is a handsome, talented ''New Yorican'' musician and singer, a star on New York City's ill- paying Latino circuit. Rudy is in his mid-30's and has just signed a recording contract that promises to take him out of Spanish Harlem and make his fortune in the English-speaking, American music market. He can hardly contain his excitement, while his longtime girlfriend, Liz (Elizabeth Pena), is worried about what fame might do their relationship.

title: David Lean Discusses His Directing Career
description: Though no Oscars were won personally by David Lean when the awards were bestowed Monday, the 76-year-old film maker will receive a tribute of sorts late tonight when Channel 13 broadcasts ''A Conversation With David Lean.''

title: ELECTRO SCIENTIFIC INDUS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
VICTOR HERMAN, EXILE IN SOVIET
description: Victor Herman, an American who went to the Soviet Union in 1931 as a teen-ager and returned to the United States in 1976 after spending 18 years in labor camps and in exile in Siberia, died of a heart attack Monday. He was 69 years old and lived in Southfield, Mich., a suburb of Detroit.

title: Overlord
description: It's in the nature of New Yorkers to want to see things first, and then brag a little. And it's in the nature of the New Directors/New Films series to satisfy that urge. For 14 springs, this movie festival has been a rite of discovery of fresh talent: among those who made their debuts in New Directors are Steven Spielberg, John Sayles, Wim Wenders, Wayne Wang and Nestor Almendros.

title: TOP STATE LABOR NEGOTIATOR ALWAYS READY TO TALK
description: When you are negotiating contracts worth $6 billion a year with unions representing 175,000 employees and the deadline is less than a week away, no place or time is off limits for bargaining or talking about bargaining.

title: GEORGETOWN HAS DEPTH, EXPERIENCE AND EWING
description: It could happen this way, but it won't.

title: INTERNATIONAL CAPITAL EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: LIFT THE ANCHOR ON CIVIL RIGHTS
description: The new Attorney General, Edwin Meese 3d, should take steps to remedy one of the worst shortcomings of the Reagan Administration's first term - its dismal civil rights record.

title: TIME FOR MORAL LEADERSHIP ON GULF WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Trio at Vanguard
description: The pianist Steve Kuhn, the bassist Ron Carter and the drummer Al Foster will play trios tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South below 11th Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is an $8.50 cover and a one-drink minimum. Information: 255-4037.

title: Koch Drops Plan To Add Shelters
description: The Koch administration last night dropped plans to renovate or expand three shelters for the homeless in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, because of community opposition.

title: COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENERS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Per share figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split last July.

title: SCOUTING ;   Ernie D Trying Another Way
description: Ernie DiGregorio, who except for a brief visit or two at tryout camps has been out of the National Basketball Association for seven years, is embarking on an effort to return, this time as a referee.

title: BRIEFS
description: Abitibi-Price Inc., Toronto, said it had acquired 99.5 percent of Barbecon Inc.'s class A shares and 99.8 percent of the class B shares in response to its bid for the shares, and extended its offer to April 15, from March 27.

title: JMB REALTY TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes gains of $1,494,154 from the disposition of a land investment.

title: 'Beach House,' romantic comedy at Circle Rep.
description: Guess who will soon be treading the boards at the Circle Repertory Company? If you come up with Swoosie Kurtz, give yourself a 10. Sam Waterston? Another 10. Now that we have the players, let's try for the director. Anyone who comes up with Melvin Bernhardt, who staged Broadway's ''Crimes of the Heart'' and ''Dancing in the End Zone,'' has a perfect score.

title: DEVILS END 8-GAME LOSS SLIDE
description: The Devils ended an eight-game losing streak tonight with a 3-2 victory over the Washington Capitals, who will finish second in the Patrick Division and meet the Islanders in the playoffs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 29, 1985 International

title: REPORT SAYS MEDICARE FUND WILL BE SOLVENT UNTIL 1998
description: The Medicare trust fund, which finances health care for 30 million elderly and disabled people, will not run out of money until 1998, seven years later than previously anticipated, according to official estimates issued today.

title: SPIRE CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $101,365.

title: Gale W. Shaw, Consultant, Is Married to Glenn Patron
description: Gale Wilson Shaw, former marketing and production director for Symphony Space, the performing arts center in Manhattan, was married yesterday to Glenn David Patron, president of Bearings and Transmissions Inc. in San Juan and Ponce, P.R. Superior Court Judge Jose Contraeras officiated at El Convento Hotel in San Juan.

title: SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
SENATE PANEL LEADERS CLASH OVER MEASURE ON NICARAGUA
description: The Republican chairman and the ranking Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee clashed today over the scope of a measure approved by the panel Wednesday night to restrict use of American foreign aid money for financing Nicaraguan rebels.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, MARCH 29, 1985
description: Companies

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Some Ground Workers Are Recalled by Pan Am By United Press International
description: Ground workers at Pan American World Airways began returning to their jobs yesterday, with the airline aiming to have 82 percent of its scheduled flights in operation within a month.

title: Candidate Seen For Trade Post
description: Clayton Yeutter, president of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and a former deputy trade representative, is considered the leading candidate to replace Bill Brock as United States Trade Representative, trade and financial sources said today. Trade sources said Mr. Yeutter met this week with Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, to discuss the post.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Comings and Goings
description: Frank Mulzoff , a former St. John's coach, has been named coach of the Long Island Knights, one of the eight teams being formed by the new United States Basketball League. . . .

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Santa Cruz, Calif., on March 18, about that city's street people, misidentified the current holder of Santa Cruz's rotating mayoralty. She is Mardi Wormhoudt; John Laird, her predecessor, is a member of the City Council.

title: Time for Moral Leadership on Gulf War
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Financial Corp. of Santa Barbara, Calif., has elected Arthur B. Hall executive vice president, chief financial officer and treasurer. Glen H. Carter was also elected executive vice president, retail banking, and Michael D. Schley was named senior vice president, general counsel and secretary.

title: Market Place ;   Divided Views On Retailers
description: Consumer spending, many economists and analysts believe, will remain flat through the first half of this year, and then recover smartly in the second half. But one of Wall Street's most respected retailing analysts, Joseph Ellis of Goldman, Sachs & Company, thinks that sales will be practically flat all year, and is therefore recommending that investors ''lighten'' all their retail stocks except for a select four or five.

title: INFINITE GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income.

title: SCOUTING ;   Hitting the Target
description: Peter Jacobsen was expounding a while back on what he and innumerable other pros on the PGA Tour regard as the inherently ungolflike quality of the three Tournament Players Club courses that the circuit visits.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Washington Bullets , at Landover, Md., 7:30 P.M. The Nets have won four of five previous games with the Bullets, taking the season series, but it is still important for them to finish ahead or at least tied with the Bullets to gain an advantage for the playoffs.

title: EARTHWORM TRACTOR CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: ADVERTISING ;   Ohlmeyer Advertising Gets ESPN Account
description: Ohlmeyer Advertising has become ad agency for the Entertainment and Sports Programming Network and the only question is, what took it so long?

title: CONVERSION OF A HOSPITAL TO APARTMENTS
description: Change is nothing new for the large, ornate structure at Second Avenue and 18th Street that used to be a hospital. But never has it experienced the sweeping internal reordering that two housing developers are imposing upon it now.

title: LINCOLN CENTER GETS A $1.4 MILLION GRANT
description: He began the week by inspiring eight Academy Awards, even though he's been dead for nearly 200 years, and yesterday Mozart was responsible for the largest single corporate grant Lincoln Center has ever received for activities in New York State.

title: Allis Set to Sell Agricultural Unit
description: The Allis- Chalmers Corporation said today that it had reached a preliminary agreement to sell its agricultural equipment operations and a financing unit, the Allis-Chalmers Credit Corporation, to a subsidiary of Kl"ockner- Humboldt-Deutz A.G. of West Germany for $100 million.

title: Tribune Company
description: The Tribune Company, wary of unfriendly takeover attempts, is seeking permission from shareholders to triple the number of its authorized common shares, to 150 million. A proxy statement, to be voted on at the annual meeting in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on May 2, said the additional stock could be used to ''impede a takeover or to make a change in the control of the company more difficult.'' There have been no reports of attempts to take over the company, which owns The Chicago Tribune, The Daily News in New York, radio and television stations and the Chicago Cubs baseball team.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Paraguay Judge Orders Destruction of Chemicals
description: A Paraguayan judge ordered today that the authorities destroy 141 tons of impounded chemicals that could be used to process eight tons of cocaine. The United States has been seeking such a decision for seven months in an effort to combat international drug traffickers.

title: DIONICS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects a tax credit of $86,000 in the latest year and $61,000 in the previous year.

title: MCO RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Debt Issues
description: American Telephone and Telegraph Co. has announced that it will guarantee payment of principal and interest on the long-term debt of ATT Technologies, formerly known as Western Electric.

title: WESTWOOD ONE reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
PLAN FOR WIDER DISTRIBUTION OF CHEAP POWER IS SET BACK
description: New York State's plan to distribute more broadly the cheap hydroelectric power produced upstate has been dealt a severe setback by a Federal regulatory agency.

title: NOBILITY HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-Net income

title: BRUINS ARE READY FOR INDIANA Coach Walt Hazzard of U.C.L.A. has found more redemption than Bobby Knight of Indiana in reaching tonight's championship game of the National Invitation Tournament.
description: ''People buried us when we were here in December,'' Hazzard said about a 19-point loss to St. John's Dec. 22, ''and I told you not to.''

title: Lyon Retracts Offer to Jacobs
description: Lyon Metal Products Inc. reversed a decision made Wednesday and said it would not repurchase the 38 percent of its stock held by Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, for $19 a share, or a total of $10.1 million. Instead, the company, based in Aurora, Ill., said it supported an earlier proposal to buy all outstanding shares for $20 each in a leveraged buyout through an employee stock plan.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''National support for building military strength has been severely battered by public perception that we pay too much for the goods and services we acquire.'' - Verne Orr, Secretary of the Air Force. (A1:6.)

title: WASTED CORNER OF AFRICA: NOTHING LEFT BUT HOPE
description: Most of the original residents of this dusty, worn-down West African town - the ''real people'' - moved on some time ago, the elderly woman said. The residents were fleeing drought, in the hope that anywhere else would be a better place to be.

title: BRIEFING ;   'Debtbusters'
description: On the chance that some painless public education may result, the Roosevelt Center for American Policy Studies has developed an audience participation game dealing with the joyless subjects of budget balancing and deficit reduction. The nonpartisan research group vows that ''Debtbusters'' is ''fun to play,'' and Representative Bob Edgar of Pennsylvania has been persuaded to put that dubious thesis to the test at a meeting of his constituents near Philadelphia Saturday.

title: Howard Johnson
description: Imperial Group P.L.C. said its investment adviser, Goldman, Sachs & Company, was holding talks with parties interested in buying its Howard Johnson Company unit, and that it would make a decision about a sale ''as soon as possible.'' Speaking to shareholders at Imperial's annual meeting in London, Geoffrey Kent, chairman, said the company would consider Howard Johnson's prospects for recovery in deciding whether to sell the American hotel and restaurant chain. Imperial bought Howard Johnson in 1980 for $630 million, and it has been a financial disappointment for the company since then.

title: MACHINE TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a credit of $173,000 from life insurance proceeds for the quarter and 6 months.

title: ART: FIGURE DRAWING IN THE 20TH CENTURY
description: ''TWENTIETH-CENTURY AMERICAN DRAWINGS - The Figure in Context'' is a fine idea for an exhibition. There is renewed interest both in drawing and in the human figure. There also continues to be uncertainty as to how the human figure should be approached. For example, how can a contemporary artist work with the subject without disregarding the history of modernism and reflecting a view of the human being as a bundle of disparate or disembodied fragments? In principle, a cross section of drawings of the human figure could have a good deal to tell us.

title: GIBSON STOCK OFFERED FOR SALE
description: Senior management at Gibson Greetings Inc. and Wesray, a partnership, are selling 3.5 million share of the greeting card company in a public offering through Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: POP/Jazz ;   JOBIM AND HIS SONGS AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: Antonio Carlos Jobim, the Brazilian composer of romantic melodies whose delicate beauty and stunning simplicity have secured a lasting place in popular culture, will perform tonight and tomorrow at Carnegie Hall. It is his first appearance in the United States since his American debut on the same stage in 1962.

title: 'TEST OF LOVE,' FROM AUSTRALIA
description: ''ANNIE'S COMING OUT,'' a book by Rosemary Crossley and Anne McDonald, is about Miss Crossley's experience at an Australian institution for disabled children, the institution in which she encountered Miss McDonald. Crippled by cerebral palsy and confined in the institution from the age of 3, Miss McDonald was entirely unable to communicate when Miss Crossley first met her. She was thought to be badly retarded and, in keeping with the harsh customs of the institution in which she was confined, was treated accordingly.

title: E.P.A. PROPOSES ALLOWING EMISSIONS OF CANCER-CAUSING SUBSTANCE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed changing its rules to allow some controlled air emissions of vinyl chloride, a cancer-causing substance.

title: EUROPEANS EXPLORING POTENTIAL ROLE IN 'STAR WARS' RESEARCH
description: Western European governments have begun identifying areas of possible European participation in high-technology research involving the multibillion-dollar Strategic Defense Initiative.

title: KNICKS' LOSE FOURTH STRAIGHT
description: Both the Knicks and the Bucks were decimated by injuries for last night's game. But Milwaukee, even without Sidney Moncrief (sore knees), Terry Cummings (bruised right foot) and Charles Davis (sore right arch), had enough talent left to defeat the Knicks, 121-116, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: The Picking of St. John's
description: The White House selected St. John's University as the site of a major speech by President Reagan because the school represented ''a cross section of students'' whose families support Mr. Reagan's policies, White House officials said yesterday.

title: AUCTION OF DOCUMENTS ON BETSY ROSS CANCELED
description: An auction of documents relating to the life of Betsy Ross, from the Elsie O. Sang collection, was called off by Sotheby's and Mrs. Sang earlier this week after the City of Philadelphia said one of the documents had been stolen from its files. The document in the dispute is a 1776 administrative bond for the estate of Betsy Ross's first husband that is signed ''Elizabeth Ross.''

title: Norfolk Drops Lawyer
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation said today that John J. Salmon of the law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood had agreed to stop representing the company in its proposed acquisition of Conrail. Norfolk said it had not been aware that J. Paul McGrath, an Assistant Attorney General, intended to join the law firm on April 1.

title: LAWE SAYS HE WON'T STRIKE THE SUBWAYS AT MIDNIGHT SUNDAY
description: The head of the city's bus and subway workers, who warned two days ago about the possibility of a transit strike next week, said yesterday that he would not authorize a walkout when his union's contract expired at midnight Sunday and never meant to suggest that he would.

title: ADVERTISING ;   Beber Silverstein Gains
description: Beber Silverstein, which earlier this year became the agency for Coty's Sophia fragrance, has now been chosen to do the creative work for its Coty Musk for Men cologne and the Coty Wild Musk perfume. Coty is a division of Pfizer Inc., which does its own media buying.

title: Arbitrate the 'Last' Transit Offers
description: A bare fortnight after assuring New Yorkers that he would not call a transit strike this year, the leader of the subway and bus union, John Lawe, warns that his members may stage walkouts anyway at midnight Sunday. The best way to avoid this, he says, is by going to binding arbitration. Governor Cuomo has an even better idea: binding arbitration of the last best offer by each side.

title: WINSTON MILLS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $664,000, a gain on assignment of license of $1,010,000 and a tax benefit of $1,602,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $181,000 and a tax benefit of $350,000.

title: CRYSTAL OIL Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of of $1,675,000 for the quarter and the year. c-Reflects an extraordinary charge of $2,176,000 for the quarter and the year.

title: GORBACHEV VOICES CONCERN ON ARMS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, said in a letter to a West German group today that American statements about the arms talks in Geneva ''cannot but put one on guard.''

title: New Computer From I.B.M. Reflecting industry's desire
description: for computers that do not fail,

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report on Saturday about a visit by Mayor Koch to Harlem incorrectly described the apartment house at 103-105 West 120th Street. The building includes the4,000th apartment rehabilitated by the city for the homeless.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   United Technologies Names 2 to Head Units
description: The United Technologies Corporation yesterday named two executives to head a restructured Building Systems Company - now its energy management and building automation subsidiary - and a new unit, United Technologies Communications and Services.

title: CANADIAN ADMITS 'STAR WAR ' DOUBTS
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney conceded today that he had reservations about President Reagan's invitation to Canada to join in researching an antiballistic missile in space.

title: CHILD ABUSE AND THE COURTS
description: The chief appeals judge of Manhattan and the Bronx said yesterday that both trial court judges and appeals court judges ''must be trained to understand the nature of the crime of child sexual abuse, which is special.''

title: STAGE: 'BILOXI BLUES,' SIMON'S NEW COMEDY
description: Although the laughter rarely stops in ''Biloxi Blues,'' Neil Simon's joyous and unexpectedly rewarding new comedy, the most surprising line of the evening by far is not a joke, but a reprimand. The reprimand is delivered to the young hero, Eugene Je rome (Matthew Broderick) - who has now graduated from the Depression adolescence of Mr. Simon's previous autobiographical play, ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' to basic training in the wartime Army of 1943.

title: A Russo Ruse?
description: Representative Marty Russo of Illinois has dispatched a ''Dear Colleague'' letter to all House Democrats listing potential candidates for leadership posts after 1986 when Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. retires. In it he names 58 candidates for speaker, 61 for majority leader, 60 for majority whip and 69 for caucus chairman, which turns out to include all the addressees.

title: PLEA BY GOETZ IS NOT GUILTY TO ATTEMPTED MURDER OF 4
description: Bernhard H. Goetz pleaded not guilty in State Supreme Court yesterday to charges that he tried to murder four young men on a Manhattan subway train last December.

title: SCREEN: 'DESPERATELY SEEKING SUSAN'
description: SUSAN SEIDELMAN, you should remember, is the young director who first came to attention three years ago with ''Smithereens,'' a wonderfully funny, independently financed, $80,000 first-feature about a pushy, punkish young woman named Wren and her adventures in the Day-Glo lower-depths of the East Village and blocks west. It's now apparent that ''Smithereens'' was not a fluke.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   40 Killed in Crash Of a Colombia Airliner
description: A commercial airliner crashed into a fog-shrouded mountain in southern Colombia during a storm today, killing all 40 people aboard, authorities said.

title: EASTGROUP PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a gain from the sale of investments of $4,221,000 in the latest quarter and $1,789,000 in the year-ago quarter.

title: LEANING TOO HARD ON THE MEXICANS
description: In its confrontation with Mexico, the United States is breaking a cardinal rule of its neighbor's politics: don't corner a Mexican President. Mexico knows no greater wrath than that of its president when his dignity - or that of his country - is compromised. By leaning too heavily on Mexico on drug-related matters, the United States is risking a drastic Mexican response.

title: 10 IN PUERTO RICO CONVICTED OF PERJURY IN 2 MEN'S DEATHS
description: Ten police officers were found guilty tonight of 45 counts of perjury and conspiracy to commit perjury for lying to Federal grand juries investigating the deaths of two radical advocates of independence.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Sanctuary Worker Given A Lighter Sentence
description: A Federal district judge today reduced the sentence of a worker in a movement that provides sanctuary to Salvadoran refugees from one year in prison to 150 days in a halfway house.

title: Max Roach Group
description: The drummer Max Roach and his group - with Cecil Bridgewater on trumpet, Odean Pope on tenor saxophone and Tyrone Brown on bass - will perform tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum. Reservations: 242-1785.

title: MED-CHEM PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. WILL BOYCOTT ELBE LINK-UP FETE
description: The United States Government has decided to boycott an anniversary gathering on the Elbe River next month of Soviet and American veterans of World War II because of the killing of a United States officer in East Germany.

title: Eisenberg Exhibit
description: More than 50 works by the artist Sonja Eisenberg will be on display and on sale beginning Sunday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street.

title: SCREEN: 'KING DAVID,' A BIBLICAL EPIC
description: ''KING DAVID,'' about the warrior king who made Israel a nation, is not a good film. As Biblical epics go, it's a tiny bit more lively than George Stevens's ''Greatest Story Every Told,'' but, as good, old- fashioned, cornball entertainment, it doesn't even attempt to compete with anything as riotously garish as Cecil B. De Mille's classic, ''The Ten Commandments.''

title: BSN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: AT THE MOVIES ;   All-American cast of virtues in 'Silverado.'
description: ''DECENCY, right and wrong, tough living, men and women, American history, excitement and adventure'' are, according to Jeff Goldblum, some of the concerns addressed by ''Silverado,'' an upcoming western. ''Silverado'' will reunite Mr. Goldblum (who is currently starring in ''Into the Night'') with Lawrence Kasdan, the director and co-screenwriter of ''The Big Chill.'' It will co- star Rosanna Arquette, Kevin Kline, Scott Glenn, Danny Glover and John Cleese.

title: Three Mile Island Protest
description: More than 150 people rallied today for a permanent shutdown of the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant as they marked the sixth anniversary of the worst accident in United States commercial nuclear history.

title: MASS TRANSIT IN MIAMI FACES A BUMPY FUTURE
description: Everyone, including the critics, agrees that Metrorail, Miami's new elevated mass transit system, looks splendid.

title: Meese Is Ordered to Provide More Details on Legal Bills
description: A Federal appeals court today ordered Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to provide more details on his request that the Government pay his legal bills stemming from an investigation of his financial affairs.

title: Berlin Octet to Perform
description: The Berlin Octet will perform music by Beethoven, Rossini and Fran,caix Sunday afternoon at 3 in Carnegie Hall. The Berlin Octet comprises members of the Berlin Symphony of East Berlin and was founded in 1964. Tickets are $8 to $15 and are available at the Carnegie Hall box office or through CarnegieCharge at 247-7800.

title: MONOLITHIC MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 17
description: The latest quarter and 6 months nets reflect a pretax gain of about $1,250,000 from recovery of an insurance claim.

title: Insiders' Rules Studied
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is considering easing rules that prohibit corporate executives from earning short-term profits by trading their company's stock.

title: FATHER AND SON IN 'PORGY'
description: ''It's exciting to have my father in the production,'' said nine-year-old Clinton Chinyelu Ingram, who plays Scipio in the Metropolitan Opera's production of ''Porgy and Bess.'' ''Like in the middle of the play, I just go up to him and talk to him during the performance and afterwards. So it doesn't have to be that scary.''

title: D.O.C. OPTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: BILL EXTENDING JOBLESS BENEFITS GAINS
description: A House Ways and Means subcommittee today approved a three-month extension of supplemental unemployment benefits that would reduce the assistance for new recipients.

title: SCOUTING ;   Do It His Way
description: The members of the Pontiac Stadium Authority voted the other day to approve $204,000 in design modifications intended to protect the Silverdome's roof against further collapse, but not before their chairman, James Clarkson, had issued the ultimate threat: ''We have to make these improvements to guarantee the integrity of the roof. If you don't do it this way, I quit.''

title: Alcan Outlook
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. has ''an urgent need'' to lower its break-even point and improve its performance, David M. Culver, chief executive, said at the company's annual meeting in Montreal. Mr. Culver was referring to pricing and oversupply problems that have hurt most aluminum companies. He said Alcan would not change its overall strategy but suggested trimming staff, lowering inventories and getting more out of Alcan's competitive advantages in owning hydropower in Canada. Mr. Culver declined to estimate first-quarter earnings but said he was ''not optimistic.''

title: Threat of Acid Rain in West
description: Lakes and forests in the mountains of the West could be just as vulnerable to acid rain as those in the Northeast, an environmental study group said today.

title: MACNEAL-SCHWENDLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The U.N. Today
description: March 29, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ON PARIS STREETS, FASHION IS UP-TO-DATE
description: The fashionable women in Paris are wearing clothes that are not much different from those on the runways. Coming and going from the showings, and around the city, chic women are already wearing spring versions of trends the designers started last season and are continuing.

title: TECHNICAL COATINGS CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Stocks Are Mixed; Dow Falls 4.20
description: Wall Street stocks rallied yesterday morning after President Reagan delivered an optimistic speech to traders at the New York Stock Exchange, but the euphoria wore off by the close and prices finished the day mixed.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Chargers Drop Muncie
description: Chuck Muncie , the San Diego Charger running back who has been under suspension since last November because of an involvement with drugs, was dismissed from the team following reports that he had violated the terms of his rehabilitation by refusing several times to submit to urinalysis.

title: BOSTON BANK CITES MORE VIOLATIONS
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation, which pleaded guilty last month to Federal charges that it had failed to properly report $1.22 billion in international cash transactions, said today that it had found an additional $110 million in such deals that went unreported.

title: Making Jury Duty a Little Less Frustrating
description: To the Editor:

title: An A.M.C. Closing
description: The American Motors Corporation said it would close assembly operations at its only United States car plant for two weeks beginning Monday in another move to reduce inventories of its slow-selling subcompacts, the Renault Alliance and Encore. The plant is in Kenosha, Wis. A.M.C. said the move would result in temporary layoffs of up to 5,000 of the 6,200 hourly workers at the plant.

title: COAST FARMERS GET A REPRIEVE ON IRRIGATION WATER
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel tonight announced a tentative agreement under which the runoff of polluted agricultural water into the Kesterson National Wildlife Refuge in California's San Joaquin Valley would be phased out starting Sept. 30.

title: Friday AN EVENING WITH SEGOVIA
description: Although he celebrated his 92d birthday last month, Andres Segovia is still eliciting magical sounds from his guitar, and will offer his only New York recital of the season tonight at Avery Fisher Hall. The Spanish-born guitarist will perform works by Luis de Narvaez, Fernando Sor, Alexandre Tansman, Heitor Villa-Lobos, Mario Castelnuovo-Tedesco, Enrique Granados, Frederico Moreno Torroba and Haydn. The concert, which is part of the Great Performers at Lincoln Center series, will begin at 8 P.M. Tickets are $10, $15 and $20. The box office ticket and information number is 874-2424; CenterCharge, 874-6770. STEINBERG BACK ON STAGE

title: Italian cuisine on East 58th St.
description: East 58th Street between Second and Third Avenues is Little Italy uptown, a block of opulent restaurants where starched cotton tablecloths are favored over red-checked poly-blends, where tuxedoed waiters recite a list of daily specials that can go on for days, and where meatballs have been banned from menus under threat of deportation.

title: PUBLISHING: A WAKE FOR A BANKRUPT BOOK HOUSE
description: The publishing house of Congdon & Weed declared bankruptcy last month, and the publishing world marked its passing with a rather upbeat wake last night at the American Irish Historical Society in Manhattan. Proceeds from the cocktail reception and buffet, to which some 450 people were invited, are to be earmarked for authors and free-lancers who are owed money, according to Thomas Congdon, who founded the house in 1979.

title: 2 Young Entrepreneurs Cited by Reagan
description: Two weeks ago, Dale A. Cain and Kent D. Abell were invited to the White House to meet President Reagan. The two young contractors, who had started an electrical business in 1981 with $1,000, wanted to thank the President for their four years of prosperity.

title: An Indictment Charges Mengel With a Murder
description: A Westchester County grand jury today indicted Alex J. Mengel for first-degree murder in the Feb. 24 shooting of Gary Stymiloski, a Westchester County police officer who had stopped Mr. Mengel for a traffic violation on the Saw Mill River Parkway.

title: THE MARMON GROUP, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: There were no share earnings available because the company has no publicly held common shares.

description: The Rockland County District Attorney said today that his office had identitified a second suspect in the murder of a 26- year-old Norwegian fashion student in Stony Point last month.

description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, said yesterday that he might try to take over the Unocal Corporation, owner of the Union Oil Company of California.

description: AS a result of a reappraisal of its agency needs, Nabisco Brands has made some changes that have brought joy to Doyle Dane Bernbach and Bozell & Jacobs and woe to J. Walter Thompson, McCann-Erickson and Benton & Bowles.

title: IRWIN LEADS BY 1 IN T.P.C. WITH 67
description: Hale Irwin could not putt from the short, back fringe of the 18th green on the Tournament Players Club course today. There was a sprinkler head in front of his ball and in his line to the hole.

description: Honduran military authorities ordered troops to surround the Supreme Court and the National Congress today in the face of a political crisis, but a Western diplomat denied rumors of a coup.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Shot Clock Sought College basketball is almost certain to have a 45-second shot clock next season, according to the editor of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's rules committee.
description: Edward Steitz , athletic director at Springfield College and longtime editor of the rules committee, told a news conference today that 62 percent of the National Association of Basketball Coaches surveyed called for the N.C.A.A. to put into place the shot clock for all games next season.

Honor Students Form Texas Vigilante Group
description: A group of students formed a secret organization called the Legion of Doom, bombed an automobile and killed a cat in a campaign of violence against drug use and crime at their high school, the authorities say.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Store Owners Return At Los Angeles Blast Site
description: Merchants forced to close when a weekend explosion demolished a clothing store in their area returned to work today after fire officials found no trace of the natural methane gas that had been leaking for four days.

title: PATROLS IN GERMANY:POSTWAR VESTIGE
description: The fatal shooting of an American officer in East Germany last Sunday violently marred one of the most smoothly functioning relationships between the United States and the Soviet Union: administering their vestigial occupation rights in Germany. The carefully tempered anger of the United States over the killing of Maj. Arthur D. Nicholson Jr. by a Soviet sentry appeared to suggest a wish to contain the incident and not allow it to disrupt the arms talks.

title: A Welcome Curb on Deadly Force
description: The Supreme Court's restrictions on the use of deadly force by the police ratify longtime standards of both decency and effective law enforcement. They are particularly welcome at a time when public sentiment seems to be encouraging official violence in response to criminal violence.

title: BRIEFING ;   Praising Mrs. Reagan
description: A warm glow of recognition is suffusing the office of Nancy Reagan in the White House these days.

title: NOVO CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $875,000 for the latest year and $563,000 for the previous year.

title: Diner's Journal
description: An engaging new restaurant-nightspot has opened in the atrium of Trump Plaza at 61st Street and Third Avenue. Called Alo Alo, it is the latest American project of Ricardo Amaral, the Brazilian-born entrepreneur who owns the discoth eque Club A as well as Tucano, a French restaurant, both at 333 East 60th Street.

title: The Lost White Tribe
description: South Africa's agony has become America's living-room theater. Intensive television coverage has made the principal actors, white, black and brown, comprehensible. And it has underlined the message of prior press reports: the bafflement of a lost white tribe that cannot understand why Americans are so aroused. South Africa's leaders deserve a hearing, and an answer.

title: VERMONT'S ICE CREAM UPSTART
description: Following a trend toward what has been called ''high touch'' in the food business, Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc. has combined natural ingredients and personality to turn a few thousand dollars into millions.

description: In recent years, Krzystof Zanussi

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $350.9 million, to $210.44 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: EXPORT FALL WIDENS TRADE GAP
description: The United States trade deficit widened to $11.4 billion last month as the biggest drop in exports in seven years canceled out a slight decline in the flood of imports, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Singapore President Out; Drinking Problem Cited
description: President C. V. Devan Nair resigned Wednesday, admitting that he had developed a drinking problem and had deceived the Prime Minister for a year about it, Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew said today.

title: WAITING FOR NIXON TAPES? DON'T HOLD YOUR BREATH
description: In December 1974 Congress passed a law seizing control of all Nixon White House tapes and documents and calling for regulations to open those with historical significance for public inspection.

title: HOUSE VOTE GIVES FINAL APPROVAL FOR PURCHASE OF 21 MX MISSILES
description: President Reagan's request for 21 additional MX missiles survived the final test of a yearlong battle today as the House of Representatives voted 217 to 210 to release $1.5 billion earmarked for their purchase.

title: WILSHIRE OIL CO OF TEXAS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1983 net and share earnings do not include $1,420,000, or 16 cents a share, from the company's former banking subsidiary through Feb. 18, 1983, at which time the stock of Trust Co. was distributed to Wilshire Oil stockholders.

title: Delos String Quartet
description: The Delos String Quartet will play music by Antonin Dvorak and Josef Suk in its recital at the 92d Street Y Sunday night at 8.

title: 'DEDICATED MAN' OPENS STORY SERIES
description: Having completed its grand dissection of the British Raj in the dramatization of four Paul Scott novels presented as ''The Jewel in the Crown,'' public television's Masterpiece Theater is now catching its breath with a series of short stories, produced for Britain's Granada Television and collected under the umbrella title ''All for Love.'' The first story in a series of five, beginning Sunday night at 9 on Channel 13, is ''A Dedicated Man'' by Elizabeth Taylor, adapted by Hugh Whitemore.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''THE JEWEL IN THE CROWN'' may have gone on its royal way, but that hasn't halted the current reign of television parties. This week they ranged from Oscar to ''Tosca.'' Still, there was no lack of revelers who chose to go out.

title: NEW YORK PLANS MORE MORTGAGES AT LOW INTEREST
description: A new offering of low-interest mortgages, with altered rules for awarding them, was announced today by Governor Cuomo.

title: Winans Case Defense Rests
description: With lawyers for two co-defendants in the trial of R. Foster Winans declining to call their clients to the witness stand, the defense rested yesterday and testimony in one of the most celebrated insider-trading cases came to an end.

title: Season Off for N.A.S.L. With only two franchises left, the North American Soccer League
description: announced yesterday that it was suspending operations for the 1985 season, but hoped to revive professional soccer next year. ''We simply ran out of time,'' said the acting league president,

title: ADVERTISING ;   Publisher Set For U.S. News
description: Morton B. Zuckerman, the new owner of U.S. News & World Report, yesterday disclosed the name of his new publisher, Richard C. Thompson, 51-year-old director of advertising sales at Business Week. And for a kicker he threw in an associate publisher as well, James C. Mason, 40, another Business Week man who is worldwide director of marketing.

title: Expos Are Happier With Carter Gone
description: Earlier this week, someone clipped and posted a newspaper article about Gary Carter on the bulletin board in the Montreal Expos' clubhouse in West Palm Beach. With a blue pen, someone had underlined each mention of ''I'' and ''me'' in the article. There were 18 such blue lines.

title: BRIEFING ;   He Who Is 1st but 4th
description: Representative James H. Scheuer, Democrat of Queens, bounced into his office the morning after the Ninth Annual Congressional Chili Cookoff and told his staff, ''I got the first prize.''

title: Reputed Deputy In Mob Is Indicted
description: The reputed second-in-command of the Gambino organized-crime group and nine other people described as ''members and associates of the family'' were indicted yesterday on Federal racketeering charges.

title: ONE OF MODERN ART'S GIANTS
description: Marc Chagall, for 75 years a prominent member of the international art scene, the originator of images that had an almost universal potency and a master of large-scale commissions that have left a permanent mark on the cities in which they were located, died yesterday at his home in St. Paul de Vence, France. He was 97 years old.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Member of Racist Group Begins Serving Sentence
description: Bruce C. Pierce, reputed head of a militant white racist group who was arrested this week on four Federal warrants, has begun serving a two-year sentence in the Federal Penitentiary in Atlanta for counterfeiting, a prison official said today.

title: Providence in Final; 62 Saves for Terreri
description: Chris Terreri, the Providence goalie, made a tournament-record 62 saves tonight as the Friars captured a dramatic 4-3 triple-overtime victory over Boston College in a National Collegiate Athletic Association semifinal at Joe Louis Arena.

title: Isles Near Bahamas Get a New Leader
description: GRAND TURK, Turks and Caicos Islands, March 28 (Reuters) - Former Deputy Chief Minister Nathaniel Francis has been chosen as the new leader of this British colony near the Bahamas, after the arrest of his predecessor, Norman Saunders, on drug-smuggling charges in Miami.

title: Laura Tucker Is Wed To Lawrence F. Camp
description: Laura Lynn Tucker, a banking officer with Interfirst Bank Dallas in New York, and Lawrence Forsythe Camp, a vice president of Security Pacific National Bank in New York, were married yesterday in London. The Rev. John Irvine performed the Anglican ceremony at Holy Trinity Church.

title: OFFICER TESTIFIES IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: A white police officer, testifying before an official inquiry into the killing last week of 19 black people, told a judicial inquiry today that he had feared for his life when a crowd of blacks advanced on his armored vehicle and had no choice but to fire in self-defense.

title: NEW GOALS AT MATURING LOTUS
description: Mitchell D. Kapor, the freewheeling chairman of the Lotus Development Corporation, found it disconcerting recently when competitors started referring to Lotus as ''the I.B.M. of software.''

title: ART: SHOW PROPOUNDS A 'PRECIOUS' ESTHETIC
description: Those who believe that religion, craftsmanship and sentiment have vanished from contemporary art are laboring, it seems, under a modernist misapprehension. In this best of all possible, post-modern art worlds, all three attributes are cherished. By way of proof, the Grey Art Gallery at New York University, 33 Washington Place, has come up with ''Precious: An American Cottage Industry of the Eighties'' (through May 4). The show was organized by Thomas W. Sokolowski, the gallery's new director, and is the first under his aegis to be presented in New York.

title: CLABIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,128,000 for the quarter and the year on the retirement of debt. c-Net loss. Results include foreign currency losses of $786,000 for the latest quarter and $2,448,000 for the year, compared to $365,000 for the year-earlier quarter and $411,000 for the prior year.

title: SENATE, ASSAILING JAPAN, CALLS FOR IMPORT CURBS
description: The Senate today passed, 92 to 0, a resolution condemning Japan's ''unfair'' trading practices and calling on President Reagan to retaliate by curbing imports to reduce a $37 billion trade deficit.

title: PEKING EXPRESSES ITS THANKS
description: South Korea returned a torpedo boat and its surviving crew members to China today in a rendezvous on the Yellow Sea. South Korea took possession of the vessel after what it said had been a mutiny.

title: TRADE FIGHT WITH JAPAN
description: After years of protesting and posturing by the United States over the spread of Japanese goods in the American market and this nation's lack of access to the Japanese market, trade relations between the two countries appear to be at the boiling point. The Japanese announced today that they would let their automobile shipments to the United States grow 24.3 percent over the next year. They hoped that this step would defuse some of the acrimony over trade, since they were under no commitment to impose any limit whatsoever.

title: INTEREST RATES OFF SHARPLY
description: Interest rates declined sharply in all maturities yesterday as securities dealers and investors were encouraged by growing investor demand for the heavy supply of new Treasury notes and bonds, as well as recent statements by Federal Reserve officials suggesting that the Fed was not likely to encourage higher interest rates soon.

title: Bridge:New Team Event Is Created By Tournament Organizers
description: In 60 years of contract bridge, tournament organizers have thought up many types of contests and methods of scoring. All these may force a player to make slight modifications in technique, both in bidding and play.

title: NADLER DECLARES CANDIDACY FOR BOUROUGH PRESIDENT
description: Saying that he wants to give the voters a choice, Assemblyman Jerrold Nadler announced his candidacy yesterday for Manhattan borough president.

title: MEASLES OUTBREAK IN PUERTO RICO
description: An outbreak of measles in Puerto Rico has affected nearly 300 people, most of them young children, Federal health officials said today.

title: ADVERTISING ;   Ted Bates Clarifies Makeup of Its Board
description: As the result of reports about his agency in Adweek, a trade publication, that he felt reflected some organizational leaks from inside the board room, Robert E. Jacoby, president of Ted Bates Worldwide, informed his employees recently in a house memo that he would cut the board of directors to perhaps three or four members from its current 14.

title: Bechtel Petroleum

description: Everybody has been crying and acting sad, like the world is coming to an end. But I look at it like this: I'm 23 years old. I have a wife. I have money in the bank. And I have the rest of my life to live. It could have been a lot worse.''

A group of anti-MX lobbyists intercepted him outside the House Monday and gave him a red button reading ''Stop MX.''

Topics ;   Cool Heads, Warm Winds ;   Out Like a Lamb This has been a surprising March, a friend says, in that it's behaved exactly like March is supposed to behave. This hasn't been true of any month you can name for the last two years, which is why she kept looking for different - i.e. pleasant - weather. March, however, has not been accommodating. March has been mean. It came in like a lion. The winds have been high, and so have the clouds, and even on the few sunny days there was a bite in the air. The daffodils on the north side of our friend's street are looking good, but the ones on the south are still struggling through dirt. A forsythia bush outside her window has burst only a few buds, and as yet looks more naked than dressed.
description: When she left the office at night, she was forever hoping it'd be warm enough for the three-block walk and the 10-minute wait for a bus. But the cold sneaked up the sleeves of her coat and hit her stockinged legs, so she ran for the subway.

title: Henderson's Cast Off
description: The cast was removed from Rickey Henderson's sprained left ankle Thursday, but Henderson said he did not know whan he would be ready to play ''until I can run on it.'' Dr. Dan Kanell said Henderson could start playing in four or five days and ''for sure'' would be ready by opening day, April 8. . . . The Yankees defeated Montreal, 4-3, in 11 innings when Juan Bonilla singled home the tying run in the ninth and then singled home Billy Sample with the winner. Sample had tripled for his fourth hit. Bob Shirley pitched four hitless innings in relief.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Girl, 14, Dies of Cancer; Court Ordered Therapy
description: Pamela Hamilton, the young cancer victim whose parents lost a fight to prevent her from receiving medical treatment on religious grounds, died today, ''peacefully at her home in the company of her family,'' a doctor said.

title: Dealer Denies Financial Woes
description: Landmark Government Securities, a 12-year-old dealer in government securities, yesterday denied market rumors that it was in financial difficulty.

title: Dynamics' Hiring Questioned
description: An Assistant Secretary of the Navy was interviewed for employment by the General Dynamics Corporation for two months or more while he was in office, according to Navy and company documents.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Top Yield Set at 10 3/4% On Texas Utility Bonds
description: A $225 million issue of Austin, Tex., utility system revenue bonds was offered with a maximum yield of 10 3/4 percent for bonds due in 2010 and 2015 through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 7.50 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 10.20 percent in 2000.

title: ART: 'WORDS AND WORKS' FROM KURT SCHWITTERS
description: As a poet in collage, a maker of constructions, a pioneer of environmental pieces that were literally ''as big as a house,'' a maker of idiosyncratic books and magazines and a pioneer performance artist of hallucinatory stature, Kurt Schwitters has his place in all the history books. Not only did he do what he did better than almost anyone else, but he did it sooner. He made magic with the detritus of everyday life, he made a strange ecstatic music with wordless sounds, and he mixed and mated art with architecture in ways peculiar to himself. Activities of this sort have long been standard avant-garde practice, but it was Schwitters who raised them to a level of unpretentious poetry that has never been surpassed.

description: The Air Force announced today that it had suspended the General Electric Company from future Pentagon contracts because of the company's indictment earlier this week on charges that it falsified claims and lied to the Government about work on a nuclear warhead system.
