description: b-Net loss.

title: BEST PRODUCTS Co, Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: The year-ago quarter and year results were restated to reflect a change in the company's method of valuing its electronics inventory. There were 53 weeks in the latest year and 52 weeks in the prior year.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Curveball for Luzinski
description: Officials of the Burlington County Scholastic League in New Jersey, responding to the arrival of the former Chicago White Sox star,

title: SCOUTING ;   Standard Time
description: Coach Ray Perkins of Alabama expresses concern that the 2.0 grade- point minimum and higher entrance- exam requirements - recruiting standards due to take effect in 1986 - might shred the quality of play among longtime football powers: ''I'm all for academic standards, but I'm afraid we've gone too far.''

title: Jazzy Masked Ball
description: Tonight at 8:30, the Kitchen, 59 Wooster Street, at Broome Street, will present a masked ball with jazz dance music by the Henry Threadgill Orchestra, featuring Jean-Paul Bourelly on guitar. Tickets are $6; information, 925-3615.

title: RICHARDSON ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
THREE COLTS DOMINATE FLAMINGO FIELD
description: The Flamingo Stakes here Saturday matches Chief's Crown, Proud Truth and Stephan's Odyssey, three of the four early favorites for the Kentucky Derby on May 4. Although it is difficult to overlook each one's serious drawbacks, it is even harder to find anyone else in the field of eight remotely capable of scoring an upset.

title: It Is the Middle-Level Family Farm That Needs Federal Help
description: To the Editor:

title: President Is Resigning At General Instrument
description: C. Morris Chang, who was named president and chief operating officer at the General Instrument Corporation just over a year ago after a 25- year career at Texas Instruments Inc., said yesterday that he intended to resign, effective April 15.

title: Quake Felt in North Japan
description: A strong earthquake shook the northern Japanese islands of Honshu and Hokkaido early today, the Central Meteorological Agency reported. There were no immediate reports of damage or casualties. The quake had a preliminary reading of 6.8 on the Richter scale, with the epicenter in Akita Prefecture.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Arizona State Dean May Head F.D.I.C.
description: L. William Seidman, dean of Arizona State University's business school, and former economic aide to President Ford, has emerged as President Reagan's choice as the next chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, White House and Senate sources said yesterday.

title: Langer Given Fine For His Slow Play
description: Bernhard Langer stepped off the Tournament Players Club course today contending that he would protest a $500 fine for slow play on his last hole of the second round of the $900,000 Tournament Players Championship.

title: 2 MORE ARRESTS IN TULANE CASE
description: A convicted gambler and a sixth Tulane University student were arrested today in a scandal involving charges of point-shaving among members of the school basketball team.

title: MX DEBATE: IT'S NOT OVER
description: Behind the Reagan Administration's hard-won victory on the MX missile this week was mounting evidence of trouble for the Pentagon's military program. By framing the MX vote as a test of national resolve at the outset of arms control talks in Geneva, the Administration held at bay a number of forces that threaten not only the future production of the MX but other weapons as well. These forces include the pressures of the budget, partisan politics and skepticism about the Defense Department's military aims.

title: Evidence Against Nurse Is Lacking, Official Says
description: The police may have moved too quickly in arresting a nurse suspected in the mercy killing of an elderly patient, a prosecutor said today.

title: AGREEMENT NEAR IN MICHIGAN FISHING DISPUTE
description: Negotiators from nine groups have signed an agreement aimed at ending a 15-year legal dispute over Indian and sports fishing rights in part of the Great Lakes.

title: AIR CRASH REPORTED IN CANADA
description: Two Canadian C-130 Hercules transport planes collided in midair over the northern outskirts of Edmonton this evening and 10 crew members were presumed dead, a military spokesman said today.

title: PERUVIAN IS AWARDED RITZ PRIZE
description: Mario Vargas Llosa, the Peruvian writer, was awarded the Ritz Paris Hemingway Award for his epic historical novel ''The War of the End of the World'' at a ceremony today.

title: Youths Sentenced In Train Crash
description: Two Fair Lawn teen-agers were sentenced today to up to five years in a youth correctional facility for causing the fatal derailment of a passenger train in July 1982.

title: EGGS, SYMBOLS OF THE SEASON;LORE AND LEFTOVERS
description: The sculptor Constantin Brancusi called the egg ''the most perfect form of creation.'' Imbued with a certain mystery, it is associated with life, fertility and immortality. There are hundreds of superstitions and legends about the egg in every culture. According to one, the world was created when God took two halves of an egg and had one fertilize the other.

title: RAILROAD REGULATION
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission this week issued the first of two proposed agency rules that could restore some regulation of the railroad industry.

title: U.S. Banker Slain in London
description: A 39-year-old American banker was stabbed and killed Thursday night while resisting a mugger near Piccadilly Circus, the police said today. They identified the victim as John Sterling of Denver, a Citibank executive based in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, who was in London on a business trip.

title: KENNEDY AIDS RECALL HIS DEEDS AND DREAMS
description: For the last two days, white-haired former members of the Kennedy Administration have mingled with younger scholars on the campus of Hofstra University, affectionately recalling the youthful John F. Kennedy and the zest and style with which he touched the hearts of his countrymen.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   The Redman, er, Woman
description: Body of a man trapped inside head of a woman.

title: DR. EDWARD ROSEN, CITY U. PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Edward Rosen, one of the world's leading authorities on Copernicus and the origins of modern astronomy, died of congestive heart failure Thursday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 30, 1985 International

title: LEADER IN SACKS EAGER TO FACE GENERALS
description: Kit Lathrop is looking forward to playing against Doug Flutie and Herschel Walker of the Generals Saturday night. ''Two Heisman Trophy winners,'' Lathrop said today. ''How often do you get to do that?''

title: REAGAN ASKED TO SUPPORT PRESIDENTIAL LIBRARY BILL
description: President Reagan, a proponent of voluntary giving, has so far passed up an opportunity to let his supporters assume some of the Government cost of operating a future Reagan Presidential library.

title: Salt Lake City Mayor To Take College Post
description: Mayor Ted L. Wilson of Salt Lake City said Wednesday that he would resign July 1 to take a college post before considering any elective office again.

title: GAFF LIKELY TO GO ON DISABLED LIST
description: The focal point of the Mets' spring training camp has been pitching, so much so that even during a morning batting practice it is the pitcher who draws considerable attention. This time, it was Brent Gaff, and it is beginning to appear that the relief pitcher might open the season on the disabled list.

title: Manson Group Member Refuses to Leave Prison
description: Sandra Good, a member of the Charles Manson group who served 10 years for mailing death threats to businessmen, refused to leave prison today because she would be prohibited from associating with Mr. Manson or his other followers, officials said.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
RESORTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from the sale of equity securities and metals transactions of $24,552,000. c-Net income after losses from securities transactions of $1,747,000 for the quarter and $10,525,000 for the year. d-Includes losses from securities transactions and metals of $23,947,000.

title: Dance:Bits and Pieces by the Bucket Theater
description: Garth Fagan can fashion bright bits and peices of movement. Judging from the program that his Bucket Dance Theater of Rochester presented Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street), he enjoys doing so. And he has dancers who can make his movments shine with special brilliance.

title: PATENTS ;   SWEEPING MINES AT HIGH SPEED
description: WASHINGTON

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Redmen and Green Men
description: On the night of another recent St. John's game, a number of Philip Morris employees were at the New York State Theater, being treated to the Joffrey Ballet's performance of ''Romeo and Juliet.''

title: CITY INVESTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $557,000,000 for the quarter and the year on sales of subsidiaries in connection with the liquidation plan adopted by stockholders in December 1984.

title: ARGENTINA'S 'FUNNY DIRTY LITTLE WAR'
description: After the 1955 coup that ended his 11-year dictatorship, former President Juan Peron of Argentina settled in Spain, leaving behind him economic and emotional chaos, runaway inflation and a number of public works, including a huge international airport that, even at occasional rush hours, looked unused.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Dream Deal Deflated
description: Trade

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Double-Check
description: It was one of those tips that seemed to check out - that the University of Arizona had purchased basketball uniforms from a company that had engaged the school's basketball coach,

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on Thursday with an article about a photograph of Abraham Lincoln auctioned at Sotheby's misidentified the photographer. He was Anthony Berger.

title: STANLEY L. STEVENS
description: Stanley L'Arminie Stevens, former president of Stevens Associates, a real- estate and public-relations concern in Garden City, L.I., died Tuesday at Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L.I., after suffering a heart attack at his home in Garden City.

title: SHULTZ SAID TO SUMMON RUSSIAN ON SHOOTING
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has summoned the Soviet Ambassador, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, for a meeting Saturday to discuss the shooting of an American military liaison officer in East Germany, Administration sources said tonight.

title: REAGAN EXPECTED TO WARN JAPANESE ON BARS TO TRADE
description: President Reagan plans to tell Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone that unless Japan opens its markets to American goods he will be unable to prevent Congress from enacting retaliatory protectionist legislation, according to a senior White House official.

title: HERO, JUSTICE, PRESIDENT: CHRISTOS SARTZETAKIS
description: Even before Christos Sartzetakis was elected President of Greece yesterday, some movie theaters in Athens had adorned their facades with posters reminding people that he was a real-life hero of the movie ''Z.'' Justice Sartzetakis, a 56-year-old Supreme Court member with an apolitical background, established a reputation for courage as a young prosecutor by cutting through an official coverup to prove that the killing of a leftist legislator at a disarmament rally in 1963 had been deliberate. Costa-Gavras's award-winning 1970 film was closely based on the episode.

title: Energy Secretary Reaffirms Pledge
description: The Federal Energy Secretary has denied in a letter to a House subcommittee chairman that his agency was seeking to impose an emergency plan at the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: BIONDI, JAEGER BETTER OLYMPIANS' MARKS
description: Matt Biondi is a University of California sophomore from Moraga, Calif. Tom Jager is a U.C.L.A. junior from Collinsville, Ill. They are two of the brightest stars in the new generation of American swimmers, as they have proved the last two days in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's men's championships.

title: MONTANA MISSILE SITES GATHERING NEW INTEREST
description: Next to Ed Butcher's barn are a dozen cylindrical metal silos holding grain he will feed his cattle and ship to market.

title: VILLANOVA CALLED 'HOT'
description: Teams reach the Final Four for more reasons than simply being talented. Timing, luck and emotion can make just as much difference as 1-3-1 zones and offensive execution, especially amid the pressures of a three-week single-elimination tournament.

title: A CASE OF MEMORANDUMS AT 10 PACES
description: Ever since he assumed the chairmanship of the Consumer Product Safety Commission earlier this year, Terrence M. Scanlon has tried to steer it away from what he considers a confrontational stance with industry, seeking voluntary agreements instead of commission orders and recalls.

title: OHIO DEPOSITORS LOOKING TO CITICORP
description: New York's giant Citicorp has come to represent the hope of thousands of Ohio depositors in the bankrupt Home State Savings Bank. They have been encouraged to believe that Citicorp, with its $150 billion in assets and its determination to be in every financial market throughout the country, will enable them to get their money back - $668 million - by buying the failed Cincinnati-based savings and loan association. Home State ran into trouble because of its dealings with the failed E.S.M. Government Securities Inc.

title: Jackson's New Campaign
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson is engaged in a project these days

title: BUSINESS NEWS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 30, 1985

title: SCOUTING ;   Priorities Set
description: As his No. 1 ranking on the PGA Tour's money list suggests, Curtis Strange has not missed much of anything this year, be it fairways or greens, putts or cuts. But he stands a pretty good chance of missing one of the most cherished prizes in sports: the Masters.

title: CONSUMERS UNION TOASTS BEING IN THE BLACK
description: After more than three years of budget cutting and nail biting, Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports magazine, is in the black once again.

title: Phone Rule an Issue
description: A Government order changing the way local telephone companies calculate charges to long-distance companies for completing calls signals a further retreat from economic protection of companies competing with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, regulatory analysts say. The Federal Communications Commission voted Thursday to replace the flat-rate method for charging A.T.&T.'s competitors for call completion with a usage-based method, the same method applied to A.T.&T.

title: DOME MINES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results include losses of $55,697 in the latest year and $290,947,000 in the previous year attributable to the company's holding in Dome Petroleum Ltd.

title: MYERS, L.E. COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: STRENGTH OF DOLLAR CUTS FOREIGN BUYING IN CITY
description: New York City merchants say the strong dollar is taking its toll on business, leading foreigners to curb their spending on everything from real estate to restaurant meals.

title: 4% Drop Against Mark
description: The dollar's fall against the mark today culminated a week in which it has lost almost 4 percent of its value against the West German currency.

title: Rainfall Low in Jersey
description: Rainfall in North Jersey since Aug. 1 has been at an all-time low, according to state officials who today asked people there to conserve water in preparation for a possible emergency.

title: SPENDING IS FOCUS OF ALBANY TALKS
description: After agreeing on deep cuts in state income taxes and auto registration fees, Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders turned today to negotiations over spending.

title: ALAN M. STROOCK, 77, LAWYER AND JEWISH LEADER, IS DEAD
description: Alan M. Stroock, a retired senior partner in the New York law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan and a longtime leader in Jewish affairs, died Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 77 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: SCOUTING ;   Young Player Gets Pro Advice
description: Ken Hodge, the former Bruin and Ranger wing, is now executive state director of the Special Olympics in Massachusetts, but he still finds time to get to the rink occasionally. The rink he's most interested in these days is the one at Boston College.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BARS 29 GROUPS OF FOES FROM ANY MEETING
description: The South African authorities, facing a crisis of unrest in the country's black townships, today outlawed meetings by a major nonparliamentary opposition group and 28 other organizations.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Comings and Goings
description: Bill Watson , the Minnesota-Duluth junior who has led the Western Collegiate Hockey Association in scoring for two seasons, received the fifth annual Hobey Baker award as the outstanding college player. . . .

title: Freeze on Benefits Analyzed
description: A Freeze on Social Security cost-of-living adjustments would save $33.8 billion over five years but push about 400,000 people below the poverty line, according to a Congressional Budget Office study released Thursday.

title: Bid for Mohasco
description: The Mohasco Corporation, a maker and distributor of furniture and carpets, said Columbia Enterprises Inc., a Miami investment company that holds 9.4 percent of its stock, had offered to buy the remaining shares of the company for $32 a share, or about $197.1 million. The investment group, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said it would consider other options for gaining control of the company if Mohasco rejected the offer.

title: DEVELOPMENT CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $3,956,000 for the quarter and $5,988,000 for the year. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,916,000 for the quarter and $4,615,000 for the year. d-Net income.

title: BRIDGE: FREDDIE NORTH'S NEW BOOK BRINGS BACK 'AUNT AGATHA'
description: There is one British expert who has a remarkable distinction: his surname appears in every bridge column published anywhere. The expert, Freddie North, who once had to decline an invitation to represent his country in the European Championship, is an entertaining author.

title: AN ETERNAL HELLO TO ARMS
description: In Geneva we have these talks. They

title: Folk Singers Performing
description: Leon Bibb and Pete Singer, two veteran folk singers infrequently heard in New York City these days, will perform in a musical program at Symphony Space today.

title: CLEANUP PROPOSED FOR 26 WASTE SITES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed adding 26 sites to its ''national priority list'' of waste dumps eligible to receive money for long-term cleanup under the toxic waste law.

title: WOMAN RECANTS A RAPE CHARGE SIX YEARS LATER
description: A New Hampshire woman who said this week that she had falsely accused a man of rape, sending him to prison for six years, says she decided to tell the truth because of her religion.

title: Auto Union Nearing Accord
description: The United Automobile Workers has tentatively agreed on the major issues that would complete a split between its American and Canadian branches, Owen Bieber, president of the union, said Thursday. Details of the agreement were worked out at a meeting in Chicago. Bob White, the union's Canadian director, announced last December that he wanted to form a separate Canadian union because the international union interfered in a 13-day strike against General Motors of Canada last year.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about real estate lawyers misidentified a partner at Cahill Gordon & Reindel. He is Lawrence A. Kobrin.

title: TOP-RATED AT 15, GIRL CHALLENGES CHESS WORLD
description: At the age of 4 she came across a chess book and asked her father what it was. He explained, set up a chessboard and showed her the moves. A few months later she played in the Under-11 Championship in Budapest and won every game.

title: CONCERT: RICCI PLAYS BACH
description: Although Ruggiero Ricci shared his all-Bach concert Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall with the oboist Harry Sargous and the University of Michigan Chamber Strings, he was at his best when standing alone on the stage, violin in hand, playing the celebrated solo Chaconne from the Partita No. 2 in D minor (BWV 1004). It was a fine performance; Mr. Ricci tempered the music's natural austerity with a lyrical sweetness.

title: Minutes Point to Steady Fed Course
description: The Federal Reserve disclosed today that some members of its Open Market Committee thought last month that a ''firming'' of policy might be needed to restrain monetary expansion.

title: Lawyers and the Mob
description: Is every lawyer for an accused mobster a ''mob lawyer''? Not necessarily. Some lawyers do serve as decoys or accomplices in crime, showing up swiftly at police headquarters to represent any mob underling, on a retainer that finds them sharing in the gang's profits. Some are also routinely available to launder money, coach perjury or lend their offices as sanctuaries for the planning of criminal acts.

title: FOR EGYPT, THE SPRING OF DISCONTENT
description: The Cairo flower hawkers have returned to the bustling city streets. The capital's gray, polluted winter sky is temporarily blue, fresh and clear. The chilly winds off the Nile have turned balmy. But not even spring can lift Egypt's gloom. The national and opposition press have been filled with grim news. The depression is reflected in press commentaries deploring the results of President Hosni Mubarak's trip to Washington earlier this month.

title: SOVIET COUPLE LOSE COURT RULING
description: A Federal district judge today ruled against a request to exclude what defense lawyers termed ''prejudicial'' evidence from the trial of a Russian emigre couple accused of being Soviet spies.

title: SOUTH LEBANON BATTLES WIDEN
description: Ten days of clashes between Christian and Moslem forces around Sidon in southern Lebanon widened today to involve Palestinians in two refugee camps in that area.

title: ACID RAIN STARTING TO AFFECT ENVIRONMENT AND POLITICS IN WEST
description: Acid rain, a pollution problem usually associated with the forests and lakes of the Northeast and Canada, is emerging as a serious environmental and political issue in the Rocky Mountain states as well.

title: Oilers Lose; Kurri Out HARTFORD, March 29 (UPI) - The Edmonton Oilers, playing
description: without Jarri Kurri, the league's leading goal-scorer, were beaten tonight by the streaking Hartford Whalers, 8-7. Kurri, who has scored 70 goals, suffered a broken left hand during

title: Opinions Split on Flamingo
description: The trainers of the three Kentucky Derby favorites who will clash in the Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah Park Saturday agree on one thing: Proud Truth will be favored in the betting over Chief's Crown and Stephan's Odyssey. Other than that, their perceptions of the three colts are a round- robin of contradictions.

title: ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $23.1 million and a loss on disposal of operations of $51.6 million. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $17 million, a loss on disposal of operations of $1.9 million and an extraordinary gain of $3.4 million. d-After a loss of $77.1 million from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $1.6 million. e-Net income after a loss of $22.1 million from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $6.9 million. Revenue figures represent operating revenue.

title: BACK IN THE A.B.A.
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.

title: Books of The Times;   Geometry of Emotions
description: MUSEUM PIECES. By Elizabeth Tallent.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13.

title: Multimedia Theater At Church of St. Ann
description: Candles and electric lights, projections and recorded sounds, videotapes, films, and musicians will fill the historic Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights tonight at 8 o'clock. It's all part of ''Journey Through Sacred Time,'' a multimedia theater piece by Manuel Lutgenhorst and Somei Satoh.

title: 8 GUILTY IN RIGGING OF SLOT MACHINES
description: Eight people have been convicted in a cheating ring involving slot machine that prosecutors say rigged $1.6 million in jackpots in Nevada and New Jersey and was the largest of its kind ever uncovered.

title: YOUR COAT, SIR?
description: At the end of each Congressional work week, Representative Guy V. Molinari, Republican of Staten Island, boards a New York Air flight to Newark.

title: R.P.I. GAINS FINAL IN 3D OVERTIME, 6-5
description: John Carter scored on a power play with 4 minutes 15 seconds left in the third overtime tonight as Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute beat Minnesota-Duluth, 6-5, in a hard-fought, tight- checking National Collegiate Athletic Association semifinal game.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
BRIEFING ;   A Job Offer
description: Albert R. (Rusty) Brashear, most recently press secretary to William P. Clark, when he was Secretary of the Interior, has been offered the position of deputy White House press secretary. Mr. Brashear was interviewed yesterday by Patrick J. Buchanan, the White House communications director.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Storer Ruling
description: The Federal Communications Commission turned aside a request by Storer Communications Inc. that a dissident shareholder group's proxy fight be subjected to a full review because Storer owns seven television stations. The F.C.C. accepted the investor group's contention that control of the company rests with the shareholders and that a change in the membership of the board would not constitute a transfer of control of the TV stations. The investor group has said it would try to replace Storer's directors at the May 7 annual meeting and then liquidate the company.

title: HONDURAS CRISIS DEEPENS AS PRESIDENT ACCUSES DEFIANT CONGRESS OF 'TECHNICAL COUP'
description: A growing political crisis took a new turn today, with the Honduran Congress moving to defy President Roberto Suazo Cordova.

title: KOCH STUDIES A BAN ON SALE OF STRIPED BASS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday asked the city's Health Commissioner to determine whether striped bass are so contaminated with PCB's that sale of the fish should be banned in New York City.

title: Davis Oil Deal
description: The Apache Corporation said it would will pay $180 million for the Davis Oil Company's holdings in eight states. Davis Oil is owned by Marvin Davis, part-owner of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation. Apache plans to buy 390 of Davis's oil and gas wells in Colorado, Wyoming, New Mexico, Louisiana, Texas, Oklahoma, North Dakota and Utah.

title: Hughes Contracts
description: The Army awarded Hughes Helicopters Inc. a total of $686.9 million in four contracts for production of AH-64 attack helicopters, plus another $3.1 million for AH-64 spare parts, the Defense Department said.

title: REAGAN PRESSES CALL FOR ANTIMISSILE PLAN BEFORE SPACE GROUP
description: President Reagan today renewed his call for research on a space-based defense against nuclear missiles, invoking a line from the film ''Star Wars'' to rebut critics of the proposal.

title: SCOUTING ;   Slow Progress
description: Conversations continue between Commissioner Pete Rozelle and Al Davis in an effort to strike an out-of- court agreement on how much the National Football League must pay the Raiders and the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum in antitrust damages. But neither side seems particularly optimistic.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Billy Smith Fined $500
description: Billy Smith , the Islander goaltender who accused a referee of being ''out to get'' him, has been fined $500 for challenging the integrity of a National Hockey League official. Smith was cited for a remark he made about Referee

title: HOUSE PANEL TO STUDT 7 MILITARY CONTRACTORS
description: The House Armed Services Committee said today that it would audit seven arms producers as part of an investigation of Pentagon contracting.

title: Roasting a Cuomo
description: Governor Cuomo of New York is a subject of keen interest among Washington politicians who regard him, despite his protestations, as a potential Democratic Presidential candidate in 1988. Some party professionals were disappointed that he declined an invitation to the Gridiron Club dinner in Washington last weekend, but he has agreed to participate in a Washington fund-raising event for Independent Action, the political action committee operated by Representative Morris K. Udall, Democrat of Arizona.

title: Eusebio Mujal, Labor Leader From Cuba and a Castro Foe
description: Eusebio Mujal, an anti-Communist Cuban labor leader who fled to the United States within a month after the 1959 revolution, has died at his home in Washington his family said today. He was 69 years old.

title: Consumers Power Is Denied Rate Rise
description: A sharply critical State Public Service Commission denied an immediate rate increase today for the financially ailing Consumers Power Company, and listed demands the utility must meet to get a $99 million- a-year rate increase later.

title: TOURISTS DESCEND ON A CENTER OF THE AVANT-GARDE
description: ''Mildred!'' Minna Kirzenbaum yelled to a companion on the Avant- Garde Art Tour of the East Village, ''

title: Of Offers and Officers
description: To the Editor:

title: SPANIARDS HAIL ENTRY INTO THE MARKET
description: The news that Spain had come to terms on joining the Common Market was joyously greeted at almost all levels of Spanish society today.

title: Tuition at Cornell To Increase 9.4%
description: The trustees of Cornell University voted today to raise undergraduate tuition for its private colleges 9.4 percent, to $10,500, for the 1985-1986 year.

title: Landmark Rulings on the 'Right to Die'
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Fund the 'Contras'
description: It must be clear to everyone that the confrontation between the Reagan Administration and the Sandinista Government has neared a breaking point. Both the Sandinistas and Americn policy makers seem unwavering in their determination to survive each other. Only Congress can defuse this time bomb.

title: LEXINGTON TOURNAMENT: MORE THAN BASKETBALL
description: They have been doing funny things with basketballs here this week: dipping them in tempera paint, throwing them against canvas-covered backboards and selling the result as art.

title: Unocal Refuses To Shift Meeting
description: The Unocal Corporation said it would not postpone its annual meeting, rejecting a request for a delay by a group led by T. Boone Pickens. Meanwhile, Mr. Pickens's group, Mesa Partners II of Amarillo, Tex., announced that it had filed preliminary materials with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington for a proxy fight on the issue.

title: LAWE SEEKING TO EXTEND SUBWAY CONTRACT BRIEFLY
description: The leader of the city's bus and subway workers said yesterday that he wanted to extend his union's contract two or three days beyond its expiration at midnight tomorrow.

title: Reagan Profanity Asserted
description: President Reagan became ''angry and profane'' at Representative Bill Alexander, Democrat of Arkansas, when he telephoned the Congressman this week to seek support for the MX missile, a Congressional aide said today. The aide, Steven Skardon, said Mr. Reagan got angry when Mr. Alexander told him he should instead propose a balanced budget. Mr. Skardon quoted the Congressman as saying Mr. Reagan ''got angry and started cussing me,'' but did not disclose what words the President used other than to say they were ''angry and profane.'' A Reagan aide called the conversation ''confidential.''

title: Britons in Iraqi Capital Are Warned on Safety
description: British nationals were advised by their Government today to move out of central Baghdad because of the danger of explosions, embassy officials said.

title: No Headline
Duarte Vows to Resume Peace Talks With Rebels
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte said today that he would resume peace talks with leftist rebels regardless of the outcome of elections on Sunday.

title: BROCK HOTEL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,376,000 for the latest year and $242,000 for the prior year. c-Net income. Latest year loss includes $26,632,000 in writedowns, writeoffs and losses relating to dispositions and closings of Showbiz Pizza Place restaurants.

title: KNAPP BID ON THRIFT UNIT LOANS
description: An investment group headed by Charles W. Knapp, former head of the troubled Financial Corporation of America, said today that it was seeking to buy all the troubled loans and foreclosed property of Financial's American Savings and Loan Association.

title: CITY EXPANDING ITS PLAN TO HELP VICTIMS OF AIDS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday announced plans to expand services for New York City residents suffering from AIDS, and denounced those who have said his administration had not done enough for victims of the illness.

title: Poland's Leader Threatens a Crackdown
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, threatened a crackdown today on dissidents and supporters of the banned Solidarity union if they continue to oppose the country's Communist system.

title: Ecusta Buyout
description: The Olin Corporation, an industrial chemical concern based in Stamford, Conn., said that Morgan Lewis Githens & Ahn Inc., its investment banker, had agreed to organize a leveraged buyout of Olin's Ecusta cigarette paper and fine printing paper business. Previously, the First Boston Corporation had been selected to organize the acquisition. Olin said it and First Boston ''couldn't reach an agreement on terms.''

title: Reagan Errs on the Holocaust
description: President Reagan apparently believes that all Germans alive today are under 60 years old. According to him, ''very few'' Germans today even remember, let alone took part in, the Second World War, and none of them ''were adults and participating in any way'' in the events of 40 years ago.

title: U.C.L.A. WINS FINAL OF N.I.T.
description: U.C.L.A., ending Walt Hazzard's first year as coach on a high note, captured its first National Invitation Tournament title last night with a 65- 62 victory over Indiana before a crowd of 12,454 at Madison Square Garden.

title: TV:'THE FOURTH WISE MAN' ON ABC
description: With Passover and Easter arriving next week, television is scheduling a number of related specials. The biggest and most impressive is ''A.D.,'' a 12-hour mini-series that runs for five consecutive nights on NBC, beginning tomorrow at 8 o'clock. Among the smaller and more charming offerings is the hourlong ''Fourth Wise Man'' on ABC this evening at 8.

title: Cox Will Not Investigate Rhode Island Chief Judge
description: Archibald Cox, the former Watergate special prosecutor, has refused a request from a judicial ethics panel to investigate the Rhode Island Chief Justice's associations with reputed organized crime figures, the panel chairman, Judge Joseph F. Rodgers Jr. of Superior Court, said today.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46

title: PATENTS ;   Inducing Reproduction Of Injured Tissue Cells
description: In an effort to harness the inherent healing power of the human body, Leonard J. Bonnell, a mechanical engineer in Harrington Valley, Pa., has patented a method to electronically stimulate the reproduction of damaged tissue cells without surgery.

title: 'What Have I Done' Depicts A Funny, Unfamiliar Spain
description: ''What Have I done to Deserve This?'' is an absolutely wonderful black comedy about a Spain few foreigners ever see - and, for that matter, not all Spaniards, since over the last five years or so Spanish mores have been changing at a dizzying speed.

title: Von B"ulow's Stepson Denies Knowing Potential Witness
description: Alexander von Auersperg, a stepson of Claus von B"ulow, denied yesterday that he was a friend of David Marriott, a potential witness in the retrial of Mr. von B"ulow in Providence, R.I.

title: FIRST-TIME STARTER HELPS DEFEAT NETS
description: In 26 games, Charles Jones has gone from a player who signed two 10-day contracts with the Washington Bullets as a replacement for the injured Jeff Ruland to one who made a significant contribution tonight in his first start in the league.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Delta State Shifts
description: Delta State will switch its long-successful women's basketball team from Division I to Division II and compete in the Gulf South Conference.

title: THE I.R.S. IMAGE PROBLEM
description: A couple of weeks ago, I wrote a

title: DID NICARAGUA SAY WHAT U.S. SAYS IT SAID?
description: In a speech last year, President Reagan discounted the Nicaraguan Government's explanations for its military buildup.

title: WHERE THE BUILDINGS GONE?
description: I lost the Chrysler Building a few weeks ago.

title: 14 Children Die in Ghana
description: Fourteen children were killed Thursday when they fell down a 300-foot unused well in a school playground, the Ghana News Agency reported today.

title: 'WAR MACHINE' OR DEFENDER OF A BESIEGED NATION?
description: The threat that Nicaragua's Army may pose to other Central American countries has become a central issue in the debate over renewed United States financing for the rebels fighting to topple the Government.

title: No Headline
description: Trimmed its roster to 31 players, sending Charlie Mitchell, Tommy McCarthy, and Robin Fuson, pitchers; Dave Malpeso, catcher; Sam Horn, first baseman, and Gus Burgess, Mike Greenwell and Kevin Romine, outfielders, to the minor leagues.CALIFORNIA (AL) - Sent Stu Cliburn, Tony Mack, Kirk McCaskill, and D. W. Smith, pitchers; Steve Liddle, catcher; Devon White, outfielder, and Mark McLemore and Norm Corrasco, infielders, to the minor leagues.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Montreal Expos , exhibition game, at St. Petersburg, Fla., 7:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.)

title: REGULATORY FAILURE ON E.S.M.
description: Steven Bisker, assistant general counsel of the National Credit Union Administration, received two visitors one day last June at his Washington office: George Mead, a senior officer of E.S.M. Government Securities Inc., and Ronald Pellerito, an E.S.M. salesman. The two were promoting what they promised would be a ''riskless'' investment designed to add two or three extra percentage points of income on securities portfolios.

title: Use the Schools for Preschoolers
description: Should the mostly half-day pre-kindergarten programs in New York's public schools be expanded? State officials say yes, but some day-care organizations are raising questions. Their doubts deserve consideration but they should not be allowed to kill the effort.

title: CBS PROXY FIGHT OFF FOR NOW
description: Fairness in Media, the conservative group linked to Senator Jesse Helms that has said it wants to gain financial control of CBS, dropped plans yesterday to conduct a proxy fight or take any other action at the CBS shareholders meeting on April 17.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Dedication. Concentration. Imagination. Meaning.'' - Susan Polgar, 15 years old, the highest- rated female chess player in the world, on what makes a great chess player. (27:2.)

title: OLD DOMINION GAINS FINAL WITH GEORGIA
description: A reserve guard, Bridget Jenkins, scored a career-high 18 points tonight to offset cold shooting by her teammates and help carry Old Dominion to a 57-47 victory over Northeast Louisiana and into the final of the N.C.A.A. women's basketball tournament.

title: TURNER'S MATURITY BOOSTS CONFIDENCE
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.

title: READING, PA., TESTING ALTERNATIVE TO FEDERAL FOOD STAMP PROGRAM
description: In this blue-collar town the Agriculture Department is conducting a high-technology experiment designed to cut costs and combat fraud in the $12 billion-a-year Federal food stamp program.

title: The News, Briefly
description: The White House News Summary is normally just that: a

title: Argentine Reforms
description: In an effort to curb an 800-percent inflation rate, Argentine Economy Minister Juan Sourrouille today announced financial reforms aimed at eliminating black markets for credit and currency exchange. He also announced increases of 26 percent in public tariffs, 35 percent in gasoline prices and 2 percent in lending rates. He said that next week he would announce the details of an anti- inflation program designed to placate the International Monetary Fund.

title: Officer in Jersey Is Shot in the Back
description: A police officer was shot in the back and seriously wounded tonight in this Passaic County community after interrupting a robbery of a gas station, the police said.

title: AIR CANADA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a special tax credit of $19,500,000. Results include gains on the sale of assets of $31,300,000 million for the latest year and $18,500,000 for the prior year.

title: Try Goetz in Court
description: To the Editor:

title: NICHLOS OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of $8.7 million on drilling equipment and a writeoff of $1.2 million for the abandonment of certain leasehold costs for the quarter and year.

title: Don't Break New York's Bottle Deal
description: New York has had 18 months of experience with its returnable-container law to keep soda and beer bottles and cans from littering highways and streets. A visibly cleaner state and measurable reduction in the volume of trash testify to the law's success - a success that Governor Cuomo envies and would now jeopardize.

title: GREEK PARLIAMENT PICKS PRESIDENT IN CLOSE VOTE
description: The candidate of the governing Socialist Party was narrowly elected President of Greece today in a special session of Parliament.

title: SALES OF NEW HOMES JUMP BY 6.2%
description: Sales of new single-family homes rose 6.2 percent in February, the biggest increase in five months, the Government reported today.

title: Condemned Murderer Is Married in Prison
description: James D. Briley, who has been sentenced to die April 18 for two murders, was married Thursday in a ceremony at his cell.

title: Derailed Train Catches Fire
description: Three cars of a freight train carrying flammable liquid derailed today at 11:45 A.M. and burst into flames, forcing 2,000 people to be evacuated from their homes.

title: Letter: On Tax Reform;   Charity Deductions Aren't Subsidies
description: To the Editor:

title: Development Benefits
description: Downtown Stamford

title: SETS SIGHTS ON THE FINAL
description: Chris Mullin's college basketball career has come down to this: a 40- minute duel Saturday to determine whether that career will end or will continue for one last run in the national championship game.

title: POLICE SEARCH L.I. ESTATE FOR BODIES
description: Authorities searching for human remains dug at the Long Island home of a New York City art dealer yesterday, but they found no bodies or other evidence in a spreading investigation of the murder of a Norwegian fashion student in Rockland County last month.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A RENOIR Jean Renoir, the French movie maker, must have inherited some of the flair for color that his father, Pierre Auguste Renoir, brought to Impressionist art. This would seem the case, at least, with the director's 1955 film ''French-Cancan.'' The film, with 15 minutes that was excised when it was first released now restored, has just started a run at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, near Astor Place.

title: Studio Ringl and Pit
description: Prints by the avant-garde German photographers Grete Stern and Ellen Auerbach, known professionally as Studio Ringl and Pit, will be on view through April 27 at Goethe House, 1014 Fifth Avenue, at 82nd Street.

title: GIVING UP CIGARETTES IS GOOD FOR YOUR HEALTH
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITE SUPREMACIST SENTENCED TO SERVE 25 YEARS IN PRISON
description: Gary Lee Yarbrough, a white supremacist described as a chief lieutenant for a violent neo-Nazi group, was sentenced Friday to 25 years in prison on 11 Federal convictions.

title: Bombing in Paris Leaves 20 Wounded
description: About 20 people were wounded tonight when a bomb exploded in a central Paris theater showing Jewish films, the police said.

title: Bond and Note Prices Are Up
description: Treasury note and bond prices continued to rise yesterday, as improved investor demand was buttressed by purchases of speculators.

title: Arms Negotiator Named
description: President Reagan nominated Robert Blackwill, a career Foreign Service officer, today as the American representative at negotiations in Vienna on reducing nonnuclear forces in Central Europe. If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Blackwill will succeed Maynard Glitman, who is negotiating at the American- Soviet talks in Geneva on medium- range missile forces.

title: Minsk Party Chief Replaced
description: The Minsk region's Communist Party leader, Vladimir A. Mikulich, has been removed from office, the official Soviet press agency Tass said today. It said Mr. Mikulich, 64 years old, would be replaced by Anatoly A. Malofeyev.

title: SAMPLE IMPRESSING YANKEES
description: When George Steinbrenner remarked earlier in the week that Billy Sample, following his performance against the Mets, ''takes a lead in that race,'' nobody, least of all Sample, knew for sure what race the Yankee owner was talking about.

title: SPONGES FOR BIRTH CONTROL:A WARNING
description: USERS of contraceptive sponges received a warning this week from New York's Attorney General: Despite what advertisments may have implied, the sponge is not so effective in preventing pregnancy as the birth control pill.

title: No Liquidation For Datapoint SAN ANTONIO, March
description: 29 (AP) - The new chairman

title: U.S. Aides Monitor Crisis
description: United States diplomats say they are standing on the sidelines, watching Honduras's democratic Government resolve its ''constitutional crises,'' a State Department official said today.

title: Giving Up Cigarettes Is Good for Your Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Close Strongly; Dow Up 6.07, to 1,266.78
description: Stock prices rose yesterday on Wall Street in moderately heavy trading, as big investors rearranged portfolios at the end of the quarter and smaller investors chased takeover rumors.

title: COMPANY WANTS MORE POOR TO PAY TELEPHONE DEPOSITS
description: A new rule waiving the deposit requirement for low-income telephone customers is causing problems for the New York Telephone Company, a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: Reagan's Eye Is Discolored
description: President Reagan has suffered a burst blood vessel in his left eye, causing it to partly fill with blood and appear noticeably red. The White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, said, ''There's no pain, it doesn't affect his vision and there's no treatment.'' Mr. Speakes said the President first noticed the condition when he awoke Thursday. By Friday, there was a bright redness. Mr. Speakes said the condition had occurred two or three times before in the Reagan Presidency.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article and accompanying box on Easter music in Weekend yesterday listed an incorrect date for a performance of Scarlatti's ''Stabat Mater'' and Heinrich Sch"utz's ''St. Matthew Passion'' at Grace Church, Broadway at 10th Street. The performance will be at 8 P.M. Tuesday.

title: LEADING INDICATORS UP BY 0.7%
description: The Government's main economic forecasting gauge rose seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, less than half the January increase, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CLOSED-END FUNDS' PRICING
description: -END FUNDS are an alternative to the better-known mutual funds, or open-end funds, for individual investors seeking diversification, marketability and professional management. The timing of purchases is a key element in deciding whether to invest in closed-end funds.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Trouble in Birmingham
description: Marvin Warner , the principal owner of the Birmingham Stallions, is having financial problems and has put his interest up for sale, but, according to the club's president,

title: CONTROL DATA'S WOES
description: The Control Data Corporation, hurt by the banking troubles in Ohio and weakness in its peripherals business, said yesterday that it would report ''lower than expected earnings for 1985.'' It did not say how much lower.

title: PATENTS ;   Boeing Has New Plan For Placing Jet Engines
description: The Boeing Company of Seattle has patented a design for the installation of jet engines that it hopes will solve some of the problems posed by the need for fuel efficiency.

title: Texaco Raises Oil Price
description: Texaco USA yesterday raised the price it will pay for West Texas Intermediate and West texas sour - the nation's benchmark crude oils - by 50 cents, to $27.50 a barrel. Earlier this week Conoco Inc., another large American refiner, lifted its buying price for the key crudes by 90 cents, to $27.65 a barrel. Analysts said the Texaco and Conoco moves signaled a strengthening in domestic oil prices.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   A Mall for Manhattan
description: It was a classic New York opening - champagne for 500 guests, superlative-laced speeches, Mayor Koch cutting a golden ribbon with golden scissors.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   First Boat of Spring
description: At 10:30 A.M. yesterday, the urban equivalent of the robin - the Circle Line boat - slipped out of its berth on the Hudson River and made its first trip of the season around Manhattan.

title: COMMON MARKET DISCUSSING GREEK VETO THREAT
description: Western European leaders of the Common Market began crucial negotiations here Friday night with Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece, who has threatened to veto the entry of Spain and Portugal into the market next year.

title: PRICES PAID FARMERS DOWN 0.7%
description: After holding steady for most of the winter, prices that farmers get for raw products dropped by seven- tenths of 1 percent in March, the Agriculture Department said today. Prices averaged 7.6 percent below the levels of a year earlier.

title: Castle & Cooke
description: Castle & Cooke Inc. said it entered into an agreement to restucture about $260 million of its debt to certain of its lenders. As a result, the company said it is now able to pay interest and principal, including $7 million of interest on its public subordinated indebtedness.

title: JAPANESE CONCERNED
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone was questioned today by Japanese politicians at a session of Parliament about how Japan would respond to American criticism of its import policies and said, ''We hope to reach a mutual understanding of our differences.''

title: Austria Welcomed Hitler, and Its Anti-Semitism Persists
description: To the Editor:

title: 800 SEARCH OUT SUMMER HOUSEMATES
description: The trouble is, Pat DeJohn was saying above the hubbub of some 800 voices on Wednesday night, that while women make up their minds early enough, men often wait until June to decide, which is certainly a problem when you're renting shares in a summer beach house and you would like an equal number of men and women.

title: GREEK PARTY BOYCOTTS PRESIDENT'S INSTALLATION
description: Christos Sartzetakis was sworn in tonight as President of Greece. He was elected Friday in a tumultuous special session of Parliament.

title: Seefeld
description: To the Editor:

title: A Healthy Birth Isn't 'Wrongful'
description: The ''moral, social and emotional advantages'' of the birth of a healthy child outweigh any financial hardships the parents may face, the New York Court of Appeals said last week. At stake was a malpractice claim for child-rearing expenses brought by the parents of a baby girl, KellyAnne O'Toole, who was conceived after her mother had had a sterilization operation.

title: AN ARRAY OF CONCERTS TODAY
description: THIS is an incredibly busy Sunday, with nearly a dozen musical happenings to report.

title: NUTRITIONIST TO TELL OF EVEREST CLIMB
description: PRISCILLA BRIGGS of Southport, who used to consider a cup of coffee and a doughnut a day's meal, served last summer as a nutrition expert to a group of mountain climbers at Mount Everest in the Himalayas.

description: CANARSIE The Jews and Italians of Brooklyn Against Liberalism.

description: LOVE & WAR / ART & GOD

description: WESTFIELD

title: The Obstacles To Freer Trade
description: The next economic summit meeting in May of the seven leading industrial democracies could be more agitated than usual if reports last week of looming clashes between the United States and France and between Japan and all the others are confirmed.

title: Tank Car Leaks Chemical
description: Officials say about five pounds of methyl chloride, described as a ''moderately toxic'' chemical, escaped at the Union Carbide Corporation's plant here Thursday after a railroad tank car developed a leak. A state air pollution official, Carl Beard, classified the chemical as an irritant but said it was not explosive.

title: WHAT AMERICANS THINK NOW
description: TEN YEARS AFTER THE END OF the Vietnam War, the lessons it once seemed to teach about placing restraints on the use of power are losing effect. Americans are increasingly prepared to use troops, whether in El Salvador or in Europe, and are about equally divided on employing the Central Intelligence Agency to overthrow unfriendly governments, a New York Times Poll shows.

title: Volcker Calls Inflation Drive The Key in Attracting Capital
description: The Federal Reserve must keep up its anti- inflation fight if the nation is to continue attracting the foreign capital needed for the United States trade and budget deficits, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today.

title: HONEST ITALIAN WORTH THE WAIT
description: AN unprepossessing exterior and a large, dim bar area open into the bright and busy dining room of Ponticello in Astoria, Queens. It is an unpretentious restaurant of modest size that has built a loyal following.

title: SEE HOW THEY PLAY
description: GEORGE

title: Free Tampon Exchange Called Unrelated to Suit
description: The offer by International Playtex Inc. to provide free exchanges for tampons linked to the often fatal toxic shock syndrome was unrelated to a multimillion-dollar judgment against the company, its president says.

title: CONSUMER RATES
POWER, GREED AND GLORY ON WALL STREET
description: Under the negotiated severance agreement, Peter Peterson, former chairman of the board, was able to walk away from Lehman Brothers with about $18 million (not counting a $5 million loan to his new company), including $300,000 annually, as ''supplemental retirement benefits.''

title: FOOTNOTES ON A GAME OF TRIVIA
description: When a bunch of bridge- players gather together, it is almost certain that they will either play their game or talk about it. For a group of New York players at a party, a unique compromise was provided recently: They played a game about bridge.

title: FOR THE POPULIST SUPPLY SIDERS
description: WASHINGTON

title: S.R.O. BILL FRUSTRATES UPGRADING BY SMALL OWNERS
description: VICKI SIVESIND is a widow who lives

title: ALICE ARLEN REWRITES THE NEWS FOR 'ALAMO BAY'
description: Screenwriters are a sour bunch, says Alice Arlen: ''Movie writing is never good enough for them. It's a director's medium! A lot of writers are really novelists, or playwrights, or great journalists, and for them working on a movie can be very frustrating. But for me it's the best!''

title: GREAT STAMP WAR
description: GOOD government or good politics? The motivation behind the Suffolk County Legislature's ''Great Stamp War,'' as one legislator refers to it, depends on whom you talk to.

title: MATRIARCHS OF THE MEADOW
description: THE JOCKEY CLUB, A SOCIETY OF 91 thoroughbred owners whose roster is littered with Bancrofts, Phippses and Vanderbilts, has an image corresponding to its Madison Avenue location. To outsiders, its name and address conjure a picture of overstuffed millionaires in overstuffed leather club chairs, sipping sherry as they vote to exclude horses and owners of weak pedigree from the so-called Sport of Kings.

title: Small Truck Concerns Resist a Teamster Pact
description: Negotiators for major trucking concerns and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters continued bargaining today on a nationwide contract, but hundreds of smaller companies were resisting the contract terms, according to industry sources.

title: GIVING NEW LIFE TO THE 'THREAD CITY' MILLS
description: WHEN the American Thread Company announced last summer that it was closing its complex of mills in Willimantic, Conn., town officials worried about the loss of what for nearly a century was one of their largest employers.

title:
GARDENING;

GIVING YOUR LAWN A GOOD START
description: LAWN clippings are bulky and take up a lot of space. They are also a major contributor to the overflowing landfills in our region. The irony is that there is seldom a reason to remove the clippings from the lawn in the first place. Left there they will soon disintegrate, and return plant nutrients back to the soil. As much as 25 percent of the lawn's requirement can be supplied this way, according to turf-grass specialists.

title: BRINGING MUSIC TO LIFE FOR CHILDREN
description: WHO is afraid of modern music? Chances are, not the nearly 3,000 third through sixth graders who took part this month in ''What's New, Maestro?'' - a music-education program produced by the New Orchestra of Westchester that culminated in two free concerts scheduled last week at the State University of New York campus at Purchase.

title: Casino Hotels Report Drop in Profits in '84
description: The profits of Atlantic City's casino hotels fell 28 percent last year, despite the addition of a 10th casino hotel, the state's Casino Control Commission said.

title: VIETNAM IN AMERICA: A PREFACE
description: NEARLY A DECADE HAS PASSED SINCE the fall of Saigon, but the haunting image of that last helicopter poised for flight on the roof of the United States Embassy still lingers in the American imagination. April 30 will mark not merely the 10th anniversary of the Communist takeover of South Vietnam, but also the decisive moment when America was dealt its first military defeat. For a while, the pain of the Vietnam experience was such that Americans suffered a collective repression. Now there seems to be a willingness to examine this chapter in our past. What is Vietnam's legacy in America? To find out, The New York Times asked a team of reporters to examine how the Vietnam experience affects our everyday life, our high art and popular culture, and the veterans who fought the war. The result is this special issue of The Times Magazine on how Vietnam lives on in the hearts and minds of Americans.

title: A Go-Slow on Mining
description: Environmentalists received another boost last week, when the Interior Department withdrew a rule designed to ease exploration for minerals in wilderness areas. The rule, made final last month, would have required the Bureau of Land Management to determine merely that there were ''exposed'' minerals at a site before permitting a holder of mineral rights to begin the development process.

description: WASHINGTONRonald Reagan's mastery as a

title: Curry Wins 22d
description: Unbeaten Donald Curry of Fort Worth, the World Boxing Association's welterweight champion, won his 22d fight and his first as a junior middleweight today, stopping James (Hard Rock) Green of Irvington, N.J., at 40 seconds of the second round.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: GREAT RIVER: The Rio Grande in North American History, by Paul Horgan. (Texas Monthly Press, $14.95.) Running from Colorado to the Gulf of Mexico, the 1,900-mile Rio Grande is the nation's second longest river. J. Frank Dobie wrote in The Book Review in 1954: ''Paul Horgan is an artist, which means that he is a master of proportions, perspective and details. His book is an unfoldment of life with streches of narrative.'' ''Great River'' won a Pulitzer Prize for history.

title: A RURAL TOWN BRACES FOR GROWTH
description: DRIVING eastbound into Columbia on Route 66 the wooded land is seen dotted with a row of ''For Sale'' signs. When the woods end, a string of newly built houses sit across the road from a farm.

title: AN APOSTLE OF THE AGE OF COMPUTERIZED LIFE
description: ''YOU'VE noticed in banks that you've started to see automatic teller machines,'' said Gerald H. Schoenberg of Locust Valley. ''Expanding that concept into supermarkets and arenas and shopping malls and places of that nature, it is evident that you can sell theater tickets and tickets for all sorts of sports events, airline tickets, bus tickets, transportation tickets in general - and perhaps even purchase things like insurance policies without an attendant being required.''

title: Data Bank; March 31, 1985
BRUNELLESCHI & COMPANY
description: Jacob Burckhardt, whose eloquent ''Civilization of the Renaissance in Italy'' is one of the best- known histories ever published, appears in a very different guise in THE ARCHITECTURE OF THE ITALIAN RENAISSANCE (University of Chicago, $50). He kept adding to it for 30 years after it first appeared in 1867, and it is more a collection of notes than a book; its style is often reminiscent of Burton's ''Anatomy of Melancholy.''

title: A NEW LOOK AT THE OLD ENEMY
description: Americans never did seem to grasp clearly what was stirring in Vietnam - how history and personality combined at a certain time to engulf the United States, a fledgling country by Asian standards, in an impossible conflict. In the war's aftermath, many Vietnamese also felt their youthful ideals betrayed. Their story, adding a special dimension to Americans' own reflections, is still being told. And Truong Nhu Tang is one of the tellers.

title: Headliners ;   An Archbishop's Apology A Roman Catholic Archbishop performed an act of contrition last week. After pleading guilty to charges of drunken driving,
description: Archbishop John R. Roach of Minneapolis-St. Paul apologized to ''those I have disappointed.''

title: Senator Might Want Presidency Someday
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts says he is maintaining his political committee and contacts, should he decide to run for the Presidency in 1988, when his fourth term in the Senate expires.

title: POWER, GREED AND GLORY ON WALL STREET
description: I read Ken Auletta's article with great interest and regret. I was the partner in charge of the Southwest for Lehman Brothers from 1958 to 1977, when I resigned to take another position.

title: ABORTION ISSUE CITED
description: The United States, expressing concern over the reported use of forced abortions as a means of population control in China, today withheld $10 million earmarked for a United Nations agency that operates in China.

title: U.S. High Jump Record Is Set in Los Angeles
description: Dennis Lewis of Long Beach City College set an American record in the high jump when he cleared 7 feet 8 1/4 inches in the event in a junior college meet today.

title: COLLEGE IS COMMUNITY CENTER
description: THE forecast was for freezing rain, but 350 art lovers ignored it last Sunday to gather at Quinebaug Valley Community College, an institution that has emerged in the past year as a regional cultural center.

title: 'FOR US, THE WAR IS OVER'
description: Michael Norman, a metropolitan reporter for The Times, writes the ''Our Towns'' column. He is preparing a book about the men he served with in Vietnam.

title: JAPAN'S MADE-IN-AMERICA CARS
description: DETROIT

title: A War Machine Mired in Sleaze
description: The Defense Department is in crisis. Its managers are again dosing the symptoms by loudly demanding refunds from greedy or corrupt contractors. Congress should not be deceived. The sleaze in the weapons industry reflects only the dissipation of purpose in the Pentagon. Never mind the wildfire of waste: The root problem is national security and its debilitation by a sclerotic defense bureaucracy.

title: THAT FISH CHANGED MY LIFE
description: FISHERMEN ARE FOREVER searching for something beneath the surface, in another world; for a shrewder lure, a more accommodating rod; for something they've lost in a past that persists - or some shadow barely glimpsed in the year ahead. In March, as the chill recedes, inchmeal, they grow restless. They have counted the months, the days; now they count hours before the new season will begin. Forsythia is already bright yellow in the park. It is time to quit the city, go astream again. What matter that for all the homes they've found on far-flung rivers, Ithaca has too often proved Ho-Ho-Kus.

title: WHEN THE SURNAME TOLD OF ONE'S WORK
description: OF all the valued things any one of us owns, the most important is one's family name - and to many, its significance at the time it was first given to an ancestor.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN OLD TAPPAN
description: NOT unlike its earliest Dutch settlers, who moved from Manhattan late in the 17th century to take up a rural life along the fertile banks of the Hackensack River, today's residents of Old Tappan, N.J., cite its semirural qualities to explain their affection for this Bergen County community.

title: U.S. BANKERS REACHED AN AGREEMENT WITH MEXICO LAST WEEK

Everyone remembered that it was Mexico's inability to meet its obligations in August 1982 that had triggered the panic over what they called an international ''debt bomb.''

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: TRANS-ATLANTIC ROUTES, FLORIDA DRIVE-AWAY
description: Two Airlines Add Runs To Britain For airline passengers to Britain, the horizons are expanding. Beginning tomorrow, British Airways will offer the only nonstop scheduled air service between New York and Manchester in the heart of England. And on May 1 British Caledonian Airways will inaugurate daily nonstop scheduled service between Gatwick Airport, outside London, and Kennedy International Airport in New York.

title: Doing Hard Time A man who was falsely accused of rape and who has spent six years in prison because of it might be expected to bear a grudge. But
description: Gary Dotson said last week he had forgiven Cathleen Crowell, who confessed that she had made up the story when she was 16 years old because she thought she was pregnant by a boyfriend.

title: HUNGARY APPOINTS DEPUTY TO KADAR
description: A four-day congress of the Hungarian Communist Party has ended here with the re-election of Janos Kadar and the selection, for the first time, of a designated deputy to the 72-year-old party leader.

title: MULLIN REDUCED TO BEING A DECOY
description: Chris Mullin had watched Patrick Ewing swat away his shot and immediately throw down a dunk at the other end. He had been sent sprawling out of bounds by the force of Ewing's shoulder. He had beaten Georgetown almost by himself, with his long-range shooting. For 11 games over four seasons, Chris Mullin had reason to think he had seen everything there was to see from the Hoyas.

title: AS REAGAN PROMISED, THE RICH PAY MORE
description: Some people still consider the 1981 Reagan tax cut as welfare for the rich - or, to quote the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a ''reverse Robin Hood process, taking from the poor and giving to the rich.'' But newly released figures from the Internal Revenue Service on 1983 tax returns show that the tax cut had just the opposite effect. After the cut, the rich paid more and carried a larger share of the total, while the poor paid less. Lower taxes encouraged the rich to earn more taxable income and shelter less - that is, to spend more time with engineers, clients and market researchers and less time with tax attorneys and accountants.

title: TOPICS
description: THROUGH no fault of mine, sewing my own covers for our home computer has become a never-ending job.

title: ALUMNI GATHER FOR A MARLBORO ANNIVERSARY
description: The Music From Marlboro Touring Ensemble will celebrate its 20th anniversary tomorrow with a commemmorative concert at Town Hall. Three generations of Marlboro alumni will perform - the violinist Felix Galimir, associated with the Marlboro Festival for more than three decades; the pianist Murray Perahia, who was a regular participant at the Marlboro Festival from 1968 until 1972, and three young string players, Hirono Oka, Benjamin Simon and Sara Sant'Ambrogio, all of whom began their association with Marlboro in the last two years. The program will include music by Mendelssohn, Dvorak and Alban Berg.

title: SPORTSLOCK
description: IN ANOTHER WEEK, THE BASEBALL SEASON will open. But the pro basketball and hockey playoffs have yet to begin, and the United States Football League is not even halfway through its springtime schedule. To add to the confusion of it all, if not to the consternation, something that wishes to be known as the United States Basketball League is planning to begin operations this summer.

description: We know little about the early culture and practices of the people of the Micronesian Islands of the South Pacific. We understand even less about how these natives of the Marshall, Caroline, Gilbert (now Kiribati), Ellice (now Tuvalu) and Nauru Islands were able to master weaving, basketry and carving to produce the extraordinary fans, belts, mats, hair ornaments, brushes and objects on view through May 5 in the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title:

DESPITE FORECASTS, REVENUES ARE DOWN
description: A recent survey by the Internal Revenue Service seems to show that upper-income people are shouldering more of the tax load than they did before 1981, when tax rates were slashed across the board. In 1981, people with at least $100,000 of income paid 15.2 percent of the total tax take; the recent I.R.S. figures for 1983 show that people with incomes of at least $100,000 paid 20 percent - 4.8 percentage points more.

title: VERBATIM: ROOTS OF REVOLT
description: 'When corporations can be viewed as enjoying a profit in the neighborhood of $2 or $3 billion and not paying taxes, that is when the revolution comes in; that is when my constituents say, ''You know, I do not mind paying taxes, but I think it is unfair when people do not pay taxes who enjoy as large a development of capital as some corporations have.'' It is the idea that we want our tax system to be fair, that when people enjoy a large profit, by gosh, they pay for it.'

title: Not Telling About Rape
description: More than 1.5 million rapes or attempted rapes took place in the United States between 1973 and 1982, but according to a Justice Department study made public last week, only about half the victims reported the crime to the police.

title: SOFT SOAP AND THE NITTY-GRITTY
description: BECAUSE euphemism, which is an effort to make something sound specially nice, implies that unless prettified it will be specially unacceptable, a euphemistic formation can easily turn into its opposite. That would be a ''dysphemism,'' a coinage almost as ugly as what it describes. Easy and obvious examples are found in the troubled area of racial names. For many years, ''Afro-Americans,'' ''the colored'' and ''Negroes'' were prevalent as efforts, more or less highfalutin, to say what it is now accepted procedure to express by the word ''black.'' The latest word is notably inexact, since most of the people it designates are different shades of brown, sometimes very light. (It is, to be sure, no more inexact than the word ''white'' applied to a spectrum of faces from pinko-gray to swarthy.) But it is a ''genuine'' word, implying in its very overstatement rejection of all efforts to mitigate or evade the basic facts; it is, in addition, not the word of outsiders.

Here are some of the highlights as musicians and worshipers gather to mark Holy Week:

title: PUERTO RICO'S QUIET EDGE
description: People in San Juan refer to the rest of Puerto Rico as la isla (the island), as if the capital city were on the mainland. It could well be argued that sanjuaneros are much closer psychologically to the United States than Puerto Ricans living outside the city, but the custom really goes back to the 16th and 17th century when San Juan Bautista, as the city was known, was limited to what is today the Old City, on an islet off Puerto Rico's northeast corner. Regardless of whether the continued use of the term la isla betrays underlying political attitudes, the fact remains that more and more Puerto Rico has come to be divided into the San Juan metropolitan area, now encompassing roughly one-third of the island's population, and the rest of Puerto Rico. The overwhelming majority of the hundreds of thousands of tourists who visit Puerto Rico every year never step out of San Juan, thus missing most of the still unspoiled and most attractive areas the .island has to offer.

title: EAST-WEST PARLEY AT HALFWAY MARK

description: The men's varsity heavyweight crews of Princeton and Navy staged one of the closest races in the 12-year history of the Smith Cup today, with the Midshipmen winning in the final strokes by 1.2 seconds, or 10 feet.

title: GRAPPLING WITH THE GLORY
description: MICKEY MANTLE AND ROGER MARIS ARE STROLLing again across a dewy greensward in the golden haze of a summer afternoon, bumping big shoulders, laughing softly, flexing their thick hands around their clubs. Maris pats Mantle on the backside as he moves into position to hit the ball. It would be a dream from another time if the game wasn't golf and the place wasn't Fargo, N.D., Maris's hometown, and if a voice from behind a suddenly thrusting microphone didn't say, ''It mustfeel like old times, the two of you battling it out.''

title: TOPICS
description: DO you remember a wonderful sendup of a watch commercial that appeared on an early ''Saturday Night Live,'' in which they demonstrated the simplicity of using a multifunction digital watch? ''Just push the top right button while holding in the button on the bottom left,'' the ad instructed. ''Then, while holding in the top right and bottom left buttons'' - a third hand appeared and the voice-over continued - ''just tap the upper left button twice.'' A fourth hand appeared. ''And tap the lower right button. Now, your watch is set.''

title: CASTAWAYS ON A FRENCH ISLE
description: Greta Garbo never said ''I want to be alone,'' but rather ''I want to be left alone,'' a subtle but monumental difference. ''We did nothing,'' a frequently heard comment about St. Barthelemy, really means that there's nothing one feels compelled to do. You can choose to visit any of some 20 beaches, to sun, sail, snorkel, scuba dive, wind surf, to dine well, to shop. It's a fine place to pamper your psyche, a nice island for lovers. On St. Barths doing nothing nourishes.

After all, library shelves are stacked with books analyzing the dramatist and his work. The plays of America's first world-class playwright have been regarded, mused over and written about to the point where the work too often overwhelms contemporary players.

We are voices in a chorus that transforms lived life into narrated life and then returns narrative to life, not in order to reflect life, but rather to add something else, not a copy but a new measure of life; to add, with each novel, something new, something more, to life.

GIVING YOUR LAWN A GOOD START
description: LAWN clippings are bulky and take up a lot of space. They are also a major contributor to the overflowing landfills in our region. The irony is that there is seldom a reason to remove the clippings from the lawn in the first place. Left there they will soon disintegrate, and return plant nutrients back to the soil. As much as 25 percent of the lawn's requirement can be supplied this way, according to turf-grass specialists.

title: NOT TO BE A PRIEST
description: Anthony DePalma paints the priesthood as a sad refuge of men frustrated by the lack of progeny. On the contrary, many of us are very happy; I dare say most of us feel graced to be fathers of a different kind. The only real sadness is that we do have some sons, like Mr. DePalma, who do not understand their fathers or appreciate what the fathers do for the sake of their sons - a fate shared by fathers in both the natural and the supernatural order. REV. PETER M. J. STRAVINSKAS Catholic League for Religious And Civil Rights
