title: CORPORATE HAVEN
description: A rapidly expanding corporate presence is changing the landscape of Morris County, N.J., and bringing in many new managers and their families. To serve that growing market, a development of 260 town-house condominiums and 29 single-family homes is now under construction on a 95-acre tract in Montville near the old Morris Canal.

title: UNIONS ARE SHIFTING GEARS BUT NOT GOALS
description: Local 128 of the United Electrical Workers is conducting a spirited campaign to stop the Black & Decker Manufacturing Company from closing a toaster oven plant here.

title: CONDO TOWER
description: In 1979, King Fook, the Hong Kong-based gold concern, bought the six-story building at 675 Fifth Avenue and opened a branch of its retail operation there, complete with a pagoda-style entrance.

title: AFTER FIRE, PARK SHIFTS IMAGE
description: JACKSON TOWNSHIP

title: RANGERS TIE MARK IN LOSING TO FLYERS
description: The Flyers have reached the point in the regular season where they have nothing to win. They have wrapped up their second Patrick Division title in three years. They stand only one triumph away from tying their team record of 51 victories. And they will possibly finish with the best overall record in the National Hockey League.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL ;   HOSPITAL LAWSUITS
description: NEW YORK HOSPITAL filed two new lawsuits last week in an effort to get the White Plains Common Council to consider rezoning the hospital's 218-acre property for offices, stores and apartments. It also began trying to persuade state and Federal preservation offices that its property is not worthy of listing on state and national registers.

title:
DINING OUT;

CLUB-LIKE AIR IN ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS
description: ''OH, IT'S a mixed bag.'' This was the reply I got when I telephoned Eton's, the luxurious new restaurant in Englewood Cliffs, to ask what kind of food we would find there. As it turns out, the gentleman on the telephone was spot on; the fare at Eton's ranges from Italian oreganatas to swinging-singles' potato skins to steakhouse staples.

title: Sports of The Times;   The Cubs' New Shortstop
description: IN the early days of spring training, Jim Frey, the Chicago

title: POLITICS: GIBSON CONFIDENT OF CHANCES
description: TRENTONWHEN he met with the press last month to announce his candidacy for Governor, Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark said, ''Don't try to paint me into a corner.''

title: CLASSICAL CELEBRATIONS OF EASTER
description: THE oratorios of Easter are in season and most church musicians around the state have refused to turn their backs on the repertories of Johann Sebastian Bach, George Frideric Handel and Domenico Scarlatti, despite the vast number of performances generated by the 300th anniversaries of the three composers' birth.

title: CHILLING MEMORIES OF ALZHEIMER VICTIM
description: Reading Barbara Fader's article (''When Alzheimer's Strikes,'' Opinion Page, March 10) brought back chilling memories. My mother began acting strangely several years after my father's death.

title: HAMBRECHT & QUIST LOSES ITS EDGE
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: SUSAN SEIDELMAN STRIKES A BLOW FOR INDEPENDENTS
description: The day of independents may be at hand or, at least, a little nearer than it's been for some time. It's still too early to tell how it will do at the box office, but Susan Seidelman's just-opened, comparatively mainstream comedy, ''Desperately Seeking Susan,'' is so funny, so stylish and - don't underestimate this aspect of it - so economically efficient that it should give heart to those of us who sit in the audience, as well as to those independent American film makers who want to work in the commercial cinema, which not all of them do.

title: ART ;   A NAIF AND NINE REALISTS
description: LAWRENCE TWP.

title: PANEL OFFERS CUTS IN MILITARY STAFF
description: One of the three proposals for the 1986 military budget approved in secret last week by a subcommittee of the Senate Armed Services Committee would reduce Pentagon staffing by 175,000 over two years, a Senate aide said tonight.

title: With Friends Like That...
description: Joseph A. Bevilacqua has said he can associate with anyone he pleases so long as it does not affect his duties as Chief Justice of the Rhode Island Supreme Court.

title: HOUSEKEEPING HAVENS
description: To many vacationers in the Caribbean, a room or suite with kitchen or kitchenette can be more attractive than a regular hotel room. Facilities for preparing snacks and light meals offer convenience and flexibility to those visitors who prefer freedom to come and go - or stay right where they are - to the necessity of going to restaurants two or three times a day or paying for room service.

title: WESTCHESTER OPINION ;   CARING FOR THE WHOLE PATIENT
description: THE larger the hospital the less pleasant it is to visit; and the more demoralizing it is to be a patient in residence, no matter how short the stay. I put before you the following situation as an example of administrative decisions that leave the sick sicker, at least in spirit.

title:
DINING OUT;

STYLED AFTER AN OLD ENGLISH PRINT
description: SALERNO'S has long been one of our favorite informal county dining spots. The crowds that would wait faithfully at the bar for tables (Salerno's takes no reservations) seemed to share our feeling that the restaurant does a good job of preparing fresh ingredients in ways that are interesting and appealing without being outre. Although the place is as popular as ever, these days the crowds wait on weekends only, and even then not for long, as diners enjoy the additional seating a new dining room affords.

title: Professor's Widow Files Suit Against Vietnamese
description: A widow filed a $12 million suit Friday against a Vietnamese student convicted of killing her husband, charging he had caused a wrongful death. She and others also asserted that prosecutors in the case had failed to pursue information pointing to a political assassination.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEATED BY THE CAPITALS, 4-3
description: The last confrontation before the real duel begins left the Islanders still searching for lost inspiration. They took only 17 shots on goal and lost to the Capitals, 4-3, tonight.

title: PRESERVING THE LAND
description: BARRING an unanticipated complication, the Town of East Hampton is about to make the largest land purchase for preservation in its history. At a recent meeting the Town Board voted to have Supervisor

title: Minority Caucus Seeks Ouster of Prisons Chief
description: Members of the Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus protested for more than two hours outside Governor Cuomo's office today, calling for the resignation of the Commissioner of the State Department of Correctional Services because of comments he made in an interview.

title: DIAMONDS ARE FOREVER
description: THE NATIONAL ANTHEM seemed to go on forever. And before that, I thought that the lineups would never end, either; it was like a reading from ''The Domesday Book.'' Finally, the announcer boomed my name. ''Give it all you've got, Bill,'' he added loudly.

title: THE SCRIBBLING MILLIONS
description: A BOOK OF ONE'S OWN People and Their Diaries.

title: U.S.F.L. Labor Pact
description: There may be some doubts about whether the United States Football League can survive the next four seasons, but if it does, the league will be assured of labor peace. After nine months of negotiations the owners and the Players Association have approved a four-year agreement that

title: TEAMS AT SCHOOLS LACK COACHES
description: IT has been a decade since Nick

description: THE AMERICAN ACADEMIC PROFESSION: A Synthesis of Social Scientific Inquiry Since World War II. By Martin J. Finkelstein. (Ohio State University, $17.50.)

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CRASH-LANDING. By Peter Spielberg. (Fiction Collective, Cloth, $12.95, Paper, $6.95.)

title: Webb Beats Williams For Bowling Crown
description: Wayne Webb of Indianapolis, the top- seeded bowler, won his second consecutive event with a 196-150 decision over Mark Williams of Beaumont, Tex., in the championship game of the $130,000 Fair Lanes Open today.

title: Q&A
description: Question:

title: Spring Storms Spread Over Parts of Nation By The Associated Press
description: Spring snow carried by a storm coming out of the Rockies moved into the Texas and Oklahoma panhandles and toward the middle of the nation yesterday, while melting snow and torrents of rain flooded streets in Michigan and washed out West Virginia bridges.

title: THE WAR AND THE ARTS
description: Samuel G. Freedman is a New York Times culture reporter.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Bouquet Deliveries From Pleasantville

title: CUBAN REFUGEE CRIME TROUBLES POLICE ACROSS U. S.
description: A diplomatic agreement providing for the the United States to deport back to Cuba 2,746 refugees classified as criminal or mentally ill offers little comfort to law-enforcement officials, who say that refugees who fled the port of Mariel in 1980 have been linked to an unusually large number of crimes.

title: Some Fish Worth Watching
description: Considering what often ends up in New York's waters, it pays to keep an eye on the seafood that comes out of them. Last week, Mayor Koch asked his Health Commissioner to check out the safety of three favorite items on city menus: striped bass and raw clams and oysters.

title:
ART;

ART SHOWN IN MODEL HOMES
description: IT is not unusual to find the decor

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PEARL. By Anne Leaton. (Knopf, $14.95.)

title: A DANCER RETURNS TO NATIVE GROUND
description: Among world-class ballet dancers, Richard Cragun, born in Sacramento, Calif., is a phenomenon: an American dancer whose career has evolved and developed exclusively in Europe. His rise to international prominence was fostered by a single choreographer, the late John Cranko, a single company, the Stuttgart Ballet, and a single and singular partnership - that with the Stuttgart's director and prima ballerina, Marcia Haydee. Indeed, as the Stuttgart Ballet's leading male dancer for some 23 years, Mr. Cragun has placed his markedly American energy in the service of a predominantly European dance sensibility.

title: POWER, GREED AND GLORY ON WALL STREET
description: The bottom line of Ken Auletta's article is clear: Even a company with deep roots and the long genteel tradition of Lehman Brothers succumbs in today's corporate milieu, in which rapacious leadership votes itself huge bonuses and stock options while company profits are plunging. Then enter that great American corporate innovation, the merger, and the greed is unbelievable, with settlements for individual partners reaching as high as $23 million.

title: GOLF THE OLDE-FASHIONED WAY
description: THE FIRST TIME I PLAYED THE OLD COURSE, AT ST. ANdrews, I had one of those inimitable Scottish caddies who - if Dickens had played golf - would have been immortalized in a character with some such name as Sloppy MacSod. A frayed cap. A rumpled topcoat, green with age. Pants that drooped like an expiring concertina over his wrinkled shoes. His left shoulder was permanently depressed from all the bags he'd carried. He re-lighted the stub of a cigarette that was already disappearing between his lips and tramped off at a crippled angle. A straight drive produced the tribute: ''We're rait doon the meddle.'' The first slice evoked: ''You're way awf in the gorrrse.'' (Scottish caddies, like nurses, alternate between the first person plural and the second person singular as a handy method of distributing praise and blame.)

title: A COLLECTOR INTENT ON PRESERVING AN ERA
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I. h One of the world's most diligent pursuers of contemporary art, Richard Brown Baker has given new meaning to the word "eclectic." Covering the scene for more than 30 years, he's zeroed in like a talent scout on artists of every persuasion, largely buying the work of the new and unknown, and not selling, no matter how euphoric the market. Jackson Pollock and Teruko Yokoi, Louise Nevelson and Theo Wujcik, Willem de Kooning and Sarah Supplee are among the names in Mr. Baker's collection, and if it lacks what's fancily called "a profile," it has both quality and quantity - more than 1,200 objects so far - comprising a very useful chronological survey of big tides and little ripples from World War II to date. Two ingredients compound the Baker formula: fiscal credit and confidence in his eye, and with it he's gone from amateur status in the sport to full-time professional. Parts of his holdings have often been shown, but the biggest and most comprehensive selection from it ever - more than 160 works - is now on view at the Museum of Art, Rhode Island School of Design, here in Mr. Baker's old home town (through April 28; then on to the West Coast). Set out cheek by jowl with period furniture and Old Master paintings in this small but eloquent teaching museum, the exhibition includes the most important Baker holdings - Jackson Pollock's "Arabesque" (1948), Franz Kline's "Wanamaker Block" (1955), Hans Hofmann's "Fortissimo" (1956), Roy Lichtenstein's "Blam" (1962), among others - and a supporting cast chosen to give an overall impression of the collection's international range as well as its diversity of mediums and approaches. The eye is not always unfailing - for one, by my lights there's too much in the way of the bland non-style known as Photo-Realism - but Mr. Baker obviously didn't set out to "shape" his holdings. Instead, while buying to please himself, he seems to have a mission to preserve the period, making what he calls his "study" collection as representative as possible of the art world in the middle years of our century. "My collecting approach has been chronological - new work as it comes out," he says. Acknowledging with a smile that "self-interest and vanity" may play a part in his acquisitionship, Mr. Baker also likes to think he is helping artists "become known to as broad a public as possible. I believe they need a wide basis of support, and private collectors are as necessary as museums to their well-being in an economic and emotional sense." He intends to leave the collection to his alma mater, Yale (where part of it is already housed), and the Rhode Island School of Design museum. "One reason why I don't sell is that I feel the scene should be available to the future. The collection might be interesting for people looking back to the 50's, 60's, 70's and 80's. They may remember de Kooning, but not lesser lights. In our own period, we see all sorts of artists who'll be forgotten later." Yet, as he points out, there are big gaps - no works by Rothko, Francis Bacon or Clyfford Still, for instance - gaps that he says he doesn't "feel obliged to fill. After all, I'm not an institution." Often, when he would like to follow an artist's career to full peak, success will drive prices too high for what Mr. Baker calls his "limited means." An example is Roy Lichtenstein: though Mr. Baker was one of the first to buy his work on canvas in the early 60's, by the 80's he could afford to purchase only the artist's prints. On the other hand, a current heavy, Julian Schnabel, is not in the collection at all. "By the time I'd heard of him, his paintings were already $80,000," says Mr. Baker. The collection had its genesis in the late 1940's when Mr. Baker, then a foreign affairs specialist for the State Department in Washington, "retired" early on a private income to try his hand at writing. Arriving in New York in late 1952, he began to make the round of galleries, and took to the young, postwar generation of abstract artists. With the idea that it would "helpful and challenging to buy the work of the living, the young and unestablished," he began making serious acquisitions and one of his very earliest purchases (on view in the show) was a tiny collage by Kurt Schwitters, bought in 1954 from the Museum of Modern Art's Art Lending Service for $250. Two years later, he had already acquired Pollock's now classic "Arabesque," Jean Dubuffet's strong and witty "Winter Landscape With Two Dogs" (both pictures for under $5,000), Kline's powerful "Wanamaker Block," and an ardent Calder whimsicality, "A Mobile With a Stabile Tail" (1947). And then he was off and running, branching out as trend succeeded trend, occasionally piling as many as 70 purchases in a single year. A tour of the two gallery floors that hold the collection in this small museum gives the viewer a luxurious chance to pit his own taste against Mr. Baker's. Agreed, the Pollock and the Kline are two superb choices, worthy of great museums. No less rewarding are the two Hans Hofmann paintings, "Pond" and "Fortissimo," the former a cool, muted body of green between shores of riotous color; the latter a gorgeous, ordered explosion of brushstrokes that lifts the eye upward. "Aerial," a serenely surreal canvas by William Baziotes, is at the top of that artist's form. A dazzling treatise in black and white is offered by Al Held's infinitely polished "Volta VIII," with its ballet of geometric forms traced in white against a flat black ground, and Cy Twombly's nearby "Untitled," scribbled white rectangles deployed with graffiti-like ease against a backdrop of black. William Beckman's steely "Self Portrait," a puritanical figure against a seductively taffy-colored gessoed ground, is as fine an example of contemporary Realism as anything around. A wonderful charcoal drawing of a reclining nude by Jules Olitski makes one wish for more figurative work from this echt abstractionist. Not to be dismissed lightly, either, is the sense of humor that Mr. Baker brings to his calling. It's especially apparent in such works as Robert Arneson's ceramic sculpture "The Last Gasp," a portrait of the artist as a red- faced swimmer, mouth open like a fish, perched atop a Roman column (and installed in a gallery under a flossy, putti- filled 18th-century painting by Gian Battista Tiepolo). On the other hand, one could carp at more than a few of Mr. Baker's selections, and wonder why he rushed to buy so much, perhaps at the expense of better. The small Nevelson wall piece, for instance, is certainly not representative of that artist at her best, and Kenneth Noland's big, target-like "Rhyme" shows us the weaker side of Noland's work. Lucas Samaras's recent baroque sculpture has seemed to me not one of his finest efforts, and the small piece here reinforces that opinion, especially in context with other Samarases in the show. One has seen better contributions from Dorothea Rockburne than her drawing "Triangle, Small Square," and one wishes that less slick examples could be found from the current Neo-Expressionist scene than Leonard Koscianski's "Hunting Ground." Yet if there's such a thing as an auteur collector, Mr. Baker is it. Looking at the larger, overall scope of his efforts, we can be glad that someone of taste and spirit was around to save so much of the present for the future. - GALLERY VIEW

title: Victims of Rape - and Despair
description: Many crimes are not reported because the victim doesn't want the bother . . . or doesn't have any insurance to claim . . . or doesn't expect the police to think it worth their time. But when it comes to rape, none of those reasons apply. Why then did nearly half the 1.5 million rapes or attempted rapes in the United States between 1973 and 1982 go unreported? The reason, it seems, is despair.

title: MARTINA'S UNFAIRNESS DOCTRINE
description: THE NIGHT BEFORE, MARTINA Navratilova had played a match against Eleni Rossides. This was in Washington, in a gym at George Washington University, one of those gyms with wooden bleachers and humming overhead lights and banners tacked to the wall with masking tape and the kind of acoustics that make every noise in the place seem two or three times as loud, and there, in the first round of the Virginia Slims of Washington tournament, 28-year-old Martina Navratilova, perhaps the greatest athlete and certainly the biggest moneymaker in the history of women's tennis, had played a match against Eleni Rossides, 17, a local girl you have never heard of. When Miss Navratilova came onto the court before the match, there was polite applause. When her opponent walked onto the court, there was a standing ovation.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Passion for the Now

title: WARNED PUBLIC OF CIGARETTE PERIL
description: Dr. Luther L. Terry, who as Surgeon General of the United States was instrumental in preparing a 1964 report that said cigarette smoking contributed so substantially to the death rate that ''appropriate remedial action'' was called for, died Friday in Philadelphia, where he had lived for 20 years. He was 73 years old.

title: IND Stops
description: To the Editor:

title: IN A NEW ROLE, JESSICA TANDY INHABITS BOTH PAST AND PRESENT
description: As has happened so often before, Jessica Tandy is inhabiting a world that hovers restlessly between past and present, dream and reality. It is not a New Orleans street echoing with the sound of a jazz piano, nor a drab St. Louis apartment where a young girl collects glass animals. This world is a tide-washed beach in Greece, barren except for stray weeds, a few rocks - and a young man lying nude on the sand. We are in Salonika, the site of fierce fighting during World War I - and the title of a play starring Miss Tandy and Elizabeth Wilson that will open Tuesday at the Public.

title: THE MOLES OF THE VATICAN
description: THE NOONDAY DEVIL

title: IRS OFFERS ADVICE ON PHONE SYSTEM
description: FOR many Americans, filling out tax returns is a frustrating experience - and equally frustrating at this time of year is trying to call the Internal Revenue Service to ask a question.

title: THE FAITHS OF HER CHILDHOOD
description: DAVITA'S HARP

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;

LESSONS FROM CHINA'S ECONOMIC BOOM
description: ; Sam Nakagama is chief economist of Nakagama & Wallace Inc., an economic advisory firm in New York.

title: NEW PROSECUTOR ON JOB DESPITE CUOMO STAND
description: Despite objections from Governor Cuomo, William F. Dowling took over this week as special prosecutor for investigating corruption in New York City's criminal-justice system.

title: 2 ROLES FOR CHURCH
description: SOUTH NYACK,N.Y.

title:
ART;

MILTON AVERY AND FAMILY
description: THE stock of Milton Avery has been rising steadily since 1982, when an exhibition of his work was mounted at the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York. Not the least of Avery's major contributions to painting was that he brought a palette of vivid color into American art.

title: HOUSE WITH A LUSTROUS PAST
description: The lovely Georgian estate known as Ditchley Park is situated 14 miles from Oxford, on the outskirts of Enstone, in the rolling foothills of the Cotswolds. A triumphant pairing of pastoral simplicity (woolly sheep graze drowsily near the entry gate) and formal Georgian architecture, the estate is worth a lingering look. And such a look is possible, though on a limited basis. Ditchley Park, which now operates as a conference center, permits the public to tour the principal rooms, the grand bedrooms on the upper floors and the extensive park during two weeks of the year and by prior arrangement at other times.

title: INSIDE STORIES
description: Even for avid architecture buffs, opportunities for exploring admired structures usually end in the public areas. But on four Tuesdays in April the Municipal Art Society will be offering occasions to see the inner workings of major buildings.

title: DRUNK AGAIN
description: THE euphemism used to be inebriated or

title: SERVICE IN REDDING FOR SLAIN SOLDIER
description: THE flag on the village green in Redding flew at half-staff yesterday as residents attended a memorial service for Maj. Arthur D. Nicholson, who was shot to death last Sunday by a Soviet sentry in East Germany.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE KILLING ANNIVERSARY. By Ian St. James. (Morrow, $17.95.)

title: WEIBRING FALLS TO A 3-WAY TIE
description: D. A. Weibring increased his 2-stroke second-round lead to 4 by the turn of the third round today, but tumbled back to the field on the home side with bogeys on the 17th and 18th holes. Weibring thus finished the third round of the $900,000 Tournament Players Championship tied with Hale Irwin and Calvin Peete for the lead at 208, which is eight under par for 54 holes.

title: THREE SHOWS IN NEW ROCHELLE TO SALUTE PHOTOJOURNALISTS
description: THE despair of the Depression, the horror of war and the plight of the Jews in the Warsaw Ghetto are subjects vividly depicted in photographs - many never displayed before - to be shown at a series of exhibitions scheduled in New Rochelle over the next three months.

title: No Headline
description: CONDOMINIUMS made stunning inroads into the new-home market during the early 1980's and prompted speculation that a profound social revolution was in progress - that Americans were no longer dreaming about owning a detached colonial-style home with brick accents and a basketball hoop over the garage door.

title: A PLAN TO UNLOCK THE GREAT GRID IN THE SKIES
description: MANY of the nation's largest airports were snarled last summer by record-setting lines of idling airplanes and frustrated travelers. The Government last week disclosed its plans for avoiding another season of flight- line gridlock.

title: YOUNG FARM FAMILY REAPING A BITTER HARVEST OF PROBLEMS
description: Don Tenon, the manager at the local grain elevator, summed matters up crisply. ''Shorty is in a tough situation,'' he said.

title: SUTTER AND BRAVES: A HAPPY MARRIAGE
description: Except for the beard, there is really no way to distinguish Bruce Sutter from anyone else standing casually on the outfield grass at Al Lang Stadium. His cap is tilted back and his arms are folded - just like every other pitcher shagging fly balls - and he is casually engaged in a conversation with a Met player near the right-field foul line.

title: PERSISTANT FLOOD THREAT WEARS ON WET HOUSTON
description: Richard Voorhees likes his home in Southeast Houston, but when the sky grows dark, he begins to worry.

title: SENSITIVE MATERIAL PRESENTED WITH COMPASSION
description: Every other evening there is a movie on television about someone dying of a terminal disease or facing a family-shattering crisis such as teen- age suicide. One would think that television had, in fact, co-opted the so-called problem play, for years largely the property of the theater. Therefore, when the theater attempts to treat such issues, it must take an approach that urgently justifies the use of the dramatic form. This is the case with William Hoffman's ''As Is'' at the Circle Repertory Company, a problem play about Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome. Even as scientists search for answers, the diagnosis is the equivalent of a death sentence.

title: Transactions
description: Placed Todd Cruz, infielder, on waivers. METS (NL) - Obtained Randy Niemann, pitcher, from the Chicago White Sox in exchange for Ken Reed, minor- league pitcher, and Gene Autry, third baseman.

title: THE PAST MEETS THE PRESENT ON THE A TRAIN
description: I TOOK a trip to the heart of darkness

title: ROHATYN SEES DIRE EFFECTS IN REAGAN POLICIES
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, warned today that the Reagan Administration, with its proposed budget cuts and tax proposals, could ''cripple'' New York City and New York State.

title: Music
description: Keyboard enthusiasts not eager to rush off and hear the same old faces play the same old music have some variety to look forward to this week. Yes, the presence of Maurizio Pollini Sunday evening at Avery Fisher Hall is a familiar one and well worth our attention; but Sunday afternoon at 2, young Jon Klibonoff plays 18th- and 19th- century piano music at Carnegie Recital Hall, and Sunday night at 8 at Merkin Hall, the veteran West German pianist, Detlef Kraus, concludes his three-concert survey of Bach's''Well-Tempered Clavier.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DANCING BEAR. By Chaim Bermant. (St. Martin's, $13.95.)

title: NETS DEFEAT KNICKS AND GAIN PLAYOFFS
description: Thomas and Thelma King, the parents of pro basketball's King brothers, Bernard and Albert, were in their regular seats for last night's meeting between the Knicks and the Nets at Madison Square Garden.

title: BEST SELLERS March 31, 1985
description: Fiction*1

title: REFORMS HAVE OPENED THE DOOR TO CRONYISM, BRIBERY AND FRAUD
description: China's reformers are in trouble. To a Westerner, things seem better than they have been at any time since the Communists took power in 1949. Vitality surges through every corner of life, the economy is booming and ordinary people are cheerful. But behind the scenes, China's maximum leader, Deng Xiaoping, and his modernizers have run into choppy waters, and the confidence they exuded a few months ago seems suddenly strained.

title: EUROPEANS TRY TO REDUCE UNEMPLOYMENT OR MAKE IT PAY
description: When a business executive from Troyes, a small city south of Paris, lost his job two years ago, he became eligible to pick up 12 monthly unemployment checks, for 90 percent of his former salary. Instead, like thousands of other recently laid-off Frenchmen, he chose an option that provided six months' unemployment pay in a lump sum and used it to start a new business.

title: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION AND 'SUPERSTARS'
description: Dr. Homer Neal's initiative as described in the March 3 article (''Campus Minority Hiring Lags'') in response to the minority hiring lag at Stony Brook is typical of what is deficient in the affirmative-action program. The ''Steinbrenner'' approach in attempting to recruit minority superstars may improve the statistics, but it does little for helping the disadvantaged.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, exhibition, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 1:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.)

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: SUMMER SAVINGS IN THE CARIBBEAN
description: Come April 15 or thereabouts, most Caribbean islands will undertake their annual ritual of slashing prices and offering premiums to try to convince tourists that the area has as much to offer in spring, summer and fall as in winter.

title: Toxic Chemicals In the Air
description: America's air is far more polluted than most people have suspected. A Congressional survey of scores of chemical companies released last week disclosed that cancer-causing agents and other hazardous materials are being sent into the atmosphere from hundreds of factories.

title: LAMB FOR ALL TASTES
description: SINCE CHILDHOOD, I HAVE BEEN fascinated with people's preferences about how well or little done they like red meat. Years ago, a great deal more was made of the matter, and there were those who felt that rare meat was fit only for cannibals. Others thought that eating red meat, meaning rare, was synonymous with being a genuinely red-blooded American. Either that, or it was thought of as something for effete and decadent foreigners, notably the French. (Americans, by gum, like their foods well done.)

title: ;   POWER, GREED AND GLORY ON WALL STREET

Glucksman - was ''the violations of the consensual traditions of a partnership.'' I was almost as stunned as the partners that Peterson, Glucksman, Ball and Rubin would bring a

title: NEW ATTACKS FEARED AFTER PARIS BOMBING AT A JEWISH FESTIVAL
description: Politicians and Jewish leaders warned today against an upsurge of racism and anti-Semitism in France after a bombing Friday night at a Jewish film festival that wounded 18 people.

description: MARXISM

title: INEFFICIENCY LAID TO WEAPON MAKERS
description: Industry data supplied by the Pentagon to Congress indicate that major military contractors are using far more labor to make weapons than the contractors calculate would be needed if they operated efficiently.

title: THE P.L.O. CANNOT BE IGNORED
description: JERUSALEM

title: U.S. OFFICER SLAIN IN EAST GERMANY
description: After cooperating in the defeat of Germany, the Western powers and the Soviet Union coordinated the occupation of the land that had been their common enemy. Nearly four decades old, the accords that regulated each other's activity in the four zones of occupation now result in a kind of legalized spying. Last week, they also resulted in tragedy and tension.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: MARYKNOLL PURSUES ITS VISION OF MISSION
description: OSSINING

title: MEDICARE SEEMS HEALTHY, AT LEAST FOR A WHILE
description: Earlier studies had predicted that without drastic cost cutting or a massive infusion of money, the Medicare trust fund might run out of money by 1991. Last week, though, the Government, in its annual report on the financial health of the fund, predicted that the Medicare pool should not run dry before 1998.

title: Manhattan Valley Project in Trouble
description: -HOUSE development in Manhattan

title: COMING ATTRACTIONS
description: THE QUESTIONS CONCERNING the sports world arrive with the vernal equinox: The year's sports scene enters its spring and summer phase, as the vines on the Wrigley Field outfield wall grow lush, the black-eyed Susans at the Preakness bloom and the historic tale of the Rose of Cincinnati unfolds.

title: THE REAGAN PLAY-BY-PLAY STILL PLAYS
description: Even as he waxed authentic before his first microphone, things went mellifluously for Ronald Reagan. In a tryout for a radio announcer's job as a 22-year-old child of the Depression, he was able to combine the raw talent of his voice with his active imagination to recreate, as if live, a college football game in which he had played. Alma Mater, Eureka College, still beat Western Illinois. But in Reagan the announcer's retelling at station WOC in Davenport, Iowa, Reagan the lineman gallantly made a downfield block that he had missed in reality.

title: ZEN AND THE ART OF SWIMMING
description: THE OCEAN SWELLS ARE UP TO SIX FEET. LIFEguards are heading out to the course; their boat tips on its stern against a wall of water. Hundreds of us stand on the beach, resembling some fictional colony of outer-space creatures with our bright caps and goggles. Gulls circle overhead, jellyfish ride in on the waves. Foamy seaweed blows shoreward and washes our feet, sinking them into the sand. It is almost twilight.

title: PRESIDENTIAL PERSUASION WINS ANOTHER ROUND
description: WASHINGTONPRESIDENT REAGAN and his allies won another victory last week when the House of Representatives followed the Senate and voted to add 21 new MX missiles to the nation's strategic arsenal. But the White House barely had time to celebrate the end of a yearlong struggle before storm warnings were flying over Capitol Hill, with a clear message for the White House: Trouble is coming not only for the rest of the MX program, but for the Administration's entire budget strategy of increasing the Pentagon's share of the pie while cutting back on domestic programs. ''The White House knows better than anybody that this is about as far as we can go,'' said Representative Norman D. Dicks, a Washington Democrat who has long supported the MX program. ''It's just political reality.''

title: R. P. I. TOPS FRIARS FOR TITLE
description: Scoring once on the power play and once while short handed, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute beat a spunky Providence College team 2-1 tonight to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey title before 16,282 in Joe Louis Arena.

title: LOYAL EMPLOYEES
description: To the Editor:

title: U. S. HALTING FUNDS FOR SOME JOBLESS
description: Despite a last-minute push by House Democrats to win extension of a program for people who have been out of work for a long time, the program will expire Sunday, ending coverage for more than 325,000 people.

title: N. B. A. ;   Cavaliers Rout Pacers, 117-94
description: World B. Free scored 27 points today as the Cleveland Cavaliers beat the Indiana Pacers, 117-94, in the race for the final playoff berth in the Eastern Conference. Indiana suffered its ninth consecutve defeat, and 15th loss in 16 games.

title: IS OPTICAL MEMORY NEXT FROM I. B. M.?
description: IF Walter Winchell were writing today, his column would no doubt cover the personal computer industry. That's where the gossip is. Form this week's instant millionaire, to the latest corporate collpse in the making, to who is merging with whom, a steady stream of speculation, unparalleled since the heyday of Hollywood, emanates from the electronics industry. Feaders of the trade weeklies Infoworld and PC Week turn first to John C. Dvorak's Inside Track and Spencer F. Katt's Rumor Central before perusing the ''news'' of the industry.

title: Issue of Free Speech
description: In 1978, Oklahoma passed a law, at the urging of the entertainer Anita Bryant, that permitted school boards to dismiss a teacher for ''advocating, encouraging or promoting'' homosexuality. Last week, in a tie vote, the Supreme Court upheld a Court of Appeals decision that the law violated the First Amendment.

description: European leaders resolved a bitter financial dispute with Greece today, paving the way for Spain and Portugal to join the Common Market at the start of next year.

title: Victims Get a Say in Court
description: A law signed by Governor Cuomo last week requires judges in New York State to weigh a new factor when they decide sentences for convicted criminals: what the victim has to say. The law gives victims of serious crimes the opportunity to offer their version of an incident, even if they did not testify during the trial.

title: PRESIDENT FORD SPEAKS AT PURCHASE
description: A DECADE after trying to remedy an economy plagued by rising inflation and high unemployment, former President Gerald R. Ford came to the county and pronounced the nation in ''good'' fiscal health. That condition, he said, could prevail ''provided we have the wisdom and the courage to do what's right in the management of our Federal Government's economic policy.''

title: POWER, GREED AND GLORY ON WALL STREET
description: The summation of the Lehman Brothers articles offered them as ''a tale of political intrigue, of incompetence unmatched even in the civil service, a sordid tale of vanity, avarice, cowardice, lust for power and a polluted Lehman culture.''

title: Proposed Dam Project Causes a Stir
description: A new phase in the struggle over whether the Great Northern Paper Company should be allowed to build a dam for generating hydroelectric power on a magnificent portion of the West Branch of Maine's Penebscot River enters a new phase tomorrow when the state's Land Use Regulation Commission begins its hearings on the project.

title: Pharmaceuticals
description: To the Editor:

title: IT'S HARD TO FIND ANY CHINKS IN KEAN'S ARMOR
description: Until last week, the Democratic field in the race for Governor was usually described as ''Representative James J. Florio and the others.'' After Mr. Florio announced on Monday that he would rather stay in Congress, however, each of the five other candidates wasted no time trying to distinguish themselves from the rest of the pack. Two of them made forays into southern New Jersey, the political base that gave Mr. Florio an easy victory over 12 other Democrats in the gubernatorial primary in 1981. The day after Mr. Florio's announcement, Peter Shapiro, the Essex County Executive, visited a child-care center at the Camden YWCA. By the end of the week, former United States Attorney Robert J. Del Tufo had moved his campaign into Gloucester and Cape May Counties. Former State Senator Stephen B. Wiley and Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark were also setting their sights south of Trenton. State Senate majority leader John F. Russo of Toms River, who waited until Wednesday to announce his candidacy, appears to be the one who will benefit the most from the Congressman's decision.

title: Ernest T. Thompson; A Presbyterian Leader
description: Dr. Ernest Trice Thompson, a theologian who led a move that reunited the Southern and Northern denominations of the Presbyterian Church, died here Friday. He was 90 years old.

title: Patrick Ewing Gets a Vote
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: RING LARDNER AT 100 -- FACING A LEGACY
description: I DON'T know why the vagaries of the decimal system should cause people to mount exhibits, print posters, make speeches, perform plays and issue proclamations in honor of someone not otherwise in the news. But the Ring Lardner Centennial - held on the campus of Albion College in Albion, Mich., a few weeks ago - could not have been better timed so far as I was concerned. I had been thinking about my grandfather, in a way, all my life. Although he died in 1933, 15 years before I was born, hardly any early memory looms larger than the recurring one of being asked if I was related and answering in a voice honed to just the right degree of becoming modesty.

title: MEDIOCRE MOUNTING OF A POWERFUL PLAY
description: UNDER Edward Gilbert's direction, the Long Wharf's current production of Tennessee Williams's ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' is half realized at best. What blazes forth is the play's concise construction, its stunning sense of characterization and, of course, the gorgeous language that touches the heart and reaches for the gut.

The controversial decision by the Hialeah Park stewards prompted loud booing from the stands and angry complaints from the Chief's Crown camp.

title: THE ART OF JOSEPH BULOFF
description: When Joseph Buloff walked onto a stage, the world came to magical life even before he spoke a line. You could enjoy his virtuosity of gesture, you could marvel at it, but finally no one could quite explain it.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;

WHEN TEXT BECOMES A NECESSITY
description: Only a few years ago it was easy to understand photography. On the one hand there was magazine and newspaper photography, which was accompanied by explanatory text blocks and captions, and was not art. On the other hand, there was art photography, which might be accompanied by a brief title, but was generally self-explanatory, if explainable at all, and consisted of close-ups of rocks, roots and vegetables and medium shots of nudes which were often posed and framed to look like vegetables.

It has Ellesse written on a black tag on the wrist, so I cover the name by rolling up the cuff. But I can't fool the tennis cognoscenti and other consumers of status sports clothes, who can tell by the familiar trademark - a red and gold sunburst over my heart.

title: Baseball;   TRADE MARKET AMONG SLOWEST IN YEARS
description: A trade that would send Mike Schmidt to the Los Angeles Dodgers would add spice to the slumbering spring trading market, but it won't happen, and barring last- week developments, this will be one of the slowest springs in recent years for trades. The only ones worth noting have been Toby Harrah from the Yankees to Texas for Billy Sample, and Dusty Baker from San Francisco to Oakland for two minor leaguers.

title: South Africa Bans Meetings
description: South Africa's white minority Government appears on the defensive, unsure how to handle the black unrest that has intensified in the past year and has caused at least 260 deaths. Last week, the authorities made good a threat by President P.W. Botha to take ''appropriate steps'' and outlawed meetings by the principal opposition force in the country and 28 other organizations.

For the amount of beer consumed and the twin punishments of broiling sun during the day and sleepless hours at night, the annual trek is seen by nonparticipants as either a testament to youthful vigor or stunted emotional development.

However, the author makes much of the ''superpowers'' of finance elbowing aside the older partnerships, the ''dinosaurs'' of Wall Street, and very little of the moral of his own story: Businesses are run by humans, and to err is human.

title:
GARDENING;

GIVING YOUR LAWN A GOOD START
description: LAWN clippings are bulky and take up a lot of space. They are also a major contributor to the overflowing landfills in our region. The irony is that there is seldom a reason to remove the clippings from the lawn in the first place. Left there they will soon disintegrate, and return plant nutrients back to the soil. As much as 25 percent of the lawn's requirement can be supplied this way, according to turf-grass specialists.

And two new surveys do provide some interesting figures on the cost of cars and on the way the average driver views the folks who ring up automotive repairs.

title: THE ENDURING LEGACY
description: A YOUNG BRONZE GOD OF WAR.'' JOHN DENTON FIRST HEARD that phrase in harangues and pep talks when he was going through officers' training as a marine. It resurfaced in his mind a generation later at a sun-dappled Fourth of July family picnic. What brought it back was an encounter there with a young soldier who seemed as eager for action as Denton himself had been when he took command of his first platoon in Bravo Company, Seventh Engineer Battalion, at Danang, South Vietnam, in 1966. Denton, now an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, hadn't realized that soldiers like that were still being turned out. Trying to express how moved and transfixed he felt when he saw the young man, Denton described a vision: ''He was 21, if that, and he took me right back to what I was. He was ready, and he was going to do it, almost to the point of saying, 'I sure hope they've got a war going someplace.' It made me feel good, but at the same time I wanted to go over and put my arm around him and say, 'Hey, have you got about five minutes? I want to tell you a few things.' '' Denton never had that conversation. If he had spoken, he would have talked, he said, about the responsibilities rather than the glory of command, about the strength a leader derives from his men, about devotion to them as an element of valor.

title: THE ONCE AND.. FUTURE KINGS
description: COUCHING OVER HOME PLATE IN RIVERFRONT STADIUM one night last September, claiming it in that aggressive manner he has made his own, he couldn't be confused with one of your latter-day, California-bred ballplayers: flaxen-haired, features finely chiseled, the manner of man who in the off-season might be doing a guest spot on ''Dynasty'' or finishing a Merrill Lynch trainee course. Endlessly striving Pete Rose, home at last, at bat for the 15,099th time in his major league life, was a throwback to an earlier age. If he didn't exist, Ring Lardner might have invented him. If he hadn't been capable of playing ball, then surely the alternative would have been shifting beer cases or working on a construction site. He hit a line drive. A single.

KOSHER CHOICES FOR PASSOVER
description: BECAUSE many area shops now stock a wide range of dry and off-dry ''kosher for Passover'' wines, observant Jews will have an excellent opportunity this year to serve other than thick, sweet reds with the traditional holiday meals (seders). In fact, the heritage of syrupy, Concord grape kosher wine is not part of Jewish dietary law, but more an American innovation, popularized soon after Prohibition when domestic taste preferences favored sugary dessert-style drinks.

title: LEADING INDICATORS GAIN BUT SLOWLY
description: Growth in the economy appears to have slowed, but is still advancing at a healthy pace. The index of leading economic indicators, which rose a revised 1.5 percent in January, gained seven-tenths of 1 percent in February. It was not a strong gain, but exceeded many expectations. Still, it caused further uncertainty about the direction of the economy, given the ''flash'' report of 2.1 percent economic growth in the first quarter and the troubles in foreign trade.

title: Second Jury Ups the Charges in Goetz Case
description: The case of Bernhard H. Goetz grew much more complicated last week with a decision by a Manhattan grand jury to indict him for attempted murder. The new charges accuse Mr. Goetz of having used more violence than necessary to defend himself when he shot four men, two of them in the back, on a subway train in December.

title: MCENROE, JARRYD ADVANCE TO FINAL
description: John McEnroe made short work of Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, 6-3, 6-2, tonight and moved into the final of the $380,000 Fila Trophy indoor tennis tournament.

title: BLISTERS AND BLISS ON A FROSTY BEACH
description: THE idea had originated one gray afternoon in early January, in Room 204 of Bellport Senior High School. The restless members of Students for Environmental Quality (S.E.Q.) were presented with this challenge: ''How would you guys like to go on a 21-mile hike on Fire Island?''

title: Revenge of the Green Monster
description: Duane Kuiper has the worst home-run-per-time- at-bat record in the majors (one homer in 3,374 times at bat), but Jerry Remy has gone to the plate the most times since his last homer. It has been 2,321 times at bat since the Boston second baseman hit a homer, off Matt Keough on Aug. 20, 1978. While five Red Sox teammates had 20 homers last year Remy, a left- handed batter, extended his homerless streak to six years.

title: PRIVATE PRESERVATION EFFORTS FOR THE PUBLIC GOOD
description: In 1979, during the Carter Administration, Congress appropriated $634 million for state and Federal conservation agencies to acquire unspoiled land. In the last few years, however, the Federal investment in land preservation has dwindled, and under the proposed Interior Department budget sent to Congress by President Reagan this year, it would disappear altogether.

title: IN THIS LIVABLE CITY, GIANTS SEEK A HOME
description: SAN FRANCISCO is arguably America's most livable city, certainly its most beautiful. Mass transit is clean and not too crowded. Flower beds are attended to daily in public parks. Spectacular views are accented by the pastel-colored Victorian homes dotting steep hills. Eucalyptus fills the air. The city has a budget surplus. All of this leads to greater civility.

title: WIFE OF GILLIS LONG LEADS IN LOUISIANA FOR HIS HOUSE SEAT ALEXANDRIA, La., March 30 (AP) - Cathy Long took a strong lead today in a five-way primary race for the Congressional seat left vacant when her husband, Representative Gillis W. Long, died in January.
description: With 351 of 458 precincts, or 77 percent, reporting from the Eighth Congressional District, Mrs. Long, 61 years old, had 48,569 votes, or 54.2 percent of the votes cast.

title: DISCIPLINE FOR MENTAL HOSPITALS?
description: WHENEVER I visit a psychiatric hospital, I am struck by the behavior of the patients.

title: AN UNRESOLVED MYSTERY AT INDIAN POINT
description: TO scram, in nuclear power plant terminology, is to shut down a reactor quickly in an emergency. Some say the term is an acronym for Safety Control Rod Ax Man, which dates to the early days of nuclear reactors in the 1940's. A man, equipped with an ax, stood by in case something went wrong. If need be, he could chop the ropes that suspended reactor control rods above the reactor. The rods then dropped into the reactor core, stopping the nuclear-fission process.

title: No Remains Are Found In Search at 2d L. I. Site
description: Authorities investigating the murder of a Norwegian fashion student in Rockland County said yesterday that they had dug for human remains at a second site on Long Island but had found no evidence of other victims.

title: MUCH MORE, MUCH LESS THAN A GAME
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: A MAJOR effort is under way in New Jersey to develop signs to help the Jewish hard of hearing and deaf understand the Hebrew language. More than 5,000 people are expected to take advantage of the new program.

title: SLIDING GENTLY PAST THE MID-LIFE CRISIS
description: doze button on the alarm clock to steal an extra 10 minutes in bed. But instead of a second buzz, what got me up were simultaneous kisses on each cheek by my two daughters, who whispered ''Happy Birthday, Dad'' in perfect stereo.

title: ISRAEL'S TROOPS ARE LEAVING, BUT THE 'LEBANON PROBLEM' PERSISTS
description: JERUSALEMYOSSI Sarid, a member of the Israeli Parliament and a vociferous critic of the war in Lebanon, tells of watching an Israeli troop convoy go by on a road in south Lebanon while on a recent tour of voluntary reserve duty there. Suddenly one of the trucks screeched to a halt and the driver stalked over to Mr. Sarid.

title: Gretzky and the Goal Standard
description: The playoffs are put up or shut up time. Bobby Hull (the Golden Jet) scored 129 points (62 goals, 67 assists) in 116 National Hockey League playoff games, averaging 1.11 points a game; Maurice (The Rocket) Richard scored 126 points (82 goals, 44 assists) in 133 games, averaging .95; Gordie Howe scored 160 points (68 goals, 92 assists) in 157 games, averaging 1.02, and Mike Bossy has 141 points (77 goals, 64 assists) in 110 games, averaging 1.28.

title: D'AMATO ALLY FAILS TO GET POST
description: SENATOR Alfonse M. D'Amato's plans for a top Federal appointment for a Long Island friend ran into a White House roadblock last week.

title: A BIBLICAL EPIC MADE WITH CONVICTION
description: Spanning five consecutive nights on NBC, beginning this evening at 8, and running for a total of 12 hours, including commercials, ''A.D.'' is a biblical film epic with a difference. It actually pays attention to the New Testament message of Christian love and charity. Large chunks of the Gospel according to St. Luke are included almost intact. It grapples with historical facts and pauses to explain complicated details. Beneath the standard ingredients of film spectacle, generously overlaid with lavish sets and costumes, there can be detected the unusual presence of a guiding intelligence interested in something more than costumed circuses. Action addicts are bound to get a bit grumpy, and assorted interested parties are likely to have objections relating to the interpretations of either history or religious dogma. But ''A.D.'' has, mostly for better and occasionally for worse, the courage of its convictions.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;

Photography
description: In ''Western Spaces,'' an exhibition of landscape photographs at the Burden Gallery, 20 East 23d Street, through April 27, some youngish Americans tackle one of the oldest subjects in photography, the deserts and mountains of the American West. On the whole, they do not make the subject look very appealing, but then that was probably not their intention.

title: WALTERS WON'T BE A REGULAR WHEN THE NATIONAL SECURITY COUNCIL CONVENES
description: According to Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, who stepped down last week as chief representative to the United Nations, ''they are the highest, frankest, most authoritative discussions of United States foreign policy.'' She was talking about the meetings of President Reagan's National Security Council which she regularly attended, but which her successor, Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters, will not, at least not on a regular basis. Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who wanted to limit the power of the U.N. reprsentative, won the White House's agreement not to renew the N.S.C. pass for General Walters.

title: Q AND A

title: Fate of Yankee Farmers
description: Don't look for the Yankees to get much of a benefit from their farm system unless George Steinbrenner trades himself instead of his players.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL ;

TOP-10 DINERS
description: The world has known some great diners in its time. For example, at the turn of the century there was James Buchanan ''Diamond Jim'' Brady, the man one restaurateur described as ''the best 25 customers we ever had.'' At Rector's, a favorite haunt, Diamond Jim reportedly would, with some regularity, work his way through a meal that included four-dozen oysters, a dozen hardshell crabs, six or seven large lobsters, a large steak, a tray of French pastry and coffee. Supposedly, it was his habit to leave four inches between his stomach and the table so that, in his words, ''when I feel 'em rubbin' together pretty hard, I know I've had enough.''

title: Transit Talks Go Down To the Wire
description: New York City's transit workers came into contract negotiations this month like lambs but went out last week like lions. John E. Lawe, president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, had suggested that his union would not strike if no new agreement with the Metropolitan Transit Authority was reached before the current contract expires tonight. He even said he would encourage his membership to wait to see what the city eventually agreed on with its police officers, firefighters and other employees. But after Governor Cuomo declined to support Mr. Lawe's request to submit the dispute to binding arbitration, the union leader backed down from his no- strike pledge. At week's end, Mr. Lawe offered to extend the contract temporarily and to discourage his membership from taking job actions, while he seeks support in Albany for arbitration. The Senate agreed to take it up today.

title: LANGLYKKE'S LEGACY AT HUDSON MUSEUM
description: IT is a little more than four years

title: SURVIVOR ON PARK
description: Only two of the monumental brick-and-limestone office buildings erected on the prime stretch of Park Avenue north of Grand Central Station before World War II survived the thoroughfare's glass-and-steel architectural transformation in the postwar years. One is the former Grand Central Building that lies athwart the avenue at 46th Street. It is now called the Helmsley Building and is notable for its gold-leafed detailing. The other is the former Postum Building at 250 Park Avenue, also at 46th Street, and it is now undergoing a multimillion dollar restoration.

title: EAST END BAYMEN'S WAY OF LIFE HINGES ON STRIPED BASS
description: LIKE his grandfather and father before him, Daniel King, an East End bayman, has always made his living on the water. Now, he is telling his son to buy a rake, a lawnmower and a pickup truck and go to work for the summer people because he would make more money that way.

description: THE WAR DIARIES OF JEAN-PAUL SARTRE November 1939/March 1940.

title: GIVING VOICE TO SEXUAL AMBIGUITY
description: Ever try to introduce opera to a complete innocent? Eventually, recounting the story of some familiar work (''Faust,'' ''Rosenkavalier'') you have to explain a topic that is bound to be confusing and may be unsettling: ''Well, you see, the character is a man, but a woman plays the part.''

title: Can the Summit Get Serious?
description: The point of holding the annual economic summit of Western leaders earlier than usual this year - May 2-4 in Bonn - was to manifest their unity on the 40th anniversary of the end of Europe's great war. The preliminaries manifest anything but.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Inflation Fears Deflated

title: WILDCATS WIN, 52-45
description: If it wasn't already a brassy celebration of Big East basketball, it certainly is now. For Villanova, which finished with the fourth-best overall record in the conference, eliminated the lone interloper, Memphis State, 52-45, this afternoon to earn a berth in the national collegiate basketball championship final.

title: IT'S TIME FOR THE LAWMAKERS TO COME OUT OF HIBERNATION
description: Years ago there was a Broadway play, ''The Fifth Season,'' about the garment center's lament that its year had five seasons: spring, summer, autumn, winter and slack. The action in Albany last week recalled that theory. The political year follows its own calendar, too.

title: NEW PENSION RIGHTS FOR FORMER SPOUSES
description: Starting this year a new Federal law gives couples who are splitting up the go-ahead to put a new item on the bargaining table: the husband's pension. As a result of the Retirement Equity Act of 1984, an ex-wife can now be assured of collecting on her former husband's pension if a judge has awarded her that right. She can also start drawing the money before he retires. And even if her husband has remarried, she may still arrange to receive survivor's benefits if he dies before retirement.

title: 2d VOTE SET ON SCHOOL SALE
description: FOR the second time in less than three years, Hewlett- Woodmere residents will vote in a controversial referendum on whether to sell 4.5 acres of school district land with a vacant junior high school to a Great Neck developer for $3.25 million. The latest offer would save the 50-year-old Woodmere Elementary School - part of the complex - and an acre of property for community use.

title: DEVILS WIN AND REMAIN IN PLAYOFF RACE
description: The scramble for the last playoff spot in the Patrick Division remained alive today after the Devils achieved a 6-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Grading Ambassadors
description: There's a movement to let a knowledgeable screening panel appraise the credentials of candidates for ambassadorships, the way bar associations routinely evaluate nominees for judgeships. It's worth a try.

title: It's Secretariat by 79 Lengths
description: The Kentucky Derby is usually won in somewhere around 2 minutes, with Secretariat posting the fastest time, 1:59 2/5, in 1973.

title: Two Die in Bus Crash
description: A tractor-trailer rig slammed into the back of a Las Vegas-bound tour bus on Interstate 15, killing two people and injuring several others, the authorities said today. The two dead people were believed to have been thrown through the bus windshield in the collision shortly after 11 P.M. Friday, a California Highway Patrol dispatcher, Vicki Jugenheimer, said in Barstow.

title: Tax Evasion From Within
description: Guess who failed to file their New York income-tax returns for as long as five years in a row? At least 69 employees of the State Department of Taxation and Finance, the very agency that tries to make sure that other people play by the rules. The violations, discovered in an internal investigation, were detailed in a two- inch-thick stack of documents the department delivered to the Albany County District Attorney last week.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES ALL-STAR TEAMS
description: WHO ARE THE BEST PLAYERS AT their positions in baseball today? Four of The Times's baseball experts - Dave Anderson, Murray Chass, Joseph Durso and George Vecsey - got together recently and offered their selections. They could agree on only five of the 11 positions and some of their choices were surprises. What follows is an edited transcript of their discussions.

description: I enjoyed Anthony DePalma's article, ''Not to Be a Priest'' (About Men, Feb. 24).
